title: A-Rod: 0 for 2
description: In Alex Rodriguezs second turn at the plate, with Bobby Abreu on first and nobody out in the bottom of the third, and with many of the fans in the capacity crowd on their feet, he hit a 1-0 pitch with a sharp crack of the bat to deep center field. The audience roared in anticipation, and bulbs flashed again. But center fielder Jerry Owens tracked it down at the front edge of the warning track near the 408-foot marker.

title: From Iraq to the Campaign Trail
description: For months, Rudolph W. Giuliani mainly chose to speak about the Iraq war only in passing, or when asked to comment on a specific event or issue like President Bushs troop buildup.

title: A-Rod: 0 for 3 (but, Wow!)
description: Alex Rodriguez batted for the third time in the fourth inning with the Yankees holding a 9-3 lead and Charlie Haeger on the mound in relief of Jos Contreras. At that point, the Yankees already had four home runs. Bobby Abreu and Robinson Can had three-run home runs, Melky Cabrera had a two-run homer and Matsui had a solo shot.

title: A-Rod: 0 for 4, but Others Continue Bombardment
description: Alex Rodriguez batted for the fourth time in the bottom of the sixth inning, this time against Gavin Floyd, a right-hander. At this point, the Yankees led, 11-3, and all but two of them  Rodriguez and Andy Phillips  had at least one hit. Rodriguez was the only Yankee not to have reached base. (Phillips was safe on an error in the third.)

title: A-Rod: 0 for 5, and a Souvenir for a Fan
description: By the time Alex Rodriguez batted for the fifth time in the game, in the seventh inning, the atmosphere had turned surreal. Just before Rodriguez batted, Shelley Duncan, replacing Bobby Abreu, hit the eighth home run of the game for the Yankees to give them a 16-3 lead. But Rodriguez flied out to center to make his box score line 0 for 5, all on fly balls. When Rodriguez returned to the dugout, he handed his bat to a young boy in the box seats. As the Yankees took the field for the eighth inning, Chris Basak was at third base in place of Rodriguez.

title: Television in Afghanistan
description: Owning a TV was a crime under the Taliban. But in a study this year of Afghanistan's five most urban provinces, two-thirds of all people said they watched TV every day or almost every day.

title: Access vs. Quality
description: Stanley Fish has written an Op-Ed for The Times that appears in print and online today. Post a comment about it below.  The Editors

title: This Harry Stands Out From the Crowd
description: LAUREL HOLLOW, N.Y., July 28  Harvinder Anand, the new mayor of this Long Island village of multimillion-dollar homes, private beaches and yachtsmen, is, like many other residents, a successful business executive, a boater and a connoisseur of world travel. His Sikh turban and beard drew double takes when he moved to the community about 10 years ago, but it does not get many anymore. At least not among the locals.

title: A Pedophiles Blog (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Giants Want Strahan Back, but Not as a Distraction
description: ALBANY, July 31  The Giants finally spoke to Michael Strahan, their wayward defensive end, though they did not learn if he intended to report to camp or retire. A simple yes or no would not end the focus on Strahan. The Giants have concerns, whether Strahan comes back or not.

title: Murdochs Journal: Dont Expect Hedgeless Funds Headlines
description: You can bet serious money  billions even  that the article about the sale of The Wall Street Journal and the rest of Dow Jones & Company in todays Journal will be fully and ferociously reported, with no quarter given to its new owner, Rupert Murdoch.

title: Mets Float Some Offers, but Cannot Close a Deal
description: MILWAUKEE, July 31  The nonwaiver trade deadline came and went Tuesday afternoon with the Mets looking exactly as they had when they arrived here Monday night: with a new second baseman, Luis Castillo, but their pitching staff intact.

title: New Deal Debate for a New Era
description: From the very beginning of the nations modern social welfare system  even before Michael Moore began to explore the issue  there was a tension in it: What should the government be expected to provide? What should be left to the individual? How much government is too much?

title: Democrats Scrambling to Expand Eavesdropping
description: WASHINGTON, July 31  Under pressure from President Bush, Democratic leaders in Congress are scrambling to pass legislation this week to expand the governments electronic wiretapping powers.

title: Overpass Collapses in Northern California; 2 Are Injured
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 31  A freeway overpass under construction collapsed on Tuesday, injuring a road worker, trapping a truck driver for hours and snarling commuter traffic in the fast-growing area of Butte County, about 152 miles northeast of here.

title: Lottery Numbers
Correction: For the Record
description: An article in some editions on Saturday about criticism of Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales by some Justice Department lawyers misquoted an opinion article in The Denver Post that was written by one of those lawyers, John S. Koppel. He wrote that under the Bush administration the Justice Department had been thoroughly politicized  not thoroughly publicized  in a manner that is inappropriate, unethical and indeed unlawful. Also, a chart in some editions misidentified the forum for a May 23 hearing at which Monica M. Goodling, a former aide to Mr. Gonzales, testified. The hearing was in the House, not the Senate.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in some copies on Saturday about the complex relationship between Gov. Eliot Spitzer of New York and Andrew M. Cuomo, the state attorney general, whose office released a report criticizing Mr. Spitzers aides for misusing the State Police to discredit a political rival, misidentified the division once headed by Mr. Spitzer in the Manhattan district attorneys office, where Mr. Cuomo also once worked. It is the labor racketeering unit, not the rackets bureau. (The error appeared in an article in some copies on July 19, 2005, and in an article on May 22, 2002.)

title: Seize the Cesium
description: London

title: Manhattan Media Buys a Weekly
description: The New York Press, the citys second-largest free weekly newspaper after The Village Voice, was expected to be sold today to Manhattan Media, a publisher of weekly newspapers.

title: Chinese Market Awash in Fake Potter Books
description: SHANGHAI, July 31  Chinese readers could not wait for the official release of Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows, the much anticipated seventh and concluding book in the series, a little more than a week ago. And they did not have to.

title: Childrens Health Plan Focus of New Struggle
description: WASHINGTON, July 31  The Childrens Health Insurance Program has suddenly become a vehicle for an ideological struggle between President Bush and Congress over the future of the health care system.

title: Jets Ferguson Lives Every Mans Dream: Food and Plenty of It
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., July 31  Only in the National Football Leagues does a man weighing 290 pounds appear to be supermodel slim.

title: Hurricane Victims Rush to Apply for Grants as Deadline Looms
description: NEW ORLEANS, July 31  Hundreds of Louisianians whose homes were ruined by Hurricane Katrina rushed to meet a Tuesday deadline set by the states troubled housing aid program, even as a deficit of billions of dollars threatened to leave thousands without a grant.

title: U.N. Approves Peacekeepers for Darfur
description: The United Nations Security Council voted unanimously yesterday to authorize the deployment of up to 26,000 peacekeepers to try to stop the violence in Darfur, in western Sudan, where some 200,000 people have been killed in four years of conflict.

title: Adu Makes Jump From M.L.S. to Portugal
description: Freddy Adu has gone to Portugal and life goes on in Major League Soccer.

title: Plight of Muslim Immigrants in Post-Sept. 11 America
description: In their no-frills documentary, Out of Status, Pia Sawhney and Sanjna N. Singh examine the actions of the Immigration and Naturalization Service after 9/11 and the devastating repercussions for Americas Muslims.

title: It Will Take More Than Charm
description: The New York Police Department has managed to hold down crime in impressive ways, but it has yet to earn the confidence of a large number of the people it protects, especially among minority communities. Hoping to ease tensions, the department has turned to cultivating charm, or at least basic people skills, with its officers. Its a good start, but its not nearly enough.

title: South Korea Urges U.S. to Change Stance on Negotiating With the Taliban
description: SEOUL, South Korea, July 31  Shocked by the killing of a second South Korean hostage in Afghanistan and weary from the 13-day-old crisis, South Korea on Tuesday urged the American and Afghan governments to show flexibility over Taliban demands for the release of imprisoned militants.

title: U.S. Death Toll in Iraq in July Expected to Be Lowest in 07
description: BAGHDAD, July 31  The death of a marine in western Iraq brought the American military death toll to 74 so far in July, on course to be the lowest monthly figure this year.

title: Sacrificing Food Safety (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Congress Not Expected to Vote on Iraq Policy Before Recess
description: WASHINGTON, July 31  Congressional Democrats pulled back Tuesday from a final series of votes on Iraq policy before the August recess, hoping a month spent at home with voters frustrated by the course of the war would persuade more Republicans to join Democrats in supporting a troop withdrawal.

title: F.C.C. Hands Google a Partial Victory
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 31  The Federal Communications Commission moved cautiously Tuesday toward creating a more open national wireless broadband network, handing a partial victory to Google, which was pushing for more competition in cellphone services.

title: Islamic Opposition Group Pulls Out of Elections in Jordan
description: AMMAN, Jordan, July 31  After months of growing tension with the Jordanian government, the opposition Islamic Action Front abruptly withdrew from nationwide municipal council elections on Tuesday. The group cited voting irregularities in the elections, which were seen as a test for the more politically sensitive parliamentary elections this fall.

title: Sex Slaves Returning Home Raise AIDS Risks, Study Says
description: Adding another bleak dimension to the sordid world of sex slavery, young girls who have been trafficked abroad into prostitution are emerging as an AIDS risk factor in their home countries, according to a study being released today.

title: Bodies of 4 Afghan Judges Are Found
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Aug. 1  The bodies of four Afghan judges kidnapped 10 days ago were found today in a mountainous area of Ghazni province, south of Kabul, the same province where 21 South Korean hostages are being held by suspected members of the Taliban, officials said.

title: Jeremy Blake, 35, Artist Who Used Lush-Toned Video, Dies
description: Jeremy Blake, an up-and-coming artist who sought to bridge the worlds of painting and film in lush, color-saturated, hallucinatory digital video works, has died, the New York City Police said yesterday. He was 35 and lived in the East Village in Manhattan.

title: Manhattan: Agreement on West Side Medical Tower
description: Two New York developers have signed an agreement to build a 1.2 million-square-foot office tower on the Far West Side that would serve as a hub for manufacturers of devices, diagnostics, computer systems and other equipment for the medical industry. The developers  Gary Barnett, the chief executive of the Extell Development Corporation, and Israel Green  said they planned to begin construction in early 2009. The tower would rise at 11th Avenue and 34th Street, on a site that is now home to the Copacabana nightclub. Mr. Green has spent five years developing the concept and pursuing a Manhattan location. He said it was an opportunity for New York City to become the principal center for the $260 billion global market for medical devices and diagnostics. The project may have to wait until the city completes part of an extension of the No. 7 subway line, which passes beneath the site.

title: Queens: Councilman Fined for Ethics Violation
description: City Councilman James F. Gennaro, left, a Queens Democrat, has been fined $2,000 for asking a staff member to volunteer for his 2003 re-election campaign and for allowing city equipment to be used to write and print a campaign letter, both violations of the city ethics code, the Conflicts of Interest Board said yesterday. In a settlement with the board, Mr. Gennaro said he did not remember asking the staff member to volunteer for him and did not know that his city-supplied computer, printer and paper were used for a campaign letter, but he did not dispute either allegation. Council member Gennaro accepts responsibility for any oversights that took place in his office in 2003, his lawyer, Arnold N. Kriss, said in a statement. Measures have been implemented to ensure that this will not happen again.

title: U.S. Pressing Arab Nations to Increase Support for Iraq
description: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia, July 31  Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice and Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates on Tuesday coupled their military assistance package for Arab allies with a public request for Arab leaders to do more to back the Shiite-led government in Iraq.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,644 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Adu Departs After Mixed Reviews
description: Freddy Adu has gone to Portugal, and life goes on in Major League Soccer.

title: Keep Your Eyes on Adjustable-Rate Mortgages
description: Two years ago, when the housing market was roaring along, I called a mortgage broker on the West Coast and asked for some help. I told him that I wanted to interview some recent home buyers who had taken out an adjustable-rate mortgage  one of the big drivers of the boom  and he was nice enough to pass along a short list of names.

title: A Teacher Grows Disillusioned After a Fail Becomes a Pass
description: Several weeks into his first year of teaching math at the High School of Arts and Technology in Manhattan, Austin Lampros received a copy of the schools grading policy. He took particular note of the stipulation that a student who attended class even once during a semester, who did absolutely nothing else, was to be given 45 points on the 100-point scale, just 20 short of a passing mark.

title: E.E.O.C. Backs Boulud Workers
description: IN a lawsuit and a consent decree filed yesterday, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission backed accusations by workers that Daniel Boulud denied them promotions at his restaurant Daniel because of their race and ethnicity and retaliated against some who complained about it.

title: The Theme Is Ancient, but the Subject Is Modern
description: The Israeli director Ami Dayan had planned to stage Kiss of the Spider Woman for the Denver Center for the Performing Arts last year. Then the radical Hamas party swept the Palestinian Authority elections, and Israel and the United States refused to negotiate with the new leadership. I called the theater and I said, Look, weve got to do a different play,  Mr. Dayan recalled.

title: Saving a Drug Company (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Reader Responses
description: Here are excerpts from reader replies to David Leonhardts Aug.1 column on mortgages and the housing market:

title: Giuliani Seeks to Transform U.S. Health Care Coverage
description: ROCHESTER, N.H., July 31  Rudolph W. Giuliani on Tuesday called for transforming the way health care coverage is provided in the United States, advocating a voluntary move from the current employer-based system to one that would grant substantial tax benefits to people who buy their own insurance.

title: A Diet Book Serves Up a Side Order of Attitude
description: Ever since Running Press, an imprint of Perseus Books, first published the raucous, profanity-laced diet book Skinny Bitch in December 2005, it has sold steadily. From an initial print run of fewer than 10,000 copies, there are now more than 245,000 in print.

title: In Endorsements, No Athlete Is a Sure Thing
description: Michael Vick lost another endorsement yesterday because of the dogfighting charges against him. In its divorce petition, Rawlings said everything it needed to about how it weighed jurisprudence against its corporate image.

title: Dow Jones Deal Gives Murdoch a Coveted Prize
description: Rupert Murdoch finally won his long-coveted prize yesterday, gaining enough support from the deeply divided Bancroft family to buy Dow Jones & Company, publisher of The Wall Street Journal and one of the worlds most respected news sources, for $5 billion.

title: Legendary Voice Will Let Fans Do Call on Bonds
description: LOS ANGELES, July 31  When Hank Aaron broke the career home run record 33 years ago, Vin Scully made a call that evoked race, history and the American experience.

title: Man Regains Speech After Brain Stimulation
description: A 38-year-old man who spent more than five years in a mute, barely conscious state as a result of a severe head injury is now communicating regularly with family members and recovering his ability to move after having his brain stimulated with pulses of electric current, neuroscientists are reporting.

title: H.I.V. Patients Anxious as Support Programs Cut
description: SAN RAFAEL, Calif.  In the golden hills of Marin County, it is hard to imagine that free food or emergency cab fares could matter much to anyone.

title: Sports Briefing | Khannouchi Out of Half-Marathon
description: Khalid Khannouchi, the Moroccan-born American who has twice broken the world record for the marathon, withdrew from Sundays NYC Half-Marathon.Its not an injury, said Sandra Khannouchi, his wife, coach and manager. He has a mechanical problem. His foot lands flat, and he has a burning sensation.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: The Talking Business column in Business Day on Saturday, about discounting in the book industry, misstated the location and history of the Barnes & Noble bookstore on Union Square. It is on 17th Street, not 18th Street, in the former Century Building, which was acquired by Barnes & Noble in the 1990s; it is not the original store. (The first Barnes & Noble was opened on Fifth Avenue at 18th Street during the Great Depression.)

title: A Director Also Elusive on Home Video
description: Unlike Ingmar Bergman, Michelangelo Antonioni is poorly represented on DVD. He did not have the good luck to make most of his films for a single, state-subsidized production company, and as a result rights to his films are spread around the world and are often difficult to track down.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on July 12 about bombings of natural gas pipelines in Mexico, and a correction in this space on July 23, referred incorrectly to the cause of minor bombings in Mexico City last year. A coalition of guerrilla groups claimed responsibility for the bombings  not the splinter group whose correct name is the Revolutionary Army of the Insurgent People.

title: Senate G.O.P. Hearings May Start by Next Week
description: ALBANY, July 31  Senate Republicans said Tuesday that they would start hearings as early as next week that could become a public forum for investigating Gov. Eliot Spitzers administration. They did not rule out seeking to compel the governors testimony.

title: Breast Cancer Strikesan ABC Host
description: Her voice muffled at times by tears, Robin Roberts, above, told viewers of Good Morning America yesterday that she had been given a diagnosis of breast cancer and would undergo surgery on Friday. As she clutched the hand of her co-host, Diane Sawyer, Ms. Roberts said she had found a lump in her breast during a self-examination she conducted on the night she completed a segment about the death of another colleague, Joel Siegel. Mr. Siegel, an ABC film critic, died on June 29 at 63 after a long battle with colon cancer. Ms. Roberts, 46, told viewers that she was grateful her cancer had been detected in the early stages. After her surgery, Ms. Roberts said, she would undergo further treatment, which she did not specify. Asked afterward how much time Ms. Roberts expected to take from Good Morning America, an ABC News spokeswoman said, At this point, shes not expected to be away for an extended period of time.

title: Recipe: Cornstarch Ice Cream
description: Time: 20 minutes, plus chilling

title: Nigeria: New Leader Shakes Up Army
description: President Umaru YarAdua reshuffled top officers in Nigerias powerful army, retiring about a dozen generals and shifting the commanders of several divisions. The shake-up of the command, two months after Mr. YarAdua took office in the first turnover in power between democratically elected leaders, was described by senior government officials as a routine shift from one generation of officers to the next. He was elected in April in a vote heavily criticized by international observers, but has made overtures to include opposition parties in his government. Unlike many of his predecessors, Mr. YarAdua, a former governor and chemistry teacher, has never served in the military.

title: Michelangelo Antonioni, Bold Director, Dies at 94
description: Michelangelo Antonioni, the Italian director whose chilly depictions of alienation were cornerstones of international filmmaking in the 1960s, inspiring intense measures of admiration, denunciation and confusion, died on Monday at his home in Rome. He was 94.

title: Michel Serrault, 79, a Star of Cage aux Folles, Is Dead
description: Michel Serrault, a French film star known internationally for his role as the temperamental drag queen Zaza in the original film version of La Cage aux Folles, died on Sunday at his home in Honfleur, France. He was 79.

title: Queens Day Care Worker Gets 20 Years in Rape of 4-Year-Old
description: A State Supreme Court justice sentenced a Queens day care worker to 20 years in prison yesterday for raping a 4-year-old boy in her care. The justice said that some parents continued support for the worker made him question whether the community had lost every grasp of our moral compass.

title: Yankees Have Pitching, So They Add Betemit
description: On July 8, the day before the All-Star Game break, the Yankees led the Angels by 10 runs when Scott Proctor was sent in to pitch the eighth inning. To the Yankees decision makers, this was an obvious sign that Manager Joe Torre would probably always favor Proctor over a pitcher just up from the minors, no matter how promising that pitcher seemed.

title: Mayor Takes the Subway  by Way of S.U.V.
description: He is public transportations loudest cheerleader, boasting that he takes the subway virtually every day. He has told residents who complain about overcrowded trains to get real and he constantly encourages New Yorkers to follow his environmentally friendly example.

title: Jittery Stock Market Drops as Mortgage Fallout Spreads
description: With little respite on the horizon, the mortgage market was hit with another wave of bad news yesterday, sending the stock market down sharply.

title: Cease to Assist?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Ford and G.M. Expect a July Sales Drop
description: DETROIT, July 31  Over the last 18 months, General Motors and the Ford Motor Company have cut thousands of jobs and billions of dollars in costs and narrowed their North American losses. That helped each post unexpectedly strong second-quarter profits.

title: Ice Cream Thats a Stretch
description: WHY do we always try to make ice creams smooth? When we add egg yolks (or cornstarch, as Mark Bittman does this week in The Minimalist) to an ice cream mix, and then stir it constantly while it freezes, we do it to block the growth of hard-edged ice crystals. But smooth ice cream doesnt give the mouth much to do. Just for a change, how about ice cream that is coarse and crunchy? Or chewy?

title: A Kitchen Crowd for Fox
description: With an all-rerun lineup of sitcoms followed by CSI: Miami, CBS earned the title of most-watched network on Monday. But Fox, with an assist from Hells Kitchen, posted the highest ratings among adults 18 to 49. According to Nielsens estimates, the cooking competition delivered the nights best numbers in that demographic market, leading the 9 p.m. hour over all with 8.6 million viewers. CSI: Miami remained dominant at 10 (8.8 million), ahead of both NBCs Dateline (6.2 million) and the second half of ABCs special Six Degrees of Martina McBride, which averaged a last-place 4.3 million viewers from 9 to 11. NBC ranked third for the night, as it did at 9 with a new installment of Age of Love (5.4 million). ABC was fourth.

title: Red Sox Add Gagn for Bullpen Insurance
description: LOS ANGELES, July 31  The Boston Red Sox have the best record in Major League Baseball, but that does not mean they are content. Even the best team can improve, which is precisely what the Red Sox did yesterday before the nonwaiver trading deadline by obtaining reliever Eric Gagn from the Texas Rangers for pitcher Kason Gabbard and two minor leaguers.

title: Lender Agrees to Contribution of $2 Million to a Student Fund
description: One of the nations largest student loan companies, Nelnet, agreed yesterday to pay $2 million into a fund to educate high school students about financing college, settling an inquiry into its business practices by the New York attorney general.

title: Language Evolutions Slippery Tropes
description: All branches of science search for origins. Biologists want to know how life on earth began. Astronomers want to know how the universe got started. Even in mathematics, questions about how different numerical systems came to be constitute a legitimate line of inquiry.

title: Lazard Posts 2.2% Profit Decline
description: Lazard, the investment bank run by Bruce Wasserstein, said today that its second-quarter profit dropped 2.2 percent from the same period a year ago, as its asset management business continued to grow while its mergers and acquisitions advisory work dipped slightly.

title: Obama Calls for U.S. to Shift Focus on Terrorism
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1  Senator Barack Obama said today that the United States should shift its focus from the war in Iraq to a fight against terrorism in Afghanistan and Pakistan. He said that if the Pakistani government fails to eradicate terror operations inside its borders, the United States should withhold aid and should strike Al Qaeda targets there itself.

title: Peekskill Finds New Use for an Old Landfill
description: Peekskill, an economically struggling city 40 miles north of Manhattan on the Hudson River, has formed a partnership with a private developer to cap an 11-acre former municipal landfill and build the citys first Class A office space in decades.

title: To Be Title Contender Again, Celtics Are Looking to Garnett
description: With the addition of Kevin Garnett, the Boston Celtics believe they have been transformed from rebuilders to title contenders.

title: Still Lagging, Paterson Schools Stay Under New Jersey Control
description: New Jersey education officials said yesterday that the Paterson public schools would remain under state control after a new state report found continuing problems with the districts academic instruction and school board operations.

title: Hub of Halfpipes Rises in Corner of California
description: CARLSBAD, Calif., July 31  Ten years ago Bucky Lasek moved west with his wife, newborn daughter and commitment to a career in skateboarding, settling in this laid-back seaside community in northern San Diego County.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Breast Cancer Strikes

title: Uncertainty Now in a Golden Youths Trajectory
description: WASHINGTON, July 31  No matter what his doctors eventually tell John G. Roberts Jr., or the world, about the diagnosis and outlook for his seizure disorder, it is clear that something changed irrevocably following the 52-year-old chief justices momentary loss of consciousness on a vacation island dock on Monday afternoon.

title: Recipe: Fish Stew With Rice (Thiebu Djen)
description: Adapted from Ken Alice Ndoye
