description: To the Editor:

title: Earthly Hurts: Yes, You Can Take Them With You
description: Heaven is low on testosterone in the bleak but whimsical vision of Betty Shamieh, the author of The Black Eyed, a thoughtful but rambling new play that opened last night at New York Theater Workshop. Adrift in an afterlife seemingly devoid of men, four women from Palestine debate the ethics of terrorism, the long history of female oppression and the knotty problems of the contemporary Middle East.

title: Amid War, Passion for TV Chefs, Soaps and Idols
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, July 25  Seven years ago, during a very different time in a very different Afghanistan, a medical student named Daoud Sediqi was bicycling from campus when he was stopped by the Talibans whip-wielding religious police. The young man immediately felt an avalanche of regret, for he was in violation of at least two laws.

title: Dining Briefs
description: NEW PLACES

title: Joint Chiefs Nominee Questioned on Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, July 31  The Navy admiral nominated to become chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff said Tuesday that American military efforts in Iraq would fail unless Iraqi leaders did more to bridge sectarian divides. But he also warned that a rapid exit of American troops could turn Iraq into a cauldron for broader Middle East strife.

title: Hostile Fans and Quiet Bat for Bonds
description: LOS ANGELES, July 31  Barry Bonds had five friends at Dodger Stadium on Tuesday night. Actually, he had five protectors, the security officers who stood as rigid as marines in left field as Bonds warmed up between innings. They formed a loose wall near Bonds, just in case.

title: Leave Your Name at the Border
description: Dinuba, Calif.

title: Criminal Case After Adoptions Spurs Review
description: Child welfare workers in New York City said yesterday that they were poring over hundreds of records for possible cases of adoption fraud and abuse after a woman who adopted 11 foster children, and collected subsidies for them, was arrested in Florida and charged with abusing and neglecting the teenagers and young adults living under her care.

title: Norma Gabler, Leader of Crusade on Textbooks, Dies at 84
description: Norma Gabler, a Texas homemaker who recoiled at material in her childrens textbooks and became the public face of a crusade with her husband to rid schoolbooks of content they considered antifamily, anti-American and anti-God, died on July 22 in Phoenix. She was 84.

title: South Africa: Anglogolds Chief to Retire
description: Robert M. Godsell, the chief executive of AngloGold Ashanti, plans to retire after running the company since its creation in 1998 and helping it become the worlds third-biggest gold producer with operations in 10 countries. Mr. Godsell, left, who will step down on September 30, will be succeeded by Mark Cutifani, the chief operating officer of Companhia Vale do Rio Doces nickel unit, AngloGold said. Mr. Godsell, 54, was the chief executive of Anglo Americans gold and uranium division from 1995 before taking over as head of AngloGold, a company formed by a merger of Anglo Americans separately traded gold companies and the gold assets of Minorco. Other acquisitions included Ashanti Goldfields of Ghana.

title: Access vs. Quality
description: Whenever Im asked, and sometimes even before Im asked, I advise parents of college-age children to not send their sons and daughters to private schools, but to send them to public institutions, at least if there are any good ones in their state.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article last Wednesday about the death of a Staten Island teenager who was a passenger in a car that the police said was speeding before it crashed misspelled the name of a street where car racing was reported in April. It is Drumgoole Road, not Drumgould.

title: A Chronicler of Alienated Europeans in a Flimsy New World
description: Decades before it was given a name, Michelangelo Antonioni recognized the malady we now call attention deficit disorder. In his great 1960s films, LAvventura, La Notte, Eclipse and Red Desert, but especially in LAvventura, his masterpiece, it wasnt diagnosed as a chemical imbalance, but as a communicable social disease.

title: Father and Son Restaurateurs in New York City Plead Guilty to Tax Evasion
description: Two members of the Cipriani family, renowned for its string of opulent restaurants in New York and Venice, pleaded guilty to tax evasion yesterday and agreed to pay $10 million in restitution and penalties to resolve a case brought by Robert M. Morgenthau, the district attorney of Manhattan.

title: Russia Offers Support to Palestinian President
description: MOSCOW, July 31  Russia gave some support to the American and European approach to the Palestinian question on Tuesday, offering military aid to President Mahmoud Abbas, leader of the secular Fatah faction, and saying it had downgraded relations with the rival Islamists of Hamas.

title: Retired General Is Censured for Role in Tillman Case
description: WASHINGTON, July 31  The Army moved on Tuesday to stanch the furor over the mishandling of the friendly fire death of Cpl. Pat Tillman in Afghanistan by censuring a retired three-star general for errors and deceptions and apologizing profusely to the Tillman family and the public for mistakes, misjudgments and a failure of leadership.

title: Mark Twains Dead: An Unexaggerated Report
description: The dates have been set for Mark Twains new play (yes, explanation to come).

title: Subscriber Gain Helps Sirius Narrow Loss
description: Sirius Satellite Radio, the pay-radio broadcaster planning to buy XM Satellite Radio Holdings, posted a narrower second-quarter loss after gaining more subscribers than analysts expected.

title: Footnotes
description: Barbara Walters told viewers of The View yesterday that she would officially announce today who would replace Rosie ODonnell as the shows moderator. ... A back injury has forced the Dutch conductor Edo de Waart to cancel his engagements with the Boston Symphony Orchestra at Tanglewood on Saturday and Sunday. He will be replaced by James Levine at the first concert and Ludovic Morlot at the second. Both programs remain unchanged. ... Janeane Garofalo, Denis Leary, Bill Maher, Sarah Silverman and Damon Wayans will be among the performers at the fourth annual New York Comedy Festival, Nov. 6-11 at sites like Carnegie Hall, Avery Fisher Hall, Town Hall, the Beacon Theater and Carolines on Broadway. ... World premieres by Camille A. Brown and Frederick Earl Mosley, as well as company premieres of Maurice Bjarts Firebird and Robert Battles Unfold, will highlight the 2007 New York season of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, at New York City Center, from Nov. 28 through Dec. 31. ... Unexpected problems and expenses during renovations may prevent the Bolshoi Theater in Moscow from reopening early next year, Reuters reported. The theaters director general, Anatoly Iksanov, said he hoped it would reopen in the fall. ... Next year, the Eagles plan to issue their first full-length studio album since The Long Run in 1979 and to tour, Billboard.com reported.

title: Detroit Is Outsold by Imports in U.S.
Ill Have the Fish Paste Sushi With the Green Tea Rice
description: CHICAGO, July 31  If you believe the vendors at the annual Institute of Food Technologists convention, you may soon be able to eat and drink your way to better health.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on July 12 about bombings of natural gas pipelines in Mexico, and a correction in this space on July 23, referred incorrectly to the cause of minor bombings in Mexico City last year. A coalition of guerrilla groups claimed responsibility for the bombings  not the splinter group whose correct name is the Revolutionary Army of the Insurgent People. (Go to Article)

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Sunday about lawsuits filed over proceeds from the sale of handmade quilts from Gees Bend, Ala., omitted the surname of one plaintiff. She is Lucinda Pettway Franklin.

title: Saudis Consider Embassy in Baghdad
description: JEDDA, Saudi Arabia, Aug. 1  Saudi Arabias foreign minister today said his country was considering opening an embassy in Baghdad and said he was astonished by recent criticism of its Iraq policy by a Bush administration official.

title: A Home Run Parade That Rodriguez Is Unable to Join
description: The Yankees have played 16,218 games since their first season in 1903. Never have they hit more home runs than they did last night at Yankee Stadium. Seven players slugged a total of eight homers in a 16-3 rout of the Chicago White Sox, tying a club record set in 1939.

title: Before Them, Films Were Just Movies
description: BY an awful and uncanny coincidence  the kind of occurrence that, in a movie, would have to be taken as symbolic lest it seem altogether preposterous  Michelangelo Antonioni and Ingmar Bergman died on the same day. Since Mr. Bergman was 89 and Mr. Antonioni 94, neither mans death came as much of a shock, but the simultaneity was startling. Not only because they were both great filmmakers, but more because, in their prime, Mr. Antonioni and Mr. Bergman were seen as the twin embodiments of the idea that a filmmaker could be, without qualification or compromise, a great artist.

title: Britney Spears Sheds Another Husband
description: The second of Britney Spearss two 2004 marriages has officially ended in divorce, according to her lawyer, The Associated Press reported. Exit Kevin Federline, above with Ms. Spears, a backup dancer, actor, rapper and successor to Jason Alexander, a childhood friend of Ms. Spearss who departed via annulment after 55 hours. Everything is finalized, Ms. Spearss lawyer, Laura Wasser, said Monday after a hearing in Superior Court in Los Angeles. The court commissioner, Scott Gordon, signed orders for dissolution of marriage, an alimony agreement and child custody. Ms. Wasser said the alimony agreement would not be made public unless enforcement becomes an issue, and, citing the interests of the children, she added that the child custody agreement had been sealed pending a hearing on Aug. 14. Since February, Ms. Spears, 25, and Mr. Federline, 29, have shared custody of their sons, Sean Preston, 22 months, and Jayden James, 10 months. Ms. Wasser said that Ms. Spears, who cited irreconcilable differences in seeking the divorce on Nov. 7, was O.K. with the terms of the settlement but would like to be with her kids more.

title: Johnson & Johnson Plans to Cut 4,800 Jobs
description: With generic competition looming for two of its blockbuster drugs and use declining for its drug-coated stents, Johnson & Johnson said yesterday that it would eliminate up to 4,800 jobs.

title: A Plea for Respect for a Familiar Fish
description: I WISH Id had Al Gore with me at Wild Salmon, where I stumbled across a new sign of climate change. It concerned dessert, and it might well have concerned him.

title: What You Get for... $8.5 Million
description: Dorset, Vt.

title: Republicans Shun Debate, and Right Cries Out
description: When the leading Republican presidential candidates started to squirm last week about attending a Sept. 17 YouTube debate, in which the public would ask questions via video, there was a surprising backlash from the world of Republican and conservative bloggers.

title: A Simple Thirst, a Great Cab
description: SNOHOMISH, Wash.

title: Finding Dakar in New York
description: RESTAURANTS

title: Ethiopia: Interpreter Freed
description: Mohamed Abdi, an Ethiopian-American interpreter detained for more than two months without being charged, was released over the weekend, American officials said. He had been working as an interpreter for the American military in the volatile eastern Ogaden region when Ethiopian troops arrested him and two American soldiers in early May. The Americans were promptly released, but Mr. Abdi was sent to a military camp where he was kept until Sunday. An Ethiopian military spokesman said he had no information about the events.

title: Zimbabwe: New $200,000 Bill
description: The central bank issued a new $200,000 Zimbabwe bill as a convenience to beleaguered citizens, already so battered by hyperinflation that the common method for carrying currency is not a billfold, but a grocery bag. The new note is worth either $13 or $800 in United States money, depending on which of the governments official exchange rates one uses, but on the black market patronized by most Zimbabweans, it is worth a bit over one American dollar. On the street, the $200,000 bill will buy roughly a quart of gasoline or a two-pound bag of sugar. Previously, the $100,000 note was the highest bill in circulation. The government released the new note as the International Monetary Fund issued a report warning that annual inflation in Zimbabwe  officially 4,500 percent but more than 10,000 percent by conservative unofficial estimates  could reach 100,000 percent by years end.

title: Campaign Puts Giuliani and Ailes in Uncharted Territory
description: Roger Ailes and Rudolph W. Giuliani have been pulling for each other for nearly two decades.

title: Taking the Guesswork Out of Which Subway Escalators Are Broken
description: For many straphangers, encountering a broken elevator or escalator can be one of the more unpleasant surprises of travel in the subway system, requiring a long trek up a hot flight of stairs. For riders in wheelchairs, it can be far more than an inconvenience, requiring a lengthy detour to get out of the subway system.

title: Rumsfeld Denies Cover-Up in Tillman Case
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1  Former Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said today he felt terrible about the militarys flawed handling of the death of Cpl. Pat Tillman, the former football star who was killed in Afghanistan. But he and other former Pentagon leaders insisted that there had been no attempt to cover up the way it happened.

title: Getting a University to Aim Higher
description: LEXINGTON, Ky.  A thick loose-leaf book jammed with charts and graphs details Lee T. Todd Jr.s ambitious plans for the University of Kentucky. But in a recent speech to a chamber of commerce, Dr. Todd, the universitys president, summed them up in three brisk words: Research drives jobs.

title: New Interest in Bridgeports Neglected Neighborhoods
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn.  Not long after John M. Fabrizi was elected to a full term as mayor in 2003, he joined with business leaders in inviting the Urban Land Institute, a research organization sponsored by the real estate industry, to advise Connecticuts poorest city on how to turn itself around.

title: House, 411-8, Passes a Vast Ethics Overhaul
description: WASHINGTON, July 31  The House on Tuesday overwhelmingly approved sweeping ethics rules that would require lawmakers to disclose the names of lobbyists who gather more than $15,000 in political contributions for them within a six-month period. The measure would also impose new restrictions on accepting gifts, discounted airfare and other long-held perquisites of office.

title: To Ethiopians in America, Bread Is a Taste of Home
description: IN neat head scarf and stained apron, Frehiwot Reta welcomed a customer into her tiny apartment in Harlem on a Sunday afternoon. Squeezing between stove, desk and dining table, she passed the woman a steamy bag of fresh injera, the tart, spongy flatbread that is, literally, the foundation of every Ethiopian meal.

title: A Drowsy Family Vacation, Except for That Little Affair
description: Summer 04, the second feature by the German director Stefan Krohmer, is being praised as a daring work, and the synopsis is enticing. Its a dark drama in which upper-middle-class vacationers  liberal parents (Peter Davor and Martina Gedeck), their easygoing teenage son (Lucas Kotaranin) and the sons 12-year-old girlfriend (Svea Lohde)  meet a depressive yet magnetic German-American expatriate (Robert Seeliger), who pals around with the girl, then has a secret affair with her boyfriends volcanically sensual mom.

title: Voting Officials Face New Rules to Bar Conflicts
description: The state officials who run the nations elections  most with little oversight  are facing new efforts to limit what have been widely criticized as political and financial conflicts of interest.

title: Following in Lafayettes Footsteps, or Rather, His Wake
description: ROCHEFORT, France, July 29  Piece by piece, a graceful structure of whimsy and magic is taking shape in this old river port, fulfilling the dream of a group of seafaring Frenchmen to honor a founding father of French-American friendship.

title: Report Assails Oversight of College Lenders
description: The federal Department of Education, after months of criticism for its lax oversight of the student loan program, still has no system to detect and uncover misconduct by lenders and protect student borrowers, a new government report says.

title: Glavine Delivers, but History Must Wait
description: MILWAUKEE, July 31  Those in the 300-victory club choose new members very carefully. When a worthy candidate comes along, flashing his credentials, he is considered but given this warning: Hardly anyone comes in on his first try.

title: Iwo Jima Sculpture, Model for Marine War Memorial, Is Losing Its Home on Floating Museum
description: A 62-year-old sculpture of the flag-raising on Iwo Jima is getting the heave-ho from the museum on the aircraft carrier Intrepid while the ship is docked in Staten Island for an overhaul, museum officials and the sculptures owner said yesterday.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on July 17 about the NorthEast Two-Spirit Society, an organization for gay American Indians based in Manhattan, referred incorrectly to one member, Kevin VanWanseele, a Kumeyaay Indian. Before he moved to New York, he had been living in a suburb of San Diego  not on the nearby Barona Indian Reservation, where he had grown up.

title: Ethics Questions Plague Other Alaska Senator
description: WASHINGTON, July 31  Senator Lisa Murkowski, Republican of Alaska, has been drawn into a swirl of ethics accusations that have already brought F.B.I. scrutiny to the two other members of the states Congressional delegation and resulted in a raid this week on the home of Senator Ted Stevens.

title: Calendar
description: In and Around 34th Street

title: 2 Killed and 7 Are Wounded as Shots Fly in Brooklyn
description: Two people were killed and seven wounded by gunfire during a bloody four hours overnight in Brooklyn, the police said yesterday. It did not appear that the four shootings were related, the police said, even though two of them occurred three blocks apart.

title: Sometimes, Better to Leap Without Looking
description: One of the toughest challenges Charles Altmann faced in switching careers was learning to keep his mouth shut. But that is the sort of sacrifice you have to make if you heed the call of your inner entrepreneur.

title: Manhattan: No More Baby Formula in Gift Bags
description: New York Citys 11 public hospitals will no longer offer free samples of baby formula in gift bags to new mothers, the citys Health and Hospitals Corporation announced yesterday. The agency said the decision was meant to promote breast-feeding as part of the citys campaign to improve infant health. The agency estimated that 24 percent of women who deliver at public hospitals breast-feed exclusively after they are discharged, up from fewer than 15 percent of such women a year ago. Breast-feeding is a very important way to protect the health of babies and mothers, said Dr. Thomas R. Frieden, the commissioner of the citys Department of Health and Mental Hygiene. Officials with the hospital agency said formula would be available for women who request it.

title: Indian Movie Star Gets 6 Years in Gun Trial With Terrorist Link
description: NEW DELHI, July 31  One of Bollywoods best-loved film stars was sentenced Tuesday in a Mumbai courtroom to six years in prison for illegally possessing weapons, a judgment hailed by critics and supporters of Indias judiciary as a strong, if unusual, example of its willingness to stand up to the countrys rich and powerful.

title: New Policy on Cuba (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the restaurateur Daniel Bouluds settlement of a discrimination lawsuit misidentified the plaintiffs in a lawsuit filed against the Restaurant Opportunities Center of New York, an organization that had criticized Mr. Boulud. They are former employees of Windows on the World, the World Trade Center restaurant destroyed on 9/11  not of Colors, a restaurant created after 9/11 by other former employees of Windows on the World.

title: Khmer Rouge Figure Is First Charged in Atrocities
description: BANGKOK, July 31  A tribunal in Cambodia charged the commandant of the main Khmer Rouge torture house with crimes against humanity on Tuesday, bringing the first charge in a long-delayed trial in the deaths of 1.7 million people in the late 1970s.

title: Coming Clean in the Capitol
description: It took a while, and the process certainly hasnt been pretty, but the Democrats are close to winning passage of their long-promised ethics reform bill. We suspect it will take a lot more than one new law to break the binding and corrupting ties of lobbyist cash and politics. But the bill, which the House approved with overwhelming, bipartisan enthusiasm yesterday, is a good start.

title: From Eggless Custard, Summers Iced Treat
description: LAST winter, I wrote about custards  puddings, really  that are thickened not with eggs but with cornstarch. When the weather warmed and I started making ice cream, I wanted to see how the puddings would perform as a stand-in for my traditional six-egg-yolk custard, the base for what Ive always believed was the best ice cream.

title: In Praise of Tap Water
description: On the streets of New York or Denver or San Mateo this summer, it seems the telltale cap of a water bottle is sticking out of every other satchel. Americans are increasingly thirsty for what is billed as the healthiest, and often most expensive, water on the grocery shelf. But this country has some of the best public water supplies in the world. Instead of consuming four billion gallons of water a year in individual-sized bottles, we need to start thinking about what all those bottles are doing to the planets health.

title: Government Makes a Case, and Holds Dogs as Evidence
description: SURRY, Va., July 31  More than 60 dogs seized from Michael Vicks property have been sheltered here and in kennels across several counties in southeastern Virginia since April.

title: Off the Menu
description: Looking Ahead

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A picture caption with an article in Business Day on Friday about plans by Goldman Sachs to start a hedge fund, which will be managed by Raanan A. Agus, the head of its equity proprietary trading desk, misidentified the man shown. He is Daniel H. Stern, founder of Reservoir Capital  not Eric Mindich, who had previously been a part of that trading desk at Goldman.

title: In Murdochs Past, Clues to The Journals Future
description: So now what?

title: Senate Bill Revisits Medical Safeguards
description: For the fourth year in a row, Senator Byron Dorgan, Democrat of North Dakota, is seeking to pass legislation that would curb the shortcomings of boxings medical safeguards.

title: Judge Orders Author to Pay Film Company $350,000 in Legal Fees
description: Laura Albert, the fiction writer better known as JT LeRoy, was ordered yesterday to pay $350,000 in legal fees to a film production company that sued her successfully for fraud.

title: Cutting a Tumultuous Eras Soul Soundtrack
description: One day in the early 1960s, a young man who worked as driver and baggage handler for a group called Johnny Jenkins and the Pinetoppers lugged its instruments into the studios of Stax Records in Memphis, where the band was scheduled for a recording session. As it happened, the young man sang too  in a husky tenor  and spent his idle hours that afternoon begging people to hand him a mike.

title: A Rolling Stone Prepares to Gather His Memories
description: Lets see how much he remembers: the guitarist Keith Richards, a founding member of the Rolling Stones, is writing an autobiography, to be published by Little, Brown & Company in the United States and Weidenfeld & Nicolson in Britain in the fall of 2010.

title: Hempstead Village Divided on $2 Billion Comeback Plan
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., July 31  For centuries this village was the center of activity on Long Island, until modern suburbia exploded around it and decay set in.

title: Stocks Close Higher After Late Rally
description: Stocks closed higher on Wall Street today after a rally late in the session, reversing course from a slump yesterday that led to a sell-off in Asia and carried over in Europe because of concerns about the mortgage industry.

title: Going From Behind a Sales Counter to the Old Course
description: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, July 31  There was a time, not that long ago, when the only thing that seemed more unlikely than a Womens British Open being held here was a Womens British Open being held here with Carri Wood in the field.

title: Fine Diner to Riffraff: Tipsy Tales of 4-Star Benders
description: THE Bordeaux was flowing, the foie gras abundant and the well-heeled epicures at Daniel were having a refined old time when suddenly all eyes turned toward a table against one wall and all conversation ceased.

title: When the Doctor Says Its Cancer (7 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Roberts Facing Medical Option on 2nd Seizure
description: Despite his quick recovery from the seizure he suffered on Monday, Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. faces a complex diagnosis and a difficult decision.

title: Oil Prices Continue to Rise, With a Close Above $78
description: The great oil rally, now in its fourth year, shows no sign of slowing down.

title: Nutrition Labels Proposed for Alcohol
description: A PROPOSAL to require the alcohol content, servings per container and some nutrition information be printed on alcoholic beverage packaging was published yesterday by the Treasury Department. It comes several decades after the agency was first petitioned to require the information and four years after the most recent request.

title: Mr. Abe on the Ropes
description: Japans deeply unpopular prime minister, Shinzo Abe, is insisting that he wont step down, even after his Liberal Democratic Party won only 37 of the 121 contested seats in the upper house of Parliament in last Sundays election. Mr. Abe is not legally required to go so as long as he holds on to the lower house majority, but the political message is clear: If he is determined to stay, he must change course.

title: Getty to Return 40 Artifacts to Italy
description: ROME, Aug. 1  The J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles has agreed to hand over 40 objects from its antiquities collection that Italy contends were looted, putting an end to a long and complex negotiation, the museums governing trust and the Italian Culture Ministry said in a joint statement today.

title: Gaining Admittance to the Club
description: As second home developers continue to build communities geared to popular pastimes like golf, tennis, horseback riding and fishing, property ownership often includes a club membership application.

title: Whats on Tonight
description: MIDNIGHT (IFC) INDIE SEX II: CENSORED The burlesque performer Dita Von Teese, at left with a friend, who knows that sometimes less obvious is more scintillating, is the host of this four-night festival, which explores how sexual fantasies have been played in independent films  and made it around production codes. First stop: Indie Sex: Censored, which moves from Eadweard Muybridges human-motion studies of naked men and women to the 1930s Hays Code to the Motion Picture Association of Americas institution of a formalized rating system in 1968 to its request at this years Sundance Film Festival that young filmmakers create more NC-17 movies. Peter Sarsgaard, Miranda July, Heather Matarazzo, John Cameron Mitchell, John Waters, Tatum ONeal, Rosanna Arquette, Piper Perabo, Ally Sheedy, Guinevere Turner and Ms. Von Teese tell us what they think.

title: A Cotswolds Country Home
description: Digging in the lush gardens of their Cotswolds country home often inspired Rebecca and Cyrus Harvey Jr. to create new soaps and scents for Crabtree & Evelyn, the botanical body and home products company that they founded in 1973.

title: Restoring the Faith After Hitting the Bottom
description: What good is a nadir if its denied or ignored? Whats the value of reaching the lowest of the low if it cant buy a cheap epiphany?

title: Tapes Implicate Tijuana Police in Drug Trafficking and a Killing
description: TIJUANA, Mexico, July 31  Just days before a critical governors election in Baja California, federal authorities have released tapes to a newspaper suggesting that many members of the Tijuana police force have worked for drug traffickers and helped in the killing of a federal agent, the newspaper reported Tuesday.

title: Bill Would Extend Lawsuit Window
description: The House passed a bill that would give workers more time to file wage discrimination lawsuits. The bill passed on a vote of 225 to 199, not enough to override a threatened veto from President Bush. In May, the Supreme Court ruled that under the terms of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 an employee had 180 days to bring suit after the first unfair paycheck was issued. The Senate is working on a similar measure.

title: Violence Rages in Iraq as Sunni Bloc Leaves Cabinet
description: BAGHDAD, Aug. 1  Iraqs largest Sunni political faction resigned from Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Malikis cabinet on Wednesday, severely weakening the governments credentials as a national unity coalition and setting back hopes of reconciliation.

title: Dow Jones Deal Gives Murdoch a Coveted Prize
description: Rupert Murdoch finally won his long-coveted prize yesterday, gaining enough support from the deeply divided Bancroft family to buy Dow Jones & Company, publisher of The Wall Street Journal and one of the worlds most respected news sources, for $5 billion.

title: A Requiem for Tenants of Carnegie
description: The process server played his knuckles on the door, fortissimo.

title: Readers May Be Wary, but Ad Executives Are Not
description: Villain, savior or just an ambitious businessman? In Manhattans financial district yesterday, core Wall Street Journal readers who had been following the drawn-out Dow Jones takeover events had no shortage of opinions about Rupert Murdoch.

title: Recipe: Peanut Stew With Lamb (Mafe)
description: Adapted from Ken Alice Ndoye

title: In Civil Unions, New Challenges Over Benefits
description: NEWARK, July 31  United Parcel Service now grants full health benefits to same-sex partners of its employees, provided they have registered for a civil union in New Jersey (as opposed to, say, in Vermont). But FedEx does not provide benefits to the partners of its New Jersey workers  unless they happen to work at Kinkos, a FedEx subsidiary.

title: Edwardss Campaign Tries to Harness Internet
description: WASHINGTON, July 31  Most presidential campaigns mark their progress by how they are doing in the polls and how much money they are raising.

title: To Ford, a Disaster. To Edsel Owners, Love.
description: KINGSTON, N.Y., July 31  Martin Lennox took out an ad in the local paper to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the day his car rolled off the assembly line. Then he gave a party.

title: In Dense Stews From Senegal, Intriguing Secrets
description: WITH its spotless new white-tile floors and gleaming stainless-steel ovens, the basement kitchen of Patisserie des Ambassades, a French cafe in Harlem on Frederick Douglass Boulevard, has the fit and finish of a laboratory. On a recent weekday morning, its two resident scientists  bakers in starched white coats  glazed mixed-berry tartlets and spread crme Chantilly over thin sheets of millefeuille pastry on a long steel table.

title: A Writer Finds the Rare Lives of Two Rare-Book Dealers Worth Singing About
description: LONG BRANCH, N.J.  The New Jersey Repertory Company here has always had a taste for the unusual, and the genesis of its current production, a world-premiere musical called Bookends, is suitably quirky. The piece came about when the woman who took Sidney Poitier home for dinner met the rare-book dealers who exposed Louisa May Alcotts dark secret.

title: As Easy as Pie, and It Sizzles
description: IF it werent for a certain 10-year-old friend of mine, I might never have contemplated a summer fling with deep-frying. But when I heard that Madeleine got an electric mini-deep-fryer for her birthday, I begged her mother to let her take it with us for the weekend.

title: 43 Are Arrested in Gang Inquiry in Los Angeles
description: LOS ANGELES, July 31  More than 400 police officers and federal agents took part in predawn raids on Tuesday, arresting 43 people suspected of being members of the Eastside Pain Bloods gang in a narcotics and gun trafficking investigation, federal and city officials said.

title: Campaign for a Yogurt Enlists Stylish Partners
description: THE images are eye-catching, luscious and tactile: on the left-hand page of the magazine is an advertisement for a Tourneau watch, its elaborate silver face shown up-close and in striking detail.

title: Call by U.S. House for Sex Slavery Apology Angers Japans Leader
description: TOKYO, Wednesday, Aug. 1  Prime Minister Shinzo Abe expressed some irritation on Tuesday at the resolution approved by the House of Representatives in Washington that calls on Japan to acknowledge its wartime sex slavery. His reaction indicated strongly that the Japanese government would not offer surviving victims an official apology.

title: Japan: Maker of Subaru Posts Loss
description: Fuji Heavy Industries, the maker of Subaru cars, posted a loss for the first time in eight quarters after sales declined in the United States and Japan. The net loss was 332 million yen ($2.8 million), or 0.46 yen a share, compared with a profit of 4.6 billion yen, or 6.42 yen, a year earlier, Fuji said. Sales fell 3.4 percent, to 318.2 billion yen from 329.5 billion yen. Separately, Suzuki Motor said first-quarter profit rose 20 percent, helped by increased sales of compact cars in Asia and Europe and a weaker yen. Net income climbed to 24.4 billion yen ($205.3 million), compared with 20.3 billion yen, a year earlier, the Tokyo-based company said. Sales rose 17 percent, to 894.5 billion yen. Mazda said first-quarter profit fell 63 percent as losses from currency hedging more than doubled. Net income fell to 2.48 billion yen ($21 million), from 6.61 billion yen, a year earlier. Sales rose 11 percent, to 814.3 billion yen. Mazda is based in Hiroshima.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article and headline on July 19 about Exxon Mobils cleanup of an underground oil spill in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, referred imprecisely to the source of the 17 million gallons of oil and oil products that the state estimates has contaminated Newtown Creek and its banks. Although an explosion in 1950 contributed to the contamination, the area has been used by various petroleum companies for more than 140 years, and the 17 million gallons accumulated gradually over that time  not all at once after the explosion. (The error also appeared on Nov. 1, 2005; June 23, 2006; and on Feb. 9, July 16 and July 18 of this year.)

title: Nine Roles, One Able Soprano and Abundant Conniving
description: Of the myriad challenges a soprano can set before herself in a recital, none offer precisely the same sort of demands as Judith Weirs King Haralds Saga, from 1979. The works wide vocal range and elaborately curling melodies require a singer with exceptional flexibility and flawless intonation. Then there are the dramaturgical concerns: Ms. Weirs quirky piece is a three-act opera that includes nine roles, all sung by unaccompanied soprano in the space of 12 minutes.

title: Davies Finally Tees Off at the Old Course
description: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, July 31  Laura Davies of England has been a professional golfer for more than 20 years and has won dozens of tournaments all over the world. But until Tuesday she had never played the Old Course.

title: World Stock Markets Fall Sharply
description: SINGAPORE, Aug. 1  Stock markets in Asia fell sharply today on concerns about widening mortgage woes in the United States and the threats they pose: that investors are being forced to sell Asian assets to cover losses in the United States, and that hard-pressed American homeowners will scale back their demand for Asian exports.

title: Letters
description: Farm Animal Welfare

title: U.S. Death Toll in Iraq in July Was the Lowest in 07
description: BAGHDAD, Aug. 1  The deaths, announced today, of four American soldiers in Baghdad on Tuesday brought the total American military death toll in July to 78, the lowest monthly figure so far this year.

title: O. J. Simpson Book Rights go to Goldman Family
description: A federal bankruptcy judge has awarded rights to the reviled O. J. Simpson book If I Did It, a hypothetical account of how he could have killed his former wife, Nicole Brown Simpson, to the family of Ronald Goldman, right, her friend who was murdered with her in a 1994 knife attack, The Associated Press reported. After 13 years of trying to get some justice, today is probably the first time we had any sense of seeing light at the end of the tunnel, said Mr. Goldmans father, Fred. Mr. Simpson was acquitted of murder in 1995 but lost wrongful-death civil lawsuits to the Goldman and Brown families, who are seeking to satisfy their multimillion-dollar judgments against him. He has maintained his innocence. Under the settlement with a court-appointed trustee, which was approved by the judge, A. Jay Cristol, in Miami, the Brown family is to receive part of the first 10 percent of gross proceeds from the book and the Goldmans the rest. Publication of the book by HarperCollins was canceled amid public outcry. David Cook, the Goldmans lawyer, said that discussions with literary agents, publishing houses and movie studios were in progress.

title: From Wyoming to Montana on Foot
description: TEN THOUSAND feet above sea level, just north of the Wyoming-Montana border, lies Albino Lake, a fish-shaped oblong of icy water bounded on its east by a reddish, rock-slide-scarred ridge and on its west by the high, bare peak of Lonesome Mountain. A few tiny, rocky islands poke up from the water, and on one stands a thatch of purple wildflowers that glow like neon in the golden light of late afternoon. When night falls, the surface of the lake turns silver, then black. The rough stillness in the air is a constant reminder that, although a thin trail runs along the shore, this is the very edge of civilization  the frontier.

title: Hal Steinbrenner Steps Into the Spotlight
description: The last time I remember hearing Hal Steinbrenner speak was at a news conference introducing Jos Contreras in 2003. He was representing his father, George, and he stood up and said one sentence: Ill keep it brief, but were expecting great things.

title: Late September
description: The mail truck goes down the coast

title: Poems by Charles Simic
Currents
description: For the home (and the closet and liquor cabinet), all things Trump and more.

title: Private Equity Goes Back to School
description: Among the many sources of private equitys huge war chests has been cash from university endowments. Now buyout firms are pouring some of that money back into colleges  and the companies that service them and their students.

title: More Red Ink After Alcatel-Lucent Merger
description: The telecommunications equipment maker Alcatel-Lucent posted its second consecutive loss in the second quarter on costs related to its recent merger and an unfavorable product and geographic mix, the company said Tuesday.

title: Guessing Murdochs Strategy for The Journal
description: Since the News Corporations offer for Dow Jones & Company was made public three months ago, Rupert Murdochs business career, character and motives have been dissected in an effort to predict what he might do as the owner of The Wall Street Journal.

title: Former Merrill Broker Sentenced in Squawk-Box Case
description: A former Merrill Lynch broker was sentenced Tuesday in federal court in Brooklyn to a year and a day in prison for witness tampering and making false statements in connection with an alleged scheme to misuse information broadcast over brokerage squawk boxes.

title: Manhattan Media Said to Buy The New York Press
description: The New York Press, the citys second-largest free weekly newspaper after The Village Voice, was expected to be sold Wednesday to Manhattan Media, a publisher of weekly newspapers, according to The New York Times.

title: Banks Must Wait for South Koreas Big I.P.O.s
description: South Korea is encouraging state firms to go public, but investors and big banks will have to wait until next year at least before crown jewels like Incheon International Airport hit the market.

title: Alitalia Chairman Steps Down in Wake of Failed Auction
description: Berardino Libonati, chairman of Alitalia, the Italian state-controlled airline, resigned Tuesday following the failure of the governments attempt to sell the carrier. Mr. Libonati, who had been appointed to guide the airlines privatization, resigned after all prospective buyers pulled out of the sale last month following a seven-month auction.

title: Aon May Sell Combined Insurance Unit
description: Aon said Tuesday that it is once again considering a sale or spinoff of its Combined Insurance Company of America unit, a move analysts applauded along with the parents stronger-than-expected financial results in the second quarter.

title: Brookfield Plans Infrastructure Spin-Off
description: Canadas Brookfield Asset Management plans to spin off a 60 percent stake in its infrastructure operations to its shareholders in a deal worth about $600 million, the company said Tuesday.

title: EGL Shareholders Approve $2 Billion Buyout
description: EGL shareholders have approved the $2 billion buyout of the logistics provider by Ceva Group, the company said Tuesday. The buyout of Houston-based EGL by Ceva, which is owned by affiliates of Apollo Management, is expected to close Thursday.

title: Third Bear Stearns Fund Skids on Mortgages
description: Another Bear Stearns hedge fund has been hit by turmoil in the mortgage market.

title: The Wall Street Journal Under Murdoch
description: Since the News Corporations offer for Dow Jones & Company was made public three months ago, Rupert Murdochs business career, character and motives have been dissected in an effort to predict what he might do as the owner of The Wall Street Journal. Based on his history, Mr. Murdoch is expected to try to broaden The Journals influence beyond pure business readers.

title: Technology Partners Raises $300 Million
description: Technology Partners, one of the first venture capital firms to get into clean technology, announced it has raised $300 million for its eighth fund. The firm will use the funds to invest in clean tech companies as well as life sciences and health/lifestyle companies.

title: New Zealand's Dairy Farms
description: Since New Zealand's government drastically reduced subsidies to farmers in the 1980s, its agricultural community has never been the same.

title: Sovereign Wealth Funds: The New Hedge Fund?
description: One of the enduring criticisms lobbed at hedge funds is their lack of transparency. Now, regulators and lawmakers may soon have a new target in their fight against opacity.

title: Dow Chemical Said to Prepare Imperial Bid
description: Dow Chemical, the largest chemicals group in the United States, is considering making a rival offer for Imperial Chemical Industries, the British maker of Dulux paints, The Telegraph reported.

title: 3i Said to Pull NCP Auction Amid Market Turmoil
description: The turmoil in the debt markets has claimed another casualty, with a British private equity firm, 3i, pulling its auction of NCP Services, a company that supplies traffic wardens to many of Britains local councils, according to The Telegraph.

title: Enron Plaintiffs Call for White House Support
description: Former investors in Enron called on the White House on Tuesday to support efforts to hold third parties accountable when their actions help a company defraud investors.

title: Jones Apparel Favors Japanese Bid for Barneys
description: The Jones Apparel Group said Wednesday it plans to accept a $900 million cash bid for Barneys New York from Fast Retailing of Japan.

title: Ampd Mobile Seeks to Sell Assets
description: After holding an emergency auction, the bankrupt wireless carrier Ampd Mobile is seeking approval for very discrete asset sales in a Wednesday, Aug. 1, hearing, The Deal.com said, citing a court schedule.

title: Discovery Said to Embrace Treehugger
description: Discovery Communications has scooped up a companion Web site to its upcoming Planet Green cable network, agreeing to buy Treehugger.com for about $10 million, The New York Post reported.

title: Macquarie Warns on Debt Fund Losses
description: Australias Macquarie Bank warned on Wednesday that retail investors in two debt funds face losses of up to 25 percent as fallout from the global credit crunch widened, knocking 10 percent off its shares.

title: Deutsche Bank Posts Rise in Profit
description: Deutsche Bank, Germanys biggest bank, said profit rose 31 percent, beating analysts estimates, on record second-quarter trading revenue. Net income climbed to 1.78 billion euros ($2.43 billion), or 3.60 euros a share, from 1.35 billion euros, or 2.44 euros, a year earlier, the Frankfurt-based bank said on its Web site Wednesday.

title: Lazard Earnings Fall 2.2% as Fewer Deals Are Done
description: Lazard said second-quarter earnings fell 2.2 percent, as the firm completed fewer merger and acquisition assignments, but the profit was higher than analysts had forecast. Profit declined to $61.5 million, or 53 cents a share, from $62.9 million, or 60 cents a share, a year earlier, the New York-based company said.

title: Tanglewood Festival: Can Music Talk Politics?
description: Lenox, Mass.  One question being explored at this summers Festival of Contemporary Music is whether concert music can effectively express political concerns. But when it comes down to it, there seem few illusions about that. Works with texts can do it, of course. But then its the text thats making the statement; the music, if it is effective at all, can amplify the text and give it emotional resonance and dimension.

title: The Dow Jones Sale: Wall Street Speaks
description: Villain, savior or just an ambitious businessman? In Manhattans financial district Tuesday, core Wall Street Journal readers who had been following the drawn-out Dow Jones takeover events had no shortage of opinions about Rupert Murdoch.

title: Murdoch and Dow Jones: How The Deal Got Done
description: While Rupert Murdoch finally won his long-coveted prize  gaining enough support from the deeply divided Bancroft family to buy Dow Jones & Company, publisher of The Wall Street Journal  closing the $5 billion deal was a marathon of conference calls and all-nighters for those involved in the deal-making process.

title: Morning Buzz: The Mayors Unusual Commute, Tax Evasion Convictions, and More
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has often boasted of his subway-riding prowess, casting himself as a straphanger who uses the subway for his daily commute. But after five weeks of observing the mayors commuting habits, a team of New York Times reporters has concluded that the mayors routine is somewhat unusual, Michael M. Grynbaum reports. When he does take the subway to work  at least several times a week  he is picked up by two S.U.V.s and driven from his town house on 79th Street to the subway station at 59th Street, where he catches the express train (the No. 4 or No. 5 subway line) to City Hall. Where would you drive from in Manhattan to a subway station? an M.T.A. spokesman, Jeremy Soffin, said when told about the routine. That would be pretty crazy.

title: Shadowing the Mayor of New York
description: When I started as a reporting intern on The Timess Metro desk, I didnt expect I would find myself shadowing the mayor of New York. But when my editor asked me how Id feel about waking up every morning at 6 oclock to hop on a subway and stand around a street 70 blocks from my apartment, it seemed too good to pass up. The story was irresistible: Checking Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs assertion that he commuted regularly to work by subway. It was a perennial political question: Did image live up to reality?The last time Id been conscious at that hour involved finishing up a term paper from the night before. But Mayor Bloomberg is a notorious early riser  in his 1997 autobiography, he recalls chastising a colleague for arriving to work at 8 a.m.

title: Quick Bits: AOL Shrinks, Dell Gains Support
description: A lot of follow-ups on yesterdays events:

title: 2008: Obama on Terrorism
description: For the last few weeks, Republican candidate Mitt Romney has been accusing the Democrats of using defeatist language on terrorism and the war in Iraq. Rudolph W. Giuliani has arguably been even tougher, calling Democrats the party of losers who refuse to admit the existence of Islamic terrorism.

title: DealBook Talks Dow Jones
description: On Tuesday nights episode of The Charlie Rose Show, DealBooks Andrew Ross Sorkin sat down with Charlie Rose and The New Yorkers Ken Auletta to talk about the News Corporations $5 billion deal for Dow Jones. You can watch the full video after the jump.

title: Lightly Updated
description: Subtle revisions (a decorator calls them the 50-year fix-up) in a town resistant to change.

title: Genstar Adds Adviser for Canadian Deals
description: Genstar Capital, a private equity firm based in San Francisco that focuses on midsize companies, added Kevin T. OLeary to its strategic advisory board.

title: WSJ: Opinions Not for Sale
description: The Wall Street Journal editorial page wants its readers to know that it wont be changing its political perspective just because Rupert Murdoch bought Dow Jones, the company that owns The Journal:

title: Race and Restaurants
description: On Monday Daniel Boulud settled a lawsuit filed by busboys and runners who said he didnt promote them to be waiters because they werent white. Today, the federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission weighed in, filing a lawsuit that backed the workers complaints.

title: Quadrangle Hires Former Yahoo Executive
description: Quadrangle Group, a media- and communications-focused investment firm based in New York, said Wednesday it had hired Daniel Rosensweig, the former chief operating officer of Yahoo, to open an office in Silicon Valley in September.

title: Frugal Traveler: Absaroka- Beartooth Wil
description: Matt and his camping partner hike and skinny dip on the way to Hidden Lake, in the Absaroka-Beartooth Wilderness.

title:
Living with Music:
A Playlist by Irvine Welsh
description: On Wednesdays, this blog is the delivery vehicle for Living With Music, a playlist of songs from a writer or some other kind of book-world personage. Why? Because books and music, on good days, just seem to go together. And because the celebrity playlists on iTunes never get around to asking writers to pitch in.

title: Wet and Wonderful and, Best of All, Free
description: Its not often that I use a post on this site to link to the editorial page of the newspaper, but today I felt I simply had to. Please read In Praise of Tap Water.

title: Gol! Gol! Gol!
description: [Correction appended]

title: Bears Stock Hits New 52-Week Low
description: Does James Cayne still feel like hitting the greens?

title: Murdochs Deal History Shows Fickle Streak
description: Dont count on Rupert Murdoch holding on to Dow Jones and the Wall Street Journal for the long term, warns Slates Jack Shafer, the media critic who has written many scathing columns about Mr. Murdoch since the media barons News Corporation made its bid in May. Hell keep it long enough to destroy it, then sell it off, Mr. Shafer predicts.

title: Bull Says Non to H.P. Takeover Rumors
description: Bull, a French computer services company, said on Wednesday that, contrary to a recent report, it was not in negotiations with Hewlett-Packard nor had it received an offer from the American computer giant. There are no ongoing negotiations, and we have not received a formal offer, Bulls chief executive, Didier Lamouche, told a conference call when asked about Hewlett-Packard.

title: When Hedgies Drink Box Wine, Thats News
description: This just in: Hedge fund managers like to drink expensive booze, Dan Dorfman revealed Wednesday in the New York Sun. He reports that six hedgies showed up at Tse Yang, a Chinese restaurant in New York, and spent $4,800 on a single round of a rare cognac.

title: Transcript: Houston Dynamo Coach Dominic Kinnear
description: It was a rare day off on Monday for Coach Dominic Kinnear and his defending M.L.S. champion Houston Dynamo.

title: July Heat Wilts 2 More Hedge Funds
description: Two more hedge fund managers may need a swig of something to ease the pain of stinging losses for July.

title: New Deal Debate for a New Era
description: In her web column today, Robin Toner tackles the newest incarnation of one of the nations oldest debates:

title: The Web Site as Self-Defense
description: Some writers Web sites are expansive and welcoming. Others are grudging and spartan.

title: Justice Robertss Full Disclosure
Democrats Welcome Representative Maloneys Backing
description: Micah Z. Kellner was reminiscing this week about his successful race for an Assembly seat on the East Side of Manhattan last June. He spoke of the hours he spent campaigning and the consistent support he got from his chief political benefactor: United States Representative Carolyn B. Maloney.

title: Ladies and Gentlemen, Plug In Your Engines
description: The first 30 teams have been announced in the Automotive X Prize, and that brings up one question:

title: Something to Nosh On: Heres the Skinny on Jewish Delis
description: Every aspect of the Jewish delicatessen  from the declining popularity of kishka to the rise of online sales to the gentrification of the Lower East Side  was touched upon at a panel discussion before a standing-room-only crowd Tuesday night at the Museum of the City of New York. References to pitcha (calfs foot jelly, an old delicacy) and the long-gone Garden Cafeteria drew knowing and nostalgic sighs. The owners of three legendary Jewish eateries spoke.Matthew Goodman, the author of Jewish Food: The World at Table, moderated the panel, held in conjunction with the exhibition The Jewish Daily Forward: Embracing an Immigrant Community, on view through Nov. 25. Despite talk of a revival, the number of Jewish delis has fallen precipitously in the post-World War II era, a theme that dominated the discussion.

title: Brazil, Guyana and Rainforest Emissions Credits
description: For years developing nations like Brazil argued that they should play no role in cutting greenhouse gas emissions. After all, they said, the rich world has been responsible for putting most of the CO2 already there up in the atmosphere, and poor countries need to industrialize at top speed to alleviate grinding poverty.

title: Tanglewood Festival: Stacking the Deck With Jazz
description: Lenox, Mass.  Lots of big, not entirely supportable generalizations are being made about the Generation of 38 composers who are being celebrated at Tanglewoods Festival of Contemporary Music this year. One is that drawing on popular music is a generational hallmark. Pop, for this generation, is jazz. And the jazz they grew up with  that of Mingus, Monk and Dave Brubeck, for example, and the later Ellington works  differs from contemporary classical music more in accent and (sometimes) instrumentation than in substance.

title: Deep Brain Stimulation
description: An animation depicts the insertion of electrodes into the brain of a patient with severe brain injury. (Source: Cleveland Clinic) Eds note: No sound

title: Dave's Cutting-Room Floor
description: David Pogue reviews trivial gadgets in his weekly video report.

title: Liars Cant Be Trusted
description: The news that Bear Stearns has halted withdrawals from a third hedge fund  one that sounds much less risky than the two that collapsed  is a reminder what happens when people suspect lies.

title: Analysts on Blackstone: Buy, Buy, Buy
description: The Blackstone Group has been feeling a chill on many fronts lately  from Capitol Hill, labor unions and the stock market, just to name a few. But the private equity giant got a big batch of love letters Wednesday from the research departments at investment banks, which initiated coverage on Blackstone en masse with droves of buy ratings.

title: Onischuk and Radjabov Take Over Lead at Biel as Carlsen Stumbles Again
description: The wheels continued to fall off for Magnus Carlsen of Norway as he lost a second consecutive game at the Biel International Chess Festival, this time to Loek Van Wely of the Netherlands. The tournaments leaders are now Alexander Onischuk of the United States, who today beat Boris Avrukh of Israel, and Teimour Radjabov of Azerbaijan, who decided to take the day off by playing a 10-move draw against Alexander Motylev of Russia. (Playing does not seem like the right verb to describe such a game.) The games can be followed live or replayed at the touraments official Web site.

title: You Asked, We Answer
description: With permit in hand, our builder, Johnny, is ready to begin, but he cant start construction until Bank of America closes our loan. He thinks its stupid, but it is bank policy. And since the bank is waiting for a couple of documents from the county, weve got to wait, too  but it looks like we can actually break ground in about a week!

title: Bloomberg: The Story Is What It Is
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg brushed off questions this afternoon about a report on his morning subway commute that revealed he is typically driven in an S.U.V. to a Midtown express subway stop 22 blocks from his Upper East Side home.

title: Movie Minutes: 'Hot Rod'
description: The New York Times Co-Chief Movie Critic A. O. Scott reviews "Hot Rod" a film about an unintelligent, untalented, aspiring stuntman.

title: Movie Minutes: 'El Cantante'
description: A. O. Scott reviews "El Cantante," starring Marc Anthony and Jennifer Lopez.

title: Garden State Riddle: How Will the Chicken Cross the Road?
description: Oh, all right, so maybe this isnt about chickens, but in its plans to widen a part of the Garden State Parkway to three lanes from two, the New Jersey Turnpike Authority has set aside $9 million to build tunnels for certain animals to cross to the other side. It doesnt include chickens because theyre not on federal or state threatened or endangered species lists, as far as we know. Those critters that are on that list  there are 14 and they include the Pine Barren tree frog, the eastern tiger salamander and timber rattlesnake  will be able to avail themselves of tunnels made of 36-inch reinforced concrete to get from one side of the parkway to another, according to an article  in todays Star-Ledger.

title: Disney to Buy Club Penguin Web Site
description: The House of Mouse is about to its doors to flocks of virtual penguins.

title: A Push to Restrict Tinted Windows in Cars
description: The citys public advocate, Betsy Gotbaum, and lawmakers in the State Legislature and the City Council are calling for law enforcement authorities to crack down on the use of illegally tinted windows.

title: What Were Reading on the Blogs
description: Odd couple: Rudolph W. Giuliani and Norman Siegel. [The Daily Politics]

title: Parsing Obamas Tougher Talk
description: Barack Obamas declaration, during a foreign-policy address today, that he would be willing as president to use military force against Al Qaeda in Pakistan (If we have actionable intelligence about high-value terrorist targets and President Musharraf wont act, we will) has provoked a blogburst. (Heres The New York Times news story on Obamas speech.)

title: Dispute Festers Over Moving of 9/11 Ceremony
description: The decision to move the 9/11 memorial ceremony this year to Zuccotti Park from ground zero  where it was held every year from 2002 to 2006  continued to spark debate today.With construction finally under way at ground zero, the authorities say the site cannot accommodate the ceremony. Instead, the ceremony is scheduled to be held at Zuccotti Park, at Broadway and Liberty Street, which was built in the late 1960s and originally known as Liberty Plaza Park. The park reopened in 2006, under a new name, after an $8 million renovation.

title: Hey, Were Walking Here
description: It sometimes seems as if theres advertising around every street corner in mid-Manhattan. At Fifth Avenue and 39th Street, at least until today, there was advertising at the street corner: this makeshift mini-billboard for a nearby Subway sandwich shop. Then the Department of Transportation arrived.

description: CNBC Advertisement with Herb Kelleher, President and Chief Executive, Southwest Airlines.

description: CNBC Advertisement with Mel Karmazin, Chief Executive, Sirius Radio.

title: Smiles of a Web Video
description: Of the two great filmmakers who died this week, Ingmar Bergman lent images to the world of pop culture in a way that Michelangelo Antonioni did not  mainly by virtue of the chess game with Death in The Seventh Seal. (Of course, he was also referenced by Woody Allen, over and over and over.)

title: Tanglewood Festival: Composers in Waiting, Well, Wait
description: Lenox, Mass.  Things are winding down here. The Festival of Contemporary Music offers only two more concerts, an orchestral performance tonight and the closing concert tomorrow, split between works of the jazz composer Julius Hemphill and electronic works by Musica Elettronica Viva (Alvin Curran, Richard Teitelbaum and Frederic Rzewski). As a coda, the Friday night Boston Symphony Orchestra concert, led by James Levine, includes the Concerto for Bass Viol and Orchestra by John Harbison, the festivals director (on a program otherwise devoted to Beethoven, Mozart and Ravel).

title: Can Zwinky Save Ask?
description: Barry Diller may be missing Jeeves, but at least he has Zwinky.

title: Food Shortage in Zimbabwe
description: Zimbabweans try cope with the effect of 10,000-percent-a-year hyperinflation on their food supply.

title: NASA Plans a Near-Miss
description: Enceladus is the coolest place in the solar system youve likely never heard of. And Enceladus, one of the moons of Saturn, is indeed cool  its surface temperature averages about minus-325 degrees Fahrenheit. It is also the shiniest object in the solar system, reflecting almost all of the light that hits it.

title: Rumsfeld Testifies on Tillman Death
description: Former Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld testified about his knowledge of the death of Army Ranger Pat Tillman.

title: Giuliani and Fox News
description: In case you glide by The Timess home page on the Web tonight, wed like to call your attention to an article by Russ Buettner on the long-longstanding relationship between former New York Mayor Rudy Giuliani and Roger Ailes, of Fox News.

title: Bonds in L.A.
description: A group of hecklers stood outside the visiting clubhouse at Dodger Stadium on Tuesday night, waiting for Barry Bonds.

title: International Influence
description: Exchange-rate-rich Europeans are not the only foreign buyers gobbling up property in the United States, according to a first-of-its kind study by the National Association of Realtors.

title: Your Comments on my Farm Column
description: My Thursday column is from Yamhill, Oregon, my hometown, and is about the disgraceful new farm bill that House Democratic leaders have backed. We all know that our ag subsidies harm Africa and are hugely costly, but one of my points is that they are also bad for the family farm and rural America itself. Id welcome your comments here.

title: Selig Watches Bonds, Grudgingly
description: Commissioner Bud Selig was at Dodger Stadium to watch Barry Bonds pursue Hank Aarons record again on Wednesday night, but Selig did not sound like someone who was thrilled to be in Los Angeles.

title: You Can Survive Polyester
description: COMMON wisdom in fashion says that it is easier to take a luxury brand downscale than to make a mass brand more expensive. But that doesnt explain why the most popular mens shirts at Scoop this spring, or those that flew off the racks at Jeffrey New York, were made by Gant. Gant?

title: Russia Set to Plant Flag on Arctic Seabed
description: The Russian research ship Akademik Fyodorov, escorted by a nuclear icebreaker, has reached the North Pole on a mission to send two small piloted submarines to plant a Russian flag on the seabed of the Arctic Ocean, directly under the pole, the Interfax news agency reported. The Mir submarines will dive 15,400 feet, possibly tomorrow, and a member of Parliament will accompany the crew to the bottom. The mission is intended to support Russias claim that the Artic Ocean, including the North Pole, lies within Moscows exclusive economic zone. Russia maintains that a geological feature called the Lomonosov Ridge, directly under the pole, forms part of the Siberian continental shelf and thus belong to Russia. At issue are scientific projections that the ice cap will recede because of global warming, opening the Artic Ocean to offshore oil drilling. Canada and Denmark also claim the Lomonosov Ridge.

title: A New Kicker for the Giants Tries to Settle In
description: ALBANY, Aug. 1  Training camp separates players from their families, purposely cutting away the distractions of home to focus on the team. None of the Giants know this feeling as acutely as Lawrence Tynes.

title: Safety Violations Cited for Deaths in Subway Work
description: The deaths of two subway workers in April resulted primarily from flawed safety procedures and a lax organizational culture in which track workers and supervisors flouted basic safety rules and failed to alert operators of oncoming trains to the presence of workers on the tracks, according to reports released yesterday by New York City Transit.

title: A Heckler Dresses Up as Bonds
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 1  A group of hecklers stood outside the visiting clubhouse at Dodger Stadium on Tuesday night, waiting for Barry Bonds.

title: On a Home Network, the Right Drive Means Storage for All
description: It does not take much effort these days to accumulate several hundred gigabytes of data. A few hundred songs, a couple of vacations worth of photos, a dozen movies and television programs  and suddenly the 80 gigabyte hard drive in the notebook computer is straining.

title: Whoopi Goldberg Joins The View
description: Rosie ODonnells name wasnt mentioned on The View Wednesday morning. But a few moments after Barbara Walters introduced Whoopi Goldberg to a live television audience as the shows new moderator, replacing Ms. ODonnell, Ms. Goldberg left no doubt that a new era was dawning.

title: Getting One for the Price of One
description: This week, Rudy Giuliani is focusing on health issues, attacking Democrats plans to get the government more involved in covering the cost of medical care. In a campaign tour of New Hampshire town meetings, he used the word socialism so often that it crowded out the old nonterror-related record-holder, Ronald Reagan. Other frequently repeated nouns were choice (good) and France (bad).

title: Engineers See Dangers in Aging Infrastructure
description: A steam pipe explodes near Grand Central Terminal, a levee fails and floods New Orleans, a bridge collapses in Minneapolis.

title: A Queer Lion Comes to Venice
description: After four years of negotiations, the Venice Film Festival plans to award a Queer Lion. A spinoff from the events principal prize, the Golden Lion, the Queer Lion will be awarded to the best film in competition or in any festival sidebar that features a gay theme or character, Reuters reported. The Berlin Film Festival has been awarding a similar prize, the Teddy, a play on its Golden Bear, for the last 21 years.

title: Belly Up, My Man. We Need to Talk.
description: Anyone who watched the British Open this month had to notice Sergio Garcias new belly putter  an extra-long putter that stays anchored in the belly during the stroke. It helps keep the hands from shaking. In other words, its a putter for total wusses. Just ask Garcias colleague Ernie Els, who once said: Nerves and the skill of putting are part of the game. Take a tablet if you cant handle it.

title: Queens: Trade School Owners Charged
description: The owners of a Jackson Heights trade school were charged yesterday with giving students the answers to tests for state asbestos-removal certificates and with allowing illegal immigrants to use false information to apply for the certificates, prosecutors said yesterday. The owners, Juan Herrera, 61, and Julia Herrera, 49, both of Clifton, N.J., were charged in Criminal Court on Tuesday night with falsifying business records and tampering with government records, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said detectives who went undercover as students at the Herreras school, Senagryph Training Facilities, were told to use fake Social Security numbers on certificate applications and given answers to questions on the certifying exam. Mr. Brown said the lapses allowed illegal immigrants to gain access to high-security work sites, including bridges, tunnels and airports.

title: Gonzales Offers a Defense to Senate Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1  Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales offered a narrowly drawn defense of his recent Congressional testimony on Wednesday, saying he had been truthful in denying that there had been serious disagreements within the Bush administration about the National Security Agencys program of wiretapping without warrants.

title: And the Band Stayed On
description: Fairfax, Va.

title: Elle Has a Little Work Done
description: THE most glamorous thing about the offices of Elle magazine is that they have an excellent view of Cond Nast, eight blocks to the south, where Vogue and GQ and Vanity Fair exist in movie-set-worthy splendor and Town Cars idle in perpetuity. Roberta Myers, the editor of Elle, wears Prada, but she takes the subway to work.

title: In a Spotlight, This Village Barely Noticed
description: PORT CLYDE, Me., Aug. 1  The annual sale of fisherman dolls went on here Wednesday morning without a hitch at 10 oclock, villagers popped into the general store for groceries and iced tea, and kayakers set out for the water.

title: Police Announce Breakup of Extensive Car-Theft Ring
description: WEST TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 1  It was a far-flung, multimillion-dollar luxury auto theft and fencing ring, the police said, the largest New Jersey had ever seen. A gleaming new Mercedes-Benz or BMW, sitting in the Port of Newark and destined for a driveway in the suburbs, would be stolen, stuck in a container, shipped across the ocean and sold  at up to double the retail price  on the streets of faraway cities like Cairo.

title: Arbitrator Awards Avery a Raise, Keeping Him a Ranger
description: Rangers forward Sean Avery finished last season believing he had found a home in New York, and thanks to an arbitrators ruling, he will live in it for another year.

title: Jamaica Bay Loses Marshes at Faster Rate, Report Says
description: The saltwater marsh islands of Jamaica Bay  crucial habitat for dozens of species of fish and birds  are vanishing at a rate far faster than previously thought and could disappear within five years, according to a report scheduled to be released today.

title: Updating Newport, Ever So Gently
description: Newport, R.I.

title: After Torrid July, Matsui Is Also Nearing Milestone
description: Hideki Matsui wears ice packs on his knees after most games. Is there something seriously wrong? No, no, its not that bad, Matsui, speaking through an interpreter, said with a smile. Im just getting old.

title: Shaky at the Start, Prez Settles in to Strike Out 11
description: MILWAUKEE, Aug. 1  The Mets needed six relievers to plow through Tuesdays mess of a loss, and the last thing Manager Willie Randolph wanted to see up on the scoreboard in the second inning Wednesday night was a big 5 beside the word Brewers. The number was not too far from where Prince Fielders majestic home run landed an inning earlier, and Oliver Prez was in danger of losing his grasp on the evening.

title: And Now, Folks, Behold the 15-Minute Publisher
description: In the Middle Ages, a book was a big production. It might take a year for a monk to copy a manuscript, which is Latin for written by hand, onto a specially prepared calf, sheep or goat skin and then to decorate it with silver or gold.

title: Whats My House Worth? And Now?
description: THE value of my house fluctuates more often  and for even more mysterious reasons  than my weight these days.

title: In Mexico, Rebel Politician Courts the Law-and-Order Vote
description: TIJUANA, Mexico, Aug. 1  As politicians go, Jorge Hank Rhon, the former mayor of this teeming border town, is more colorful than most. He built his fortune with a network of betting parlors, and he keeps a private zoo of thousands of animals, including leopards, lions and a parrot in his office whose screeches make it difficult to carry on a conversation.

title: West Bank: Israel Starts Razing Wall Near Hebron
description: Israel began dismantling a low concrete barrier that ran for 25 miles along roads south of Hebron. Israel had claimed that the barrier, though just 32 inches high, was intended to provide additional security for Jewish settlers, but in February 2006 the High Court accepted the contention of the Association for Civil Rights in Israel that the wall violated the rights of Palestinian residents in 21 rural communities and prevented farmers from crossing the roads with their herds of livestock. The court gave Israel six months to remove the barrier. When it failed to do so, the civil rights group sought to have the state held in contempt of court. Last week, the court ordered the walls destruction within two weeks.

title: Tip of the Week: Open-Source Computer Programs
description: TIP OF THE WEEK: Software like Adobe Photoshop and Microsofts Office suite are industry standards  and expensive. If youre on a budget and not afraid of working without telephone support, consider open-source software. Developed by programmers all pitching in  and available to download free  open-source programs let you create files in standard formats at a price that is hard to beat. For image editing, theres the GIMP at http://gimp.org/. The software suite at OpenOffice.org offers a word processor, a spreadsheet program and more. Both have versions available for Windows, Linux and Mac OS X.

title: Lazard Posts 2.2% Profit Decline
description: Lazard, the investment bank run by Bruce Wasserstein, said yesterday that its second-quarter profit dropped 2.2 percent from the period a year ago, as its asset management business continued to grow while its mergers and acquisitions advisory work dipped slightly.

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: City Councilman Accused of Rape Tells a Grand Jury That He Is Innocent
description: Councilman Dennis P. Gallagher appeared before a Queens grand jury investigating rape allegations against him yesterday and asserted his innocence, telling the panel that a sexual encounter with his accuser was consensual, his lawyer said.

title: Latest Cronenberg Film to Open London Festival
description: A David Cronenberg thriller set in London is scheduled to open the London Film Festival on Oct. 17. The film, Eastern Promises, reuniting Mr. Cronenberg with Viggo Mortensen, right, the star of his History of Violence, centers on a mysterious, ruthless man tied to a Russian organized-crime family who crosses paths with an innocent midwife (Naomi Watts) who is trying to right a wrong she has accidentally uncovered. The screenplay was written by Steven Knight (Dirty Pretty Things).

title: Whats on Tonight
description: 7 P.M. (Cinemax) TWO HANDS In 1964, at the age of 36 and at the height of his career, the pianist Leon Fleisher, above, inexplicably lost the use of two fingers on his right hand. He didnt regain it for some 30 years. This documentary from Nathaniel Kahn (My Architect) tells the story of Mr. Fleishers struggle, and of his rebirth as a two-handed performer. There was a lot of despair and misery and unhappiness, but there were commensurate ecstasies, he says in the film, adding that you cant really expect to have one without the other. Two Hands is the second film in Cinemaxs presentation of this years Oscar-nominated short documentaries.

title: And Heres to You Mr. Robinson, My Friend
description: Son. Thats what Bill Robinson called Darryl Strawberry. Not Darryl or Straw or any street variations. Son. On days when Darryl wasnt quite ready to play, Bill would materialize in front of Darryls locker, using that deep, melodious voice.

title: Senate May End an Era of Cloakroom Anonymity
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1  Nowhere in the ponderous rules of the United States Senate is there any reference to the Mae West hold, the chokehold or the rotating hold.

title: Obama Calls for Military Shift in U.S. Focus on Terrorism
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1  Senator Barack Obama said Wednesday that the United States should shift its military focus away from the Iraq war to a broader fight against Islamic extremism, vowing to dispatch American forces to eradicate terrorist camps in Pakistan if that nation failed to take such action.

title: Content Makers Are Accused of Exaggerating Copyright
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1  An association of computer and communication companies, including Google, Microsoft and Yahoo, on Wednesday accused several professional sports leagues, book publishers and other media companies of misleading and threatening consumers with overstated copyright warnings.

title: Birds of a Feather, Obese Together (3 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: One Woman, 11 Adoptions and a Time of Urgency
description: Judith Leekin, who was charged by Florida prosecutors yesterday with abusing 11 children she had adopted from New York City, has been described by the authorities as a devious swindler adept at gaming the child welfare bureaucracy.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: August 1, 2007

title: Brooklyn: Park Restoration Planned
description: City officials announced plans yesterday for a $40 million restoration of Dreier-Offerman Park in Bensonhurst. The 77-acre park, which overlooks Gravesend Bay, was acquired through a series of donations and purchases, starting with a gift of land from the Dreier-Offerman Home for Unwed Mothers in 1933.
