Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said the development project called for the construction of three baseball fields, six soccer fields, kayak launches, nature trails, a playground and a recreation center. The work, scheduled for completion in 2011, is part of an effort to ensure that every New Yorker lives within a 10-minute walk of a park or open space, the mayor said.

title:
Over-
Equipped on the Links?
description: Jason Fagone argues in todays newsletter that golfers who use the new, weird putters strip the game of one of its inherent challenges. Take it a step further: Has modern equipment altered the game for better, or worse, and why?

title: Once Shunned, Freestylers to Meet Rivals
description: CARSON, Calif., Aug. 1  As the X Games prepared to introduce freestyle motocross in 1999, the sports organizer, Paul Taublieb, received a call from a representative of a motorcycle manufacturer. He wanted to know if there was any way to stop the sport from being added.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,645 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:

title: Senate Approves Tighter Rules on Ethics and Lobbying
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2  The Senate gave final approval today to a sweeping package of new ethics and lobbying rules, with an overwhelming majority of Republicans and Democrats agreeing to better police the relationship between lawmakers and lobbyists.

title: Dozens Missing as Minneapolis Search Efforts Are Halted
description: Rescue workers halted their efforts this afternoon to search the waters of the Mississippi River in Minneapolis for dozens of people still missing in the wreckage of a collapsed highway bridge after strong currents blocked their work.

title: Manhattan: Tax Credits for Child Care
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer authorized a city program yesterday that will offer impoverished families tax credits to help offset child care costs. Under the program, part of Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs broad effort to reduce the citys high poverty rates, families earning $30,000 or less who use accredited child care services for children up to age 4 would be eligible for credits worth up to $1,700 per household, city officials said. The program is to cost the city $42 million a year and serve up to 49,000 families.

title: Bridge Collapse in Minneapolis Kills at Least 7
description: An Interstate highway bridge in downtown Minneapolis loaded with rush-hour traffic dropped more than 60 feet into the Mississippi River last night, sending at least 50 vehicles and passengers into the water.

title: Mets Decide to Shift Sosa to the Bullpen
description: MILWAUKEE, Aug. 1  Jorge Sosa, who stabilized the back of the Mets rotation by winning six of his first seven starts, has been shifted to the bullpen as the team readies for the eventual return of Pedro Martnez.

title: House Passes Childrens Health Plan 225-204
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1  Over angry Republican objections, the House on Wednesday passed a sweeping expansion of the Childrens Health Insurance Program, financed with increases in tobacco taxes and cuts in subsidies to private Medicare insurance plans for older Americans.

title: Innovation and a Jolt Jump-Start a Festival
description: On Tuesday night at Avery Fisher Hall, as the immensely gifted young cellist Alisa Weilerstein played the volatile solo part in the New York premiere of Osvaldo Golijovs mesmerizing Azul for cello and orchestra, conducted by the dynamic Louis Langre, it was hard not to pinch yourself and wonder whether this really was the opening concert of the 41st Mostly Mozart Festival.

title: Judge Allows Class-Action Bias Suit Against Novartis
description: A federal judge has ruled that female drug sales workers for Novartis Pharmaceuticals may proceed with a class-action gender discrimination lawsuit against the company.

title: Im Ripping You Off
description: YAMHILL, Ore.

title: Bosnia Plans to Expel Arabs Who Fought in Its War
description: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina  When Fadhil Hamdani first came to Bosnia from Iraq in 1979 he had no idea he would stay so long. But after prolonged studies, marriage to a Bosnian woman, the birth of five children and citizenship, the years turned into decades.

title: Bring It On: Dodgers Beimel Challenges Bonds
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 1  Joe Beimel was about 13 when he waited in the parking lot of Three Rivers Stadium in Pittsburgh to get one of his favorite players to autograph a baseball card. The player signed the rookie card and Beimel saved it in a binder. He still has it. The player was Barry Bonds.

title: A Leg Up on Running Injuries
description: As the rush of fall road-running races nears, one challenge is to reach the starting line without first joining the large majority of runners -- as many as 80 percent -- who suffer a leg injury each year. A review of injury studies about lower-body injuries among runners, published in the current issue of The British Journal of Sports Medicine, provides some explanation for what causes so many injuries. It might not be everything youd expect. Those most likely to be injured, the review found, include people whove been injured before; are too obsessive, running for a year or more without a break; or are men taller than 5-foot-6. (No study in the review looked at the issue of women's height.) Runners with a relatively high body mass appear to somehow avoid foot injury -- perhaps, the authors speculated, because Clydesdales, in general, run less. Surprisingly, some factors didnt contribute to injury risk, including having legs of different length, using alcohol, or running after dark, when people may be more prone to misstep. The one element that was found to prevent running injuries most consistently was increasing mileage gradually, to a maximum of about 40 miles per week.

title: A 13th Top 10 for Prince
description: The latest installment in the Now Thats What I Call Music! franchise held out against Prince and the Hairspray soundtrack to remain the No. 1 album in the country for the second week in a row. No. 25 in the Now franchise has songs by T-Pain, Avril Lavigne, Gwen Stefani, Mims and 16 others, and has sold 149,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan, a 33 percent drop from last week. Hairspray (New Line) moved up two spots on the Billboard chart to No. 2 with 101,000 sales. The new CD from Prince, right, titled Planet Earth (NPG/Columbia), moved 96,000, opening at No. 3. Planet Earth is his 13th album to reach the Top 10; his first was 1999 24 years ago. The Canadian pop-punk band Sum 41 opened at No. 7 with Underclass Hero (Island), and Every Second Counts (Hollywood) by Plain White Ts jumped 11 spots to No. 10 on the strength of that groups No. 1 single, the ballad Hey There Delilah.

title: Martha Stewart Extends Losses
description: Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia, producer of the Martha cooking and home crafts television show, reported a wider second-quarter loss as it redesigned its Web site and its sales at Kmart declined.

title: In Fox News, Giuliani Finds a Friendly Stage
description: Roger Ailes and Rudolph W. Giuliani have been pulling for each other for nearly two decades.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page obituary on July 25 about Albert Ellis, a psychologist who pioneered a straightforward approach to psychotherapy, misstated the period during which he lived with a companion, Janet L. Wolfe, a former executive director of the Albert Ellis Institute in Manhattan. It was 1965 to 2002, not 1966 to 2003. A picture caption with the continuation of the obituary referred incorrectly to the St. Johns University students he was shown lecturing to in a nursing home last December. They were graduate students in school counseling, not psychology. (Go to Article)

title: The Presence of Malice
description: South Hadley, Mass.

title: No Defense These Days for Yankee Offense
description: The Yankees hit five more home runs last night in an 8-1 victory against the Chicago White Sox at Yankee Stadium, but none were by Alex Rodriguez, who leads the majors with 35 but remained stalled at 499 for his career.

title: Luxembourg: Profit Up at Steel Maker
description: Arcelor Mittal, the worlds biggest steel maker, reported a 50 percent increase in second-quarter profit, more than analysts had estimated, after raising prices in Europe and the Americas and accelerating cost savings. Net income climbed to $2.72 billion, or $1.97 a share, the Luxembourg-based company said. That compares with $1.82 billion, or $1.31 a share, based on figures Arcelor Mittal calculated as if it had existed a year earlier. Sales gained 21 percent, to $27.2 billion. Arcelor Mittal said it was ahead of schedule in reaping the cost benefits of its $38.3 billion combination last year.

title: Cigna Profit Slips on Enrollment Decline
description: Cigna said second-quarter profit fell 27 percent because of costs related to a discontinued insurance business. Enrollment in Cignas health plans fell, and the companys shares declined.

title: A Welcome Mat for the Myspace Generation
description: Trying to get your teenager into the gym? You may be in luck. As The Times reports today, some smaller, independent gyms have started wooing teenagers instead of shooing them. In the last year, these centers have fitted themselves with foosball tables and juice bars, and provide classes for teens, and -- of course -- Internet access. The goal: A places to work out and hang out.

title: The China Connection: Globalization and the Narcotics Trade
description: For all its global reach, there is something antiquated about the drug trade. The story of a bag of cocaine peddled in an American suburb, for instance, often begins in the Andes, where Quechua and Aymara Indians have harvested coca for centuries.

title: For Your Inner Math Lover, the Calculator Goes Retro
description: Hewlett-Packard introduced the first hand-held scientific calculator in 1972 and sent the engineers stalwart slide rule the way of the buggy whip. Named the HP-35 because it had 35 keys, the pocket-size device sold 10 times as well as expected in its first year, no small feat considering that it cost $400. The HP-35 was discontinued after three years, but the company has just released a retro version to mark its 35th anniversary.

title: Louisiana: Hospital Executives Testify Before Congress
description: The five major New Orleans private hospitals are going to lose $135 million this year and more than $400 million by the end of 2009, hospital executives told a Congressional committee. Speaking at a hearing of a House Energy and Commerce Subcommittee. The executives attributed the losses to increased costs from the effects of Hurricane Katrina, including increasing insurance and utility rates, an increase in bad debt and in uninsured patients and paying higher salaries to attract and keep doctors and nurses.

title: Sparks Stuck in Transition After Losing Key Players
description: Midway through a sentence about the sudden retirement of the star point guard Chamique Holdsclaw, Michael Cooper quickly excused himself and ran from reporters onto the floor of Madison Square Garden.

title: You See Duct Tape, They See a Moneymaker
description: Its sticky, and many Americans have a roll, just in case, but a number of resourceful entrepreneurs have made duct tape the focus of their businesses.

title: 2 Laptop Bags That Also Hold the Kitchen Sink
description: When you think of Logitech you think of computer accessories  the electronic kind. But next month the company will add the Kinetik line of computer bags: a backpack, shown here, and a briefcase.

title: Lead Paint Prompts Mattel to Recall 967,000 Toys
description: Mattel, the maker of Barbie dolls and Hot Wheels cars, is recalling nearly one million toys in the United States today because the products are covered in lead paint.

title: Florida: Lawyers for Padilla Co-Defendant Rest Their Case
description: Lawyers for a co-defendant of Jose Padilla rested their case, a day after Mr. Padillas lawyers said they would not call defense witnesses. Lawyers for the co-defendant, Adham Amin Hassoun, 45, a Lebanese-born Palestinian, ended after more than a week of testimony. On Tuesday, Anthony Natale, a lawyer for Mr. Padilla, told Judge Marcia G. Cooke of Federal District Court in Miami that his team did not plan witnesses. The men are accused of participating in a North American support cell that prosecutors say provided money, goods and recruits to assist global jihad.

title: Keyboard for Xbox Speeds Typing
description: Sending voice and Webcam picture messages to fellow Xbox 360 players over Microsofts Xbox Live service is a cinch, but tapping out old-fashioned text messages using the 360s onscreen keyboard isnt much fun. A new $30 miniature keyboard called the Chatpad speeds up text entry to let you best even the fastest BlackBerry touch-typists.

title: Novartis Faces Class Action Over Sex Bias
description: A federal judge has ruled that female drug sales workers for Novartis Pharmaceuticals may proceed with a class-action gender discrimination lawsuit against the company.

title: Japan: Land Values Rise
description: Japanese land prices rose 8.6 percent last year, more than nine times faster than in 2005, when a 16-year property slump ended as the countrys economy rebounded. The average land price jumped to 126,000 yen ($1,063) a square meter, the National Tax Agency said. In 2005, land prices rose 0.9 percent. Prices in Tokyo, home to a 10th of Japans population, increased for a third year, surging 17 percent to 570,000 yen a square meter in 2006. Land prices are recovering after dropping by more than half from their peak in 1991. Prices rose or were stable for the first time in 15 years in areas outside the three largest regions  Tokyo, Osaka and Nagoya. The most expensive land nationwide was again in the fifth block of Ginza, a central shopping district in Tokyo, where prices soared by a third, to 24.9 million yen a square meter. That is still about a third less than peak prices in 1991.

title: For Close Relatives, Questions With No Answers
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 2  The couple were having their typical after-work conversation on Wednesday. Sherry Engebretsen, a financial director, told her husband, Ron, that she had had a long day full of meetings. He said that they should talk about it later, when she got home. She said, O.K., Ill see you in a few minutes.

title: Russia Plants Underwater Flag at North Pole
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 2  A pair of Russian submersibles descended more than two miles under the ice cap on Thursday and deposited a Russian flag on the seabed at the North Pole. The dive was a symbolic move to enhance the governments disputed claim to nearly half of the floor of the Arctic Ocean and potential oil or other resources there.

title: Sunni Faction Quits Iraqi Cabinet; Blasts Kill 76 in Capital
description: BAGHDAD, Aug. 1  Iraqs largest Sunni political faction resigned from Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Malikis cabinet on Wednesday, severely weakening the governments credentials as a national unity coalition and setting back hopes of reconciliation.

title: Youth Soccer Group Agrees to Withhold Taxes From Coaches
description: In a case widely watched by youth sports leagues across the country, the Internal Revenue Service has reached an agreement with the Fairfield United Soccer Association that clarifies the employment status of the groups coaches, the associations president said yesterday.

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: Striking Out With Sweet Peas

title: An Incomplete Energy Bill
description: The House will begin debating Friday on a generally useful energy bill that would increase energy efficiency, encourage more responsible oil and gas development on public lands and stimulate investment in cleaner fuels. Yet the bill is incomplete. If it truly hopes to address the problems of global warming and energy independence, three vital issues need to be addressed.

title: Hungry Bears Are Lured by the Well-Stocked Home
description: TAHOE CITY, Calif.  In the 17 years the Hyde family has lived at the edge of a national forest, bears have broken into their garage three times, but nothing prepared them for what they found in July after returning from five days of wilderness camping.

title: Gates Offers Blunt Assessment of Iraqi Progress
description: Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said today that he was discouraged by the departure of the major Sunni Arab bloc from Iraqs coalition government, and noted that the Bush administration may have misjudged the difficulty of achieving reconciliation among Iraqs sectarian factions.

title: Panel Approves China Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1  (Bloomberg News)  The Senate Banking Committee approved legislation Wednesday aimed at forcing the Treasury Department to take a tougher line against China and other countries lawmakers say are keeping their currencies weak to bolster exports.

title: Titters, Snickers and Guffaws, With a British Accent
description: LONDON, Aug. 1   Here are three ideas for sitcoms that even the greenest television producer would shrug off as too stale to fly. So how do they also happen to be the plots for three of the freshest shows in London this summer?

title: Murdoch and Dow Jones Pick 5 to Safeguard Wall St. Journal
description: Five people just signed on for what may be the most thankless task in journalism: making sure that Rupert Murdoch plays fair with his new acquisition, The Wall Street Journal.

title: Education Dept. Criticized for Loans Oversight
description: The federal Department of Education, after months of criticism for lax oversight of the student loan program, still has no system to detect and uncover misconduct by lenders and protect student borrowers, a new government report said yesterday.

title: U.S. Halts Heating Oil Deliveries by Two Companies Accused of Swindling
description: After charges of theft and money-laundering against officials with two major New York City heating oil delivery companies, federal prosecutors announced yesterday that deliveries by their trucks would be halted.

title: An Easy-to-Use HD Digital Recorder (and at a Lower Price)
description: Most cable companies offer high-definition digital TV recorders for a low monthly price, but many people find these devices lacking in features and difficult to program. The new TiVo HD recorder is aimed squarely at that market, offering 20 hours of HD storage (or 180 hours of standard TV), an easy-to-use interface and the ability to record two channels at once.

title: Man Regains Speech After Brain Stimulation
description: A 38-year-old man who spent more than five years in a mute, barely conscious state as a result of a severe head injury is now communicating regularly with family members and recovering his ability to move after having his brain stimulated with pulses of electric current, neuroscientists are reporting.

title: Nature Red in Tooth, Claw and Carapace
description: I HAVE been hand-watering my vegetable garden this summer because we have a drought here in central Maryland. Its painful to see the fields of stunted corn, the skimpy potato plants, the undersized tomatoes with blossom-end rot.

title: Artwork Pulled From Show
description: A video installation by the Singaporean artist Lynn Lu has been withdrawn from the Singapore Art Show after Ms. Lu conceded its close resemblance to the work of an American artist, Jason Mortara.  After the installation was mentioned in an article published in The International Herald Tribune on July 20 (and in The New York Times on July 25) Mr. Mortara wrote to the National Arts Council in Singapore to declare that Ms. Lus work, identified by the title X, above, was a substantively direct copy of a copyrighted piece that he created in 2002 and called Memories Revisited. In it he used ink to write memories from his life on pieces of toilet paper before burning them over a candle. In X Ms. Lu wrote the names of former friends, colleagues and lovers on toilet paper using apple juice so that the names would appear briefly when exposed to the heat of the candle. Mr. Mortara said a coincidence was impossible, because he and Ms. Lu knew each other and they had performed on the same night at a show in San Francisco in 2003. After questioning by Heman Chong, curator of the Singapore show, Ms. Lu said that she had been inspired by Mr. Mortaras work and that she and he had agreed to retitle her installation X (After Memories Revisited by Jason Mortara) and to share the small grant she had received for her work. She said: It had not occurred to me before this that Mr. Mortara would consider X a copyright infringement of his work, as artists often influence each other, but I saw it as a grave insensitivity and carelessness on my part. I apologized to Mr. Mortara for my poor judgment, and suggested crediting him with the new title.

title: Murcer Revisits Emotional Night About Munson
description: It was, to Bobby Murcer, his best and most emotional game.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article last Thursday about a government report that found many more cases of West Nile virus than at the same time a year ago misstated the extent of the viruss spread since it first appeared in the United States in 1999. It has spread to every state but Alaska and Hawaii, not to every state.

title: A Crooner Who Woos With Modesty, Humor and More Than a Little Swing
description: Michael Bubl wants the world to know that just because he is a swinging crooner from the old school, he is not a good little mamas boy looking to please the grown-ups by singing their music. Thats why he called his third studio album Call Me Irresponsible, he joked from the stage of Radio City Music Hall on Tuesday evening.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: O. J. Simpson Blames His Ghost

title: Downtown Diner Is Moving to Wyoming, Lock, Stock and Original Stools
description: La Barge, Wyo., is a small town. It is so small, it does not have its own grocery store. Nor does it have a restaurant  well, one that is open, anyway. Thats all about to change, though, and in big-city style.

title: Foreign Automakers Pass Detroit in Monthly Sales
description: DETROIT, Aug. 1  Detroit auto companies grip on the American automobile market ended in July, when dismal auto sales gave foreign nameplates the lead for the first time ever, sales reports showed Wednesday.

title: Television Adjusts Coverage of Bonds
description: ESPN2, which added San Francisco Giants games Tuesday night and last night to follow Barry Bondss attempt to tie and break Hank Aarons career record of 755 home runs, will also carry tonights Giants-Dodgers game at 10 Eastern.

title: Women Lagging in Birthplace of Golf
description: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, Aug. 1  Up the road from the 18th green at the Old Course, roughly 160 paces as a caddie counts, is a two-story stone building barely big enough to contain the history of womens amateur golf in the British Isles.

title: As Ex-Leader Awaits Sentencing, Hollinger Files for Bankruptcy
description: Hollinger Inc., the Canadian company that Conrad M. Black used to control his newspaper empire, filed for bankruptcy yesterday and said it would explore options for the Sun-Times Media Group while facing payments on debt and shareholder suits.

title: Democrats Plan to Assess Voting State by State
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1  The Democratic Party will announce on Thursday a state-by-state effort to identify potential problems in how elections are administered before the 2008 presidential election.

title: Initiations: Exciting, Mundane or Awful
description: My First Time, an exercise in Web-theater synergy at New World Stages, consists of short monologues about inaugural encounters with sex that together channel all the thrill of a photo album chronicling a trip you didnt take. Where was this vacation? Certainly not on distant white beaches but perhaps somewhere on the outskirts of a midsize American city.

title: Caps on Prices Only Deepen Zimbabweans Misery
description: BULAWAYO, Zimbabwe, July 28  Robert G. Mugabe has ruled over this battered nation, his every wish endorsed by Parliament and enforced by the police and soldiers, for more than 27 years. It appears, however, that not even an unchallenged autocrat can repeal the laws of supply and demand.

title: Design Steps Up in Disasters Wake
description: AFTER Hurricane Katrina destroyed Karen Parkers house on Division Street two summers ago, her first instinct was to leave her storm-ravaged hometown of Biloxi, Miss., behind. But she couldnt bring herself to abandon two generations of extended family there, any more than she could see living indefinitely with her six children in their 10-foot-wide FEMA trailer. So, a few weeks after the storm, Ms. Parker decided to rebuild on her street.

title: 3 Die in Home Near Atlanta; 2 Boys Injured
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 1  Two boys were the only survivors of an attack at a home in a normally peaceful, middle-class suburb northwest of Atlanta that killed a mother and her two teenage daughters, investigators said Wednesday.

title: A Familiar Set Helps to Create a New Cultural Market
description: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates  One of the most popular talent shows to hit Arab television this year has some of the trappings of similar shows in Europe and America: swaggering contestants, big-budget sets, grizzled judges and the chance to become a real star.

title: Judge Rules 3 Can Be Charged With Hate Crimes in Gay Mans Death
description: Three men accused of beating a gay man to death during a robbery attempt can be charged with hate crimes without evidence that they were motivated by hatred for gay men, a judge ruled today.

title: Manhattan: Theater to Close
description: The Actors Playhouse, a 62-year-old Off Broadway theater that has been home to such productions as Funhouse, Torch Song Trilogy and Naked Boys Singing! and actors including Robert De Niro and Lily Tomlin, is closing. The theaters rent, which had doubled in the last six years, was getting too expensive, said Peter Breger, who has operated the playhouse since 1995. Basically, we just couldnt make it, Mr. Breger said yesterday. The Playhouse is the latest in a string of Off Broadway theaters to close in the last few years; others include the Promenade, the Perry Street Theater and the Variety Arts theater. The owner of the property, Duell Management, did not respond to a message seeking comment; Mr. Breger said his understanding was that Duell was in negotiations with people to turn it into something other than a theater.

title: Manhattan: Lawyer Admits Using a Runner
description: A Manhattan lawyer pleaded guilty yesterday in State Supreme Court to obtaining clients in personal injury cases from a go-between and lying to the state Office of Court Administration to hide the arrangement, prosecutors said. The lawyer, David Sheeger, 50, was charged with offering a false instrument for filing by paying the go-between to bribe hospital workers to obtain information about patients who had been treated for accidents, typically car accidents, said Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan district attorney. The go-between, who was paid $500 per case, would contact the patients on behalf of Mr. Sheegers law firm, Mr. Morgenthau said. It is illegal in New York for lawyers to accept referrals from nonlawyers. Mr. Morgenthau said that Mr. Sheeger had obtained 67 cases using a go-between from April to November 2002. After his plea, Mr. Sheeger was disbarred, placed on probation and ordered to forfeit $110,000 obtained through the scheme, prosecutors said.

title: A Study Finds Some States Lagging on Graduation Rates
description: Dozens of states accept any improvement in high school graduation rates as adequate progress, and several set a goal of graduating fewer than 60 percent of their students, according to a study released yesterday by the Education Trust in Washington.

title: Reliving a Week at Magic School, or a Decade of Rock
description: When someone says, everyone is dead and youre next, there is only one thing to do: start the week over. That is exactly what young sorceress-in-training Lilet Blan does in Vanillawares strategy game GrimGrimoire.

title: Sudan Agrees to U.N. Peacekeepers to Complement African Union Force
description: DAKAR, Senegal, Aug. 1  Sudans foreign minister told reporters Wednesday that the government supported the deployment of a United Nations peacekeeping force for Darfur, as authorized by the Security Council, while a number of countries in Africa, Asia and Europe volunteered to send troops to join it.

title: Schoolchildren Struggled to Escape
description: They all said the same thing: It was as if they were suddenly in a movie.

title: Gaza: Israeli Troops Kill 2 in Raid
description: Israeli forces killed two armed Palestinians and wounded several others during an army incursion into northern Gaza. The dead men belonged to the military wings of Hamas and the Democratic Front for the Liberation of Palestine, according to statements from the groups. An army spokeswoman said a rocket-propelled grenade had been fired at soldiers but caused no casualties. Palestinian witnesses said that army bulldozers had razed large areas of farmland in the operation.

title: With Rove Absent, Aide Is Grilled by Senate Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2  The Senate Judiciary Committee grilled a young political aide from the White House today about the firings of nine United States attorneys and voiced disdain for a man who was not there: the aides boss, Karl Rove, President Bushs chief political adviser.

title: Alan M. Pottasch, 79, Dies; Creator of Pepsi Generation
description: Alan M. Pottasch, who became known as the father of the Pepsi Generation for leading the team that devised exuberant commercials in the 1960s and 70s that linked Pepsi-Cola to the likes of skydivers and skateboarders, died Friday in Los Angeles. He was 79 and lived in New Fairfield, Conn.

title: The Side Deal in the Deal for Dow Jones
description: On Sunday night, after months of debate within the Bancroft family about protecting the editorial independence of Dow Jones & Company, the discussion turned to a very different, 11th-hour, question: would Rupert Murdochs News Corporation cover the Bancrofts legal and banker fees?

title: Mom, Im at the Gym Doing Homework (Really!)
description: IT is 5 p.m. on a Tuesday and Victor Cal and Suliman Sharif, both 14, have already taken Overtime Fitness in Mountain View, Calif., by storm. They hopped wildly on the flashing lighted squares of an In the Groove dance pad, rode stationary bikes, shared cellphone pictures, chatted with a personal trainer and played a rousing game of table tennis. The pair, friends since seventh grade, once spent five hours at this airy health club.

title: Allies Urge Republicans to Join YouTube Debate
description: When the two leading Republican presidential candidates started to squirm last week about attending a Sept. 17 YouTube debate, in which the public would ask them questions via video, they faced a surprising backlash from their ideological allies in the blogosphere.

title: Disney Acquires Web Site for Children
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 1  Racing to solidify its dominant position in childrens entertainment on the Internet, the Walt Disney Company said Wednesday that it had acquired a subscription Web site aimed at preteenagers, Club Penguin, in a deal that could total $700 million.

title: Glavine Doesnt Dwell on the One That Got Away
description: MILWAUKEE, Aug. 1  It was past midnight when Tom Glavine met up with his family after Tuesday nights 4-2 loss to the Brewers, and he was the calmest one among them.

title: CNBC Admirers Talk About Their Climb Up the Ladder
description: JUST in case Rupert Murdoch is wondering who watches CNBC  the business network that he plans to compete with this fall when he introduces a competitor, the Fox Business Network  a series of commercials starting today will tell him.

title: Jets Rookie Is Back Playing First Love
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Aug. 1  Jesse Pellot-Rosa was a starting guard on the Virginia Commonwealth basketball team that upset Duke in the first round of the N.C.A.A. tournament in March.

title: Wall Street Continues Its Rebound
description: Stocks staged their second consecutive late-afternoon rally today, recovering even more losses from the sharp sell-off last week.

title: Americas Most Coddled
description: Senator Charles Schumer got partway off the fence this week on the issue of whether the most highly paid Americans  mainly partners at hedge funds and private equity firms  should continue to enjoy a super-low tax rate. Currently, at a typical hedge fund or private equity firm, partners pay a flat tax of 15 percent on most of their mega-earnings. Salaried employees and wage earners  the majority of the work force  face income tax rates as high as 35 percent.

title: Excavating Data  From Ancient Disks
description: Q. I have a boxful of 5.25-inch floppy disks that I used during college in the 1980s, and Id like to extract the information from them. Where can I find a drive that supports these disks?

title: Trenton: Meadowlands Developer Fined
description: EnCap Golf Holdings, a developer that has faltered in its bid to transform garbage dumps in the Meadowlands into homes and an entertainment district, has been fined $1.054 million for allowing methane gas to escape from one of its construction sites, the New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection said yesterday. According to agency documents, the gas was released from the Kingsland Landfill in Lyndhurst, where one of EnCaps construction sites is located. The leaks were detected from October of last year through July 24. Methane gas is typically funneled through underground pipes underneath the landfill. EnCap, which is owned by Cherokee Investment Partners in North Carolina, was also fined for not obtaining permits to operate at the landfill. The company plans to appeal the fine, a spokesman said.

title: South Korea: Exports Surge
description: South Koreas exports grew at the fastest rate in six months in July, as global demand was strong enough to counter the effects of a stronger won. Exports rose 20 percent from a year ago after climbing 15.3 percent in June, the commerce ministry said. Exports climbed to $30.9 billion and imports gained 14.9 percent to $29.4 billion, resulting in a trade surplus of $1.6 billion in July, the ministry said. Mobile-phone exports gained 30.5 percent in the first 20 days of July from the same period last year, the ministry said. Shipments to China, South Koreas largest trading partner, rose an estimated 30.4 percent in the first 20 days of July from a year ago. Exports to the United States gained 24.7 percent, the report showed.

title: Pradas Sassy Sister Knows How to Party
description: CHAMPAGNE was pouring in the afternoon last week for the grand reopening of the Miu Miu store on Prince Street in SoHo, after a brief but total renovation.

title: Go Ahead, Fight With Mother Nature
description: DO you worry that your face sends the wrong message? These days, there are more ways than ever to adjust a look, according to aesthetic physicians, psychologists and makeup artists.

title: A Fall in the Park
description: Daniel Sullivan, the director of the Public Theaters Shakespeare in the Park production of A Midsummer Nights Dream, fell through a trapdoor on the set Monday during a tech rehearsal and was taken to the hospital, where he was treated for four fractured ribs and a collapsed lung, a spokeswoman for the Public said yesterday. He is expected to return to rehearsals in a couple of days, she said, although he is still being treated. It is unclear whether previews would begin on Tuesday as planned.

title: Providers of Child Care May Now Vote on Unionizing
description: The state has given the go-ahead for New York Citys 28,000 home-based child care providers to hold an election on whether to unionize.

title: O. J. Simpson Blames His Ghost
description: O. J. Simpson has distanced himself from the description of the 1994 slaying of his former wife Nicole Brown Simpson and her friend Ronald L. Goldman in his aborted book If I Did It, Reuters reported. In an interview streamed live on Tuesday by the Web site Market News First (www.MN1.com) Mr. Simpson, who was acquitted of criminal charges in the case but found liable for the deaths in a subsequent civil trial, said the book was composed by an unidentified ghostwriter and that he reluctantly assented to a chapter about the night of the crime as told by him only after the publishers agreed to label it hypothetical. Mr. Simpson said he allowed the author to ask him questions, but was otherwise passive in describing the killings. I read what he wrote, and I saw all of these major holes, all of these impossible things, Mr. Simpson said. All of these other parts of the book I would correct, but I told myself, If I correct this, there are going to be people out there that say, Oh, look how accurate this is,  Right? Rights to the book, dropped by HarperCollins after a public outcry, have been awarded to the Goldman family in payment of the multimillion-dollar civil judgment against Mr. Simpson. He criticized them, The Associated Press reported, saying, I find it sort of hypocritical that they talked everybody in America to boycott the book: it was immoral, it was blood money. But now we see it wasnt blood money if they got the money. David Cook, a lawyer for the Goldman family, said: Mr. Simpson himself has placed us in this horrific setting of seeking to liquidate this asset. His comments are beyond redemption.

title: For Buffalo Dreams
description: TEPEES may be available at only one store on Ibiza, but there are plenty of sources in the United States.

title: Elvis Lives On as a Robotic Head, Descended From a Chimpanzee
description: If there is a rash of Elvis sightings later this month, it may be because of the arrival in stores of the WowWee Alive Elvis, an animatronic Elvis bust with infrared eyes and lips that sync to music.

title: In Cold Blood, Re-enacted in Our Time
description: CHESHIRE, Conn.

title: NBCs Formidable Talent
description: With a 90-minute Americas Got Talent, NBC once again proved unbeatable in the ratings on Tuesday. According to Nielsens estimates, 10.7 million viewers tuned in from 8 to 9:30 p.m. to watch the NBC talent show featuring David Hasselhoff, below, as a judge. Following it at 9:30, the NBC show Singing Bee (9.8 million) held steady from its week-ago ratings to post the nights highest numbers among adults 18 to 49. NBCs Law & Order: Special Victims Unit (7.3 million) also finished first at 10 while tying ABCs Primetime (6 million) in the 18-to-49 set. ABC ranked second for the night in that demographic, but third in total viewers behind CBS, which got a boost from an NCIS rerun at 8 (7.8 million) and Big Brother at 9 (7.1 million). Fox was fourth overall. In the cable-news race for July, MSNBC and CNN fought for second place in the desirable demographic of adults 25 to 54 during prime time. While Fox News remained entrenched in first place (318,000), MSNBC improved 35 percent from its year-ago levels to draw 191,000 viewers, finishing just short of second-place CNN (213,000).

title: Room to Improve
description: Q. How can I enliven an empty stairwell?

title: If There Must Be Change
description: JOHN PEIXINHO described Newport style as having a certain well-worn comfort and a reverence for the past; also, mildew is an issue. That might explain all the slipcovers. Here are some objects he coaxed into Newports old houses and clubs:

title: Top Seeds Win Team Event at Nashville Championships
description: The 64-board final of the premier event, the Spingold Knockout Teams, at the American Contract Bridge Leagues Summer North American Bridge Championships took place in Nashville on Sunday. The No. 1 seeds and defending champions, Nick Nickell of New York; Bob Hamman and Hemant Lall of Dallas; Jeff Meckstroth of Tampa, Fla.; Eric Rodwell of Clearwater Beach, Fla.; and Paul Soloway of Mill Creek, Wash., defeated Andrei Gromov and Aleksander Dubinin from Russia, and Cezary Balicki and Adam Zmudzinski from Poland, by 120 international match points to 55. At halftime Nickell led by only 3 imps, but the second half was a rout. Nickell conceded only one swing of greater than 5 imps on any board, and to hold world-class opponents to fewer than 1 imp per board is unusual and impressive.

title: Prosecutor Will Weigh Full Inquiry of Governor
description: ALBANY, Aug. 1 District Attorney P. David Soares of Albany County is conducting a preliminary review to determine whether his office should investigate Gov. Eliot Spitzer and his staff, Mr. Soares said on Wednesday.

title: Contractor Calls Shooting of Two Men Self-Defense
description: One man was killed and another wounded after being shot in Queens late Tuesday by a contractor who told investigators that the men had demanded $20,000 from him and threatened to harm his wife, law enforcement officials said.

title: A Wide Range of Sounds, From Antillean to Zouk
description: It has been more than a decade between New York City shows for Kassav, the band from Martinique and Guadeloupe that has brought French Antillean music to an international audience since the 1980s and regularly sells out large theaters in Europe. On Tuesday night, with a sold-out audience at S.O.B.s, Kassav had obviously not been forgotten. Audience members shouted along on nearly every song, singing not only the words but also the zigzagging horn-section lines. And Kassav has had so many hits it had to pack them into medleys.

title: When a Mayor Plays Just Another Straphanger
description: Fred Siegel keeps a vivid memory of encountering a certain mayor on the subway.

title: Baseball Gets Into Resale of Tickets
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 1  Major League Baseball once frowned on scalping, the resale of tickets among fans and sidewalk entrepreneurs. On Thursday, professional baseball will announce plans to get into the business.

title: A Last-Minute Rally Saves the Day, if Not the Week
description: They bobbed and weaved. Then, seemingly out of nowhere, they surged.

title: Iran Hangs 9 Convicts, 7 Publicly, in a Crackdown on Thugs
description: TEHRAN, Aug. 1  Iran held a public hanging on Wednesday in Mashad, in the northeast, of seven men convicted of rape, the ISNA student news agency reported. Two other men were hanged Wednesday in a prison in Zahedan, in the southeast, convicted of armed smuggling of narcotics, the news agency reported.

title: A New Tribe of Tepee Dwellers
description: IBIZA, Spain

title: Panel Queries Rumsfeld on Tillman Battle Death
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1  With Donald H. Rumsfeld seated at the witness table, the chairman of a House committee investigating the bungled aftermath of the friendly fire death of Cpl. Pat Tillman told a packed Capitol Hill hearing room Wednesday that the time had come for some answers. What did Mr. Rumsfeld and other top Defense Department officials know about Corporal Tillmans accidental killing by American forces, he asked, and when did they know it?

title: Spitzer Vetoes Bill on Training Aid Recipients
description: ALBANY, Aug. 1  Gov. Eliot Spitzer vetoed legislation late Wednesday night that would have required social service agencies to train welfare recipients for better-paying jobs and train women for work in construction, computer sciences and other jobs traditionally held by men.

title: World Bank Agency Finds Its Africa Projects Are Lagging
description: At a time when the International Finance Corporation, the World Bank Groups private-sector arm, is in the midst of a major expansion of its investments in sub-Saharan Africa, an internal evaluation released yesterday found that its projects there over the past decade had performed below average compared with those in other regions.

title: I Am Not a Crab: When Wrinkles Lie
description: ARLENE MILLER of Newton, Mass., was aware that her face had changed as she aged. But she had no idea how striking her expression had become to others until a trip to the grocery store several years ago.

title: California Struggles to End Budget Deadlock
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 1  California lawmakers scrambled Wednesday to end a deadlock over the states overdue budget, as $1 billion in payments to hospitals, nursing homes, colleges and dozens of state suppliers ground to a halt.

title: MasterCard Meets Most Estimates
description: Shares of MasterCard Inc., the second-biggest credit card company after Visa, dropped the most since last years initial public offering after the company reported earnings that fell short of the most optimistic analyst estimates.

title: In Prison Call, Inmate Feared New Action in a Cold Case
description: Through a telephone at the Attica state prison, a feared figure of Russian organized crime learned last year about movement in a murder case 14 years cold.

title: When Frank Lloyd Wright Scandalized Chicago
description: Unlike most writers of historical fiction Nancy Horan has not had to inflame the passions of real people in order to create a transporting drama. If anything, she has had to tamp down the truth behind Loving Frank, a novel about the most fearsome chapter in the wildly eventful life of Frank Lloyd Wright.

title: Getty Agrees to Return 40 Antiquities to Italy
description: ROME, Aug. 1  After long negotiations, the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles has agreed to hand over 40 objects from its antiquities collection that Italy contends were looted from its soil, the two sides said on Wednesday.

title: Despite Deadlines Long Past, States Budget Battles Drag On
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 1  Five states missed their July 1 deadline to pass new budgets, and on Wednesday, three of them  California, Illinois and Wisconsin  entered the second month of the fiscal year without one.

title: Sub-Saharan Africa: A Less Encouraging View (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Get Your Free Net Phone Calls Here
description: The price of home phone service has dropped 30 percent since 1999. Surely, say the analysts, that trend line will eventually plummet all the way to zero. Surely, thanks to the Internets ability to carry your voice, landline phone calls will soon be free.

title: Saudi Arabia Says It May Meet Israel
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 1  Saudi Arabias foreign minister said Wednesday that his country would consider attending President Bushs planned Israeli-Palestinian peace conference in the fall, which would put Saudi officials publicly at the same table as their Israeli counterparts for the first time since 1991.

title: House to Leave Fuel Efficiency Out of Debate on Energy Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1  The House of Representatives will open debate on a complex package of energy legislation on Friday, but strict new auto mileage standards will not be part of the discussion, Congressional leaders said Wednesday evening.

title: Marvin Zindler, 85, Crusader in Whorehouse in Texas Case, Is Dead
description: HOUSTON, July 30  Marvin Zindler, an antic and a populist television crusader here who became known nationally when he had the best little whorehouse in Texas closed on corruption grounds, died here on Sunday. He was 85.

title: System Used to Monitor Foreigners Is Vulnerable, Report Says
description: The computer system used by the Homeland Security Department to monitor foreigners entering the United States is extremely vulnerable to manipulation by unauthorized users, compromising the governments ability to intercept terrorists, a new report by Congressional investigators concluded. The report by the Government Accountability Office warns that someone could easily erase, modify, copy or simply gain access to records of millions of travelers. The computer system, which is set up at 285 air, sea and land ports nationwide, has cost the government $1.7 billion since 2002.

title: Just What Is Victory in Iraq? (6 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Japan: Polls Indicate Public Wants Abe to Go
description: More Japanese want Prime Minister Shinzo Abe to resign than support his decision not to quit after his governing Liberal Democratic Partys drubbing in Sundays election in the upper house of Parliament, according to polls conducted Monday and Tuesday by three major news organizations. In polls in the nations two largest newspapers, Yomiuri and Asahi, 45 percent and 47 percent, respectively, said Mr. Abe should step down; 44 percent and 40 percent said he should remain. In a poll by Kyodo, the largest news service, 50 percent said Mr. Abe should resign, while 44 percent backed him. Yomiuri said its poll was a telephone survey of 1,725 eligible voters. Asahis, also a telephone survey, included 1,094 voters. Kyodo did not state its sample size.

title: Back Up iTunes Your Way
description: Q. The iTunes program has an option to back up the library to CD or DVD. How can I back it up to a U.S.B. flash drive?

title: Manhattan: Man Held in Hotel Robberies
description: A 22-year-old man was in custody in Massachusetts late yesterday in connection with robberies at two Manhattan hotels, the police said. Detective Kevin Czartoryski, a New York police spokesman, said the man, Ermal Qoshja of Revere, Mass., was being held by Massachusetts State Police, who had acted on information from detectives in New York. Mr. Qoshja had not been charged yesterday evening, he said. The police said Mr. Qoshja was located after he used a cellphone taken in one of the hotel robberies. In the first, on April 13, a couple and their 9-year-old daughter were held at gunpoint and robbed in their room at the Millenium Hilton downtown. In the second, on May 31, a woman was struck in the face with a pistol and robbed in her room at the Roosevelt, and another man was struck when he tried to prevent the assailant from fleeing.

title: Russia Threatens Cut in Belarus Gas Supply
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 1  In the latest of Russias many disputes over energy payments with neighboring countries, the natural gas monopoly Gazprom warned Wednesday that it would reduce supplies to Belarus by 10 a.m. local time on Friday unless the former Soviet state pays an outstanding gas bill of $456 million.

title: Bodies of 4 Kidnapped Afghan Judges Are Found
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Aug. 1  The bodies of four Afghan judges, who were kidnapped 10 days ago, were found Wednesday in a mountainous area of Ghazni Province, the province where 21 South Korean hostages are being held by people suspected of being Taliban members, officials said Wednesday.

title: Patriarch Teoctist, 92, Romanian Who Held Out Hand to John Paul II, Dies
description: Patriarch Teoctist, who as head of the Romanian Orthodox Church helped begin healing the thousand-year schism between Christianitys Eastern and Western churches when he invited Pope John Paul II to Romania in 1999, died in Bucharest on Monday. He was 92.

title: With Left-Hander on the Mound, Damon Finds Himself on the Bench
description: When Johnny Damon arrived at Yankee Stadium for last nights game against the Chicago White Sox, he saw his name was not in the starting lineup and he was not happy.

title: Illinois: City Not Responsible in Porch Collapse, Court Finds
description: The City of Chicago is not legally responsible for the 13 deaths and dozens of injuries in a porch collapse in 2003, the Illinois Appellate Court ruled. Victims and family members had sued the city in 38 suits. They said city inspectors had failed to act despite knowing that the porch, built without a permit and not complying with codes, was unsafe. The court said the city was not responsible for injuries on private property not in compliance with codes.

title: Iraq Snapshots Give 2 Views
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1  July ended with a monthly death toll for American troops in Iraq that was the lowest this year. Then August dawned with car bombs in Baghdad that killed scores of Iraqis.

title: British Police Criticized in Shooting After Terror Attack
description: LONDON, Aug. 2  The London police misinformed the British public about the identity of an innocent man shot dead by the police at a subway station the day after an attempted terror attack in London in 2005, an investigation by a police watchdog group concluded today.

title: Doctor Recounts Imprisonment in Libya
description: SOFIA, Bulgaria, Aug. 1   In the yard of the Bulgarian presidential residence, on the foothills of Vitosha Mountain, Ashraf al-Hazouz on Tuesday recounted his years of imprisonment and torture in Libya and aired his grievances: the beatings, the electrical charges all over his body, the injection that he was told carried the virus that causes AIDS.

title: Surviving Without Subsidies
description: OHINEWAI, New Zealand  Watching grass grow is supposed to be dull. But watching it grow with a dairy farmer like Malcolm Lumsden is anything but.

title: Notes About Competition
description: If we were in any other business, a risky takeover of a powerful competitor might lead to celebration. Not in our business. Good journalism, which is an essential part of American democracy, thrives on competition.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page obituary on July 25 about Albert Ellis, a psychologist who pioneered a straightforward approach to psychotherapy, misstated the period during which he lived with a companion, Janet L. Wolfe, a former executive director of the Albert Ellis Institute in Manhattan. It was 1965 to 2002, not 1966 to 2003. A picture caption with the continuation of the obituary referred incorrectly to the St. Johns University students he was shown lecturing to in a nursing home last December. They were graduate students in school counseling, not psychology.

title: Home & Garden Calendar
description: A Japanese Garden

title: Your Cheatin Listenin Ways
description: JANICE RASPEN, a librarian at an elementary school in Fredericksburg, Va., came clean with her book club a couple years ago. They were discussing A Fine Balance, a novel set in India in the 1970s by Rohinton Mistry and an Oprahs Book Club pick, when she told the group  all fellow teachers  that rather than read the book, she had listened to an audio version.

title: Charles Simic, Surrealist With Dark View, Is Named Poet Laureate
description: Charles Simic, a writer who juxtaposes dark imagery with ironic humor, is to be named the countrys 15th poet laureate by the Librarian of Congress today.

title: Bridge Collapse: Day 1
description: The entire span of a bridge in Minneapolis collapsed Wednesday, sending at least 50 cars and passengers into the Mississippi River.

title: Bridge Collapses in Minneapolis
description: An Interstate highway bridge in downtown Minneapolis loaded with rush-hour traffic dropped more than 60 feet into the Mississippi River Wednesday night, sending at least 50 vehicles and passengers into the water and killing at least seven people.

title: Bridge Collapse
description: The entire span of a bridge in Minneapolis collapsed Wednesday, sending at least 50 cars and passengers into the Mississippi River.

title: Tahoe Homeowners' Unwelcome Guests
description: The Lake Tahoe area is experiencing a rise in bear home invasions.

title: The End of Tolerance in Amsterdam
description: For one Amsterdam mayor, the Netherlands' famous tolerance has gone too far. Morrocan-born Ahmed Marcouch is taking the tough cop approach in a rough Amsterdam neighborhood, pushing his fellow immigrants to integrate. But some consider him a traitor.

title: Physical Culture | Gear Test, Locks
description: Brad Quartuccio, editor of Urban Velo, a magazine that focuses on city cycling, tests locks in his day-to-day travels through Pittsburgh.

title: Funny in the Summertime
description: A look at some of the shows that are drawing audiences to London theaters.

title: So you want a romantic French wedding?
description: We all gawk at photos of lavish celebrity weddings in France of high watt couples like Eva Longoria who marched down the aisle with a bouquet of orchid stems at the Church of Sain Germain lAuxerrois to marry Antonio Spurs point guard Tony Parker.

title: Hollinger Files for Bankruptcy
description: Hollinger, the Canadian company that Conrad M. Black used to control his newspaper empire, filed for bankruptcy Wednesday and said it would explore options for the Sun-Times Media Group while facing payments on debt and shareholder suits.

title: As Dow Jones Is Sold, CNBC Launches New Ads
description: Just in case Rupert Murdoch is wondering who watches CNBC  the business network that he plans to compete with this fall when he introduces a competitor, the Fox Business Network  a series of commercials starting Thursday will tell him.

title: Options Backdating Rears Its Head Again
description: The governments investigation of improperly dated stock options, which seemed quiet lately, is back in the headlines. The first chief executive caught up in the inquiry was sentenced Wednesday to five years of probation.

title: Terra Firma Clinches EMI Deal
description: The private equity firm Terra Firma Capital Partners, run by the British financier Guy Hands, said Wednesday it had succeeded in its 2.4 billion pound ($4.9 billion) takeover of the music company EMI Group, garnering the 90 percent of shares needed to let it force out minority shareholders.

title: Banks Said to Have Turned a Deaf Ear to Subprime Risks
description: Investment banks that bundle and sell home mortgages often commissioned reports showing growing risks in subprime loans to less creditworthy borrowers but did not pass on much of the information to credit rating agencies or investors, according to some of those who prepared the reports.

title: Canaan Partners Leads Two Funding Rounds
description: Canaan Partners said it led a $10 million financing for Associated Content, marking the second funding announcement for a community journalism Web site in one week. Canaan, a venture firm based in Menlo Park, Calif., also said it led a $15 million funding round for EzRez Software, which makes online travel-reservation software.

title: Crescent Investors Approve Morgan Stanley Buyout
description: Crescent Real Estate Equities said Wednesday that its shareholders overwhelmingly approved the sale of the company to Morgan Stanley Real Estate. At a morning shareholders meeting, 74 percent of the total shares outstanding voted in favor of the sale for $22.80 a share, Crescent said.

title: Canadian Investment Firm Snags Hotel REIT
description: British Columbia Investment Management has struck a deal worth 1.2 billion Canadian dollars ($1.1 billion) to acquire the Canadian Hotel Income Properties Real Estate Investment Trust, offering 19.10 Canadian dollars per unit.

title: Nasdaq Supports L.S.E. Bid for Italian Rival
description: The Nasdaq Stock Market said late Wednesday that it supports the London Stock Exchanges plans to acquire an Italian rival, Borsa Italiana.

title: Landrys in Talks Over Debt Refinancing
description: Landrys Restaurants says it is negotiating with its bankers to replace $400 million in bond debt with bank debt.

title: Bear Hit by Legal Claim Over Failed Hedge Funds
description: A day after two ailing Bear Stearns hedge funds filed for bankruptcy, the bank was slapped with a legal claim for allegedly misleading investors about the funds exposure to subprime mortgages, a lawyer for an investor said Wednesday.

title: Cadbury Considers a Spinoff Amid Sale Doubts
description: Cadbury Schweppes said Thursday morning it is prepared to spin off its North American soft drinks business if the proposed 7 billion pound ($14 billion) sale is scuppered by turmoil in credit markets. The group made the announcement as it unveiled a fall in first-half profits.

title: Marathon Settles Trading Case
description: Houston-based Marathon Oil, which on Tuesday agreed to buy Western Oil Sands of Canada for about $5.56 billion, will pay a $1 million fine to settle allegations it tried to manipulate oil prices in 2003.

title: Advanced Medical Walks Away from Bausch Bid
description: Advanced Medical Optics on Wednesday withdrew its $4.23 billion unsolicited takeover bid for its rival eye-care company Bausch & Lomb, saying Bausch had put up unrealistic hurdles to a potential deal.

title: Martha Stewart Said to Join GTCR on 2 Deals
description: Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia is joining forces with a private-equity partner GTCR Golder Rauner, to buy food-crafting company Wilton Industries and a paint-by-number specialist, Dimension Holdings, The New York Post reported.

title: V.C. Funding Down, Report Says
description: A new report from Dow Jones VentureOne reveals that venture firms in the United States have raised less capital during the first half of 2007 than in any other six-month period in almost four years.

title: Schering-Plough Plans $2.5 Billion Offering
description: The pharmaceuticals maker Schering-Plough said Thursday it plans to sell 50 million common shares and $2.5 billion in mandatory convertible preferred stock in a public offering.

title: Credit Suisses Profits Rise 48 Percent
description: Credit Suisse said second-quarter net income was up 48 percent from a year ago to 3.189 billion Swiss francs ($2.66 billion), well ahead of expectations, lifted by record earnings from investment banking and wealth management.

title: Some Hedge Funds Slam Doors on Investors
description: Some hedge funds that have suffered losses on investments are closing the gate on clients who want to pull money out, a move that could further undermine confidence in already shaky financial markets. Hedge fund managers argue that by temporarily barring withdrawals, they are essentially protecting investors from themselves, by preventing sales of securities at deeply depressed prices.

title: Barclays Posts Rise in Profit
description: Barclays, the British bank competing to buy ABN Amro, posted a 14 percent increase in first-half net income and said subprime mortgage defaults in the United States will not slow the investment bank this year.

title: NYSE Euronext 2nd Quarter Profits Rise
description: NYSE Euronext reported Thursday a second-quarter profit that more than doubled, getting a boost from record trading on its European stock and derivatives markets.

title: London Theater Journal: British Fear West End Turning Into (Shudder) Broadway
description: LONDON, Aug. 2  Alarm-bell essays have appeared in The Times of London and The Guardian in recent days, warning of the imminent death of the proper play at the hands of the mega-musical. The argument is that bloated facsimiles of song-and-dance movies (Dirty Dancing), jukebox shows (a stage version of Desperately Seeking Susan, with the songs of Blondie, is on the horizon) and flash-filled American imports (Wicked) are becoming so dominant that the day is at hand when the West End will be little more than  oh, the horror, the horror  a British version of Broadway.

title: Why Buyout Firms Wont Walk Away
description: Wall Street underwriters these days are probably wishing that buyout firms would abandon some of their announced leveraged buyouts, rather than force the banks to find financing in troubled markets. But according to The Financial Times Lex column, there are lots of reasons why that wont happen.

title: Baseballs Deal With StubHub: The Benefits of Big
description: Mostly, it seems that when start-ups get acquired by big companies, they lose whatever pluck and speed that made them successful enough to be bought in the first place.

title: The Leaking of the Private Equity Bubble
description: While market conditions have worsened, hedge funds may continue to feel prolonged pain, but private equity probably will not  at least, not for some time. So while firms like Bear Stearns, Sowood Capital and Tudor Investment may see sudden losses in their profits, buyout firms should feel the pain only later on, Breakingviews argues.

title: Tanglewood Festival: I Hear a Symphony (at Last)
description: Lenox, Mass.  Whatever doubts one might harbor about devoting a new-music festival almost entirely to composers born during a three-year period in the 1930s, the quality of the works performed at this years Festival of Contemporary Music has been consistently high. That isnt always a given: most years, memorable peaks are offset by troughs  although given the partisanship of the new-music world, listeners may disagree about which is which.

title: Morning Buzz: Track Worker Deaths; Giuliani and Fox; Florida Abuse Case; and More
description: The deaths of two subway track workers  Marvin Franklin, 55, and Daniel Boggs, 41  in April resulted mainly from flawed safety procedures and a lax organizational culture, in which track workers and supervisors flouted basic safety rules and failed to alert operators of oncoming trains to the presence of workers on the tracks, according to reports released yesterday by New York City Transit. William Neuman describes the reports as a broad indictment of the Metropolitan Transportation Authoritys safety practices.The report on Mr. Franklins death was particularly scathing, asserting that organizational culture was such that critical safety rules were not practiced in day-to-day operations. The workers failed to cover up the electrified third rail or set up warning lights, and a supervisor who had promised to act as a flagman, watching for trains, left his post. Moments later, Mr. Franklin was dragged under a train and killed, and his co-worker was seriously injured after he was pinned between the train and a wall [].

title: Nitrogen and the Rapidly Dwindling Jamaica Bay Marshes
description: Out at Jamaica Bay, just a chip shot away from the runways at Kennedy International Airport, a battle is brewing between environmental groups and the citys Department of Environmental Protection over just what is causing the bays marsh islands  tidal flats covered with marsh grass that are the lifeblood of all kinds of fish and birds  to wash away so fast that they could all be gone in as little as five years.An advisory committee put together by the City Council and the office of the mayor is today releasing a report [pdf] about the alarming rate of marshland loss  twice what it was just a few years ago. The committee, led by Brad Sewell of the Natural Resources Defense Council, said that many factors contribute to the disappearance: changing currents, sea level rise and overdevelopment around the fringes of the bay. (This shows the areas of marsh loss.) But the principal culprit, the committee said, is an excess of nitrogen from four municipal sewage treatment plants that ring the bay.
