title: EUROPE | Italy: Insurers Income Tops Estimates
description: Assicurazioni Generali, Italys largest insurer, reported first-half profit that beat analysts estimates and agreed to sell its Nuova Tirrena unit for 1.25 billion euros ($1.71 billion). Net income advanced to 1.78 billion euros from 1.4 billion euros a year earlier, the company said. Generalis first-half operating result from its Italian life insurance business rose 14 percent, to 979 million euros, as the company made a greater proportion of its premiums from its proprietary sales network. Gross domestic life insurance premiums fell 10 percent, to 8.35 billion euros, as bank sales dropped 34 percent. Generali, based in Trieste, Italy, is considering acquisitions abroad as the Italian life insurance market contracts, and it will use funds from the sale of Nuova Tirrena, a car insurer, to expand internationally.

title: Son of Falsely Convicted Man Seeks More of Award
description: BOSTON, Aug. 3  Lawyers are asking a judge to increase the amount of the award given to Edward Greco, the son of one of four men the government has been ordered to pay $101.8 million for falsely convicting them of a 1965 gangland murder.

title: Man Killed by Gas Fumes After Electricity Is Cut Off
description: MASTIC BEACH, N.Y., Aug. 2  A 19-year-old Long Island man was killed Thursday and seven members of his family were sickened when a gasoline-powered generator they were using because their power had been shut off for nonpayment spewed carbon monoxide fumes into their home, the authorities said.

title: Some Restaurant Chains Still Serve Too Much Trans Fat, Group Says
description: More than a month after the deadline for city restaurants to stop preparing food with artificial trans fat, some fast-food chains are still serving French fries with high amounts of it, a nutrition advocacy group said yesterday.

title: Nugent Is Hoping to Build on Last Seasons Success
description: HEMPSTEAD, N. Y., Aug. 2  The goal posts were 57 yards away, but they were within range for Mike Nugent. During a sultry Thursday morning at Jets practice, Nugent broke the monotony by kicking the ball between the uprights and ending a two-minute drill.

title: Shining Light on Inner Lives to Explore Them on the Stage
description: The duo behind Diquis Tiquis, a company from Costa Rica, makes for an odd pair. At first, Alejandro Tosatti, lanky like a rag doll with gloomy features seemingly etched from an Edward Gorey drawing, appears worlds apart from Sandra Trejos, whose earthy fluidity and mane of dark curls embody voluptuous warmth. Oddly, they fit together like bookends.

title: A Cultured Retreat in the Shadow of the Seven Sisters
description: IN 1933, a radical arts academy opened in a remote valley about 15 miles east of Asheville, N.C. Simply called Black Mountain College, after the town where it was built, the school was founded by John A. Rice, a maverick educator who sought to create a sort of paradise for painting, architecture, sculpture and the liberal arts in the heart of Depression-era Appalachia.

title: At Hussein Grave, Legend Lives as Fury Simmers
description: AWJA, Iraq  The grave site has a forlorn, even jumbled air. There are filigreed inscriptions hailing him as a martyr, as a hero of the insurgency and as the eagle of the Arabs, his favorite sobriquet. But alongside these there is the mundane bric-a-brac of his life  a carved wooden eagle hung with his personal prayer beads, and a gallery of informal photographs, one showing him with a cigar.

title: Creating a Myth With Canvas and Paint
description: Until his death from tuberculosis in 1857, at the age of 44, William Ranney was among the liveliest and most beloved suppliers of homespun imagery of the hazards and romance of the American West. But after the Civil War he fell out of sight as tastes changed and that kind of work was no longer fashionable.

title: A First Step to Save Darfur
description: The United Nations Security Council has at last taken a meaningful step toward stopping the genocide in Sudans Darfur region, authorizing a joint United Nations-African Union peacekeeping force to begin operations this fall. With 26,000 soldiers and police officers, it will be the worlds largest peacekeeping effort.

title: In Cultural Haven, Cubans Need Not Choose Sides
description: MADRID  This is surely not the only city in the world where a handful of Cubans can spend a day together and avoid talking politics. But it is certainly the preferred one for Cuban artists and intellectuals of all political stripes, who find the freedom here that they could never have in Havana and the opportunities that may elude them in Miami, both polarizing cities in the endless debate about Fidel Castro and the nature of exile.

title: Lawyer Seeks Mental Testing of Suspect in J.F.K. Case
description: The lawyer for a former air cargo worker charged in a plot to detonate fuel tanks at Kennedy International Airport asked a federal judge yesterday to allow a psychological examination of the man to determine his intellectual limitations.

title: A Question Recurs: How Safe Is Las Vegas?
description: LAS VEGAS, Aug. 2  The morning after a gunman opened fire inside the New York-New York Hotel-Casino a month ago, Sylvia Cunningham, a tourist from Dallas, received two text messages from her mother urging her to cut short her annual six-day trip to Las Vegas.

title: Senate Passes Childrens Health Bill, 68-31
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2  The Senate defied President Bush on Thursday and passed a bipartisan bill that would provide health insurance for millions of children in low-income families.

title: European Bank Signals September Rate Rise
description: FRANKFURT, Aug. 2  The European Central Bank signaled Thursday that it would raise interest rates in September to curb inflation amid an expanding economy. Its president, Jean-Claude Trichet, also vowed to pay great attention to volatile developments in global financial markets.

title: Russians Plant Flag on the Arctic Seabed
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 2  A Russian expedition descended in a pair of submersible vessels more than two miles under the ice cap on Thursday and deposited a Russian flag on the seabed at the North Pole. The dive was a symbolic move to enhance the governments disputed claim to nearly half of the floor of the Arctic Ocean and potential oil or other resources there.

title: Put Out This Tobacco Bill
description: Washington

title: Where a Literary Couple Catch Their Breath Down the Shore
description: GAY TALESE never learned to swim and only occasionally ventures onto the beach. The wind makes it impossible for him to read the newspaper and, he said, during a recent visit to his second home in Ocean City, N.J., Im not going to sit on the sand swatting flies.

title: A Family Torn Apart by Deception, Betrayal and War
description: Of all the wounds inflicted by modern guerrilla war, the one that leaves perhaps the deepest emotional scars is that of families torn apart by conflicting loyalties, replacing familial love and faith with suspicion and mistrust. In Masked, a powerful play by Ilan Hatsor at the DR2 Theater, three Palestinian brothers are locked in a life-and-death struggle over issues of deception and betrayal.

title: Within Discredited Stem Cell Research, a True Scientific First
description: The world of stem cell research was set reeling two years ago when its most successful practitioner, the Korean scientist Hwang Woo Suk, was found to have fabricated much of his work. But according to a new post-mortem of his research, he did achieve a scientific first, though not the one he claimed.

title: New Rules on Bridge Construction to Begin Soon
description: In October, the federal government will begin enforcing new rules for highway bridge design meant to make new structures more efficient, more reliable, safer and longer lived  and implicitly better than hundreds of thousands of existing spans across the nation.

title: The Profane Before the Sacred
description: With The Ten, David Wain uses the Ten Commandments the way a suicide uses a bridge. Stringing together a series of stone-tablet-based short films  from the gross to the surreal to the certifiably nuts  Mr. Wain, the writer and director of Wet Hot American Summer, repeats his strategy of aiming low and trusting in the higher power of genitalia.

title: House Votes to Ensure Leave for Forces in Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2  The House voted on Thursday to limit how quickly American troops can be sent back to Iraq after serving a rotation there, in the Democrats latest challenge to Bush administration war policy.

title: With Starrett City Deal Nearly Dead, Developer Tries Again
description: Only days before the expiration of his $1.3 billion contract to buy a sprawling Brooklyn housing complex, David Bistricer is throwing the real estate equivalent of a Hail Mary pass.

title: Kandy-Colored Dot-Flake Streamline Maverick
description: Peter Youngs art is a blast from the past that singes the present. His almost-major career, which flourished during the fashionably mythic late 1960s and early 70s, has been drifting just out of reach for decades, a tantalizing medley of dotted, stained, gridded and geometric paintings, rarely seen but not forgotten.

title: Dance Listings
description: DANCE

title: Tales by Baghdad Diarist Are True, Magazine Says
description: In a note online, The New Republic said it had confirmed that all the anecdotes reported by the Baghdad Diarist, an American soldier in Iraq writing under a pseudonym for the magazine, had been investigated and confirmed. Conservatives writing at The Weekly Standard online and elsewhere had questioned whether the cruel incidents recounted by the diarist, Pvt. Scott T. Beauchamp, had occurred. We spoke with five other members of Beauchamps company, and all corroborated Beauchamps anecdotes, as did other sources contacted, the statement said. The one inaccuracy, it said, was that a conversation mocking a disfigured woman turned out to have occurred at Camp Buehring in Kuwait, before the units arrival in Iraq.

title: American Home Mortgage Says It Will Close
description: American Home Mortgage Investment, the troubled mortgage lender based in Melville, N.Y., will close today, making it the latest company to fail this year as loans made to home buyers, some even with solid credit histories, go bad.

title: Nortel Loses $37 Million as Sales Falter
description: The Nortel Networks Corporation, the biggest maker of telecommunications equipment in North America, posted a second-quarter loss of $37 million yesterday on declining sales to phone companies.

title: Comforting Words for a Nerve-Wracked Nation: McGarrett. Five-0.
description: In 1968, one of those awful years for which the term hell in a handbasket was invented, a war-weary, riot-torn nation gave its heart to a cerebral man of action with a passion for law and its elusive partner, order.

title: Congress Is Getting Ready to Debate Energy Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2  This was to have been the year that that Congress finally took meaningful action to address the related problems of energy dependence and global warming. The new Democratic majority vowed to make these issues a top priority, President Bush spoke of ending Americas addiction to imported oil and industry groups promised to do their share to build a cleaner and more efficient future.

title: Judge Backs C.I.A. in Suit on Memoir
description: Valerie Wilson may be the best known former intelligence operative in recent history, but a federal judge in New York ruled Wednesday that she was not allowed to say how long she worked for the Central Intelligence Agency in the memoir she plans to publish this fall.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on July 7 about the popularity of 100-calorie packages of snack foods misstated the annual sales figure for such products. It is $200 million a year, not $20 million. (Go to Article)

title: Survivor Recounts Terrifying Plunge
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Thuy T. Vo, 26, was stopped in traffic midway across the Interstate 35W bridge here on Wednesday evening when it collapsed into the Mississippi River.

title: Evacuees Return After Vast Fires in Canary Islands
description: MADRID, Aug. 2  Residents and officials in Spains Canary Islands on Thursday were surveying the charred aftermath of devastating forest fires that raged across the archipelago in recent days, burning homes and destroying thousands of acres of pine forest that are home to some of the islands unique wildlife.

title: Job Growth in July Is the Slowest in Months
description: The job market lost some of its punch last month as employers added 92,000 jobs  the fewest in five months, the Labor Department said today. In a further sign that hiring has slackened somewhat, the government also reported that the unemployment rate edged up last month to 4.6 percent from 4.5 percent.

title: Unilever to Cut 20,000 Jobs
description: LONDON, Aug. 2  Unilever, the maker of Dove soap, Vaseline cream and Knorr soup, said on Thursday that it plans to cut 20,000 jobs over the next four years to speed up a recovery program aimed at narrowing the gap with Procter & Gamble.

title: Estimate of Missing Is Lowered in Bridge Collapse
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 3  An official estimate of the number of people still missing after the collapse of a highway bridge over the Mississippi River fell sharply today to as few as eight, as divers continued to search the water for more bodies.

title: For Young Earners in Big City, a Gap in Womens Favor
description: Young women in New York and several of the nations other largest cities who work full time have forged ahead of men in wages, according to an analysis of recent census data.

title: Dream Performance Is Canceled
description: The first preview of the Public Theaters Shakespeare in the Park production of A Midsummer Nights Dream, scheduled for Tuesday night at the Delacorte Theater, has been canceled because of the director Daniel Sullivans injuries from an accident on the set this week. The previews will begin on Wednesday.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings
description: CLASSICAL

title: People in the News
description: People

title: The Utopia of Sharing in Oneida, N.Y.
description: THEY wanted to create a heaven on earth. For 33 years they believed theyd succeeded, at a utopian commune infamous for free love.

title: In London, Pirates of the Coliseum, With an Imperial Majesty
description: LONDON, Aug. 2  Whats the connection between Pirates of the Caribbean and 19th-century choreography? Answer: The old ballet called Le Corsaire (corsair = pirate).

title: Stampeding Congress, Again
description: Since the 9/11 terrorist attacks, the Bush administration has repeatedly demonstrated that it does not feel bound by the law or the Constitution when it comes to the war on terror. It cannot even be trusted to properly use the enhanced powers it was legally granted after the attacks.

title: Underground Renaissance Man: Watch the Aesthetic Walls, Please
description: IF youre looking for ways to wax poetic about the New York City subway and the vast planning that went into building it, Ibsen and Shakespeare may not be the first authors who leap to mind, especially as August settles its annual swelter on the tourist-packed platforms. Kafka maybe? Beckett? Dante? De Sade?

title: Never Pick a Fight With a Washing Machine
description: Hot Rod might be called the poor mans Eagle vs. Shark if Eagle vs. Shark were not already the poor mans Napoleon Dynamite. It certainly lacks the conceptual purity and aesthetic integrity of the Jackass movies. In any case poor certainly describes the quality of the filmmaking. Directed by Akiva Schaffer from an improvisation-enhanced script by Pam Brady, Hot Rod is unapologetically, almost proudly crummy looking, as though paying tribute with its sloppy framing and clumsy editing to the goofy, half-baked quality of its heros stunts.

title: Movie Guide and Film Series
description: MOVIES

title: Eye Infections From Solution Continuing to Harm Users
description: More than a fourth of the contact lens users who suffered serious eye infections linked to Advanced Medical Optics recalled Complete MoisturePlus lens cleaner have required corneal transplants, according to an update on the outbreak released yesterday by federal health care authorities.

title: Still Searching, but With Darker Eyes
description: Jaw clenched, brow knotted, body tight as a secret, Matt Damon hurtles through The Bourne Ultimatum like a missile. Hes a man on a mission, our Matt, and so too is his character, Jason Bourne, the near-mystically enhanced superspy who, after losing his memory and all sense of self, has come to realize that he has also lost part of his soul. For Bourne, who rises and rises again in this fantastically kinetic, propulsive film, resurrection is the name of the game, just as it is for franchises. This is the passion of Jason Bourne, with a bullet.

title: Sergei Antonov, 59, Bulgarian Accused in Plot to Kill a Pope, Is Dead
description: Sergei Antonov, a key figure in the so-called Bulgarian connection in the plot to assassinate Pope John Paul II in 1981, was found dead in his apartment in Sofia, Bulgaria, on Wednesday. He was 59.

title: An Old Ski Town Faces the March of the Wine Bar
description: NOT long ago, Mammoth Lakes, Calif., was the kind of place where night life might involve hanging out in the condo-village game room and pumping quarters into the Elvira-Mistress of the Dark pinball machine. Its sleepy assemblage of shingled mini-malls, bait and tackle shops and Alpine-style motels was clustered in a small downtown, and a few cabins and vacation houses were on the outskirts. At 7,800 feet near the Sierra Nevadas eastern edge, it drew visitors mostly for the skiing  Mammoth Mountain averages close to 400 inches of snow a year.

title: For 2 Suspects in Killings, Records of Repeat Offenses
description: WATERBURY, Conn., Aug. 2  One of two men accused of burglarizing the home of a Connecticut woman and killing her and her two daughters told the authorities that he used to steal money and electronics from upscale homes to feed his crystal methamphetamine habit, while the other violated his parole after failing a drug test and once escaped from detention, according to parole files released on Thursday.

title: Sorenstam Gets Helpful Text From Woods
description: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, Aug. 2  Fifteen minutes after Annika Sorenstam teed off in the first round of the Womens British Open, Lorena Ochoa signed off on her six-under-par 67.

title: Marine Is Guilty of Unpremeditated Murder of an Iraqi Man
description: A Marine Corps squad leader was found guilty yesterday of killing an Iraqi man whom he and several other service members abducted last year while searching for an insurgent leader who lived nearby.

title: Is the Dance Over? Citigroup Is Upbeat
description: Charles O. Prince III cannot catch a break.

title: Rice Backs Appointed Palestinian Premier and Mideast Democracy
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank, Aug. 2  Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice, embracing an appointed Palestinian prime minister here in the West Bank, said Thursday that the United States still supported democracy in the Middle East. But she defended the American refusal to recognize the earlier, elected, Hamas-led government.

title: Stocks Fall Sharply Amid Credit Fears
description: Stocks tumbled today on fears that the worsening ills in the mortgage and debt markets could soon take a significant toll on consumers, businesses and the overall economy.

title: Whats in a Name? (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: A Test for Democrats
description: Its been a good Democrats, bad Democrats kind of week. The bill expanding childrens health insurance that just passed in the House makes you want to stand up and cheer. Reports that Senator Charles Schumer opposes plans to close the hedge fund tax loophole make you want to sit down and cry.

title: Ford Moving Closer to Sale of Car Units
description: The Ford Motor Company, which sold its Aston Martin sports car brand in March, would like to be rid of its Land Rover and Jaguar operations by the end of the summer, and Volvo by the time winter arrives.

title: Martnez Stays Cool Under Hot Florida Sun
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., Aug. 2  Pedro Martnez took the mound in a simulated game Thursday morning at Tradition Field expecting to throw about 45 pitches in his bid to return to the Mets this season. He ended up throwing 67 and said the process proved therapeutic.

title: Court Rules Against F.B.I. in Raid on Lawmaker
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3  Representative William Jefferson, the Louisiana Democrat under indictment on corruption charges, won a partial victory in court today as an appellate tribunal ruled that federal agents went too far when they searched his office last year.

title: Fighting Addiction, on a Variety of Fronts
description: ONCE one accepts the premise that addictions are as unique as snowflakes or thumbprints, the addiction confessed by Karen M. Carpenter-Palumbo, commissioner of the New York State Office of Alcoholism and Substance Abuse Services, seems practically legitimate.

title: Growing Pains for a Yearly Tribute to Classic American Cars
description: ROYAL OAK, Mich., Aug. 1  It used to be that the string of suburbs north of Detroit turned the third Saturday of August  and just the third Saturday  into a gas-fired playground for classic car lovers.

title: Whats on Tonight
description: 10 P.M. (CMT) CMT AT SUMMERFEST 2007 In late June more than 890,000 revelers descended on Milwaukee for 11 days for this 40th annual music festival, which calls itself the worlds largest, and CMT was there. This three-night series presents concerts by a trilogy of chart-topping country music artists, starting with the sweet sounds of Sugarland. A performance by Sara Evans will be broadcast at 10 p.m. tomorrow, and one by Big & Rich, above, at 10 p.m. on Sunday.

title: Porto Hussong and Chi
description: Porto Hussong

title: A Queens City Councilman Is Indicted in a Rape Case
description: City Councilman Dennis P. Gallagher has been indicted by a Queens grand jury investigating rape allegations against him, the councilman and his lawyer confirmed yesterday.

title: Spare Times
description: AROUND TOWN

title: Minneapolis Bridge Had Passed Inspections
description: The eight-lane bridge in Minneapolis that collapsed on Wednesday had been diligently inspected for years and had always passed, state officials said yesterday.

title: Teacher Convicted of Abuse of Elementary School Girl
description: SYRACUSE, Aug. 2  In an emotionally charged case that has touched on differences in race, class and religion, a music teacher who regularly let elementary school girls sit on his lap while the class watched movies in a darkened classroom was convicted Thursday of sexually abusing one of them.

title: ASIA | South Korea: U.S. Beef Is Blocked
description: South Korea halted imports of beef from the United States after a shipment from Cargill was found to contain a bone part banned as a precaution against mad cow disease. South Koreas quarantine authority found a piece of the vertebral column of a cow in one of 1,176 boxes from a shipment imported on July 29 weighing 18.7 metric tons, the Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry said. Cargill said it had packaged the beef. A Cargill spokesman, Mark Klein, said the company is investigating the incident and will work with United States and South Korean officials.

title: Homelessness Could Mean Life in Prison for Offender
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 2  A sex offender who was unable to register his address with state officials because he was homeless is facing life in prison for violating a new registry law that politicians in Georgia have hailed as the nations toughest.

title: Israel to Revise Plan for Stipend for Holocaust Survivors
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 3  Trying to forestall an embarrassing protest march by aged survivors of the Holocaust, Israeli Prime Minister Ehud Olmert agreed on Friday to rethink a widely criticized plan to give them a monthly stipend of some $20.

title: Gap Tries a Somewhat Old-Fashioned Campaign
description: GAPS advertisements have nearly always been memorable  but, particularly in recent years, not necessarily for selling pants.

title: Bragging With Brocade in Baroque-Era Tapestries
description: When the Metropolitan Museum of Art presented Tapestry in the Renaissance: Art and Magnificence five years ago, it was the sleeper of the season. Curators had feared it would be too scholarly, too esoteric to attract large audiences. But they were wrong. The show brought in some 215,000 visitors, more than twice the museums estimates.

title: Big Money, Big Houses and Big, Nasty Demons
description: If I Didnt Care, an undernourished little noir set in the Hamptons during the winter, stokes the tempting fantasy that this elite enclave on the southeastern shore of Long Island is the seat of all evil. Where big money settles, souls disappear, devoured by the demons of real estate envy and other cravings.

title: Lottery Numbers
Thaddeus E. Owens, 88, Who Was Judge in Racially Tense Case, Dies
description: Thaddeus E. Owens, the judge best known for presiding over the series of trials stemming from the murder of Yusuf K. Hawkins on a street in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, in 1989  a killing that stoked racial tensions in New York City  died in Brooklyn on July 21. He was 88 and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Mexico: New Allegations of Corrupt Police for Tijuanas Ex-Mayor
description: Jorge Hank Rhon, the fabulously wealthy former mayor of Tijuana, faced new accusations of corruption in his citys police force, just four days before voters are to decide whether he will be the new governor of Baja California. The newspaper Reforma reported that authorities had issued arrest warrants for two of Mr. Hanks former police commanders, alleging the cover-up of a murder by police officers in 2005 and the killing of another police commander in 2006. Mr. Hank, 51, who operates a network of betting parlors, has been running on a promise to clean up crime in the drug-plagued state, while his political opponents have accused him of being involved in crimes ranging from money-laundering to murder. He denies any wrongdoing and has never been charged with a crime.

title: Gay, Worlds Fastest in 07, Keeps on Going Unaided
description: LONDON, Aug. 2  Standing outside a news conference, Tyson Gay was bored. So without looking up, Gay, the fastest man in the world this year, began sprinting down an empty hallway Thursday as if in slow motion. For the next few minutes, he concentrated on the carefully honed movements of his arms, repeating them until they were exactly right.

title: Yankees Tire After Matching an Eight-Run Inning
description: Dozens of reporters surrounded Alex Rodriguez long after a draining game at Yankee Stadium. He had two hits yesterday, although not his 500th home run, and the first question was whether he felt better about his at-bats.

title: London Police Misled Public, Report Says
description: LONDON, Aug. 2  The London police misinformed the British public about an innocent man shot dead by the police at a subway station the day after an attempted terrorist attack in London in 2005, an investigation by a police watchdog group concluded Thursday.

title: Spare Times: For Children
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: In Ways Large and Small, Many Bridges Meet Definition of Deficient
description: More than 2,000 bridges in New York State meet the federal governments definition of structurally deficient, from the heavily traveled on-ramps of the Brooklyn Bridge to a 28-foot span across Trout Brook near the Canadian border.

title: Ahead of Schedule, Adu Shifts Career to Europe
description: Without kicking a ball or breaking a sweat, Freddy Adu said yesterday that his transformation from domestic wunderkind to expatriate soccer player was complete.

title: In Increments, Senate Revisits Immigration Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2  When a broad immigration bill failed in the Senate in June after a vitriolic national debate, many legislators said the issue was dead, perhaps until President Bush left office. But already some of the less contentious pieces of the bill are returning to life.

title: Tough Delay for Big Game by Take-Two
description: Take-Two Interactive, the video game publisher, said yesterday that it was postponing the release of the latest game in its wildly popular Grand Theft Auto series. The delay is likely to have ripple effects on the broader video game industry during its crucial holiday selling season.

title: Life, Assembled One Room at a Time
description: The Portuguese film Colossal Youth was one of the most fascinating competition entries at the 2006 Cannes Film Festival. To judge by the noisy walkouts during its press screening, it was also one of the most disliked  although the truer word might be misunderstood. Beautifully photographed, this elliptical, sometime confounding, often mysterious and wholly beguiling mixture of fiction and nonfiction looks and sounds as if it were made on another planet. And, in some respects, it was.

title: When the Bay of Fundy Swells, a River Roller Coaster Begins
description: THE guide piloted our boat into the roiling rapids and we hit the first wave head-on. The force lifted us skyward and dropped us with a thud. We smacked into the next few waves in this set of rapids and got bucketsful of water in our faces as we shrieked and laughed. Then our guide circled around and we hit the rapids again.

title: $32.5. Million for Undersea Cable to Link 21 Countries
description: The board of the International Finance Corporation, the private-sector arm of the World Bank Group, approved investing up to $32.5 million in an undersea fiber-optic cable project that is designed to connect 21 African countries. The East African Submarine Cable System is to link sub-Saharan Africa to Internet and telecommunications services, giving development a boost. It will run from the southern tip of the continent to the Horn of Africa, connecting South Africa, Mozambique, Madagascar, Tanzania, Kenya, Somalia, Djibouti and Sudan. Construction of the cable is expected to begin in weeks and to be finished by 2009, according to the I.F.C. Thirteen more adjoining countries are to be linked to the system, financed by public and private investors. Total construction costs are estimated to be $235 million.

title: Art in Review
description: GENESIS, IM SORRY

title: Cerberus Completes Deal for Chrysler
description: AUBURN HILLS, Mich., Aug. 3  For almost a decade, people here debated whether Chryslers should still be considered American cars, how to correctly pronounce Daimler and what to make of the man with the German accent and funny mustache running one of Detroits automakers.

title: National Briefing | West | California: Virus Deaths Prompt State of Emergency Declaration
description: Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger declared a state of emergency in three counties where people have died after being infected with the West Nile virus. There have been four deaths in the state attributed to the virus, he said. To try to stop the spread of the disease, which is mosquito-borne, the governor declared a state of emergency in Kern, Colusa and San Joaquin Counties, making financial assistance available to the local vector control districts and directing state agencies to take proactive measures to protect Californians from further spread of the virus. I will continue to ensure our local agencies have whatever resources they need to fight the spread of this disease, Mr. Schwarzenegger said in a statement.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings
description: ART

title: The Police: Sing Along With Sting, One More Time
description: During their exultant encore at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday night, the Police played songs from their first and last albums, released only five years apart. For the few people in the arena who werent singing along, it was a reminder of the actual brevity of this bands reign. And when Sting altered the lyrics to one of the older songs, singing Welcome to the Andy Summers show in a verse of So Lonely, it was a reminder of why ages passed before this reunion tour.

title: Old Course Plays Exactly as Ochoa Imagined It
description: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, Aug. 2  The Old Course at St. Andrews is for the discerning artist, its holes blending together like colors in an Impressionist painting. It takes a creative mind to conquer a layout in which the fairways are not neatly framed by trees and the greens look more like amorphous puddles than elbow patches sewn into the ground.

title: Feeling the Heat, Not Breathing Fire
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 2  The first purchase by the Chinese governments new overseas investment fund, a $3 billion stake in the Blackstone Group, has produced an unusual public reaction within China.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,647 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Iran: 2 More Public Hangings
description: Two men convicted of shooting a judge to death in his car two years ago were publicly hanged from cranes on two pickup trucks in Tehran. The hangings were in front of the courthouse where the judge, Hassan Moghaddass, was killed. The executions took place a day after nine hangings in other parts of Iran.

title: Last Words of Missing Echo as Relatives Wait for News
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 2  The couple were having their typical after-work conversation on Wednesday. Sherry Engebretsen, a financial director, told her husband, Ron, that she had had a long day of meetings. He said that they should talk about it later, when she got home. She said, O.K., Ill see you in a few minutes.

title: The 2010 Economic Doomsday
description: Just about everybody remembers Captain Louis Renault, in Casablanca, declaring, Im shocked, shocked to find that gambling is going on here.

title: Congress Backs Tighter Rules on Lobbying
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2  The Senate gave final approval Thursday to a far-reaching package of new ethics and lobbying rules, with an overwhelming majority of Republicans and Democrats agreeing to improve policing of the relationship between lawmakers and lobbyists.

title: Yankees YES Network Stake Not for Sale
description: Goldman Sachs is evaluating whether possible new investors in the YES Network, the channel of the Yankees, would pay enough to place a value of at least $3 billion on it  about four times what it was worth nearly six years ago when it was formed.

title: Leonard Lief, 83, an Educator and a Lehman College President, Dies
description: Leonard Lief, the first president of Herbert H. Lehman College of the City University of New York, died Monday at his home in New Rochelle, N.Y. He was 83.

title: Jazz Listings
description: JAZZ

title: Zimbabwes Chaos: The Powerful Thrive
description: BULAWAYO, Zimbabwe, July 28  Earlier this month, shortly after Zimbabwes president, Robert G. Mugabe, proposed legislation mandating a gradual transfer of all businesses to what he called indigenous ownership, a Zimbabwean businessman said he received an unexpected telephone call. The caller, a stranger, said that he represented a group of indigenous investors.

title: Belarus Says It Will Pay Russian Gas Debt
description: Belarus said it would pay $460 million it owes Russia for natural gas supplies within days, signaling a possible end to another conflict that has threatened gas deliveries to Europe. Belarus accepted gas rate increases that went into effect in January and it has paid 55 percent of the bill. A Russian threat to cut off gas for Belarus today raised fears that Belarus would siphon gas and that shortages in Europe would result. Aleksandr G. Lukashenko, the Belarussian president, ordered the government to pay, although it was not immediately clear where it would find the money. Gazprom, the Russian gas monopoly, said that there was time for a settlement, although one had not yet been reached yesterday.

title: Strahans Holdout Makes Way for His Opposite
description: ALBANY, Aug. 2  Justin Tuck was expected to ultimately replace Michael Strahan at left defensive end for the Giants. No one imagined that day could arrive so soon.

title: Big Law Firm Embracing Bankruptcy Practice
description: For Richard Levin, the commute to his new law firm from the Upper West Side required only a slight adjustment: simply get off the subway one stop earlier.

title: When the Salsa Throbs, a Singers Soul Is Revealed
description: On the evidence of El Cantante, in which he plays the salsa singer Hctor Lavoe, Marc Anthony is not much of a screen actor. When the character is not in front of an audience, Mr. Anthony seems to recede behind his high, delicate cheekbones and tinted glasses, as the director, Leon Ichaso, buries him in distracting formal gimmicks and camera stunts. For the viewer Mr. Lavoe remains out of reach, an artist whose inner life remains locked inside the actors diffidence.

title: Nuclear Weapons Comment Puts Obama on the Defensive
description: Senator Barack Obama found himself on the defensive again yesterday about his views on foreign policy, this time over a comment he made about the use of nuclear weapons in Afghanistan or Pakistan.

title: Easy Getaways
description: WHO Beverly Parnes, 54, a high school teacher from Ardsley, N.Y., shown with her husband, Jerry, 57, a structural engineer

title: Correction; For the Record
description: A chart on Sunday with a front-page article about universities that charge different tuitions for different majors misstated the undergraduate division at Iowa State University that charges more than other programs. It is the College of Engineering, not the business school.

title: A Landing Pad of the Well-Off, as Busy as Ever
description: EAST HAMPTON, N.Y., July 27  Binoculars in hand, Jim Brundige, manager of the tiny airport here, surveyed the Friday night comings and goings. In one five-minute span, three helicopters landed, a corporate jet took off on Runway 10-28 and a propeller plane taxied to a halt about 30 yards from the terminal.

title: Take-Two Delays Grand Theft Auto IV
description: Take-Two Interactive, the video game publisher, said yesterday that it was postponing the release of the latest game in its popular Grand Theft Auto series, a delay that has implications for the broader video game industry during its crucial holiday selling season.

title: Bringing Serious Muscle to an Already Brawny Beethoven
description: The Grosse Fuge will sound better after a glass of wine, Geoff Nuttall, the St. Lawrence String Quartets gregarious violinist, joked before the ensemble performed Beethovens String Quartet in B-flat (Op. 130) in the Kaplan Penthouse on Wednesday, part of the Mostly Mozart Festivals Little Night Music series.

title: A Poets New Post
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Fully Prepared for Anything
For Young Earners in Big City, Gap Shifts in Womens Favor
description: According to an article in todays New York Times, young women who live in New York and several of the nations other largest cities who work full time have forged ahead of men in wages.

title: Voyage of the Acorn
description: Images of Duke Riley's voyage to intercept the Queen Mary II with his replica of a Revolutionary Era-war submarine in Red Hook, Brooklyn.

title: Jay Leno's 1909 Baker Electric
In Hunt for Programmers, Desperation Sets In
description: See update at the bottom; LinkedIn says it made a mistake.

title: Boston Scientific Reverses on Endosurgery Offering
description: The medical device maker Boston Scientific said Thursday that it had decided against selling a minority stake in its endosurgery group to the public, a move that it had explored to raise as much as $1 billion in cash and help pay off debt from a $27 billion acquisition.

title: Morgan Stanley Settles a Bias Suit
description: Morgan Stanley has agreed to settle a class-action lawsuit that accused it of unfair treatment of black and Latino employees in the retail brokerage division since 2002.

title: Ex-Wall St. Executives Go to Bat to Help Nonprofits
description: An organization founded by two former Goldman Sachs partners is using Wall Street methods to help charities raise money to finance expansion.

title: Big Law Firm Embracing Bankruptcy Practice
description: While other Manhattan firms are building up their bankruptcy departments, Cravath, Swaine & Moore, is just getting into the practice. For the first time in its history (parts of the firm date back to 1819), Cravath is forming a restructuring practice. And it has broken tradition to do so, by hiring a partner from outside the firm.

title: Nortel Is Ready to Make Deals
description: Nortel Networks is in takeover mode, chief executive Mike Zafirovski told Reuters on Thursday, confirming what Wall Street has been saying for a while about the maker of telecommunications equipment.

title: American Home Mortgage Says It Will Close
description: American Home Mortgage Investment, the troubled mortgage lender based in Melville, N.Y., will close Friday, making it the latest company to fail this year as loans made to home buyers, some even with solid credit histories, go bad.

title: Sowoods Fall Hits State Pension Fund Hard
description: The Massachusetts state pension system lost $30 million with this weeks collapse of Sowood Capital Management, the first evidence that public money also went down the drain when the $3 billion Boston hedge fund lost more than half its value in July.

title: MarketWatch Founder Takes Seat at V.C. Table
description: Larry Kramer, former president of CBS Digital Media and founder of the financial Web site MarketWatch, has joined a venture capital firm, Polaris Venture Partners, as a senior adviser.

title: Tedeschi Realty Unloads Shopping Centers
description: Tedeschi Realty, based in Rockland, Mass., on Thursday sold 25 shopping centers, most in the greater Boston area, to Dividend Capital Total Realty Trust of Denver for $377 million.

title: G.E. Spinoff Genpact Rises in Market Opening
description: Shares of a business service provider, Genpact, soared nearly 20 percent Thursday in their market debut, producing a 289 percent partially realized gain on investment for the companys two private equity backers, General Atlantic, and Oak Hill Capital Partners.

title: ABN Amro Chief Goes Back to Court
description: ABN Amros chief executive was back in court Thursday as a group of shareholders who lost a bid to halt the $21 billion sale of the companys United States division kept up their fight. This time, they are pushing for an investigation into alleged mismanagement.

title: Shell Taps $2.4 Billion in 3 Refinery Deals
description: Royal Dutch Shell said Thursday it had agreed to sell three oil refineries in France and stakes in two Norwegian Sea fields worth $2.47 billion (1.8 billion euros).

title: Judge Approves Delphi Investment Plan
description: Delphi took a big step on its road to recovery Thursday when a bankruptcy court agreed to let Appaloosa Management and other investors inject up to $2.55 billion into the struggling auto-parts maker.

title: Will Disneys Penguin Deal Put Rivals on the March?
description: Walt Disneys deal to buy Club Penguin for up to $700 million is causing tremors among the companies that have developed online digital communities, not least because of the price tag.

title: Developer of HIV Drugs Raises $31 Million
description: Tobira Therapeutics, a new company developing a pair of HIV drugs, raised $31 million in a first round of funding led by Domain Associates. Other investors who threw in included Frazier Healthcare Ventures, Montreux Equity Partners, and Canaan Partners.

title: Dells ASAP Deal May Be the First of Many
description: Dells $340 million acquisition of ASAP Software could lead to similar, if smaller deals, by the struggling computer company, analysts told The Deal.com. The company is copying its rivals who are pushing deeper into the services business, which provides higher margins than computers and is in high demand from Dells corporate buyers.

title: Madison Dearborn Chief Builds Team for Cubs Bid
description: As news that a stake in YES Network may be on the block sparked talk Thursday of a possible sale of the Yankees, another auction of a highly-prized baseball team has been heating up.

title: Candover Said to Mull Revision of Stork Bid
description: Britains Candover is considering revising the terms of its 1.5 billion euro ($2.1 billion) offer for Stork, the Dutch industrial conglomerate, after it emerged that Marel, an Icelandic company that opposes the deal, had built a blocking stake, The Financial Times reported.

title: Next Stop for Silicon Valley: Vietnam
description: For Silicon Valley investors, theres new hot spot on Asian horizon: Vietnam. The San Jose Mercury News reports that a tech gathering in the Valley to discuss Asias new roaring tiger drew drew an array of participants, from Google representatives to Ho Chi Minh City start-up executives.

title: Evergreen Executive Out Amid Tepid Performance
description: Evergreen Investments, Wachovias asset management unit, said its chief investment officer was leaving after more than two decades with the firm. The executive, Christopher Conkey, will officially leave the firm, which has $281 billion under management, in a couple of weeks and will be temporarily succeeded by Evergreens chief executive Dennis Ferro.

title: Anglo American Paves Way for Tarmac Sale
description: Anglo American put its Tarmac road-building business up for sale on Friday as it met forecasts with a 22 percent rise in first-half earnings and pledged to return a further $4 billion to shareholders. The chief executive, Cynthia Carroll, said the sale of Britain-based Tarmac, which analysts say could fetch at least $6 billion, was the mining groups last major piece of restructuring as it moves to focus on its metals and minerals businesses.

title: London Theater Journal: How One Really Good Show Can Turn Around a Dour Day
description: LONDON, Aug. 3  I so needed the shot of adrenaline I received last night, and Im grateful to the National Theater for the injection. It had been a gray, viscous day, with the look and feel of an oyster. I had breakfasted over whinging newspaper stories about British ineptitude (the rail service, the underground, the airways), complaints I heard echoed at a lunch party later that day.

title: Yankees YES Network Stake Not for Sale
description: Investors who were licking their lips Thursday on the news that YES Network might be up for sale may be disappointed to learn that only a portion of the Yankees channel is being shopped. The New York Times reported that Goldman Sachs is evaluating whether possible new investors in the YES Network would pay enough to place a value of at least $3 billion on it  about four times what it was worth nearly six years ago when it was formed.

title: Dow Jones Sale Heats Up Presidential Race
description: It was probably only a matter of time before one of the most written-up deals of the summer  Rupert Murdochs $5 billion bid for Dow Jones & Company  entered into the rhetoric of presidential hopefuls.

title: RBS Reports Strong Profits Amid ABN Battle
description: The Royal Bank of Scotland, one of the banks in a takeover battle for ABN Amro, beat analysts expectations with an 11 percent rise in profit and lifted its dividend by 25 percent.

title: Is the Dance Over? Citigroup Is Upbeat
description: Charles O. Prince III cannot catch a break.

title: Blackstones Falling Stock Sparks Anger in China
description: The first purchase by the Chinese governments new overseas investment fund, a $3 billion stake in the Blackstone Group, has produced an unusual public reaction within China, The New York Times reports. Since Blackstone went public on June 22, the companys shares have fallen steeply, pushing down the value of the Chinese governments investment by more than $425 million in just six weeks.

title: Subprime Rattles Germanys Union Investment
description: Union Investment Asset Management, Germanys third-largest mutual fund manager, halted redemptions from a fund holding subprime mortgages after clients withdrew 100 million euros ($137 million) in the last month, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Merrill Move Rocked Bear Stearns Funds
description: A late June move by Merrill Lynch to protect its clients from a struggling hedge fund run by Bear Stearns helped hasten the funds ultimate collapse, Reuters reported Friday.

title: Hedge Funds Feel the Markets Chill
description: Warren E. Buffett once said when the tide goes out, you find out who is naked. There is suddenly a lot of skin showing on Wall Street, writes The New York Times Jenny Anderson.

title: Morning Buzz: A New Look at the Regions Bridges; Young Womens Rising Earnings; a Councilmans Indictment; and More
description: Government officials throughout the New York region responded to the Minnesota bridge disaster on Wednesday night by ordering safety inspections of the regions aging infrastructure. In The Times, Russ Buettner reports that more than 2,100 bridges in New York State have been deemed structurally deficient by the federal government, even though the term has varying definitions. New York City officials said the citys bridges are safe even though three of them  including the Brooklyn Bridge  were rated poor in the citys annual bridge report card last year. Meanwhile, Gov. Eliot Spitzer of New York and Gove. Jon S. Corzine of New Jersey have ordered reviews of bridges in their states.Under the federal rating system, The Daily News reports, the Brooklyn Bridge scored dramatically lower than the bridge in Minneapolis that collapsed. (Perhaps that fact raises even more questions about the rating system than it does about the Brooklyn Bridge.)

Actually, its the best thing weve heard yet from the junior U.S. Senator from Illinois. The editorial adds:

title: The Alaia Chronicles
description: Alex A gets right to the point: How does Azzedine Alaia do it? I think there are several things to keep in mind about Alaia and his method of working.

title: Of Open Wounds and Decent Intervals
description: In the Twin Cities today, a counselor at a day camp for small children may start to lead a circle of youngsters in London Bridge is Falling Down  and then stop short. A movie buff in the public librarys video room may reach for The Bridge on the River Kwai  and then put it back on the shelf. Card players may wonder whether their weekly bridge game really feels right. Conversation in a dental office may stumble over a mention of bridgework, in a surgical supply store over trusses, in a writing workshop over concrete examples, at a poker table over going down to the river.

title: 2008: Republicans Set to Debate
description: On Sunday the Republican presidential candidates will gather for a live ABC News debate from Des Moines, Iowa. The war in Iraq will surely be one of the issues on the agenda, and a Bloomberg News story today notes subtle changes in the way some candidates are talking about the war.

title: Playing the Buffett Buying Game Again
description: We know that Warren E. Buffett is on the prowl for a $40 billion to $60 billion deal. Now that the credit markets have sidelined potential private equity rivals, the Berkshire Hathaway chief may have an even easier go of it, Bloomberg News suggests.

title: As Take-Two Swerves, Funds Take a Hit
description: If you play the activist-investor game, be prepared to get burned. That is the lesson for Oppenheimer Funds, a mutual-fund manager that took the unusual step earlier this year of leading a campaign to take control of Take-Two Interactive, the maker of the wildly popular Grand Theft Auto video game series.

title: Hedge Funds Thank Heaven for Lockups

Under lockup provisions, investors capital cannot be withdrawn for some period, often one to two years. Funds with lockups of two years or longer were exempt from the fund-registration rule.

title: Watch Your Mouth
description: Since the Heysel Stadium riot that killed 39 Juventus fans in Brussels in 1985 and the Hillsborough disaster  that killed 93 soccer fans in 1989, authorities have been evangelical in their efforts to curb hooliganism and end dangerous behavior in stadiums around the world.

title: Whats Fresh in the City Greenmarkets This Weekend
description: The bins at city greenmarkets will overflow this weekend with dozens of varieties of fresh local produce, including fragrant ripe peaches, sweet corn, heirloom tomatoes, apricots, potatoes and eggplants. The first pears of the season have arrived. Artichokes will make an appearance.

title: Revised Rules Coming on Filmmaking and Photography, After Uproar
description: After an outcry from videographers, filmmakers and still photographers  including a satirical rap video and an online protest petition that has gathered more than 20,000 signatures  the Mayors Office of Film, Theater and Broadcasting announced this afternoon that it would redraft proposed rules that would have restricted how images can be recorded in New York City, one of the most filmed and photographed places on the planet.

title: Cubs Knock on Wood
description: The long, strange trip of Kerry Wood has, yet again, reached Wrigley Field. Before todays game, the Cubs will activate Wood, who has not pitched in the major leagues since June 6, 2006, because of the same shoulder problems that have bothered him since the start of 2005. Wood has had 11 stays on the disabled list and two major surgeries.

description: Stocks tumbled yesterday on fears that the worsening ills in the mortgage and debt markets could soon take a significant toll on consumers, businesses and the overall economy.

description: To the Editor:

title: Mets Start Out With Patience, Then Pile It on in the Ninth
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 3  If the Mets were to plot the effects of Howard Johnsons three weeks as hitting coach on a graph, they would draw a few surges, a couple of dips and one gigantic spike. That came Friday, when the patient hitting approach that Johnson, following team orders, has worked to instill resulted in a season-high 11 walks against the Chicago Cubs at Wrigley Field.

title: So Many Investigations
description: It seems that everywhere they turn these days, New York Gov. Eliot Spitzer and his staff face another investigation. There have already been two inquiries into the pushing of State Police to release embarrassing information about the governors top political opponent, Senator Joseph Bruno. Now there could be three or even four more, ready to sidetrack everything else important going on in Albany.

title: Obamas Flexibility (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: A Nostalgia for Yesterdays Future
description: Masters of Science Fiction is an odd summertime diversion. Into the season of Americas Got Talent and So You Think You Can Dance, ABC is dropping a series of four talky, philosophical dramas based on stories by well-known science-fiction writers (well, three well-known science-fiction writers and Howard Fast). Its a pure throwback, a Twilight Zone homage with Stephen Hawking in the Rod Serling role.

title: Airplane Crashes Create Anxiety Among Brazils Travelers
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 3  Alire Assis Brasil, in town to visit an aunt, waited patiently Thursday for her bus back to her home in Florianopolis  some 18 hours away.

title: Keeping a Hitting Machine Humming
description: SAN DIEGO, Aug. 3  What can you do for Barry Bonds? Joe Lefebvre, the batting coach for the San Francisco Giants, has heard the question, which is really more of a disguised criticism, so often that he has a prepared answer.

title: Oil Refineries (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Press Baron Champions Viewspaper
description: Anthony OReilly is perhaps best known in the United States as the former chief executive of the H. J. Heinz Company and a champion of all things Irish. But his broad business interests include investments in hotels and natural resources and a major stake in Waterford Wedgwood. Lately, however, Mr. OReilly has been drawing attention as the founder, major shareholder and chief executive of Independent News and Media, the British-based publisher of Londons Independent, The Irish Independent and more than 100 newspapers in Australia, New Zealand, South Africa and, most recently, India.

title: Bottled vs. Tap Water? (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: On the Move, the Parisian Way (3 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: The Screenwriter as God, Examining His Creations
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 3  A big, sand-colored house atop a grass slope in this citys genteel Hancock Park district is one key to unlocking the meaning of The Nines.

title: 7 Arrested in Death of Oakland Newspaper Editor
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Aug. 3  A day after a prominent newspaper editor was shot to death downtown, the police here on Friday arrested seven men and seized several weapons that they suspected were used in his killing and those of two other men.

title: Haunted by Seamus
description: Most high-profile politicians acquire weird little bits of biography that you just cannot shake out of your mind. A reporter once told me that he sat next to a member of Congress on a trip, while said lawmaker kept eating mayonnaise out of those little packets they give you at fast-food restaurants. Even if this guy someday single-handedly resurrects the Equal Rights Amendment and shepherds it through 37 State Legislatures, when I look at him, a corner of my brain will always think condiments.

title: Toyota Says Quarterly Profit Jumped 32%
description: TOKYO, Aug. 3  Toyota Motor reported a 32 percent rise in quarterly profit on Friday, continuing a streak of record earnings as the Japanese car company seeks to widen its lead over General Motors as the worlds largest automaker.

title: Mystics Defeat Liberty
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP)  Alana Beard scored 24 points and Nakia Sanford added 16 to help the Washington Mystics beat the Liberty, 80-68, on Friday night.

title: Managers See Basics as a Buy in Risky Times
description: The stock markets volatility is making portfolio managers nervous, but it is not making them sell, many say. Instead, their response to the cascade from record highs has been to ensure that they own shares of businesses less sensitive than most to changes in economic conditions or to the whims of investment fashion.

title: Report Says S.E.C. Erred on Pequot
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission bungled a promising investigation two years ago into suspicious trading at Pequot Capital Management, a giant hedge fund, according to the final report released yesterday by Congressional investigators looking into the matter.

title: Risks of Pregnancy (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Elite American Racer Finds Full-Time Commitment Pays
description: Last summer, at age 29, Peter Gilmore made a career decision. He decided to suspend his life as a part-time elite runner and part-time businessman and put all his energy into distance running.

title: Hes Still No Seer, but Underdog Is Here
description: A motherless boy, a graceless dog and a witless script propel Underdog, a live-action resurrection of the 1960s television series about a canine superhero who speaks in rhyme while fighting crime. (Sorry, its catching.)

title: Bollywood Goes on a Trip to the A.T.M.
description: Cash on my mind/Making money all the time. ... Sounds like a rap hit, but no, its the theme to Cash, a Bollywood caper providing abundant proof that Hollywood pictures have no monopoly on ostentatious wealth, or, to use a spent expression, bling.

title: National Briefing | California: Reporter Suspended Over Relationship
description: Mirthala Salinas, a broadcaster in Los Angeles who covered politics for Telemundo and became romantically involved with Mayor Antonio R. Villaraigosa, was suspended Thursday for two months without pay. Her suspension followed an investigation into whether the ethical standards of the station, KVEA-TV, had been violated because of her relationship with the mayor. The stations news director was also suspended, its general manager reassigned and the stations group president reprimanded.

title: Court Partly Rebuffs F.B.I. on House Office Search
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3  An appeals court ruled on Friday that the F.B.I. violated the Constitution in the methods used to search evidence seized in the office of Representative William J. Jefferson, the Louisiana Democrat indicted on bribery charges involving $90,000 found in his home freezer.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: The Dog Runs Free

title: Lawmaker Calls for Registry of Drug Firms Paying Doctors
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3  An influential Republican senator says he will propose legislation requiring drug makers to disclose the payments they make to doctors for services like consulting, lectures and attendance at seminars.

title: Book Tackles Old Debate: Role of Art in Schools
description: When two researchers published a study a few years ago concluding that arts classes do not improve students overall academic performance, the backlash was bitter.

title: Complications Hindering Moynihan Station Plans
description: The proposed overhaul of Pennsylvania Station, Madison Square Garden and the surrounding neighborhood has long been described by the developers as a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity. It is also a project that is getting more complicated with each passing month.

title: Bush Visits Collapsed Bridge in Minneapolis
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 4  President Bush surveyed the pancaked concrete, contorted steel and hulks of half-sunken cars this morning on a visit to the bridge that collapsed over the Mississippi River.

title: William J. Tuttle, Master Movie Makeup Man, Dies at 95
description: William J. Tuttle, a Hollywood makeup artist whose work was so renowned that he won an Oscar years before there was an official Academy Award for makeup, died on July 27 at his home in Pacific Palisades, Calif. He was 95.

title: To Get a Clearer Look at the Poor, an Artist Uses Distorted Images
description: A young woman travels to an impoverished district in a large, sprawling city where she distributes cameras among children and invites them to take photographs of themselves and their surroundings. The photographs are printed and make their way into galleries in other cities, on other continents.

title: A Pakistani Envoy in Britain Defuses Cultural Land Mines
description: London

title: Chvez Takes Crazy Battalion of Supporters on the Road
description: LA FRIA, Venezuela, Aug. 3  Surely they will take photos of us by satellite, said President Hugo Chvez, referring to intelligence agencies from the United States, as his Airbus touched down Friday in this Andean city with the actor Sean Penn, a clutch of cabinet ministers and visiting dignitaries from half a dozen countries in tow.

description: To the Editor:

title: Schumer and Tax Breaks (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Workers Say They Feel Blindsided by Lenders Failure
description: MELVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 3  Among the 1,400 or so people who lost their jobs here Friday, there were undoubtedly some who understood the macro and micro factors that led American Home Mortgage Investment Corporation, one of the largest and fastest-growing mortgage companies in the country, to crash in a heap this week, even as it was hiring employees by the dozen.

title: Night Raid in Iraq: Seeking Militants, but Also Learning the Lay of the Land
description: FORWARD OPERATING BASE KALSU, Iraq  Capt. Eric Nylander passed the word down the line of soldiers in the darkened Chinook helicopter: Ice, meaning the landing area was free of enemy fighters.

title: Judge Orders Corzine Mail Turned Over to the Court
description: TRENTON, Aug. 3  A state judge rejected on Friday an attempt by Gov. Jon S. Corzine to dismiss a lawsuit filed by Republicans seeking public disclosure of e-mail messages he exchanged with the state union official who is also a former companion.

title: In the Alps, a Conquest Takes Two Generations
description: John Harlin III was 9 years old when a frayed rope sliced over a rough edge of limestone, sending his father plunging 4,000 feet to his death. It was the winter of 1966, and John Harlin IIs climbing team was nearing the end of a grueling siege against a new route on perhaps the biggest, most notorious mountain wall in Europe  the North Face of the Eiger, in the Swiss Alps.

title: Charity Work, American Idol-Style
description: Seven years ago, during a gripe session in the teachers lounge, Charles Best and others counted up things they needed. Books. Pencils. An occasional field trip. And they talked about a fact of life: generous people would be glad to give money to buy supplies, but not necessarily to write a check that would vanish into the maw of the school system.

title: Clinton Will Hold Chat Session With Bloggers After All
description: The Clinton campaign reversed itself yesterday and decided that Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton would attend an individual meeting with liberal bloggers this weekend in addition to her appearance at a larger forum featuring most of the other Democratic presidential candidates.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on July 26 about the reopening of the north end of City Hall Park, which surrounds the Tweed Courthouse in Lower Manhattan, included outdated information from a park advocacy group about park hours and access. A path from Broadway to Centre Street is open to the public from 6 a.m. to 1 a.m. daily without interruption; it is not closed at certain times for exclusive use by a nearby charter school. Only one gate on Chambers Street  not two  is occasionally closed to the public, and those occasions are the times the school is in session, not just when students are arriving and being dismissed. The second gate, on the west side of the Tweed building, is open to the public without restriction during park hours.

title: After Protests, City Agrees to Rewrite Proposed Rules on Photography Permits
description: Responding to an outcry that included a passionate Internet campaign and a satiric rap video, city officials yesterday backed off proposed new rules that could have forced tourists taking snapshots in Times Square and filmmakers capturing that only-in-New-York street scene to obtain permits and $1 million in liability insurance.

title: Bergman, Antonioni and the Religiously Inclined
description: In this weeks obituaries for Ingmar Bergman, perhaps no character in the great filmmakers work was mentioned more frequently than God.

title: Partisan Anger Stalls Congress in Final Push
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3  Congress stumbled toward its August recess on a discordant note Friday as angry partisanship and distrust slowed the House and Senate in the latest example of the ideological standoff that has made progress difficult all year.

title: Robert E. Keeton, 87, Author of Influential Law Treatises, Is Dead
description: Robert E. Keeton, a former federal judge and Harvard law professor who wrote widely influential treatises on tort law, courtroom tactics and no-fault auto insurance, died July 1 in Cambridge, Mass. He was 87 and lived in Cambridge.

title: Marine Sentenced in Killing of Iraqi
description: A military jury sentenced a Marine squad leader to 15 years in prison yesterday for killing an Iraqi man whom he and seven other squad members abducted near Hamdaniya last year.

title: A Tide of Wine May Drive European Growers From a Way of Life
description: PERPIGNAN, France  A few months ago Isidore Santamaria went out into his picturesque vineyard in southwestern France and ripped row upon row of neatly cultivated vines out of the ground.

title: States Across the Country Race to Inspect Bridges
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 3  As recovery divers moved from car to car in the murky waters of the Mississippi River on Friday, state officials across the country raced to inspect bridges that are similar to the steel-deck truss bridge that collapsed here, killing at least five people.
