title: Spitzer Aide, the Subject of an Investigation, Resigns
description: ALBANY, Aug. 3  An aide to Gov. Eliot Spitzer who is accused of threatening a Republican state official resigned abruptly on Friday, adding to the controversy here.

title: Police Say Driver of Ice Cream Truck Sold Drugs Near School
description: The driver of a Mister Softee ice cream truck was arrested yesterday on charges of selling cocaine and marijuana from his truck while it was parked outside a middle school in Queens, the police said.

title: Slowly, Clinton Shifts on War, Quieting Foes
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3  A little more than a year ago, before Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton entered the race for the White House, she drew a storm of boos from an audience of liberal Democrats here as she declared that it would be a mistake to set a date certain for withdrawing American troops from Iraq.

title: The Arts in School (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A headline on Page 7 of the Travel section this weekend, with the Next Stop column, refers imprecisely to the relationship between the city of Nantes, France, and the region of Brittany. Although Nantes was long the capital of Brittany and remains strongly identified with it, Frances current administrative structure puts it in the Pays de la Loire region.

title: Keeping a Hitting Machine Humming
description: SAN DIEGO, Aug. 3  What can you do for Barry Bonds? Joe Lefebvre, the batting coach for the San Francisco Giants, has heard the question, which is really more of a disguised criticism, so often that he has a prepared answer.

title: Lottery Numbers
Scenes From an Overrated Career
description: Chicago

title: As the Vision Fades, the Indignities Grow
description: Robert Masello used to laugh at his parents when he went out to eat with them. If the restaurant had a menu with pictures, his father would point to any vaguely appealing image. For his farsighted mother, Mr. Masello, in his teens at the time, would hold the menu up from across the table.

title: State Puts Restrictions on Self-Described Pedophile
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 3  In a surprise to parent groups and their lawyers, a judge issued a statewide restraining order Friday prohibiting a self-described pedophile from coming closer than 10 yards to any minor in California.

title: Suspect in Connecticut Killings Left Long Trail of Lawbreaking
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 3  Throughout more than two decades in and out of Connecticut prisons for everything from stealing pocketbooks to possessing weapons, Steven J. Hayes was given many chances to turn his life around, chances he often squandered.

title: Florida Counties Try to Contain Phosphate Mines
description: PORT CHARLOTTE, Fla.  Arguing that the State Environmental Protection Department is far too lax in regulating open-pit phosphate mines, three Gulf Coast counties are spending millions of dollars in an effort to keep the mines from further expansion in a major watershed.

title: With Sale, Chryslers Identity Is Simplified
description: AUBURN HILLS, Mich., Aug. 3  For almost a decade, people here debated whether Chryslers should still be considered American cars, how to correctly pronounce Daimler and what to make of the man with the German accent and funny mustache running one of Detroits automakers.

title: A Surer Way to Feed the Hungry
description: Globally, about 800 million people are chronically hungry, and the number rises every year. The Bush administration is pushing what should be an obvious policy change to help those most acutely in need  victims of catastrophe or some other emergency. Instead of shipping American-grown food abroad, Washington would send American dollars to buy food from local farmers.

title: Stop and Frisks Decrease in 2nd Quarter, the Police Say
description: The New York Police Department released information last night showing that officers stopped 113,945 people on city streets for the second quarter of this year, a number that a spokesman said was 12.4 percent lower than that recorded in the same period in 2006.

title: Wood Activated by the Cubs
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 3  The long, strange trip of Kerry Wood has again reached Wrigley Field. Before Friday 6-2 loss to the Mets, the Cubs activated Wood, who has not pitched in the major leagues since June 6, 2006, because of the shoulder problems that have bothered him since the start of 2005. Wood has had 11 stays on the disabled list and two major surgeries.

title: Stock Market Cycles
description: SALES of high-end art, jewelry and wine are booming. Stocks, until recently, were hitting new highs, and consumer confidence and spending are solid.

title: The Generation of 38, Still Kicking
description: LENOX, Mass., Aug. 2  The Tanglewood Music Centers Festival of Contemporary Music, for which composers and new-music fans assemble here every summer, has evolved into a compact parade of competing modern styles. Often that competition has to do with one generations concerns giving way to those of the next. This year the composer John Harbison, who directed the festival, assembled a program in the competing aesthetic ideas of a single generation.

title: Dramatic Fall Exposes the Risk in Extreme Sports
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 3  When the telecast of the skateboard Big Air event at the X Games on ESPN cut to a commercial Thursday night, the scoreboard screens at the Staples Center kept the crowd entertained with footage of crashes from past X Games events.

title: Passengers Scowl as Airlines Smile
description: THE nations airlines are beginning to right themselves, but for passengers, air travel is becoming much worse. The two things are not unrelated, according to Knowledge@Wharton, the online journal of the Wharton School of Business (knowledge.wharton.upenn.edu).

title: An Artist and His Sub Surrender in Brooklyn
description: At slack tide off Red Hook, Brooklyn, there are usually lots of things floating in the water, most of which you would not want to touch without the help of a good hazmat suit. But just after sunrise yesterday, something truly strange was bobbing there in the shallows near Pier 41: a submarine fashioned almost completely from wood, and inside it a man with an obsession.

title: WFAN Said to Be Replacing Imus With an Ex-Quarterback and a Jersey Guy
description: WFAN, the AM radio station in New York City that served as a flagship for Don Imuss show before he was fired over his racial and sexual asides about a college womens basketball team, has apparently settled on a permanent successor.

title: Whats Good for a Business Can Be Hard on Friends
description: A month ago, Brandy McDowell sat down with her longtime friend, Kezia Chandler, and told her she had switched cellphone carriers. Their relationship has not been the same since.

title: China: Pro-Tibet Protesters Arrested
description: The authorities detained as many as 200 ethnic Tibetans this week after a protest in the town of Lithang, in Sichuan Province, an area populated by Tibetans, Radio Free Asia reported. It said the group had apparently demanded the release of a Tibetan man who was arrested Wednesday after calling for the return of the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader, the Dalai Lama, during a celebration sponsored by the Chinese Government. The celebration was part of an annual festival in the town. The Dalai Lama fled Tibet in 1959, after a failed effort to gain independence from China. Many of his followers in Tibet continue to believe that the territory should be independent from China.

title: Prosecutors Charge Five in the Death of a Student
description: Two Rider University officials  the dean of students and the director of campus Greek life  and three fraternity members were charged yesterday in connection with the death of a freshman in March after a night of binge drinking at a fraternity party on the main campus in central New Jersey.

title: Deal for Dow Jones a Springboard for Murdochs Plans
description: DOW JONES & COMPANY has a new owner; meanwhile, more companies succumbed to the latest mortgage meltdown, and Mattel announced a huge toy recall.

title: So Many Parking Rules, Even Marines Are in Trouble
description: WHITE PLAINS

title: Mostly Someone Other Than Mozart
description: The Mostly Mozart Festival at Lincoln Center has, in its first week, been mostly Beethoven. And that mini-festival culminates today in a long two-part re-creation of one of Beethovens most famous concerts, in 1808, which presented the premieres of major works including his Fifth and Sixth Symphonies and Fourth Piano Concerto. Louis Langre will conduct the festival orchestra at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: So Long to the Analog Era; Home Movies Reborn on DVD
description: OVER the years, we have videotaped many precious moments: the birthday parties, the out-of-tune recorder concerts, the school plays (Is that him? No, look behind the moving cactus), the baseball all-star game (lovely except for the voiceover of my shouting Over here! Look over here!).

title: Hands-On Role for Wife in Thompsons Campaign
description: One Friday afternoon last month, Jeri Kehn Thompson took attendance at the testing-the-waters presidential campaign headquarters of her husband, Fred D. Thompson. Mrs. Thompson checked to see which staff members were working at their desks, said a Republican close to the campaign, and went on to chide those who were A.W.O.L.

title: The Distance-Running King Isnt Resting on His Laurels
description: Haile Gebrselassie walked through Manhattan on a sweltering afternoon, a slight man in a simple khaki outfit, drawing attention only because two burly bodyguards cleared a path for him. Gebrselassies trademark smile, unwavering in yesterdays heat and commotion, erupted in laughter when two passersby wondered aloud if perhaps he was the president of an African country.

title: Olmert Will Rework Aid Plan for Survivors of the Holocaust
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 3  Trying to forestall an embarrassing protest march by survivors of the Holocaust, Prime Minister Ehud Olmert of Israel on Friday agreed to rethink a widely criticized plan to give them a monthly stipend of about $20.

title: Preventing the Next Bridge Collapse (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Fannie Hillsmith, Distinctly American Cubist, Dies at 96
description: Fannie Hillsmith, a late-blooming Cubist painter, died on July 27 at her home in Jaffrey, N.H. She was 96.

title: In Tanning Circles, the Roof Is Becoming History
description: A lone cluster of clouds gathers demurely behind the Con Edison Building as Claire Kuhn and Jessica Watson spread their striped beach towels into a pristine pool of sun that has formed on the roof. Un-self-consciously, they splay their bikini-clad bodies toward the light.

title: Centrist Democrats Still Have a Role (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Britain Responds to Disease Outbreak
description: LONDON, Aug. 4  British authorities burned 60 head of cattle found infected with foot and mouth disease on a farm in southern England today as they moved quickly to try to contain any spread of the disease that devastated the British livestock industry in 2001.

title: Understated Safety Slips Into a Starting Role
description: ALBANY, Aug. 3  It was just about a year ago when James Butler, a little-known Giants safety, was cleared to practice after surgery on his kidney. He reluctantly met with reporters, and short stories were written about the surgery he had to unclog a blockage, the extra padding he would wear under his uniform and the extra fluids doctors told him to consume.

title: Our Man in Iraq, Embedded Unhappily
description: An appendix to Nicholas Kulishs debut novel about a gossip columnist who finds himself embedded with the marines at the outset of the Iraq invasion notes that among the authors favorite books are Evelyns Waughs Scoop and Sword of Honour trilogy, Graham Greenes Our Man in Havana and Joseph Hellers Catch-22. Normally, this might be leading with ones chin. But Mr. Kulish, the Berlin bureau chief for The New York Times, was actually embedded with the marines in 2003 while working for The Wall Street Journal, and he has brought home a story worthy of his literary idols. This is a very good book: funny, harrowing and sympathetic.

title: Game-Show Royalty Clash, With Jester on the Sidelines
description: On Grand Slam, a single-elimination tournament of game-show champions that will be broadcast on GSN starting tonight, the questions are often difficult. They encompass algebraic equations, geometric proofs and anagrams for Irish playwrights. But no question is tougher than the one viewers may ask: What is Dennis Miller doing here?

title: Arraigned on Rape Charges, Councilman Is Out on Bail
description: City Councilman Dennis P. Gallagher, who prosecutors say raped a woman in his Queens campaign office on July 8 after meeting her at a neighborhood bar, surrendered at a Forest Hills police station early yesterday to face 10 counts of rape, criminal sexual acts and assault. He pleaded not guilty at an arraignment later in the day and was released on $200,000 bail.

title: In the Hayloft
description: At the moment, Im sitting in my office watching someone else mow the lawn. Hes just caught the mower blades on some weed-barrier cloth at the edge of the hostas. Hell probably clip the nearly hidden rocks just down the hill from the paperbark maple. And I wouldnt be surprised if he got stuck in one of the holes I dug for a tree that never got planted. I never think about these things when I mow the lawn. I miss them instinctively. Theyve somehow grown into my bones like everything else about this place  bedrock surfacing in the middle pasture, monarchs drifting over the milkweed, bumblebees drinking at the edge of the spot we keep wet for the pigs.

title: Shy Scot Steps Into Spotlight at the Womens British Open
description: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, Aug. 3  Before the Womens British Open, it was easy to overlook the best title prospect from Britain, Catriona Matthew.

title: U.S. Airstrike on 2 Taliban Commanders in South Wounds at Least 18 Civilians, Afghans Say
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Aug. 3  The United States military said Friday that it had carried out an airstrike on two Taliban commanders during a sizable meeting of insurgents in a remote region of Helmand Province in southern Afghanistan, but that it could not be sure the men had been killed.

title: Abbas and Olmert May Meet in Jericho
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 4  Palestinian officials said today that President Mahmoud Abbas and the prime minister of Israel, Ehud Olmert, will meet on Monday in the West Bank city of Jericho. This would be the first meeting of the two leaders in Palestinian territory.

title: Younger Players Give Yanks a Spark
description: Chien-Ming Wang and Robinson Can will always be linked by their entry into the major leagues early in 2005. Their instant production helped save that sagging season and caused an epiphany for the Yankees management.

title: Belarus: Russia Suspends Threat of Gas Cuts
description: Gazprom, the Russian natural gas monopoly that is controlled by the Kremlin, said it would not cut natural gas shipments to Belarus, signaling an end to a payment stand-off that had threatened customers downstream in Europe. The announcement was made after Belarus agreed in negotiations to pay the nearly $460 million it owed in back payments, according to Gazprom. The first payment was made yesterday, and Gazprom said Belraus had agreed to pay the balance within a week. The pricing dispute underscored anew the shifting relations between the Kremlin and Aleksandr G. Lukashenko, the Belarussian president, who has relied in part on Russian support to maintain what Western officials have called the last dictatorship in Europe.

title: Valerie Plame Wilson Loses C.I.A. Lawsuit
description: A federal judge has ruled in favor of the C.I.A. in its effort to prohibit the former agent Valerie Plame Wilson from disclosing the dates she worked for the agency in her coming book, Publishers Weekly reported yesterday. Ms. Wilson, along with her publisher, Simon & Schuster, filed a lawsuit in late May in New York seeking to stop the C.I.A. from interfering with publication of the book, Fair Game, right. In their suit they argued that since the dates of Ms. Wilsons C.I.A. service have been made public, she should be able to use them in her memoir. But Judge Barbara Jones ruled that the dates were never declassified, and said that a letter from the C.I.A., which neither Ms. Wilson nor her publisher has seen, convinced her that there were national security reasons for keeping the dates out of the book. A spokesman for the publisher said that it was disappointed in the courts ruling, which we believe runs counter to the First Amendment, sets a dangerous precedent and creates an unreasonable standard by which the government can disappear public information and rewrite history. He added that no decision had been made about whether to appeal the ruling, but that Simon & Schuster still expected to release the book this fall.

title: Inching Along, Divers Battle Jagged Debris and Currents
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 3  Along the banks of the Mississippi on Friday, people found bluffs and outcroppings and stood there in clusters, watching. Except for a lucky few, who glimpsed divers slipping in and out of the water, they were watching a drama that was invisible.

title: European Company Close to Reaching Libyan Arms Deal
description: PARIS, Aug. 3   European Aeronautic Defense and Space, Europes largest aerospace company, confirmed Friday that it was close to signing two weapons contracts with the government of Libya. It would be the first arms deal with the North African country since the European Union lifted military sanctions on it nearly three years ago.

title: Limits Sought on Use of Surplus U.S. Ships
description: A Senate committee unanimously approved an amendment to the Coast Guard reauthorization bill that would more tightly restrict how private owners could use surplus Coast Guard vessels obtained from the government.

description: Maplewood, N.J.

title: After Chief Justices Return, Court Frees Musharraf Critic
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Aug. 3  Pakistans Supreme Court on Friday ruled to free one of the countrys main opposition leaders, Javed Hashmi, who had been serving a sentence for treason and inciting mutiny in the armed forces.

title: Hundreds of Inspectors Check Nations Old Steel Bridges
description: On the old bridge that carries Missouri Route 5 over the Lake of the Ozarks, near a place called Hurricane Deck, men with hammers spent yesterday whacking the girders and plates on the underside and listening to the voice of the steel. A subtle whisper could indicate a crack that could cause a collapse like the one in Minneapolis on Wednesday.

title: The Van Gogh That Wasnt
description: Experts have determined that Head of a Man, a painting attributed to van Gogh for more than 70 years, is a fake, probably painted by one of van Goghs peers, The Associated Press reported yesterday. Gerard Vaughan, the director of the National Gallery of Victoria, in Australia, said that a team at the van Gogh Museum in Amsterdam had found that the painting differed stylistically from the artists other works and was mostly likely painted by one of his contemporaries. The painting was taken to Australia in 1939 by Keith Murdoch, father of the media mogul Rupert Murdoch. The museum bought it in 1940 for about $3,500. It was purchased as a van Gogh work, and had been accepted as a van Gogh for more than a decade before the purchase, Mr. Vaughan said in a statement. The paintings authenticity was first called into question last August, when it was on display at the Dean Gallery in Edinburgh. Critics said the work, dated 1886, was of a different style than other van Gogh paintings of the same period and was not mentioned in any of the artists letters. When the Edinburgh show closed, the National Gallery of Victoria sent the painting to the van Gogh Museum for analysis. It is very important to make the point that its not a forgery, Mr. Vaughan told reporters. There is no evidence to suggest that someone produced this picture ... to pass it off as a work by van Gogh. When it was thought to be a van Gogh, the painting had been valued at about $21 million.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Airports are full of grumpy travelers who have either sat or are about to be seated in cramped spaces for a long time. So spas in airports seem logical. Xpresspa has taken the idea and run with it, having opened full-service spas in airports like John F. Kennedy, Dallas-Fort Worth and Raleigh-Durham. Now the company is going global. Last month, it opened not one but two new spas at Cancn International Airport, and is scheduled to open a center at Amsterdam Schiphol Airport on Nov. 1. Built with all-natural materials, all of the spas offer massages, waxing, facials and manicures/pedicures (www.xpresspa.com). ... Olivia.com, a company that caters to lesbians, is offering a Caribbean cruise to promote awareness and raise money for breast cancer research. Cruise for Our Cause, scheduled for March 30 to April 6 of next year, will include a walk led by a lesbian sports celebrity and an auction. Items will be donated by Melissa Etheridge and the music group Heart, featuring Nancy Wilson (above) and Ann Wilson, who are also scheduled to perform during the cruise. Tickets start at $1,499. ... Good through Sept. 30 (subject to availability and blackout dates), the two-night package includes a suite, a helicopter tour of the city, a cruise, dinner for two at Tang Court, daily breakfast, a laundry allowance and round-trip transportation between the airport and the hotel. Rates start at $1,997 (hongkong.langhamhotels.com). ...Through the end of the summer, discounted midweek packages are available at bed-and-breakfasts like the St. Francis Inn in St. Augustine, Fla. The deal includes an evening ghost walk, a bay cruise, museum admissions and two nights of accommodations for $179 per person a night, based on double occupancy. The Long Dell Inn in Centerville, Mass., is offering a two-night package that includes two round-trip ferry tickets to Marthas Vineyard or Nantucket ($349 a night per person, based on double occupancy). See www.bnbfinder.com/midweek for more deals and details. ... Eurosocks (www.eurosock.com) has introduced a line of socks and underwear: TravelSox. title: Inside the List
description: BURKES BLOWDOWN: The great crime writer James Lee Burke turned 70 in December. As a kind of belated birthday present, his new novel, The Tin Roof Blowdown, is receiving some of the best reviews of his career  the book enters the fiction list this week at No. 4. Burke has long written about Louisianas Gulf Coast, and in The Tin Roof Blowdown he pokes around in the aftermath of Hurricane Katrinia. In the book, his stalwart hero, Detective Dave Robicheaux, is among the relief workers looking for survivors in the flood. The message boards on Burkes Web site are full of posts arguing that the book should be required reading for the boys and girls in Washington, D.C. Writing in The Washington Post, the thriller critic Patrick Anderson called Burkes novel the best fictional portrait of Katrina that we have so far. But Anderson urged readers to keep Burkes achievement in perspective: Theres a bigger, better novel, perhaps by some as-yet-unknown Robert Penn Warren, waiting to be written about this American tragedy.

title: Fiction Chronicle
description: DEVILS IN THE SUGAR SHOP. By Timothy Schaffert. (Unbridled, paper, $14.95.) Think Sex and the City. Now make the city ... Omaha. The circle of women in this sprightly and eager-to-please novel  an artist, a writer, a hostess of sex-toy parties and a pair of twins who own a bookstore  are wise and worldly, enjoying the gentrification campaign that has given them their own ersatz Manhattan. Ashley, a writer of sexy novels that dont sell very well, conducts erotica-writing workshops and fights valiantly against the genres clichs, forbidding any characters mouth from forming into a perfect O of pleasure or surprise or delight, or into an O of anything, for that matter. With her best friends  Viv, the artist, and Deedee, who has found great success selling, Tupperware-style, what used to be called marital aids  Ashley has made her little slice of redeveloped downtown Omaha into a swanky scene that meets chick lits exacting locational criteria. But its setting aside, can a novel still be called chick lit if (a) its written by a guy, and (b) most of the chicks in question are in their late 30s to early 40s and not especially interested in shoes? When the characters spend as much time as these do searching for love, sipping cocktails and seeking comfort in one anothers company, the answer is yes, though Schafferts version of it is a good deal smarter and funnier than most of the disposable volumes cluttering up this genres walk-in closet.

description: Why do people get fat? We habitually divide the causes of obesity into two categories: genetic predisposition (having lots of overweight relatives) and lifestyle choices (eating too many chips or even, according to a recent study, having fat friends). A new field called developmental programming maintains a third possibility: that obesity, like many aspects of our physiology, can be traced to the months just before and after birth, when the brain and other organs are still fine-tuning themselves.

title: The Republicans Candidate Debate
description: The following is a transcript of the Republican candidates debate hosted by ABC News and moderated by George Stephanopoulos, of ABC News, and David Yepsen, of the Des Moines Register.

title: In a Maze of Indexes, Finding Prices to Live By
description: HOW fast is the cost of living rising?

title: G.I. Gets 110 Years for Rape and Killing in Iraq
description: A 23-year-old Army private was sentenced last night to 110 years in prison, a day after a military jury convicted him of rape and four counts of murder for his role in the attack last year on an Iraqi family in Mahmudiya, a hostile Sunni Arab town south of Baghdad.

title: Correction: The Week Ahead: July 15-21
description: A film entry in the Week Ahead report on July 15 about screenings of the digitally restored version of the 1927 film Fritz Lang film Metropolis included incorrect information from the films distributor about the amount of material that was restored. The restored version contains more than 1,200 rescued shots, not 1,200 rescued scenes.

title: Young Athletes Try New Coach: The Psychologist
description: A competitive gymnast for most of her life, Heather Benjamin has traveled the country and won her share of awards. But last year she developed a fear of jumping from one bar to the other in the uneven bars event. So she did something familiar to professional sports stars  she talked to a sports psychologist.

title: Correction: Wrapped in the Star-Spangled Toga
description: An article on July 1 about comparisons of America to ancient Rome referred imprecisely to a statue of George Washington once housed in the United States Capitol. The sculptor, Horatio Greenough, modeled his work after a Classical statue of the Greek god Zeus. Although Greenoughs unpopular statue had been nicknamed George Jupiter Washington  after Zeuss Roman counterpart  it was not Washington in the guise of a Roman god.

title: Were All Geeks Here
description: San Diego

title: Larry Mathews, a 24-Hour Hairdresser, Dies at 86
description: Larry Mathews, who earned a reputation as New Yorks most wide-awake hairdresser by opening what seems to have been the citys first 24-hour beauty parlor to serve insomniacs, talk-show guests, showgirls and other working women, died on Tuesday in Aventura, Fla. He was 86.

title: Buzz Marketing
description: About a year ago, Philips Norelco began the push to sell a device called the Bodygroom as a product to help men shave areas of the body other than the face. At the time, according to Jim Olstrom, director of the home division of the retail-data collection firm NPD Group, the idea of a product specifically made for below-the-neck shaving barely existed. Today, the Bodygroom is one of at least four products in whats seen as a distinct and fast-growing category; nearly 250,000 body-hair trimmers have been bought in the United States in the last year, according to NPD data (which does not count Wal-Mart). Nobody was talking about this category, Olstrom says. Now its completely out in the open.

title: Condo Music
A French Actresss Life on Screen. Kind Of.
description: PARIS

title: When It Comes to Rebalancing, a Little Means a Lot
description: ITS a question that has been on many investors minds since the stock market hit the skids two weeks ago: Should portfolios be rejiggered in light of rising market volatility?

title: Dont Let the Sun Catch You Tanning
description: THE villain in Danny Boyles new sci-fi thriller Sunshine is  spoiler alert!  a certain someone who wants our nearest star to go completely dim, even if all of humanity never gets to tan again.

title: The Days and Nights of Maurice Cherry
description: AS his bus exited the Garden State Parkway, Maurice Cherry gazed out the window, waiting for the precise moment when the gleaming silhouette of Atlantic City would swim into view. Suddenly there it was, lit up like noon even at midnight.

title: Laura Efros, Noam Kugelmass
description: Laura Lisa Efros, a daughter of Magdalena Efros of Haworth, N.J., and the late Norbert Efros, was married last evening to Noam Kugelmass, the son of Judy W. Kugelmass and Harold Kugelmass of Interlaken, N.Y. Rabbi Morton M. Rosenthal officiated at the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts in Philadelphia.

title: Animals? In a Zoo? Heavens!
description: Animals? In a Zoo? Heavens!

title: Doggy Bags
description: Novelty handbags often suggest different breeds of dog. There is the wrinkly shar-pei, right, whose folds of skin are reflected in an array of puckered leather bags. There also are dogs who call to mind the shaggy-look leather bags, above and left. The artisan dog handbags by Priscilla Snyder, bottom left, are intricately embroidered works of art. Some of Ms. Snyders newest bags are three-dimensional sculptures.

title: Against the Current
description: They follow her along the banks of the Nile, entreating: Halloo. Come here! They hike up their djellabas and wade in after her. They want to row for her; they insist they are bolice officers. And in ways at once oddly innocent and salacious, they nudge the conversation toward sex. Of the Egyptian men she encountered in Aswan and Luxor, Rosemary Mahoney writes: You never knew whether to give them a brisk slap for the impertinence or to welcome the irreproachable trust they seemed to offer. It was ... what made them interesting.

title: Grass Roots Rising
description: Blessed Unrest is about a movement that no one has noticed, not even the people involved. The movement, as Paul Hawken calls it, is made up of an unknowable number of citizens and mostly ragtag organizations that come and go. But when you do see it, you understand it to include NGOs, nonprofit agencies and a seemingly disparate range of people who might describe themselves as environmental activists, as well as people who might not describe themselves as anything at all but are protesting labor injustices, monitoring estuaries, supporting local farming or defending native people from being robbed of the last forests. There are a few billionaires, working hard to give their wealth away, and there are even some Christian evangelicals, who have decided the earth is not theirs to trash, but the movement is mostly about shared beliefs, even if those beliefs are unproclaimed. Life is the most fundamental human right, Hawken writes, and all of the movements within the movement are dedicated to creating the conditions for life, conditions that include livelihood, food, security, peace, a stable environment and freedom from external tyranny.

title: Correction: 36 Hours in Edinburgh
description: The 36 Hours column last Sunday, about Edinburgh, Scotland, referred incompletely to air service between New York and Edinburgh. Although there are no direct flights between New York Citys two airports and Edinburgh, Continental does offer nonstop service from Newark.

title: If the Shoe Fits, Write on It
description: EVERY edgy pastime eventually loses some of its outlaw luster, thanks to corporate Americas proficiency at borrowing lingo and imagery from the underground. Consider tagging, the act of covertly spray-painting nicknames and slangy messages on walls. Different from graffiti in that it refers primarily to script, not artwork, tagging is the sort of rebellious hobby that disaffected teenagers love and strait-laced adults abhor.

title: Alexandra Pulver, John Bassett
description: Alexandra Bouchard Pulver, a daughter of Michele B. Pulver and Judge George J. Pulver Jr. of Catskill, N.Y., was married last evening to John Lancaster Bassett, a son of Jacqueline M. Bassett and William W. Bassett of Alamo, Calif. The Rev. Phillip Smith, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at St. Marys Church in Hudson, N.Y.

title: Zelig of the Night
description: ONCE, a seemingly endless list of late-night radio talk-show hosts broadcast out of New York: Barry Gray, Long John Nebel, Tom Snyder, Big Joe Rosenfield and his Happiness Exchange.

title: Our Town
description: When I first met with Judy Sigwalt and her fellow village trustee Paul Humpfer this past April, they were, understandably, feeling assured, if not emboldened. A few weeks earlier, with the endorsement of the two local newspapers, they were elected to their village board on the platform that their town, Carpentersville, Ill., should do everything in its power to discourage illegal immigrants from settling there. They vowed to pass a local ordinance that would penalize landlords that rented to illegal aliens and businesses that hired them. They also pledged to make English the official language of the village, which would mean discontinuing the practice of printing various notices  including building-code violations and the monthly newsletter  in both English and Spanish. The third candidate on their slate also won, giving them a majority on the board. Sigwalt and Humpfer considered their election a mandate. Indeed, many in this village consider them heroes. Their supporters wear buttons that read, Illegal Means Illegal, and: Im tired. Are you? Ask Me Why! with a sickly looking bald eagle wrapped in the American flag.

title: When a Co-op Building Commandeers a Terrace
description: Q Our terrace is the staging area for work on the co-ops facade, rendering it virtually unusable. Are we entitled to a maintenance reduction?

title: Lara Pellegrinelli, Steve Smith
description: Lara Veronica Pellegrinelli was married on Thursday to Steve Smith at Studio 450, a loft in New York that is used for events. Mary Beaty, a chaplain of the Humanist Society, officiated.

title: Can a New Lease Halt Eviction?
description: Q If a landlord starts an eviction proceeding against a rent-stabilized tenant for nonpayment, but then during the proceeding the landlord sends the tenant a renewal lease and ultimately accepts the signed lease and an additional security deposit, what impact would that have on the eviction?

title: The Loan Comes Due
description: SUDDENLY its not so easy to borrow.

title: Six Novels of Clues to the Soul of Mother Russia
description: CONFRONTING the career-ending possibilities presented by a mass grave unearthed in central Moscow, a government supervisor in Martin Cruz Smiths new novel, Stalins Ghost, frets aloud: What if the grave runs under the entire court?

title: Erin Torneo and Sascha Paladino
description: AS a girl growing up in Connecticut, Erin Torneo was more likely to have her nose in a book than be dressing up as a bride. As a grown woman, she grew so weary of listening to friends dissect the intricacies of butter cream frosting and white dresses, she helped write a book about how society puts pressure on women to marry.

title: Nicole Lipman, Michael Ellis
description: Nicole Shein Lipman, the daughter of Lydia Lipman and Dr. Derek Lipman of Lake Oswego, Ore., is to be married there this evening to Michael Sanford Ellis, a son of Suzanne Ellis of Orlando, Fla., and Raymond Ellis of McLean, Va. Rabbi Shlomo Levin, an uncle of the bride, officiated in a city park next to the home of the brides parents.

title: Pedaling Through a City Reborn
description: A SOLITARY clarinetist tweaked out a mournful melody on a lawn in front of the Federal Chancellery, a sleek marble and concrete construction that looms over the Spree River. It was an overcast morning, and I was bicycling along the Spreepromenade, a gravel path that curves through the legislative heart of Berlin, the German capital. On either side of the river rose some of the striking new buildings that have confirmed the city's place at the forefront of modern architecture: the glass-domed Reichstag building and the Paul-Lbe-Haus, an annex to the German Parliament.

title: Katherine Townshend and Robert Stockton
description: Katherine Elston Townshend, a daughter of Joan Elston Townshend of Berwyn, Pa., and the late John Frank Townshend, was married yesterday afternoon to Robert William Stockton, a son of Barbara B. Stockton and Richard Warren Stockton of Vero Beach, Fla. Barbara King Briggs, an Episcopal deacon and a cousin of the bridegroom, officiated at the Round Barn in Waitsfield, Vt.

title: A Volatile Week Ends With a Thud
description: Volatility was the catchphrase for the stock market last week. Stocks veered up and down sharply, and a swoon in the last two hours of trading on Friday plunged the market into negative territory for the week.

title: Energy Bill Adopted by House Requires Utilities to Use Renewable Power Sources
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4  The House passed a wide-ranging energy bill on Saturday that will require most utilities to produce 15 percent of their electricity from renewable sources like wind and solar power. President Bush has vowed to veto the bill because it does nothing to encourage increased domestic production of oil and gas.

title: Kathleen Moran, James Fisher
description: Kathleen Mary Rose Moran, a daughter of Mary and James J. Moran of Garden City, N.Y., was married yesterday to James Marshall Fisher, the son of Suzanne and Marshall Fisher of Rockville, Md. The Rev. Timothy J. OConnell, a minister of the Association for Contemporary Catholic Life, officiated at the Cosmos Club in Washington.

title: Sexy Beast
Leslie-Anne Skolnik and Steve Brill
description: ON May 25, 2004, one of New York Citys foremost foragers, Steve Brill, and his wife, Leslie-Anne Brill, seemed to have been forsaken by natures generosity.

title: Archive to Expand Access to Files on the Holocaust
description: BAD AROLSEN, Germany, Aug. 2  Like other Holocaust victims, Noemi Ban has gone back numerous times to survey the ghostly field of chimneys at Auschwitz-Birkenau, the Nazi concentration camp in Poland where she and her family arrived in July 1944, and she alone survived.

description: ISLIP

title: After a Lull,  Signs of a Bump in Bankruptcies
description: Filing for bankruptcy was never a walk in the park, but until recently it was fairly easy to do. Why pay off your bills when you could liquidate and get a clean slate? That philosophy got out of hand, though, and lawmakers noticed.

title: Shelter Cares for 19 Dogs Taken From Mastic Home
description: SOUTHAMPTON

description: Kathleen Elizabeth Reeder and Matthew Gregory Paley were married yesterday afternoon at the Church of the Holy Comforter in Broomfield, Colo. Bishop Donald Hultstrand, who retired as the Episcopal bishop in the Springfield, Ill., diocese, performed the ceremony.

title: 10 Ways to Keep Europe Within Reach
description: THE dollar recently plunged to a record low against the euro, pushing prices for gondola rides in Venice and beer in Brussels to new heights for American travelers. The sticker shock has been even worse in Britain, where the ratio of the pounds value to the dollars has been more than 2 to 1. But you dont have to eat at McDonalds or stay at a fleabag hotel to afford a European vacation. Below are 10 ways to save money.

description: IS going upstairs getting you down? You might be a candidate for a stair lift, a chair that runs up the staircase on a rail.

title: Yellowstones Wolves Save Its Aspens
description: Aspens may be symbols of the West, but over the last half century, theyve been disappearing from the Lamar Valley of Yellowstone National Park. The reason is not a mystery. The elk that winter there were eating the young aspen shoots before they had a chance to grow.

title: Often on Point but Rarely in Charge
description: THE image of a woman rising on point, simultaneously authoritative and fragile, exalted and vulnerable, is central to ballet. As Balanchine wrote in a 1965 essay in Life, the ballet is a woman.

title: Tasteful Shadings in Colors and Flavors
description: WHEN the tumbling translucent surf is only a block and a dune away, a restaurant cannot compete; it must complement. Blue succeeds effortlessly at both design and dinner.

title: Zoe Billinkoff, Michael Furman
description: Zoe Ruth Lewin Billinkoff, the daughter of Dr. Sharon Lewin and Donald Billinkoff of New York, is to be married this evening to Michael Saul Furman, the son of Robyn Furman and Dr. Martin J. Furman of Providence, R.I. Rabbi Wayne M. Franklin will officiate at Congregation Rodeph Sholom in New York, with Rabbi Matthew D. Gewirtz taking part in the ceremony.

title: Courting Fantasy Fans (and Everyone Else)
description: NEIL GAIMANS novel Stardust, the source for the new movie of the same name that opens Friday, is a bit of an anomaly among the works that have made him a legend in the comics world. To begin with, though it was originally published in four installments by DC Comics in 1997, Stardust was never a comic book series with panels and dialogue, like, say, Mr. Gaimans famous Sandman. Its a prose novel with Arthur Rackham-like illustrations by Charles Vess, and came out in a comics format only because traditional book publishers didnt want to spring for so much color printing. Stardust (Being a Romance Within the Realm of Faerie) was subsequently reissued as a hardback and trade paperback, and in 1999 was published in a text-only version, without the Vess illustrations.

title: Elizabeth Zeltser, Ronen Voloshin
description: Elizabeth Zeltser, a daughter of Natasha Zaitseff of New York and Mark Zeltser of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., was married yesterday to Ronen Voloshin, a son of Ilana Voloshin and Arkady Voloshin of Bethlehem, Pa. Judge Barrington D. Parker Jr. of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in the Southern District of New York officiated at the Boathouse Restaurant in Central Park.

title: For Beer Tastes, on Beer Budgets
description: VISITING the big city can leave you parched, especially in summer. It's easy to develop a more-than-one-beer thirst as you gamely tramp from museum to museum, from landmark to landmark.

title: Fire Guts Historic Building at a Tarrytown School
description: A fire, which may have been caused by a lightning strike, gutted a historic building that contained the library of the private Hackley School in Tarrytown, N.Y., early yesterday, school officials said.

title: Amy Miller, Jeffrey Shaman
description: Amy Beth Miller, a daughter of Susan and Donald S. Miller of Bayonne, N.J., is to be married today to Jeffrey Abraham Shaman, a son of Carol Shaman and Col. Paul R. Shaman of Fairfax Station, Va. Rabbi Gordon Gladstone is to officiate at the Newark Museum.

title: Dont Be Afraid of Rupert Murdoch
description: London

title: When Dangerous Mistakes Become a Pattern
description: WITH the July 17 airplane crash in So Paulo, in which 199 people died, aviation safety has once again become a matter of intense concern among travelers. But it is not just Brazil that is in the spotlight. In the last few weeks, planes landing and taking off have come within seconds of colliding at airports much closer to home  like La Guardia and Orlando International. How can consumers find out which airports, airplanes and airlines have a pattern of dangerous errors?

title: Christmas Turkeys
description: In Washington, they call them earmarks. In New Jersey, they call them Christmas tree appropriations. They are pet grants quietly slipped into major legislation, usually at the last minute, that benefit someone or something in a legislators district. Whatever their name, they create the potential for big trouble.

title: In Hollywood, a Sacred Cow Lands on the Contract Table
description: JASPER JOHNS isnt paid based on the number of years his flag paintings remain popular attractions at museums. Rem Koolhaas doesnt cash a check every time an architecture fan takes a trip to Seattle to see his space-age public library. So why should the writers, directors and actors responsible for box-office bombs like Gigli be able to pocket some cash every time somebody buys the DVD?

title: Rats, Roaches and the Naked Man With the Gun
description: IN 1979 and 1980, my father, Esteban Torres, worked under an exterminators license setting traps in and fumigating businesses and homes throughout the Bronx and Manhattan. I wont bore you with roach and rodent stories  those could run on forever. Instead, Ill tell you about some of the people my father worked for, the ones he called crazy or knuckleheads.

title: You, Your Friends, Your Friends of Friends
description: IN a way it all seems so obvious. Your friend found a lump in her breast, so you have that long-delayed mammogram. One by one your friends stop smoking, so you stop, too. Of course people are affected by their friends habits and their health.

description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 4  Mat Hoffman sat in a Staples Center locker room Friday night after the BMX freestyle Big Air event, his injured leg propped on a chair.

title: Ann Sulzer, Ted Keizer
description: Ann Sulzer and Ted E. Keizer are to be married today at Krugers Farm on Sauvie Island in Portland, Ore. The officiant will be Jess Lord, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event.

title: Whats a Fed Chairman to Do?
description: PAUL VOLCKER faced a recession and double-digit inflation when he became chairman of the Federal Reserve in 1979. Alan Greenspan took over the Fed in 1987 and two months later ran into the worst market crash since the Depression.

title: Tamara Mann, Benjamin Tweel
description: Tamara Beth Mann, the daughter of Sharyn Mann and Stephen Mann of New York, is to be married today to Benjamin Charles Tweel, a son of Patricia Tweel and Dr. Charles Tweel of Columbus, Ohio. Rabbi Jeremy Kalmanofsky will officiate at the Puck Building in New York.

title: Emotional Day at Canton as Six Enter Hall of Fame
description: CANTON, Ohio, Aug. 4  For Charlie Sanders, the most difficult moment of Saturdays Pro Football Hall of Fame induction speech came near the end. Sanders thought about his mother, Parteacher, who died when Sanders was 2 years old.

title: Less, Less, Less! More, More, Moore!
description: FROM the very beginning of the nations modern social welfare system  even before Michael Moore began to explore the issue  there was a tension in it: What should the government be expected to provide? What should be left to the individual? How much government is too much?

title: With New Rules, Congress Boasts of Pet Projects
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4  If the idea was to shame lawmakers into restraint, it did not work.

title: Britain Rushes to Contain Foot-and-Mouth
description: LONDON, Aug. 4  The British authorities burned the bodies of 60 cattle found infected with foot-and-mouth disease on a farm in southern England on Saturday as they moved quickly to try to contain any spread of the disease, which devastated the British livestock industry in 2001.

title: The Road to Rightville
description: As I grow older, I avail myself more and more of the ancient prerogatives of old men. I hitch my pants high, shake my head at the barbarous young and drive a stone-cold 55 on the highway. Im risk-averse and dress as I please. (In my beginning is my end: Ive evolved from slob to hipster slob to ironic slob back, finally, to slob.) I distrust change, labor unions and Al Sharpton and believe that at high enough rates income taxes become confiscatory. In short, I am white, privileged, middle-aged and boring. But one thing I am not, and never will be, is a conservative. The recent essay anthology Why I Turned Right: Leading Baby Boom Conservatives Chronicle Their Political Journeys (Threshold Editions, $23) has given us liberals a chance to think about why, even in our calcifying stodginess, American conservatism remains a nonstarter for us, a stack of loyalty oaths wed never be tempted to sign.

title: Vitamin for the Heart or a Fruity Cabernet?
description: All the health benefits of red wine  without the hangover.

title: Vacation, All I Never Wanted
description: First the provocative statistic, then a discussion of how it has been interpreted and then my own reflections on the topic, The Decline of the American Summer Vacation, an already-much-scrutinized phenomenon that accounts, as it happens, for my need to write this article efficiently and swiftly. Like the roughly 50 percent of working Americans who wont take warm-weather getaways this year (and the 46 percent of those who will take holidays but will stick by the pool instead of surfing the breakers so they can use their BlackBerrys and laptops), Im scarily overtired and need to crash soon

title: Luckily, Theres Plenty of Her for Everybody
description: MONIQUE had a choice: Go to an all-eyes-on-her interview in the restaurant of the W Hotel at Union Square or make a pit stop in her suite upstairs. This comedian and actress had flown to New York from Los Angeles one recent morning for a whirl of publicity about her various projects, including the third special of the hit television franchise MoNiques F.A.T. Chance, and had just finished a Today interview with the correspondent Natalie Morales.

title: Built for Speed: Race Weekend in an Arab Kingdom
description: WHEN compared with Melbourne, Monaco or Magny-Cours, the tiny Middle Eastern island of Bahrain doesnt seem like the most obvious place for a Formula One race: local mores mean no camping at the track or alcohol in the grandstand; and the occasional bomb inspection when your taxi approaches a hotel in Manama, the capital city, reminds you that more dangerous places  like Iraq  are just a herculean stones throw away.

description: Rooting for the Yankees alongside luminaries like Billy Crystal, Spike Lee, Adam Sandler, and the current and former mayors, Michael R. Bloomberg and Rudolph W. Giuliani, is only another day at the ballpark for Francisco Estevez.

Martin Boylan, a Roman Catholic priest and an uncle of the bride, taking part.

title: On a Students Budget
description: Morningside Heights has long been home to Columbia University students, but in recent years many young families have settled here, lured by the spacious apartments, access to parks, excellent private schools and transportation. These affordable restaurants serve both populations well.

She received that title in 2002  not in April of this year, when she was given additional responsibilities and the title of Fidelity Investments president for distribution and operations.

description: Californias top election official on Friday decertified three voting systems widely used in the state but said she would let counties use the machines in Februarys presidential primary if extra security precautions were taken.

title: A Fine White, Still Winning
description: Although many California wineries have lost interest in the fine Loire grape chenin blanc, Dry Creek Vineyard in Sonoma has championed it for 35 years.

title: Seren Levinson, Craig Cepler
description: Seren Beth Levinson, the daughter of Hilary Levinson and Dr. Elcon Levinson of Avon, Conn., is to be married this afternoon to Craig Matthew Cepler, a son of Helene Cepler and Richard Cepler of Jericho, N.Y. description: A report on July 22 about the marriage of Katie R and Eric Scheidt misstated the surname the bride will use. She will be known as Katie Scheidt; she will not keep her name.

title: Up Front
description: Michael Beschloss, who not long ago was named the official presidential historian of NBC News, became interested in American presidents at the age of 8, when his parents took him to visit the Abraham Lincoln house in Springfield, Ill. From that moment on, he wrote in an e-mail message, Lincoln was the man for me. Soon after, it dawned on me that one could write history books on presidents as a profession. Beschloss has gone on to write about Franklin Roosevelt, Harry Truman, Dwight Eisenhower, John Kennedy and Lyndon Johnson. His latest book, Presidential Courage, recently spent nine weeks on the best-seller list. Asked how George W. Bush fits his idea of presidential courage, Beschloss observed: Bush partisans will insist that the president was brave to go to war in Iraq because the outcome of his presidency would depend on whether or not America won. But presidential courage  as I define it in the book  is when a president risks his popularity for an important cause for which Americans of the future are grateful. At the moment, its sadly hard to imagine that future Americans will feel that way about the Iraq war.

title: Jennifer Furlong, William Bogardus
description: Jennifer Corinne Furlong and William Edward Bogardus were married yesterday afternoon at St. Catherine of Siena Church in Riverside, Conn. The Rev. Francis T. Hoffman performed the ceremony.

title: Mortgage Mania Didnt Grip Everyone
description: THE seized-up United States mortgage market claimed more victims both here and abroad last week. The American Home Mortgage Investment Corporation, once a big lender, closed its doors, laying off more than 6,000 workers. In Germany, IKB Deutsche Industriebank received a $4.8 billion bailout from a government-owned group that said it would cover potential subprime losses at the bank.

title: Holocaust Survivors Protest Israels Stipend Plan
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 5  Several dozen survivors of the Holocaust, supported by hundreds of younger relatives and supporters, marched in protest today in front of Prime Minister Ehud Olmerts office, saying that a planned government stipend was too small, insulting both the living and the dead.

title: The Independent
description: One of the fascinating side streets in American film is the history of race pictures, celluloid productions by black artists for black audiences during those decades when Jim Crow laws enforced segregation. The mainstay of race pictures was Oscar Micheaux (1884-1951), an intrepid filmmaker-novelist-entrepreneur whose career spanned four decades and who made more than 40 movies. Not surprisingly, given that he opened doors for future black filmmakers and collaborated with important figures like Paul Robeson and the novelist Charles Chesnutt, a whole scholarly industry has grown up around Micheaux. Now Patrick McGilligan, biographer of Alfred Hitchcock, Fritz Lang and George Cukor, has synthesized the advance work of these scholars and written Oscar Micheaux, a popular life of this colorful figure.

title: Lost in Tehran
description: A memorable title will surely attract readers, but when a book becomes a classic, its hard to say whether the title has been part of its canonization or has merely become retroactively canonical. Would Trimalchio in West Egg, one of Fitzgeralds initial choices, have in time accrued the same force as The Great Gatsby? The Septembers of Shiraz, poignant once youve read this first novel by Dalia Sofer, is, on its own, a title at once overly poetic and misleading. An American reader might be forgiven for thinking Sofer has written a romance set in the Napa Valley, Sideways with Vaseline on the lens. And that would be a great shame because The Septembers of Shiraz is a remarkable debut: the richly evocative, powerfully affecting depiction of a prosperous Jewish family in Tehran shortly after the revolution. In this fickle literary world, its impossible to predict whether Sofers novel will become a classic, but it certainly stands a chance.

title: Not the Presidents Men

What if, when the young man came knocking, the grown woman hid, locked her bedroom door and stayed motionless on her bed, not answering, hugging her knees tightly? What if, when he refused to believe she couldnt love him, she didnt run to him, but from him?

title: Family Resemblances
description: About three-quarters of the way through George Hagens galloping, brazenly eventful family saga, Tom Bedlam, the title character briefly pauses to catch his breath and ponder the strange convergence of his past with the lives of his children. As well he might  though strange convergence may actually understate the case. What seems to govern the fate of Tom and his kin over the 40-some years the story blithely spans might more accurately be described as pure, out-of-the-blue coincidence. One of his daughters calls it providence; another isnt so sure. Readers could be similarly split: some delighting in the ingenuity of Hagens plotting, others finding its ease and godlike capriciousness a little (or more than a little) suspect. Tom Bedlam is the sort of novel that tends to be described, not always admiringly, as old-fashioned. But its odder, and better, than that: a strange convergence of the English novels estimable past and our own, rather less confident, present.

title: The Days of Their Lives
description: There are certain faces in old portraits that feel familiar, oddly enough, by virtue of their very anonymity. If youve visited any of the stately homes of England, youll have seen them lurking high on the walls of the ancestral gallery, banished to the dim reaches far above the Canalettos the ninth earl brought back from his grand tour and Gainsboroughs notorious rendering of Countess Camilla en dshabill. While the tour guide may linger eloquently over those, shell probably ignore the nondescript canvases of glum-faced Jacobean worthies, their lace and armor glinting dimly under darkened varnish.

title: Down the Nile
description: ON THE DAY that I hoped to buy a rowboat in Luxor, Egypt, I was awakened, as I had been every morning in Luxor, by a Koranic antiphony drifting from the Islamic boys' school next door to my hotel. With all the zeal of a Baptist preacher's, a young boy's amplified voice shrieked repeatedly in Arabic, "There is no God but God, and Muhammad is his witness!" and a shrill chorus of his schoolmates howled the words back at him. I got out of bed and went to the window - at 7:00 a.m. the glass was already warm as an infant's forehead - and discovered that during the night many colorful cloth banners had been strung above the corniche, Luxor's Nilefront boulevard. In hand-fashioned Arabic characters, the banners read, "Welcome Mister President of the Government, Muhammad Hosni Mubarak, the Leader of Our Victorious and Progressive Destiny." Scores of teenage Egyptian soldiers in black uniforms, woolen berets, and white plastic spats lined the avenue in the ninety-eight-degree heat, more or less at attention, rifles at their sides, evidently awaiting the president's arrival. Profiting from a police barricade, the usually hectic street was, for once, mercifully quiet. Across the glittering ribbon of the Nile, the Temple of Hatshepsut and the Valley of the Kings lay blanketed in the pink morning light.

title: Falling Behind: How Rising Inequality Harms the Middle Class

A recent conversation with a neuroscientist friend shed some light on why this device is often so effective. Different parts of the brain, it seems, specialize in thinking about different things. When we are confronted with a question in a specific domain, blood flows to the relevant part of the brain, priming it to think more effectively about the related ideas to follow.

title: Coetzees Canon
description: A little knowledge may be a dangerous thing, but dangerous things are very often exciting, and only the truly saintly would deny that there is a pleasure in forming opinions of writers whom one has never read a word of. Without experience to cloud ones judgment or information to slow ones thinking, the passage from ignorance of a writers work to a vague acquaintance with its main elements  courtesy, say, of an essay or a review executed by someone better versed  can be a stimulating imaginative exercise. On the basis of brief descriptions and short quotations the reader is free to conjure up a figure who may not much resemble the artist in question but is rich in associations anyway and who will do  will have to do  for now (which sometimes, sadly, is all the time one has).

title: Paperback Row
description: THE LAY OF THE LAND, by Richard Ford. (Vintage Contemporaries, $14.95.) The third installment, following The Sportswriter (1986) and Independence Day (1995), in the serial epic of Frank Bascombe  flawed husband, fuddled dad, writer turned real estate agent  was selected by the Book Review as one of last years 10 best books. Its Thanksgiving 2000: the Florida recount grinds on, and Bascombe, now 55, battles prostate cancer, copes with a strange turn in his second marriage and logs long hours on the highways and back roads of New Jersey, taking expansive stock of middle-age defeats. By now, we have gotten to know Frank Bascombe well enough to take his measure, and to appreciate that, like almost no one else in our recent literature, hes life-size, A. O. Scott wrote here.

The result, if successful, might be a canny contemporary Gesamtkunstwerk, a heavy-metal update of Wagners total artwork. title: Paying More, but Reaching Fewer Ears

The study reviewed industry trends since 1996, when the Telecommunications Act of 1996 loosened rules on station ownership.

title: Ghostwriter Disputes Simpsons Account
description: The ghostwriter of the aborted book If I Did It has contradicted O. J. Simpsons accounts of its creation and content, including the hypothetical description of the slaying of his former wife, Nicole Brown Simpson, and her friend Ron Goldman, Reuters reported. The ghostwriter, Pablo Fenjves, disputed Mr. Simpsons characterization of himself as a mostly passive participant in the composition of the chapter that depicts him holding a bloody knife at the scene of the crime. The whole book, the whole idea for a book, originated with O. J. Simpson and a couple of his handlers, Mr. Fenjves said. O. J. read the book, his book, several times. I made every change he asked for, and he signed off on it. In an Internet interview last week Mr. Simpson said he had been approached by publishers at HarperCollins about doing the book and had reluctantly consented to a chapter about the night of the crime as told by him only after they had agreed to label it hypothetical. Mr. Fenjves said: I find it completely unnecessary to defend myself against this man. All I can say is that if there are errors in the book, its because O. J. didnt correct them, or worse, he fed them to me. Amid public outrage, publication of the book was canceled last year. Rights to it were awarded last week to Mr. Goldmans relatives to satisfy a $33.5 million judgment they won against Mr. Simpson in a civil trial after he was acquitted of the slayings in a criminal case.

He had memorized the 13th-century text during long hours grazing animals on the steppes of Central Asia. And as is true of many ancient sagas, he sang of arms and the man  that is, of warfare and heroism.

Inspired by a best-selling book, then the movie version, young couples wrote their names on a padlock. They chained their locks around lampposts on Ponte Milvio. Then they symbolically cut off escape by tossing the keys into the wine-dark Tiber below.

description: Beyonc walked onstage at Madison Square Garden on Saturday night, made a quick commanding gesture, and sparks rained down. Her band kicked into the funk beat of Crazy in Love, and she started to sing and dance, alternating stop-motion angular poses and serpentine shimmies, switching between robot and seductress. Her face was angry and exultant; she belted the song with bright swoops and vehement rasps. Like many of Beyoncs songs, Crazy in Love treats romance as a power struggle, and its hard to imagine her not winning in the end.

title: The Executioners Hood
description: Many people assume that execution by lethal injection is simple and gentle. Its neither. An inmate is given three drugs to do three things: (1) Knock him out. (2) Paralyze him so he doesnt flop around or gasp in a way that upsets witnesses. (3) Kill him. If a step goes awry, an inmate can be paralyzed, inadequately sedated or unable to move or cry out as the poisons do their agonizing work.

description: CARSON, Calif., Aug. 5  Wearing thick black sunglasses and a black and white bandanna that pulled back his tangled red mane, Shaun White looked every bit the sports superstar he has become since winning the 2006 Olympic gold medal in halfpipe snowboarding.

title: Lost Van Gogh Is Found
description: First a fraudulent van Gogh was ousted from the catalog of his works. Now comes word of the discovery of a new van Gogh. The painting was found below the paint surface of van Goghs Ravine, owned by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. The news, announced by that museum and the Van Gogh Museum in Amsterdam, came as the National Gallery of Victoria, in Australia, was reporting that a team at the Van Gogh Museum had determined that Head of Man, attributed to van Gogh for more than 70 years, was probably executed by one of his peers. The painting beneath Ravine was discovered during a technical examination by Meta Chavannes, a Museum of Fine Arts conservator. It was most likely painted in June 1889, when van Gogh was at the asylum of St.-Paul-de-Mausole and was reused as a support for Ravine a few months later. Louis van Tilborgh, the van Gogh research curator at the Van Gogh Museum, related it to Wild Vegetation, a drawing van Gogh sent his brother Theo in mid-1889. Scholars have suggested that the drawing was one of about a dozen copies of paintings that van Gogh sent to Theo at that time, but until now, no one was aware of a painting upon which this drawing could have been based.

Condemned by the protesters as a tasteless portrayal of terrorism and its victims, the show  one of 2,050 offerings of drama, music and comedy by nearly 19,000 performers through Aug. 27  was defended by its producer, James Lawler of the Silk Circle Production Company. We have no intention of causing offense or insult with this show, he said. It is simply a musical comedy. The show tells the story of Sayid, a young Afghan peasant who dreams of success as a flower farmer selling poppies to the West. But on the night a jihadi cell is to attack Western targets, including one known as the Unidentified, Very Prestigious Landmark, he must decide whose side he is on.

description: A Queens woman has been charged with driving drunk and running over two women and a child Saturday, prosecutors said yesterday. The woman, Susan E. Karnabe, 54, of Alderton Street, was scheduled to be arraigned in Criminal Court last night on charges of vehicular assault, reckless endangerment and driving under the influence of alcohol, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said Ms. Karnabe struck Aviva Govshovitz, 57, her mother, Frida Shein, 86, and her granddaughter, Mia Tetelman, 3, about 2:45 p.m. as they crossed at Gerard Place and Yellowstone Boulevard in Forest Hills. title: Will Scarborough Shift Become Permanent?
description: MSNBC has not yet decided to hand its morning program, formerly led by Don Imus, to Joe Scarborough, though negotiations with him continue, an NBC News executive said yesterday.The Associated Press reported Saturday that it was likely that Mr. Scarborough would be appointed the permanent replacement for Mr. Imus, who was host of the morning program at MSNBC until he was fired in April over racially insensitive remarks. The NBC executive, who asked not to be identified because the talks are continuing, said that Mr. Scarboroughs appointment remained likely, though theres a chance it may not work out. The executive said a final decision might not be made until September. Mr. Scarborough, a former congressman from Florida, has previously worked as a prime-time host for MSNBC. Under the title Morning Joe, Mr. Scarborough has been host of the morning MSNBC program regularly for the past several months. The NBC executive did confirm that with WFAN radio about to name Boomer Esiason and Craig Carton as the permanent radio replacements for Mr. Imus, MSNBC would not be interested in returning to the simulcast it participated in with WFAN during Mr. Imuss tenure.

Restrictions for outdoor water use were lifted yesterday morning, but officials were waiting for water quality test results, expected this morning, before making further decisions.

title: Madonnas Adoption of Malawian Boy Delayed

According to the weekly Malawi News, Kate Kainja, Malawis minister of women and child development, accused the monitor, Penstone Kilembe, of obtaining an airline ticket and money from Madonna without government approval. Ms. Kainja told the newspaper, We have already contacted Madonna that someone else and not Kilembe will come to assess her because we feel Mr. Kilembe personalized the whole issue when other people can go. Mr. Kilembe dismissed suggestions that he had personally asked Madonna for airfare. The High Court appointed him to travel to Britain and was to rely on his testimony in deciding if Madonna and her husband, the filmmaker Guy Ritchie, should be allowed to adopt the child. Madonna took the motherless boy, David Banda, in October after his father, Yohane Banda, placed him in an orphanage. Mr. Kilembe said, What this means is that the whole adoption process may crumble and David sent back to his village.
