title: Fake Steve Blogger Comes Clean
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 5  For the last 14 months, high-tech insiders have been eating up the work of an anonymous blogger who assumed the persona of Steven P. Jobs, Apples chief executive and one of the worlds most famous businessmen.

title: Fortis Shareholders Back ABN Amro Bid
description: LONDON, Aug. 6  Shareholders of Fortis, which is part of a group bidding for ABN Amro, voted on Monday in the first of two meetings to support what would be the worlds largest banking takeover.

title: Bush Signs Law to Widen Reach for Wiretapping
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5  President Bush signed into law on Sunday legislation that broadly expanded the governments authority to eavesdrop on the international telephone calls and e-mail messages of American citizens without warrants.

title: Professor Puts Swings Rhythm to Music
description: In Room 415 of the Becton Center, a gray and humorless building on the edge of the campus of Yale University, a physics professor named Robert Grober spent a recent morning hitting scuffed golf balls into a beat-up net.

title: A Top Official at Bear Stearns Ousted
description: The crisis in the credit markets finally reached the executive suite of Wall Street firms last week, and the victim was an unexpected one: Warren J. Spector, a co-president at Bear Stearns who some had thought could become the firms next chief executive.

title: The Bolshois Whiz Kids on Display in London
description: LONDON, Aug. 4  The Bolshoi Ballets latest whiz kid, Ivan Vasiliev, is a colorful, engaging, 18-year-old firecracker who looks good as a smiling, fully clad and mustachioed slave in a virtuoso divertissement pas de deux in Act 1 of Le Corsaire or as a stone-faced, near-naked, painted-gold-all-over dancing statue in Act 2 of La Bayadre.

title: Whats on Tonight
description: 7 P.M. (Bravo) INSIDE THE ACTORS STUDIO Michelle Pfeiffer, left, waxes philosophic about her life, career and the films she made on her ascent to stardom, from her role as Elvira Hancock, the icy arm candy of Tony Montana (Al Pacino) in Scarface, to her current incarnation as the shellacked Velma Von Tussle in Hairspray. The famously beautiful Ms. Pfeiffer also offers this nugget about filming a love scene: Its awkward, she says. Sometimes peoples wives show up. Its like, Hey, how you doin?

title: Murdoch and the Journal
description: I think the hand-wringing about Murdoch buying Dow Jones is probably overdone. I read the Wall Street Journal every day and love it, and I would be horrified if he messed it up  but Id bet that he wont.

title: Your Comments on my Darfur Column
description: My Monday column notes that President Bush discussed with aides the possibility of sending ground troops into Darfur but was persuaded not to by Condi Rice. My sourcing on that is very solid, and I think the episode reflects the fact that Bush is actually more interested in Darfur than most of the people around him. He seems to raise it with foreign leaders and with cabinet members more than they raise it with him.

title: The Second Year of YearlyKos
description: At YearlyKos, now an annual gathering of liberal bloggers and progressive activists, the online and Washington worlds came together.

title: Letter from Michael Strahan to Giants Fans
description: To the New York Giants Fans:

title: Jimmy Wales: 2 Million Articles Down and More to Do
description: At the Wikimania conference in Taipei, this weekend there was a group of volunteers active in editing the online encyclopedia who started calling themselves The Old-Codgers Coalition. Like many at the conference, they were trying to cope with the impact of the sites popularity.

title: Mortgage Woes
description: Last week a large lender, American Home Mortgage, closed up shop, the latest among several such failures. Stocks tumbled over mortgage worries. Many home owners are feeling pressure from increased monthly payments as adjustable-rate mortgages climb with interest rates. Others are finding it more difficult than in the past to renegotiate the terms of their mortgages to avoid default. (Sundays Week in Review section published a guide to the problems.)

title: Foreign Workers and the Building Boom
description: Construction workers, a million strong in Dubai and famously mistreated, have won some humble victories.

title: Ex-Home Depot Chief to Lead Chrysler
description: Robert L. Nardelli, who was ousted as chief executive of Home Depot this year amid shareholder discontent over his enormous pay package, will soon take on one of the most prominent jobs in corporate America: revitalizing the troubled automaker Chrysler.

title: Telus Hangs Up on BCE Bid
description: Telusabandoned its pursuit of its rival BCE, the parent company of Bell Canada, stymied in large part by its inability to get regulatory guidance on which assets it might have to sell to make the merger acceptable to Canadian regulators.

title: Germany Looks Into Subprime Fallout at IKB
description: Prosecutors in Dsseldorf and government regulators in Berlin are looking into how a German bank became overexposed to the subprime mortgage lending crisis in the United States, but stopped short Friday of announcing a formal investigation.

title: Canadian Bomb-Disposal Company Buys Rival
description: Canadas Allen-Vanguard, which makes bomb disposal equipment, has struck a cash and stock deal worth 650 million Canadian dollars to acquire a privately held explosive-disposal company, Med-Eng Systems

title: Burned Once, but Starting Up Again
description: In his 1998 book Burn Rate, the journalist Michael Wolff describes his misadventures in starting and abandoning a technology company in the 1990s. The book became a parable for an era and elevated the term in the title, which refers to the amount of money a company blows through each month above its revenue, into the popular lexicon.

title: International Power Harvests Trinergy Wind Farms
description: A British-based electricity generator, International Power, said it had clinched a 1.84 billion euro ($2.52 billion) deal to buy German and Italian wind farms owned by their European operator Trinergy.

title: Union Seeks to Restrain 2 Financial Firms
description: The A.F.L.-C.I.O. has asked the Securities and Exchange Commission to require that the private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company and the hedge fund Och-Ziff Capital Management Group, both planning public stock offerings, be regulated as investment companies.

title: Brocade Jury Breaks for Weekend
description: The jury in the first criminal trial associated with stock-option backdating adjourned early Friday afternoon without returning a verdict.

title: Sun Capital Ties Up Deal for Limited Stake
description: Sun Capital Partners said Friday that it had completed the acquisition of the Limited chain of stores and has named the retailers co-presidents to top management positions. The deal finalizes Limited Brandss exit from the Limited and Express apparel businesses to focus on lingerie and body care.

title: London Theater Journal: M. Poirot and the Mysterious Case of the Sore Throats
description: LONDON, Aug. 6  All cardinals look alike from a distance, particularly if the one with the recognizable face has gone missing. That, in any case, seemed to be the opinion of the white-haired gent who started chatting to me (or was it to himself?) in the mens room of the Haymarket Theater on Saturday afternoon.

title: Journal Editor Interviews Self on Murdoch
description: Paul E. Steiger, former managing editor of The Wall Street Journal and now editor at large of the paper, was a keynote speaker at the annual convention of the Asian American Journalists Association in Miami and had intended to discuss the future of journalism.

title: Decision on Google Deal May Shape Web
description: The behind-the-scenes battle over federal approval of Googles proposed $3.1 billion acquisition of DoubleClick could shape the Internets future, The Los Angeles Times wrote. At stake is control of the growing online advertising market, estimated at $21.7 billion this year.

title: Millionaires Who Dont Feel Rich
description: The New York Times takes a look at a peculiar psychological phenomenon in Silicon Valley, where accomplished and ambitious members of the digital elite still do not think of themselves as particularly fortunate, in part because they are surrounded by people with more wealth  often a lot more.

title: Report Faults S.E.C. on Pequot Investigation
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission bungled a promising investigation two years ago into suspicious trading at Pequot Capital Management, a giant hedge fund, according to the final report released by Congressional investigators looking into the matter.

title: Fortis Shareholders Vote in Favor of ABN Bid
description: Fortis, the Belgian financial group, moved a step closer to buying part of ABN Amro Holding after Fortis shareholders backed its financing plan.

title: Auburn Avenue
description:
Images from the King Center, the King National Historic Site and Preservation District and the
APEX Museum in Atlanta.

title: After Postini, Whats Next for Google?
description: Googles recent purchase of Postini could be a prelude to more deals in the security business, according to the research firm 451 Group. It speculates that the Web search giant might try deals in the areas of URL filtering, anti-data leakage and identity and access management.

title: Sowood Founder Offers Apology
description: A contrite Jeff Larson, founder of the Boston hedge fund Sowood Capital Management, spoke to his clients for the first time Friday and tried to explain how events of recent weeks wiped out more than half of their $3 billion investment.

title: Measuring the High-Yield Debt Pile-Up
description: A string of debt offerings, many related to private equity buyouts, have recently crashed on the rocks of an imploding credit market. So how many of these deals have met with resistance from increasingly wary debt investors?

title: Akzo Raises ICI Offer to $16 Billion
description: Britains Imperial Chemical Industries, the maker of Dulux paints, has tentatively agreed to a sweetened 8 billion pound, or $16.3 billion, takeover offer by a Dutch rival, Akzo Nobel and a German partner, The Wall Street Journal reported.

title: The Real Fake Steve Unveiled
description: The parlor game that has captivated high-tech insiders for the last 14 months has come to an end after The New York Times Brad Stone unmasked the man behind The Secret Diary of Steve Jobs, a blog that channels and lampoons Steven P. Jobs, Apples chief executive and one of the worlds most famous businessmen.

title: Bidder for Barneys Goes Higher
description: Fast Retailing of Japan has increased its offer to acquire Barneys New York, the luxury retailer, to $950 million after Istithmar, an investment group based in Dubai, matched Fasts original $900 million offer, Barneys owner, Jones Apparel Group, said Sunday.

title: Morning Buzz: A Newark Murder Mystery; a Brooklyn Pizza Battle; Coney Islands Future; and More
description: Newark authorities are struggling to comprehend the grisly slayings of three friends who were lined up against a wall in a schoolyard and shot, execution-style. A 19-year-old woman, Natasha Ariel, 19, a student at Delaware State University, was also shot and survived.

title: Is Merger Advice Worth the Price?
Top Official at Bear Stearns Is Ousted
description: The crisis in the credit markets finally reached the executive suite of Wall Street firms last week, and the victim was an unexpected one: Warren J. Spector, a co-president at Bear Stearns who some had thought could become the firms next chief executive.

title: Why Plant a Flag at North Pole?
description: Russias planting of a flag at the North Pole was more than your latest piece of odd news. A historian writing in The Los Angeles Times says that Russia is hardly alone in audacious, and slightly weird, claims to territory over the years:

title: So What?
description: While Hendrick Hertzberg finds the appeal of nostalgia at YearlyKos, other liberals simply find the deja vu repellent. YearlyKos will add nothing to a much needed debate on the future direction of our country, insists Nancy (The Hankster) Hanks. The time for insurgence in the DP is over. Without a relationship to independent voters  left, center and right  YearlyKos will remain safely within the boundaries of the very partisan political culture that is responsible for the bad policy we are living with right now.

title: Clinton and the Lobbyists
description: O.K., it was a steamy weekend in early August, not a time when everyone is riveted to the presidential campaign trail. But a heady amount of politics took place this weekend. And from within that brew, a couple of moments are beginning to emerge as potentially significant.

title: Boomer Chases His Own Home Run History
description: David Boomer Wells looked hyperactive. What else is new?

title: 2008: From Debate to Debate
description: Fresh off back-to-back debate appearances over the weekend, the Republican and Democratic candidates will be looking to carry their momentum forward as they begin a busy week on the campaign trail. The Democrats face two more forums over the next few days  one in Chicago sponsored by the A.F.L.-C.I.O. on Tuesday and another in Los Angeles on Thursday organized by the Human Rights Campaign. It will focus on issues important to the gay and lesbian community.

title: The Skim
description: A quick hike through the Sunday (and a few non-Sunday) book review sections.

title: Edwards, McCain in Iowa
description: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa  Two of the presidential candidates  John Edwards and John McCain  are giving policy speeches here today.

title: Foreclosures: A Call to Action
description: In todays Times, Gretchen Morgenson has a frightening piece about the troubles facing many homeowners, headlined Mortgage Maze May Increase Foreclosures.

title: Ask About Latino New York
description: Carolina Gonzlez and Seth Kugel, freelance journalists who wrote Nueva York: The Complete Guide to Latino Life in the Five Boroughs (St. Martins/Griffin, 2006) and run Nueva York, a blog about Latino life in New York City, are taking questions from City Room readers this week. Readers are invited to submit their questions in the comment box below.

title: Bloomberg Reports for Jury Duty
description: 3:40 p.m. | Mr. Bloomberg was dismissed as a potential juror in the asbestos case. He was sent back to the jury room, where he and other jurors released from the case could potentially be selected for another jury. Mr. Bloomberg and the other jurors in the room were sent home and told to come back at 9:30 a.m. tomorrow.

title: Mia Farrows Darfur Gambit
description: A quick scroll down the front page of Mia Farrows Darfur blog suggests that she is not just another Hollywood do-gooder vapidly backing a fashionable cause. LOOK at this!! If this is true he has done NOTHING is a typical comment from her: focused on actions and results as opposed to words, of which there are many hopeful ones on the subject.

description: Beginning today, we present a bigger sampling of letters online, to make up for the reduced size of the print edition of The Times. The available space for letters in print has been reduced by about a third.

title: Guerrilla Marketing on the Upper West Side
description: Would you be happy if you had just spent millions of dollars to renovate one of the Upper West Sides grandest landmarks and you were selling condominiums in that landmark for up to $6.7 million and you learned that guerrilla marketers had  without your permission  splashed an animated, illuminated Samsung logo on your freshly restored stonework?

title: The Value of Deal Advice: A Closer Look
description: What is merger advice worth? One way of answering that question is to look at the post-deal performance of companies that made major acquisitions. Depending on which investment bank advised the buyer, the results are strikingly different.

title: Cramers Own Bond-Driven Meltdown
description: While the debt markets continue their convulsions  or their return to sanity, depending on whom you ask  one high-profile stock picker is calling for action in the strongest terms. On Friday afternoon, the voluble Jim Cramer appeared on CNBC to talk with Erin Burnett about Bear Stearns latest hedge-fund-related troubles.

title: How Quickly and How Much do Menu Prices Change?
description: As I noted in a recent post on this blog about a return to the restaurant Falai, prices on the dinner menu had increased substantially over the two years of the restaurants existence. These increases seemed to reflect much more than normal inflation, much more than any rise in the costs of doing business.

It had been billed as the superstars Major League Soccer regular season debut ( which should not to be confused with his L.A. Galaxy exhibition debut against Chelsea on July 21 or what would have been his SuperLiga debut on July 24 against Pachuca). But on Saturday, Beckham said he would again sit out due to his nagging ankle injury.

description: Bear Stearns is getting the lions share of attention, but other investment banks are having hedge-fund problems of their own as the credit crisis deepens. Case in point: Global Alpha, the $10 billion flagship fund of Goldman Sachs, which Financial News says fell 8 percent in one week at the end of July and is down more than 12 percent on the year before fees.

description: Mel Karmazin, the chief executive of Sirius Satellite Radio, is turning up the volume in his effort to persuade regulators to approve his companys merger with its main rival, XM Satellite Radio.

description: When pundits go looking to explain the stock markets recent selloff, they often point to an expected slowdown, or worse, in leveraged buyouts. But Ryan Kloster, an analyst at Lehman Brothers, ran some numbers and concluded that a buyout freeze, if it happened, would barely register across the markets as a whole.

title: Blogtalk: Debating the FISA Bill
description: Blogs on the right and left have been reacting to legislation President Bush signed over the weekend that expands the governments authority to eavesdrop on Americans as part of its broader terrorism surveillance program. Congress passed the measure on Saturday by a vote of 227 to 183 despite serious objections from many Democrats about the scope of the executive branchs new eavesdropping power, The Timess Carl Hulse and Edmund L. Andrews reported.

description: New York City is a great reality instructor, to borrow Saul Bellows unflinching phrase. The city teaches you to always exercise a certain amount of caution and skepticism and to seldom let your guard down.

description: The new issues of The Believer and The Oxford American arrived in the mail last week, and theyre both stuffed with things I know Im going to want to  have to  read.

title: Seven Tie for First at U.S. Open
description: Instead of providing clarity, the last round of the U.S. Open in Cherry Hill, N.J., produced a seven-way tie for the championship. The five players in the lead going into the ninth and final round all drew their games, allowing two other players who trailed the leaders by half a point to catch them after they won their last round games. The games and the results can be viewed at Monroi.com.

title: New York Press Gets Rid of Sex Ads
description: The new owners of New York Press, the free alternative weekly founded in 1988, announced a major change today, and it has nothing to do with the papers political coverage, underground sensibility or arts listings. The scrappy weekly is dropping its sexually themed ads.The banned ads include those that advertise illegal massage parlors and blatant ads promoting prostitution, the local chapter of the National Organization for Women announced today. (The New York Observers Media Mob blog reported the decision last week.)

title: Brooklyn Artist in Troubled Water
description: Duke Riley was detained after his replica of a submarine from the Revolutionary War neared the Queen Mary 2.

description: A sculpture depicting a tearful elephant in chains that was designed in New York and became the center of a federal lawsuit in Washington was put on display in Union Square Park today, with the blessing of New York City officials.

title: A Union Splits Primary Endorsements
description: CHICAGO  As union leaders gathered here today for the Democratic presidential debate they are holding tomorrow at Soldier Field, the International Association of Machinists announced a novel political strategy: for the first time in its 119-year history, it plans to endorse both a Republican presidential candidate and a Democratic presidential candidate before the two parties hold their primaries.

title: Bondss Record-Breaking Ball Is Upon Us
description: Barry Bonds is as close as he can be to breaking Hank Aarons home run record. Starting with tonights game against the Washington Nationals, hell have seven games at his home stadium to hit number 756.

description: After they returned from Africa, Leana, Will and Nick sat down with MTV to recount their journey to Rwanda, Congo and Burundi. The video was recently posted on mtvU.com.

description: Before the finale of the Yankees last series in Toronto, on May 30, their record was 21-29. Since then, including a 5-4 victory here on Monday, the Yankees are 41-21, the best record in the majors in that span.

description: Conservative bloggers accused Senator Dick Durbin, an Illinois Democrat, of violating Congressional ethics rules for using the official Senate seal in a video appeal to the liberal netroots at the YearlyKos convention this past week.

description: Tough is a brand all the Republican candidates want to own as they run for president. Tough on terrorism, tough on crime, tough on Democrats.

description: Judith Warner has written an Op-Ed for The Times that appears in print and online on Tuesday. Post a comment about it below.  The Editors

description: So who was the mystery boy from Dartmouth with whom Hillary Rodham spent a Saturday night when she was an undergraduate at Wellesley?

description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 6  Willie Mays is protective and proud when he speaks about Barry Bonds. Mayss words come slowly, or they simply stop, if he dislikes a question. Mayss words flow in bursts if he is discussing something compelling about Bonds.

title: Research Identifies Brain Site for Fever
description: The area of the brain responsible for causing fever would just about fit on the head of a pin, researchers are reporting.

title: Brower Takes His Spot in the Bullpen; Chamberlain Is Due Up Next
description: TORONTO, Aug. 6  Piece by piece, in small moves more than splashy ones, the Yankees have tightened their roster. They have a new backup catcher, a new backup infielder, and their bullpen remains under construction.

description: SEAVIEW, N.Y.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Friday about the Minneapolis bridge collapse rendered incorrectly the hometown of one victim. It is Mounds View, Minn., not Moundsview.

title: Baseball and Umpires Clash Over Background Checks
description: Major League Baseball and its umpires union are locked in disagreement about baseballs right to conduct background checks on umpires, representatives from baseball and the World Umpires Association said yesterday.

title: TV Show Suspended After a Drowning
description: Death by drowning has prompted suspension of a popular survivor television show in Nigeria, Reuters reported. The victim, Anthony Ogadje, was one of 10 contestants who had gone to Shere Hills Lake in the hilly Plateau State of Nigeria to prepare for the Gulder Ultimate Search, a program that poses an assortment of physical challenges for the participants. A statement yesterday from Nigerian Breweries, a unit of the Dutch brewer Heineken, which sponsors the show, said Mr. Ogadje had died suddenly and was believed to have drowned. All attempts to revive him by the attendant medical team and the lifeguards, including his fellow contestants, failed, Nigerian Breweries said. Broadcasts were to have begun on Thursday. The winner of the elimination contest receives $39,000 in cash, a four-wheel-drive jeep and $3,900 for clothes, as well as celebrity status in Nigeria, where most people live in extreme poverty and benefit little from the countrys oil weath.

title: Setback for Novartis in India Over Drug Patent
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 6  Indian companies will be free to continue making less expensive generic drugs, much of which flow to the developing world, after a court rejected a challenge to the patent law on Monday.

title: Booker Comes Under Siege After Bloodshed
description: NEWARK, Aug. 6  As a weekend of bloodshed gave way to a day of mourning, the sleep deprivation and public battering were beginning to take a toll on Mayor Cory A. Booker, his face a curtain of sadness and fatigue. A group of protesters on the steps of City Hall were calling for his resignation, while a large huddle of reporters down the street waited with unanswerable questions about Saturday nights fatal shooting of three college students in a West Ward schoolyard.

title: Four Trips to Hell and Back at the Opera
description: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 5  Orpheus, the awesomely gifted musician and poet of ancient myth, whose lyrics and songs could entrance wild animals and alter the course of churning rivers, is the hero of countless operas, including Monteverdis landmark Orfeo of 1607. With this historic work Monteverdi set the parameters and pointed the way for what was to come in the genre.

title: Raul Hilberg, 81, Historian Who Wrote of the Holocaust as a Bureaucracy, Dies
description: Raul Hilberg, a Jewish migr from Nazi-occupied Vienna who helped begin the field of Holocaust studies with his long and minutely detailed 1961 study of the massacre of European Jews, died Saturday in Williston, Vt. He was 81.

title: NATIONAL BRIEFING | SOUTH | Florida: Deputy Is Shot After Traffic Stop
description: An undercover Broward County sheriffs deputy was shot in the head by a motorcyclist he had pulled over, the authorities said. The deputy, Maury Hernandez, 28, stopped the suspect, identified as David Maldonado, 23, who the authorities said jumped off his bike and shot the deputy. Deputy Hernandez was reported to be in critical condition. He was on his way to an undercover operation when he made the stop, and was wearing plain clothes and driving an unmarked vehicle. Mr. Maldonado was arrested at a nearby condominium complex.

title: Those Missing Guns in Iraq
description: American taxpayers are rightly prepared to pay for all the equipment our soldiers need to defend themselves in Iraq. What is harder to accept is that because of the Pentagons scandalous mismanagement, they may have been paying to arm Iraqi insurgents who are shooting at American soldiers.

title: Strong Probability Outbreak Originated in Labs
description: LONDON, Aug. 7  There is a strong probability that the outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease in Britain was caused by viruses that escaped somehow from a pair of veterinary laboratories where vaccines are made, a government report said today.

title: To Punish Thai Police, a Hello Kitty Armband
description: BANGKOK, Aug. 7  It is the pink armband of shame for wayward police officers, as cute as can be with a Hello Kitty face and a pair of linked hearts.

title: Before Running Cars, Ethanol Fuels Land Boom
description: DeKALB, Ill.  While much of the nation worries about a slumping real estate market, people in Midwestern farm country are experiencing exactly the opposite. Take, for instance, the farm here  nearly 80 acres of corn and soybeans off a gravel road in a universe of corn and soybeans  that sold for $10,000 an acre at auction this spring, a price that astonished even the auctioneer.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of a production error, the Bridge columns diagramed deal yesterday misplaced some cards. The ace, king, queen, seven and five of clubs were part of Easts hand, not Wests; and the two shown in Easts hand was one of the diamonds, along with the queen, jack, ten and nine.

title: Six Trapped After Collapse in a Utah Coal Mine
description: HUNTINGTON, Utah, Aug. 6  Scores of rescue workers toiled into the night Monday to try to find six coal miners who were trapped inside a shaft that collapsed with such force that seismologists at first thought an earthquake had occurred.

title: 121-Year-Old Pier Seen as Portal to Harbor District
description: For the past 20 years, Pier A has been an overlooked remnant on the waterfront of Lower Manhattan.

description: Baron Elie de Rothschild, who oversaw the restoration and ascent of the renowned wine estate Chteau Lafite Rothschild after World War II, died Monday while on a hunting trip near the village of Scharnitz, in the Austrian Alps. He was 90.

title: Mental Abilities: Good Readers Better Able to Retain Brain Skills

title: Russia: Ex-Yukos Official Sentenced to Life in Murders

He had earlier been sentenced to 24 years in prison. His arrest in 2003 registered the start of the Kremlin-backed campaign against Yukos, once Russias largest oil company, and its founder, Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky.

title: Heat Waves Are Getting Longer
description: Researchers studying western European temperature records have found that the length of heat waves there has doubled since 1880, from 1.5 days to 3 days on average. They also say that the number of summer days that are far hotter than the average for a particular date has tripled. The team described its work in the current issue of the Journal of Geophysical Research-Atmospheres. The scientists, led by Paul M. Della-Marta of the University of Bern in Switzerland, said the findings supported the idea that global warming from human activities could be making Europe more prone to extreme conditions. They recommended that health agencies in the region work on ways to limit human health risks from summer heat.

title: Beethovens Final Sonatas Blossom in Complex Simplicity
description: KATONAH, N.Y., Aug. 5  Virtuosos are often praised with the statement that they make the music sound easy. The last 3 of Beethovens 32 piano sonatas did not sound easy when Mitsuko Uchida played them on Sunday afternoon at the final concert of this years Caramoor International Music Festival. The beginning of Opus 109  Sonata No. 30  sounded like a tangled wealth of notes that took all the work of 10 fingers to keep under control. This was, of course, an interpretive decision; if the music sounds difficult in the hands of Ms. Uchida, it is definitely because she wants it to.

title: Memo Pad

Eliot Spitzer last week. The legislation, originally drafted by a state assemblyman from Queens, Michael N. Gianaris, would take effect Jan. 1, although the airline industry has said it is considering a legal challenge. The Airline Passengers Bill of Rights came in response to instances of passengers being stranded for hours on parked planes, with inadequate ventilation and food and deteriorating hygienic conditions. On Feb. 14, for example, thousands of JetBlue passengers sat on parked planes during a snow and ice storm for as long as 10 hours at Kennedy International Airport.

Mr. Gnther declined to comment on the conflict, as did Guenter Gaugler, a spokesman for Infineon.

title: METRO BRIEFING | NEW YORK | Manhattan: Leadership Posts Lost

The Queens councilman, a Republican, had volunteered to give up his positions as minority whip and on several committees at the suggestion of Speaker Christine C. Quinn, she said. We are deeply, deeply troubled by the allegations and the charges that are pending against council member Gallagher, Ms. Quinn said at a City Hall news conference. Thats why we believe removing him from his leadership position and committees is an appropriate action. The Council declined to take further steps, citing a request from Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney, to defer any investigation or proceedings until the criminal case is resolved.

title: Ingmar Bergman Archive in Peril
description: The future of an Ingmar Bergman archive is in doubt, Variety.com reported yesterday, only days after the death of Mr. Bergman, the master filmmaker. Astrid Soderberg-Widing, one of five employees of the archive, in Stockholm, said that in addition to the $250,000 annual budget provided by the Swedish government, $600,000 was needed to digitize Mr. Bergmans papers. She said his early notes were written on paper so thin that it is nearly impossible to leaf through them. Uncertainty also surrounds the continuation of government financing after the current allocation ends in February. The archive was established by the Swedish Film Institute in collaboration with the Royal Dramatic Theater, Swedish Television and Svensk, a producer and distributor. Support could come from the Bonnier family, whose media holdings in Sweden include television and newspapers. We will see what we can do to save the archives, a representative of the family said. It is important not only to us; it is important for filmmakers, for scholars and for the Swedish culture that this heritage is not destroyed or wasted.

Ms. Lohan, whose films include Herbie Fully Loaded, was treated at the Wonderland Center in Los Angeles in January and, after a Memorial Day weekend that led to her arrest on suspicion of driving under the influence, she was treated at the Promises rehabilitation facility in Malibu, Calif. title: Japan: Broad Survey Points to Growth
description: Japans broadest indicator of the outlook for growth signaled for the first time in eight months that the economy would expand. The leading index climbed to 80 percent in June, the Cabinet Office said, the first time it has been at or over 50 since October. A reading of 50 or more indicates the economy may expand in three to six months. The index is derived from as many as 12 monthly indicators. The economy will probably accelerate in coming months as a pickup in U.S. exports brings a positive impact on the economy over all, said Takeshi Minami, chief economist at the Norinchukin Research Institute in Tokyo. As foreign demand remains robust, we can expect sustainable growth.

title: Farrow Offers to Take Sudan Prisoners Place
description: The actress Mia Farrow, above left, has told the president of Sudan that she is willing to take the place of Suleiman Jamous, above right, the ailing humanitarian coordinator for the rebel group Sudan Liberation Army who has been virtually imprisoned for more than 13 months, Reuters reported. Mr. Jamous, 62, has been confined to a United Nations hospital in Kordofan, east of Darfur, where he was moved by the United Nations without permission last year. He is in need of a stomach biopsy, which cannot be performed there. The government, based in Khartoum, has said he will be arrested if he leaves, but has declared itself open to discussing his release. In a letter to President Omar Hassan al-Bashir  of Sudan, posted yesterday on her blog at www.miafarrow.org, Ms. Farrow, who is also a Unicef goodwill ambassador, wrote: At the Inter-Sudanese talks in Abuja in 2005, before his seizure, Mr. Jamous played a crucial role in bringing the S.L.A. to the negotiating table and in seeking reconciliation between its divided rival factions. She said, I am therefore offering to take Mr. Jamouss place, to exchange my freedom for his in the knowledge of his importance to the civilians of Darfur and in the conviction that he will apply his energies toward creating the just and lasting peace that the Sudanese people deserve and hope for. International experts have estimated that 200,000 people have died and that 2.5 million have been driven from their homes in more than four years of fighting in Sudans remote west.

title: Bring Your Own Crossbones
description: Credit the artist Banks Violette with the recent surge in skull imagery, from consumer items to ludicrously luxe objets dart. The artists obsession with all things goth and death metal, and his collaboration with the hardcore band Sunn 0 have made him an art-world celebrity, and one of the youngest people ever to have a solo show at the Whitney. His latest exhibit, split between the Team Gallery in SoHo and the Gladstone Gallery in Chelsea, is a bit cooler than his previous work, Martha Schwendener writes  the metal artifacts on view, like exploded drum kits and liquor bottles, are literally frozen. And hes been moving toward performance art lately; catch this retrospective before he joins the line-up of Ozzfest.

description: A federal judge yesterday rejected New York Citys efforts to prevent the release of nearly 2,000 pages of raw intelligence reports and other documents detailing the Police Departments covert surveillance of protest groups and individual activists before the Republican National Convention in 2004.

title: The Contest Outside the Ropes at St. Andrews
description: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, Aug. 6  The gorse bushes on the Old Course were as thorny as advertised, and the pot bunkers were about as much fun to get out of as quicksand. But neither hazard worried the players at the Womens British Open as much as the one lurking outside the gallery ropes, in the realm of public opinion.

title: Bridge Collapse Revives Issue of  Road Spending
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 6  In the past two years, Gov. Tim Pawlenty of Minnesota twice vetoed legislation to raise the states gas tax to pay for transportation needs.

title: Inmates Have Political Pull in Some New York Counties
description: More than 6 in 10 people who live in the western New York town of Groveland have probably never heard of their representative on the Livingston County Board of Supervisors, James C. Merrick. They certainly have never voted for him.

title: A New Owners Unspoken Aggressiveness
description: The last time the Mets played the Atlanta Braves, the new ownership of the Braves was in place for only a week, certainly not time enough to make a difference. As the Mets prepare to play the Braves at Shea Stadium tonight, nearly three months later, the difference is palpable.

title: U.N. Worker Is Accused of Falsifying Visa Letters
description: A Russian citizen working in New York for the United Nations was arrested yesterday on charges of using the organizations letterhead to create fake documents that allowed several Uzbek citizens to illegally obtain visas to enter the United States.

title: Timbuktu Hopes Ancient Texts Spark a Revival
description: TIMBUKTU, Mali  Ismal Diadi Hadara held a treasure in his slender fingers that has somehow endured through 11 generations  a square of battered leather enclosing a history of the two branches of his family, one side reaching back to the Visigoths in Spain and the other to the ancient origins of the Songhai emperors who ruled this city at its zenith.

title: From Fresh Ideas and Better Steel, Safer Bridges
description: The collapse of the eight-lane steel-deck truss bridge last week in Minneapolis focused attention on deficiencies in many older spans around the nation. Despite these troubles, engineers say, new ideas and technologies are making bridges safer  not to mention longer and more beautiful  than they have ever been.

title: Universities Install Footbaths to Benefit Muslims, and Not Everyone Is Pleased
description: DEARBORN, Mich.  When pools of water began accumulating on the floor in some restrooms at the University of Michigan-Dearborn, and the sinks pulling away from the walls, the problem was easy to pinpoint. On this campus, more than 10 percent of the students are Muslims, and as part of ritual ablutions required before their five-times-a-day prayers, some were washing their feet in the sinks.

title: Guests, Running Late, Wake Up Hotels
description: Hotels have upgraded their beds, enhanced their technology, added more spa services and become more pet- and child-friendly in recent years. But their wake-up service? That is another story.

title: Reggae Songs in Anglican Hymnal
description: Songs by the reggae greats Bob Marley, below, and Peter Tosh, who practiced Rastafarianism, will appear in new Anglican church hymnals in Jamaica, The Associated Press reported. Church leaders preparing a new collection of hymns said Marleys One Love and Toshs Psalm 27 would be the first reggae tunes to appear beside traditional worship music on the island where reggae was born. The Rev. Ernle Gordon, a church spokesman, said members of the Anglican Church of Jamaica were enthusiastic about including the songs in the hymnals, despite the sometimes vocal opposition of Marley (1945-1981) and Tosh (1944-1987) to Christianity. They may have been anti-church, but they were not anti-God or anti-religion, he said.

title: Fail, Then Pass (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Rescuing a Student From a Life in the Mines
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Aug. 4  A sharp tongue does not preclude a good heart. Sterling proof of this truth is personified by Miss Moffat, the schoolmistress played with appealing zest by Kate Burton in the Williamstown Theater Festivals spirited revival of Emlyn Williamss 1938 comedy, The Corn Is Green.

title: Asia | India: Wal-Mart Wholesale Deal Set
description: Wal-Mart Stores and the Bharti Group of India have agreed to set up wholesale stores and a supply chain in India, eight months after they signed an initial agreement. Their venture will open its first wholesale store by the end of 2008, according to Rajan Mittal, the joint managing director of Bharti Enterprises, who spoke at a news conference in New Delhi. Wal-Mart signed a tentative agreement to start a wholesaling business with the Bharti Group in November. The venture, a 50-50 partnership known as Bharti Wal-Mart Private, is planning to open 10 to 15 wholesale stores over the next seven years to sell to small retailers, hotels and restaurants. The proposed Bharti venture would supply the retail market with goods that come directly from producers like farmers, craftsmen and artisans, Mr. Mittal said.

title: It Banishes Uterine Fibroids, but for How Long?
description: A little over a year ago, desperate for relief from uterine fibroids that made her menstrual periods last all month, Sharyn Sowell tried a new noninvasive procedure that uses focused high-intensity ultrasound beams to destroy the uterine growths.

title: Lottery Numbers
In Wireless Competition, Mockery Is the Latest Style
description: WITH growth in the wireless market slowing, Alltel is turning to a sophisticated online campaign to maintain and expand its customer base.

title: Judge Limits Navy Sonar, Citing a Threat to Wildlife
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 6  A federal judge on Monday ordered the Navy to stop using medium-range sonar in training exercises off Southern California, saying that the Navys own assessments predicted that dozens of marine mammals, particularly deep-diving whales, could be harmed by the intense sound waves.

title: In Dusty Archives, a Theory of Affluence
description: For thousands of years, most people on earth lived in abject poverty, first as hunters and gatherers, then as peasants or laborers. But with the Industrial Revolution, some societies traded this ancient poverty for amazing affluence.

title: $1.5 Billion Verdict Against Microsoft Is Set Aside
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 6  A federal district court judge delivered a major setback to Alcatel-Lucent on Monday by setting aside a jurys $1.5 billion judgment against Microsoft in a patent infringement lawsuit over digital music technology.

title: In a Hospital Stay, No Time to Rest
description: Grand Central Terminal may be synonymous with noise and haste. But as I recently discovered, it can be a lot quieter than a hospital bed.

title: Jews in Argentina Wary of Nations Ties to Chvez
description: BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 6  President Hugo Chvez of Venezuela said Monday that his country would help the government of President Nstor Kirchner refinance more of Argentinas debt and increase its energy supplies.

title: Jack Cole, Creator of People Locator, Dead at 87
description: Jack Cole, a businessman who used early computer technology to sort the world  or at least millions of the people in it  by street address, creating a series of reverse directories that remain invaluable to detectives, debt collectors, telemarketers and anyone who needs to find someone, died on July 29 at his home in Spearfish Canyon, S.D. He was 87.

title: Doping Is a Safety Issue (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Proper Care of Camel Hair, One Hump or Two
description: IN a hidden courtyard at the Bronx Zoo on a recent weekday, Ruth Iannuzzi soaped and scrubbed, then hugged, Alexander, 5, and Balkor, 3, a couple of two-humped camels from Asia who have had visitors doing double takes since they arrived at the zoo two years ago.

title: Pensions and the Mortgage Mess
description: Even as the plunge continues in investments tied to dicey mortgages, government regulators remain skeptical of the need for new rules to cover these newfangled derivative products or the hedge funds that tend to buy them.

title: Its a Female Dog, or Worse. Or Endearing. And Illegal?
description: The New York City Council, which drew national headlines when it passed a symbolic citywide ban earlier this year on the use of the so-called n-word, has turned its linguistic (and legislative) lance toward a different slur: bitch.

title: Poisonous Choices, Women at Risk
description: When the Supreme Court voted 5 to 4 to uphold the federal Partial-Birth Abortion Ban Act this spring, the ambivalently pro-choice public was largely quiescent, believing, as Congress had previously ruled, that the procedure was gruesome and inhuman, medically unnecessary, highly controversial in the medical community and so rare as to be little missed.

title: Woman, 20, Found Dead in Apartment Near N.Y.U.
description: Detectives are investigating the death of a 20-year-old woman whose badly decomposed body was found on Sunday wrapped in bedding in her mothers apartment at a Greenwich Village building owned by New York University, officials said yesterday.

title: Bonds Is Hailed, but Hits No Homers
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 6  Before Barry Bonds took a swing Monday night, he received two standing ovations. There was anticipation, a tingly expectation, that Bonds would hit a homer into the cool, dark night and become the career home run leader. But it never happened.

title: Bear Stearns Heir Apparent Tries to Restore Some Faith
description: Yesterday morning, the top 50 executives of Bear Stearns filed into the firms 12th-floor dining room. Nerves were taut  Bears president in charge of its bond business, Warren J. Spector, had just been forced out in the wake of the collapse last month of two of the firms hedge funds.

description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,657 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of these Americans over the past week:

title: 2 Charged in Connecticut Murder Appear in Court
description: NEW HAVEN, Aug. 7  The two men accused of the brutal murders of a Connecticut family during a home invasion last month appeared in court today under unusually high security to hear the charges against them.

title: Theater Briefs
description: Theater for a New Audience has announced its 2007-8 season, with three works exploring Europe and Americas relationship with Africa: The Ohio State Murders, by Adrienne Kennedy; Oroonoko, an adaptation by the Nigerian writer Biyi Bandele of Aphra Behns 1688 novella; and Shakespeares Antony and Cleopatra, starring Christine Baranski as Cleopatra.

title: Bridge Hero Gets Offer: Paid Tuition
description: Among the dozens of wrenching accounts to come out of the collapse of the Interstate 35W bridge in Minneapolis, the actions of 20-year-old Jeremy Hernandez were a bright spot: Trapped in a tipping school bus with 50 children, he kicked open the back door and began helping them one by one to safety.

title: Israel Removes Settlers in West Bank
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 7  Pelted by rocks and metal, hundreds of Israeli riot police today forcibly removed Jewish settlers from houses they had been occupying illegally for months in the West Bank city of Hebron.

title: Yale Is the Front-Runner in a Balanced Ivy League
description: NEW HAVEN, Aug. 6  When Jack Siedlecki, the Yale football coach, learned that the Bulldogs were a clear favorite to win the Ivy League championship, he said he did not think it was the kiss of death. Instead, he said, it was logical.

title: Family Guy Shows Its Muscle
description: With four Sunday reruns of Family Guy, which garnered the nights top ratings among adults 18 to 49, Fox led in that demographic over all, while CBS once again earned the title of most-watched network for the night. According to Nielsens estimates, the Family Guy episodes drew total viewer audiences ranging from 4.5 million viewers at 8 to 6.5 million at 9:30. Those numbers fell short of the competition on CBS, Big Brother at 8 (8 million), followed by a Cold Case repeat at 9 (7.2 million), which each led their respective time slots. At 7, CBSs 60 Minutes delivered 8.7 million viewers, the nights largest audience over all. NBCs Law & Order: Special Victims Unit (6.4 million) finished No. 1 in the 10 oclock hour, ahead of CBSs Shark in second place (6 million). NBC ranked second for the night in total viewers, but fourth in the 18 to 49 set. ABC, whose lineup typically leads the night during the regular season, finished third with reruns.

description: Akzo Nobel, the worlds largest maker of paints and coatings, raised its bid for Imperial Chemical Industries to 8 billion ($16 billion) and won access to the British companys books.

description: You cant manufacture  and shouldnt plan  a memorable call for a significant sports event. The best ones flow naturally. On Saturday, Barry Bondss 755th home run and Alex Rodriguezs 500th did not yield poetry.

title: Loss Widens at Trump Entertainment
description: The news only gets worse for Trump Entertainment Resorts.

title: The Fear of Fear Itself
description: It was appalling to watch over the last few days as Congress  now led by Democrats  caved in to yet another unnecessary and dangerous expansion of President Bushs powers, this time to spy on Americans in violation of basic constitutional rights. Many of the 16 Democrats in the Senate and 41 in the House who voted for the bill said that they had acted in the name of national security, but the only security at play was their job security.

title: Whats on Tonight
description: 10 P.M. (FX) DAMAGES Patty (Glenn Close) is faced with a threat to her litigation against one of the countrys wealthiest C.E.O.s (played by Ted Danson). Ellen (Rose Byrne, left), Pattys protge, learns what will be expected of her, and Tom (Tate Donovan) discovers some interesting information about Katie (Anastasia Griffith).

title: Yankees Two Young Catalysts Cook Up Another Victory
description: TORONTO, Aug. 6  Robinson Can had already doubled in the tying and go-ahead runs in the sixth inning Monday. As he crossed the plate on a single by Melky Cabrera, he clapped his hands in delight. Sure enough, at first base a moment later, Cabrera clapped, too.

title: Pacers ONeal Open to Deal
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 6 (AP)  Indiana Pacers forward Jermaine ONeal is not demanding a trade to the Los Angeles Lakers, but he is open to the idea.

title: Teacher-Astronaut to Fly Decades After Challenger
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6  Barbara R. Morgan is now an astronaut by profession, heading into space this week for the first time on the space shuttle. But she said she would be approaching her mission with the mind, eyes, ears and heart of a teacher.

title: Van Crash Kills Boy
description: A van from a summer camp in Sullivan County overturned on a highway in Maine yesterday, killing a 15-year-old boy and injuring 12 other people, authorities said. Two people were in critical condition. The van, from Camp Serene Springs in Bethel, N.Y., towing a trailer with canoes, was carrying 11 campers and two counselors for a trip to Maine so campers could canoe the Penobscot River and hike Mount Katahdin. The campers were all boys, 14 to 18. It overturned on Interstate 95 in Artgyle Township about 7 a.m., Stephen McCausland, a spokesman for the Maine Department of Public Safety, said. The victim was identidied by camp officials as Gedalya Rosenblatt. (AP)

title: Recalling a City in Fear During the Year of Son of Sam
description: Thirty years ago New Yorkers were held in horrified thrall as a serial killer armed with a .44-caliber revolver and calling himself Son of Sam prowled the nighttime streets for just over a year. He killed six people and injured seven, mostly in Queens and the Bronx, before being captured.

title: Security Crosses the Line: Confiscating Chocolate
description: Running a business that trains professionals who work in the oil, natural gas, power and green energy markets requires an energy reserve of ones own. I founded this business back in 1991, and travel at least twice a month, mostly internationally.

title: Spitzer Aides Linked to Effort to Tarnish Bruno Used Personal Accounts for Some E-Mail
description: ALBANY, Aug. 6  Top aides to Gov. Eliot Spitzer, including some at the center of an effort to tarnish the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, kept second BlackBerrys on which they sometimes communicated about political business, a spokeswoman for the governor said Monday.

title: Goodbye, George and John
description: Names matter. People named Dennis and Denise are disproportionately likely to become dentists. People named Lawrence or Laurie are disproportionately likely to become lawyers. People named Louis are disproportionately likely to live in St. Louis, and people named Georgia are disproportionately likely to move to the state that served as home in Gone With the Wind.

title: Bonds Still at 755 After 3 At-Bats
description: Barry Bonds returned to San Francisco on Monday to try to hit his 756th homer and break Hank Aarons career home run record. Bonds was ready, the San Francisco Giants were ready and the fans were ready. Even Willie Mays, Bondss godfather, was here for the potentially historic moment.

title: Americas Sagging Automakers
description: Robert L. Nardelli, who was just named chief executive at Chrysler, faces enormous challenges. Chrysler is in the midst of its fourth turnaround effort in three decades and Japanese companies like Toyota and Honda are surging. In July, foreign auto companies surpassed their American counterparts in monthly sales for the first time.

title: Sharing Paris
description: A look at a Parisian apartment with a shared ownership.

title: Anonymous Nat Stings (Old) Killer Bee
description: The night was supposed to be about Barry Bonds, but John Lannan made sure there would be no celebration in San Francisco. John Who? Lannan, a 22-year-old left-hander who was making his third major league start for the Washington Nationals, silenced one of the best hitters of all time and made sure the home run record would be shared for at least another day.

title: $100,000 Homes
description: Homes on the market in Pigeon Forge, Tenn., Seaside, Ore., and Boulder, Colo.

description: Images of Annie Sessler and her fish prints.

description: McDonalds said Monday that it had agreed to sell its meat-and-potatoes Boston Market restaurant chain to the private equity firm Sun Capital Partners for an undisclosed sum.

title: Temple-Inland to Sell Land and Pass Proceeds to Investors
description: The forest products company Temple-Inland, which is under pressure from the activist investor Carl C. Icahn, said Monday that it would sell 1.55 million acres of timberland to the Campbell Group for $2.38 billion and then issue a $1.1 billion special dividend.

description: There appear to be some mixed signals surrounding the proposed $25 billion buyout of student lender Sallie Mae.

description: At Bear Stearns, the torch, it seems, has been passed.

description: American Home Mortgage Investment filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection Monday in Wilmington, Del., capping a tumultuous 10 days for what had been one of the nations biggest home lenders.

description: Xstrata, which won a bidding war last year for Canadian nickel company Falconbridge, said Tuesday that it intends to offer 7.53 billion rand ($1.06 billion) for Eland Platinum Holdings of South Africa.

description: When Robert L. Nardelli was sent packing from Home Depot in January with a $210 million exit package and a reputation as an imperious chief executive who had made strategic blunders, he seemed tarnished forever.

description: Talks between the New York Stock Exchange and the New York Mercantile Exchange may be heating up.

description: Topps said Monday that rival Upper Deck is free to begin a $425 million bid for Topps, setting up a potential showdown for the maker of baseball cards and Bazooka bubble gum.

description: ICx Technologies, which develops sensing technologies used in the homeland security market, is seeking to raise as much as $184 million in an initial public offering, according to a regulatory filing Monday with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Canada Said to Mull Australian Media Rules
description: In the aftermath of three major takeovers in Canadas broadcasting sector, the nations regulators appear poised to consider revamping the rules on media consolidation, using a system pioneered last year by the Australian government, The Globe and Mail reported.

description: The billionaire Paul Allen is selling the majority of his stake in DreamWorks Animation SKG and stepping down from the board of the animation company he helped bankroll in its infancy.

description: The British cable operator Virgin Media postponed its $23 billion (11.3 billion) sale of the company on Tuesday after it became apparent buyers would not have access to the debt needed to do a deal right away.

description: Morgan Stanley on Monday shrugged off the turmoil in leveraged debt markets by appointing Peter Bacon to a new position as chairman of European financial sponsors, signaling a desire to expand its undersized private equity business.

title: Congressman Launches Private-Equity Blog
description: Blogging about private equity is so easy, even a congressman can do it, writes Dan Primack on PEHub. He is referring to New York Republican Tom Reynolds, whom he describes as an opponent of raising taxes on carried interest, which makes up the bulk of income of private equity managers.

description: The Weinstein Company/strong> has taken the wraps off a $285 million fund to fully finance the development, production, acquisition, marketing and distribution of a large slate of Asian-themed films over the next six years.

title: Saint-Gobain Cements Deal for Maxit Mortars
description: Cie. de Saint-Gobain, Europes biggest supplier of building materials, agreed to buy the Maxit unit of HeidelbergCement for 2.13 billion euros ($2.94 billion) to double its production of industrial mortars.

title: Indias Wipro to Buy U.S. Outsourcing Firm
description: Wipro is acquiring a United States outsourcing company, Infocrossing, in a deal valued at $600 million, the latest in a slew of overseas buys by Indian companies.

description: Venture capital investment has reached its highest level since 2001, according to a report scheduled to be released Tuesday.

description: Bear Stearns, in an effort to protect itself from shareholder lawsuits related to the collapse of two of its hedge funds, may establish a precedent for other failed hedge funds.

title: London Theater Journal: A 21-Day Marathon Nears Its End With a Subdued Execution
description: LONDON, Aug. 7  I attended a public hanging last night. It was, as you might imagine, a grim spectacle: the hooding of the head of the man to be executed; the sudden drop from the scaffold; the unbearable spastic twitching succeeded by the unbearable silence.

title: Archstone Says Deal May Be Delayed
description: The giant apartment landlord Archstone-Smith said Monday that the closing date of its purchase by a group led by Tishman Speyer and Lehman Brothers could be pushed back to the fourth quarter.

description: Amazon.com has led a first-round venture investment in AmieStreet.com, an online music store with a social-networking twist. AmieStreet, which is less than a year old, sets the price for downloads according to a songs popularity and allows users to rack up credits by recommending songs to their friends. The size of the funding round was not disclosed.

title: Tyco Posts $3.55 Billion Loss
description: Aug. 7 (Bloomberg) -- Tyco International Ltd. (NYSE:TYC) , the world's biggest maker of fire and security systems, posted a third- quarter loss of $3.55 billion on costs to settle a shareholder lawsuit and split the company in three.

title: Evercore Says Adjusted Earnings Doubled
description: Evercore Partners said Tuesday its adjusted pro forma net income nearly doubled from a year ago to $15.5 million in the second quarter. Advisory fees rose, as the investment bank picked up more revenue-generating clients and larger success fees, Evercore said.

title: Morning Buzz: More Police Surveillance Files; Newark Reeling from Killings; an N.Y.U. Death; and More

McFadden reports.The judge, Magistrate Judge James C. Francis IV, did agree to the deletion of sensitive information in the documents to protect the identities of undercover officers and confidential informants and to safeguard police investigative methods and the privacy of individuals caught up in investigations.

It is real enough that neighbors on the Lower East Side have been grumbling ever since a wall-sized poster for the Walbridge City Mall went up recently over an excavated lot on the block. Protest banners hang from nearby fire escapes. Walbridge Go Home, says one.

As a result, many of the investment banks that agreed to finance these deals are on the hook to make the loans themselves  at least until buyers and sellers can settle on a price and the debt can be resold.

description: Heres todays second Jack Kerouac post  having found this clip on YouTube, its impossible to resist.

The publication said Julius Baer is being advised by Goldman Sachs.

description: Since eBay acquired the Internet phone service Skype in 2005  a $2.6 billion deal widely believed to have been way too expensive, at least judging from the results thus far  it has refrained from making billion-dollar acquisitions.

title: Ex-Amaranth Trader Says New Firm Is On the Brink

title: Fred Thompsons Site Gets an Upgrade
description: Its one more sign that former Senator Fred Thompson is dipping in more than just his toe as he tests the waters for a presidential bid. By the look of the slickly revamped Web site his committee rolled out today, wed say hes in  at least knee-deep.

description: Micheline Maynard, The Timess Detroit bureau chief, reported today on the comeback of Robert L. Nardelli, who seemed tarnished forever after leaving Home Depot but has emerged at the top of Chrysler.

title: The Dalai Lama and Understanding Wikipedia
description: After three days at the Wikimania gathering of Wikipedia contributors in Taipai, with dozens of panels and presentations and even more chats in the hallways, its clear to me that the Wikipedia phenomenon can only be understood through contradictions. Here are some of the puzzles that may lead to enlightenment:

title: Realtors Jump Into Carried-Interest Debate
description: In what at first seems like an unlikely alliance, the National Association of Realtors has weighed in on the side of the private-equity industry in its fight against raising taxes on carried interest.

title: The Event at Apple Is About Events (in More Ways Than One)
description: Sometimes you feel like Steve Jobs could hold a press conference on the beach and declare this mornings tides the greatest movement of water in history. As regularly as the tides, Apple, like all technology companies, upgrades its products to take advantage of new and cheaper parts. And, like all fashion companies, it changes the look of its line to make its customers lust after the latest thing.

title: Principal Is Cited for Occult Cleansing Ritual
description: A principal at a high school in Lower Manhattan had heard the jokes about using a sage, or spiritual guru, to perform a cleansing of the building to counteract misbehaving students. The principal took the jokes seriously - performing a Santeria ceremony during the schools midwinter break in 2006, according to a report released today by the special commissioner of investigation for the New York City public schools.One day last winter, the principal, Martiza Tamayo, told an assistant principal, Melody Crooks-Simpson, that she had a friend who could do just that. Ms. Tamayo promised that the friend could burn sage and incense in the school and it would calm the students down, according to the report. (Santeria is an Afro-Caribbean syncretic religion, some of whose adherents believe in trances, animal sacrifice and sacred drumming and dance.)

title: From the Self-Referential Dept.
description: Brad Stone pulled the wraps off of Fake Steve Jobs before Dan Lyons, a.k.a. Fake Steve, and Forbes, his employer, could pull the wraps off Fake Steve Jobs on their own. That got a lot of people in a lather, as you can see from the comments to the blog post about the article.

title: The Browns Finally Sign Someone! (But Not a Player)
description: Yesterday, something that Ive been following professionally  the online secondary ticketing market  collided with one of my private interests, my hometown football team, the Cleveland Browns. The Browns announced that they would allow fans to resell their tickets through Viagogo.com, a European rival to StubHub that will now officially enter the American market.

title: Making Booker
description: The longlist for the 2007 Man Booker prize has been announced.

title: Words of Protest: Challenging Musics Lyrical Standards
description: To the shouts of Hey, hey, ho, ho, dirty lyrics has got to go, dozens of protesters marched amid the bustling crowd this afternoon in front of the Virgin Megastore in Times Square.The crowd came out in support of the Decency Initiative, a campaign by the Rev. Al Sharptons National Action Network to address lyrical standards in the music and entertainment industry. Mr. Sharpton was in Detroit, one of 20 cities where the initiative scheduled rallies for today.

description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer appeared in Jamestown, N.Y., today and gave an interesting and rather high-minded speech on the tension between power, humility and social justice. Quoting liberally from the famed cold war theologian Reinhold Niebuhr, Mr. Spitzer drew links between the Bush administrations handling of the Iraq war and his own efforts to clean up Albany  even alluding to recent occasions where those efforts went a little awry (this quotation comes from the prepared text):

description: The subprime mortgage market gave rise to trouble of a different sort on Tuesday, as MGIC Investment said that it believes it is not obligated to close its deal with the Radian Group. The nations largest mortgage insurer said in February that it would acquire its rival for $4.9 billion.

title: Capital One to Buy NetSpend for $700 Million
description: Capital One Financial, a credit card issuer and banking company, said on Tuesday it agreed to buy NetSpend Holdings, a marketer of prepaid debit cards, for $700 million in cash. The transaction is not expected to have a material impact on Capital Ones earnings per share until 2009.

Like Mr. Paul himself, the message is a mixture of traditional Republican pitches (the announcer says, Ron Paul has never voted to increase taxes) and those with a decidedly libertarian bent (text proclaims, Stop the national I.D. card).You can see the ad here.

description: CHICAGO  Labor groups are ready to hand out 10,000 rain ponchos, but hope their members wont have to use them tonight when the Democratic candidates and thousands of union members and leaders gather at Soldier Field.

description: Jozy Altidore, the New York Red Bulls 17-year-old striker, has landed a coveted gig in the sports world: He will appear on the cover of EA Sports FIFA Soccer 08 sold in North America.

title: U.S. Delays Decision on Grants for Congestion Pricing
description: Supporters of the mayors congestion pricing proposal will have to wait a few more days before getting a crucial federal go-ahead on the plan. The United States Department of Transportation, which had been slated to make an announcement on Wednesday about New Yorks status in a federal competition for more than $500 million in funds, now says the decision will be delayed.We wont be making the announcement tomorrow, said Brian Turmail, a spokesman for the department. We dont know when its going to happen.

Well try to keep the football metaphors to a minimum here, but whether one or the other was on offense or defense, we have to say that foreign policy issues  somewhat spurred by Senator Obamas recent Pakistan speech  and of course, the war in Iraq and trade issues, produced a few of the hottest exchanges on the stage.

Eventually the unfortunately-named HIPs will be required for all homes under the new law, which mandates that sellers produce a packet of inspections and disclosures to hand prospective buyers.

title: Wait a SecondIs Bonds Starting on Tuesday Night?
description: When Ron Wotus, the bench coach for the San Francisco Giants, ripped the lineup card off a bulletin board on Tuesday night, a buzz circulated around the clubhouse. Was Barry Bonds being scratched from the lineup? To be honest, the buzz was mostly among the reporters who are in San Francisco to chronicle Bondss pursuit of history.

description: The summer is ending and so is Matt's trip.  On his last and final week, he drives up the Pacific coast to Seattle, his final destination.

description: Michael D. Falkouski, a volunteer assistant fire chief in the Albany suburb of Rensselaer, was awakened at 2:30 a.m. on Jan. 23, 2005, in the middle of a blizzard. There had been an explosion and a bad fire; a man was severely burned.

title: Hey, Kids, Is Everybody Up for Some Guerrilla Warfare?
description: This slapdash sequel to Daddy Day Care finds its hero, Charlie Hinton (Cuba Gooding Jr., replacing the original films star, Eddie Murphy), taking over Camp Driftwood, the ramshackle day camp he attended as a boy. He hopes to expand his business; bond with his overprotected son, Ben (Spencir Bridges); and avenge an ancient humiliation by his childhood nemesis, Lance Warner (Lochlyn Munro), a rich swine who attended a rival day camp and now owns it.

title: Manhattan: Principal Faces Dismissal After Religious Ritual
description: A principal at a Lower Manhattan high school who performed a Santeria religious ceremony at the school and coerced an assistant to help pay for it is likely to be fired, officials of the Department of Education said yesterday. The principal of Unity Center for Urban Technologies, Maritza Tamayo, paid a friend $1,800 to perform a ritual that involved sprinkling chicken blood on the floors to wipe out negative energy and as an antidote to students who misbehaved, according to a report released yesterday by the departments special commissioner of investigation. During the school break in February 2006, Ms. Tamayo invited the friend to conduct the ceremony and urged an assistant principal to attend and pay $900, the report said.

description: Open Now

title: Doll, You Oughta Be in Pictures
description: Morton Bartlett is already considered a great outsider artist by many. But his achievement gains new dimensions in a revealing show of his photographs, drawings and sculptures at the Julie Saul Gallery in Chelsea. Bartlett, who was born in 1909 and died in Boston in 1992, is known for making a group of about 15 ivory-skinned, anatomically complete plaster sculptures of young children and adolescents. Most are female, and he fashioned exquisite wardrobes for them. Then he took small, haunting black-and-white photographs of the figures, usually clothed but sometimes naked.

description: Miami

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article by The Associated Press on Thursday about flight recorder transcripts released after a fatal plane crash in So Paulo, Brazil, on July 17 reversed the identities of the pilot and the co-pilot, and their final comments. The pilot was Kleyber Lima, and he gave the first indication something was wrong when he said, Only one reverser  spoiler nothing. It was the co-pilot, Henrique Stephanini Di Sacco, who responded: Look at that. Slow down. Slow down. Then Mr. Lima responded: I cant. I cant. Oh my God! Oh my God! Then Mr. Di Sacco said: Go! Go! Turn! Turn! Turn!

description: WestLB Mellon Asset Management suspended redemptions of an asset-backed securities fund yesterday amid investor concern about the problems in the subprime mortgage market in the United States.

title: Space Shuttle Set to Lift Off
description: The space shuttle Endeavour and its seven-astronaut crew are scheduled to lift off this evening and head to the International Space Station. The 10-minute launching window starts at 6:31 p.m. Forecasts give an 80 percent chance of favorable weather, with a small chance of showers the only concern. The Endeavour is carrying a truss segment to be added to the space station in the first of four spacewalks. The mission is scheduled to last 11 days, but will be extended to 14 days if a new system allowing the shuttle to draw electrical power from the station works as planned. NASA will broadcast the launching live at www.nasa.gov/multimedia/nasatv/.

title: Signature Theaters Hunt for New Home Continues
description: Having already lost a place it had been promised at ground zero, the Signature Theater Company now finds its downtown plans scuttled again: It will not relocate, as planned, to Fiterman Hall on West Broadway.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in The Arts on Saturday about In the Shadow of Justice, a documentary on Dateline NBC about the murder of a bouncer at a Manhattan nightclub, included incorrect information from the maker of the film, Dan Slepian, about its editing. While Mr. Slepian shot and assembled most of the film, it was edited by Rob Allen, not by Mr. Slepian.

description: Facing an overflow crowd of 15,000 at Wingate Park in Brooklyn on Monday night, Lauryn Hill said: Lets see how many people remember me. I know I havent been around for a while.

description: There are bands that shuffle humbly onto the stage of Madison Square Garden, happy to be there and nervous about filling the room with sound. (And with fans.) Then there is Muse.

title: Dyspepsia of the Soul While Training for Utopia
description: The idea that human beings are perfectible is probably as old as the human race. But where are all those primitive feelings of anger, lust and revenge supposed to go? And do gods, gurus and self-control really work? In his satiric parable Dysphoria, part of the Ontological-Hysteric Incubator series for emerging artists, Alec Duffy paints a picture on the wall of humanitys cave, and it isnt pretty.

title: All the Vulgar Charm, in a Smaller Box
description: TOLSTOY had it wrong about happy families, because there are none like the Shopsins.

title: Manhattan: Mayor Completes Jury Duty
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg joined the citys jury pool for a second day yesterday, but he was back to work at City Hall by early afternoon. The mayor was considered for a civil case involving a taxicab accident, but lawyers ultimately dismissed him. I dont take it personally, Mr. Bloomberg said later. I dont take any pride in not being picked, or dissatisfaction either way. Mr. Bloomberg, who spent his morning reading newspapers, postponed a jury duty call last summer because of the Queens blackout, a spokesman said.

title: For Champagne, Hors Doeuvres From the Sea
description: UPON arriving in Paris a couple of months ago, I headed for Rech, a 1930s fish restaurant that Alain Ducasse has taken over. I ordered Champagne. Then the waiter offered a plate bearing a small jar of gray stuff topped with glittering red beads of tobiko (flying fish roe) and slices of toasted baguette. I set to work on this somewhat loosely textured spread made of mackerel, and thought it was an excellent accompaniment for my flute of blanc de blancs.

title: Marion Barry to Be in Wax Museum
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8  A decade and a half after a videotaped cocaine arrest that would have ended most political careers, former Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. has won yet another election.

title: Whats on Tonight
description: 8:30 P.M. (ABC) THE KNIGHTS OF PROSPERITY An unlikely gang that steals from celebrities has a new target: Ray Romanos house. The group also stages the kidnapping of Louis, one of its members, hoping his wealthy father will pay the ransom. At 9:30, in a special episode, the plot against Mr. Romano, above, continues, but the gang realizes that it has overlooked a crucial detail.

title: Prez Digs Early Hole, and Braves Pile It Up
description: When Oliver Prez is pitching, it is easy to tell if the Mets are winning or losing without peeking at the scoreboard. Just look at the way he leaves the field after recording a third out. If the Mets are winning, Prez will race toward the first-base line and vault over it with the aplomb of an Olympic decathlete. If they are losing, Prez takes an entirely different approach.

title: Steelers Tomlin Expects to Last and Win
description: When Mike Tomlin attended the College of William and Mary, he worked at a place near campus called Pauls Deli Restaurant. The owner, Peter Tsipas, had no idea that Tomlin would eventually become an N.F.L. head coach, but he recognized early that Tomlin was hungry. Not just hungry to succeed, but hungry  period.

Trump even envisioned pocketing $500 million from selling at a handsome premium his one-third stake in this company bearing his name.

description: For students starting college, August is the time to quit the summer job, dump the high school sweetheart and, finally, open the book their college has asked them to finish before classes start.

description: EDINBURGH, Aug. 7  Producers must have fantasized about it. Couldnt we just eliminate the actors?

description: Over a three-day period in June, four New York traffic agents gave the impression they were busy by issuing a multitude of tickets. But as it turns out, they issued dozens of those tickets from the comfort of their cars or while enjoying a meal, according to police officials.
