title: Court Papers Said to Show Added Payments by Reporter
description: A former New York Times reporter who wrote an article in late 2005 about a teenager who operated a pornographic Web site may have sent more money to the young man than he had previously acknowledged, according to people familiar with sealed documents filed with a court in Tennessee.

title: Georgia Accuses Russia of Missile Attack; Moscow Denies It
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 7  Officials of the Republic of Georgia accused Russia on Tuesday of violating the countrys airspace and firing a guided missile, which did not detonate, into Georgian territory.

description: Boulder, Colo.

title: Queens: Passenger Sneaks Monkey Aboard Plane
description: A man and his small spider monkey were detained yesterday after a flight crew alerted airport officials that they had a monkey aboard their aircraft en route to La Guardia Airport. The man boarded a Spirit Airlines flight on Monday night from Lima, Peru, to New York by way of South Florida, but did not report that he had a monkey with him, an airline spokeswoman said. It was only on the second leg of the flight, from Fort Lauderdale, that other passengers noticed the monkey. It was clinging to his ponytail underneath his hat, said Alison Russell, the airlines spokeswoman. When the plane landed at 3:01 p.m. yesterday, the monkey was turned over to New York City Animal Care and Control, and the man, who was not named by airport officials, was turned over to federal officers for questioning, said Pasquale DiFulco, a spokesman for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which runs La Guardia Airport. How the passenger got through security, I cant begin to say, Ms. Russell said.

title: Tintin Prompts a Suit
description: A Congolese student has initiated legal action in Belgium to have the 1931 comic book Tintin in the Congo declared racist and removed from bookstores, Reuters reported. Its racist, and it is filled with colonial-era propaganda, said the student, Mbutu Mondondo Bienvenu, who lives in Brussels. He is also seeking symbolic damages of one euro ($1.38) from Moulinsart, a company that owns the rights to Tintin but does not publish the comic. Belgian prosecutors said a judges decision on proceeding with Mr. Bienvenus motion could take six months. A spokesman for Moulinsart said: The book dates back to 1931 and has to be seen in the context of the time. We are surprised to see this complaint after so many years. Some stores in Britain and the United States have moved the book from their childrens shelves to the space for adult graphic novels. This year is the 100th anniversary of the birth of Georges Remi, the writer and artist who created the popular series under the name Herg.

title: Starbuckss New Book
description: Starbucks has announced its latest book selection: Listening Is an Act of Love: A Celebration of American Life From the StoryCorps Project. Published by the Penguin Press and edited by the Peabody Award-winning radio documentary producer and StoryCorps founder Dave Isay, it comprises 50 stories reflecting everyday American lives that were drawn from more than 10,000 recordings from the StoryCorps oral history project. The book and a CD set will go on sale on Nov. 8.

title: Lunch Recipe: Take One 7-Year-Old ...
description: THERE are plenty of ways to flatten a pan bagnat, the traditional tuna and vegetable sandwich from Nice. You could weight it with heavy books, or with a nice fat brick. You could squeeze it under a cast-iron skillet piled with cans, or press it beneath a stack of plates. Or you could find a child of about 7 and simply have her sit on it.

title: Russias Castaway Intellectuals in Revolutions Wake
description: In 1922, five years after the Bolshevik revolution, no one knew where Russia was headed. In an about-face, Lenin had initiated the quasi-capitalist New Economic Policy. For the moment, a nervous sort of freedom persisted, notably in the arts but, to a limited degree, in politics as well. Anyone looking for a portent, however, might have noticed a ship leaving Petrograd that September, carrying into permanent exile a carefully selected group of writers, intellectuals and scholars whose ideas the Bolshevik regime found objectionable. The Philosophy Steamer, as it came to be known, was followed six weeks later by a second ship. The machinery of totalitarianism was kicking into gear.

title: A Moment of Stray Voltage, and a Life Upended
description: It was one of the muggiest days of the summer a decade ago. Philip Vanaria had gone for a walk in Greenwich Village, where he had lived most of his adult life. A friend wanted ideas for his birthday, which was coming up. At the corner of Hudson and Morton Streets, he called her from a pay phone.

title: Bill Aims to Spur Housing for New Yorks Poor
description: New York City officials and state legislators have reached an agreement to overhaul a popular tax break for apartment building developers. The aim of the revision is to encourage the construction of tens of thousands of apartments for New Yorkers of limited means.

title: Injured Beltrn Hopes to Return This Week
description: Carlos Beltrn hit, ran and played catch yesterday for the first time since straining his left oblique muscle July 25. He said he was feeling better, but was not yet well enough to play in a game.

title: Tale of Ruling Class Privilege Touches a Nerve in Italians
description: ROME, Aug. 7  In the opening chapter of The Caste: How Italian Politicians Became Untouchable, readers learn that Italy has a unique sense of altitude.

title: Salzburg Festival Loses a Soprano
description: The Russian-born soprano Anna Netrebko, below, has become the latest in an extended list of talent to withdraw from the Salzburg Festival. Ms. Netrebko, who was to have performed a stabat mater by Pergolesi this week at the event in Austria, said she was suffering from laryngitis, Agence France-Presse reported. Jrgen Flimm, artistic director of the festival, said, We are very disappointed with Anna Netrebko, that she lets us down. Among those who have pulled out of the festival for various reasons this summer are the soprano Patricia Petibon, the tenor Neil Shicoff and the tenor Rolando Villazn, PlaybillArts.com reported.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A music review on Monday about a Beethoven program at the Mostly Mozart Festival misidentified the key of the Mass in which movements were played. It was C major, not C minor.

title: Moodys to Reorganize Into 2 Units
description: Moodys said yesterday that it would reorganize into two divisions, separating its credit ratings unit from sales, marketing and analytics to underscore the independence of its opinions on debt securities.

description: Following is the text of a statement released by the Federal Reserve yesterday after the Feds monetary policy panel, the Federal Open Market Committee, decided to leave interest rates unchanged.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A brief article in Science Times yesterday about the possibility that a persons reading level might protect against neurological damage from lead exposure misspelled the given name of an author of the study. She is Dr. Margit L. Bleecker, not Margrit.

title: In Case of Apocalypse Later, a Plan to Ensure Americas Regreening
description: The botanists forged through a thicket and crossed a rocky ravine bed. Their quarry, Polygonatum pubescens, was proving elusive. But they would not rest. They had promised a shipment of its seed to their partners in a bunker across the ocean.

title: Fed Leaves Rate Steady; No Sign of Future Cut
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7  The Federal Reserve kept its key interest rate unchanged on Tuesday and signaled that it still expected to avoid cutting short-term rates despite the recent tumult in credit markets and on Wall Street. The Fed suggested that it would change course only if economic conditions deteriorate badly in the weeks and months ahead.

title: Iran: Another Reformist Paper Closed
description: The authorities shut down Shargh, a leading reformist newspaper, after it published an interview with an Iranian poet who lives in exile and writes about female sexuality, Saghi Ghahraman. It was the third time the paper has been ordered closed, and it was unclear when it might be allowed to resume publishing. The closing was another sign of the increasing pressures on press freedom. In May, the authorities shut down the reformist newspaper Hammihan, and last week, a journalist and blogger, Soheil Assefi, was arrested.

title: A Less-Expensive Way to Own in Paris
description: Ever since she and her late husband spent their honeymoon in Paris more than 20 years ago, Dr. Iris Litt-Vaughan had dreamed of owning an apartment there.

title: War on Terror Takes Focus at Democrats Debate
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 7  The Democratic presidential candidates tangled over foreign policy Tuesday night, criticizing Senator Barack Obama for proposing an attack against Al Qaeda in Pakistan. He struck back at his rivals who had supported the Iraq war, saying they had engineered the biggest foreign policy disaster of our time.

title: Potential Flaw Is Found in Design of Fallen Bridge
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 8  Investigators have found what may be a design flaw in the bridge that collapsed here a week ago, in the steel parts that connect girders, raising safety concerns for other bridges around the country, federal officials said today.

title: Some Words About Interpreting
description: Correction Appended

title: For a Young Wallace, Success Is Slow to Come
description: Steve Wallaces stock-car driving career was supposed to take off this year. Wallace, the 19-year-old son of the 1989 Winston Cup champion Rusty Wallace, had won in almost any kind of car he raced. He was a prodigy with a pedigree.

title: Pete Doherty Warned
description: A disheveled Pete Doherty, below, was warned yesterday that he faces jail unless he proves his determination to quit drugs within a month, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Doherty, 28, the lead singer of Babyshambles, appeared in West London Magistrates Court, where Judge Davinder Lachlar said: If he does not show his motivation, its prison, as simple as that. Depending on what information I have when you next come to court, the decision will be made. Mr. Doherty has admitted possessing crack cocaine, heroin, marijuana and ketamine, as well as two driving offenses. Judges previously ordered him to take part in a detoxification program, but a review yesterday of his progress found he had since tested positive for drugs. A hearing was scheduled for Sept. 4.

title: Chris Schwarz, 59, Dies; Photographer Who Honored Polish Jews
description: Chris Schwarz, a freelance photographer who roamed the ancient heartland of Polish Jewry to record remnants of a disappeared people, then opened a museum to celebrate their cultural heritage, died July 29 at his home in Krakow, Poland. He was 59.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on July 29 about the uneven quality of medical care for cancer gave an incomplete list of cancers that can be prevented or cured with surgery alone. Skin, cervical and colorectal cancer can be prevented if precancerous lesions are detected and removed. Melanoma and other skin cancers, along with cancers of the prostate, breast, colon, rectum and cervix, can sometimes be cured with surgery if diagnosed early and removed. Colorectal and cervical cancers are not the only ones preventable or curable by surgery alone.

title: Bonds Hits No. 756 to Break Aarons Record
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 7  Barry Bonds swung and then immediately threw his arms in the air, realizing that he had become the most prolific home run hitter in major league history. Everyone in the ball park instantly realized the importance of what they had witnessed as well, watching Bondss latest and most important white streak soar into the night.

title: 2 Lenders Voice Confidence as 2 Others Curb Operations
description: The Countrywide Financial Corporation and the CIT Group said they would be able to ride out the mortgage industrys credit squeeze as two more rivals, the HomeBanc Corporation and Impac Mortgage Holdings, curtailed new loans.

title: Blast Cause Wont Be Known for 2 Months, Con Ed Says
description: Consolidated Edison said yesterday that it would be at least two more months before the company knew what caused a steam pipe to explode three weeks ago in Midtown Manhattan.

title: The End of the Road
description: "NOTHING but sagebrush for 130 miles, said the construction worker in the orange vest who was temporarily blocking U.S. Highway 20 in southeastern Oregon. As the Volvo idled in the midday heat, I looked past her at the landscape  at the dry, slowly rising hills matted with blue-green-purple tufts of hip-high scrub  then down at my map, and was impressed with her precision: For almost exactly 130 miles to the east, south and west, there was indeed nothing but sagebrush. This really was the desert. I shut off the engine and crossed my fingers, hoping the car and I would survive.

title: U.S. Says Iran-Supplied Bomb Kills More Troops
description: BAGHDAD, Aug. 7  Attacks on American-led forces using a lethal type of roadside bomb said to be supplied by Iran reached a new high in July, according to the American military.

title: Accusations of Impeding Murder Case
description: A woman was charged yesterday with interfering in the murder case against her brother and two other men, who have been accused in the shooting of two police officers during a traffic stop in Brooklyn last month.

title: The Almighty Ruble
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 6  The ruble got no respect.

title: Free Lunch on Health? Think Again
description: The great hope of every health care reformer is that better care will mean cheaper care.

title: Georgia Offers Evidence That Russia Fired Missile
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 8  The Republic of Georgia presented what it called a mounting body of evidence today that a Russian warplane had entered deep into its airspace and fired an air-to-ground missile. It said it was seeking a special session of the United Nations Security Council to address the incident.

title: Before the Big Night: Beethoven, Sweat, Tears
description: Sex, drugs and chamber music! Slapped on a bumper or emblazoned across a T-shirt, that phrase wouldnt have the incendiary ring of the celebrated original, would it? Nevertheless, those are three key elements in Opus, an absorbing new play by Michael Hollinger that opened last night at the 59E59 Theaters as part of the Primary Stages season.

title: Why Terrorists Arent Soldiers
description: THE line between soldier and civilian has long been central to the law of war. Today that line is being blurred in the struggle against transnational terrorists. Since 9/11 the Bush administration has sought to categorize members of Al Qaeda and other jihadists as unlawful combatants rather than treat them as criminals.

title: Police Fight to Remove West Bank Settlers
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 7  Pelted by rocks and chunks of metal, hundreds of Israeli riot police officers on Tuesday forcibly removed Jewish settlers from houses they had been occupying illegally for months in the West Bank city of Hebron.

title: NBC to Air Games on Internet
description: NBC Universal Sports will stream 2,200 hours of live Summer Games coverage free from Beijing next year on its Web site, nbcolympics.com. It is the first time that NBC, or any network, has carried the Olympics on the Internet. . The broadband coverage will augment another 1,400 on NBC, USA, MSNBC, CNBC and Telemundo.

title: Dont Knock Bergman Off His Pedestal (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: A Spy Chiefs Political Education
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7  Last Thursday evening, during the frantic endgame of a White House push to broaden its eavesdropping authorities, Democratic leaders from the House and the Senate gathered in the Capitol office of Nancy Pelosi, the speaker of the House, for a conference call with Mike McConnell, the nations top intelligence official.

title: Cooking Up More Uses for the Leftovers of Biofuel Production
description: The baking tins and muffin cups lining the countertops in a corner of Ronald Holsers cluttered laboratory were filled with curious substances resembling angel food cakes and loaves of bread.

title: Judge Dismisses Law on Violent Video Games
description: A federal court has struck down as unconstitutional a California law to label violent video games and prohibit their sale to minors, Reuters reported. The decision, by Judge Ronald Whyte of the District Court for the Northern District of California, said, At this point, there has been no showing that violent video games as defined in the Act, in the absence of other violent media, cause injury to children. He continued, In addition, the evidence does not establish that video games, because of their interactive nature or otherwise, are any more harmful than violent television, movies, Internet sites or other speech-related exposures. The Video Software Dealers Association and the Entertainment Software Association had argued that their games were protected under the free-speech clause of the First Amendment. The law was passed in 2005 with strong backing from Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger, after many legislators argued that violent video games could cause psychological harm and incite aggressive behavior in minors. The governor said he would appeal Judge Whytes decision.

title: Announcers Offer Balance After 756th
description: The Barry Bonds ESPN Road Show finally ended last night. It was a peculiar and enervating march toward the finale, freighted not only with accusations of steroid use, but also the irregularity with which he was still hitting home runs. This was not the Mark McGwire-Sammy Sosa Dinger Derby of 1998, when Fox and ESPN stumbled over each other to carry the games they were playing so as not to miss a crucial homer.

title: For an Iraq Contractor, Duty, and Then Death
description: SOUTHERN PINES, N.C., Aug. 5  Brenton Thomas Gray was no longer a soldier when he died a soldiers death last August on a northern Baghdad road. There were an armored car, a curbside bomb, a sizzling explosion. The sky went black with smoke and melting tar.

title: Correction
description: A front-page article on July 29 about the uneven quality of medical care for cancer gave an incomplete list of cancers that can be prevented or cured with surgery alone. Skin, cervical and colorectal cancer can be prevented if precancerous lesions are detected and removed. Melanoma and other skin cancers, along with cancers of the prostate, breast, colon, rectum and cervix, can sometimes be cured with surgery if diagnosed early and removed. Colorectal and cervical cancers are not the only ones preventable or curable by surgery alone.

title: Russia: Prison for Activists Killers
description: A St. Petersburg court sentenced four young men to prison terms of up to 12 years for their roles in a stabbing attack in the city in 2005 that killed Timur Kacharava, left, a 20-year-old student who belonged to an antifascist group that campaigned against hate crimes. Three young men received suspended sentences. The harsh sentences are a victory for prosecutors and rights groups who complain that Russian courts have underplayed the extent of neo-fascist violence in the country by handing down light punishments for hate crimes.

title: In Bridge Collapse, Refugee Group Faces a New Ordeal
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 7  Among the hardest hit in the bridge collapse last week was a group that had survived war and strife in their homeland, Somalia, and a move across the world to settle here.

title: Russia: Top Court Upholds Ban on Party
description: The Supreme Court upheld the Moscow City Courts ban of the National Bolshevik Party as an extremist organization. The small fringe party has gained notoriety for its vocal and theatrical antigovernment demonstrations. The groups leader, the writer Eduard Limonov, said in a telephone interview that he did not expect the latest ruling to affect its activities, including participation in the Other Russia coalition, a loose movement of anti-Kremlin forces that includes the former chess champion Garry Kasparov. They will not shut us up, Mr. Limonov said. We have no fear. He said the party would appeal the ruling to the European Court of Human Rights.

title: Rhodes Is Lights, Camera, All Action
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Aug. 7  For Jets safety Kerry Rhodes, reporting to training camp means turning a page. It means leaving behind his off-season pursuits  parts in two movies, a magazine cover shoot, raising money for childrens scholarships in Alabama  and immersing himself in football again.

title: 4 Americans Killed in Bombings in the Baghdad Area
description: BAGHDAD, Aug. 7  Roadside bombs killed four American soldiers in and around the capital, the United States military said Tuesday, and a proposal for an expanded United Nations role in Iraq moved closer to a vote.

title: Two Little-Known Pitchers Have Kept Bonds in Check
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 7  Two ballplayers stand atop the career list, one beefy and one slender, one active and one retired, one left-handed and one right.

title: Progress Reported in Drilling for Miners
description: Rescue teams have drilled about one-third of the way down the 1,500-foot distance to where six coal miners have been trapped underground since early Monday, a mine official said today.

title: Suspects Face Jeers and Victims Family in New Haven
description: NEW HAVEN, Aug. 7  With roughly a dozen members of the Petit family sitting grimly in the front two rows, the two parolees accused of murdering three of their relatives during a brutal home invasion last month in Cheshire appeared in court on Tuesday under intense security.

title: Leaders of 2 Koreas Will Meet in the North
description: TOKYO, Wednesday, Aug. 8  The two Koreas announced Wednesday morning that they would hold a summit meeting later this month, the first since a groundbreaking meeting in 2000 began an ongoing reconciliation process on the Korean peninsula.

title: Wells Still in the Rotation for Padres
description: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 7 (AP)  The latest poor start for David Wells will not cost him a spot in the rotation with the San Diego Padres.

title: Court Rejects the Right to Use Drugs Being Tested
description: A federal appeals court ruled yesterday that patients with terminal illnesses do not have a constitutional right to use medicines that have not yet won regulatory approval.

description: To the Editor:

title: An Ice Cold War
description: Aboard Training Vessel Arctic Tern, off Newport, R.I.

title: 32 Killed in U.S. Raid in Iraq Shiite Stronghold
description: BAGHDAD, Aug. 8  An American raid and airstrike killed 32 people in the Shiite stronghold of Sadr City today, in what American military officials described as the latest assault on a network linking Iraqi militants with money and deadly roadside bombs from Iran.

title: Secrets of the Police
description: The city of New York is waging a losing and ill-conceived battle for overzealous secrecy surrounding nearly 2,000 arrests during the 2004 Republican National Convention. Yesterday, for the second time in three months, a federal judge ordered the release of hundreds of pages of documents that detail the Police Departments covert surveillance leading to the convention. People who were detained, some for days and without explanation, may finally begin to get some answers.

title: Burn Victims One Thought After Blast: Make It Stop
description: The seriousness of what had just happened did not register with Judith Bailey until she looked into a mirror. Layers of skin were peeling off her body. My skin was gone, she recalled yesterday in an interview from her hospital bed.

title: When Cooks Dreams Outgrow Their Ovens
description: DEBBIE BONNERS carrot cake, with its moist, macadamia-spiked layers, pineapple tang and aroma of candied ginger, could have come straight from her familys kitchen in North Carolina.

title: Jones Apparel Gets New Bid for Barneys
description: The fierce bidding war over Barneys New York, the luxury clothing retailer, escalated today when a private equity firm from Dubai raised its offer to $942 million  $117 million more than it had originally bid for the chain.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: The Cheering Section article in sports on July 29, about the excitement among N.B.A. newcomers over posing for rookie trading-card photographs, referred incorrectly to Brandan Wright of the Golden State Warriors. He was chosen No. 8 in the draft by the Charlotte Bobcats and then traded to the Warriors; he was not drafted by the Warriors.

title: Founders of the Gap Now Plan a Museum
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 7  Even in this citys constellation of old-money heirs and dot-com multimillionaires, Donald and Doris Fisher hold a special place, having built a jeans and T-shirt shop into a global brand name known as the Gap.

title: Executive Once Seen as Candidate to Be Next Chief Steps Down at Fidelity
description: Ellyn McColgan, a Fidelity executive who had been considered an heir apparent to the chairman and chief executive, Edward C. Johnson III, resigned unexpectedly yesterday.

title: Investors Lining Up for Pieces of Seattles Comeback
description: The Seattle office market has made a spectacular recovery in the last few years. As a result many real estate investors want to park their money there. No one knows that better than Alfred Clise.

title: City Has Short List for Cutoff of Water
description: After spending much of the last year trying to fix its outdated and unreliable water billing system, New York City is finally getting tough on delinquent ratepayers  but only on 11 of them.

title: Manhattan: Airlines Seek Agents Testimony
description: A group of airlines and public transportation agencies sued the F.B.I. and the C.I.A. yesterday, seeking permission to interview five special agents and two intelligence officers who may have knowledge helpful in their defense of wrongful death lawsuits arising from the Sept. 11 terror attacks. The lawsuit was filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan by American, United, Continental, US Airways and Delta Air Lines, and the public agencies that run the airports in Boston and Washington, after the bureau and the agency refused to grant access. Richard Kolko, an F.B.I. spokesman, declined to discuss the suit. The C.I.A. press office did not return phone calls seeking comment yesterday.

title: A Kitchen Blitz, When 10 Minutes Seems Like an Eternity
description: This list was inspired by a recent Minimalist column on recipes that can be made in 10 minutes or less. But these recipes can be ready even faster, in 60 seconds or less. A skilled cook with imagination and a sense of adventure may feel free to improvise.

title: Shaky Results in Core Areas Deflate High Hopes for Boston Scientific
description: FOR some time now, Wall Street optimists were saying things about Boston Scientific like at these prices, there is not much downside risk. Alas, in the last month, the continuing decline in Bostons shares has made them look bad.

title: Knicks Morris Is Charged With Driving Recklessly
description: Knicks forward Randolph Morris was arrested and charged with reckless driving early yesterday morning in Lexington, Ky.

title: Giving Bottles a Second Life
description: Not long ago, we argued in this space that because America has some of the best tap water available, it is time to start thinking twice about drinking commercially bottled water. One big reason is that a lot of petroleum is required to manufacture and transport the plastic bottles, thus adding to global warming and other environmental problems. Of course, in certain circumstances bottled water is necessary. It is essential during emergencies  think Katrina  and it is certainly a better alternative when the only other drinks come loaded with calories.

title: Ex-Brocade Chief Convicted in Backdating Case
description: Federal prosecutors scored a guilty verdict yesterday in the first options backdating case to go to trial, securing a conviction that is expected to embolden them to pursue similar cases.

title: Mr. Gorbachev, Show Off This Bag
description: ABOUT a decade ago, Mikhail Gorbachev starred in a television ad for Pizza Hut, which praised America for delivering the benefits of capitalism to his country. Now he is trading in fast food for fine leather, appearing in an international print ad campaign for Louis Vuitton.

title: First a Hook, Then Ink: An Artists Catch
description: MONTAUK, N.Y.

title: All the Way to Timbuktu
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Some Quietly Intense Chills, Imported From Brazil
description: There is a deliriously inventive strain of popular music from the Brazilian state of Minas Gerais, best known from Milton Nascimentos hot streak of records in the first half of the 1970s. They are ambitiously cooperative, full-throated singing albums; they are also guitar-heavy and harmony-rich. Some prominently included a guitarist in his early 20s named Toninho Horta.

title: Nascar Driver Punished for Actions in Montreal
description: Nascar fined the driver Robby Gordon $35,000 yesterday for his vigilante-style antics at a Busch Series race Saturday in Montreal, and instead of suspending him, it placed him on probation for the rest of the year.

title: Raise a Glass for the Taste, Not the Toast
description: LETS begin with a couple of questions. Forgive me if I offer some answers as well.

title: Newark: Corrections Officer Fatally Shoots Gunman
description: A New Jersey corrections officer fatally shot a man last night on a street after the man pulled a gun on him, the Newark police said. The corrections officer, whose name was not released, was shot in the foot during the confrontation and was in stable condition at the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey Hospital. The officer was sitting on a porch on Grand Avenue about 9:30 p.m. when he was approached by the man, whom the police did not identify. The man then brandished a gun, the police said, and the officer fired. The state attorney generals office is investigating, the police said.

title: Cute Kitty Is Pink Badge of Shame in Bangkok
description: BANGKOK, Aug. 7  It is the pink armband of shame for wayward police officers, as cute as it can be, with a Hello Kitty face and a pair of linked hearts.

title: Britain Asks to Take Back 5 Guantnamo Detainees
description: LONDON, Aug. 7  In a shift in policy, Britain on Tuesday asked the United States to release five detainees at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, who have resided in Britain but are not citizens.

title: Music Found in Moscow May Be Hitlers
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 7  Hitlers outward hatred for Jews and Russians may have belied a secret passion for some of their greatest musical works, if a recently discovered cache of records proves to be the remains of his private music collection.

title: The Return of Foot-and-Mouth
description: You dont have to be an English farmer to understand the fear raised by the recent discovery of foot-and-mouth disease on two farms in Surrey. The last time there was an outbreak, in 2001, the farming north seemed to become a funeral pyre, and life in rural areas ground to a halt.

title: Bush Vows a Veto on Any Tax Increase
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8  With Wall Street skittish over the current state of financial markets, President Bush today described the economy as thriving and reiterated his belief that lower taxes are the best way to guarantee economic prosperity.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A report in the Whats Online column in Business Day on Saturday, about an Inc.com feature on young entrepreneurs, misspelled the surname of the owner of bestparking.com, which tracks parking garage rates in several cities. He is Benjamin Sann, not Samm.

title: Tornado Hits Brooklyn; Subway Back in Service
description: Most of the New York City subway system was back in service by this evenings rush hour after a fierce morning storm disrupted transit service throughout much of the region and unleashed a rare and destructive tornado that whipped southwestern Brooklyn with winds of up to 135 miles an hour.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: The Sports of The Times column on Monday, about Tom Glavines milestone victory as the Mets beat the Cubs, referred incorrectly in some copies to the accomplishment. It was his 300th career victory, not his 500th.

title: Veikko Karvonen, 81, Top Marathoner in the 50s, Dies
description: Veikko Karvonen, a Finnish postal clerk who became one of the worlds best marathon runners in the 1950s, died Aug. 1 in Turku, Finland. He was 81.

title: Viewers Tune In to Singing Bee
description: With a special hourlong Monday edition of Singing Bee, NBC surged into first place in the night in total viewers, while Fox remained the nights leader among adults 18 to 49. According to Nielsens estimates, the Singing Bee game show delivered 7.8 million viewers at 8, down from its recent average on Tuesdays at 9:30 but enough to make Bee No. 1 in the hour, just ahead of ABCs Wife Swap (6.4 million). After it, NBCs finale of Age of Love drew a series-best 7 million viewers in second place at 9. Fox came in first in the highly competitive time slot with Hells Kitchen, which drew 8.7 million viewers and the nights top ratings in the 18-to-49 demographic. Also at 9, the debut of ABCs Fat March attracted 4.4 million viewers in fourth place. ABC and CBS tied for third behind Fox and NBC in the 18 to 49 set. On Saturday 5.8 million viewers tuned in at 8 for Nickelodeons Drake & Josh: Really Big Shrimp, the largest audience for a made-for-television movie in the channels history.

title: Newark Officials Say They May Soon Identify a Suspect in the Killing of 3 Friends
description: NEWARK, Aug. 7  Through a survivors account and ballistic evidence, investigators here were close to identifying at least one suspect involved in the Saturday night killings of three friends in Newark, law enforcement officials said on Tuesday.

title: Abuses Belie China Pledge on Rights, Critics Say
description: BEIJING, Aug. 7  Human rights groups on Tuesday accused China of failing to improve its record on civil liberties, and of harassing lawyers, dissidents and journalists, despite official promises to make human rights a centerpiece of the 2008 Olympics in Beijing.

title: Ethanol Is Feeding Hot Market for Farmland
description: DEKALB, Ill.  While much of the nation worries about a slumping real estate market, people in Midwestern farm country are experiencing exactly the opposite. Take, for instance, the farm here  nearly 80 acres of corn and soybeans off a gravel road in a universe of corn and soybeans  that sold for $10,000 an acre at auction this spring, a price that astonished even the auctioneer.

title: Hollywood Starts Making Bollywood Films in India
description: MUMBAI, Aug. 7  An Indian woman in a flowing beaded gown glides through a pond. A mosquito net brushes over her lover. And to insistent drumbeats of the Indian heartland, a dancing phalanx of tunic-clad women twirls.

title: A Weak Dollar and the Fed
description: Despite the Federal Reserves stay-the-course message yesterday, investors are betting on at least one interest-rate cut by January, intended to quell turmoil in the markets and to juice the slow economy. But with the dollar also weak  recently hitting its lowest point in 15 years against an index of other major currencies  the Fed may be reluctant to oblige.

title: Good Scores on National Economics Test
description: The nations high school seniors performed significantly better on the first nationwide economics test than they did on other recent national exams in history and science, and demonstrated a better understanding of basic market forces like supply and demand than officials expected.

title: The Democratic Candidates Forum
description: The following is the transcript of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. candidates forum, as provided by Federal News Service.

title: Mangosteens Arrive, but Be Prepared to Pay
description: DONT be surprised if you see a round purple fruit in a locked jewel case at the grocery. Small shipments of fresh mangosteen, a Southeast Asian fruit legendary for its exquisite flavor but long unavailable legally on the United States mainland, started coming in last week from Puerto Rico.

title: Nurse Practitioners (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Consumers Picked Up Pace of Borrowing in June
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (Bloomberg News)  Borrowing by American households rose more than forecast in June, as consumers turned to credit cards and nonmortgage loans to maintain spending.

title: Should This Milk Be Legal?
description: THERE was the name of a Web site scrawled on cardboard and quickly torn to bits by an anonymous farmer in the Greenmarket at Union Square. Then came the paperwork, legal enough presumably, to protect the source of the illicit substance. Finally, Yaron Milgrom-Elcott received the monthly drop site: an address near Chelsea, open for two hours, show up or lose the white stuff.

title: Canada: U.S. Seeks New Ruling in Lumber Dispute
description: The United States resumed its trade dispute over Canadian softwood lumber, just 13 months after signing an agreement intended to settle the decades-old issue. Susan C. Schwab, the United States trade representative, said in a statement that she would seek binding arbitration over allegations that Canada is not upholding its commitments under the accord. The United States contends that Canada should have begun reducing exports from British Columbia and Alberta in January and that it gives the lumber industry in Ontario and Quebec unfair assistance. David Emerson, Canadas international trade minister, said in a statement that the dispute stems from differing interpretations of the Softwood Lumber Agreement by Canada and the U.S.

title: Stricker Traces Upswing to Trailer
description: TULSA, Okla., Aug. 7  Two years ago in Madison, Wis., on a course sheathed in snow, Steve Stricker set out to find the remnants of his swing inside a three-sided trailer.

title: Serve Breakfast in Class, Advocates for Poor Urge
description: Advocates for poor children urged the citys Department of Education yesterday to serve free breakfast in classrooms, saying that the practice of serving it in cafeterias failed to attract most of the children who need it.

title: Checking Out Real Estate in New York to Make a Map, Not a Deal (Really)
description: The city that never sleeps is also the city that never stops rebuilding. Most New Yorkers  certainly any who have ever been awakened by jackhammers at dawn  realize that construction is simply a fact of city life.

title: Bonds Leaves Lasting Mark With No. 756
description: Its his record. Barry Bonds earned it with 756 disciplined swings. Lets give him a pass the way a thousand pitchers did. For one day, lets call a truce, the way the generals did in ancient Greece when athletes were headed to Olympia.

title: U.S. Set for a Crackdown on Illegal Hiring
description: In a new effort to crack down on illegal immigrants, federal authorities are expected to announce tough rules this week that would require employers to fire workers who use false Social Security numbers.

title: NBC Will Offer Olympics on the Internet
description: NBC Universal Sports will stream 2,200 hours of live Summer Games coverage free from Beijing next year on its Web site, nbcolympics.com.

description: Judge Dismisses Law on Violent Video Games

title: 101 Quick Meals? Make It an Even 111
description: SUMMER Express: 101 Simple Meals Ready in 10 Minutes or Less, the Minimalist column on July 18, clearly struck a chord.

title: Restaurateurs-to-Be Look Before Leaping
description: PASQUALE VIGGIANO and his wife, Geraldine, thought they knew the restaurant business. Ms. Viggiano had helped her mother run a cafe in Honduras and Mr. Viggiano had grown up hearing his parents fond tales of the luncheonette they opened when they came to Brooklyn from Italy.

title: Safety Issues Slow Mine Rescue Efforts
description: HUNTINGTON, Utah, Aug. 7  Efforts to reach six trapped coal miners came to a crawl on Tuesday as continued seismic activity forced out rescue teams, and drilling equipment began slowly chewing through thousands of feet of rock to where the men were working early Monday when parts of the mountain shook and fell.

title: Ancient Nomads Offer Insights to Modern Crises
description: ALMATY, Kazakhstan  Every summer for the past eight years, Michael Frachetti has come to the desert steppe that rolls like endless yellow waves across this expansive Central Asian nation searching for evidence of a vast, connected nomadic society.

title: Families of South Korean Hostages in Afghanistan Seek Solace, and a Solution
description: BUNDANG, South Korea, Aug. 6  Seo Jeong-bae was not too worried when his daughter and son, both Christians, told him last month that they were going to Afghanistan on an aid mission to help children in the Islamic country.

title: Two Brothers, One Down and One Out
description: The French filmmaker Christophe Honor was born in 1970, almost two years to the month after his country was seized by revolutionary fervor. By then, the New Wave had crested, and the no-longer-young Turks who had shaken up the art had moved on and apart.

title: One Fan Follows a Sluggers Chase From Behind Bars
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 7  Forty miles from the fireworks, the streamers and the flashbulbs, Greg Anderson could only hope to commandeer the television.

title: Boyfriend of Victim Slits Wrists, Police Say
description: A boyfriend of the 20-year-old woman whose decomposed body was found on Sunday wrapped in bedding in her mothers apartment in Greenwich Village was taken into custody last night after he slit his wrists on a rooftop on the Upper West Side, the authorities said.

title: Deputy Editor Is Out at Portfolio
description: Portfolio, a heavily promoted new business magazine that is about to publish its second issue, yesterday fired one of its top editors, James Impoco, according to several people at the magazine and the company.

title: Giants Playing Without a Net at Fullback
description: ALBANY, Aug. 7  Robert Douglas could be the loneliest member of the Giants, particularly when players chat with teammates at the same position. Or he could be the luckiest member of the Giants, especially when it is time for preseason cuts.

title: Some Wonder if Cash for Good Test Scores Is the Wrong Kind of Lesson
description: Should cash be used to spur children to do better on reading and math tests?

title: Corzine Selects a Colleague to Serve as His Chief of Staff
description: TRENTON, Aug. 7  Gov. Jon S. Corzine opted for loyalty and familiarity on Tuesday, naming Bradley I. Abelow, the state treasurer and a former colleague at Goldman Sachs, to be his chief of staff.

title: Stolen Picassos are Recovered
description: Two Picasso paintings and a drawing valued at $66 million have been recovered, and three suspects were under arrest yesterday in Paris in connection with the theft of the art in February from the home of the artists granddaughter, Diana Widmaier-Picasso, Agence France-Presse reported. The works are apparently in good condition, said her lawyer Olivier Baratelli. Ms. Widmaier-Picasso was asleep in her house in the Seventh Arrondissement when thieves took the oils Maya With Doll (1938), top, and Portrait of Jacqueline (1961), above, as well as the drawing.

title: More Generics Slow Rise in Drug Prices
description: A quiet coup is taking place in American medicine cabinets. Prescription bottles bearing catchy brand names like Zoloft and Flonase are being pushed aside by tongue-twisting generics like sertraline and fluticasone propionate.

title: Warming Threatens Farms in India, U.N. Official Says
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 7  As exceptionally heavy rains continued to cut a wide swath of ruin across northern India, a top United Nations official warned Tuesday that the vagaries of climate change could destroy vast swaths of farmland in this country, ultimately affecting food production and adding to the woes of already desperate peasants who live off of the land.

title: Shuttle Takes Off With Ex-Teacher on Board
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Aug. 8  Culminating a smooth countdown, the space shuttle Endeavour lifted off into the hazy, humid skies this evening, carrying pieces of the International Space Station and a living reminder of the loss of the space shuttle Challenger two decades ago.

title: Carnegie Tenants Gain a Reprieve
description: Thirty-three of the 45 tenants of the tower studios above Carnegie Hall have won a reprieve from plans by the Carnegie Hall Corporation to evict them to make way for renovations to expand the halls music education programs, which serve about 115,000 children, and improve its backstage space. The remaining 12 tenants are not part of the lawsuit. State Supreme Court Judge Eileen Rakower issued a temporary restraining order on Friday barring Carnegie Hall from further action until a hearing on the tenants case on Sept. 17.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A picture caption with an article yesterday about a debate at some colleges over the installation of footbaths that Muslim students can use in ritual ablutions before prayers referred incorrectly to footbaths at the University of Michigan-Dearborn. The university is planning to install them, but has not yet done so.

title: British Outbreak May Be Linked to Human Action
description: LONDON, Aug. 7  An investigation, ordered by Prime Minister Gordon Brown, on Tuesday concluded that the spread of foot-and-mouth disease among livestock at two farms in southern England was probably caused by human movement from nearby laboratory facilities that was either accidental or deliberate.

title: Spitzer Acknowledges Need to Wield Power With Humility
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer spoke on the tension between power and humility during a visit to the Chautauqua Institution yesterday, criticizing the Bush administration for failing to recognize its mistakes in Iraq while acknowledging that his own administration had allowed our passion to get the best of us in recent weeks.

title: Manhattan: Contract Settled With Police Lieutenants
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday that the city had reached a tentative contract settlement with the Lieutenants Benevolent Association, the union representing police lieutenants. The agreement, for 26 months beginning on Sept. 1, calls for an 8.16 percent wage increase and applies to roughly 1,600 supervisors, the mayor said.

title: The Joba Chamberlain Era Begins
description: It was an eventful night here at the Rogers Center, to say the least. Need a story line? Take your pick: Joba Chamberlains debut, Roger Clemenss stingy pitching or the bench-clearing fracas after Alex Rodriguez took a fastball in the calf from Josh Towers?

title: Home Run History
description: Barry Bonds hit a Major League Baseball record 756th home run last night. The achievement moves Bonds past Hank Aaron for career home runs. Several Sports of The Times columnists recalled other record-setting moments in baseball: Hank Aarons home run record, Maury Willss record for stolen bases in a season, Cal Ripkens consecutive games, Barry Bondss earlier feat, the most home runs in a single season, and Pete Roses career hits.

title: Morning Buzz: Suspect Caught in N.Y.U. Killing; Deal on Tax Breaks for Housing; Anguish and Anger After a Blast; and More
description: A boyfriend of the 20-year-old woman whose decomposed body was found on Sunday wrapped in bedding in her mothers apartment in Greenwich Village was taken into custody last night after he slit his wrists on a rooftop on the Upper West Side, Al Baker reports. The man, Michael A. Cordero, 23, later told doctors and nurses that he had killed his girlfriend, Boitumelo McCallum, a student at Mills College in Oakland, Calif., and the daughter of two New York University professors, the police said. While investigators had not named any suspects in the killing, they had said earlier yesterday that they were eager to speak with Mr. Cordero.The New York Post reports that a friend of Mr. Corderos entered the Sixth Precinct station house early Tuesday and told the authorities that Mr. Cordero had confessed to the crime. Citing the police, The Post reports that Ms. McCallum was probably killed on Thursday, the day after she held a raucous party at her apartment, at 4 Washington Square Village. According to The Post, a friend of Ms. McCallums in California told the police that Mr. Cordero regularly beat his girlfriend.

Escobar is filling in for the injured Edgar Renteria, who is out for a few weeks with a sprained ankle. Renterias average? Its a cool .336. Korns untitled new album (Virgin) opens at No. 2, with 123,000 sales; it is the bands seventh consecutive Top 10 album. Other new releases include the self-titled album by Sean Kingston, the 17-year-old Jamaican singer whose reggae-pop song Beautiful Girls is No. 1 on the singles chart. His album, released by Epic, opened at No. 6, with 75,000 copies sold. Kidz Bop 12 (Razor & Tie), with toddler-friendly versions of pop hits by Avril Lavigne, Gwen Stefani, Gym Class Heroes and others, reached No. 7 in its first week out, with 71,000 sales. Last weeks No. 1, Vol. 25 in the Now Thats What I Call Music! series, fell to No. 3 with 123,000.

title: An Exhibitions Artis in the Bag
description: After weeks of rumors, the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles confirmed yesterday that a retrospective of the work of Takashi Murakami, opening on Oct. 29, would include a fully functioning Louis Vuitton boutique, to sell handbags, above, and coin purses customized for the show by Mr. Murakami. The museum said that Louis Vuitton would pay for the construction and staff of the 1,000-square-foot boutique, and that no revenues from its sales would go to the museum, which receives some public financing. But at a time when several museums have been criticized for close relationships with commercial interests in the mounting of exhibitions, the museums officials took pains to justify their decision to include the store, saying that it symbolizes the interweaving of high art, mass culture and commerce that has become essential to Murakamis philosophy. Mr. Murakamis artwork has long included creating consumer and luxury goods. The museums chief curator, Paul Schimmel, who asked Louis Vuitton to participate, said the store would encourage viewers to experience the commercial work of Murakami as profoundly as they will the most complex paintings, sculptures and exhibitions.
