description: MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 8  Investigators have found what may be a design flaw in the bridge that collapsed here a week ago, in the steel parts that connect girders, raising safety concerns for other bridges around the country, federal officials said on Wednesday.

title: S. Carolina G.O.P. Moves Up Primary
description: CONCORD, N.H., Aug. 9  The South Carolina Republican Party has moved up its primary to Jan. 19, leapfrogging ahead of the Florida primary and setting the stage for more states to move up their contests, potentially pushing the nominating calendar into December and moving up the date of the New Hampshire primary.

title: Fossils in Kenya Challenge Linear Evolution
description: Two fossils found in Kenya have shaken the human family tree, possibly rearranging major branches thought to be in a straight ancestral line to Homo sapiens.

title: Dialing 911 With VoIP
description: Q. Is it true there is no 911 emergency call function if you have VoIP service?

title: NATIONAL REVIEWING | POLITICS | A Manager Without a Campaign
description: Just two weeks after Fred D. Thompson shook up his political committee  the one that is testing the waters as he gears up to run for the Republican presidential nomination  Mr. Thompson announced that he had hired a senior-level campaign-manager-in-waiting, William B. Lacy, a former strategist to Bob Dole and aide to President Ronald Reagan. Mr. Lacy, who is on leave from the Robert J. Dole Institute of Politics at the University of Kansas, also advised Mr. Thompson during his successful 1994 bid to represent Tennessee in the Senate. He helped revive a struggling campaign in which Mr. Thompson was trailing his Democratic opponent by a wide margin.

title: SPORTS BRIEFING | GOLF | Aboff Wins Womens Met Open
description: Susannah Aboff, a Princeton University junior, added a four-under-par 68 to her opening-round score of 72 to win the 20th Annual Lincoln Womens Met Open Championship at Ridgewood Country Club yesterday. Aboff of Huntington Country Club became the fourth amateur to win the event. Her round included one bogey, on the par-5 17th hole, along with five birdies.

title: The Blogs Are Alive With the Sound of Angry Democrats
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8  Progressive and liberal groups and left-leaning blogs are furious, tossing around fighting words like spineless, craven and weak.

title: Bush Faults Easy Money for Volatility
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8  President Bush, seeking to reassure Americans about the economy and combat Democratic criticism of his policies, said on Wednesday that recent financial market turbulence was not a cause for worry but a natural adjustment from the improvident lending of recent years.

title: Utah Coal Area, a Region Apart, Knows Well the Perils of Mining
description: HUNTINGTON, Utah, Aug. 8  Coal is probably not the first thing that comes to mind when people think about Utah, and there is good reason for that.

title: Woman Was Strangled, Medical Examiner Says
description: A 20-year-old woman whose body was found in a Greenwich Village apartment on Sunday was strangled and smothered with a towel, the medical examiners office ruled yesterday. Her boyfriend was charged with second-degree murder in the killing.

title: Theater Briefs
description: Chazz Palminteris  one-man show, A Bronx Tale, which played off Broadway in 1989 and was made into a 1993 film, will come to Broadway this fall, opening on Oct. 25 as a limited engagement at the Walter Kerr Theater. Jerry Zaks will direct the production, scheduled to run through Feb. 10.

title: Endeavour Ready for Evening Launch
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Aug. 8  The space shuttle Endeavour is fueled up and ready for liftoff at 6:36 p.m. today. Forecasts give an 80 percent chance of favorable weather, and launching preparations have proceeded without any glitches.

title: Johnson & Johnson Sues Red Cross Over Symbol
description: The red cross symbol is an icon of relief from disaster. For months, it has also been the subject of a festering disagreement between major American institutions: the health care company Johnson & Johnson and the American Red Cross.

title: Official at the Smithsonian Resigns After Meeting Transcript Is Destroyed
description: A high-ranking official has resigned from the Smithsonian Institution after acknowledging that he destroyed a transcript from an important Board of Regents meeting, the institution confirmed yesterday.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page article and picture caption on Tuesday about a surge of interest in the ancient books and texts stored in Timbuktu, Mali, misspelled the middle name of a Timbuktu resident whose family owns a 16th century Arabic text and whose ancestors ruled the city at its zenith. He is Ismal Diadi Hadara, not Diad. (Go to Article)

title: Miley Cyrusgoes Roaming
description: The singer, songwriter and actress Miley Cyrus, 14, will perform as herself and as her Disney Channel character, Hannah Montana, when she embarks in the fall on her 54-date Best of Both Worlds concert tour, beginning on Oct. 18 in St. Louis and ending on Jan. 9 in Albany. Ms. Cyrus, left, will perform at the Nassau Coliseum on Long Island on Dec. 27 and 28 and at the Prudential Center in Newark on Dec. 29 and 30. ... Paintings by Bob Dylan will hang among works by Picasso, Munch and Toulouse-Lautrec in an exhibition opening on Oct. 28 at the Chemnitz Art Collections in Germany, Agence France-Presse reported. The three-month show, The Drawn Blank Series, will feature more than 200 works in watercolor and gouache.... With seven nominations each, Justin Timberlake and Beyonc led the field of nominees for the MTV Video Music Awards, The Associated Press reported. Beyoncs Irreplaceable was nominated for video of the year, as was Mr. Timberlakes What Goes Around, co-starring Scarlett Johansson. Kanye Wests five nominations included video of the year (Stronger) and male artist of the year. The 24th annual Video Music Awards will be conferred during a live two-hour show on Sept. 9 at the Palms Hotel and Casino in Las Vegas.

title: South Carolina Joins in Race for Early Primaries
description: States jockeying for influence are continuing to move their presidential nominating contests earlier and earlier in a kind of accelerating domino effect.

title: Analyzing Iraq Optimists
description: About a third of Americans say the war in Iraq is going well. Maybe in the end, their steadfast support and optimism will be rewarded, but for now, theyre a decided minority, leaving those on the other side to ask, who are these people and why do they think that way?

title: Cable TV Is Having Breakout Summer
description: Cable television has always feasted on the summer audiences abandoned by the largely vacationing broadcast networks, but this season has been a spectacularly good one.

title: Bono, Foreign Aid and Skeptics
description: Almost nobody has campaigned so energetically for the poor in Africa as Bono, but when Bono spoke at a conference in Africa recently, he was heckled. Several Africans scolded him for demanding more foreign aid, saying thats not what Africa needs.

title: Jamaica Bay Marshlands (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Fewer Mexican Immigrants Are Sending Money Back Home, Bank Says
description: This year a smaller percentage of Mexican immigrants in the United States sent money back to their homeland than in 2006, according to a report released yesterday by the Inter-American Development Bank. The bank said the reduction had left at least two million people in Mexico without the same financial help they had once received.

title: An Easily Pocketed G.P.S. Tracker
description: Hansel and Gretel may have had bread crumbs, but this is the 21st century  theres no reason to resort to baked goods to keep track of your path through the woods. The Trackstick II is a tiny G.P.S. tracker that can record your wanderings for weeks at a time.

title: NATIONAL BRIEFING | WEST | California: Stem Cell Program Appointment
description: Californias $3 billion stem cell research program appointed an interim president, Richard A. Murphy, while it continued a longer-than-expected search for a permanent chief. Mr. Murphy recently retired as president of the Salk Institute for Biological Studies in San Diego. The previous stem cell program president, Zach Hall, announced his retirement in December and left at the end of April. The search for his successor has apparently been slowed by salary issues and doubts about how much authority a president would have, according to the California Stem Cell Report, a blog that monitors the program, the California Institute for Regenerative Medicine.

title: Dinner Reservations? Speak to My Hair Stylist
description: LAST month, a gaggle of assistant stylists took a fashion-themed field trip along Fifth Avenue. They made several stops: Gucci, Bergdorf Goodman and the Peninsula and Four Seasons hotels.

title: Businesses Near Blast Struggle to Return to Normal, or Even Just to Reopen
description: The front door to the Old Bridge Gourmet Deli, at 41st Street and Lexington Avenue, is about as close as any to the crater left by the steam pipe explosion outside Grand Central Terminal last month. Like several other businesses nearby, it remains closed.

title: Correction: On a Northwest Island, a Whiff of England
description: An article on July 19 about gardeners in Washington State misstated the location of Heronswood, a plant nursery founded by the botanist and explorer Daniel Hinkley. It was on the Kitsap Peninsula, not the Skagit Peninsula.

title: A Vote to Immortalize a Former Mayor for Life
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8  A decade and a half after a videotaped cocaine arrest that would have ended most political careers, former Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. has won yet another election.

title: Critic at New Republic to Join New Yorker
description: James Wood, a senior editor at The New Republic, where he has been the literary critic for the past 12 years, is leaving to become a staff writer at The New Yorker.

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: Tidying Up the Untidy

title: First Father: Tough Times on Sidelines
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8  There are times in the life of George Herbert Walker Bush, the 41st president of the United States and father of the 43rd, that people, perfect strangers, come up to him and say the harshest things  words intended to comfort but words that wind up only causing pain.

title: Near Brawl With Jays May Hurt Yanks Yet
description: TORONTO, Aug. 8  A day after the benches cleared twice at Rogers Center, the Yankees were still feeling the reverberations of their near brawl with the Toronto Blue Jays.

title: Happy Birthday! You Have Spam!
description: Q. Why am I suddenly flooded with fake greeting-card messages?

title: Two Crimes So Dark, Blurring the Images of Two Towns So Different
description: NEWARK

title: Two Bodies Found in Minneapolis Bridge Debris
description: A week after divers in Minneapolis began searching the Mississippi River near the wreckage of a huge bridge collapse, they found two bodies today, bringing the death toll in the collapse to seven, with at least six others still missing.

title: An Ape Types in Iowa
description: Des Moines

title: An Entire Bookshelf, in Your Hands
description: WHEN Paul Biba, a lawyer in Bernardsville, N.J., finds himself stuck waiting, he likes to pull out his Nokia E61i cellphone and read one of the 20 or so books he usually stores on it.

title: Aaron Moves Over, Bonds Moves Up, but Questions Remain
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 8  On the night that Barry Bonds reached the peak of the most monumental home run hill, his wife, Liz, wore a black shirt with white letters. Written across it was The King and I. Surely, her statement Tuesday was about more than fashion.

title: Game Show Buoys CBS
description: The new CBS game show Power of 10, with Drew Carey as host, delivered strong ratings in its preview on Tuesday, helping lift the network to second place for the night. NBC remained the leader over all with its combination of a 90-minute Americas Got Talent at 8, which attracted 10.7 million viewers, according to Nielsens estimates, followed by a half-hour of The Singing Bee at 9:30 (9.2 million). Meanwhile, both Power of 10 at 8 (9.2 million) and CBSs Big Brother at 9 (7.2 million) earned second-place finishes in their respective time slots. ABC posted an improved night in the ratings, despite finishing third over all. The premiere of that networks YouTube-inspired news program, i-Caught, which features amateur video submitted by viewers, drew 6.3 million viewers at 10. Among adults 18 to 49, the news program led the hour, ahead of repeats of CBSs NCIS (6.8 million) and NBCs Law & Order: Special Victims Unit (6.4 million). Fox finished a distant fourth for the night.

title: Is There an Iran Connection in Iraq? (6 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Amicably Split, and Still Sharing
description: FOR two people who might, in the society Mitchell Gold has been lobbying to create, be just another divorced couple, Mr. Gold and Bob Williams appear to get along exceptionally well. The men continue to run the furniture company that bears their names, and occasionally they even double-date, as they did last month at the Los Angeles wedding of Sarah Gore, the youngest daughter of Al and Tipper. They have even bought a pied--terre together in a newly built Manhattan tower (actually two apartments they combined) with a 180-degree view of the city from the 58th floor: the Hudson River to the west, the Statue of Liberty to the south, Times Square to the east. It is a view that dazzles, and Mr. Gold, an outgoing and down-to-earth man whose father was a grocer, appreciates it.

title: 12th Graders Show Better Grasp of Market Forces Than Expected on U.S. Economics Test
description: The nations high school seniors performed significantly better on the first nationwide economics test than they did on other recent national exams in history and science, and demonstrated higher than expected understanding of basic market forces like supply and demand than officials expected.

title: The Misery Strategy
description: The path the country has set on since the defeat of immigration reform in the Senate in June enshrines enforcement and punishment above all else. It is narrow, shortsighted, disruptive and self-defeating. On top of that, it wont work.

title: Vatican Plays Down Meeting With Priest Accused of Anti-Semitism
description: ROME, Aug. 9  The Vatican worked to distance itself Thursday from a brief meeting between Pope Benedict XVI and a Polish priest accused of making anti-Semitic statements, in the latest of several tense episodes recently between Jews and Catholics.

title: Swimming with the Fish
description: The Beijing Olympics open a year from this week, and Michael Phelps is not the only American swimmer poised to capture a chest full of gold. Natalie Coughlin has also mastered several strokes, and in 2004 left Athens with five medals, including two gold.

title: Newark: Bank Robber Is Sentenced
description: A North Bergen man was sentenced yesterday in Federal District Court to nearly 17 years in prison for robbing 10 banks in New York and New Jersey, prosecutors said. The man, Eduardo Quevedo, 44, was arrested on June 19, 2006, a day after robbing a Bank of America branch in North Bergen, said Christopher J. Christie, the United States attorney in New Jersey. When Mr. Quevedo was arrested, Mr. Christie said, federal agents seized an assault rifle, a handgun and ammunition. Mr. Quevedo admitted robbing 10 banks in 2005 and 2006 and was sentenced to 16 years and 8 months in prison. He was also ordered to repay more than $66,000, the amount taken in the robberies, prosecutors said.

title: It's My World, They're Just Playing in It
description: The world of professional sports is a depressing one these days; dogfighting, game fixing, steroids, punters stabbing punters, Joe Morgan. Fortunately, I havent had to deal with any of it for about two weeks now: Ive been busy playing PlayStation 3.

title: Bankruptcy Trustee Sues Big Investor in Refco
description: The trustee for Refco, a commodities brokerage firm that collapsed in fraud a few months after it went public in 2005, has sued Thomas H. Lee, the private equity firm that controlled Refco, saying the firm should have known about the fraud before it sold stock.

title: Queens: Driver Charged After Fatal Crash
description: A driver who suffered a seizure just before a fatal car crash last year has been charged with falsely stating on his drivers license renewal form that he did not have a medical condition that could cause unconsciousness, prosecutors said yesterday. The driver, Alexander Juwah, 44, a St. Albans psychiatrist, was charged yesterday in Criminal Court with offering a false instrument for filing, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said Dr. Juwah suffered a blackout on Springfield Boulevard on Nov. 4, 2006, causing a multicar accident that killed three people and injured seven. Mr. Brown said Dr. Juwah knew that he suffered from a seizure disorder at the time he renewed his drivers license.

title: Central Bank Raises a Key Interest Rate
description: Australias central bank raised its benchmark interest rate a quarter-point to the highest rate in almost 11 years. The bank raised the overnight cash rate to 6.5 percent, the first adjustment since November, to curb inflation running faster than the bank had forecast and to cool the biggest surge in lending since 1989. The increase might undermine Prime Minister John Howards campaign this year to win a fifth term. This does not help the government in the lead-up to the campaign, said John Edwards, the chief economist at HSBC Bank Australia in Sydney.

title: No. 757 for Bonds Follows Long Night
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 8  Barry Bonds pulled a maple bat out of the rack for batting practice, began swinging it and said that he felt weak.

title: A House Thats Just Unreal
description: FROM the roof deck of Sherman Ochss Mexican-style villa atop a breezy bluff, the entire island of Jalisco, population about 20, spreads out below. It is a picturesque place of palm trees, lush lawns and near-cloudless skies. And, of course, there are the perfect sands around the lagoon, where residents grind their perfect bodies together in an N.C.L., or Naked Conga Line. It is not exactly real, of course: Mr. Ochs is Don Ainsworth, a 57-year-old retired music teacher who lives in Ventura, Calif., and Jalisco is a sim (for simulator), a plot of land in Second Life, the virtual world introduced in 2003 by Linden Lab, a San Francisco company.

title: Equity Firm Invests in NBC Universal-News Corp. Online Venture
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 8  The joint venture between NBC Universal and the News Corporation to bring their television shows and movies onto the Internet still lacks a Web site. It still has no name. It also has yet to announce a clear mission that persuades the large number of skeptical observers that real-world rivals can cooperate online.

title: Sales Outpace Inventories at Wholesalers
description: Sales at United States wholesalers rose faster than inventories in June, increasing the chances that companies will order more from factories and help offset the housing recession.

title: Walkie-Talkies for Chat and Emergency Alerts
description: Walkie-talkies have long been an alternative to cellphones for keeping in touch with family members and fellow adventurers on camping trips or Disney World jaunts  and without burning monthly minutes or suffering from lack of signal coverage. Motorolas new Talkabout T9580RSAME two-way radios take communication even further by broadcasting emergency alerts through the handset as well.

title: A Morning of Misery Amid Sweltering Company
description: At high noon yesterday, in the steamy subway station at Times Square, two sweating women were at dueling distance.

title: Blockbuster Acquires Movielink
description: The video rental chain Blockbuster said yesterday that it had acquired the Internet movie provider Movielink to offer video downloading services to customers.

title: Go Ahead, Expect Surprises
description: Artists make great exhibition curators. They have expert eyes, a personal stake in the game and contacts with all kinds of other artists, including those who ride under the establishment radar. Museum surveys of contemporary art rarely produce surprises. Artist-organized gallery shows almost always do.

title: Internet Radio Made Easier
description: Youve heard of air pollution and noise pollution? Dont look now, but another depressing form of toxicity is taking the fun out of life: ad pollution. Thats the creeping commercial crud that has sapped the pleasure out of TV, faxes, e-mail and, of course, radio. These days, it seems as though AM radio has 52 minutes of ads an hour.

title: Golfs Wild Kingdom
description: Sometimes birdies and eagles arent enough. Occasionally, moose, bears, elk and wolves are necessary ingredients for a complete golf experience. They are all part of the Big Sky allure. Situated midway between Bozeman and Yellowstone National Park in southern Montana, Big Sky Resort is best known for its uncrowded downhill ski facilities, which were developed in part by Chet Huntley, the native Montanan and legendary newsman, in the early 1970s. Perhaps the regions biggest boost came via the 1992 film, A River Runs Through It, which featured a section of the Gallatin River near Big Sky. Fifteen years after its I have to go there moment, Big Sky is busting out again, this time as a golf destination. Among the new real estate communities are Yellowstone Club and the more accessible Spanish Peaks, which opened its private Tom Weiskopf-designed golf course on Aug. 3. With its mountain vistas and 7,000-foot elevation, this is breathtaking golf, indeed. Public players tee it up at Big Sky Golf Course, a flattish, if scenic early Arnold Palmer layout. If you like your golf on the wild side, walk this way.

title: A Korean Bridge Must Span Years of Bias and Sadness
description: SOROK ISLAND, South Korea  After the clod-covered offramp is smoothed over with asphalt, after the road signs are put up and the construction cranes taken down, a bridge, long anticipated, will open here in September. Spanning a third of a mile over seawater, it will connect this islet to the Korean mainland for the first time.

title: Last of a Kind Has Some Words for Woods
description: Tulsa, Okla.

title: Barry Bonds at 756*
description: The natural curve of a baseball sluggers performance resembles the arc of a high, looping home run  up and up and up and then, inevitably, down and down. The ball can do nothing about gravity, and, ideally, the athlete can do nothing about growing older except to learn, if he hasnt already, a certain patience and grace.

title: When the Burden of Status Is Too Much to Shoulder
description: JEAN TOUITOU, the irrepressible designer of the influential French label A.P.C., makes no bones about his disdain for kitchen-sink-size status bags. They belong to the trash bin of fashion history, he stated, or rather spewed, via e-mail. Theyre so vulgar even a hooker shouldnt wear them. That would be bad for her business. O.K., so theyre not for everyone.

title: Win for J. Lo, Loss for O. J.
description: Jennifer Lopez, below, whose net worth is estimated by Forbes magazine at $110 million, added about $545,000 after an award by a Los Angeles arbitrator in Ms. Lopezs lawsuit to muzzle her first husbands efforts to publish a tell-all book about their 11-month marriage, Agence France-Presse reported. Ms. Lopez sued her former husband Ojani Noa for breach of contract, maintaining that the book violated an agreement not to divulge details of their relationship. Court papers on Wednesday showed that the arbitrator, Richard Chernick, had ordered Mr. Noa to give Ms. Lopez all copies of materials relating to the book and enjoined him from criticizing, denigrating, casting in a negative light or otherwise disparaging Ms. Lopez. ... O. J. Simpson has been ordered to pay the family of Ron Goldman any money he earns from a video game featuring his likeness, The Associated Press reported. A Los Angeles judge ordered that the money from the game, All-Pro Football 2K, be turned over to Mr. Goldmans father, Fred Goldman, to satisfy a wrongful-death judgment now valued at $38 million in connection with the death of Ron Goldman, who was slain with Mr. Simpsons former wife Nicole Brown Simpson in 1994.

title: Using Technology and a Pint-Size Guitar for Big-Time Songs
description: There are no strings to break on Hasbros $70 Power Tour Electric Guitar, coming next month to stores and to hasbro.com/tiger. Instead, your fingers glide on a glassy, lighted fret board that picks up the electrical charge of your fingers  not unlike your computer touchpad  to sense the pitch.

title: Whats on Tonight
description: 9 P.M. (Discovery) LOBSTERMEN: JEOPARDY AT SEA Now that the sharks have retreated, its time for other scary creatures of the deep  and the anglers who put their lives at risk so we can eat them. Tonight in this series premiere the territorial crews of five boats prepare to lay claim to their portions of the sea.

title: Bush Says Iraqi Leader Shares His View on Iran
description: President Bush said today that he was confident that Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki of Iraq shared the White Houses view that Iran is a destabilizing force in the region. Mr. Bushs remarks came after Mr. Maliki visited to Tehran for talks with Iranian government officials on security in Iraq.

title: Alous Homer Gives Mets an Edge in the Game and Perhaps Beyond
description: Moises Alou stepped to the plate in the eighth inning last night with the score tied and so much more hanging in the balance. The Atlanta Braves were trying to prove that they  not the first-place Mets  were the team to beat in the National League East. The Braves already had a good argument, having beaten the Mets in 7 of the 10 games they had faced each other this season.

title: Japan: Mobile Phone Companys Profit Surges
description: The Softbank Corporation, the Japanese mobile phone company, posted an eighteenfold increase in first-quarter profit after adding users at a pace twice that of the market leader, NTT DoCoMo. Net income rose to 25.1 billion yen ($211 million), or 22.36 yen a share, in the three months that ended June 30, from 1.42 billion yen, or 0.81 yen a share, a year earlier, Softbank said. Earnings were helped by one-time gains. Operating profit rose 45 percent, to 78.7 billion yen. Softbank cut prices to as little as 980 yen a month, the lowest in Japan, and said it would extend coverage by installing more base stations. Overall sales at Softbank, which controls 17 percent of the mobile market, increased 34 percent, to 663.1 billion yen.

title: Gaza Could Face Economic Meltdown, U.N. Warns
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 9  The United Nations issued a severe warning today that Gaza could face an economic meltdown with disastrous consequences unless the main border crossings into the territory are reopened.

title: Britain Eases Livestock Restrictions
description: LONDON, Aug. 9  British authorities relaxed their ban on the movement of livestock in the country today, a sign that the outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease, a highly contagious and potentially devastating virus, was coming under control.

title: Cable Networks Boost News Corp. Earnings
description: The News Corporation reported strong quarterly earnings yesterday, but the announcement was upstaged by Rupert Murdochs comments on the companys recent deal to buy the publisher of The Wall Street Journal.

title: Louis Moyse, Founder of Music School, Dies at 94
description: Louis Moyse, a flutist, composer and founder of the Marlboro Music School and Festival, died on July 30 in Barre, Vt. He was 94 and lived in Montpelier, Vt.

title: That Wind That Left Part of Brooklyn Upside Down? It Was a Tornado, All Right
description: It took experts until late in the afternoon yesterday to confirm what many in southwestern Brooklyn knew had descended on their neighborhoods as a new workday dawned. It was a tornado  the first to hit Brooklyn since modern record-keeping began  and it turned whole sections of Sunset Park and Bay Ridge upside down.

title: Georgia Seeks U.N. Security Council Session About Missile
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 8  The Republic of Georgia presented what it called a mounting body of evidence on Wednesday that a Russian warplane had entered deep into its airspace and fired an air-to-ground missile. It said it was seeking a special session of the United Nations Security Council to address the matter.

title: With One U.S.B. Hub, the Whole Network Can Access Peripherals
description: The modern PC is a constellation of devices orbiting a humming box. But now U.S.B. devices dont have to be tied to one computer.

title: Glue Maker for Big Dig Is Charged in 06 Death
description: BOSTON, Aug. 8  The supplier of the epoxy that federal officials have blamed for the collapse of a Big Dig tunnel was indicted Wednesday in the death of a woman crushed by falling ceiling panels.

title: Frank Rosenfelt, Studio Chief, Dies at 85
description: Frank E. Rosenfelt, who as a top executive at MGM helped steer the studio into new ways of making and showing movies, as well as acquiring and producing movies like Doctor Zhivago and Network, died Aug. 2 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 85.

title: A.F.L.-C.I.O. Decides Not to Endorse for Now, Freeing Unions to Do So
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 8  The A.F.L.-C.I.O.s executive council voted on Wednesday against endorsing any presidential candidate, reflecting divisions over which Democrat to support and setting the stage for its 55 member unions to make individual endorsements.

title: Little Building Defies Beijings Olympic Ambitions
description: BEIJING, Aug. 8  Beijing observed the one-year countdown to the 2008 Olympics on Wednesday night with fireworks and pageantry at a celebration in Tiananmen Square. A few blocks away, Sun Ruoyu and her sister saw the streaks of color in the sky but did not dare leave their battered home.

title: Tracking Fugitives, With French Nail Tips
description: How have female bounty hunters become a feature of the modern world? Three developments appear to have made it inevitable: Google, G.P.S. and Taser.

title: Generals Dont Need a Watchdog
description: BY now, most Americans know the story of Cpl. Pat Tillman. He bravely chose military service rather than the National Football League, and he was killed in Afghanistan in 2004 by fire from his comrades.

title: A Patriarch Holds Court at His Own Party
description: I got to tell you one more, B. B. King said from the stage on Tuesday night, and then Im going to work. And he spun another story about how he secretly loves the way beautiful young women pat old men on the head, and how he never saw an electric light bulb until he was 16, or how bringing a pile of paper money back home to your sweetheart isnt as effective as it used to be.

title: Fossils in Kenya Challenge Linear Evolution
description: Two fossils found in Kenya have shaken the human family tree, possibly rearranging major branches thought to be in a straight ancestral line to Homo sapiens.

title: To Savor the Local Flavors, Head to the Airport
description: Airports have never been known for selling delectable food, but as the travel industry grows and airports strive to distinguish themselves, food and beverage courts are diversifying, too. For local brands, that can mean landing a tiny space in a big terminal and attracting lots of customers.

title: Fans Risk Their Safety for Prized Homers
description: Matt Murphy, a Mets fan in a Jos Reyes jersey, emerged Tuesday night bloodied but potentially wealthier from his successful sortie to retrieve Barry Bondss 756th home run ball from dozens of San Franciscans at AT&T Park. Murphy, of Elmhurst, Queens, was led from the scrum to safety by two police officers.

A picture caption on Friday with an article about a study contending that French fries at some fast-food restaurants in New York still have high amounts of trans fat, despite the citys restrictions on its use, misidentified the Manhattan restaurant shown at lunchtime. It was a Wendys, not a Burger King. (The study found that fries at both chains were high in trans fat.)

title: Shuttle Endeavour Lifts Off Toward Space Station
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Aug. 8  The space shuttle Endeavour lifted off into humid skies on Wednesday evening, carrying pieces of the International Space Station and a living reminder of the loss of the shuttle Challenger two decades ago.

title: A Special Moment for a Pitcher Who Isnt Special
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 8  The moment that provoked so much dread  among the commissioner, the public and pitchers everywhere  was saved by the man it hurt the most.

title: When in Pain, PGA Tour Players Turn to Healer
description: TULSA, Okla., Aug. 8  The most sought after guru at the 89th P.G.A. Championship once spent 730 days blindfolded.

title: He Lived to Tell the Tale (and Write a Best Seller)
description: On June 7 Marcus Luttrell was discharged from the Navy, having served with the elite Seals, survived a fierce battle in Afghanistan and earned a Navy Cross for combat heroism. Less than a month later Lone Survivor, Mr. Luttrells memoir of the 2005 battle and his rescue, became a best seller.

title: Automakers See a Weak Year for Sales
description: DETROIT, Aug. 8  Major automakers are openly acknowledging what the rest of the country already knew: a soft housing market and high gasoline prices are damping sales of cars and light trucks.

title: Calm Prevails as Iraqi Shiites Pilgrims Gather

title: Government May Raise Limits on Home-Loan Purchases
description: Alphonso R. Jackson, the secretary of housing and urban development, said yesterday that the government might raise the limit on purchases of home loans by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac to increase liquidity in the mortgage market.

title: Church Remembers Stalins Victims, While Kremlin Looks Away
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 8  A giant cross now commands the field where the first shots of Stalins Great Terror sounded 70 years ago. It was erected on Wednesday with religious pomp but little recognition from a government prone to whitewash one of Russias darkest eras.

description: F. SCOTT FITZGERALD once described Daisy as drowsing asleep at dawn with the beads and chiffon of an evening dress tangled among dying orchids.

description: BALTIMORE, Aug. 2  Donnie Andrews was a stickup man with a .44 Magnum who robbed drug dealers and was sentenced to life in prison for murdering one of them.

title: Correction: Garden Q.&A.
description: An illustration of wax begonias accompanying the Garden Q. & A. column last Thursday was published in error. It should have shown sweet peas, as the caption said they were.

An obituary on Friday about the Irish musician Tommy Makem misidentified the source of an account he gave of his arrival in Boston in 1955, including his description of being told by a customs agent, Have a great life, and his declaration more than a half century later, I took him at his word. It was an interview last year with The Boston Globe, not The Associated Press.

title: Senate Joins Knockoff Battle
description: THE movement by American designers to ban other companies from knocking off their work has gained some momentum since the idea was first introduced last year. At a news conference yesterday at the Fashion Institute of Technology, Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, talked about a bill proposing to extend copyright protection to fashion that had been introduced in the Senate last week, mirroring one that has been under consideration in the House since April 2006.

title: Lawyers Still Like Edwards, but Spread the Wealth
description: When he ran for the 2004 Democratic presidential nomination, John Edwards, who had gained fame as one of the nations most successful trial lawyers, was the darling of many in the legal community, which opened its checkbooks and poured money into his campaign.

description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 9  An earthquake rattled the Los Angeles area early today, shaking many people out of bed and causing officials to temporarily close a busy bridge after chunks of concrete came loose from the span.

description: A brief but fierce storm drenched the New York region just before the morning rush yesterday, paralyzing the transit system, flooding major thoroughfares, cutting off electricity to thousands of homes and causing confusion that lingered through a humid, sweaty day.

title: Original Suitor Sweetens Its Barneys Offer to $942 Million
description: The fierce bidding war over Barneys New York, the luxury clothing retailer, escalated yesterday when a private equity firm from Dubai raised its offer to $942 million  $117 million more than it had originally bid for the chain.

title: Asians Make Broad Gains in New York Population
description: Asians were the only major racial or ethnic group to record population gains in every county in the New York metropolitan region since 2005, according to census figures released yesterday.

title: Which Club Is More Exclusive?
description: Even as Barry Bonds was breaking the home-run record, people were predicting that Alex Rodriguez would someday overtake him. In the meantime, Tom Glavine gained his 300th victory, with seemingly fewer pitchers poised to ever reach that plateau. Which got us wondering: Is the 300-victory mark a more daunting, and impressive, achievement these days than reaching 755 home runs?

title: Kazakhstan: Austria Rejects Extradition
description: Austria will not extradite Rakhat M. Aliyev, the former son-in-law of President Nursultan A. Nazarbayev, to face kidnapping charges because there is no guarantee that he will get a fair trial in Kazakhstan, a spokesman for the Vienna public prosecutor said. He made the comments after a federal court ruled that Mr. Aliyev, until recently the Kazakh ambassador, could remain a free man in Austria. Austrian authorities are still investigating a charge of money laundering.

title: Survivor of Newark Shootings Picks Out a Suspect
description: NEWARK, Aug. 8  The lone survivor of a schoolyard shooting that left three college students dead on Saturday night has identified a suspect in a photo array, investigators involved with the case said on Wednesday.

description: WHEN Tara Ruotolo recruited far-flung pals and friends of friends to run the 197-mile Nike Hood to Coast relay race in northwest Oregon, she didnt choose her partners in grime based on talent or tenacity alone.

description: BERLIN, Aug. 8  Prime Minster Jaroslaw Kaczynski of Poland fired his interior minister on Wednesday over accusations that he had hindered a corruption investigation by leaking delicate information.

title: The Emperor of Swat
description: SORRY, Barry Bonds. Youre still 112 home runs away from the home run record, the real record, that is. Hitting 756 dingers is certainly quite an achievement, more than anyone else has hit in Major League Baseball history. But it is far behind the world record, the 868 homers slugged by Sadaharu Oh when he played for the Tokyo Yomiuri Giants from 1959 to 1980.

title: What Bright Effects You Have
description: FEELING blue? Dont blame your serotonin or endorphins. Shades of blue may be hiding in your makeup.

title: Bruno Case Inquiry Suspended
description: ALBANY, Aug. 8  The State Commission of Investigation said Wednesday that it would suspend its review of actions by aides to Gov. Eliot Spitzer involving the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, until the Albany County district attorney, P. David Soares, completed his own inquiry.

title: Living and Painting by His Own Rules
description: Joe Andoe grew up in Tulsa, Okla., living a life straight out of Chuck Palahniuks twisted imagination. Mama was a gum-popping cutie. Little Joe was a big slug of a baby. His mother says she didnt see much of him during his formative years. My only explanation, he writes, is that I tried to stay the hell out of the way.

title: Floating Arctic Ice Shrinking at Record Rate
description: The area of floating ice in the Arctic has shrunk more than in any summer since satellite tracking began in 1979, and it has reached that record point a month before the annual ice pullback typically peaks, experts said.

title: When High Price Is the Allure
description: WHEN readers leaf through the September issue of Vogue, which arrives on newsstands next week, they will encounter a Prada mohair twin set tagged at $2,925; a chunky Giles sweater, at $3,675; and a supersize Marc Jacobs bracelet, at $2,180. And as fall looks begin trickling into stores this month, shoppers will find basic designer sheath dresses selling for $1,200, coats for just under $4,000 and designer sunglasses for $500 or more.

title: Former Take-Two Official Is Sentenced in Backdating Case
description: Take-Two Interactive Softwares former general counsel, Kenneth I. Selterman, was sentenced yesterday to three years of probation for falsifying a letter to regulators. He is the third former executive from the video game company, the maker of the Grand Theft Auto series, to be sentenced in a stock option backdating investigation.

title: Queens: Gunman Sentenced to Life in Prison
description: A Jamaica man who fatally shot his father and his brother in 2002 was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court to life in prison without parole, prosecutors said. The man, James Seecoomar, 38, was convicted of first-degree murder in February, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said Mr. Seecoomar, a deli worker, shot his brother, Leonard, 35, in the back of the head with a revolver on March 27, 2002, as he watched television. When his father, James, 66, ran into the room, James Seecoomar shot him in the head and body, Mr. Brown said.

title: Room to Improve
description: Q. How can I make a guest room more inviting?

title: Two Are Arrested in Newark Shootings
description: NEWARK, Aug. 9  The police have arrested a 15-year-old and a 28-year-old man in connection with the schoolyard shootings on Saturday that left three college students dead and another seriously injured.

title: Bronx: School Aide Charged in Assault
description: A 22-year-old school aide has been arrested on charges of raping and sexually abusing an eighth-grade student, the office of the special commissioner of investigation said yesterday. The aide, Anthony Casey Jr., is accused of raping the student, a 13-year-old girl attending Lola Rodriguez de Tio Junior High School in the Bronx, twice in May, the commissioners office said, and at least one other time in June. Some of the rapes occurred at Mr. Caseys Bronx apartment, the office said. Mr. Casey, who was suspended without pay, worked at the school for two years.

title: A Violinist Tones Down the Twang
description: The violinist Jenny Scheinman specializes in a slippery rusticity. Acoustic folk, Gypsy swing and country can all crop up in her music, in ways that elude classification. This is often the case in her weekly residency at Barbs in Park Slope, Brooklyn, where she interacts with a rotating cast of players. It was less obviously so on Monday night at Joes Pub, where she led what sounded a lot like a working band.

title: Its Summer: Isnt Anyone at Work?
description: ITS a wonder you are reading this article at all.

To Sleep the Big Sleep? Call It Murder, My Sweet
description: Among the many pleasures of classic noir films from the 1940s and 50s is their chiseled dialogue. Goons, floozies and stoolies talk in aphorisms and one-liners, usually at machine-gun tempo. A hard-boiled dame playing coy wont just say, Go away, when she can say, Thats between me and the lamppost, and you aint no lamppost. A gumshoe on the hunt always has a wisecrack in his back pocket, like, Its funny, but practically all the people I know were strangers when I met them.

title: In First Game Back, Martnez Is Hit Hard but Shrugs It Off
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., Aug. 8  The last time Pedro Martnez pitched, the home plate umpire sidled up to him as he was leaving the simulated game and asked him to autograph a baseball.

title: Hope Over Experience
description: The association of Chrysler and its new chief executive, Robert Nardelli, may go down in history as one of the most unusual matchups of corporate outcasts.

title: Olympian Task: Measuring 26.2 Miles, to the Inch
description: Late Tuesday night and into yesterday morning, exactly one year before the start of the Beijing Olympics, two middle-aged men rode their bikes through Central Park, attending to a critical detail in the selection of Americas top male marathoners for the Games.

title: For a Young Polish Player, One Trip Yields Two Gold Medals
description: At the 21st European Youth Team Championships in Jesolo, Italy, which ended July 21, there were three events: girls, won by Poland; junior, won by the Netherlands; and schools, won by Poland. The scheduling made it possible for someone to compete in both the girls and schools events, and Joanna Krawczyk made the most of the opportunity, picking up two gold medals.

title: Hurdles Frustrate Effort to Shrink Guantnamo
description: The decision this week by the British government to request the return of five Guantnamo detainees with British ties was welcome news for Bush administration officials eager to cut the detention centers population.

description: There were minute-by-minute (and hour-by-hour) accounts of commutes thwarted  and accomplished, if in triple the usual time. There were comparisons of New York to third-world countries, of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to the Taliban.

title: Beltrn Not Ready to Bat Right-Handed Yet
description: Carlos Beltrn is eligible to come off the disabled list today. But if his left oblique muscle is still causing him problems when he bats from the right side, he will not play in the series finale against the Atlanta Braves.

title: Rescuers Close In on Utah Miners
description: HUNTINGTON, Utah, Aug. 9  Rescuers said they were within six hours of possibly making contact with six coal miners trapped more than 1,500 feet underground by a cave-in since early Monday.

title: Gaza: Israeli Troops Kill Hamas Gunmen
description: Three Hamas militants were killed by Israeli troops in northern Gaza. An army spokesman said two armed men were spotted approaching the perimeter fence in the morning and were killed in an exchange of fire. Hamass military wing said they were its members. The third, killed later in the day near the Erez crossing, was identified as a member of Hamass paramilitary police, known as the Executive Force.

title: Islamic Finance and Its Critics
description: GENEVA  Before the attacks of Sept. 11, Prince Muhammad al-Faisal al-Saud felt welcome in America. A member of the Saudi royal family and a pioneer of Islamic finance, he was a pillar of a Saudi business establishment that has long relished its ties with the United States.

title: British Criticize Air Attacks in Afghan Region
description: SANGIN, Afghanistan  A senior British commander in southern Afghanistan said in recent weeks that he had asked that American Special Forces leave his area of operations because the high level of civilian casualties they had caused was making it difficult to win over local people.

title: Pakistanis Express Ire at Army and Musharraf
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Aug. 8  Before, our children would salute our soldiers when they passed. Now they spit on them.

title: U.S. Attack Kills 32 in Sadr City
description: BAGHDAD, Aug. 8  An American raid and airstrike killed 32 people in the Shiite stronghold of Sadr City on Wednesday, in what American military officials described as an assault on a militant network bringing in money and bombs from Iran.

title: New York Company Indicted in Collapse of Big Dig
description: BOSTON, Aug. 8  The supplier of the epoxy that federal officials have blamed for the collapse of a Big Dig tunnel was indicted today in the death of a motorist crushed by falling ceiling panels.

title: Dow Falls 387 Points on New Loan Fears
description: Stocks on Wall Street today suffered their biggest one-day decline since February after the turmoil in the home-loan market caused renewed concerns about tightening credit worldwide.

title: Tip of the Week: Speed Your Online Mapping
description: TIP OF THE WEEK: If you spend a lot of time looking up locations around the United States on map sites, the Map+ add-on for the Firefox browser can save time. Once you install Map+ (available at https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/addon/2394), you can highlight an address on a Web page and right-click on it to see a small Yahoo map of the location pop up in the Firefox window. J. D. BIERSDORFER

title: Panel Takes Step Toward Denying Reappointment to Judge
description: A District of Columbia judicial panel has taken a first step toward denying reappointment to a local administrative law judge who sued a dry cleaner for $54 million over a pair of lost pants, said a government official who spoke on the condition of anonymity because the action concerned a personnel matter. The official said the panel voted unanimously Monday to send a formal letter to the judge, Roy L. Pearson Jr., expressing concerns about both his lawsuit against the business, Custom Cleaners, which he lost in June, and his record as a jurist. Mr. Pearson has 15 days to respond in writing and request a hearing before the panel, which could rule on his reappointment, to a 10-year term, as early as next month.

title: David Shaw, Writer for Stage and Screen, Dies at 90
description: David Shaw, a Tony Award-winning writer for stage, screen and television, died on July 27 at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 90.

title: Minorities Now Form Majority in One-Third of Most-Populous Counties
description: In a further sign of the United States growing diversity, nonwhites now make up a majority in almost one-third of the most-populous counties in the country and in nearly one in 10 of all 3,100 counties, according to an analysis of census results to be released today.

title: In Augusts Heat, Planning for Cooler Days
description: ITS hard to think of planting anything new when temperatures are in the 90s, but now through early September is the time to plant fall greens and root crops. I need some fresh young arugula and basil to go with all those tomatoes now ripening on the vine. And beet and mustard greens are sweeter in the fall.

description: When Donnie Andrews and Fran Boyd got married, it was the culmination of a lengthy courtship that was as much about turning their lives around as it was about finding each other.

title: Socializing Online
description: Todays New York Times has an article about people who use the online community Second Life to live out their Architectural Digest-style fantasies. Second Life users have built cities, created clothing lines and programmed their avatars  the characters that represent them in the three-dimensional space of Second Life  to ride horses, dance and have sex, Seth Kugel writes. People use online communities to network for their real-life careers, to stay in touch with friends, and to publicize their political campaigns.

description: A look at some of the dance performances at the 2007 New York International Fringe Festival.

description: Updated, 6 p.m. | The New York City transit system is mostly back to normal this morning, a day after a fierce storm paralyzed the subways, unleashed a tornado in Brooklyn and created misery for commuters. (For more news, see our Morning Buzz roundup.)

description: The Universal Music Group said on Wednesday that it had acquired a stake in the operator of the urban social networking Web site Loud.com.

description: Take-Two Interactive Softwares former general counsel, Kenneth I. Selterman, was sentenced Wednesday to three years of probation for falsifying a letter to regulators. He is the third former executive from the video game company, the maker of the Grand Theft Auto series, to be sentenced in a stock option backdating investigation.

title: Blockbuster Acquires Movielink
description: The video rental chain Blockbuster said Wednesday that it had acquired the Internet movie provider Movielink to offer video downloading services to customers.

title: Providence Backs NBC-News Corp. Site
description: The joint venture between NBC Universal and the News Corporation to bring their television shows and movies onto the Internet still lacks a Web site. It still has no name. It also has yet to announce a clear mission that convinces the large number of skeptical observers that real-world rivals can cooperate online.

title: Murdochs Dow Comments Eclipse News Corp. Earnings
description: The News Corporation reported strong quarterly earnings Wednesday, but the announcement was upstaged by Rupert Murdochs comments on the companys recent deal to buy the publisher of The Wall Street Journal.

description: All the hand-wringing lately over how hard the investment banks and the hedge fund industry will be hit by the current market turmoil may be for naught, according to one report.

title: Langone: Private Equity Is About a Quick Buck
description: Who benefits from private equity? That was one of the questions kicked around by participants in a panel talk during the Academy of Managements annual conference this week. BusinessWeek framed the issue this way: Do buyout firms like Blackstone Group and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts add value to companies or just collect a heaping wad of cash?

title: At Fidelity, a Born-Again Star  or a Has-Been?
description: The resignation of Ellyn McColgan, a Fidelity executive who had been considered an heir apparent to the chairman and chief executive, Edward C. Johnson III, may have paved the way for Rodger Lawson, president of Fidelity to take the reins.

title: Online Educator to Test Public Markets
description: American Public Education, a provider of online post-secondary education, filed Wednesday for an initial public offering of its common stock.

title: Investors Pile on E-House Debut
description: Shares of E-House, a Chinese real-estate services company, rallied more than 40 percent Wednesday as Wall Street dove into a play on the hot real estate sector in China. The Shanghai-based company bills itself as Chinas largest real estate agency and consulting services company.

title: Sign Up Now: More Cash and Fewer Hangups for U.S. Goverment Work
description: There are a lot of reasons why a man would give up his undercover status after 30 years with the C.I.A. For Jose Rodriguez, whose identity was revealed Wednesday, it was to participate in minority recruitment events, The Associated Press reported.

title: Dells Former Chief Set for $48.5 Million Payout
description: Dell said in a regulatory filing Wednesday that once it finally files an annual report, it intends to pay $48.5 million to Kevin Rollins, who resigned as its chief executive early this year. The money comes in the form of a payment in lieu of stock options, the company said.

title: Successful Bond Sales Help Ease Fears
description: The deep freeze on corporate borrowing is showing signs of thawing, and that helped Wall Street post its third straight gain Wednesday. Although few analysts were willing to sound the all-clear for battered markets  for one, the bonds that sold well Wednesday were corporate grade  the mood has brightened significantly in the last few days.

title: Arb Funds Feel Fallout from Credit Markets
description: Merger arbitrage hedge funds, which bet on the outcome of mergers and acquisitions, lost money in July over concern that turmoil in the credit market could derail some deals.

title: Thomas H. Lee Partners Sued Over Refco Debacle
description: The trustee for Refco, a commodities brokerage firm that collapsed in fraud a few months after it went public in 2005, has sued Thomas H. Lee Partners, the private equity firm that controlled Refco, saying the firm should have known about the fraud before it sold stock.

title: Fast Retailing Drops Out of Barneys Race
description: A Dubai-based investment fund appeared to have won the bidding war for Barneys New York, the luxury clothing retailer, after a rival bidder pulled out of the race Thursday.

title: Fortis Profits Beat Expectations
description: The Belgian-Dutch financial services group Fortis, which is involved in a bidding war for the Dutch bank ABN Amro, reported a 16 percent year-on-year rise in second-quarter net profit on Thursday, beating analysts expectations thanks to strong banking results.

title: Dolans Cablevision Offer May Be Looking Sweeter
description: The roiling credit markets and mediocre second-quarter results may be the push the Dolans, Cablevision Systems founding family, need to persuade shareholders to green light their $36.26 a share offer to take the company private, The New York Post says.

title: J.P. Morgan Sued by Ex-Bond Salesman in Greek Scandal
description: The former J.P. Morgan Chase salesman at the center of a Greek bond scandal is suing the bank, alleging he has been made a scapegoat.

title: Coade Takes the V.C. Plunge
description: After resisting entreaties from would-be buyers and investors for years, an industrial design and engineering software maker, Coade, took the venture capital plunge, accepting $42 million in growth and liquidity funding from New York-based Insight Partners.

title: Eurazeo Weaves $3.4 Billion Deal for Elis
description: Eurazeo, the French private equity firm, agreed Wednesday to buy a textile rental and cleaning service company, Elis GIE for 2.28 billion euros ($3.14 billion) from PAI Partners.

title: Dubais OMX Move Threatens Nasdaqs $3.7 Billion Deal
description: Dubai Borse on Thursday announced it is seeking to buy up to 25 percent of shares in OMX, the Nordic exchanges and technology group at 230 krona per share, threatening to derail an the Nasdaq Stock Markets agreed 25.1 billion-krona ($3.7 billion) bid for the Nordic exchanges and technology group.

title: Rosneft Gobbles Up More Yukos Assets
description: Rosneft won another Yukos bankruptcy auction, buying key transport assets, including those used for exports to China, as it continued its drive to swallow up what was once Russias biggest oil producer.

title: RBS to Delay British Hotel Sale, Report Says
description: The Royal Bank of Scotland has postponed the sale of a 1.1 billion-pound ($2.23 billion) British hotel portfolio because of spiraling costs in the wake of a global credit crunch, Reuters reported citing an unnamed source. It is not yet clear whether the deal has been permanently scrapped or simply delayed until the costs of borrowing and insuring debt have steadied, Reuters said.

title: Wesfarmers Sweetens Coles Offer to Save Deal
description: Australias Wesfarmers, whose takeover of the Coles Group is in jeopardy because of a slide in its stock, said shareholders in the supermarket chain can opt for more cash as it seeks to make the offer more attractive.

title: Tata May Gulp Down AriZona, Report Says
description: Indias Tata Tea is interested in acquiring AriZona Beverages and the Tata Group could make a $2 billion buyout offer, The Economic Times said on Thursday, citing unnamed sources.

title: Ryerson Defends Its Buyout
description: The steel services company Ryerson on Wednesday defended its $1 billion deal to be bought by Platinum Equity, despite opposition from a hedge fund, Harbinger Capital Partners, and said it had extensive discussions with potential buyers.

title: Campbell Soup Says It May Sell Godiva
description: Campbell Soup said it may sell its Godiva Chocolatier luxury chocolate brand to focus on soups, snacks and drinks. We are exploring strategic alternatives, which also includes the divestiture of Godiva, a Campbell spokesman, Anthony Sanzio, said to Bloomberg News.

title: Morning Buzz: Chronicling a Day of Chaos
description: The punishing thunderstorm that paralyzed the subways and sent a tornado roaring over parts of Brooklyn and Staten Island thoroughly dominated the local coverage in New York Citys newspapers today.The transit system is mostly back to normal, with some delays. City Room has posted the latest updates.

title: As Liquidity Exits Subprime, Enter Wilbur Ross
description: Wilbur Rosss $50 million investment in American Home Mortgage Investment during the lenders bankruptcy reorganization will apparently not be the last for the investor in distressed companies. In a Q&A with BusinessWeek, Mr. Ross said that he sees attractive targets in the subprime sector.

title: Paribas Freezes Funds as Subprime Woes Keep Spreading
description: Anyone know how to say subprime in French?

title: Home Depot Says Supply Unit May Be Sold for Less
description: The ongoing troubles in the debt markets may have rocked yet another major buyout. On Thursday, Home Depot said it is in talks with the three private equity firms that agreed to buy its supply unit  discussions that may lead to a lower price than the agreed-upon $10.325 billion. Home Depot also said it would cut the price it is offering in its share buyback.

description: It all started on Wednesday night in Pakistan, according to Reuters. Television stations started reporting that Gen. Pervez Musharraf, the embattled president, was about to declare emergency rule, which would increase the militarys powers and postpone elections.

description: In the unlikely event that someone decides to compile an online anthology called Best American Blog Posts 2007  please dont, by the way  I know one that ought to make it into the books literary/academic section.

description: Suleiman Jamous, the confined Sudanese rebel leader who Mia Farrow offered to trade places with, will be freed when peace talks to end war and strife in Darfur begin, a top Sudanese official said today. The rebels would like the talks to start in two or three months.

description: I do a lot of stuff for The Times: a weekly print column, this weekly e-column, a daily blog, a weekly audio podcast and a weekly video. Which got us wondering: Is the 300-victory mark a more daunting, and impressive, achievement these days than reaching 755 home runs?

title: Next Week
description: The newsletter next week will look at some more of the stories covered in the new issue of the magazine, including the cover story, a profile of Serena Williams, the most exciting player in women's tennis, on the eve of the U.S. Open.

title: Beltran a Model Citizen of Baseball
description: Carlos Beltran said this morning that he is still feeling discomfort from the right side the plate. He is ready to come off the 15-day disabled list today but still appears to be a few days away from playing in a game.

title: Vern, M.L.S.s Failure to Sign Him, and the Legacy of the N.A.S.L.
description: You may remember the stir a couple of weeks ago when it seemed the increasingly venerable Argentine star Juan Sebastian Vern might leave his hometown club, Estudiantes de La Plata, and sign with D.C. United. That has not come to pass  on Sunday Vern opened the season with Estudiantes in an atmosphere hed never encounter in the M.L.S.: a packed stadium full of passionate fans, celebrating the clubs centennial, no less.

title: Q & A: Fighting Racism in European Soccer
description: When U.S. international DaMarcus Beasley and his Rangers teammate Jean-Claude Darcheville were reportedly the victims of racist abuse during a Champions League qualifier against FK Zeta in Montenegro, UEFA said it would investigate. It would not the first time such ugly behavior at a soccer match has marred the game.

title: Gannett: Reading Between the Lines

But it is so huge  with a market capitalization of nearly $11 billion  that it is hard to imagine who the acquirer would be. Jon Morton, a newspaper analyst, told The New York Times in June that only a big, non-media buyer  he mentioned General Electric or a buyout firm  could possibly do such a deal, and even thats unlikely.

title: The Venice Biennale With a Guide
description: We are planning to go to the Venice Biennale in October and would like to get an in-depth view of the exhibitions with a knowledgeable guide. I would appreciate suggestions on how to book one. Alternatively, are there tours that concentrate on the biennale?

description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

description: Election 07? South Carolinas Republicans are going to move their presidential primaries to Jan. 16, 2008, which will likely set off a domino effect in New Hampshire, Iowa and elsewhere, that could push the start of voting to New Years Day or even to before Christmas, according to The Washington Post.

title: The Abner Louima Case, 10 Years Later
description: Ten years ago today, a 30-year-old Haitian immigrant named Abner Louima was arrested and sodomized with a broomstick inside a restroom in the 70th Precinct station house in Brooklyn. The case became a national symbol of police brutality and fed perceptions that New York City police officers were harassing or abusing young black men as part a citywide crackdown on crime.The case also marked the beginning of the unraveling of Mayor Rudolph W. Giulianis relationship with the black community in New York. That relationship would deteriorate even further, after the police shot two unarmed black men, Amadou Diallo in February 1999 and Patrick Dorismond in 2000.

description: Fasten your seatbelts, as Bette Davis once advised, its going to be a bumpy ride.

title: Wachovia Analyst Is Latest Buyout-Firm Convert

Bloombergs PlaNYC 2030 plan for environmental sustainability, which calls for adding 800 acres of new public space by 2030.

title: Germany: Strike Affects Telecom
description: Deutsche Telekom, the largest phone company in Europe, reported a fifth consecutive decline in quarterly profit after a strike led to more fixed-line customer losses. Second-quarter net income fell to 608 million euros ($831 million) from, 1.02 billion euros a year earlier, the company said. Sales rose 2.9 percent, to 15.6 billion euros. Revenue from abroad topped German sales for the first time after Deutsche Telekom lost 516,000 traditional phone lines in its home market while it added mobile phone customers in the United States. To help meet a 2 billion-euro cost-reduction goal this year, Deutsche Telekom moved 50,000 service employees into the new T- Service unit and cut their salaries, starting the biggest strike in more than a decade. The six-week strike ended in June after the Ver.di union agreed to a compromise reduction.

title: Side by Side at a Crash Site, and Love Amid the Bodies
description: The three lives that intertwine in Human Error, a new play by Keith Reddin at the Atlantic Theater Companys Stage 2, are not individually particularly interesting. Mr. Reddin, though, gets something out of them by simple juxtaposition, showing admirable subtlety in the process.

title: Dancer Pleads Guilty
description: Nilas Martins, a principal dancer with the New York City Ballet and the son of Peter Martins, the companys master in chief, pleaded guilty yesterday in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., to a reduced charge of disorderly conduct stemming from his arrest there on July 3, when he was charged with felony possession of cocaine. City Court Judge Douglas Mills sentenced Mr. Martins, 40, to 40 hours of community service and ordered him to undergo a drug and alcohol test. Outside of court, his lawyer, E. Stewart Jones Jr., said Mr. Martins welcomed the test. He does not use drugs, Mr. Jones said. He has not used drugs. He will never, ever use drugs. He added that Mr. Martins took the plea to protect another, unidentified person who was with him in his car when he was arrested by a passing police officer in Saratoga Springs, where the company was in summer residence.

title: On the Roof, a Weaning From Weeding
description: YOU should hurry up and see my roof garden. This year we still have our view of the Manhattan cityscape in its full gleaming glory, all the way from South Ferry to the Empire State. But thanks to the charmless chunk of schmancy condos now going up on Brooklyns Fourth Avenue (the Champs lyses of auto parts stores), the rooftop sunsets we savored in summers past were, it turns out, our last.

title: France: Bear, Farmers Foe, Killed by Car
description: Franska, one of five brown bears from Slovenia let loose in the French Pyrenees to increase the native bear population, was killed in a collision with a car, according to the police. The driver was unhurt, and the police said they would investigate. Opposition to the repopulation plan has been fierce, with local farmers accusing Franska of killing as many as 150 sheep. If people had only listened to us, Franska would be living a happy and peaceful life in Slovenia, Bernard Moules, a farmers union official, told Agence France-Presse.

title: Comprenez-Vous Woody Allen Films? Heres a Paris Version
description: The metabolism of Julie Delpys biting romantic comedy 2 Days in Paris runs full tilt from the opening scene, of lovers asleep on a fast train from Venice. Once they awaken, the pace accelerates even further, and you strain not to miss a word of their smart, revealing and frequently crazy repartee.

title: To See the World in Ballpoint Pen
description: The attraction for artists of the ballpoint pen has grown over the years, particularly in affectedly informal contemporary drawing.

title: U.S. Backs Free Elections, Only to See Allies Lose
description: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates Aug. 9  Lebanons political spin masters have been trying in recent days to explain the results of last Sundays pivotal by-election, which saw a relatively unknown candidate from the opposition narrowly beat a former president, Amin Gemayel.

title: When Stars (Celestial) Fall, and Stars (Hollywood) Fly
description: In Stardust, a sprawling, effects-laden fairy tale with the thundering stamina of a marathon horse race, Michelle Pfeiffer is Lamia, as deliciously evil a witch as the movies have ever invented. Shooting deadly green lightning from rings on her tapering long-nailed fingers, she suggests a seriously lethal beauty contestant of a certain age who will stop at nothing to seize the crown.

title: Democrats Voice Support of Gay Rights in TV Forum
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 9  Six Democratic presidential candidates participated Thursday night in a televised forum devoted to gay issues. All voiced strong support for equal rights and government benefits for gay Americans, though the three leading candidates said they opposed same-sex marriage.

title: Two Bushes in a Book Deal
description: Laura Bush and her daughter Jenna will write a childrens book for HarperCollins. The book, as yet untitled, to be published in English and Spanish in the spring, is set in a school where a mischievous little boy learns the fun of reading with the help of his teacher. An announcement yesterday from HarperCollins said the story, with illustrations by Denise Brunkus, is loosely based on the authors experiences as teachers. Their net proceeds and a portion of the publishers proceeds are to go to two national teacher programs.

title: Industrial Echoes in Michigans Copper Country
description: FOUR hundred feet underground, in a musty, dripping passage into the Quincy Mine, Ed Yarbrough pointed to a dark opening in the wall. Heres an old explosives bin, he said, tracing a flashlight beam along the rock, hence the no-smoking sign.

title: Divers Find More Remains in Wreckage of Bridge
description: A week after divers in Minneapolis began searching the Mississippi River near the wreckage of a massive bridge collapse, they found the remains of at least two people yesterday, bringing the confirmed death toll in the collapse to at least seven, with others still missing.

title: Relatives of Victims to Have Access to Ground Zero on 9/11 Anniversary
description: Relatives of those killed on Sept. 11, 2001, at the World Trade Center will be allowed to descend briefly into the ground zero site on the sixth anniversary of the attack, City Hall said yesterday. The decision was the result of a compromise reached by the families and the mayors office on this years commemoration of the day.

title: Stem Cell Amendment Changes Little in Missouri
description: ST. LOUIS  When Missouri voters approved a constitutional amendment last November protecting human embryonic stem cell research, it was viewed as a key endorsement of the research even in states with deep religious roots and strong antiabortion forces like this one.

title: A New Kind of Bank Run Tests Old Safeguards
description: A few generations ago, savers responded to financial panics with runs on banks, and even healthy institutions could fail if they could not raise enough cash quickly enough.

title: Harry Potter and the Leopard-Walk- Up-to-Dragon
description: Harry becomes a fat, hairy dwarf after being caught in a sour and sweet rain; he loses all his magic and can get it back only by obtaining the magic ring. After he does, Harry becomes a dragon that fights evil. Voldemort has an even more powerful brother who makes trouble for Harry.

title: Pavarotti Is Hospitalized
description: Luciano Pavarotti has been hospitalized in stable condition with a fever in Modena, Italy, his hometown, The Associated Press reported. The local daily, Il Resto del Carlino, reported that he was suffering from pneumonia. Officials and his manager said Mr. Pavarotti, 71, who underwent surgery for pancreatic cancer last year, was expected to be released in a few days.

title: 08 Landscape in Flux as States Seek to Change the Rules
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 10  When state Democratic leaders from around the country meet this weekend in Vermont, the California chairman, Art Torres, expects to be peppered with the sort of questions that have been clogging his in-box for weeks.

title: Deaths in Newark
description: Newark has seen hundreds of senseless killings over the years, but few have shaken its weary residents like last weekends brutal murders of three young people and the shooting of a fourth. One can only hope that the savagery of this latest crime will at last bring the city together in a new determination to end the bloodshed.

title: Harry Potter and the Showdown
description: Harry makes his last visit to No. 4 Privet Drive, and his aunt and uncle are surprisingly kind to him. Snape shows up unexpectedly to ruin Bills wedding. Professor McGonagall reopens Hogwarts with Professor Slughorn as her deputy.

title: NATIONAL BRIEFING | WEST | California: Fishing Banned Near Channel Islands
description: The federal government has banned fishing in eight sites in the Channel Islands National Marine Sanctuary, off Southern California, and has limited fishing in a ninth, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration announced. The action adds about 110 square nautical miles of protected areas to more than 100 square nautical miles already protected by the state and creates the nations second-largest network of marine protected areas, after reserves in the northwest Hawaiian Islands.

title: Earlier Terrorist Screening to Begin for Flights Into U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9  By early next year, passengers on flights bound for the United States will have their names checked against terrorist watch lists before departure, instead of after takeoff, Homeland Security Secretary Michael Chertoff announced Thursday.
The Really? column in Science Times on Tuesday misstated one of the compounds that block UVA radiation and are frequently found in sunscreens. It is avobenzone, not avobenzene.

title: Shiite Pilgrims Converging on Baghdad Shrine Are Protected by Improved Security
description: BAGHDAD, Aug. 9  Tens of thousands of Shiite pilgrims converged on a shrine in western Baghdad on Thursday to honor an eighth-century imam, chanting and waving flags and in some cases riding in government vehicles. There were few instances of the violence that has blemished previous celebrations.

title: Harry Potter and the Big Funnel
description: After six years at Hogwarts, Harry Potter becomes an intern sorcerer and is assigned to teach at the Honiton School. Harry has a painful time in his aunts house, as Dudley has met a belly-dancing girl. As Harry prepares to report to his job, Bat Bug warns him disaster awaits.

title: A Boy Rendered Speechless by Life
description: Jeffrey Blitzs tender but hardheaded Rocket Science plumbs the tormented consciousness of Hal Hefner (Reece Daniel Thompson), a fragile teenager with a paralyzing speech impediment that leaves him unable even to order lunch in his high school cafeteria. As he stands there desperately trying to articulate the words racing through his head (will it be pizza or fish?), you feel his excruciating humiliation.

title: Queens: 40-Year Sentence for Rape
description: A homeless man was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court to 40 years in prison for raping one woman and trying to rape another last year, prosecutors said. The man, James Clark Brown, 45, was convicted of rape, attempted rape and robbery on July 23, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. He said that on the morning of June 13, 2006, Mr. Brown told a woman near the post office in Springfield Gardens that he had a gun and would kill her if she did not come with him. He ordered the woman to follow, but she escaped by pretending to tie her shoe before running away. About 15 minutes later, Mr. Brown forced another woman to accompany him to a nearby garage, where he raped and robbed her, the district attorney said.

title: F.D.A. Is Reviewing Heartburn Drugs After Studies Find Possible Heart Risk
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9  Two small studies of the popular heartburn drugs Prilosec and Nexium found that patients who took the medicines over many years had an increased risk of sometimes fatal heart attacks and heart failure.

title: Manhattan: Cellphone Bill Vetoed
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday vetoed a bill intended to chip away at his administrations ban on cellphones in public schools. The bill would allow students to transport cellphones to and from school, putting the onus on school officials to give students a place to store phones during school hours. The Department of Education is exploring the possibility of installing lockers from private vendors for cellphone storage. Mr. Bloomberg has said that cellphones disrupt learning. The City Council, which voted 46 to 2 in favor of the bill last month, is expected to override the mayors veto.
