description: WESTBROOK

title: Rentals Reach a New Level of Luxury
description: A GOLF simulator that lets residents imagine theyre playing the 18th hole at St. Andrews in Scotland.

title: Struggling Mets Starter Becomes Thriving Reliever
description: Jorge Sosa was so ineffective as a starter last month that the Mets sent him to the bullpen on July 31. Since then, Sosa has been so effective as a reliever that they may keep him there indefinitely.

title: State of Infrastructure (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Still Jumping Into the Job Pool
description: WHEN Cate Fahey applied for a summer job at the J. Crew store at The Westchester mall in April, she must have made a good impression. At age 19, she is outgoing, poised and hard-working.

title: The Future: Bright. The Fashion: Blinding.
description: WHAT was it about 70s television that brought out the worst in futuristic fashion? The Six Million Dollar Man legitimized leisure suits; Battlestar Galactica gave us Lorne Green in padded shirts.

title: Datebook
description: ROME

title: Iran Completes Espionage Investigation of 2 Academics
description: TEHRAN, Aug. 12  The Iranian government has completed its investigation of two Iranian-American academics who were arrested in May on espionage charges, a prosecutor told the state-run IRNA news agency today. The development may move the case, which has worsened tensions between the United States and Iran, closer to resolution.

title: Truth and Consequences
description: We already know one legacy of our continued presence in Iraq  twice the number of amputees among American veterans than in either world war, thanks to advances in both improvised bombs and battlefield medicine. Perhaps the sight of missing limbs will underscore a universal truth: no one comes home from combat intact, and the psychological devastation of warfare is as crippling as the physical.

title: No, It Wouldnt Happen. Couldnt. No Way.
description: WELL, a New York political reporter can dream, cant he?

title: Can This Marriage Be Saved?
description: You ask me for intimacy, Marie was telling her husband of 22 years, Clem  and, unavoidably, the therapist and four other couples in the room  the same way you ask if Id like croutons on my salad. She spoke slowly, deliberately, each word chipping out of her mouth like an ax striking wood. I dont hear the difference.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Bonds: The Home Run King

title: Worlds Best Medical Care?
description: Many Americans are under the delusion that we have the best health care system in the world, as President Bush sees it, or provide the best medical care in the world, as Rudolph Giuliani declared last week. That may be true at many top medical centers. But the disturbing truth is that this country lags well behind other advanced nations in delivering timely and effective care.

title: A Drug-Runners Stronghold Finds a New Life
description: IT was Thursday evening in Medelln and the open-air bars and cafes along fashionable Lleras Park were overflowing with after-work singles. At Triada, a stylish lounge with an orange neon bar and low-slung couches, laughter filled the subtropical air along with the deep-toned drumming of cumbia music. From around the corner, a small group of motorcyclists screeched by, their shiny engines puttering like machine guns. No one flinched, and the party kept rolling.

title: Correction: Every Penny Counts
description: An article on July 29 about people who demonstrated exceptional discipline in saving to buy homes included incorrect financial data from a buyer about his purchase of an apartment. Obi Onyejekwe paid $400,000 for his co-op in Gramercy Park, not $420,000. The down payment amount was $100,000, not $84,000. His assets reported to the board were roughly $100,000, not $84,000.

title: What, Me Worry? When It Comes to Retiring, Yes
description: It has been a steady drumbeat: Americans are not saving nearly enough for retirement, and they will pay the price later, by having to totter into the office until theyre 98.

title: Sickening Acts
description: In a corner of Brentwood, where the streets have names like Apple, Peach and Cocoanut, there is a wooded path known as a place of drug use and violence. Its reputation is well deserved. A pair of shocking crimes there in the last 11 months claimed two male victims. Both were savagely attacked and died of their injuries.

title: 36 Hours in Budapest
description: LIKE the blue Danube River that separates Castle Hill in Buda from the flneur-worthy boulevards of Pest, the Hungarian capital of Budapest has a sophisticated and hedonistic side. Old World grandeur, stunning architecture and a rich cultural heritage give Budapest its undeniably noble air. But the city also offers plenty of opportunities to cut loose, relax and overindulge on everything from opera and wine to nightlife and cool art. What's more, few of these luxuries are prohibitively expensive. There are ornate public bathhouses, trendy design shops with flea-market prices and beautiful museums that don't cost a cent. So whatever side you choose, let your curiosity be your guide.

title: Sad End to a Long, Slow Slide
description: UNIONDALE

title: A Museum to Get Lost In, and How Israel Is Fixing It
description: JERUSALEM

title: Letters: No Comparison; Show-Stopping Required; An Overlooked Trailblazer; Suzanne Farrells Ideal Role
description: BERGMAN AND ANTONIONI

title: Christmas in August
description: Proving that one persons pork is anothers example of government at its finest, Democrats who control the Legislature are engaged in a mud fight with the governors office over how to pay for local projects. The Legislature is holding up its approval of more than $2.5 billion in bonding for the next two years unless Gov. M. Jodi Rell agrees, as part of the package, to $208 million worth of playgrounds , athletic fields, emergency centers, roof replacements and the like  stuff thats known here, in Washington and in state capitols across the land, as Christmas tree projects, but pork to you and me.

title: Smoldering Auteur With a Short Fuse
description: CAN a director be too independent for independent film? In an arena increasingly seen as an annex of the major studios and where one of Hollywoods contributions has been the acceptance of compromise, the career of the writer and director Tom DiCillo would suggest its true.

title: The Insiders Arent So Bearish, After All
description: THE sharp stock market decline that began in late July is more likely to be a minor downturn in a continuing bull market than the beginning of a major bear market. That, at least, is the conclusion of an extensive analysis of corporate insiders trading behavior.

title: Chilled, for Dog Days
description: Burgundy produces little dry sparkling wine. Louis Bouillots Perle dAurore ros Crmant de Bourgogne is among the best. Chilled well, its a terrific mid-August refresher.

title: In a Credit Crisis, Large Mortgages Grow Costly
description: When an investment banker set out to buy a $1.5 million home on Long Island last month, his mortgage broker quoted an interest rate of 8 percent. Three days later, when the buyer said he would take the loan, the mortgage banker had bad news: the new rate was 13 percent.

title: Woods Widens Lead and Beckons a New Challenger
description: TULSA, Okla., Aug. 11  Beneath the beating rays of the summer sun, Tiger Woods continued the business of hitting and chasing his golf ball, bending shots around the doglegs of Southern Hills to reprise his chase of Jack Nicklaus.

title: Bad News Begins With the Bullpen and Ends With Lo Ducas Injury
description: The Florida Marlins came back to beat the Mets, 7-5, in dramatic fashion yesterday at Shea Stadium. For the Mets, that was not even the worst news of the night.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: AIRLINE SEATS

title: Much More Than Clams
description: One shouldnt look for modesty in a business that dubs itself a castle, especially when its housed in a low-slung single-story affair made of wood, not stone, without a crenelation in sight. Yet at the Clam Castle, a bit of boasting seems appropriate, given that its been besieged by summertime seafood lovers for more than 40 years.

title: The Dismal Science, Dismally Taught
description: WHEN I began teaching economics in the 1970s, I noticed that people were generally disappointed when they learned what I did for a living. When I began asking why, many said something like this: I took Econ 101 years ago, and there were all those horrible equations and graphs.

title: Cagliari: The Other Sardinia
description: MANY of us imagine Sardinia as a Versace ad come to life: European playboys lounging on megayachts and Champagne flowing endlessly at clubs named, without irony, Billionaire. And its so  at least during the fashionable months of July and August, if you limit your visit on the island to the tiny, northeast jet-set enclave known as Costa Smeralda, or the Emerald Coast.

title: Paving Over Fun
description: WHERE we come from, fun is much more circumscribed, friends from Frankfurt told me, wide-eyed, when I took them out to Coney Island a few years ago.

title: Bridge Collapse Puts Focus on Aging Local Spans
description: EILEEN DAILEY cant remember much about her rescue on June 28, 1983, from the collapse of the Mianus River Bridge on Interstate 95 in Greenwich, Conn., that sent her Toyota and three other vehicles plunging 75 feet into the dark water at about 1:30 in the morning. But she still lives with the partial paralysis that has been the legacy of the disaster for her.

title: Poland to Hold Early Elections
description: WARSAW, Aug. 12  Seeking to end months of political turmoil, Polish officials confirmed today that the government would hold elections by November, two years ahead of schedule.

title: A Neighborhood in Waiting
description: ELVIA NUEZ first arrived in the Bronx at age 11, when her family moved to the Fordham neighborhood from Mexico. They settled on Lorillard Place, in the Belmont section just below Fordham Road. There, they found an ethnically diverse neighborhood with a growing Latin American population.

title: Exotics on the Easy Payment Plan
description: WERE F. Scott Fitzgerald alive today, he might be surprised to learn that the very rich are not always so different from you and me, at least in how they pay for their cars.

title: Imposing a Sublet Fee
description: Q Would a co-op have to amend its proprietary lease in order to impose a fee when shareholders rent out their apartments? My co-op has no restrictions on subletting, and the board says that because the proprietary lease does not require shareholders to obtain its consent to sublet, the lease would have to be amended before the board could impose a sublet fee. And that would require the vote of two-thirds of the shareholders.

title: Chicken Littles Brethren, on the Trading Floor
description: THE job of an economist, among many other duties, is to put things into perspective. So, because I am an economist, among other duties, here is a little perspective on the recent turmoil in the stock and bond markets.

title: An Abundance of Cruelties
description: Anyone who reads the papers or watches TV news sooner or later confronts something appalling  journalism is, among other things, a catalog of human cruelties. Recent accounts of severe and shocking mistreatment of animals in the New York region have underscored this truth in a heartsickening way.

title: When Conflict Washes Up on a Quiet Maine Island
description: Vinalhaven, Me.

title: Educating With Bribes (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: In Clam-Shack Country, the Classics Reign
description: LOCAL bounty is increasingly the attraction in the world's best eating places. And although the waters off Cape Cod have seen a terrible decline in fish (if it were discovered today, it would be named Cape Clam Shack, or Cape Summer House) there are still enough commercial fishermen to supply local restaurants. So I wish the reigning philosophy would be more as it is in coastal communities elsewhere: Here's what we've got, and we hope you like it. Aren't well-traveled Americans, having eaten whelk in France, head-on sardines in Italy, and fresh sea cucumber in Spain, venturesome enough to sample local shark, monkfish, octopus, skate and more?

title: Who Owns the Concept if No One Signs the Papers?
description: WHO owns a bright idea? If the technology associated with an idea is new and the opportunities it offers are valuable, it will have many authors  most of whom may argue over ownership.

title: How India Built the Bomb (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Shuffling Off to Crawford, 2007 Edition
description: THE cases of Pat Tillman and Jessica Lynch were ugly enough. So surely someone in the White House might have the good taste to draw the line at exploiting the murdered Wall Street Journal reporter Daniel Pearl. But nothing is out of bounds for a government that puts the darkest arts of politics and public relations above even the exigencies of war.

title: Look Whos Talking
description: Academia, unlike every other sector of our culture, has apparently been considered too dull and esoteric to merit a reality show, but now theres a natural vehicle: evolutionary linguistics, an emerging field awash in colorful personalities, wacky experiments and enough conflict to carry several seasons. Dont let the name throw you; the scientists who study the origins of language are a passionate, fractious bunch, and you dont have to be an egghead to be tantalized by the questions that drive their research: how and when did we learn to speak, and to what extent is language a uniquely human attribute? Call the show American Babble.

title: Jennifer Abt, Andrew Eimer
description: Jennifer Rachel Abt, a daughter of Marci Rush Abt and Richard J. Abt of Meadowbrook, Pa., was married last evening to Andrew David Eimer, the son of Nancy R. Eimer and Jeffrey H. Eimer of Dix Hills, N.Y. Rabbi Joel Alpert officiated at the Park Hyatt Philadelphia at the Bellevue, and Rabbi Richard Allen took part in the ceremony.

title: Kathleen Agresta, Thomas Price
description: Kathleen Anne Agresta, a daughter of Joan Agresta and Richard Agresta of Darien, Conn., was married Friday evening to Thomas Haile Upton Price, the son of Sondra Price and Dr. Thomas Price of Hopkinsville, Ky. The Rev. Edward J. Mills III, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the Wequassett Resort and Golf Club in Chatham, Mass.

title: Now, Even Those Temporary Wheels Can Be Greener
description: ROO ROGERS, who lives in Lower Manhattan, is helping to reduce auto emissions by not owning a car. But he still likes to take the wheel for occasional multistop spins around town, for hundred-mile drives to a vacation home on Long Island and for business trips when hes in California.

title: Jessica Kaufman, Joshua Goodman
description: Jessica Yael Kaufman, a daughter of Susan B. Kaufman and Dr. Richard E. Kaufman of Woodbridge, Conn., was married last evening to Joshua Alan Goodman, a son of Lauren E. Goodman and Dr. Richard A. Goodman of Pittsburgh. Rabbi Jo David officiated at Tribeca Rooftop in New York.

title: Correction: Letter on Peeling the Onion
description: A letter to the editor last Sunday responding to a review of Gnter Grasss Peeling the Onion misattributed an epithet applied to the critic Marcel Reich-Ranicki, who was once pictured on the cover of Der Spiegel ripping apart one of Grasss novels. It was the reviewer who referred to him as a senile tyrant, not Grass.

title: Romney Wins Iowa Straw Poll by a Sizable Margin
Superdude
description: There is much that is supergood about your performance in Superbad, which opens this week. But how do you feel about landing your first big role in a film that celebrates male immaturity and vulgarity? Any time I have a conversation with a female reporter, this kind of comes up. The way that Michael Cera and I talk in the movie is vulgar. But whether people realize it or not, this is how 17-year-old kids talk today. You might not want to believe it.

title: Ariana Rosen, Ross Levine
description: Ariana Rosen, the daughter of Barbara and Barry M. Rosen of Manhattan, was married last evening to Ross Michael Levine, the son of Deborah and Ronald S. Levine of Merrick, N.Y. Rabbi Charles A. Klein officiated at Cipriani 23rd Street in Manhattan.

title: Letters
description: Robin Marantz Henigs article (July 29) conveys the excitement of how much the new robotic generation can do  or seem to do  such as interact with civility. But it falls short of solving the puzzle of why the gap between mechanical understanding on one hand and plain old human consciousness on the other is actually growing rather than shrinking as our machines get more advanced. Berkeleys John Searle has said that figuring out what consciousness is, on its own undeniably subjective terms, is our No. 1 scientific challenge.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,674 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American last week:

title: Old School
description: Many sports give a separate award to promising rookies, and Im glad they do. It would be unfair to demand that a rosy new talent show the prime-time swagger, the champion savvy of an M.V.P.; almost no one grabs that Jeter-and-Jordan perfection his first time up.

title: Russian Voters Feeling Lost Without Translation
description: WHEN Inna Stavitsky ran for City Council from Brighton Beach in 2001, she found herself operating an unpaid sideline in translation.

title: Heather Rossi, Christopher Spadaccini
description: Heather Elizabeth Rossi, the daughter of Patricia S. Rossi and Edward J. Rossi of Pittstown, N.J., was married yesterday to Christopher Henry Spadaccini, the son of Marie Spadaccini and Henry Spadaccini of Brooklyn. The Rev. Peter G. Suhaka, performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of Christ the King in New Vernon, N.J.

title: Colonizing an Urban Frontier
description: THE NOPA district of San Francisco  the name stands for north of the Panhandle, that sliver of green jutting east from Golden Gate Park  was once known mostly for low-income housing and random shootings. But an influx of attention-getting restaurants and boutiques in the last decade has made it one of the city's cooler destinations, even as it struggles to maintain its gritty individuality.

title: Beijing 08: Let the Politics Begin
description: BEIJING

title: Correction: Kim Bendheim and Peter Fleischer
description: An article last Sunday about the marriage of Kim Bendheim and Peter Benjamin Fleischer misstated the title of a book by Susan Butler, the brides mother. It is East to the Dawn: The Life of Amelia Earhart, not East of the Dawn.

title: In Oakland, a Black Pillar Dissolves in Unrest
description: OAKLAND, Aug. 10  A federal judges order to liquidate the assets of Your Black Muslim Bakery will shutter one of this citys black nationalist institutions, a step called long overdue by many members of the clergy and community activists.

title: Auckland, New Zealand: Harrowset Hall
description: Harrowset Hall sounds like a prim English girls dormitory, so it's a bit of a shock to step through the small door on a quiet stretch of Ponsonby, a shopping district in Auckland, and discover a romantic den of feminine clutter that is more boudoir than boarding school.

title: Sorting Through the Buyout Freezeout
description: WELL, so much for the slow leak theory.

title: Volkswagens Wildest Bug
description: GREENWICH, Conn.

title: Dont Shut Off the Voters
description: Between 1997 and 2002, voters in Monroe rejected budgets approved by the Town Council 14 times, the most that any town in the state turned down its own budget during that period. This year, Monroe has outdone itself; it turned down a $70 million budget five times in the last several months before finally passing it.

title: Tomato, Tomahto, et Al.
description: The tomatoes are in at Sang Lee Farms. Not just beefsteaks and cherry tomatoes; there are teardrop-shaped yellow tomatoes, small tart green zebra tomatoes, and more than 30 other varieties grown on the farms 23 acres (beefsteaks and zebra tomatoes, $4.99 a pound; cherry and teardrop tomatoes, $3.49 a pint).

title: Bookshelf
description: PICTURES FROM OUR VACATION. Written and illustrated by Lynne Rae Perkins. Greenwillow/HarperCollins. $16.99. (Ages 5 to 8) Perkins captures the rainy days, empty-pool motel days and bent-racquet days that can make a vacation drag, until it suddenly develops its own glow. In a wonderful comic touch, Perkins (Criss Cross) has a brother and sister take pictures mostly of collapsing lawn chairs and the empty pool, while all the things its hard to take a picture of are what they will always remember.

title: Inside the List
description: CRITICAL LIST: On The Timess best-seller lists, the short descriptions that follow each title are written by editors here, who keep their opinions out of it. It wasnt always thus. Observe the paperback best-seller list below, for example, which ran in these pages 35 years ago this week  on Aug. 13, 1972. Poor William Blatty, who made No. 1 only to have an anonymous voice describe his novel as a crude occult exploitationer. Then theres Xaviera Hollander, whose Happy Hooker fares even worse. Here are the lists  at that time they were kept to five titles in each category:

title: Revival of Blondes Bounces Past Dead Spots
description: Anita Loos seemed to be hedging her bets when she wrote the short novel Gentlemen Prefer Blondes in 1925 and the sequel But Gentlemen Marry Brunettes in 1928. In fact, both her zany literary creations  the blond Lorelei Lee and her brunet buddy Dorothy Shaw  had a good chance of landing a man, whether they wound up at the altar or not.

title: Cleavage Umbrage
description: Cleavage, a word once associated with a deep rift in Republican ranks, has now appeared within the Democratic Party.

title: Taylor Swanson, Marc Holley
description: Taylor Lauren Swanson, the daughter of Teri and Stephen C. Swanson of Manhattan, was married yesterday to Marc Jacob Holley, a son of Charles L. Holley of Midlothian, Va., and the late Tina M. Holley. Judge Arlene H. Hahn of the Housing Part of Civil Court in the Bronx, officiated at the Harvard Club of New York.

title: Tara Taff, Jake Levy
description: Tara Beth Taff, the daughter of Alissa S. Taff and Dr. Ross H. Taff of Huntington, N.Y., was married in New York last evening to Jake Matthew Levy, the son of Marjory Lehrer of Newton, Mass., and Dean J. Levy of Dover, Mass. Rabbi Susie Heneson Moskowitz officiated at the Ritz-Carlton, Battery Park.

title: Cloak and Dagger Amid the Saris
description: THE three men who work at Bollywood Music on 74th Street in Jackson Heights, Queens, have never seen Rabinder Singh. Neither has Kanubhai Chauhan, president of the Jackson Heights Merchants Association. Nor has Shiv Dass, the owner of two Indian clothing stores and a jewelry shop on the same street.

title: Dads in Iraq, and the Familys on Edge
description: HASKELL

title: Shira Abilevitz, Howard Forman
description: Shira Abilevitz, a daughter of Felice and Baruch Abilevitz of Brooklyn, is to be married today to Howard Leon Forman, a son of Susan Forman and Dr. Arthur J. Forman of Tampa, Fla. Rabbi Josh Blass is to perform the ceremony at Congregation Shaare Zion in Brooklyn.

title: Restoring Trust in Mass Transit
description: Residents, commuters and visitors showed a tremendous amount of grace and forbearance last week when torrential rains closed much of the subway system. Despite uncomfortable heat and humidity, they piled into overburdened buses and found other ways to cope. Now that everyone has had a chance to cool off, officials need to work overtime to regain the publics confidence in mass transit.

title: Erin Fischer, Gregory Acton
description: Erin Nicole Fischer, a daughter of Judge Nora Barry Fischer and Dr. Donald R. Fischer of Pittsburgh, was married yesterday to Gregory Francis Acton, the son of Joyce V. Acton and David H. Acton of Media, Pa. The Rev. Thomas Burke, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Paul Cathedral in Pittsburgh.

title: Bonds's Future Is on the Line, but His Past Is in the Way
description: Barry Bonds has worked for years to construct his reputation as the surly superstar, a man who cares so little about public opinion that he could barely face a television camera without sneering. Image and perception became a toxic mix once accusations of steroid use called into question his accelerating home run totals, completing Bondss public image as an arrogant jerk who probably cheated.

title: Riding the Velvet Rails
description: AS the train rolled across the Tibetan countryside, I stared out into a harsh, bleak landscape. Tibetan nomads rode horses across seemingly endless grasslands dotted with small alpine lakes and ravines cut across snow-capped peaks. Tibetan traders hauling wheelbarrows piled with meat and barley walked a solitary road alongside the train route.

title: Expect Slowdown on the Way to the Chase
description: WATKINS GLEN, N.Y., Aug. 11  Clint Bowyer is chasing a championship in only his second season in the Nascar Nextel Cup series. But he had decided that it might not be such a good idea to push the pace Sunday.

title: Like a Candy Store for Grown-Ups
description: Anyone who has stood, small coin in small hand, in an old-time candy store will get back that feeling of excitement when studying the seductive stock at Wm. Nicholas & Co. in Katonah. But instead of candy (although thats available, too), glistening jars, bags, boxes and bowls of fine foods cram the shelves and display cases, tempting the adult customer.

title: Visiting Justice
description: My wife's sister left her husband of 15 years. She has invited my wife and me to an overnight visit at her new boyfriend's house. I say that accepting the invitation would give the appearance of approval. I feel she should end one relationship or at least begin legal proceedings she has not before living with another man. My wife says it is not for us to judge. Should we visit her and her cohabiter du jour?

title: China Enacting a High-Tech Plan to Track People
description: SHENZHEN, China, Aug. 9  At least 20,000 police surveillance cameras are being installed along streets here in southern China and will soon be guided by sophisticated computer software from an American-financed company to recognize automatically the faces of police suspects and detect unusual activity.

title: Sorrow and Anger as Newark Buries Slain Youths
description: NEWARK, Aug. 11  From the early morning to the late afternoon, Newark was a city of mourning on Saturday, as people gathered at three separate funerals for three young friends executed in a schoolyard a week before.

title: The Rainbow Runway
description: GOOSE-PIMPLY in a turquoise string bikini and silver heels, Stacy Wang stepped up to the microphone in a back room of East Manor, a dim sum restaurant in Flushing, Queens, and breathed deeply. Hi, everyone, she said brightly, introducing herself in Mandarin to the eight judges for the preliminary round of this years Miss New York Chinese beauty pageant. Im Stacy Wang, and I am 18 years old. I like to dance, play the piano, swim, play Go and read.

title: As Survivors, We Were Closer Than Lovers
description: LESS than a minute after I arrived alone, on Amtrak from Manhattan, I knew this wasnt going to be easy. My ex-girlfriend, who was being as gracious as she could be after enduring a couple of years of cancer and four (partly successful) combinations of chemotherapy, was lighting a candle.

title: Two Outlaws, Blasting Holes in the Screen
description: THE story of Bonnie and Clyde has been told so many times that it has acquired the patina of legend. Its the kind of historical fable that circulates to explain how the world once was and how it came to be the way it is now: a morality tale in which the wild energies of youth defeat the stale certainties of age, and freedom triumphs over repression.

title: Fatah Denies Hamas Claim on Talks
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 12  A Hamas official in Gaza said today that his organization was holding unofficial talks with representatives from the rival Fatah movement, as tension between the factions continued to simmer on the ground. Fatah officials deny that any such dialogue is taking place.

title: Masters of the Arcade Caught in a Replay
description: REDMOND, Wash.

title: Jessica Kahan, Jeffrey Dvorett
description: Jessica Elise Kahan, a daughter of Betsy Kahan and Dr. Ronald Kahan of Wilton, Conn., was married last evening in Stamford, Conn., to Jeffrey Stuart Dvorett, a son of Barbara Dvorett and Barry Dvorett of East Meadow, N.Y. Cantor Shirah Sklar officiated at the Stamford Yacht Club.

title: A Joy on Many Levels, Especially the Culinary
description: AS I stood in the roomy space with soft lighting and a gorgeous flower arrangement, watching Cab Calloway and the Nicholas Brothers perform their hearts out on a flat-screen TV, I thought to myself, I like this restaurant.

title: Correction: Letter on Edge of Evolution
description: A letter to the editor on July 29 responding to a review of Michael J. Behes Edge of Evolution: The Search for the Limits of Darwinism misstated the year that an article about protein evolution by John Maynard Smith appeared in the journal Nature. It was 1970, not 1971.

title: The Home-Run Apple: Headed for the Dugout?
description: When a player on the Mets hits a home run at Shea Stadium, a giant fiberglass apple, nine feet in diameter, rises from a 10-foot black top hat beyond the outfield wall. But this bit of theatrical kitsch, a fixture of Mets games since 1980, is unlikely to survive beyond the 2008 season.

title: Ena Marwaha and David Lebel
description: Ena Marwaha and Ronald David Lebel were married yesterday at St. Francis of Assisi Church in Gates Mills, Ohio. The Rev. James L. Caddy, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated. Afterward, Shri Ashok Kumar Bhargava, a Hindu priest, performed a Hindu ceremony for the couple at the Cleveland Marriott East in Warrensville Heights, Ohio. The couple met at the University of Pennsylvania, from which they graduated.

title: Technology Reveals New Worlds to Map
description: MORE than a decade ago, when Michelle Boivin told her father she had decided to major in geography, he was not impressed. What are you going to do with a geography degree? she recalled him saying. All you can do with geography is teach.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: The dance entry today in the Week Ahead report in Arts & Leisure misstates the date and time of a performance by Roxane Butterfly. She will perform at the Josie Robertson Plaza on Wednesday at 6 p.m., not Thursday at 8 p.m.

title: It May Look Like Chaos, but Its the Fringe
description: PLEASANT chaos powers the Midtown office of the New York International Fringe Festival. A gaggle of 20-somethings are usually in constant motion, squeezing past cluttered desks to answer phones, sort tickets or grab half-finished sodas from atop a tower of file boxes. Meanwhile their boss  Elena K. Holy, the festivals producing artistic director  stays just as busy in a corner that she has closed off with a pastel-colored curtain.

title: Old Questions Confront the Giants New Faces
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Aug. 11  Among the smattering of fans sprinkled across the red and blue seats of Giants Stadium during the Giants first preseason game Saturday night, many wore replica jerseys of players who were not in a Giants uniform, and might never be again. Side by side, children wearing jerseys reading Barber and Strahan sat near adults wearing Simms and Taylor.

title: Appealing to the Senses, and One in Particular
description: OPTIONS are the name of the game at Taste in Garden City. Diners can make a meal of Small Tastes (interesting tidbits) or choose the more traditional Tastes (appetizers) and Large Tastes (entrees).

title: Sarah Luskin, Kenan Stern
description: Sarah Ruth Luskin, a daughter of Dr. Judith Luskin and Michael Luskin of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Dr. Kenan Walter Davis Stern, a son of Dr. Margaret Ewing Stern and Henry J. Stern of Manhattan, are to be married this afternoon. Cantor Chanin Becker is to officiate at Tappan Hill, an event space in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Sounding the Alarm, or at Least Trying To
description: BUCHANAN, N.Y.

title: How a Good War in Afghanistan Went Bad
description: Two years after the Taliban fell to an American-led coalition, a group of NATO ambassadors landed in Kabul, Afghanistan, to survey what appeared to be a triumph  a fresh start for a country ripped apart by years of war with the Soviets and brutal repression by religious extremists.

title: Kristen Bethke, Christopher Wendell
description: Kristen Ann Bethke, a daughter of Patricia and Philip Bethke of Midlothian, Va., was married yesterday to Christopher Scott Wendell, a son of Lynn and Peter Wendell of San Francisco. The Rev. Amy E. McCreath, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony, and the Rev. Dr. Stephen L. White, also an Episcopal priest, participated in the chapel at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in Cambridge. The couple met at Princeton, from which they graduated, she summa cum laude, he magna cum laude.

title: The Thorns in Natures Bouquet
description: THE wildflowers are out in force: clouds of Queen Annes lace (also known as wild carrot); clusters of sharp two-toned black-eyed Susan; legions of spiky purple-hatted wild bergamot (or bee balm); and, if you are up early, the pretty petunia-like morning glory, a flower that more than lives up to its name.

title: Correction: A Neighborhood Worth the Big-Ticket Investment
description: The Living In article last Sunday, about Central Harlem, misstated the plans for brownstones that are being renovated by Housing Works and the Abyssinian Development Corporation. They are to be used as housing for homeless single adults and families with members living with AIDS or infected with H.I.V., not to be sold at below-market rates through a lottery.

title: Up Front
description: Christopher Hitchens once wrote a profile of Philip Pullman for Vanity Fair, but Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows is the first childrens book he has reviewed. Its been debated whether J. K. Rowlings novels can really be considered childrens books, when so many adults read them, but Hitchens comes down firmly on the side that they are  even though their author sometimes tries to pose adult dilemmas such as slavery and even bureaucracy, he wrote in an e-mail message.

title: Jay Leno and Conan OBrien
description: JAY LENO

title: A House to Grow Into
description: MOIM, a Korean-inspired restaurant that opened recently in Park Slope, is the kind of place that convinces Brooklynites that theyre living in the most cosmopolitan part of the city.

title: Yes, a Lot of People Died, but ...
description: MOSCOW

title: Shauna Burgess, Jonathan Friedman
description: Shauna Kathleen Burgess, the daughter of Diane and Thomas J. Burgess of Great Falls, Va., was married yesterday to Jonathan Hale Friedman, a son of Karen and Edward A. Friedman of Scarsdale, N.Y. Cantor Jan Morrison officiated at the Congressional Country Club in Bethesda, Md., with the Rev. Michael J. Kelley, a Roman Catholic priest participating.

title: Nantuckets Medical Mr. Fix-It for Whatever Happens to Ail You
description: NANTUCKET, Mass.  For an island flush with the financially fortunate, Dr. Timothy Lepore is a great leveler.

title: Baseball Brotherhood: It's Not Just an Expression
description: Justin Upton and Delmon Young began their baseball careers in similar fashion. Two years apart, they were the first players selected in the June amateur draft, Young by the Tampa Bay Devil Rays in 2003 and Upton by the Arizona Diamondbacks in 2005.

title: Not Being There
description: Granola-eating street fighter is the unimprovable description that BusinessWeek.com recently bestowed on John P. Mackey, the chief executive of Whole Foods Market. There certainly arent many people like Mackey, a vegan who has ruthlessly built Whole Foods into a $6 billion chain of organic groceries. But there are a lot of people who, one way or another, share his recent predicament.

title: Dancing Away the Heartache, Tacos Included
description: AT Tacos 2004, a taqueria in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, whose bland red-brick exterior belies the rollicking scene inside, six waitresses two-stepped and twirled their customers across an impossibly small dance floor. The women wore identical white tops and black miniskirts with high slits that fanned out when they whirled.

title: Weekley Is Not Like the Others
description: Tulsa, Okla.

title: New Brunswick Still Loves the Lads From Liverpool
description: THERE seems to be a severe strain of latter-day Beatlemania circulating at the State Theater in New Brunswick.

title: Suffering Differently
description: After the 2004 tsunami in Asia, many mental-health experts agreed that a second tsunami of mental illness in the form of post-traumatic stress disorder would strike the region. Like doctors rushing to the outbreak of an epidemic, American counselors and trauma researchers soon arrived on the scene hoping to pass on useful knowledge about PTSD. A few years on, however, their efforts have raised a troublesome question: Were they bringing the wrong treatment to the wrong people?

title: Ohio Pushes Added Leave for Maternity
description: CINCINNATI, Aug. 11  The Ohio Civil Rights Commission is pushing for a broad expansion of benefits for pregnant workers.

title: Childrens Books
description: When my son was a baby, he had two ways of reviewing a new book. If he liked it, he would say Den! at the end, for again. If he didnt like it, he would singsong Dah-doy, for goodbye. Sometimes, dah-doy came right in the middle of the book  a very negative review. A few months later, he added too bore to the review lineup.

title: Darkness Falls
description: New Yorkers have switched from light summer clothes to their annual black August. A man, left, wears Chinese-style clothes, in the right fabric for the season. Echoing the sudden swarm of black are the imaginative fly-swatter sculptures by Terence Gower in the windows at Barneys, which include a fly, above; a dragonfly, below; a spider and a beetle.

title: Laura Baur, Henryk Jaronowski
description: Laura Anne Baur, the daughter of Irene and William F. Baur of Glenwood, N.J., is to be married today to Henryk Jaronowski, the son of Lola and Efraim Jaronowski of Monroe, N.Y. Rabbi Garry A. Loeb is to officiate at the Meadowbrook, a reception hall in New Windsor, N.Y.

title: Judging Ethics in Albany
description: As a general rule, the arbiters of ethics in New York States capitol are not a particularly energetic bunch. Despite numerous indictments of legislators in recent years, for example, the Legislative Ethics Committee has seemed asleep most of the time. And the State Ethics Commission, which has moved into the spotlight as the prime investigator of Gov. Eliot Spitzer, has in the past been a politically cautious group.

title: Dark Water
description: If Id been asked to bet on whod write the definitive crime novel about Hurricane Katrina and the devastation of New Orleans, my money would have been on James Lee Burke. And thats just what he delivers in THE TIN ROOF BLOWDOWN (Simon & Schuster, $26), a hard-boiled cops-and-robbers yarn that puts a human face on anonymous acts of good and evil in the chaos and horror of this natural disaster and its manmade aftermath.

title: For Jets Clemens, the Wait Pays Off
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Aug. 11  Because quarterback Kellen Clemens appeared in only two games as a rookie last season and attempted only one pass, people assume his first season with the Jets was unproductive.

title: Wartime Lies
description: Anne Frank attracts writers. Her best-known starring role in a literary improvisation is in Philip Roths 1979 novel, The Ghost Writer, in which Nathan Zuckerman spins a surreal tale about the hidden identity of a dark-haired, sexy, European-accented young woman he meets in the house of his mentor. The year is 1956; she would be the famous diarists age had Anne Frank survived the war. Zuckerman, reviled for daring to provoke Jewish sensibilities, fantasizes about introducing this Holocaust saint to his parents as his (already pregnant) bride and being welcomed back into the fold as a result.

title: Amy Jones, Steven Freitas
description: Amy Kathleen Jones and Steven Freitas were married yesterday in Rome. Luca Badino, a city clerk, officiated at city hall.

title: Police Hunt for a Fourth Suspect in Newark Schoolyard Killings
description: NEWARK, Aug. 11  The police appealed for the publics help on Saturday in finding a 24-year-old man they said was part of a band of men and teenagers who shot and killed three young people and wounded another last weekend in a Newark schoolyard.

description: Lauren Michelle Ordene and David Andrew Edelstein are to be married today at Temple Beth Ahm in Springfield, N.J. Rabbi Dov Hillel Klein is to perform the ceremony.

description: The toy industry had its Tickle Me Elmo, the automakers the Prius and technology its iPhone. Now, the food world has its latest have-to-have-it product: the cage-free egg.

description: The 36 Hours column on July 29 about Edinburgh misstated the name of the royal residence there; the error was repeated on the map. It is the Palace of Holyroodhouse, not Hollyrood House.

description: MANY companies that have opted out of the tight Midtown Manhattan market in favor of Greenwich and Stamford office space are attracting growing numbers of young city dwellers who are turning the traditional commuting pattern on its head.

description: IT is now widely believed that the aggressive mortgage lending during the recent real estate boom was unprecedented. In the final counting, that assessment may well be accurate.

description: The dance entry today in the Week Ahead report in Arts & Leisure misstates the date and time of a performance by Roxane Butterfly. She will perform at the Josie Robertson Plaza on Wednesday at 6 p.m., not Thursday at 8 p.m. (Go to Article)

title: A Slice of Nascar Country, Far, Far North of Talladega
description: WATKINS GLEN, N.Y., Aug. 11  A long line of cars and campers crept through the intersection of Fourth and Franklin Streets here during lunchtime on Friday, over pavement painted like a checkered flag. Unlike a typical stock car race in which ornery drivers swap fender paint, the procession was orderly.

title: Between Win and Lose, the Casino Dealer
description: OVER the course of his career at the Jackson Rancheria Casino and Hotel in Jackson, Calif., Joe Hebel has been seen as a harbinger of fortune, a liaison to luck and the sweetest angel known to man.

description: If Mahalia Jackson ever spoke a cross word or had an impure thought, you wont find out about it at the Hartford Stage. Tom Stolzs Mahalia  A Gospel Musical treats the woman generally acknowledged to have been the worlds greatest gospel singer as if she were Saint Mahalia  and the audience as if it were at Sunday school instead of the theater.

title: Maureen Miesmer, Joshua Fay-Hurvitz
description: Maureen Elizabeth Miesmer, a daughter of Mary K. and Kenneth J. Miesmer of West Hartford, Conn., was married yesterday to Joshua Nathaniel Fay-Hurvitz, a son of Eileen D. Fay and Henry B. Hurvitz of West Hartford. Lois Procopion, a justice of the peace in Berlin, Conn., officiated in Riverside Park in Hartford.

title: Hallie Grainer, Mitchell Ulman
description: Hallie Beth Grainer, the daughter of Rochelle Grainer and Dr. Mark Grainer of Marlboro, N.J., was married last evening to Mitchell Adam Ulman, a son of Donna Ulman and Howard Ulman of Sharon, Mass. Rabbi Donald A. Weber officiated at the Rockleigh Country Club in Rockleigh, N.J., with Cantor Jacqueline Shuchat-Marx participating.

title: Childrens Books / Young Adult
description: Ask any high school girl: boys can be a pain. Fall for one who seems appealing, and he turns out to be a monster. One moment he acts like you dont exist, the next, he drives you crazy by playing it cool  while his brothers circle you with hungry eyes. If you take a break to cut the tension, and hang out just friends-style with a younger guy whos puppy-dogging you, what happens? Wouldnt you know, he turns out to be a nightmare too.

title: Indias Whiskey-Drinking Elite Make Room for Wine
description: GUNDAMAKERE, India  They used to grow millet in the lap of these gentle hills, and mulberry trees to eke out silkworms. Today, the land is home to Kapil Grovers shiraz vines.

description: BACH: SONATAS AND PARTITAS FOR VIOLIN SOLO

But Peter Pracilio fears that even Americas most beloved dogs suffer from needless stress, caused by the boxy crates in which they often have to sleep or travel.

description: I GREW up in a rambling clapboard house in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn with five brothers and sisters, and two maiden aunts.

title: Spawn Fishing
description: Out on the island-speckled delta of Alaskas Yukon River, a Yupik Eskimo named Ray Waska and I were cutting the heads off a pile of salmon. After about 20 decapitations, I asked, So, Ray, you guys ever get sick of eating this stuff?

title: Bridget Healy, Richard Sandler
description: Bridget M. Healy and Richard J. Sandler are to be married this evening at the Central Park Boathouse. The Rev. John OBrien, a minister of the International Council of Community Churches and an uncle of the bride, is to officiate.

title: A Chinese Tycoon, Inspired to Create Police Technology
description: SHENZHEN, China, Aug. 9  Behind Shenzhens aggressive introduction of new police technologies is an unusual computer software company that has won some of the initial government contracts, China Public Security Technology, and the wealthy tycoon who runs it, Lin Jiang Huai.

title: It Takes Deep Pockets to Fight Global Warming
description: GLOBAL warming is by nature a big-enough problem to create the kind of necessity that could be mother, father and midwife to invention. And plenty of big ideas are out there to address it, some that may even lead to substantial enterprises much as our military needs have.

title: On the Road (and in the Water) With Richter
description: One weekend during the 1994-95 N.H.L. lockout, Mike Richter  who helped the Rangers win the Stanley Cup the season before  put his goaltending gear on ice, slipped on his running shoes and participated in a half-marathon in Duluth, Minn.
