description: Southold

title: Childrens Books
description: Thirteen-year-old boys are mysteries. By and large, they dont keep diaries and no, they dont want to talk about it, thank you very much. According to booksellers and parents Ive met, they dont read books either, but this may be just a nasty rumor.

title: Road Bomb in Iraq Kills 5, Including a Governor
Jasmina H.Ahmetovic, Morgan Goulet
description: Jasmina H.Ahmetovic, a daughter of Marija and Zulfikar H.Ahmetovic of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Morgan Andrew Lombard Goulet, a son of Julie and Gerard Goulet of Warwick, R.I. Justice Joseph Covello of the Appellate Division in the State of New York, in Brooklyn, officiated at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

title: Back to Nature, the Italian Way
description: WE were not 10 miles out of Cagliari, the cosmopolitan capital of Sardinia, when the late-afternoon traffic halted. The cause was soon apparent: a flood of long-haired sheep, blank eyes framed by wild white dreadlocks, spilling slowly across the highway.

title: What's On Tonight
description: 8 P.M. (TLC) DIANA: LAST DAYS OF A PRINCESS Ten years after the death of Diana, Princess of Wales, this docudrama recreates the 12 weeks leading up to the car crash in a Paris tunnel that killed her and her companion, Dodi al-Fayed. Genevieve OReilly and Patrick Baladi, above, portray the couple in a work based on interviews with their close associates. The script also draws from the 832-page Paget Report issued by Britains Metropolitan Police Service, which examines the princesss security arrangements, the scrutiny of Buckingham Palace and the news media, her relationship with the paparazzi, her thoughts on Mr. Fayed and her unrequited love for a British surgeon. Those weighing in include Mohamed al-Fayed, Dodis father, as well as his bodyguard Kez Wingfield. At 7, Diana: Her Last 10 Days in Pictures presents some of the final photographs taken of the princess.

title: The Watch List
description: The Tigers and the Indians have allowed the Twins to creep back into the American League Central race. If Minnesota can make its annual run, Matt Garza, right, could be a contributing factor. In six starts since being called back up from the minors, Garza, the teams top pitching prospect, is 1-3, but he has a 1.70 earned run average.

title: Rocking the Boat, but Why?
description: WALL STREET responded to the Federal Reserves interest rate announcement last week with firm, if rapidly fluctuating, conviction. Stock prices and Treasury bond yields fell sharply, then rose, then continued to swing energetically through the week  and that was after the Fed left rates unchanged.

title: A Fish Tale
description: A few months ago I took the most expensive nap of my life, and when it was over I decided it was all Hemingways fault. For $500, I booked a marlin charter out of Kailua-Kona, Hawaii. I had never gone for the really big fish, and I was juiced to finally get the chance. I imagined myself sitting, like Papa, on the deck of the Pilar, fighting the big fish in the big chair, muttering through gritted teeth the great mans motto Il faut (dabord) durer  first, one must endure.

title: S.I. Woman Is Killed and Son, 26, Injured
description: A woman was fatally shot inside her Staten Island home last night and her 26-year-old son was wounded, the authorities said.

title: False Alarm Triggers Turnpike Bus Hunt
description: SOUTH BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 11 (AP)  Officers from the State Police who responded Saturday to a call about armed men aboard a school bus on the New Jersey Turnpike found out the report was correct  sort of.

title: What's Your Sign?
description: A look at how American highway signs have changed, and how we ended up with the Clearview font.

title: Abreu Makes Case to Stay; Mussina Delivers Again
description: Walking into Joe Torres office on Saturday night, after an 11-2 victory over the Indians, the first question might as well have been, So, whos starting Game 1 of the World Series?

title: Your Comments on my Iraq Column
description: My Monday column is about Iraq, arguing that we need to pull out (perhaps with the exception of a force in Kurdistan). I also welcome the idea of partition to reduce the risk of genocide  but not if we have any fingerprints on the partition. Id welcome your comments.

title: Terrorism on the Rise
description: A timeline of terrorist attacks in Afghanistan from 2002 through 2005.

title: The Man in the White Sharkskin Suit
description: On the first Thursday night of every month, Cairo grew completely still as every man, from the pashas in their palaces to the fellahin in their hovels, huddled by the radio and motioned to their wives and children not to disturb them. It was the night when Om Kalsoum, the Nightingale of the Nile, the greatest singer Egypt had ever known, broadcast live from a theater in the Ezbekeya section, her voice so transcendent and evocative that her fans could picture exactly how she looked as she came out onto the stage, enveloped in the lush white lace dress that softened and transformed her features.

title: Afterwards
description: Winter afternoon, five hours patrolling, seventeen minutes on the vehicle checkpoint and counting. Rain. Two cars, two drivers: one man, one woman. She was in the white car, three children with her. One adult passenger, male, in the other car, the red one. One multiple: four men on the rise, four in the fields, and four on the road. Two of us by the first car, two by the second. One round fired.

title: The Headmaster Ritual
description: "We were supposed to meet this morning?" asked Dyer, standing in the shaded portico of Headmaster Wolfe's residence, the humid Massachusetts air on him like a quilt.

title: Seizing Destiny: How America Grew From Sea to Shining Sea
description: The great irony of James K. Polk's career as territorial expansionist extraordinaire, the one-term President under whom the United States acquired more land than any other, is that he was personally the least expansive of men.

title: A Round Table on Harry Potter
description: There are 325 million copies of the seven Harry Potter books in print around the world, in 65 languages. The final book, "Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows," sold 8.3 million copies the first day it was on sale, a publishing record. Almost more significantly, the series profoundly changed children's publishing, proving that there was potentially a huge crossover audience for popular titles. So what, finally, was it about Harry Potter that captured so many readers' imaginations? We asked a few writers, librarians, bloggers and kids what they thought the secret of Harry's success had been. Readers are invited to add their comments to the ones posted here.  - The Editors

title: Editors Choice
description: THE MASTER BEDROOM, by Tessa Hadley. (Holt, $26.) In Hadleys novel  a chess game of slow-burn erotic maneuvers  a London professor returning to her childhood home in Wales is attracted to the teenage son of an old friend.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE WORLD IS FLAT: A Brief History of the Twenty-First Century  Further Updated and Expanded, by Thomas L. Friedman. (Picador, $16. ) Building on his 1999 book, The Lexus and the Olive Tree, Friedman, a Pulitzer Prize-winning columnist for The New York Times, maps the next phase of globalization. What leveled the worlds economic playing field? Friedman cites 10 forces, including the dot-com bubble and bust, which turned China and India into high-tech epicenters of the outsourcing world. The World Is Flat considers the great opportunities and threats globalization represents to older industrialized nations, especially the United States. In the Book Review, Fareed Zakaria called Friedmans metaphor of a flat world ingenious: Its fundamental insight is true and deeply important.

title: Correction: Linz's Favorite Son, a Danish Quartet, a Soprano's Velvety Lasso
description: A CD review of Nicole Cabells Soprano last Sunday misstated the name of the composer of one selection, A Child of Our Time. He is Michael Tippett, not the composer Benjamin Britten.

title: Correction: Singers Grounded by Sacred Roots
description: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about gospel singers who have crossed over to make pop music misidentified the performer shown at left, holding a bass guitar. He is Danyel Morgan, a member of Robert Randolphs band, not Robert Randolph.

title: New Grandmaster Shows He Is Already a Force
description: Last month, Fabiano Caruana, a 15-year-old with dual United States and Italian citizenship, completed the requirements for the grandmaster title. Yesterday, he tied for first in the 11th Hogeschool Zeeland tournament in the Netherlands. He won the tournament on tiebreak. The results and some of the games can be seen at the official Web site for the tournament.

title: Sin in the Second City
description: In the winter of 1899, a train clattered toward Chicago, fat coils of smoke whipping the sky. Minna and Ada Everleigh sat together in a Pullman Palace car, sipping wine served by porters wearing white jackets and gloves. Velvet curtains framed the windows, and thick rugs absorbed the curved heels of their boots. The sisters checked their reflections in bevel-edged French mirrors,reclined on Marshall Field'smost luxurious bedsheets, ate in a dining car where woodcock and prairie chicken were presented on tables set with Belgian linen and expensive English china. The train, lit entirely by electricity, was fitted with a new contraption - "vestibules," accordion-shaped passageways that connected the cars, shutting out the fumes and wind. The air inside their car hung heavy and whisper quiet, but the sisters were restless, giddy with plans: They would build upon what they had learned as madams in Omaha, Nebraska, and create the finest brothel in history.

title: Moiseenko Wins Arctic Chess Challenge; Carlsen Ties for Second
description: Alexander Moiseenko, a grandmaster from Ukraine, has won the Arctic Chess Challenge in Tromso, Norway, with 7.5 points out of 9. Finishing in a tie for second, a half-point back, were grandmasters Kjetil A. Lie of Norway, Vugar Gashimov of Azerbaijan and Magnus Carlsen of Norway. The games and the results are on the official Web site for the tournament.

title: An Old Lion, but Still Dangerous
description: To describe Viktor Korchnoi as an ageless wonder is a cliche, but it is also apt. Korchnoi, who is 76, is leading the fifth Marx Gyorgy Memorial tournament in Paks, Hungary, after six rounds. His nearest competitor, chronologically, is Peter Acs of Hungary who is 26. The games and information about the competitors is here at the tournaments official Web site.

title: Lunacy and Chaos
description: A look at some of the shows in the 2007 New York International Fringe Festival.

title: How the Iowa Straw Poll Works
description: How did Mike Huckabee, who had a relatively small operation, come in second in the Iowa Straw Poll? The unique process of the poll itself is a part of the answer.

title: Well-Appointed Rentals
description: Developers are redefining the term "luxury rental" in Manhattan, for people who want the feel of a high-end condominium but don't want to buy.

title: A Questionable Straw Poll
description: Obviously this was an incredible day and victory for us, said former Arkansas governor Mike Huckabee of Saturdays Iowa Republican straw poll. What happened for us today was stunning. A curious statement, perhaps, given that Huckabee was soundly trounced by Mitt Romney  he finished with 18 percent of the vote to Romeneys 32 percent  but then again, given the haphazard nature of the Ames event, perhaps close doesnt only count in horseshoes.

title: Lo Duca Needs Time Off, but How Much?
description: Catcher Paul Lo Duca, who was placed on the disabled list following last nights 7-5 loss to the Florida Marlins, said today that he could probably play through his hamstring injury. But Manager Willie Randolph said the Mets simply did not want to take any chances.

title: Reasons for Saying No
description: When I asked readers to give their reasons for not having sex, I predicted the list wouldnt be as long as the reasons for saying yes. This didnt seem an especially risky prediction, given certain biological imperatives (and the survival of our species for a couple hundred thousand years or so).

title: Yankees Bear Down on Boston as Well-Armed Orioles Come to Town
description: The good news is everywhere for the Yankees, who are 29-10 since a brutal loss at home on July 1. They are just four games out of first place after their three-game sweep of the Indians and Eric Gagns weekend implosion in Baltimore for the Red Sox.

title: Asia Booming
description: Residential housing prices are surging in parts of Asia, according to the latest report by the Global Property Guide. After years of moderate growth, prices jumped more than 10 percent in the Philippines, Singapore and South Korea, the study found.

title: Electricity From the East River
description: Powerful currents and competition upstream have delayed the installation of more underwater turbines in the East River.

title: Tommy Thompson Bows Out of Race
description: After a sixth-place finish in Saturdays Iowa Straw Poll, Tommy Thompson, the four-term governor of Wisconsin and former secretary of the Department of Health and Human Services, said he was ending his presidential bid.

title: Your Perfect Work Environment
description: An article in todays New York Times reports that as technology enables people to live and work wherever they want, increasingly they are clustering in resort playgrounds like Steamboat Springs (pop. 9,315) that have natural amenities, good weather  and, now, lots of people like themselves.

title: Finding the Perfect Quarterback, and Plenty of Other Ones, Too
description: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla., Aug. 7  His friends called, stunned, during the off-season. But for Tampa Bay quarterback Chris Simms, sitting at home in New Jersey, the transaction news this spring brought amusing, and sometimes unsettling, familiarity.

title: Somalia and Ethiopia Are Accused of War Crimes
description: RUMBEK, Sudan, Aug. 13  Human Rights Watch on Monday accused the transitional government in Somalia and the Ethiopian troops that helped bring it to power of committing war crimes in Somalia, saying Ethiopian troops had shelled hospitals, Somali officials had blocked aid convoys and both forces had shown wanton indifference toward civilians.

title: West Islip: Man Accused of Hitting Woman While Driving Drunk
description: A Medford man was charged yesterday with driving while intoxicated after he apparently accidentally backed his car into his female companions mother, the Suffolk County police said. The man, Kenneth Gonzalez, 30, left a party at his companions house in West Islip after fighting with several of her family members, the police said. Several people had surrounded his Chevrolet Lumina, which was in the driveway, and when Mr. Gonzalez backed up, he struck the woman, Denise Stark, 49, the police said. Ms. Stark was taken to Stony Brook University Medical Center, where she was in critical condition yesterday with a broken neck and head injuries.

title: And the Girls Fall Panting at Their Two Left Feet
description: The descriptions of romantic ruin given by the eight goofballs who show up for sexual makeovers tonight on VH1s Pick-Up Artist feature more slapstick than misery. The dateless guys use metaphors involving pratfalls, bottles that break on their heads and even backward cartwheels to evoke how they feel when stunned into terrified silence by desirable women.

title: F.D.A. and Tobacco (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Japanese Film Wins Top Prize in Locarno
description: The Japanese film Ai No Yokan (The Rebirth) won the Golden Leopard, the top prize, at the Locarno International Film Festival in Switzerland. Written and directed by Masahiro Kobayashi, above, the winning film is a love story about the mother of a murderer and the victims father, played by the filmmaker.

title: To Stop Abuse, Hold the Abusers Accountable (3 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Public Service  Through Mug Shots
description: Animal Care & Control of New York City, a nonprofit organization that runs the citys animal shelter system, is counting on mug shots to increase support.

title: The No-Match Non-Solution
description: Who kept telling the country that immigration reform through enforcement alone was doomed to fail? President Bush, for one. All elements of this problem must be addressed together, he warned, or none of them will be solved. So what can be said about Mr. Bushs latest stab at a policy, which fixates almost entirely on barricading the border, rooting out illegal workers and punishing their employers?

title: Catch Me, Im Falling
description: THE horrific collapse of the Interstate 35W bridge in Minneapolis was but one more in the history of infrastructure failures, and Im afraid it will be old news soon.

title: China, Filling a Void, Drills for Riches in Chad
description: KOUDJIWAI, Chad  The small plane flew in low over a scorched, peppercorn scrubland, following a broad, muddy river that was all elbows on its run to the southeast.

title: Elderly Organize to Meet Problems of Aging
description: WASHINGTON  On a bluff overlooking the Potomac River, George and Anne Allen, both 82, struggle to remain in their beloved three-story house and neighborhood, despite the frailty, danger and isolation of old age.

title: Elizabeth Murray, 66, Artist of Vivid Forms, Dies
description: Elizabeth Murray, a New York painter who reshaped Modernist abstraction into a high-spirited, cartoon-based, language of form whose subjects included domestic life, relationships and the nature of painting itself, died yesterday at her home in upstate New York.

title: It Was Over Long Before It Was Over
description: Tulsa, Okla.

title: Matthew Pulls Away
description: Catriona Matthew won the Scandinavian T.P.C. yesterday, shooting a four-under-par 68 and beating Laura Diaz and Sophie Gustafson by three shots in Loddekopinge, Sweden. Matthew finished with a nine-under 279 for her fifth victory. Annika Sorenstam, the defending champion and tournament host, closed with a 68 for her best round of the tournament and moved to 9th from 21st.

title: A Shakespearean Deal With an Unlikely Assist
description: How does that quotation from Twelfth Night go? Some are born great, some achieve greatness, and some have greatness thrust upon them.

title: Importing Chiefs, Detroit Reflects on Its Car Guys
description: DETROIT, Aug. 12  Where have all the car guys gone?

title: Republicans Debated YouTube Forum Is Back On
description: It looks as if the Republican presidential candidates, at least most of them, will be participating in a YouTube debate after all. The forum is now set for Nov. 28, the Wednesday after Thanksgiving.

Because of an editing error, an article Friday about newly released portions of an inquiry into the detention by the United States of a Syrian-born Canadian, Maher Arar, who was sent to a third country, where he was tortured, misstated in some copies the country where another Canadian, Ahmad Abou el-Maati, was tortured. It was Syria, not Kuwait. Because of an editing error, the article also misstated the current value of a compensation package offered to Mr. Arar in January. The package was estimated to be 11.5 million Canadian dollars, including legal fees, although the exact amount of the fees was not disclosed. At current exchange rates, that would be about $10.9 million, not $9.75 million.

title: Delaying the Inevitable
description: As we struggle to extricate ourselves from Iraq, its useful to look at how the Soviet Union handled a similar position in the 1980s. Then we should do the opposite.

title: East River Fights Bid to Harness Its Currents for Electricity
description: From the eastern edge of Roosevelt Island, the past and perhaps the future of New York power are on display.

title: New Formula Means More Money for Arts Groups in New York
description: The Mark Morris Dance Group got $80,000, up from $12,000 last year. The Flux Factory, an arts center in Long Island City, Queens, got $20,000, up from $3,000 last year. And the Mama Foundation for the Arts, which teaches gospel music, jazz and R&B in Harlem, got $12,500, up from $5,000.

title: If We Treat Terrorists Like Criminals (4 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: The Week Ahead
description: THE CREDIT SQUEEZE The main focus will be on the credit crisis and its effect on the markets. Wednesday will be the 45th day before the end of the quarter, the deadline by which most hedge fund investors must notify the funds if they want to redeem investments.

Because of an editing error, an article on July 26 about the family background of Joshua Komisarjevsky, one of two suspects in the home invasion slayings of a woman and her two daughters in Cheshire, Conn., referred incorrectly to In Cold Blood, which recounted the similar murders of a Kansas family in 1959. Although the author, Truman Capote, referred to the work in an interview as a nonfiction novel before its publication in 1966, it is not in fact a novel.

title: Stewart Keeps Surging as Gordon Spins Out
description: WATKINS GLEN, N.Y., Aug. 12  The race seemed over, but then the most treacherous turn on a slippery track claimed one more car. Clutching to the lead less than two laps from the finish on a chaotic afternoon, Jeff Gordon spun out.

title: Too Darn Hot for Queen of Soul
description: Aretha Franklin canceled a hometown concert scheduled for last night at the DTE Energy Music Theater in suburban Detroit, because of the heat, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Franklin, the Queen of Soul, 65, said that with temperatures forecast to go above 90 degrees, the show could not go on, and that she hoped to reschedule it at a later date. I am exhausted from the heat and cannot tolerate heat in these extremely high numbers and being in concert simultaneously, she said in a statement.

title: Formerly at Voice, Editor Takes a Job at the Competition
description: Anyone who has ever been fired abruptly from a high-profile job can perhaps relate to the revenge fantasy that David Blum seems to be living out  and the retaliation he may have in mind for his former employer.

title: Woods Takes Every Shot and Wins 13th Major
description: TULSA, Okla., Aug. 12  There was a different texture to this five-mile walk, an appearance of tension and conflict in Tiger Woodss midst as he stepped into the furnace of Southern Hills Country Club on a broiling Sunday on the Plains.

title: A Jets End Gets a Taste of What He Missed
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Aug. 12  A lot of time had passed between N.F.L. snaps when defensive end Andre Wadsworth took the field Friday night at Giants Stadium. That much was evident in the string of unfamiliar faces staring back across the line of scrimmage.

title: For a Joke-Telling Candidate, a Second-Place Finish
description: DES MOINES, Aug. 12  I cant buy you  I dont have the money, Mike Huckabee, the Arkansas Republican seeking the presidency, told Republicans at the Iowa Straw Poll this weekend. He offered a mock frown.

title: Pack Mentality Among Hedge Funds Fuels Market Volatility
description: On Wall Street, there is a rage against the machine.

title: A First Turn for Wheeldon and Company
description: VAIL, Colo., Aug. 11  Could any new ballet company have begun with more good will and eager applause than Christopher Wheeldons Morphoses? At Fridays inaugural performance at the Vail International Dance Festival in Colorado, almost all of the six dances by the new troupe were greeted by instant standing ovations from large parts of the audience.

title: The Rove Legacy
description: Karl Rove leaves the White House in anything but victory. His legendary reputation was seriously diminished by the Republican defeat in the 2006 midterm elections, and has been eroded almost every day since then, as President Bush has struggled through his second term.

title: Irene Morgan Kirkaldy, 90, Rights Pioneer, Dies
description: Irene Morgan Kirkaldy, whose defiance of white supremacy while traveling through the Upper South in the summer of 1944 led to a Supreme Court decision outlawing segregated seating on interstate bus lines, died Friday in Hayes, Va. She was 90.

title: Aiming for a New Pittsburgh, and Falling Short
description: CIUDAD GUAYANA, Venezuela  When a group of urban planners from Harvard and M.I.T. arrived here in the early 1960s to design an industrial city almost entirely from scratch, they envisioned a Pittsburgh of the tropics that could anchor industrialization and population growth in southeastern Venezuela.

title: Its Lauren vs. Heidi in Battle of the Ex-BFFs
description: The Hills, which opens its third season on MTV tonight, is more convincing than Friends and just about any other comedy about female relationships because  as anyone who has ever been a young woman knows  undying friendships die.

title: Fighting Continues Over James Brown Estate
description: David Cannon, a co-executor of the will of the soul singer James Brown, right, who has been accused of misappropriating $350,000 of Browns money, resigned on Friday after handing over a check for the full amount during a court hearing, The Augusta Chronicle reported. Almost two dozen lawyers were present at the four-hour hearing before Judge Jack Early, of the South Carolina Second Judicial Circuit, representing the numerous family members and others who are wrangling over the estate. (Browns former pastor, the Rev. Larry Fryer, has filed a motion on behalf of needy children who are meant to benefit from the singers I Feel Good Trust.) Fridays hearing also revealed that there might not be much to fight for: Adele Pope and Robert Buchanan, the court-appointed lawyers assigned to help settle the estate, reported during the hearing that the estate and the trusts set up that were to be financed by Browns music royalties appear to have a zero balance. A follow-up hearing was scheduled for Sept. 24.

title: Inflation Surges in China
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 13  Steeply rising food prices pushed inflation in China to 5.6 percent last month, the fastest pace in a decade, government figures showed today, prompting renewed concern about whether inflation would spread more widely in China and abroad.

title: Packing Their Trunks and Making Their Getaways
description: The dance component of the 11th annual New York International Fringe Festival opened appropriately with All Aboard, an hourlong, multimedia work presented on Saturday afternoon at the Linhart Theater in the East Village by the Armstrong/Bergeron Dance Company of Bryan, Tex. But the trip ran out of steam well before its destination.

title: Bronx Man, 19, Is Killed in Shooting on the Subway
description: A 19-year-old man was killed and three of his friends were wounded after a man they were arguing with opened fire aboard a subway car in the Bronx yesterday morning, the police said.

title: Most Asian Markets Spring Back From Last Weeks Plunge
description: SINGAPORE, Aug. 13  If there is a crisis in global financial markets, it wasnt apparent in Asia today.

title: Head of Chinese Toy Company Said to Kill Himself
description: SHANGHAI, Aug. 13  The head of a Chinese company that was behind the recall earlier this month of more than a million Mattel toys committed suicide over the weekend, Chinas state-controlled media reported today.

title: Lo Duca Lands on D.L. With Bruised Feelings
description: It is not clear how much time catcher Paul Lo Duca will miss with a strained right hamstring. Lo Duca said yesterday that he would be ready to return as soon as he was eligible to come off the disabled list in two weeks.

title: New British Mens Magazine, but No Nudity, Please
description: LONDON, Aug. 12  Mike Soutar refuses to say who or what will be featured on the cover of Short List, a new mens magazine he is introducing next month in Britain. But one thing seems certain: if it is a female model, she will wear at least a bit of clothing.

title: Irresponsible Threats
description: The last thing China needs is to give American politicians new excuses to erect protectionist defenses against Chinese imports. So it is stupefying that some Chinese officials  with the blessing of the government press  have been talking of using Chinas enormous cache of American Treasury bonds as an economic weapon.

title: Ten Bucks a Dance
description: Twenty-eight dance companies from around the world will converge on New York City Center for the fourth annual Fall for Dance Festival, scheduled for Sept. 26 through Oct. 6. As part of the festivals continuing effort to build new audiences for dance, tickets will once again cost only $10 for all performances in the 10-evening festival. Participants include the Kirov Ballet, the Lyon Opera Ballet and the French hip-hop troupe Compagnie Kfig. Several New York companies will join the lineup as well, including the City Center resident troupes American Ballet Theater, Paul Taylor Dance Company and Morphoses/the Wheeldon Company. Full details are available at nycitycenter.org, and tickets go on sale Sept. 9.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week included todays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.

title: Addenda
description: Accounts

title: Names in the News Get a Way to Respond
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 12  The Internet offers immediate access to articles about every breaking news event anywhere in the world. But no one in the media business has quite figured out how to exploit that revolutionary fact.

title: School Translators Can Help Parents Lost in the System
description: In an earlier life, Xin Meng chased stories as a reporter for a Chinese-language newspaper in New York. Now he spends his days figuring out how to translate mysterious phrases like empowerment school and English language learner into Chinese.

title: Iraqi Premier to Hold Talks in Search for Compromise
description: BAGHDAD, Aug. 12  Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki said Sunday that he would meet as early as this week with leaders from all the major political parties of Iraq in the hopes of forging a grand compromise among the warring factions.

title: A Filing by Gannett Has Set Off Alarms, and Reassurances
description: Has the newspaper business become like a nervous friend who jumps at every noise while you shrug it off? Its easy to poke fun, but these days you cant be so sure the friend is wrong.

title: Popular Demand
description: The Invasion, one of many heirs to the 1956 science-fiction classic Invasion of the Body Snatchers, opens on Friday. Nicole Kidman (above) plays a psychiatrist trying to stay alive and find her son before the aliens get to her.

title: Brooke Astor, 105, First Lady of Philanthropy, Dies
description: Brooke Astor, who by night reigned over New York society with a disdain for pretension and by day devoted her time and considerable resources to New Yorks unfortunate, died this afternoon at her weekend estate, Holly Hill, in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. She was 105.

title: Center Field and Center Stage Are Cabreras
description: Cleveland

title: After Ups (4 Homers) and Downs, Mets Win
description: A lot of things went right during the Mets 10-4 victory over the Florida Marlins yesterday. Moises Alou hit two of the teams four home runs, and the Mets piled on the runs, which helped end their homestand on a winning note.

title: A Matriarch After Your Attention, if Not Heart
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 10  For all her grace and gentility, Eugene ONeills Mary Tyrone was certainly a handful. Ditto Tennessee Williamss Amanda Wingfield and Lillian Hellmans Regina Giddens. Edward Albees Martha is a mother you wouldnt even wish on an imaginary child.

title: Flash of Speed From an Overlooked Part of the Giants Backfield
description: Missing from the discussions in the off-season about how to replace Tiki Barber at running back, beyond the buzz for Brandon Jacobs and the reports about Reuben Droughns, was Derrick Ward.

title: Hawaiian-Style Lilt and Flow, With a Jab at Grass Skirts
description: Patrick Makuakanes Na Lei Hulu I Ka Wekiu Hawaiian dance and music company knows how to put on a good show. Mr. Makuakane had the audience laughing and cheering on Saturday night at a performance at the Lincoln Center Out of Doors festival. And quite a few audience members rose to the occasion when he invited them to dance the hula in the aisles, as they did at the companys last Out of Doors show, in 2004.

title: Ad Seeking Portfolio Web Host Suggests, Think Tina Fey
description: What a difference an issue makes.

title: Bullet Train Churning to Hard Bop
description: Louis Hayess syncopated ride-cymbal beat helped harden hard bop in the late 1950s and early 60s. It was heard most widely on records by Horace Silver and Cannonball Adderley, and it survives as a classic mid-century American product, heavy and stylized and confident, a sound that cant be easily whisked away.

title: Xbox 360 Out of Order? For Loyalists, No Worries
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 12 Imagine your blender breaking down twice. The vacuum cleaner giving up the ghost three times. The espresso maker repeatedly going kaput. Then imagine replacing the item with the same model over and over while keeping your brand loyalty and sanity.

title: Troops Shelter an Unlikely Survivor in Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD, Aug. 12  Fatima Jbouri should be dead.

title: A Coming of Age at Nickelodeon: Noggin and the N Will Get Their Own Channels
description: Nickelodeon is expected to announce today that Noggin, the daytime commercial-free preschool network, and the N, a nighttime advertising-supported network for adolescents and teenagers, will become 24-hour stand-alone networks and no longer share channel space.

title: Manufacturers Find Ways to Navigate Web Retailing
description: FOR manufacturers, the Web can be a hazardous place. Consumers expect these companies to sell their products directly online, but retailers have other thoughts.

title: East German Shoot-to-Kill Order Is Found
description: BERLIN, Aug. 12  Seventeen years after German reunification, archivists have found the first written proof that East German border guards had been ordered to shoot to kill anyone trying to escape to West Germany, including women and children.

title: If Thompson Runs for President, Dont Look for Him in Reruns
description: Former Senator Fred D. Thompson of Tennessee segued neatly from Congress back to an acting career in 2002, when he joined the cast of NBCs long-running crime series Law & Order.

title: With Their Confidence Showing, the Yankees Complete a Sweep
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 12  When Andy Pettitte walked off the mound at Yankee Stadium on July 1, in the midst of a seven-run second inning, the Yankees were on their way to a loss that pushed them four games below .500.

title: This Land Is Your Land? This Land Is My Land!
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Taliban Release 2 Korean Hostages
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Aug. 13  Two women who were among 23 South Koreans kidnapped by the Taliban in mid-July were freed today and were later in South Korean custody, in the first major breakthrough in the hostage case in nearly a month.

title: Bay Shore: 2 Boys Injured in Boat Crash
description: Suffolk County police detectives yesterday were investigating a boating accident in which two boys were injured, one seriously, the police said. Two motorboats crashed about 10 p.m. on Saturday about a half mile south of the Bay Shore Marina. Three children, ages 11, 12 and 13, were thrown from a 22-foot boat driven by Brian Soltan, 45, of West Islip. The children, whose identities were not released, were rescued from the water and the boats were able to reach the marina, the police said. The 13-year-old boy suffered a head injury and was in serious condition yesterday at Stony Brook University Medical Center. The 11-year-old boy was in stable condition at Good Samaritan Hospital Medical Center. Mr. Soltan was in stable condition at Southside Hospital, the police said.

title: Small Investors Seen as Safer in Stock Slide
description: The wild swings in the stock market over the last few weeks have reawakened memories of the technology crash of 2000 in which many small investors lost their savings. But this time around, market experts say, ordinary investors seem less vulnerable than the professionals who have taken a beating.

title: U.S. Market Seen for Iraqi-Made Clothes
description: BAGHDAD, Aug. 12  Iraqi and American officials think Iraqs ailing economy could get a kick-start from American consumers interested in giving Iraqi-made clothes as Christmas presents.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Fighting Continues Over James Brown Estate

title: Bronx: Woman Shot to Death
description: A 22-year-old woman was found shot in the head in the stairwell of her apartment building in Claremont yesterday, the police said. The woman, Glenda Pena, who lived on the sixth floor of 1348 Webster Avenue, was found between the second and third floors about 5 p.m., the police said. Ms. Pena was pronounced dead at Lincoln Medical and Mental Health Center. There were no arrests in the case last night, the police said.

title: Man Charged in Church Shooting
description: A man accused of opening fire in a church in Missouri on Sunday, killing three people and wounding four, pleaded not guilty in court today to a range of charges including murder.

title: Is Motherhood Noble Work? Not in the World of Weeds
description: Jenji Kohan, the creator of Weeds, which returns for a third season on Showtime tonight, spent part of her career as a television writer working on Gilmore Girls, an aspect of her rsum that seems singularly significant.

title: In Study Abroad, Gifts and Money for Universities
description: As overseas study has become a prized credential of the undergraduate experience, a competitive, even cutthroat, industry has emerged, with an army of vendors vying for student money and universities moving to profit from the boom.

title: Footnote
description: The One World Symphony from Brooklyn will present One Summer Night on Thursday at 8:30 p.m. at the Church of St. Ann and the Holy Trinity in Brooklyn Heights. The 85-minute concert will feature works by Ravel, Berlioz, Beethoven and Wagner.

title: Poland to Have Elections 2 Years Early
description: WARSAW, Aug. 12  Seeking to end months of political turmoil, Polish officials confirmed Sunday that the government would hold elections by November, two years ahead of schedule.

title: Remarks by Bush and Rove
description: Here are the remarks made by President  Bush and Karl Rove at the White House this morning concerning Mr. Roves resignation, as transcribed by the Federal News Service, a private transcription service.

title: Its All About Them
description: Ask not what your country can do for you  ask what you can do for your fathers political campaign.

title: A Life of Hardship, and Now, Two Fugitive Sons
description: A few blocks from the Newark schoolyard where the killings had been carried out, Gloria Gomez sat on her porch in the fading afternoon light, hardship etched on her careworn face, and tears welled in her eyes as she spoke of her two fugitive sons and the terrible crimes for which they were being sought.

title: For Austin, Loving the Attention, Hating the Mistakes
description: TULSA, Okla., Aug. 12  With a hot sauce logo on his collar and an array of from-the-gut celebrations, Woody Austin jumped into the fray of the 89th P.G.A. Championship at Southern Hills and nearly made it his own.

title: Anger in India Over Nuclear Accord
description: NEW DELHI, August 13  Simmering distrust of the United States in the Indian parliament broke into full-throated protest today, as politicians from both the right and the left pounced on the government for its landmark nuclear accord with Washington. The prime minister, Manmohan Singh, defended the accord as good for Indias strategic and economic interests.

title: A Stock Soars After a Spam Swarm
description: Last Thursday, inboxes around the world were flooded with crude PDF documents promoting the stock of the Prime Time Group, a tiny Florida company with cellphone and convenience-store interests, among others. Insider Buying Alert!!! the messages began, promising that the stock would move like a comet.

title: Pension Fund Investments (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: From a Burmese Prison, a Chronicle of Pain in Paint
description: LONDON, Aug. 12  A color photograph of the Burmese artist Htein Lin on the day of his release from prison shows him stooped and wan, looking easily 20 years older than his real age. His face is scrawny, and in one of his thin hands he holds a white plastic bag filled with the remnants of more than six years in a cell. He stands next to a uniformed military man who ran the jail.

title: Self-Loathing in California. Self-Critique? No Way!
description: Back in 1975 Shampoo was a farce, a Hollywood sex comedy with Warren Beatty as its promiscuous, ingenuous hero. Showtimes new series Californication is more of a dirge, a Hollywood sex tragedy with David Duchovny as its promiscuous, cynical hero. Rous who love women are hard to resist. There is nothing less appealing than a Lothario who dislikes women, except perhaps a misogynist Lothario who is a middle-aged, blocked writer prone to sleeping with younger women and even teenagers. Californication is supposed to be a dark comedy about love and sex in Los Angeles, but it is not nearly dark or funny enough  less Shampoo than Rogaine.

title: New  CDs
description: LORI MCKENNA Unglamorous  (Warner Brothers Nashville)

title: Calling Rappers (Plus Size Please)
description: Fox Searchlight Pictures is looking for the next big thing in rappers. Notorious, a film about the rapper Christopher Wallace, better known as Biggie Smalls and better still as the Notorious B.I.G., left, is in the works. But the role of the rapper, who was killed in 1997, is yet to be filled. The biopics producers have decided to open up the playing field and starting today are allowing actors to submit audition tapes via the Web site biggiecasting.com. The rappers mother, Voletta Wallace, offered some advice to would-be stars in an article on the Rolling Stone Web site: I dont want you to just imitate him, she said. I want to see his swagger, his style, his energy and smile come through.

title: Most Global Markets Spring Back From Plunge
description: If there is a crisis in global financial markets, it was not apparent in Asia and Europe today. And on Wall Street, the week got off to an unremarkable start.

title: Merv Griffin, Television Innovator, Dies at 82
description: Merv Griffin, a big-band singer who became one of televisions longest-running talk-show hosts and formidable innovators, creating some of the mediums most popular game shows before becoming a major figure in the hotel and gambling businesses, died yesterday in Los Angeles. He was 82.

title: Afghan Rebels Find Aid in Pakistan, Musharraf Admits
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Aug. 12  Gen. Pervez Musharraf, the president of Pakistan, made a rare admission on Sunday before hundreds of Pakistani and Afghan delegates at a grand tribal assembly here, saying that support for militants emanating from Pakistan has caused problems for Afghanistan, and that his country should work to secure peace on its side of their mutual border.

title: The 17 Percent Problem and the Perils of Domestication
description: In June, Science magazine published an article called Domesticated Nature, which noted that by 1995, only 17% of the worlds land area had escaped direct influence by humans. The article was accompanied by one map showing the enormous human footprint on Earth and another showing in a thicket of red lines the tangle of road networks and shipping lanes across the globe. That 17 percent figure is now certainly smaller, and that thicket of transport networks gets a little more tangled every day. The article takes as a working assumption what is obviously true: There really is no such thing as nature untainted by people.

title: On Playing Fields, Grass Is an Endangered Species
description: Brandon Diaz ran across the springy grass infield, stood atop the pitchers mound and, with a short windup, let loose with a curveball to his father, John. The hardball zipped through the warm air, landing squarely in his fathers glove with a plop that could barely be heard above the raspy hiss and clang from a high-rise under construction across the street.

title: At Tanglewood, Mozart and Sounds From Closer to Home
description: LENOX, Mass., Aug. 11  Live, from the Berkshires, it was Saturday Night!

title: Another Day at the Office
description: Bob Barker made it look so easy, but apparently working on the set of The Price Is Right can be dangerous at times. The shows new host, Drew Carey, injured his arm during a rehearsal on Friday, the Web site TMZ.com reported. After getting his arm caught in a moving part of a grocery game, Mr. Carey was taken to Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles, but was released soon after and returned to the set.

title: In Third Chapter, No Box Office Rush on Rush Hour
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 12  The last big-budget movie of the summer, Rush Hour 3, opened in United States theaters with a middling $50.2 million in ticket sales, failing to match the performance of the franchises previous chapter.

title: Dear Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Karl Rove, Top Strategist, Is Leaving the White House
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13  Karl Rove, the political adviser who masterminded President George W. Bushs two winning presidential campaigns and secured his own place in history as a political strategist with extraordinary influence within the White House, announced on Monday that he would resign at the end of the month.

title: Hamas and Fatah Disagree on Whether Theyre Talking
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 12  A Hamas official in Gaza said Sunday that his organization was holding unofficial talks with representatives from the rival Fatah movement, as tension between the factions continued to simmer on the ground. Fatah officials denied that any such dialogue was taking place.

title: From Housing Haven to Foreclosure Leader
description: STOCKTON, Calif., Aug. 11  The north end of Clarks Fork Circle in Stockton tells you all you need to know about the depth of the mortgage worries here. On a curve in a handsome new residential development, four of five homes are for sale, at least two of which have already been repossessed by a lender.

title: Hamas and Opposition Clash in Gaza
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 13  Tensions rose today between the Hamas rulers in Gaza and the Fatah-led opposition there, with Hamas forcefully breaking up what opposition leaders insisted was a peaceful rally for freedom of expression.

title: Off to Resorts, and Carrying Their Careers
description: STEAMBOAT SPRINGS, Colo.  Time was you could tell the urban refugees in places like this: corporate achievers who quit the rat race to open a bed and breakfast or a candle shoppe.

title: Iranian Official Says Inquiry Into U.S. Scholars Has Ended
description: TEHRAN, Aug. 12  A senior judiciary official said Sunday that Iran had finished its investigation into two Iranian-American academics who were arrested in May on espionage charges, the official Islamic Republic News Agency reported.

title: A World Without Humans? It All Falls Apart
description: The abundant doomsday plotlines in The World Without Us make it a useful conversation piece, if a grim one. Traveling down many different avenues of scientific research, Alan Weisman postulates the complete disappearance of mankind from planet Earth. Then he extrapolates about what would happen without us. By his estimate most of our leavings would rot and crumble; much of our damage would take eons to undo. Theres one tiny bit of good news. Depleted sea species might recover if we would do them a favor and go away.

title: Saluting the Wunderkinds (Mozart and Schubert)
description: Friday nights Mostly Mozart program focused on teenage composers. Their names were Mozart and Schubert. Mozart, at 19, wrote his violin concertos (represented here by the fifth and last), and at 16 wrote his first draft of music to accompany the play Thamos, King of Egypt (though he kept revising it through the advanced age of 23). Schubert, at 19, wrote his fourth symphony.

title: After 3 Deadly Crashes in Queens, 2 Drivers Face Charges
description: Two pedestrians and a driver were killed in three accidents in Queens during the weekend, the police said. Two of the drivers were charged with driving while intoxicated.

title: Yes, the Fund-Raising Records Fell, Just Not as Far
description: For Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, it was a monumental achievement: Her campaign announced in April that she had raised $26 million in the first quarter of the year, more than any other presidential candidate.

title: A Case So Shielded One Side Is in the Dark
description: San Francisco

title: NBC Making a Clean Start in a House of Mixed Media
description: After it bought the Web site iVillage.com last year for $600 million, NBC Universal bragged that it had landed a digital darling. The women-focused Internet business was a perfect fit with the Today show, executives said, and would turbo-charge their online efforts.

title: Ann Taylor Said to Plan Boomer Unit
description: Ann Taylor wants to grow up.

title: With Spitzer Inquiry, Albanys Eyes Are on Ethics Panel Just as It Is Changing
description: ALBANY, Aug. 10  In 39 years as a litigator, Herbert Teitelbaum, who became executive director of the State Ethics Commission last month, sued Boston to let college students vote. He sued school officials in Philadelphia for not providing better English instruction for Hispanic children. And he took on the cities of White Plains, New Rochelle, Mount Vernon and Yonkers for discriminating against blacks applying for jobs as firefighters.

title: Workers at Mine Plan a Third Rescue Hole
description: HUNTINGTON, Utah, Aug. 12  Emergency workers searching for six coal miners who have been trapped for a week in a deep underground shaft announced Sunday that they would begin drilling a third hole through the mountainside and using a faster digging technique to speed up the horizontal push through the collapsed mines rubble.

title: Wrong Way Out of Iraq
description: As Americans argue about how to bring the troops home from Iraq, British forces are already partway out the door. Four years ago, there were some 30,000 British ground troops in southern Iraq. By the end of this summer, there will be 5,000. None will be based in urban areas. Those who remain will instead be quartered at an airbase outside Basra. Rather than trying to calm Iraqs civil war, their main mission will be training Iraqis to take over security responsibilities, while doing limited counterinsurgency operations.

title: Goldman and Investors to Put $3 Billion Into Fund
description: Goldman Sachs and a group of investors are injecting $3 billion of capital into one of its flailing hedge funds that lost about 30 percent of its value last week.

title: A Variation on the DVR, Without Ad Skipping
description: In a move that is certain to delight advertisers, Time Warner Cable is about to offer its customers a free recording feature for their televisions  one that will not allow them to zap through the commercials.

title: Lottery Numbers
Brooklyn: Gunman Shot by Police
description: A man was wounded in a shootout with police officers in East New York on Saturday night, the police said. The shooting occurred about 11:50 p.m., as the officers responded to a report of an assault at 247 Vermont Street. After the officers arrived, they saw two men, one of them armed. The gunman fired at three people, the police said, and when the officers ordered him to drop his weapon, he fired at them. The officers returned fire, hitting the gunman, the police said. The man, whose name was not released, was in stable condition yesterday at Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center, the police said. The officers were not injured. A loaded .22-caliber pistol was found at the scene, and charges were pending, the police said.

title: Julie Halston, Host for Awards
description: Two years ago, at the inaugural New York Innovative Theater Awards, which honor achievement in Off Off Broadway theater, the host Charles Busch coerced one of the evenings presenters  his friend the actress and comedian Julie Halston   to stay onstage and serve as his co-host for the rest of the evening. She complied. This year Ms. Halston is taking over completely and will be the host of the third annual presentation, scheduled for Sept. 24 at the Haft Auditorium at the Fashion Institute of Technology. Among the presenters who have agreed to participate in this years event are  Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker; the lighting designer Natasha Katz (Tarzan, The Little Mermaid); and the director Leigh Silverman (Well). Receiving this years artistic achievement award, presented to an individual who has made a significant artistic contribution to the Off Off Broadway community, will be Doric Wilson, one of the first playwrights to present work off Off Broadway at the Caffe Cino. His comedy And He Made a Her opened there in 1961 with Jane Lowry and Paxton Whitehead playing the lead roles.

title: Regulator in Europe Proposes a Superagency to Wield Power Over Its Phone Markets
description: BERLIN  After its success cutting mobile phone roaming fees, the European Commission is weighing a plan that could force some former phone monopolies in Europe to open their networks to greater competition.

title: And Well Call It Graceland West
description: Thursday will mark the 30th anniversary of Elvis Presleys death, and Elvis Week 2007 is all the rage in Memphis and elsewhere this week. Elvis paraphernalia  including the Kings Army shirt  is demanding huge prices on eBay, and the numerous gift shops at Graceland are selling all kinds of 30th-anniversary knickknacks, including Reeses Peanut Butter & Banana Creme Cups (in honor of Presleys favorite sandwich). Meanwhile a fan in California wants to give Graceland some competition, The Associated Press reported. Reno Fontana and his wife, Laura, recently purchased a Spanish-style white stucco home in Palm Springs with five bedrooms and seven bathrooms that Elvis and Priscilla Presley purchased in 1970. The Fontanas intend to decorate the home in Elvis style and eventually build a chapel (for weddings) and a recording studio. We may have our names on the deed, but we are the caretakers, Mr. Fontana said. This house belongs to Elvis fans around the world.

title: Dutch Company Bets on Interactivity to Make G.P.S. Devices More Useful in the U.S.
description: MILAN, Aug. 12  If you have ever been lost on the tiny, twisting, one-way back streets of Prague, Brussels or Milan, you have a pretty good idea why navigation devices that use the Global Positioning System are vastly more popular in Europe than in the United States.

title: Whats on Tonight
description: 10:30 P.M. (Showtime) CALIFORNICATION David Duchovny, left, stars as the novelist Hank Moody, a one-hit wonder who high-tails it from New York to Los Angeles when his acclaimed book is turned into a lousy romantic comedy starring TomKat. Natascha McElhone plays Karen, Hanks longtime girlfriend, who dumps him when he proves to have raging hormones coupled with a maturity level somewhere below that of their 12-year-old daughter, Becca (Madeleine Martin). Madeline Zima is Mia, whos out to sucker punch Hank in a way he never imagined. And Evan Handler is the sanctimonious if a tad envious Charlie, who wants his best friend to keep his pants on for once. Or else stop tempting Charlie with all that talk.

title: Republicans Debated YouTube Forum Is Back On
description: It looks as if the Republican presidential candidates, at least most of them, will be participating in a YouTube debate after all. The forum is now set for Nov. 28, the Wednesday after Thanksgiving.

title: Bargain tips for Paris shows and spectacles
description: Comedie Republique

title: Q & A With Karl Rove and the White House Press Corps
description: Following is a transcript released by the White House of a question-and-answer session today between Karl Rove, the president's top political strategist, and members of the White House press corps. The question-and-answer session was conducted aboard Air Force One as President Bush flew to Waco, Tex., shortly after Mr. Rove announced that he would soon be leaving the White House.

title: NBC May Take Oxygen, Reports Say
description: Oxygen, one of cable televisions last remaining independent channels, is shopping itself to NBC Universal, according to The Hollywood Reporter. The female-targeted channel has apparently been in talks to sell itself to General Electrics entertainment unit since June, the publication said.

title: A New Call to Break Europes Phone Monopolies
description: After its success cutting mobile phone roaming fees, the European Commission is weighing a plan that could force some former phone monopolies in Europe to open their networks to greater competition.

title: A Gannett Filing Sets Off Alarms and Rebuttals
description: Is Gannett in play?

title: Hedge Funds Get Bitten by Pack Mentality
description: On Wall Street, there is a rage against the machine.

title: Who Wants Dow Joness Other Titles?
description: Gannett, Lee Enterprises, and GateHouse Media may be the most likely buyers for the 22 local newspapers News Corporations chairman Rupert Murdoch plans to sell after completing his purchase of Dow Jones this year, according to analysts.

title: Consumer Groups Line Up Against Wild Oats Deal
description: Three consumer groups are siding with antitrust regulators in opposing Whole Foods Markets bid to buy a rival natural and organic food retailer, saying it would lead to higher food prices.

title: Former Comverse C.E.O. Continues to Fight Extradition
description: Jacob Alexander, the former chief executive of Comverse Technology, who faces charges in the United States of options fraud and is regarded as a fugitive, has taken his latest step to fight extradition from Namibia to New York.

title: Midwest to Consider Takeover Offer from TPG
description: Midwest Air Group said it would pursue a takeover offer, likely to exceed $400 million, from United States private equity firm TPG, which includes a passive investment from Northwest Airlines, the fifth-largest airline in the nation.

title: German Prosecutors Investigate IKB Officials
description: German state prosecutors on Friday said they were investigating whether officials at the state-controlled bank IKB may have committed breach of trust or violated German securities law. A spokesman for the prosecutors office would not identify targets of the investigation, but said they included former officials at the bank, which reported major losses related to subprime mortgages in the United States.

title: Making Sense of the Markets
description: Easy credit in the American home-loan market has turned from a sales pitch to a curse, as the troubles with subprime mortgages have developed into a credit squeeze that is shaking the worlds markets and has made loans much harder to get. Will the latest upheaval pose a threat to continued economic growth  and your own financial security? Today I will be answering questions from readers.To ask a question or to see my answers, click here.

title: Tesla Puts New Chief at the Wheel
description: Tesla Motors, the Silicon Valley electric-car startup, named Michael Marks, the former chief executive of Flextronics who joined Kohlberg Kravis Roberts in early 2006, to succeed Martin Eberhard as chief executive.

title: Revisiting the Idea of the Public Law Firm
description: When the Blackstone Group went public earlier this year, the move represented a break with the tradition of private equity firms being, well, private. Now, some are wondering if another industry which has long eschewed the public markets may be ready to throw off the private mantle.

title: All Hyped Up, VMWare Preps for I.P.O.
description: EMCs VMware software business plans to raise as much as $1.1 billion Monday in what may be the largest technology offering since Google in 2004, a signal that demand remains robust for computer-related companies.

title: Rove Resigns
description: Karl Rove, the political adviser who masterminded President George W. Bushs two winning presidential campaigns, is resigning, the White House confirmed today. Jim Rutenberg has this story.

title: Hollinger Blocks Opposition to Sun-Times Deal
description: Hollinger, the company Conrad Black used to run his newspaper empire, blocked bondholders from threatening its control of Sun-Times Media Group. Judge Peter J. Walsh of United States Bankruptcy Court in Wilmington, Del., extended an order stopping bondholders from seizing the Sun-Times shares Hollinger uses to control the company, owner of the Chicago Sun-Times and other papers.

title: Vinson & Elkins Buys Bankruptcy Boutique
description: Vinson & Elkins has acquired a New York bankruptcy boutique founded by former partners of Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz.

title: Bank of Nova Scotia Confirms Talks With Chilean Bank
description: The Bank of Nova Scotia confirmed Friday that it was in exclusive talks with a key shareholder of Chiles Banco del Desarrollo after Chilean media reported this week that a sale seemed to be imminent.

title: Despite Turbulence, BCE Buyout Remains on Track
description: The investor group taking Canadas BCE private in a buyout worth 34.8 billion Canadian dollars ($33 billion) remains committed to the terms of the transaction and will not reprice the deal, a spokeswoman told The Globe and Mail Friday.

title: U.S. Investigation of BP Widens
description: BP, the British petroleum company, disclosed that investigators in the United States have widened their investigation into its commodity trading activities.

title: Brazilian Buyout Firm Strikes Deal for Pride Assets
description: GP Investments of Brazil, the largest Latin American private equity firm, agreed to buy Houston-based Pride Internationals drilling rigs in the region for $1 billion in a bet on rising oil and natural gas demand.

title: DP World Said to Consider $2 Billion I.P.O.
description: DP World, the worlds third-largest container port operator, may sell $2 billion of shares this year in an initial public offering and list the stock in Dubai, the Middle East Economic Digest reported.

title: When Arbitrators Are Their Own Judges
description: Securities arbitration panels are supposed to offer a way to resolve disputes fairly, faster and more cheaply than the overtaxed court system. A three-member panel hears the case; one person represents the brokerage industry, and the other two are public representatives.

title: Drilling for Oil, No Strings Attached
description: China has launched a large scale program of oil exploration in Chad, one of Africa's poorest countries.

title: Accredited Sues Lone Star to Complete Deal
description: Accredited Home Lenders, the money-losing subprime mortgage lender, said on Monday it had sued the private equity firm Lone Star Funds, seeking to force it to complete the $400 million takeover of Accredited.

title: Signs of Weakness in a Sector Known for Strength
description: Financial stocks, particularly those of major investment banks, have outperformed the broader stock market in recent years. But in 2007, those stocks have fallen under a cloud. In June, they began a sharp decline that anticipated and exceeded the stock markets subsequent midsummer swoon.

title: As the Market Wobbles, VMware Is Bullish on Its Offering This Week
description: Last Thursday, when stock markets around the world fell in a panicky swoon, VMware calmly nudged up the price range on in its initial public offering.

title: Akzo Clinches ICI Deal for $16 Billion
description: Akzo Nobel, the worlds largest maker of paints and coatings, agreed to buy Imperial Chemical Industries, a British rival, for 8 billion pounds ($16 billion).

title: Blackstones Profit Triples, But Challenges Continue
description: The Blackstone Group, posting quarterly earnings for the first time since its highly anticipated initial public offering in June, said Monday that its net income more than tripled in the second quarter from a year ago, as its private-equity and real-estate businesses showed strong gains.

title: Sorting Through the Buyout Freezeout
description: With the buyout frenzy all but over and the credit markets in disarray, there is plenty of blame to go around  and some praise too. Which private equity firms have run headfirst into the crash? Which deals earned brickbats at the time they were signed, only to look wise now? And which buyouts now stand to be repriced?

title: Blackstone Takes Stake in Stiefel Laboratories
description: A privately held pharmaceutical company, Stiefel Laboratories, said Thursday evening that the Blackstone Group had made a $500 million equity investment in the dermatology specialist in exchange for a minority interest.

title: Roves August Surprise
description: Following are various strands of Karl Roves resignation, from the meaning of the Mark of Rove and initial reactions across the Web to his emotional appearance with the president today and various assessments of his legacy. Later in the day, he talked to reporters in a long session that we covered here.

title: Ailing Goldman Fund to Get $3 Billion Infusion
description: A third Goldman Sachs hedge fund is feeling the pain of current market turbulence.

title: 2008: Plotting a Post-Straw Poll Strategy
description: After his first place finish in this weekends G.O.P. straw poll in Iowa, Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney declared that he was pleased as punch and his campaign said the strong showing would give him a lift.

title: Morning Buzz: Stalled East River Turbines, a Stronger Ethics Panel, School Translators and More
description: Six underwater turbines that were installed in the East River near Roosevelt Island and are supposed to turn the rivers currents into electricity have been shut down for repairs and a basic redesign, Anthony DePalma reports. It has been a rough eight months for Verdant Power, the company that owns the equipment. Days after the first two turbines were lowered into the water, the East Rivers powerful currents sheared off the tips of several blades. New blades  made of a cast aluminum that theoretically would hold up better  replaced the ones that were broken and were also installed on the four other turbines.Together, the turbines are capable of producing about 1,000 kilowatt hours a day of clean electricity.But the East River tides have proved too formidable even for the stronger blades, putting excessive strain on the bolts that hold them to the turbine hubs, so all six turbines have been shut for repairs. A and a video accompany Mr. DePalmas article; an earlier video, in January, examined how the turbines work.

title: Deutsche Bank Hires Greenspan as Adviser
description: Deutsche Bank said it had hired Alan Greenspan, the former chairman of the United States Federal Reserve, as a consultant to provide advice and insight to the companys corporate and investment banking unit and its clients. In May, Mr. Greenspan signed a consulting deal with Pimco, the giant bond management firm, which became his first client since leaving the Fed in early 2006.

title: Humor on the G.O.P. Campaign Trail
description: Mike Huckabee, it turns out, is one of the funniest presidential contenders.

description: Karl Rove tells Paul Gigot, the editorial page editor of The Wall Street Journal, that hes resigning from the White House effective Aug. 31.Rove seems to think  or at least his comments to Gigot logically suggest that  his departure will right everything that is wrong with George W. Bushs second term. Gigot writes:

description: Maybe I was just tired and slap-happy, but I couldnt stop laughing at this brilliant spoof.

description: Amid concern that deals will be repriced or broken thanks to the worsening credit markets, at least one buyout target said it is preparing for the worst.

title: Dutch Regulator Is Said to Approve Barclays ABN Bid
description: Barclays will obtain Dutch regulatory approval to buy ABN Amro, Reuters reported Monday citing unnamed sources. Yet the Dutch banks share price showed few signs of recovery from Friday, when its shares plummeted amid concern that either or both takeover offers could fall through because of the recent market decline.

title: Rome with a view (from a double-decker bus)
description: The most difficult thing about taking Romes 110 Open Bus, the city-run double-decker tourist line, is finding one of the stops where you can actually get on it. I spent a frazzled half-hour with a friend visiting from Canada trying to figure out where she could hop on the bus along the route, which starts at Romes Termini train station, and meanders through Rome, near to most of the citys major sites like the Colosseum, the Trevi Fountain, Piazza Navona, and St. Peters.

title: A Modest Step Toward a Better-Designed Sidewalk Maze
description: Many of the sidewalks of New York have been turned into human Habitrails, mazelike tunnels of sidewalk scaffolding through which pedestrians must scuttle nervously. A boom in construction and renovation, mandatory facade inspections and the rise of unconventional outdoor advertising is the cause.

title: The Skim
description: A quick hike through the Sunday (and a few non-Sunday) book review sections.

title: Pulling Cerberuss Chief Into the Spotlight
description: Stephen Feinberg, the head of Cerberus Capital Management, loathes publicity. At an annual meeting of the private equity firms investors, he told the crowd, If anyone at Cerberus has his picture in the paper and a picture of his apartment, we will do more than fire that person. We will kill him.

title: Clip from "Yo Gabba Gabba"
description: A clip from Nickelodeon's new show, "Yo Gabba Gabba."

description: Goldman Sachs may be pumping billions of dollars in one of its troubled hedge funds, but dont call it a bailout. Or a rescue.

description: The article in todays Times on Stocktons housing woes includes a picture of a home for sale, where the broker proclaims, Priced Below New!

description: New Hampshire is still pondering when to hold its presidential primary, but it looks as if one of the options is a Saturday, either Jan. 5 or Jan. 12.

title: Actually, Winning Isnt Everything
description: Karl Roves reputation rests, in part, on the Cult of the Consultant among Washington journalists, notes Joshua Green, a senior editor at The Atlantic, in his well-timed September cover story on The Architect, headlined The Rove Presidency. (Though Greens opening sentence is less well-timed than his subject: With more than a year left in the fading Bush presidency, Karl Roves worst days in the White House may still lie ahead of him.)

title: Clintons First TV Ad
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons campaign will begin broadcasting its first television ad in Iowa tomorrow. The one-minute spot titled Invisible features Mrs. Clinton walking through farmland, talking with voters as well as several image-softening shots of her cuddling with babies and gently putting her arm on the shoulder of an older woman.

title: Why Did Crime Fall in New York City?
description: Did the broken windows strategy and CompStat drive down crime in New York City in the 1990s?

title: Fantasy Baseball: Who Would Buy the Yankees?
description: The baseball world was in heavy speculation mode a few weeks ago after a report that the YES Network, the Yankees home on cable television, was up for sale. The story hinted that the Yankees could be next on the auction block, although a report the next day in The New York Times indicated that it was just Goldman Sachss YES stake, and not the whole business, that was up for sale.

title: Ils Aiment Ron Paul
description: Republicans have not been known recently for their warmth toward the French. But at least one contender for the G.O.P. nomination has developed a dedicated, if small, fan base in Paris: Representative Ron Paul of Texas, an anti-Iraq war libertarian.

title: Report Finds Queens Library No. 1 in Circulation
description: The Queens Library is the No. 1 library system in the United States by circulation, having loaned 20.2 million items in the 2006 fiscal year, according to a new report by the Public Library Association.

She is arguing that the State Ethics Commission is the best venue for any further investigation of choppergate and that everyone else should get back to work.

title: Remembering Brooke Astor
description: Updated, Aug. 14 | Brooke Astor, the doyenne of philanthropy and high society, died at 1:50 p.m. today at Holly Hill, her estate in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., according to Kenneth E. Warner, a lawyer for Anthony D. Marshall, her son. The cause of death was pneumonia, he said. Mrs. Astor was 105.An obituary by Marilyn Berger offers a full account of Mrs. Astors life.

title: Honoring Brooklyns Role in Ending Slavery
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg today announced the appointment of a six-member Commemoration Panel that is to come up with a plan to honor Brooklyns role in the 19th century abolitionist movement.The panel, which will work with the city and the Downtown Brooklyn Partnership, is to help find and select a cultural organization to manage the project, for which the city is planning to spend $2 million over the three years.

title: I Wanna Talk About Me
description: Paul Krugman responds to readers comments on his Aug. 13 column, Its All About Them.
