description: Karl Rove is stepping down as President Bush's chief strategist, but his effect on the 2008 campaign is still felt, Adam Nagourney reports.

title: Rubes and Racehorses
description: I went up to Saratoga Springs the other day, escaping any more office discussion about Fashion Week, which people keep saying is just around the corner with an eagerness that robs the best last days of summer. Here is some of the fashion I saw at the race track on Saturday: straw porkpie hats on old gentlemen, orchid-pink lipstick on old ladies, blue-striped shirts and Herms horse ties, blue blazers, strings of pearls, floral sundresses, and stiffened tulle hats with petal brims that had a bridal cast. My favorite look was a generously cut seersucker suit worn with a bow tie and white Michael Jordan sneakers by a man who appeared to be 90.

title: A Recipe for Hamptons Controversy: Piping Plovers, Piping Hot?
description: Like the horrendous traffic and the celebrity watching, the piping plover issue has become a perennial hot topic in the Hamptons.

title: How Is Your Bridge Holding Up? Click Here.
description: Ford Fessenden of The Times has analyzed federal highway records on the bridges in the New York metropolitan region and created an interactive tool that allows readers to search the bridges of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut and examine the conditions of their deck, superstructure and substructure.

title: Campaign Cash: An Early Caucus Dividend
description: What if there were a 2008 presidential nominating caucus held this year? In addition to possibly testing the patience of the electorate, such an event could open a loophole in the 1974 campaign finance laws, potentially allowing for a flood of new donations to the campaigns.

title: The T-Shirt Groups
description: DES MOINES  They show up in red T-shirts, blue T-shirts and then, there is the Cookie Mom who is associated with the yellow T-shirt crowd. While most political rallies here in Iowa consist of politicians preaching to the crowds, a number of activist groups are turning that political model on its head. Folks in the red T-Shirts are from a group called Divided We Fail, which is part of the American Association of Retired Persons and they show up candidate gatherings to pose questions and influence the current crop of Presidential candiates.

title: Blackstones $1.1 Billion Real Estate Problem
description: Observers parsing the Blackstone Groups first earnings announcement as a public company had a lot to chew on, including its acknowledgment that the buyout boom has gone on hold. But according to Breakingviews Lauren Silva, the private equity giant may have a bigger problem on its hands.

title: Ask the New York Dog Experts
description: New York dogs have New York concerns: dog-run politics, interviewing with co-op boards and keeping up with the latest urban fashions. This week, two experts on urban dogs from the Animal Haven Shelter, Sanctuary and Adoption Center, with locations in SoHo, Flushing, Queens, and South Kortright, N.Y., are taking questions from readers.

title: Measuring Shareholder Anger at Yahoo
description: The recent history of Yahoos troubles is well-known: the company lost the search race to Google; it missed out on key trends  social networking, for instance  and potential acquisitions  Facebook, most notably; its performance disappointed; some shareholders grew restless and focused their anger on a board that gave former CEO Terry Semel one of the richest pay packages in Corporate America.

title: Straw Poll No-Shows Coming to Iowa
description: Fred D. Thompson has yet to formally announce his presidential candidacy. But his first campaign trip to Iowa this week should resolve questions  if any remain  about his intentions.

title: For Rove, Last Disrespects
description: The good must have been interred with Karl Roves resignation letter, because theres not a lot of love for him in blogland today, nor much respect for his reputation as a political mastermind.

title: Dodd Stops at Iowa State Fair
description: DES MOINES - When Senator Christopher J. Dodd finished speaking at the Iowa State Fair this afternoon, he did something that is quite ordinary for presidential candidates here. He signed autographs. He posed for a few pictures. Then, he took questions from an Australian broadcaster.

title: Brooke Astor: A Long and Storied Life
description: Brooke Astor, New York's most famous doyenne of philanthropy and society, died at 105.

title: Roves Interview Aboard Air Force One
description: During an Air Force One flight to Texas, Karl Rove engaged reporters in an altogether jolly good question and answer session, trading jokes, talking politics and only going off the record a handful of times, once to answer a question on his wifes feelings on sticking it out until January 2009.

title: Action on a Very Small Scale
description: It is not much of a leap from thinking about how the average person might begin to comprehend the potential of nanotechnology to thinking that turning it all into a computer game might help. After all, when you are talking about manipulating matter at its most fundamental atomic and molecular levels, there is no shortage of challenges to overcome  the basic element in any game.

title: Sebastien Bourdais Sent to the Slaughterhouse
description: There seems to be a strong inverse relationship between the niceness of the Champ Car champion and his odds for success in Formula One. Those whove ranked high on the rootability meter  Cristiano da Matta and Alex Zanardi  fared poorly in Formula One. Those whove won  Juan Pablo Montoya and Jacques Villeneuve  were whiny little jerks.

title: Children at Play
description: Do you agree with Howard P. Chudacoff, who suggests in his new book, Children at Play: An American History, that organized activities, overscheduling and excessive amounts of homework are crowding out free time and constricting childrens imaginations and social skills?

title: Adams, Van Wely Lead Staunton Memorial
description: Michael Adams of England, the top seed, and Loek Van Wely of the Netherlands, the second seed, are tied for first place at the Fifth Howard Staunton Memorial Tournament. Each has 4.5 points after six rounds with five remaining. Games from the tournament can be replayed at its official Web site.

title: Newark Unites After Killings
description: A week after violent killings in Newark, Mayor Cory Booker hopes to transform community outrage into action for peace.

title: America Weighs In on Vick as Trial Date Nears
description: As N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell waits for the report on the internal investigation into whether Atlanta Falcons quarterback Michael Vick violated the leagues personal conduct policy, its worth wondering what Vicks future might hold.

title: Even if Life Is a Computer Simulation . . .
description: . . . we still have some real questions to consider. Nick Bostroms argument that we could be living in a simulation, the topic of my Findings column, is a clever new twist on the old life-is-but-a-dream notions of Western philosophers (like the idealist George Berkeley), Eastern religions and science-fiction writers everywhere (cf. The Matrix, The Truman Show, and the holodeck in Star Trek: The Next Generation). A few of the questions:

description: Amsterdam's canals are home to hundreds who have elected to live on houseboats.

title: A First Ladys No-Show Is Seen as a No-No
description: PARIS, Aug. 13  Three weeks ago, Ccilia Sarkozy, the glamorous wife of the French president, drew criticism here for her high-profile role in the freeing of jailed medical workers from Libya, a job some thought was best left to diplomats. Now Mrs. Sarkozy, a 49-year-old former model, is under scrutiny again, this time for ducking out of public appearances where a presidential spouse would be expected.

title: Rove Legacy Laden With Protgs
description: Whatever history makes of Karl Roves role in the White House, his legacy as a political strategist can be measured in a presidential campaign that has already begun without him. A look at the roster of every Republican presidential candidate finds people who have worked with him, and they have brought some of his methods to this race.

title: Reputation Isnt Fixed. Sometimes You Hear It Grow.
description: ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Aug. 12  Search for Edward Elgar on YouTube, and you can find a link to a short 1931 film clip of Elgar at 74, three years before his death, conducting the London Symphony Orchestra in the stately central theme of the Pomp and Circumstance March No. 1. Known in England as Land of Hope and Glory, the tune is familiar to any American who has ever walked down the aisle at a graduation ceremony.

title: Goldman and Investors to Put $3 Billion Into Fund
description: Goldman Sachs announced yesterday that it along with a group of investors would inject $3 billion into the firms Global Equity Opportunities Fund, a flailing quantitative hedge fund that lost about 30 percent of its value in a week.

title: Whats on Tonight
description: 10:30 P.M. (Oxygen) I AM MANDY MOORE One of the few bubblegum-pop singers cum actresses of her generation not to fizzle, the normally private Ms. Moore, above, allowed cameras to follow her as she promoted her new album, Wild Hope (released in June after a four-year hiatus) and prepared for a televised concert. This hourlong special is a raw look at a six-month promotional run, Ms. Moore wrote in a letter on the Oxygen Web site (oxygen.com), with no sweetening. This from a woman with a hit titled Candy.

title: Surge in Consumer Prices Stirs Chinas Concern About Overheated Economy
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 13  Steeply rising food prices pushed inflation in China to 5.6 percent last month, the fastest pace in a decade, government figures showed Monday, prompting renewed concern about whether inflation would spread more widely in China and abroad.

title: Potter Translator Escapes Lawsuit
description: The French publisher of the Harry Potter books will not sue the teenager who was arrested for publishing his own complete French translation of the final Potter book, though he could still be charged by French officials, the BBC reported. The decision not to sue for damages was made in agreement with J. K. Rowling, the author of the books, said the books French publisher, Gallimard, which will publish the French translation of Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows on Oct. 26. The aim was never financial; it only aimed to protect authors rights, said a spokeswoman for the company. The 16-year-old, from the southern city of Aix-en-Provence, was arrested last week after he posted his unauthorized translation, which appeared within a few days of the books release in English on July 21. Gallimard said Frances anti-piracy squad found the translation as part of an inquiry into organized networks that post pirated book translations online. Investigators were reportedly struck by the near-professional quality of the boys work.

title: Ants Tend to Gravitate to What They Do Best, Researchers Show
description: The remarkable ability of ants and other social insects to divide the work in a colony is a result of many factors: genes, age, social interactions, even size or other physical attributes.

title: U.S. Seeks W.T.O. Ruling on Product Piracy in China
description: The Bush administration asked the World Trade Organization to rule in a complaint against China over piracy of copyrighted movies, music, software and books, escalating a dispute that has strained commercial relations between the two trading giants. After consultations failed to resolve differences over what the United States argues are weak Chinese laws to safeguard patents and copyrights, the Trade Representatives office took the formal step of asking the trade organization, which is based in Geneva, to decree that Chinas laws fall short of international agreements.

title: Right There on the Tarmac, the Inmates Revolt
description: ON July 29, Continental Flight 1669, a 737-700 with about 120 passengers aboard, was bound for Newark from Caracas, Venezuela, when bad weather caused the plane to be diverted to Baltimore. It sat there for about five hours with passengers on board as food and water ran low and toilets became filthy.

title: Two Co-Defendants Likely to Plead Guilty in Vick Case
description: Two more people indicted with Michael Vick in connection with a suspected dogfighting ring are expected to plead guilty in the case later this week, according to the Web site of the United States District Court in Richmond, Va.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A front-page article on Saturday about the Federal Reserves decision to inject capital into the financial system mischaracterized the central banks action. The Fed lent $19 billion against mortgage-backed securities, it did not purchase the securities. In a second action, the Fed lent $19 billion through reverse repurchase agreements.

title: Gouged Tile May Be Left Unrepaired, NASA Says
description: A small but deep gouge in the underside of the space shuttle Endeavour does not pose the potential of catastrophe, the NASA official overseeing the mission said yesterday.

title: In Reversal, Japans Central Bank Pulls Back $5 Billion
description: TOKYO, Tuesday, Aug. 14 (Dow Jones)  The Bank of Japan drained 600 billion yen ($5 billion) from the money supply Tuesday morning, after pumping money into the system for two days to ease fears of a liquidity crisis.

title: Ex-Surgeon Generals Maverick Side Was Bound to Appear, Friends Say
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13  In his speeches, Dr. Richard H. Carmona, the former surgeon general, often tells audiences about receiving the advice that if he wanted a friend in Washington, he should get a dog.

title: Producer Prices Rise 0.6 Percent in July
description: A jump in energy prices caused prices paid at the producer level to rise more than expected last month despite falling food prices and small price increases for many other goods.

title: These Moors, This Realm of Evil, This Tortured Isle
description: The moors murders  the serial sex killings of five children and the burial of four on the high border country between Yorkshire and Lancashire  stirred horrified revulsion throughout 1960s Britain. The killers, Ian Brady and his lover and follower, Myra Hindley, were soon caught, tried and condemned to multiple life sentences.

title: In Gaza, Even a Hospital Is a Battlefield
description: Like a lot of documentaries, Gaza E.R., tonight on PBSs Wide Angle series, makes a grim subject a little more palatable by occasionally tossing in some humanism via a likable character who provides perspective and comic relief. It is a mark of how messed up things are in the Middle East that this character, the one whos supposed to give us hope, ends up delivering the most dismaying comment in the film.

title: Our Lives, Controlled From Some Guys Couch
description: Until I talked to Nick Bostrom, a philosopher at Oxford University, it never occurred to me that our universe might be somebody elses hobby. I hadnt imagined that the omniscient, omnipotent creator of the heavens and earth could be an advanced version of a guy who spends his weekends building model railroads or overseeing video-game worlds like the Sims.

title: 46 Million Nokia Cell Batteries Defective
description: Nokia, the worlds biggest cellphone maker, warned consumers yesterday that 46 million of its handsets contained defective batteries made in China that could in rare cases overheat and even dislodge during recharging.

title: U.S. May Provide Billions to Mexico to Fight Drug Cartels
description: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 13  Mexico and the United States are holding intensive talks to develop a plan for the United States to provide billions of dollars to Mexico to support its fight against drug cartels, but the negotiations are not likely to produce an agreement before next weeks trilateral meeting with Canada, officials from both countries said.

title: Letters
description: The Evolution of Prosperity

title: Russia: Bomb Derails Train; Dozens Hurt
description: An explosion derailed 12 cars of a passenger train on the countrys busiest line, injuring dozens and suspending rail service between Moscow and St. Petersburg, Russian news agencies reported. A railway official said Tuesday that the tracks were ruptured by an improvised explosive device, Reuters reported. There was no indication of who may have planted the bomb. The derailment occurred late on Monday in the Novgorod region north of Moscow.

title: The Winds of Europe, in Sounds of the 1800s
description: Long before the advent of the home stereo and the iPod, all the most refined 18th-century European potentates maintained a harmonie  typically a wind octet, consisting of paired oboes, clarinets, bassoons and French horns  for private entertainment and courtly functions. By the time the craze swept through Vienna near the end of the century, harmonie arrangements of the latest operas and ballets had become all the rage and a lucrative source of income for industrious composers and skillful bandsmen.

title: Rights Group Accuses Somali Interim Rulers of War Crimes
description: RUMBEK, Sudan, Aug. 13  Human Rights Watch on Monday accused the transitional government in Somalia and the Ethiopian troops that helped bring it to power of war crimes in Somalia, saying that Ethiopian troops had shelled hospitals, that Somali officials had blocked aid convoys and that both forces had shown wanton indifference toward civilians.

title: Carrot Sticks or French Fries?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: New Yorks New Club
description: The Bowery Presents, an independent concert promoter, is expected to announce today that a new rock club is coming to New York, and its a big one: Terminal 5, with room for 3,000, at 610 West 56th Street in Clinton. The first concert, featuring the National, is to take place on Oct. 11. Others to appear in the following months include M.I.A., Justice, the Decemberists, Ween and the Shins. In the space once occupied by Exit, a cavernous dance hall, the three-floor, 40,000-square-foot club is the largest concert space to open this year in the city. Next month the Bowery Presents will open the Music Hall of Williamsburg, in Brooklyn. Tickets for the Oct. 11 show at Terminal 5 will go on sale Friday through terminal5nyc.com.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in The Arts yesterday about grants awarded to arts organizations by New York City under a new formula misstated part of the name of a dance company receiving a grant. It is the Mark Morris Dance Group, not Company.

title: VMware Shares Surge With I.P.O.
description: Shares in the software company VMware surged 75 percent in their first day of trading, closing at $51, or $22 above the initial offering price of $29.

title: In Beijings Games, a Vision of the Future
description: China Is Near. This Italian film came out in 1967, using China as a symbol of the mysterious, the powerful, the future looming over everybody. Lately, that title has been looping across the movie screen of my mind.

title: Left It in a Taxi? Good Luck Getting It Back, a Report Says
description: Assaf Rutenberg, who has a tendency to misplace cellphones, has lost four in New York taxis, and each one has been returned. Once, he said, a cabby drove to Midtown from Queens on his day off to deliver a missing Treo.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An obituary on Saturday about Richmond M. Flowers, the Alabama attorney general who opposed the segregationist polices of Gov. George C. Wallace in the early 1960s, rendered incorrectly at one point the given name of a surviving son. As noted elsewhere in the obituary, he is Richmond Flowers Jr., not Robert.

title: After Killings, Sense of Unity Surprises Newark
description: NEWARK, Aug. 13  An unexpected thing has happened to this crime-weary city since three young friends were shot to death in a school playground nine days ago.

title: Phil Rizzuto, Yankees Shortstop, Dies at 89
description: Phil Rizzuto, the sure-handed Hall of Fame Yankees shortstop nicknamed The Scooter, who extended his Yankee life as a popular and even beloved broadcaster, punctuating his game-calling with birthday wishes to fans and exclamations of Holy cow!, died late Monday night. He was 89.

title: At Australias Bunny Fence, Variable Cloudiness Prompts Climate Study
description: A fence built to prevent rabbits from entering the Australian outback has unintentionally allowed scientists to study the effects of land use on regional climates.

title: Cash-Stuffed Suitcase Splits Venezuela and Argentina
description: BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 13  A scandal involving a Venezuelan businessman who tried to sneak nearly $800,000 into this country has opened a sudden rift between Venezuela and Argentina just a week after the governments signed debt and energy deals.

title: Boats With Stories to Tell, Rescued From Obscurity
description: BUFFALO, Aug. 13  Todd Parmington was finishing a restoration of a guide boat built about 1888 that ferried campers to church services in the Adirondack Mountains when he got an e-mail message in May from a teacher in Vancouver, Wash., researching her familys genealogy.

title: Footnotes
description: Tanz im August, Germanys biggest dance festival, opens in Berlin on Friday. It will include 20 different productions at sites throughout the city, as well as concerts and exhibitions. The festival opens with the Belgian choreographer Anne Teresa De Keersmaeker and her company, Rosas, who will present their Steve Reich Evening on Friday and Saturday. The festival closes on Sept. 1. For information: tanzimaugust.de . ... Lincoln Center Theater will present Cymbeline, one of Shakespeares late romances, in a production directed by Mark Lamos. The cast of 26 will include Jonathan Cake, Michael Cerveris, John Cullum, Martha Plimpton and Phylicia Rashad. Previews begin Nov. 1; regular performances begin on Dec. 2 in the Vivian Beaumont Theater.

title: CBS and Imus Settle Differences Over His Firing
description: The voice of Don Imus could resurface somewhere on the radio dial as soon as this fall, after he and CBS announced yesterday that they had settled the remaining differences surrounding his firing in April over remarks deemed insensitive to women and blacks.

title: Wal-Mart Cuts Annual Forecast
description: Wal-Mart sneezed today. Will the economy catch a cold?

title: Truck Stop Confidential
description: Last Saturday evening, I found myself at the counter of a truck stop diner in Caroline County, Va. I was sitting next to a weathered trucker whose accent betrayed an East Texas upbringing and a lifetime devoted to tobacco products. We quickly established that we were both celebrating birthdays. He was 68.

title: Turkish Presidential Pick Sets Up Clash, Again
description: ISTANBUL, Aug. 14  Turkeys governing party has chosen Abdullah Gul, an economist and a practicing Muslim, as its candidate for president, officials said Monday, a move that places the party and its pious followers on a collision course with Turkeys secular elite.

title: Imperial Chemical Agrees to Takeover Offer
description: LONDON, Aug. 13  Akzo Nobel, the worlds largest maker of paints and coatings, said Monday that it had agreed to buy Imperial Chemical Industries for 8 billion, or $16 billion, after raising its offer twice in two months.

title: Capital Punishment (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: A Little Night Art as Visual Counterpoint for Mozart Festival
description: The real action at the Mostly Mozart Festival takes place inside Lincoln Centers halls, so Breath, a multimedia work by Marc Downie and Paul Kaiser of the OpenEnded Group, could be seen as an accompaniment, not the main attraction.

title: Defending Nuclear Pact, India Premier Faces Criticism
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 13  Simmering distrust of the United States broke into full-throated protest on Monday in the Indian Parliament, as politicians from the right and left pounced on the government for its landmark nuclear accord with Washington, heckling the prime minister before he could defend it.

title: Brooklyn: Man Killed in Elevator Accident
description: A 34-year-old Brooklyn man working in an industrial warehouse was crushed by a freight elevator last evening, the police said. The man, Arturo Gil, was declared dead shortly after 5 p.m. at the site, the Whale Industrial Terminal Building at 14B 53rd Street in Sunset Park, the police said. The elevator had become stuck between the second and third floors and Mr. Gil was trying to move it, according to relatives, who said his body was caught as the elevator began to move. The Buildings Department said that the accident was under investigation but the police said that no criminal charges were expected. The building, which is owned by Whale Realty LLC, had received an unsatisfactory rating during elevator inspections on July 10, according to Buildings Department records. It is unclear if the rating included the elevator where Mr. Gil was killed. Mr. Gil, who came here from Mexico and lived in Sunset Park, had been working in the United States for about a decade, his cousin Rodolfo Veroles said. His wife was also in New York, and Mr. Gil sent money to Mexico to support his relatives, including his children.

title: Blackstones Profit Triples, but Challenges Continue
description: The Blackstone Group, the private equity firm, said yesterday that second-quarter net income more than tripled over the period a year ago, as it made its first earnings announcement as a public company.

title: U.S. Money for Traffic Is Short of Bloombergs Plan
description: The United States Department of Transportation announced today that it had allocated $354 million to reduce traffic in New York City, giving a boost to Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs plan but providing significantly less money than the mayor had sought as part of his sweeping proposal.

title: Joe ODonnell, 85, Dies; Long a Leading Photographer
description: Joe ODonnell, who took some of the first disturbing pictures after the nuclear bombing of Japan and also captured lastingly famous scenes as a longtime White House photographer, died last Thursday in Nashville, where he made his home. He was 85.

title: Citing Learning Slumps, Mayor Presents Plan for Low-Performing Middle Schools
description: Calling middle school students the hardest to reach, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday that he would direct an additional $5 million to about 50 of the citys lowest-performing middle schools and appoint a high-level administrator to devise professional development programs for middle school teachers and principals.

title: Romney Breaks Down His Millions in Income Last Year
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13  The Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney filed a financial disclosure form on Monday showing that his family received over $8 million in income last year from his former firm Bain Capital, including some earned through a tax break Congressional committees are trying to end.

title: TV Meets the Web. All Is Safe.
description: Just to get this out of the way: i-Caught, which had its premiere last week on ABC, is not a sequel to I Spy. It is, according to the voice-over at the beginning of the program, what happens when Internet video comes together with television.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A front-page article on Sunday about how security and rebuilding efforts in Afghanistan have faltered referred incorrectly in some copies to the timing of a trip to Afghanistan by NATO representatives. The trip occurred two years after the fall of the Taliban, not one year. A front-page chart with the article gave an incorrect total in some copies for the amount spent on aid and reconstruction in Afghanistan by the United States from 2003 to 2007. It is $19 billion, not $22 billion.

title: Behavior: Hostility May Raise Risk for Disease
description: Researchers studying 313 healthy Vietnam veterans have found that anger and hostility may increase the risk for cardiovascular disease, diabetes and high blood pressure.

title: Asia: China: Motorola Receives Mobile Phone Order
description: Motorola said it had received orders worth $394 million to supply network equipment to the China Mobile Communications Corporation next year in the first half. Motorola will supply equipment based on technology known as global system mobile communications, the companies said. China Mobile will use the equipment to expand its network, which spans 16 Chinese provinces and municipalities.

title: Emphasis on Victories Adds Risk to the Chase
description: Stock-car racing has not been the same since Nascar asked Bob Latford to devise a new points system in 1974. Besides being arcane  why is a 43rd-place finish worth 34 points?  Latfords system rewards consistency more than it does excellence.

title: Louisiana: Payments to Churches Challenged
description: The American Civil Liberties Union and the A.C.L.U. of Louisiana filed a lawsuit in federal court against the governor and the state treasurer regarding payments the state made to two churches. Gov. Kathleen Babineaux Blanco signed an appropriations bill last month that gave $100,000 to Stonewall Baptist Church in Bossier City and $20,000 to Shreveport Christian Church. In a statement, the A.C.L.U. said the money was disbursed without any oversight or competitive bidding process, and the bill offers no purpose or justification for the challenged earmarks. The payments were discovered after recent changes in the states earmarking system led to each earmarked appropriations being listed individually.

title: After Glacial Retreat, Regrowth May Feed on an Ancient Snack
description: Glaciers arent necessarily forever, as the world is learning in this era of climate change. While many scientists analyze the causes of glacial retreat, others study the effects. One issue is succession: how is newly exposed ground repopulated by plant and animal life?

title: For Top General in Iraq, Role Is a Mixed Blessing
description: BAGHDAD  Gen. David H. Petraeus looked out from a Black Hawk helicopter at the vistas of Baghdad rushing by 150 feet below on a recent summer evening, pointing at bustling markets, amusement parks and soccer fields scattered through neighborhoods where miles of concrete barriers stood like sentinels against the threat of suicide bombers.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: The Popular Demand listing in the Most Wanted chart in Business Day yesterday about Nicole Kidman movies misidentified the actor who starred opposite her in Batman Forever. It was Val Kilmer, not Michael Keaton.

title: Sweatology
description: Like the finish line of a long road race, the Times Square subway platform one recent hot afternoon was a study in wet humanity, from drenched (a large woman in shorts and a skimpy, sweat-splotched top, flushed and vigorously fanning herself), to barely bedewed (an elderly man in a suit and tie calmly reading his paper).

title: Admire the Quagmire!
description: Check out this video from 1994, in which Dick Cheney says we shouldnt invade Iraq because we can create a quagmire that way. A quagmire  thats what he says.

title: Google Goes After Microsoft Again
description: Google has taken yet another step toward challenging Microsofts domination in word processing, spreadsheets and other productivity software.

title: The Death Toll in Darfur
description: On Sunday, the Times ran an op-ed piece suggesting that the Save Darfur Coalition was exaggerating the scale of genocide in Darfur and that the number of deaths was perhaps 200,000 rather than 400,000. I happened to be hiking with my kids around Mt. Hood then, but I came back to find my email account burning up with indignant emails about the essay (written, I hasten to add, by an outsider).

title: Peru: 21 Suspects Captured in Guerrilla Drug Trafficking
description: Government officials said they had captured 21 guerrillas suspected of belonging to a faction of the Shining Path, the Maoist-inspired movement that continues to operate in jungle areas rife with cocaine trafficking. More than 200 special forces carried out the raids in the countrys northeast and in Lima. The guerrillas are suspected of allegiance to a Shining Path commander who uses the name Comrade Artemio, believed to be the last member of the inner circle of Abimael Guzmn, the philosophy lecturer and guerrilla leader whose capture in 1992 led to marginalization of the insurgency.

title: Martnez Says He May Need 3 More Starts Before Return
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., Aug. 14  After his second rehabilitation start against a minor league team Tuesday, Pedro Martnez said he was pushing for a return to the Mets after his next start. But before leaving Tradition Field, he said it might take three more starts for him to be ready.

title: Open Wallet, Insert Mouth
description: The sophisticated Olympic athletes who ache to unleash their inner activists in the run-up to Beijing 2008 may find themselves overwhelmed by menu choices:

title: In Newark Murder, a Mixed Band of Men and Boys
description: NEWARK, Aug. 13  The computer, its screen blank, sat on a table in the living room of Gloria Gomezs apartment. Two blocks away, four promising young people had been shot, three fatally, and now Ms. Gomezs two sons were being hunted by the authorities. She did not want to believe that her boys could have played a role in the killings, but she consented to turn on the computer, which one of her sons had brought into the house recently, while she was away visiting her native Nicaragua.

title: A Nonconforming Eggplant
description: IN high school I had a friend whose mother was famous for eggplant salad. Id never had it before, and I found the notion perplexing.

title: Off the Hoof
description: Here are some sources for buffalo meat:

title: Reader Responses
description: Here are excerpts from reader responses to David Leonhardts Aug. 15 column on the stock market:

title: Funeral A-List: New Version of Mrs. Astors 400
description: Meet Mrs. Astors 400, vintage 2007.

title: Taking Educated Guesses to Try to Beat the Odds
description: If nothing else, Power of 10, the new sort-of quiz show on CBS, is an opportunity to ponder the question of why Drew Carey has become Americas go-to game-show host.

title: Politics Is the New Star of Indias Classrooms
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 14  Quietly, a great upheaval is taking place inside Indian high schools.

title: For Kosher Emergencies, Manna From a Machine
description: WHERE else but New York could two guys who grew up together find a way to blend kosher food, cutting-edge cooking technology and hip-hop?

title: Donaghy Pleads Guilty in N.B.A. Betting Case
description: Tim Donaghy, a former National Basketball Association referee who was investigated for his connection to a suspected gambling ring that involved wagering on league games, surrendered to federal authorities today and pleaded guilty to two felony counts related to gambling.

title: Transfer of Iraqi Projects (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Start of the Engines, Roar of the Crowd
description: The first episode of the five-part series Nascar in Primetime offers nothing new about Nascar, which raises questions about ABC Newss motivation in producing a documentary about a sport that its Disney cousins, ESPN and ABC Sports, began carrying last month under a contract worth $560 million a year.

title: ACT Scores Rise Slightly
description: The average score on the ACT college admissions test crept up slightly this year to 21.2 out of a possible score of 36, up from 21.1 last year, ACT, the testing organization based in Iowa, reported. Twenty-three percent of the record 1.3 million 2007 graduates who took the ACT earned scores showing they were prepared to grapple with introductory college courses in four areas, up from 21 percent a year ago. In some states, including New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, California and Oregon, the percentage increase in the number of students taking the exam was in double digits, said Richard L. Ferguson, ACTs chief executive.

title: Trenton: Tracking Sex Offenders
description: The operators of the social networking Internet site Facebook have agreed to cooperate with a request from New Jersey officials to help identify convicted sex offenders who might be participating in online chats. The Web sites owners issued a statement yesterday saying that the company would work with New Jerseys attorney general, Anne Milgram, above, to identify sex offenders online. Last week, Ms. Milgram sent a letter to Facebook and 11 other meeting sites asking for their help finding sex offenders online. Although it is not illegal for sex offenders to visit such Web sites, Ms. Milgram wants to determine whether such sites are being used to find potential victims.Compiled by John Sullivan

title: With Roves Departure, a New Era
description: CRAWFORD, Tex., Aug. 14  President Bush took the White House in 2001 with Texas swagger, and promptly filled the West Wing with fellow Texans who shared his ideology and determination to fundamentally change the way the capital worked.

title: Can a Girl From Queens Catch the Glamour Bug?
description: What might happen if the fashion, beauty and home design industries joined together and banned from employment anyone whose use of the term like extended too far beyond its conjunctive function? I think we would all, like, be going about our business in loincloths and yurts.

title: Mets Counting on DiFelice Behind the Plate
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 14  Judging by the ice pack and wrap encircling catcher Ramn Castros midsection, it was reasonable to surmise that the Mets were praying that Mike DiFelice would make it through Tuesday nights game intact.

title: Soft-Spoken Bdard Has Others Talking
description: rik Bdard never set out to become the hottest pitcher in the major leagues. In fact, his high school did not even have a baseball team. Bdards journey from a tiny Canadian town to Yankee Stadium, where he will start this afternoon for the Baltimore Orioles, happened by chance.

title: A Dot-Org Stresses That Its No Dot-Com
description: A LARGE marketer of financial services is seeking to become the master of a domain name.

title: How New Arabic School Aroused Old Rivalries
description: When aides to Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein were presented last fall with a proposal for an Arabic language and culture school, they thought the idea could be controversial. But they said they could not resist the appeal of a school that seemed right for the times and that would be a piece of the school systems mosaic of dual-language programs.

title: UBS Warns of Lower Profits if Market Turmoil Persists
description: LONDON, Aug. 14  Europes largest bank, UBS, on Tuesday painted the grimmest picture to date for future earnings in light of recent market jitters, raising concerns about the sustainability of profit growth in the investment banking sector.

title: F.D.A. Limits Childrens Cold and Cough Medicines
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15  In the first major reassessment of the safety of childrens cough and cold medicine in decades, federal drug officials said that the drugs should never be given to children under the age of 2 unless approved by a doctor.

title: Tony Wilson, Impresario and a Founder of Postpunk Label, Dies at 57
description: Tony Wilson, a British television reporter who became one of the most influential figures in postpunk music with his Factory Records label, died on Friday in Manchester, England. He was 57.

title: Italy: Refugee Bodies Seen Off Coast
description: The Coast Guard reported spotting as many as 14 bodies floating in the sea south of Sicily, the latest victims of the annual and deadly summer migration from northern Africa to Europe in search of asylum and economic opportunities. It said it had recovered two of the bodies. It also said it had spotted a second boat with 28 passengers.

title: To Toss the Shells Is to Discard Flavor
description: SHRIMP shells pose a problem for good cooks. Leaving them on unquestionably enhances any shrimp dish, because their flavor is about as strong as that of the meat. Peeling shrimp at the table, however delicious, is a messy and sometimes finger-burning job. Removing the shells beforehand is easy enough, but for someone who cares about taste, discarding them seems akin to a sin.

title: New York to Get U.S. Traffic Aid, but With Catch
description: The federal government said on Tuesday that it would provide $354 million for Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs broad plan to reduce traffic, but left it to the city to come up with more than $200 million needed for the most controversial part of the plan: a system to charge people who drive into Manhattan.

title: Vacation Homes as Art Projects
description: To Susan Mead, a Dallas attorney, old houses are canvases and she is the painter. Even the most dilapidated structures become striking compositions, three-dimensional landscapes for Ms. Meads blend of contemporary and antique furnishings, folk art and fine art  and always with an architectural twist.

title: Prejudice and Politics: Sacco, Vanzetti and Fear
description: Precisely 80 years on, the Sacco-Vanzetti case still resonates like a mournful chord. Almost instantly elevated to the status of myth, the trial and execution of the anarchists Nicola Sacco and Bartolomeo Vanzetti remains one of the blackest pages in the American national story, a cautionary tale of lethal passions fueled by political fear and ethnic prejudice.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a sports article on Aug. 3 about Mike Nugent, the Jets place-kicker, incorrectly described an achievement. In 2006, he had the most accurate season in team history, not the most accurate season since Pat Leahy in 1990.

title: With Jets' Jones Out, Houston Enters the Conversation
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Aug. 14  When Jets tailback Thomas Jones crumpled to the turf with an injury to his right calf muscle during practice Sunday, some of his teammates said they thought of Cedric Houston, the running back who abruptly left the team on the eve of training camp.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,681 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: U.S. Set to Declare Iran Guards Terrorists
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15  The Bush administration is preparing to declare that Irans Revolutionary Guard Corps is a foreign terrorist organization, senior administration officials said Tuesday.

title: Reading Lincolns Face
description: Recently, two researchers performed a 3-dimensional laser surface scan of two life masks of Abraham Lincoln, one made in 1860, the other in 1865. The study confirms what we have all noticed without noticing it. There was an extreme asymmetry in Lincolns face, characteristic of a condition called cranial facial microsomia. The right side of his face was much larger than the left, and the difference is most visible in the different sizes of his eye sockets. This may have been a developmental condition, or it may have been caused when, as a boy, he was kicked in the head by a horse.

The man stole money from the driver and ordered her to drive away from the station, the police said. It awards fellowships and organizes one-year study projects that gather scholars from around the world. title: Pavarotti to Leave Hospital Soon
description: Luciano Pavarotti, who was admitted to the hospital last week with a high fever, is expected to be released imminently and is in high spirits and ready to resume recording a new album, The Associated Press reported. Doctors have given the tenor the go-ahead to leave the hospital in Modena, Italy, where he has been undergoing tests since last Wednesday, his London-based manager, Terri Robson, said in an e-mail message to The Associated Press. The 71-year-old singer, who underwent surgery for pancreatic cancer last year, is looking forward to getting back to teaching his young singing pupils as soon as he is out of hospital, Ms. Robson said. Next month, she added, he plans to get back into his Modena recording studio to resume work on his new album of sacred songs.

title: Another Radio Station for New York and Web
description: WFUV says it has been awarded a $500,000 grant from the New York State Music Fund to support the development of a second full-time radio station for listeners in their 20s and 30s, which will emphasize independently and locally produced music. The fund, a grant program of Rockefeller Philanthropy Advisors, helps make contemporary music of all genres more available and accessible to diverse audiences in New York State. The station, which will cost $1.2 million to create and is scheduled to make its debut in the fall of 2008, will be available via the Internet at wfuv.org and mobile streaming audio and, in the New York area, as a high-definition radio channel at 90.7 FM. Programming will include established and emerging indie rock, electronica, world, dance and other musical hybrids. Our city boasts one of the greatest, most multicultural local music scenes in the world, said Chuck Singleton, WFUVs program director. Acts like Antibalas, Forro in the Dark and the Hold Steady, he added,  have no problem selling out venues all over town, yet they presently dont have a home on the radio in New York City. WFUV is a noncommercial, listener-supported public radio station licensed to Fordham University.

title: Britain: Inflation Rate Slips Below Target
description: The inflation rate in Britain unexpectedly fell last month below the Bank of Englands 2 percent target for the first time since March 2006, weakening the case for another interest rate increase. Consumer prices rose 1.9 percent in July from a year earlier, down from 2.4 percent in June, the Office for National Statistics said. Economists had expected inflation, which accelerated to a decade high of 3.1 percent in March, to slow to 2.3 percent last month. So-called core inflation, which excludes energy, food, tobacco and alcohol, slowed to 1.7 percent in July, down from a decade high of 2 percent in June.

The Liverpool Philharmonic said audience members from across the world would sit in a three-dimensional virtual version of Liverpools Philharmonic Hall and listen live as the real orchestra plays. The concert on Sept. 14, featuring works by Rachmaninoff, Ravel and contemporary Liverpool composers, will be led by the orchestras principal conductor, Vasily Petrenko. Audience members will be able to interact with one another (via instant messaging) and to take a bathroom break. Tickets will be offered free in a competition on the orchestras Web site: liverpoolphil.com.

In the wake of the stock market crash in 1929, they urged investors to focus on hard facts  like a companys past earnings and the value of its assets  rather than trying to guess what the future would bring. A company with strong profits and a relatively low stock price was probably undervalued, they said.

The crash occurred shortly after midnight near the Whitestone Expressway when a Chevrolet Blazer driven by Bolivar Comacho, 18, of Queens and a Honda Civic driven by Milton Flores, 20, of Queens, collided, the police said. John Reyes, 19, a passenger in Mr. Comachos vehicle, was killed and five other occupants of the Blazer and two of the Civic were injured, the police said. Both drivers were among the injured. Mr. Comacho was charged with manslaughter and reckless driving, and Mr. Flores with driving while intoxicated, the police said.

title: China: Higher Wages and Prices Lift Retail Sales
description: Chinas retail sales grew at the fastest rate in more than three years, helped by a stock market rally and higher wages and prices. Spending climbed 16.4 percent, to 699.8 billion yuan ($92 billion) in July from a year earlier, after gaining 16 percent in June, the National Bureau of Statistics said. The figures are not adjusted for inflation. The biggest increase in consumer prices in a decade contributed to the acceleration. Stock market gains and a 14 percent jump in urban incomes underpinned demand. Inflation played an important role in gains for food sales, said Paul Tang, chief economist at Bank of East Asia in Hong Kong. But in other categories, theres genuine continued gains, and overall growth is steady.

title: Lessons on Homosexuality Move Into the Classroom
description: ROCKVILLE, Md.

title: An Orchard in a Bottle, at 80 Proof
description: PORTLAND, Ore.

title: Whats on Tonight
description: 10 P.M. (ABC) NASCAR IN PRIMETIME With roots in Prohibition-era bootlegging, stock-car racing used to be a sport known primarily for its appeal to Southern white men. But these days, women make up more than 40 percent of Nascars 75 million fans, and drivers like Juan Pablo Montoya attract a growing Hispanic audience. So for the first time, Nascar has opened up its doors, and hoods and pits, to a news organization. For six months ABC News was granted uncensored access to drivers, fans and officials, both on and off the racetrack. Among the speed demons waxing poetic about life in the very, very fast lane: Jimmie Johnson, above, Tony Stewart, David Stremme, Stanton Barrett, Mark Martin, Johnny Sauter, Jeff Burton, Marc Davis and Mr. Montoya.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A picture caption yesterday about a guilty plea by Oliver M. Thomas Jr., a New Orleans official, in a federal bribery case misstated his status on the city council. He is a former president of the council, not its current president.

title: CBS and Imus Settle Differences Over His Firing
description: The voice of Don Imus could resurface somewhere on the radio dial as soon as this fall, after Mr. Imus and CBS announced that they had settled the remaining differences about his firing in April over remarks deemed insensitive to women and blacks.

title: Staten Island: Arraigned in Death
description: Edwin Garcia, 30, the Staten Island man law enforcement officials say smashed the head of his companions 21-month-old daughter, was arraigned yesterday in Staten Island Criminal Court and charged with second-degree murder. Marlene Medina, 24, the mother of the girl, Hailey Gonzalez, was charged with second-degree manslaughter. Mr. Garcia and Ms. Medina pleaded not guilty. Neither of their lawyers returned calls for comment. Prosecutors said that in an attempt to discipline Hailey on Aug. 7, Mr. Garcia slammed her onto a playpen containing hard toys causing severe trauma to her head. Despite obvious signs of distress, the couple waited five hours to get medical attention, prosecutors said. Hailey died on Monday after being taken off life support.

title: Immigrants and Hatred (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Calendar
description: Guided Beer Tasting

title: Asian Stocks Down Sharply; European Markets Also Dip
description: SINGAPORE, Aug. 15  Asian stock markets fell sharply today, amid further signs that the turmoil in the American mortgage market was spreading overseas. European share markets followed Asia lower.

title: Insuring Second Homes
description: When a 3,100-acre wildfire roared through the southern end of Lake Tahoe, Calif., last June, residents were instructed to evacuate the area. My house was about a half mile from the fire, said Fredy Buraye, the owner of a three-bedroom vacation home in the area. It was pretty close. Mr. Buraye said his anxiety about losing his home was slightly quelled because he knew he was adequately prepared for the situation. I knew I had the right insurance coverage. Mr. Buraye said he was lucky; the fire never made it to his home.

title: Reading Fortunes in a Bowl of Pasta
description: THERE was no reason to dally. So on the first of my recent visits to Caf Boulud, I dug right in and got pasta. I figured it would tell me a lot about what the restaurant had lost and how it was faring now. I braced myself.

title: Death Toll in Iraq Bombings Rises to 250
description: BAGHDAD, Aug. 15  The toll in a horrific quadruple bombing in an area of mud and stone houses in the remote northern desert on Tuesday evening reached 250 dead and 350 wounded, several local officials said today, making it the single deadliest coordinated attack since the American-led invasion of Iraq in 2003.

title: Hes Doing Whatever a Zebra Can
description: A downtrodden schoolteacher, a disabled boy and a government agent suffering from an embarrassing itch: these are the unlikely heroes of Zebraman, Takashi Miikes bizarre detour from ultraviolence into family fare.

title: China, Unregulated
description: Thats the price of doing business, is the too-often-heard excuse from American companies that choose to overlook Chinas loose business ethics and tight, verging on strangling, political controls.

title: Dow Off 167 Points in Late Swoon
description: The disquiet on Wall Street showed no signs of letting up today as the Dow Jones industrial average closed below 13,000 for the first time since April and the Standard & Poors 500-stock index erased its gains for the year.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A picture caption with an article yesterday about falling water levels in the Great Lakes misspelled the photographers surname. It is John Flesher, not Fleisher.

title: Subprime Problems Spread Into Commercial Loans
description: Turmoil in the subprime mortgage market spread again yesterday  this time to a type of short-term security held by money market mutual funds. These funds have become the investment of choice for many people seeking a safe haven.

title: Tired of Energy Ills, Syrians Doubt the West Is to Blame
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Aug. 14  Syria has had a summer of power failures and electricity shortages, and recent suggestions by Prime Minister Muhammad Naki al-Otari that American and French economic pressures are to blame are being greeted with skepticism by a weary public.

title: Editors Note
description: An article in the House & Home section on July 26 about Janna Bullock, a renovator and developer of Upper East Side townhouses, reported that one of the owners of a house she had bought on East 67th Street tried to set it on fire on the day of the closing. (Although the owner was not named, the address of the house was given in a caption.)

title: Along Both Sides of the Velvet Rope, Shallowness Reigns Supreme
description: Tom DiCillos angry comedy Delirious subjects modern celebrity culture to a microscopic examination that shows the toxic virus of fame squirming and multiplying under its lens. Here are the paparazzi posted like ravenous vermin in front of a velvet rope, ready to trample one another in a stampede at the next celebrity sighting.

title: Mattel Recalls 19 Million Toys Sent From China
description: Mattel, the worlds largest toy company, yesterday announced the biggest recall in its history.

title: After 60 Years, Will Pakistan Be Reborn?
description: London

title: So Many Ventures Did Not Spoil the Chef
description: Beverly Hills, Calif.

title: Will No Cage Hold Him? Monkey Again Escapes Zoo
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 14  For the second time in two weeks, Oliver, a 9-year-old capuchin monkey at a Mississippi zoo, escaped his cage, and this time, his keepers said he proved to be an even more artful dodger.

title: Producer Prices and Trade Data Give Fed Little Reason to Cut Rates
description: Two economic reports released yesterday suggested that the Federal Reserve was facing little urgency to lower interest rates soon.

title: Virginia Tech Shooting Payments Are Announced
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15  Families of the Virginia Tech students and faculty members killed by a student in a shooting in April will receive more compensation and benefits than was originally planned, university officials announced today.

title: Facing a Stark Reality, She Decides on a Raffle of Her Only Salable Asset
description: Iguatu, the desolate rural village in northeastern Brazil where Hermila (Hermila Guedes), a spirited 21-year-old single mother, arrives from So Paulo with her baby boy in Love for Sale, is the kind of oppressive backwater young people dreaming of a better life flee at the first opportunity. Hermila grew up there, and she returns filled with giddy fantasies of living happily ever after with her true love. Her boyfriend, Matheus, who fathered the baby, has promised to marry her and should arrive any day. Until he joins her, she and the baby stay with her aunt Maria (Maria Menezes) and grandmother Zezita (Zezita Matos).

title: Theres Money in Oil, Oystermen Find
description: HOPEDALE, La.  The brave little oyster boats chug out daily from the dock here, but their richest harvest may actually be sitting in the office towers of downtown New Orleans, 60 miles west of this remote spot where marsh, sky and water converge.

title: Samaritans Death Raises Questions About Her Choices
description: Geraldine Young was a former schoolteacher, 58 and single, who one day said God told her to take in homeless men and let them stay in the five bedrooms above her own. On this block of Crown Heights, Brooklyn, the opinion has long been divided on whether that made her a saint or a fool.

title: Beheading and Shooting by Russian Neo-Nazis on Video
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 14  The Russian authorities said Tuesday that they were investigating a video recording of what appeared to be the grisly execution of two bound and gagged young men, filmed in a forest beneath a large Nazi flag. At least one of the men was beheaded on camera as he lay in a shallow grave.

title: James Stewart, Immortalized
description: James Stewart will be honored by a stamp bearing his image, The Associated Press reported. It will be released Friday by the United States Postal Service at ceremonies in at the Jimmy Stewart Museum in Indiana, Pa., the actors hometown, and at Universal Studios in Hollywood. The photograph on the stamp, left, is based on a portrait of Stewart, who died in 1997, as he appeared in a publicity photo for the 1949 movie The Stratton Story.

title: Astronaut Teaches in Space, and Lesson Is Bittersweet
description: Barbara R. Morgan got back to teaching yesterday. The students were in Idaho; she was in space, orbiting aboard the International Space Station.

title: On the Road at 50
description: Published 50 years ago, On the Road still sells about 100,000 copies a year in various paperback editions, according to Viking. And while its era as a counterculture standard-bearer may have passed, it has far outlasted many other cult classics.

title: Write a Title, Win a Book
description: I mentioned recently in this blog that Ill be going on book leave soon to work with my wife, Sheryl WuDunn, on a book about women in the developing world. That provoked some interesting comments, and it reminded me that we still need a good title.

title: Clear Creek Eaux de Vie
description: Anybody who reads my column in Wednesdays newspaper, on the wonderful eaux de vie from Clear Creek Distillery, is likely to come away with this question: How do they get the pear into the bottle of pear eau de vie?

title: The Bison Business
description: Ive always felt sorry for food purveyors who want their products to shine at a conference but are at the mercy of the kitchen where the meeting is being held. Woe to the organization trying to promote any red meat under these circumstances, especially bison, which is a goner once it has been overcooked.

title: Ex-Software Executive Begins Prison Term
description: Sanjay Kumar, the former chief executive of Computer Associates, now known as CA, began serving a 12-year prison term Tuesday for his role in a $2.2 billion accounting fraud at the software company.

title: In a Reversal, Hedge Fund Will Support Sale of Ceridian
description: The hedge fund manager William A. Ackman dropped his opposition to the sale of Ceridian, the payroll processor, after tangling with the company for months.

title: 2 Guilty Pleas Expected in Insider Case
description: A former finance vice president at Morgan Stanley and her husband, a former hedge fund analyst at ING Investment Management, are expected to plead guilty to insider-trading charges, according to a prosecutor.

title: Documents Describe Whole Foods Strategy
description: Federal regulators filed court documents on Tuesday outlining concerns that stores in competitive markets will close and consumers will face higher prices if Whole Foods Markets $565 million purchase of Wild Oats Markets is completed.

title: AirTran Tops New Offer for Midwest Air
description: AirTran Holdings reversed course Tuesday and raised its offer for the Midwest Air Group to $445 million, topping a $424 million bid from the buyout firm TPG Capital and Northwest Airlines.

title: Fortress Battered by Wider Loss
description: The Fortress Investment Corporation posted a wider quarterly loss on Tuesday, sending its shares down 6.6 percent.

title: Trading Is Halted in Shares of Mortgage Lender
description: Trading was halted Tuesday in shares of the lender Thornburg Mortgage Asset after they fell 47 percent, the most since their 1993 initial public offering. Earlier, five brokerage firms downgraded the stock and Moodys Investors Service cut its debt rating amid turmoil in the home loan market.

title: Investors Flock to VMware on First Day of Trading
description: Shares of VMware, the fast-growing Silicon Valley software maker, jumped 76 percent in their first day of trading Tuesday as investors bet that the company would continue to fend off competitors like Microsoft for years to come.

title: Sentinel Management Freezes Fund
description: Sentinel Management Group on Tuesday froze a $1.5 billion fund, saying too many investors are trying to withdraw their money.

title: Icahn Builds Stake in Kraft
description: Confirming recent rumors, the activist investor Carl C. Icahn disclosed Tuesday in a regulatory filing that his investment firm had acquired 3.92 million shares of Kraft Foods, a holding valued at about $138.2 million as of June 30.

title: Buffett Takes Stakes in Dow Jones
description: Berkshire Hathaway, the investment firm run by Warren Buffett, bought stakes in Dow Jones and Bank of America and more than quadrupled its holdings of the health insurers UnitedHealth Group and WellPoint.

title: Behringer REIT to Buy Canadian Rival
description: The Behringer Harvard Real Estate Investment Trust of Dallas is proposing to buy Canadas IPC US Real Estate Investment Trust in an all-cash deal valued at about 1.4 billion Canadian dollars ($1.3 billion).

title: V.C. Spending in Canada Falls 30%
description: Venture capital investment across Canada fell by nearly one-third in the second quarter of 2007 with Ontario taking the hardest hit, as investment levels in the province fell to less than half their totals from the previous quarter.

title: Sainsbury Bidder Asks for Bank Guarantees
description: The banks arranging the 6 billion pounds ($11.9 billion) of debt finance for the Qatari-backed bid for Britains J Sainsburys supermarket chain have asked lenders for the money to be made available for longer as talks between the two sides drag on.

title: Dodd Backs Banks in Enron Suit
description: Senator Christopher Dodd, who heads the Senate Banking Committee, joined a number of lawmakers and officials of both parties Tuesday in calling on the Bush administration not to side with defendant companies in a Supreme Court case that could determine the fate of a separate Enron lawsuit.

title: Banks Agree to Give Basell $21 Billion in Loans
description: A Dutch company, Basell Holdings, has received a commitment for $21 billion in loans for its acquisition of Houston-based Lyondell Chemical in a signal that banks are still willing to finance some leveraged buyouts.

title: Redemption Day: Will Hedge-Fund Investors Bolt?
description: For hedge fund bosses, today could be a nail-biter.

title: Hedge Fund Managers Sue Akin Gump
description: In what The New York Law Journal regards as a cautionary tale, two former managers of a collapsed hedge fund, Veras Investment Partners, are suing Akin Gump Strauss Hauer & Feld, claiming that the law firm advised them that the late trading that led to the funds collapse was legal.

title: Tullys Coffee Not So Hot to Go Public
description: Tullys Coffee, once eager to jump into the stock markets roiling waters, now waits nervously on the shore. The Seattle-based coffee retailer has indefinitely postponed its initial public offering, citing turmoil in the stock market.

title: Janney Pays $2.5 Million to Settle Fees Case
description: Janney Montgomery Scott, the 175-year-old Philadelphia brokerage, will pay $2.5 million to settle allegations that it inflated borrowing costs and fees on stock loans.

title: Doppleganger Takes $11 Million
description: Doppelganger, a music-focused virtual realm operator, announced Tuesday that it had received an $11 million infusion of venture capital.

title: Warburg Takes Stake in Integra
description: As Integra Telecom works to close an acquisition that will greatly increase its heft, the Western operator said Tuesday that Warburg Pincus has paid $245 million for a stake in the company.

title: Aegis Files for Bankruptcy
description: Aegis Mortgage, which is owned by an affiliate of Cerberus Capital Management , became the third mortgage lender to file for bankruptcy protection in a week as the weak housing market and rapidly deteriorating secondary one for mortgage loans continues to devastate the entire industry.

title: Bear to Buy Fords Indian Finance Unit
description: Bear Stearns plans to enter India by acquiring the financial arm of Ford Motor, The Economic Times newspaper said in an unsourced story on Wednesday.

title: Tribune Denies Zell Deal is in Danger
description: Tribune said its $8.2 billion sale to a group led by the billionaire Samuel Zell is still on, disputing an analyst who said the odds of the deal closing as scheduled are no better than 50-50.

title: Troubled Dutch Investment Bank Is Sold
description: Kaupthing Bank, the biggest bank in Iceland, agreed to buy NIBC Holding for 3 billion euros ($4 billion), less than a week after the Dutch investment bank disclosed losses on United States subprime-mortgage bets.

title: Subprime Problems Spread Into Commercial Loans
description: Turmoil in the subprime mortgage market spread again Tuesday  this time to a type of short-term security held by money market mutual funds. These funds have become the investment of choice for many people seeking a safe haven.

title: Goldman to Waive Fees to Lure Investors to Fund
description: Goldman Sachs waived fees to draw investors to its Global Equity Opportunities hedge fund after stock-market losses wiped out $1.4 billion of assets this month.

title: In It Together
description: A place built to nurture both young and elderly people.

title: Mirant Auction Put on Hold, Report Says
description: The auction of Mirant is suffering from a brownout as the credit markets continue to take their toll on deal making. The Financial Times Deal Reporter site said Wednesday that buyers are waiting out the recent storm in the debt market and that the auction is merely on hold for now.

title: 2008: F. Thompsons Phantom Campaign
description: All summer, the rumors have flown about when former Senator Fred D. Thompson would officially announce his candidacy for president. Would he jump in on July 4 or perhaps later in the month? Now were hearing that its likely hell get into the race around Labor Day.

title: Cadbury Said to Choose Spinoff Over Sale
description: Cadbury Schweppes, concluding that private equity firms will be unable to raise funds to buy its United States beverage business, is moving ahead with a demerger of the unit instead of a sale, The Times of London reported, citing undisclosed sources.

title: Basis Says One Fund May Have Lost 80%
description: Australias Basis Capital Fund Management told investors losses at one of its hedge funds may exceed 80 percent as the United States subprime mortgage rout prompted creditors to force the Sydney-based company to sell assets, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Morning Buzz: A Mixed Picture for Congestion Pricing; the Six Newark Murder Suspects; the Astor Funeral Guest List; and More
description: A mixed picture has emerged on the announcement yesterday that the federal government is willing to provide $354 million to help reduce traffic in New York City and to put in effect Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs congestion pricing plan. As William Neuman notes, the city had estimated that it would cost $223 million to install a computerized system to monitor traffic and impose a traffic fee on cars entering the busiest parts of Manhattan, and asked the federal government to cover $179 million of that.But the Department of Transportation said it would contribute only $10 million to that initiative. Instead, most of the federal money was reserved for bus depots and other mass transit improvements, like expanded ferry service. New York received far more than the other four cities that also received grants: Miami, Minneapolis, San Francisco and Seattle.

title:
Living with Music:
A Playlist by Glenn Kurtz
description: On Wednesdays, this blog is the delivery vehicle for Living With Music, a playlist of songs from a writer or some other kind of book-world personage. Why? Because books and music, on good days, just seem to go together. And because the celebrity playlists on iTunes never get around to asking writers to pitch in.

title: How to Simulate the Universe
description: A lot of readers dont want to believe theyre living in a computer simulation. The last post prompted a virtual avalanche of comments from people insisting it would be impossible for any computer to create a virtual world with virtual people with virtual nervous systems.

title: Harikrishna, Acs Tie for First in Hungary; Korchnoi Fades
description: Pentala Harikrishna of India and Peter Acs of Hungary tied for first in the Fifth Marx Gyorgy Memorial Tournament in Paks, Hungary. (In an odd coincidence, the two share the same birthday: May 10, although Acs is five years older than Harikrishna.) The tournament, which was sponsored by a nuclear power plant in honor of Gyorgy, a nuclear physicist, ran from Aug. 4-15. The games and profiles of the players are on the tournaments official Web site.

title: Rice Whittles a Stick for Iran
description: Out on the campaign trail, candidates are carefully detailing their Iran policies, with Rudolph W. Giuliani being the latest. In two paragraphs of an essay in Foreign Affairs, he describes a broad strategy with the goal of proving to the theocrats ruling Iran that we can wield the stick as well as the carrot.

title: Carville on Rove
description: Writing in The Financial Times, former Clinton strategist James Carville analyzes Karl Roves career: There is no doubt that Mr Rove won elections. He has perhaps one of the most remarkable win-percentages in modern American politics. At the same time, however, He has lost an entire generation for the Republican party, Carville writes. He continues:

title: A Peek Behind the Automated Curtain
description: There is a school of thought that A.T.M.s are not technological marvels; that they are, in fact, mere facades. Behind the glowing screens and beeping buttons, this theory goes, stand rooms full of humans (or elves) who shuttle back and forth to the vault and simply slide money through the slots, performing the work of real tellers without any need for personal interaction with customers.

title: A Plaintiffs Attorney Takes His Client List Upscale
description: For years, the name Jacob H. Zamansky provoked headaches on Wall Street. The plaintiffs lawyer best known for suing Merrill Lynch over an infamous research report by Henry Blodget, Mr. Zamansky has long been known as a gadfly who represented small investors  and squeezed big settlements out of major firms in the process.

title: Another Human-Computer Match and the Result Was Predictable
description: Ten years ago, Garry Kasparov lost a match to Deep Blue, a chess computer developed by I.B.M. Anyone who wants to relive the match can go to the Web site which is still up. Although the result was a bit of shock at the time, it was also inevitable. With improvements in computer speed and programming, everyone, even Kasparov, knew that eventually computers would surpass humans at playing chess. (In 1995, Kasparov had predicted that he would not lose until about 2005, but programming and computer hardware development were not exactly his area of expertise.)

title: Buyout Blues Hit American Idol Deal
description: Not even Elvis Presley is immune from the recent credit crunch.

title: Harry Potter Behemoth Nears Russia
description: The Harry Potter craze has begun to fade in the United States, but the boy wizard has plenty of Russian fans eagerly anticipating the September 1 release of the official Russian translation.

title: Halcyon Days
description: The Halcyon

title: Romney and Richardson Unveil New Campaign Ads
description: Mitt Romney is up with yet another new ad in Iowa, this time an effort to extend his victory lap after the states Republican straw poll with a Thanks, Iowa commercial.

title: Police Issue Report on Homegrown Terror Threat
description: Updated, 5:54 p.m. | The citys Police Department this morning released a report, Radicalization in the West: The Homegrown Threat, that examines, in 90 pages, how ordinary people in the West can become radicalized and followers of what the report calls a jihadist ideology. Although the findings in the new analysis are similar to those of other studies, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said the report  prepared by the departments Intelligence Division  was an important addition to his departments arsenal of counterterrorism tools.

title: Hedge Funds Sail On, Despite the Storm
description: No liquidity problems here.

title: Q & A: Readings Marcus Hahnemann
description: Marcus Hahnemann is now in his eighth year playing in England. Last season, the Reading keeper helped his team finish eighth in the Premiere League, their first season in the top flight. He recorded 22 shutouts in 38 league games.

title: Off the Menu: Lidia Loves a Parade
description: This week in Florence Fabricants Off the Menu column, she reports that Lidia Bastianich will be the first chef to serve as grand marshal of the Columbus Day Parade. She joins an esteemed grand marshal lineage that includes Frank Sinatra, Sophia Loren  and Tommy Lasorda.

title: Each Issue Really Socks it to You
description: Ive never actually laid my hands on a copy of Ralph Ginzburgs literary-cultural magazine Avant-Garde, which existed from 1968 through 1971.

title: The Secret Language of Hedge Funds
description: When things turn bad, hedge fund managers cant get away with telling investors that the dog ate their returns. But they have an array of other, far more technical-sounding explanations for losing billions of dollars of other peoples money. And those explanations have been getting quite a workout in the last few weeks, as some well-known funds are facing double-digit losses or shutting their funds down altogether.

title: Congressional Race on Staten Island May Be a Rematch
description: For most of the 13 members of Congress from New York City, the November election is a sleepy event, with little in the way of competition. In fact, three congressmen from New York were uncontested in the general election in 2006 and eight members of Congress from the city won with 80 percent or more of the vote that year.

title: Offerman Goes Off
description: Jos Offermans bat landed him in trouble Tuesday. Or rather, its what he did with his bat: Offerman was charged with two counts of second-degree assault after hitting the pitcher and catcher with his bat during an independent minor league game in Bridgeport, Conn.

title: Vikings Land; Rubber Ducks Do Not
description: The nautical news goes farther and wider than world leaders are willing to roam this vacation season. From the North Sea to the South Atlantic, a trio of oddities on the high seas have carried on in their own odd way since we last wrote about them on July 3. Heres a progress report.

title: The Last Working-Class Bar in the Hamptons? Dont Wear Your Penny Loafers
description: The Hamptons are known for many things, but blue-collar bars are not one of them.

title: Counting Up Private Equitys Lobbying Tab
description: In Washington, as in Wall Street, money talks. And during the first half of this year, it seems private equity firms were trying to say a lot.

title: SLM Shareholders Approve Buyout
description: The SLM Corporation, commonly known as Sallie Mae, said on Wednesday its shareholders had approved the $25 billion acquisition of the student lender by a group of private equity firms and banks. The company in April accepted the cash leveraged buyout proposal, worth $60 per share, from J.C. Flowers, Friedman Fleischer & Lowe, Bank of America and J.P. Morgan Chase.

title: A Call to Ban Smoking in Cars (With Children)
description: Under a City Council proposal, New York City would prohibit smoking in cars where children are riding, joining the ranks of Arkansas, Louisiana, Puerto Rico, Bangor, Me., and Rockland County, N.Y., where similar legislation has been passed.

title: Turned Off by Giulianis Foreign Policy
description: Foreign Affairs has published Rudy Giulianis foreign policy manifesto, Toward a Realistic Peace. (The magazine has published similar essays by Barack Obama, Mitt Romney, and John Edwards, with more to come from the top U.S. presidential candidates.)

title: The Edwards  Edwards Ticket
description: Breaking news from the Maple Inn Caf in Osage, Iowa: Elizabeth Edwards is angling to be her husbands vice president.

title: Making Money Off Bush
description: You can almost count the hours between the time that a White House official says something, a Democratic candidate responds, and then  a fund-raising appeal drops into everyones inbox. In the 2008 campaign season, its already a familiar routine.
