description: By Andreas Tzortzis

title: Never Let Em See You Sweat
description: DES MOINES  Hillary Rodham Clinton may have been the coolest person at the Iowa State Fair today. According to The Des Moines Register, the heat index is 103, and everyone else here at the fairgrounds looked it. Makeup slid off womens faces. Thousands of hands wiped brows and beat the still air with cardboard fans.

title: Bomb Attacks in Northern Iraq
description: The coordinated attack on members of the Yazidi sect in two Iraqi towns near the Syrian border was the single deadliest bombing of the war.

title: The Ups and Downs of Romneys Portfolio
description: Mitt Romney has based much of his presidential run  both its image and its financing  on his experience with and investments in private equity and other alternative assets. It now seems that the former Massachusetts governor has gained even more from those investments  and lost, too.

title: Brooke Astors Last Will and Testament
description: Following are copies of the disputed last will and testament of Brooke Astor, who died on Monday at age 105.

title: Referee Pleads Guilty
description: Former referee Tim Donaghy admitted to gambling on N.B.A. games while working for the league.

title: Tango in Central Park
description: For more than a decade, tango in Central Park has been the emblem of one of the city's most obsessed subcultures.

title: Keane-O Vs. WAGS
description: What makes Roy Keane tick?

title: Answers From the New York Dog Experts, Part 2
description: Following is the second set of responses from the dog experts Marcello Forte and Jennifer Bristol, who are the executive director and associate director, respectively, of Animal Haven. Mr. Forte and Ms. Bristol are taking questions from City Room readers this week. Readers are invited to submit additional questions here. A first set of answers was posted on Tuesday.

title: U.S. U-17 Team Lands in South Korea
description: Want to feel old?

title: 1,000 Points of Darkness
description: The Dow has managed to lose more than 1,000 points in the 19 trading sessions since it first closed over 14,000. It seems like every time stock buyers manage to get a rally together, as they did earlier today, there is another piece of bad news on the credit front. Today it is KKR Finance, which cant sell enough mortgage loans, and Countrywide Financial, where a Merrill Lynch analyst named Kenneth Bruce is warning the company could go broke if it cant sell assets for high enough prices.

title: Giuliani Swings Through Iowa, Too
description: CARSON,Iowa  Rudolph W. Giuliani was nowhere to be seen in Iowa last weekend during the Iowa Straw Poll in Ames, the non-binding, pay-to-play poll for Iowa Republicans.

title: Pedicab Owners Protest Pending Regulation
description: Nearly 50 pedicabs made their way down Broadway, from Columbus Circle through Times Square and all the way to City Hall, this afternoon in a last-ditch protest as the city prepares next month to begin regulating the human-powered vehicles for the first time. Pedicab operators will be licensed, and the number of vehicles will be capped at 325. No one is certain how many pedicabs are currently in use, but estimates have placed the number as high as 800 to 1,000.The pedicab industry started in the mid-1990s. The vehicles have become popular as an unconventional way to get around Midtown, but cabbies, bus drivers and police officers have often complained that the vehicles clog the streets. In February, the City Council approved a pedicab regulation bill over objections from some cab owners. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg seemed poised to sign the bill in March, but at the last minute, he changed his mind, swayed by arguments that the tiny industry should remain relatively unregulated. Later that month, the mayor vetoed the bill, but in April, the Council voted to override the veto.

title: Dodd Woos Labor Crowd in Iowa
description: WATERLOO, Iowa  If Senator Chris Dodd of Connecticut were elected president, sleepovers might become more popular than state dinners at the White House.

title: Lessons From the Master
description: Is Hillary Clinton Slytherins heir? Mark Kleiman, a U.C.L.A. public policy professor who writes at the academic group blog The Reality-Based Community, says Clintons campaign is Roves disciple for its attacks on Barack Obama.

title: Rove vs. Clinton
description: Just two days after announcing he would be stepping down as a top adviser to President Bush, Karl Rove is ramping up his attacks on Democrats and, in particular, one of the partys leading presidential contenders, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton.

title: Will the Real Hooded Man Please Stand Up
description: Every human being has his own particular web of associations for identifying and interpreting reality, which, most often, instinctively and unthinkingly, he superimposes on every set of circumstances. Frequently, however, those external circumstances do not conform with, or fit, the structure of our webs, and then we can misread the unfamiliar reality, and interpret its elements incorrectly Ryszard Kapuscinski, Travels with Herodotus (2007)

title: A Wonderful, Wide Community of All Ages
description: Its been one year since an old man named Peter Oakley posted his first video on YouTube.

title: The Quants Explain Disaster
description: A hedge fund manager sent me a copy of a report from Goldman Sachs entitled The Quant Liquidity Crunch. What follows are Goldmans conclusion, and his dissection of that conclusion. (The manager prefers not to have his name used here. The people he mentions, if anyone needs to be told, are Warren Buffett and Charles Munger of Berkshire Hathaway.)

title: Im Outta Here
description: Im headed for vacation, although my Friday and Saturday columns will appear this week. Comments will continue to be posted, but I probably wont write new items until Aug. 27.

title: Antiwar Challenge to Kucinich
description: By March, Representative Dennis J. Kucinich of Ohio will probably know the fate of his presidential bid. At that point, he might have to worry about his partys nomination for his own Cleveland-based House seat. The race is already heating up, as his challenger for the Democratic nomination in the 10th Congressional District today accepted the endorsement of Paul Hackett, the Iraq vet and bitter war foe who himself sought a seat in Congress.

title: The Interchangeable Left-Handers
description: I touched on this briefly in my game story in this mornings paper, but I devoted a little more space to it in the notebook that will run in the early editions tomorrow: Was anyone else surprised to see Willie Randolph summon Scott Schoeneweis  and not the left-handed specialist Pedro Feliciano  with the tying run on third base and two outs in the eighth inning Tuesday?

title: Sony v. Microsoft (With Helmets)
description: A video game review published this week in USA Today has set off the latest tit-for-tat among the loyalists of the Xbox 360 and its rival, the PlayStation 3.

title: Reprieve for Bangkoks Night Bazaar
description: Bangkoks Suan Lum Night Bazaar, open for business

title: Your Comments on my Climate Column
description: In Thursdays column I focus on a wave of new research showing that climate change is already happening faster than scientists had anticipated. Most predictions about rising seas are based on computer models, but a series of new scientific studies have shown that actual measurements are worse than the models predicted. For example, the north polar ice cap is melting at three times the rate the models anticipated.

title: Dow Drops 340 Points, Then Recovers Losses
description: Stocks staged a late rally today on Wall Street after a day of wild swings as investors continued to weigh the impact of the crunch in the American credit market.

description: Purslane in Every Pot

title: CIRCUITS| An Interactive Robotic Toy to Amuse Youngsters (and Scare Pets) as It Scuttles Across the Floor
description: What has four legs, walks like a crab and uses seven batteries? Its Roboquad, a cat-size robotic toy from WowWee (www.wowwee.com) that manages to be both cute and creepy at the same time. The rotating legs give this $100 toy an insectlike motion that has the potential to send a pet under the couch. But the large darting infrared eyes give it a personable look.

title: Newly Released
description: Lets face it: August is not generally when publishing houses unveil their most precious gems, just after the arrival of the prime summer beach reads but before the autumn onslaught of prize bait. Often, as a result, the month offers a grab bag of titles that dont quite fit in any other time. Still, pearls can be found.

title: U.S. Is Prodding Pakistan Leader to Share Power
description: This article was reported by Mark Mazzetti, Helene Cooper and Carlotta Gall, and written by Mr. Mazzetti.

description: Washington

title: Chinese Want to Cut Slice Going to U.S. Middlemen
description: GROWING numbers of Chinese companies are quietly setting up operations in the United States, even as trade with China has ignited loud debates in Congress.

title: Where Is Everybody? The Gang at a Glance
description: MY daughters day camp ends at 5 p.m., and it takes only four minutes to drive there from my house if I get lucky at the stoplight on Miller Avenue, and theres a good chance that the kids in the Blue Group will be dismissed a minute or two late.

title: Amgen to Cut Jobs, a First for the Biotech Giant
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 15  The biotechnology giant Amgen announced the first major layoffs in its heretofore charmed history today in reaction to sliding sales of the anemia drugs that account for nearly half its revenue.

title: Aging at Home, and With Dignity (4 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: On Stand, Officer Tells of Affair That Grew Violent, Saying Captain Beat Her
description: The way prosecutors tell it, the trial of Alberto Sanchez revolves around a sad clich: an office romance between a married woman and her boss that spiraled into domestic violence. The exception is that they are both police officers.

title: A Credit Crunch Unlike Any Other
description: Twenty-first century financial markets react with lightning speed to events halfway around the world. Investors in China can immediately see what happened in New York and make trades in London based on the news.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,683 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:

title: Arias Alfresco, Siren Accompaniment
description: You tend to forget how good opera is until you actually hear it, Tony Zertuche, a 36-year-old playwright, said Tuesday afternoon. He was waiting in a long line in Bryant Park to buy $25 tickets to coming New York City Opera productions, which were being sold after the companys Afternoon Arias lunchtime concert in the park.

title: At Netflix, Victory for Voices Over Keystrokes
description: HILLSBORO, Ore.  Megan Funk had been on the phone for 30 minutes and had already untangled one billing knot, listened to a woman insist that she had returned a Pilates DVD when it was clear she had lost it and received one request to replace a cracked copy of Hotel Rwanda and another to replace a disappointing husband.

title: Iran Arrests 2 Chinese on Charges of Spying
description: TEHRAN, Aug. 15  Iran has arrested two Chinese citizens on charges of spying for taking pictures of a military complex in the central city of Arak, where Iran is building a nuclear reactor, the judiciary spokesman said Wednesday.

title: Study Abroad Is New Focus of Inquiry Into Perks
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15  New Yorks attorney general is opening an inquiry into the relationships between universities and providers of study abroad, delivering subpoenas to five providers on Wednesday with more to come, a senior lawyer in the office said.

title: Amateur Hour on Iran
description: The dangers posed by Iran are serious, and America needs to respond with serious policies, not more theatrics. Labeling Irans Revolutionary Guard Corps as a foreign terrorist organization  as the State Department now proposes  is another distraction when what the Bush administration needs to be doing is opening comprehensive negotiations with Tehran, backed by increasing international economic pressure.

title: Searching for the Miners
description: It is beyond belief that in this Information Age, when new technologies can eavesdrop on any conversation and track people around the globe, rescue teams have no way to communicate with the six miners trapped underground in the Crandall Canyon Mine in Utah. Instead they are drilling holes in the ground to where they guess the miners might be.

title: Neighbors of Home Invasion Victims Demand Stricter Repeat-Offender Laws
description: CHESHIRE, Conn., Aug. 15  Cheshire residents, angered by revelations that the men suspected of killing three members of a prominent family in a home invasion robbery last month had been paroled after convictions for burglary, rallied in a town park on Wednesday to demand stricter laws to keep repeat offenders behind bars.

title: Textbook Case of Unblocking, but This Ones From Real Life
description: Inexperienced players sometimes complain that textbook plays they have been taught do not occur at the table, only in classes and publications. But they do arise occasionally, as evidenced by the diagramed deal, which occurred July 6 during a two-day knockout team event at the July 4th Regional in Deerfield Beach, Fla.

title: Mood Swings as Rivera Negates Yankees Rally
description: The decibel level at Yankee Stadium soared like a firecracker during the top of the 10th inning yesterday. The 53,363 fans were ecstatic for two justifiable reasons. Shelley Duncan had tied the score against the Baltimore Orioles with a three-run homer in the ninth inning. And Mariano Rivera, a model of consistency this season, had just taken the mound.

title: Nickelodeon to Limit Use of Characters on Junk Foods
description: Add Jimmy Neutron to the list of licensed characters that are going on a diet.

title: After 20 Days, Revis and Jets Strike a Deal
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Aug. 15  The labor that delivered cornerback Darrelle Revis to the Jets was plodding, dragging on for 20 days beyond the due date. The last push started Tuesday night and continued well into Wednesday.

title: Indonesia: High Economic Growth
description: Indonesias economy grew the fastest in more than two years in the second quarter as exports rose and lower interest rates fueled spending and investment. The economy expanded 6.3 percent in the three months ended June 30 after gaining 6 percent in the previous quarter, the Central Statistics Bureau said. Private consumption increased 4.7 percent in the second quarter from a year earlier, according to the report. Manufacturing expanded 5.5 percent, construction rose 7.8 percent and agriculture gained 2.4 percent. Government spending was up 3.8 percent. Exports rose 9.8 percent on rising overseas sales of commodities, including palm oil and coal, the report said, while imports increased 7.2 percent.

title: West Bank: Talks on Japan-Sponsored Project
description: The foreign ministers of Japan, Israel and Jordan and senior Palestinian officials met in the West Bank town of Jericho to discuss the possibility of building a joint agricultural-industrial park in the Jordan Valley, underwritten by Japan. Earlier, the Japanese foreign minister, Taro Aso, announced the resumption of direct aid to the Palestinian Authority, suspended after Hamas came to power in elections in 2006.

title: By His Former Lawyers
description: Michael Jacksons former lawyers filed a lawsuit on Tuesday claiming that he owes them more than $113,000, The Associated Press reported yesterday. The Los Angeles law firm Lavely & Singer says that Mr. Jackson agreed in arbitration last year to pay $180,000 in three installments. He failed to make the final payment of $113,750 before the July 31, 2007, deadline stipulated in the settlement, the firm says in a complaint filed in Los Angeles Superior Court.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Venezuela to Purchase Thousands of Russian Rifles
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 15  A proposed contract between Russia and Venezuela that could transfer thousands of sniper rifles to Venezuela has raised concerns in the United States about the potential use or regional distribution of the weapons by the socialist-inspired government of President Hugo Chavez.

title: A Poet of the Diamond, Delivering His Lines on a Three-and-One Count
description: Williams Carlos Williams, a physician, was also an unconventional poet who died in 1963 shortly after winning the Pulitzer Prize for poetry.

title: Establishment Threads in a Radical Fringe
description: EDINBURGH  If farce is tragedy speeded up, as has been said, Enda Walshs ferociously entertaining new play might be called a drama in three gears.

title: Maker of Video Games Is Notified S.E.C. May Act in Options Case
description: The video game maker Take-Two Interactive said yesterday that it might face civil charges and fines from the Securities and Exchange Commission for backdating stock options.

title: Madden on the Wii: Fun Even for Nonenthusiasts
description: When I was a boy I used to sit with my dad in front of the TV and watch football games. He would explain the rules and tell me about the teams and the important players while I tuned him out, distracted by what looked to me like a chaotic free-for-all. I never had the slightest idea what was going on in the game and usually wasnt even sure where the ball was.

title: Push by Chvez to Abandon Term Limits on Presidency
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Aug. 15  President Hugo Chvez outlined a proposed overhaul to the Constitution on Wednesday night that would allow him to remain in power indefinitely through perpetual re-elections, an intensification of his efforts to assert greater state control over political and economic institutions.

title: Talent Will Out
description: The finale of Americas Got Talent on NBC delivered the largest audience of Tuesday night, according to Nielsens estimate, with 10.8 million viewers from 8 to 9:30 p.m. NBCs Singing Bee at 9:30 (9.8 million) tied with CBSs Big Brother among adults 18 to 49. Big Brother posted its highest numbers of the summer, attracting 7.7 million total viewers in the 9 p.m. hour. CBS ranked No. 2 for the night, just ahead of ABCs back-to-back episodes of Just for Laughs, which averaged 6.8 million viewers and came in second among the 18-to-49 set in the 8 p.m. hour. Fox was fourth for the night.

title: Remains Found in Bridge Disaster
description: Human remains were found in two of four vehicles pulled from the bottom of the Mississippi River, where they fell on Aug. 1 when the I-35W bridge in Minneapolis collapsed, the Hennepin County Sheriffs office announced today.

title: Mortgage Lender Moves to Shore Up Cash
description: Countrywide Financial, the nations largest mortgage lender, said today that it had tapped $11.5 billion in emergency loans from 40 of the worlds largest banks in an effort to shore up its cash position.

title: The New Sophisticated-Smelling Me
description: YOU can go through life for only so long smelling like a dessert topping. For a few years now, I have been wearing a mix of a coconut-y moisturizer, Skin Trip, and a cake-batter-y perfume oil, Tunisian Amber, both acquired from the Integral Yoga store on West 13th Street. It was cool for a while, but I am nearing 40, and this sweet concoction doesnt cut it anymore, unless my goal is to attract a doughnut.

title: Underneath the Normal, the Nutty
description: If yours is a normal family, it probably isnt very normal at all. We all know that family life is part facade, that a layer of weirdness or tension or both lurks beneath the Kodak moments. Long Distance, a program of three one-acts adapted from stories by Judy Budnitz, captures family life as it is but isnt: skewed, unreal but somehow painfully accurate.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Edwards Opts to Redirect Nevada Staff
description: Former Senator John Edwards is moving a handful of paid staff members from Nevada to other early primary states, according to campaign officials, who characterized the shift as a routine event that occurs in any political campaign.

title: R. Kellys Killer Serial: Video, Music, Cliffhangers, Midgets
description: The story began simply enough: the love triangle of Sylvester, Kathy and Rufus. But after 12 chapters the triangle was more like a lopsided octagon, with a dozen characters and as many cliffhangers. The dramas hinged on unlikely plot devices: leg cramps, pie allergies, the surprising things one finds hiding in cupboards.

title: Brooklyn: Call for Blast Inquiry
description: A lawyer representing one of the most severely injured victims of last months steam pipe explosion in Manhattan said yesterday that an independent monitor should oversee the testing of evidence. In a hearing on a motion filed in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, the lawyer, Kenneth P. Thompson, said that Consolidated Edison, which runs the citys steam network, could not be trusted to perform destructive testing on equipment found at the site of the July 18 explosion. Mr. Thompson represents Gregory McCullough, 21, who suffered third-degree burns. The lawyer obtained a temporary restraining order last week to stop the testing until a judge could review the motion. Henry G. Miller, a lawyer for Con Edison, said that an independent company, Evidence Security Inc., had been hired to secure evidence found at the scene. Arguments in Mr. Thompsons motion are expected to resume this morning.

title: Terrorist Label for Iran Guard Reflects U.S. Impatience With U.N.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15  In moving toward designating Irans Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps as a foreign terrorist organization, the Bush administration is adopting a more confrontational approach with Tehran, reflecting frustration with a stalled sanctions package at the United Nations Security Council, officials said Wednesday.

title: China Plans Greater Scrutiny of Food Exports
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15  Chinese government authorities are prepared to require that every shipment of food being exported to the United States and other countries be inspected for quality by the government, starting Sept. 1, a senior Chinese trade official said on Wednesday.

title: Chvezs Bid for Russian Arms Pains U.S.
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 15  A proposed contract between Russia and Venezuela that could transfer thousands of sniper rifles to Venezuela has raised concerns in the United States about the potential use or regional distribution of the weapons by the socialist-inspired government of President Hugo Chvez.

title: In Sickness and in Health?
description: After an off-season of bad news about concussions in football, the N.F.L. this week approved guidelines to help monitor and manage concussions among active players. What should the leagues responsibility be for the health of former players?

title: An Artists Artist (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Pop Charts: Hot Rap
description: Two new rap albums take the top spots on the Billboard chart this week. The first in five years from the Port Arthur, Tex., duo UGK, Underground Kingz (Jive), reached No. 1 with 160,000 copies sold, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Plies, a gruff rapper from Fort Myers, Fla., is at No. 2 with The Real Testament (Slip-N-Slide/Atlantic), which sold 96,000. The only other new album in the Top 40 is the self-titled second disc by the Jonas Brothers, a teenage trio from New Jersey whose music is on the extreme pop end of emo; it sold 69,000 copies and reached No. 5. Last weeks best seller, Commons Finding Forever (Geffen), dropped to No. 7 with sales of 58,000, a decline of 63 percent.

title: Business and Science to Join in Taking a Rivers Pulse
description: BEACON, N.Y., Aug. 13  Environmentalists and big corporations often end up in open conflict because they do not see eye to eye on whether a natural resource like a river should be protected or exploited.

title: With a New Leader and Renewed Verve, Bolshoi Soars in Londoners Eyes
description: LONDON, Aug. 15  The Bolshoi Ballets current season here, the third in four years, is such a success that it has inspired standing, shouting ovations from audiences and superlatives from sometimes finicky critics, including one who deemed a performance worthy of six stars out of five.

title: Living in Her Moment, Again
description: WHEN she breezed into Manhattan last week, Zandra Rhodes had shed some elements of her operatic style. Her fuchsia hair, which she tends to wear upswept in a chopstick-anchored bun, was straight and fastidiously groomed. Her eyebrows, crazy semaphores that she sometimes pencils in like arrows, were conventionally shaped. And her eye shadow, which she applies in a rainbow-colored medley, was confined to two or three tints of blue. The first thing I said to her, recalled Ed Burstell, an executive at Bergdorf Goodman, where Ms. Rhodes had paid a sales call, was, Zandra, youve calmed it down.

title: Thank God, This Will Only Get Worse
description: Stuart Stevens never imagined playing a sport without violence, and at one point swore to himself to never take up any sports that fat people do well. Like golf. Then, as he describes in "Thank God, This Will Only Get Worse," his essay for PLAY, a single shot of Nordic racing in his late-20s led him to obsessively pursue endurance sports. But as you get older and life becomes more complicated, its easy to start questioning the value of spending huge chunks of your days going in what amounts to glorified circles, he writes. Its an entirely rational epiphany and one that must, of course, be crushed immediately.

title: U.S. and Israel Sign Military Aid Deal
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 16  Israel and the United States signed an agreement today that will give Israel $30 billion in military aid over the next decade. Officials called the aid a long-term investment in peace.

title: Inquiry Threatens Ex-Leader of Securities Agency
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15  After operating for several decades at the highest levels of the intersection of Washington and the corporate world, Roderick M. Hills was someone whose advice was eagerly sought by companies under fire from federal authorities.

title: Toy Makers Brace for a Chill in Sales
description: For toy makers, it is beginning to look as if it may be a rough Christmas.

title: Schoeneweis Answers the Call for the Mets With a Lead in the Eighth
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 15  Scott Schoeneweis encountered two surprises at PNC Park on Tuesday. The first came when he arrived at his locker to discover that his spikes did not make the trip from New York. That problem was remedied by his borrowing an extra pair from Oliver Prez, whose size 11 Nikes were the exact model that Schoeneweis prefers.

title: China: Production Pace Slows
description: Chinas industrial production rose 18 percent in July, slowing for the first time in three months after reductions in export incentives. Output grew less than Junes 19.4 percent, the statistics bureau said. The slowdown is not likely to ease government concern that the economy may be overheating. This is still a pretty robust number, highlighting the momentum of the Chinese economy supported by exports and retail demand, said David Cohen, an economist at Action Economics in Singapore. Its premature to speculate that the economy is slowing, Mr. Cohen said. Exports jumped 34.2 percent in July from a year earlier, the fastest pace in five months. Retail sales gained 16.4 percent, the biggest increase since May 2004 after adjusting for Lunar New Year distortions.

title: More Jitters Over Credit; Markets Fall
description: Stocks fell sharply late yesterday afternoon, and one broad market index turned negative for the year as investors again questioned the economys ability to withstand financial shocks and higher borrowing costs.

title: Room to Improve
description: Q. How can I make my new apartment feel older?

title: Macys Beats Profit Estimates, but Lowers Earnings Forecast
description: Macys Inc., the department store chain, reported quarterly profit yesterday that exceeded analysts estimates but lowered its earnings forecast because of sluggish sales.

title: Newcomer Chosen for Wi-Fi in 2 Counties
description: HAUPPAUGE, N.Y., Aug. 15  A $150 million plan to make wireless broadband available across Nassau and Suffolk Counties, covering 750 square miles and nearly three million residents, took a major step forward on Wednesday when Long Island officials chose a company for the project.

title: New Home Construction at Lowest Level in  Decade
description: As more fallout from the mortgage market squeeze became apparent today, there was yet another sign that the worst of the trauma in the housing sector may not be over.

title: This Summer, a Bumper Crop of Collars
description: A FASHION watcher might look back on the last decade and, in summation, tick off names like Hedi Slimane and Nicolas Ghesquiere and trends like the skinny suit. But even someone who claims not to follow fashion would have to have noticed how one look came to rule summertime mens wear.

title: Start Spearing the News
description: Perhaps youve seen Will Durst, the political humorist, doing sound-bite commentary on television, trying to riff on questions from some stiff anchor or talk-show host, and your reaction has been, This guys kind of drab. But thats not the real Will Durst. The guy now cracking people up for 90 minutes at New World Stages in a sharp one-man show: thats the real Will Durst.

title: An American in the World Cup Is Dreaming Big
description: Whenever an American soccer team goes off to play in the World Cup, I receive eloquent letters from rugby aficionados, asking, When are you going to write about us?

title: The Less-Than-Generous State
description: You would think that we were living in the lap of the Nanny State. One of the most puzzling facts of the political debate is how much traction Republicans still get from their calls to cut taxes and public spending, and how timorous Democrats are in arguing against them.

title: The Routers Fine Print
description: Q. Why does all the fine print on the newest, fastest network routers say draft specification? What does this mean if I want to buy a new router?

title: Rove Steps Up His Attacks on Clintons Candidacy
description: Karl Rove intensified his attack on Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton Tuesday, saying she lacked the vision to be president while saying she was so weak on national security and support for the armed forces.

title: My Dad, American Inventor
description: TOMMY HABEEB just wanted to be one of the new breed of involved dads: the hands-on guys who preside over bath time without creating a flood; the ones who return home from work early enough to crawl after their children toward the realm of make-believe. His ambitions did not include inventing the Water Bottle Nipple Adaptor.

title: Forced to Pick a Major in High School
description: ENGLEWOOD, N.J.  Ninth graders often have trouble selecting what clothes to wear to school each morning or what to have for lunch. But starting this fall, freshmen at Dwight Morrow High School here in Bergen County must declare a major that will determine what electives they take for four years and be noted on their diplomas.

title: An Adviser at the Edge of a Scandal Vows to Stay at Spitzers Right Hand
description: The top deputy to Gov. Eliot Spitzer said yesterday that he could remain effective in his job, even as some Democrats quietly question whether his continued role in the administration is hurting the governor.

title: Economic Boom Fails to Generate Optimism in India
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 15  Prime Minister Manmohan Singh cautioned Indians against hubris in his annual Independence Day speech on Wednesday and promised a spate of antipoverty measures that hinted at the vulnerabilities facing his government and the nation.

title: N.B.A. Referee Pleads Guilty to Gambling Charges
description: Tim Donaghy left the basketball court as a disgraced former N.B.A. referee in July and left a federal court room yesterday as an admitted criminal, a conspirator and a gambling addict.

title: The Streets of Queens Where Rizzuto Played
description: When Phil Rizzuto was a boy in Glendale, Queens, it was rare to get your hands on an actual baseball. You played with Spaldeens wrapped in string, or flapping old cores patched with adhesive tape, and if the ball rolled into the sewer the boys went down after it.

title: Jose Padilla Convicted on All Counts in Terror Trial
description: MIAMI, Aug. 16  In a major victory for the Bush administration, a federal jury here found Jose Padilla guilty on terrorism conspiracy charges Thursday after little more than a day of deliberations.

title: Near Misses on Ground Prompt New Use of Cockpit Simulators
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15  In a step underscoring that much of the risk of air travel occurs on the ground, airlines have agreed to use their cockpit simulators to train pilots to taxi, the Federal Aviation Administration said Wednesday.

title: Bluetooth and the End of Audio Wiring
description: Here at the Pogue Purely Hypothetical High-Tech Mutual Fund, we recognize that although you cant predict the future of technology, a few calls are easy to make. Right now, for example, there are certain industries we avoid investing in  like analog recording tape, landline telephone service and wires.

title: CIRCUITS: A Way to See DVDs in (Almost) High Definition, Without Choosing a Format
description: No one knows when the battle between the HD-DVD and Blu-ray video formats will end, but whats an early adopter to do without ending up like the poor folks who bought Betamax? Until one format is the clear winner, you could try improving the video from your current DVDs instead.

title: Long-Studied Giant Star Displays Huge Cometlike Tail
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15  Astronomers have discovered that a giant star that has been studied for centuries is streaking across the sky trailing an enormous, cometlike tail.

title: Jenna Bush Is Engaged
description: CRAWFORD, Tex., Aug. 16  President Bush, who has been the sole male in his nuclear family with the exception, perhaps, of his dog Barney, will finally have a son-in-law.

title: Newark: Shooting Victim Dies
description: A man who had been shot died about 8:30 last night after the car he was driving crashed into a fence at Clinton and Seymour Avenues in Newark, the Newark police said. His car also hit two pedestrians, whose conditions were not released. The man, whose identity was not released, was dead when the police arrived. His cause of death had yet to be determined.

title: Bigger. Stronger. Better?
description: In America, the next generation of women soccer players move in virtual anonymity, not yet household names like Hamm and Foudy, members of the team that enthralled the country with their play in the 1999 World Cup. That doesnt mean the younger players are slouches. In this issues The Main Event, Jer Longman reports that the U.S. team heading to China for next months World Cup "is deeper, more of a threat to score from midfield and more sophisticated in a soccer sense than the 99 team. But until the team wins a World Cup, is it possible to call it the best U.S. squad ever?

title: Agilent Shares Drop on Forecast
description: Shares of Agilent Technologies, the maker of scientific testing equipment, fell in trading yesterday in New York after slowing demand in Asia reduced the companys sales and profit forecasts.

title: Before Halloween, This Witch Is Closed for the Season
description: MONTAUK, N.Y.

title: Finds a Home
description: Beaufort Books, a small publisher in New York, will publish If I Did It, the controversial account by O. J. Simpson, below, of the slaying of his ex-wife, Nicole Brown Simpson, and her friend Ronald Goldman, The Associated Press reported. HarperCollins, the original publisher, had dropped the book because of public outrage. Sharlene Martin of Martin Literary Management in Los Angeles announced the deal, but Denise Brown, Nicole Brown Simpsons sister, immediately called for a boycott of the work. The book will consist of Mr. Simpsons original manuscript with commentary, said Michael Wright, a spokesman for Ms. Martin. The Goldmans, the publisher and Ms. Martin will contribute portions of the sales proceeds to the newly formed Ron Goldman Foundation for Justice to help victims of violent crime, Mr. Wright said. Last month a federal bankruptcy judge awarded rights to the book to Mr. Goldmans family to help satisfy a $38 million wrongful-death judgment against Mr. Simpson.

title: A Connecticut Hillside of Feisty Beauties
description: SOUTH KENT, Conn.

title: Dramatic Warning to a Candidate
description: The blond helmet of hair is unmistakable. So, too, are the black pants, the peach-colored vest and the tiny cross dangling from her neck. And then there are the familiar flashes of sarcasm and self-righteousness, of practicality and compassion, and the rejoinders about Republicans like this bit of dialogue:

title: Muslim Groups Oppose a List of Co-Conspirators
description: Two prominent Muslim American organizations took steps yesterday to reverse what they called a Justice Department effort to smear the entire Muslim community by naming some of its largest organizations as unindicted co-conspirators in a Texas terrorism trial.

title: For Couples, a Matter of Give and Take
description: ADAM FORD, mild-mannered and trim at 170 pounds, doesnt feel odd hitting his petite wife. How else will she learn to instinctively duck or perfect her combinations?

title: Russia: Sale of Some Yukos Assets
description: The Russian court-appointed managers of Yukos, the oil company, sold its contested overseas assets at a bankruptcy auction for $306 million, taking another step toward the final dismantling of Yukos. As in previous sales, the property went to a little-known company for far less than its nominal value The buyer was a Russian real estate firm, Monte-Valle, which is owned by an American businessman, Stephen Lynch, who has worked in Russia for more than 10 years. Most of the oil fields, machinery and other Yukos assets inside Russia have already been sold. Outside of Russia, what remains of Yukos, once the countrys largest private company, is consolidated in a Netherlands-registered foundation that Yukos shareholders say controls roughly 2 billion euros ($2.7 billion) in cash and equities; the foundation is under the supervision of a Dutch bankruptcy court. The sale sets the stage for a complex and high-stakes legal struggle in the Netherlands between Mr. Lynch and former Yukos shareholders, who argue that the Russian bankruptcy process is illegitimate.

title: CARE Turns Down Federal Funds for Food Aid
description: MALELA, Kenya  CARE, one of the worlds biggest charities, is walking away from some $45 million a year in federal financing, saying American food aid is not only plagued with inefficiencies, but also may hurt some of the very poor people it aims to help.

title: Facing the Multiple Risks of Newer, Deeper Mines
description: As hope dims for the six miners trapped by a coal mine collapse in central Utah, engineers and seismologists are grappling with the broader implications of the Crandall Canyon Mine accident and the interplay of risks they say are mounting in the newer, deeper generation of coal mines, especially in the West.

title: Floyd Landis, the Outcast
description: In her profile of Floyd Landis, "The Outcast," in the latest issue of PLAY, Sara Corbett paints a poignant picture of the cyclist, who lives in limbo while awaiting a ruling from the arbitration panel that is reviewing his doping case from last years Tour de France. Corbett answered a few of our questions about what she found in her reporting.

title: Wiring the Frog, or Personal Tales From the Electronic Present
description: A year and a half ago, I began an editorial essay like this one with these words: I do not own a BlackBerry or a pager. I dont chat or instant-message or text-message. My cellphone could connect to the Web if I let it, but I dont. The essay went on to talk about the addiction of e-mail, as if that were somehow a racy new form of interhuman conversation. What an idiot.

title: On Itunes
description: All of John Lennons solo albums are available on iTunes for the first time, after Yoko Ono, Lennons widow, approved a deal, BBC News reported yesterday. Many of the recordings had already been on sale through other digital stores, but Lennon Legend and Acoustic were not legally available online. The deal, which may pave the way for the entire Beatles catalog to appear online, follows a similar one with Paul McCartney in May.

title: Astors Guardians Challenge Her Later Wills, Citing Incompetency
description: The court-appointed guardians of Brooke Astor have filed legal papers saying that the will she signed in 1997 should be the valid one. They argue that she was not mentally competent or was unduly influenced when she signed her last will in 2002 and several amendments to it over the following two years, according to people who have been briefed on the situation.

description: The billionaire Paul G. Allen may try to buy or recapitalize Charter Communications, the cable company he controls, according to a regulatory filing yesterday.

description: In a change of plans, astronauts aboard the space shuttle Endeavour will spend today studying plans for conducting a repair of the shuttle.

title: Max Roach, a Founder of Modern Jazz, Dies at 83
description: Max Roach, a founder of modern jazz who rewrote the rules of drumming in the 1940s and spent the rest of his career breaking musical barriers and defying listeners expectations, died early today in Manhattan. He was 83.

description: Gary Sheffield looked relaxed and in his environment. He wore a Detroit Tigers T-shirt, he crossed his arms and stood in front of his locker in Cleveland like a preacher by his pulpit. The words kept flowing, more opinions, more statements, more Sheffield.

title: Albany: Questions on Aid Package
description: Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky, left, a Westchester County Democrat, said yesterday that the terms of an aid package that federal officials offered this week for broad traffic reduction measures in New York City fall short of what is required under state law. Mr. Brodsky, who wrote an Assembly report critical of the plan, wrote a letter to Transportation Secretary Mary E. Peters yesterday asking for a clarification of the terms of the $354 million package. The aid is contingent on the states approval of a pilot program to carry out Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs most controversial proposal, which would charge drivers for entering the most congested parts of Manhattan on weekdays. Mr. Brodsky said a new state law that sets up a commission to study the mayors plan required a firm commitment of $200 million from federal officials by October. His comments and letter underscored continuing opposition in the Democrat-led Assembly. A spokesman for Speaker Sheldon Silver, who has expressed concerns about the plan, had no comment.

title: Parents Warned Cough Medicines Imperil Infants
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15  Hoping to halt the growing number of injuries to infants and toddlers, the Food and Drug Administration issued an advisory Wednesday warning parents never to give cough and cold medicines to children under the age of 2 unless instructed to do so by a doctor.

title: Bruce Wolmer, Editor and Art World Explainer, Dies at  59
description: Bruce Wolmer, the longtime editor and publisher of Art & Auction magazine and an expert on the heavily moneyed byways of the international art world, died in New York on Saturday. He was 59 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Bronx: E.M.S. to Replace Firehouse
description: A new emergency medical station will replace an old firehouse in Woodlawn that was closed last year because of structural problems, city officials said yesterday. Firefighters from Ladder Company 39 moved from their station at 243 East 233rd Street in June 2006 because of the buildings poor condition, city officials said. The ladder company is now based about a mile away, sharing quarters with Engine Company 63. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that the city would begin construction of a new station for emergency medical workers on the site in the fall of 2008. The new $12.4 million station will allow ambulances that are now based at three stations to operate out of one.

description: CHENGDU, China, Aug. 9  A highly infectious swine virus is sweeping Chinas pig population, driving up pork prices and creating fears of a global pandemic among domesticated pigs.

description: HONG KONG, Aug. 15  Chinas government said Wednesday that it was cracking down on false news reports, unauthorized publications and bogus journalists.

description: GYEGU, China  With the polish of veteran television M.C.s, the slick, Chinese-speaking announcers used every trick in the book to try to get a largely Tibetan crowd of a few hundred people involved in the singing and dancing on stage.

title: Offerman Charged With Assault After Bat-Wielding Incident in Minors
description: For 15 years, Jos Offerman played for seven major league teams, primarily as an infielder, earning as much as $6.75 million in 2001 and in 2002. Since May, he has been playing for the Long Island Ducks of the independent Atlantic League, earning less than $4,000 a month and hoping that at age 38 he could get back to the big leagues.

This dock lets users attach an iPod to a sound system, operate the iPod with a remote and see its menus on a TV screen. For good measure, it will also let you connect your computer to the stereo wirelessly and listen to Internet radio.

description: The September issue of PLAY comes out this Sunday, distributed inside The New York Times and online at nytimes.com/playmagazine. In this issue of the newsletter, a little peak at what youll find.

title: The Legacy of the Raj: Adrift in Two Cultures
description: As far as the worlds concerned, were not here, never were, says Owen Monroe, the hero of Glen Duncans new novel The Bloodstone Papers. Owen is an Anglo-Indian of mixed Indian and European descent. Hes a disaffected legacy of colonialism, a Half-caste, as he puts it, a Mongrel, a Pariah, a Cheechee, a Chutney Mary. The son of immigrant parents, Owen lives in London where hes a part-time college professor and pornographer writing under the delightful name of Millicent Nash.

description: The Israel Lobby and U.S. Foreign Policy is not even in bookstores, but already anxieties have surfaced about the backlash it is stirring, with several institutions backing away from holding events with the authors.

title: Pools Conceived to Make a Splash
description: NICOLE SASSAMAN, a 36-year-old designer and property developer, devoted three years to building the swimming pool of her dreams at her home in the Hollywood Hills. A 25-foot expanse of glittering blue and green glass tile from Italy, the pool, completed last year, cantilevers out from a steep hillside and hugs the 5,500-square-foot house  once Greta Garbos  so closely that the house appears to float on a sliver of blue. In the evening, the twinkling cityscape of Los Angeles is reflected in the water, which seems to drop off into the hills below.

title: A Cellphone for Those With a Modest Need to Send Messages
description: The Samsung Blast is part of a new breed of cellphones: messaging phones. Like the iPhone and the Helio Ocean, these phones arent aimed at the dedicated smartphone user or BlackBerry-loving business user. They are intended for people who need a little e-mail, a little instant messaging and not much else.

In one episode, the psychologist denies treatment to a severely depressed patient who later commits suicide.

title: New York Film Festival Lineup
description: Persepolis, an animated work based on Marjane Satrapis graphic novel about her childhood in Iran during the Islamic revolution (a scene from the film is above), will be the closing-night film at the 45th New York Film Festival. This year, the festival, presented by the Film Society of Lincoln Center, runs from Sept. 28 to Oct. 14 and is to include 28 premieres. The previously announced opening-night and centerpiece selections are The Darjeeling Limited, by Wes Anderson, and No Country for Old Men, by Joel and Ethan Coen. New American films by Noah Baumbach, Gus Van Sant, Todd Haynes and Sidney Lumet will be shown, as will international productions by Julian Schnabel and Abel Ferrara. The directors Brian De Palma, John Landis and Ira Sachs will make their festival debuts. Among the foreign films are: The Orphanage, by Juan Antonio Bayona; A Girl Cut in Two, by Claude Chabrol; and The Flight of the Red Balloon, by Hou Hsiao-hsien. Five older films will be included, among them the long-awaited definitive cut of Blade Runner by Ridley Scott. Screenings will take place at the Frederick P. Rose Hall, home of Jazz at Lincoln Center, and other sites. For information: filmlinc.com.

title: German Police Link 6 Dead Men to an Italian Mob Feud
description: FRANKFURT, Aug. 15  A bitter feud between rival southern Italian crime families erupted on the streets of a northern German city early Wednesday morning, as the police in Duisburg found the bullet-riddled bodies of five Italian men in two vehicles.

title: Iraq Toll at 250 in the Deadliest Attack of the War
description: BAGHDAD, Aug. 15  The toll in a horrific quadruple bombing in an area of mud and stone houses in the remote northern desert on Tuesday evening reached at least 250 dead and 350 wounded, several local officials said Wednesday, making it the deadliest coordinated attack since the American-led invasion of Iraq in 2003.

title: A Mayor Stands by His Comments, and Gay Advocates Stand Against Him
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Aug. 15  The uproar began last month, when Mayor Jim Naugle said that installing a single-occupancy restroom on a local beach could deter homosexual activity.

title: Mexico: Northbound Migrants Stranded
description: At least 3,000 Central American migrants remained stranded along railroad lines in southern Mexico after an American train operator shut down its operations there, officials said. For decades, immigrants from Guatemala have crossed a river into southern Mexico and hopped freight trains going north, but the rail operator, Genessee and Wyoming Inc., based in Connecticut, decided last month to cease its operations. Now at least 2,500 people are camped out along the tracks in Tenosique, in Tabasco State, and hundreds more are stranded in Arriaga, in Chiapas. They have been waiting in vain for more than 18 days for a train that will no longer arrive. Guatemalan consular officials in Tabasco say hundreds of migrants have decided to continue their journey on foot and walk more than 200 miles to the next terminus, in Villahermosa. The same was true in Chiapas, with hundreds trying to walk to Oaxaca State, according to church officials who run shelters there.

title: Above the Clouds, Its Almost Heaven, Costa Rica
description: CERRO DE LA MUERTE, Costa Rica  It had been raining for two weeks in San Jos, Costa Rica, when I heard from Peter Gorinsky. We had planned to go fishing along the countrys Caribbean coast, but the forecast was hopeless.

description: If nothing else, the rainstorm last week that left millions of commuters in the dark about the whereabouts of their trains and buses reinforced the idea that riders can never have too much information.

title: The Osmonds Rock On
description: The Osmond Brothers joined with their siblings Donny, Marie and Jimmy to tape a 50th-anniversary reunion show this week to be shown on PBS next year, The Associated Press reported yesterday. A gathering of seven Osmonds onstage has not occurred in more than 20 years. The PBS concert celebrates the anniversary of the founding of the original Osmond Brothers barbershop quartet  with Alan, Wayne, Merrill and Jay Osmond  in 1957. The Osmonds have recorded 142 albums and sold 100 million copies.

title: Rizzutos Fans Post Tributes and Recount Funny Moments
description: To his fans, Phil Rizzuto was a warm-hearted personality who charmed them during chance encounters, kept them company in their living rooms and on their picnics, and elicited smiles with his idiosyncratic one-liners, loopy conversations, fear of lightning and love of cannolis.

title: Russia: Student Held Over Execution Video
description: The police arrested a student they said had confessed to posting on the Internet a grisly video of two young men apparently being executed in front of a Nazi flag. The student, who the authorities said had turned himself in, was in custody in the southwestern city of Maikop and under investigation for inciting racial hatred. The police said that it did not appear that he was involved in making the video or the gruesome acts it showed. The video, which includes images of a man being beheaded, began circulating on Sunday and has called attention to racism and neo-fascism in Russia. An introduction to the video said one victim was from Tajikistan and the other from Dagestan.

title: Russia: Bombed Rail Line Reopened
description: Russia restored full rail service on the line between Moscow and St. Petersburg, which had been suspended after a bomb derailed a passenger train on Monday. More than 60 people were injured. The authorities continued to investigate, saying they had made sketches of two suspects seen near the tracks before the bomb, described as a homemade device, exploded under the locomotive. Various theories were being explored, the authorities said, including that Chechen separatists or ultranationalists were involved.

description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 15  One of the more popular phrases uttered within the Mets clubhouse this season is if only. As in, if only the Mets had played more consistently, they could be romping, not plodding, toward a division title. If only the Braves or Phillies had done the same, the Mets know they could be toiling behind either team.

title: Trenton: Accord on Tracing Guns
description: Police departments in New Jersey will be able to trace gun ownership almost instantly through a federal-state agreement announced yesterday. The agreement provides the New Jersey State Police with round-the-clock access to e-Trace, a nationwide computer database of firearms purchases operated by the United States Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives. The agreement, which is meant to help the police identify sources of illegal weapons, calls for each police department in the state to send gun-tracing information to the database. Just under a third of the states police departments had submitted tracing information to e-Trace, and it was not readily available to the authorities in other jurisdictions. Last year, nearly 5,000 people in New Jersey were arrested for possessing illegal firearms.

title: Whats on Tonight
description: 8:30 P.M. (WAPA America) PUERTO RICO NATIONAL BASKETBALL TOURNAMENT In this pre-Olympic tournament broadcast live over three nights from San Juan, the Puerto Rico national basketball team will face off against teams from Canada (tonight), Brazil (tomorrow) and Argentina (Saturday), including 12 N.B.A. players representing their home countries. (Above, Joel Jones of Puerto Rico.) The games will be broadcast on DirecTV (Channel 414). In 2004 Puerto Rico defeated the United States team in Athens in the most lopsided basketball loss in Olympic history. This year Puerto Rico advanced to the finals of the Pan American games before losing to Brazil.

title: Just Live, Baby!

For four decades, with quick offensive strikes, colorful players and muscular catchphrases, Davis led the most successful team in football. The league has caught up with him in recent years, and the Raiders -- like his 78-year-old body -- are in grim condition. Davis may be able to emerge every now and then to declare that reports of his death are greatly exaggerated, Curtis writes. But Daviss personality-driven football is dead.

title: Countrywides Big Credit Draw Fuels Market Fears
description: Stocks fell sharply Wednesday in the United States, set off by worries that Countrywide Financial, the largest mortgage lender in the nation, could face bankruptcy if liquidity worsens after a Merrill Lynch analyst flagged that possibility. The mood grew even more grim Thursday morning, when the lender said it tapped its entire $11.5 billion credit line to boost cash on hand.

description: Thomas & Betts, which makes electrical connectors and components, said late Wednesday it is buying a Cleveland-based supplier, Lamson & Sessions, for about $426.6 million.

title: Sal Oppenheim Takes Larger Stake in IKB
description: Sal Oppenheim said on Wednesday that it has raised its stake in IKB, the German bank beset by subprime-related woes, to 5 percent. In a statement, Sal Oppenheim, a private bank, said its purchase would reinforce its strategic partnership with IKB.

title: Kraft Said to Be Shopping Post Cereal Business

title: Schumer May Propose Partnership-Tax Bill
description: Charles Schumer, the Democratic senator from New York, is preparing legislation that would raise tax rates for partnerships in all industries, and not just in the private equity business. A spokesman said this approach would be fairer than current proposals being considered in Congress.

title: Morning Buzz: A Tax Break for Parking, High School Majors, Astor Will Dispute, and More
description: The United States Department of Transportation doled out $848 million in grants this week to mitigate traffic and reduce congestion in five cities, including New York. But as William Neuman points out, the government still seems to be sending mixed signals about driving to work. Nearly 400,000 commuters nationwide  about half of them in the New York City area  take advantage of a federal tax provision that allows them to use up to $215 a month in pre-tax wages to pay for their parking at work.(More than two million people around the country take advantage of a similar program that allows them to use pre-tax income to pay for transit expenses, but that benefit is capped at $110 a month.)

title: Notes on the News: Mayhem Moment
description: Mayhem is always in the mix in the morning news, but today its downright dominating. The lede story on many major news sites is the 7.9-magnitude earthquake centered near the capital of Peru. Initial reports from the region signal a death toll measured in the hundreds, such as this account from the mayor of Pisco reported by The Associated Press:

title: Translation of the Document
description: The following is a translation of what appears to be a memo under the letterhead of the Committee for National Security, the Kazakh intelligence service, to President Nursultan A. Nazarbayev outlining steps agents took in the 2005 presidential elections to influence the judgments of international election observers and public opinion. The document was passed to European diplomats this summer from a source with connections to Kazakh intelligence. Its authenticity could not be determined, and a Kazakh diplomat in Washington called it a "fake." The document was translated by a diplomat in Europe.

title: Deutsche Bank Demolition
description: What was the New York base of Deutsche Bank on Sept. 11, 2001, when it was badly damaged by debris from the World Trade Center, is now being painstakingly dismantled.

title: Big Mama: The New Vogue
description: The September Vogue landed on my desk, or rather, on the floor. It came in a freight box. Its very fat: 840 pages. Sienna Miller is on the cover of this super-duper issue, photographed by Mario Testino in Rome during the Valentino festivities. Though I cant comprehend her appeal, apart from an American pixy-sportiness, she looks great in the clothes, mostly feathered things. My favorite fashion piece is Grace Coddingtons revisit with Kiki de Montparnasse and French caf society in the 20s and 30s, photographed by Meisel. The clothes are right this season for a Jazz Age revue, especially Gallianos and Chanels. (And perfect timing for Making It New: The Art and Style of Sara and Gerald Murphy, a great collection of essays and photographs of the period from University of California Press.)

description: The number of New Jersey schools that failed to meet the standards of the federal No Child Left Behind law fell in 2007, as many students managed to increase their scores on achievement tests, according to data the state is releasing today.

They are mostly lesbians as well, which I find interesting.

title: 10 Firms Bail Out Canadas Commercial Paper Market
description: Amid fears of a spreading crisis in Canadas debt market, 10 firms, including Quebecs pension fund, said Thursday that they had agreed to bail out the 40 billion Canadian dollars ($37.4 billion) market for third-party asset-backed commercial paper. All told, the group, led by Caisse de Depot et Placement, will hold about two-thirds of the Canadian market for such commercial paper.

Pirro - justified her decision by saying, The principles of the Democratic Party are closely aligned with my views. She also took the opportunity to announce her plans to run for re-election in 2009.

title: Fifth Third to Acquire First Charter

Cincinnati-based Fifth Third said it would pay $31 in cash and stock per First Charter share, a healthy 53 percent premium over the targets closing stock price Wednesday.

Not least of these are Countrywides shareholders, including Barclays and Legg Mason, who would most likely lose their entire stakes. And then there are the 40 banks providing an $11.5 billion credit line to Countrywide, which the company said Thursday it had completely drawn down.

title: Riding Scooters and Carrying BlackBerrys, the Inspectors Are Coming
description: The citys newest team of inspectors will not issue tickets or fines. They wont harass landlords over leaky pipes or ensure that builders are following city codes. No, the focus of the Street Conditions Observation Unit - or Scout, for short - will be the city itself.Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg unveiled the 15-member unit today. Its mission is to cruise the city streets looking for potholes, clogged catch basins, damaged bus shelters, even homeless people. The inspectors will ride along in small three-wheeled vehicles  powered by gasoline and resembling golf carts  that the city is calling scooters.

title: Skypes Bad Day
description: The massively popular Internet phone service Skype has been down all morning. Its Web site says that engineers have discovered a software problem which will be fixed in 12 to 24 hours. That is a disastrously long time for a service that eBay, owner of Skype, has been pitching as a core business communication tool to companies and stay-at-home professionals. In fact last year, eBay itself revealed it would begin weaning itself off landlines and instead use Skype as its primary phone service. Not surprisingly, Ive been unable to raise anyone at eBay all morning.

title: Elvis Is Everywhere

Just one look at the Elvis Sighting Bulletin Board proves that point: News is being generated beyond all reason. Of course, Elvis worship is not about reason; its about love. And in the year 2007, that love is being spread in the great snow globe that is the Web. And yes, its all shook up today, the 30th anniversary of his death.

Marshall, and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg will speak at the service, which will follow the burial proceedings outlined in the 1928 edition of the Book of Common Prayer.

Ashcroft. According to one account, two White House aides asked him to approve a controversial domestic spying program, but he refused in dramatic fashion, lifting his head off his pillow and expressing himself in very strong terms.

description: Liam Rector, a well-regarded poet and educator whose work appeared in many distinguished publications, shot himself on Wednesday morning at his home in Greenwich Village. He was 57.

It occupies a small space on the second floor of a walk-up that it shares with another theater and a school on an artist-rich block just above the Lower East Side. The playhouse, under its artistic director, Alex Roe, explores America and American literature by producing old American plays, new ones based on old literary sources, and plays specifically about the city and the neighborhood.

title: Parts Supplier Pleads Guilty to Fraud
description: An owner of a small South Carolina parts supplier pleaded guilty to fraud after collecting about $20.5 million over six years from the Pentagon for fraudulent costs, including $998,798 for sending two 19-cent washers to an Army base in Texas. Cynthia Stroot, a Pentagon investigator, said the supplier, C&D Distributors in Lexington, S.C., exploited a flaw in an automated Defense Department purchasing system: bills for shipping to combat areas or American bases that were labeled priority were usually paid automatically. A federal judge in Columbia, S.C., accepted the guilty plea of the owner, Charlene Corley, to one count of conspiracy to commit wire fraud and one count of conspiracy to launder money.

title: Australia: Qantas Reports a Jump in Profit
description: Qantas Airways, Australias biggest airline, said second-half profit almost tripled and announced plans to buy back 10 percent of its stock. Net income in the six months ended June 30 rose to 361.1 million Australian dollars ($299 million) from 127.4 million Australian dollars a year earlier, the company said. Qantas, based in Sydney, forecast pretax profit would rise 30 percent this fiscal year. The chief executive, Geoffrey J. Dixon, said the airline might sell or spin off its freight, holiday and air miles units, adopting strategies proposed by the Macquarie Bank-led buyout group that made a bid of 11.1 billion Australian dollars in May. The chairwoman, Margaret Jackson, above, who will leave in November after being criticized for her support of the buyout, said the company would spend about a billion Australian dollars buying back 10 percent of its stock.

title: Where Concept of a Pet Rock Has Reached Its Apex
description: HYDERABAD, India  They rise unexpectedly between glass office towers or at the base of a 12th-century fort. Sometimes they are perched precariously, one on top of another, as though they were the left-behind playthings of a civilization of giants. More and more, they are broken into bits, first by dynamite, then painstakingly by hand, so that the earth can be flattened and new office towers can come up.

title: Aide to Ex-Representative Is Given Probation
description: The former chief of staff to former Representative Bob Ney was ordered to serve two years probation for his role in the corruption scandal surrounding the lobbyist Jack Abramoff. The man, William Heaton, 29, left, who often served as Mr. Neys contact with Mr. Abramoff, must also perform 100 hours of community service and pay a $5,000 fine, Judge Ellen Segal Huvelle said in Federal District Court. Mr. Heaton pleaded guilty to one count of conspiracy in February. Prosecutors did not seek a prison term for Mr. Heaton, who cooperated with them by taping conversations with his boss. Mr. Ney, an Ohio Republican, is serving a prison term of two and a half years.

description: WHAT Lakefront resort and residential development.

title: A Good Deed Is Rewarded, With a Catch
description: Brooke Astor, whose 105 years will be celebrated at her funeral today, donated a fair chunk of change to the New York Public Library. That gave her something in common with Ruth Cooper Jacobs, practically a kid by comparison at 98. Ms. Jacobs also sends money to the library, pretty much every year.

title: Bogus Diabetes Test Strips Traced to Chinese Distributor
description: A global hunt started by Johnson & Johnson has tracked to China some counterfeit versions of the test strips used by 10 million Americans to measure their blood sugar levels.

title: Michigan: Suit Over Rules About Ships Water Is Dismissed
description: A federal judge in Detroit dismissed a lawsuit brought by a coalition of shipping interests challenging a Michigan law intended to curb the introduction of invasive species into the Great Lakes. The law, enacted earlier this year, requires all oceangoing ships sailing into Michigan ports to obtain permits showing that the vessels will not discharge ballast water, which is held in the ballast tanks or cargo holds of ships to provide stability, into Michigan waters, or, if they do plan to discharge the water, that it will first be treated to remove any non-native species. On Wednesday, the judge, John Feikens of Federal District Court, rejected the shipping coalitions claim that the law was unconstitutional. Judge Feikens wrote that invasive species posed a serious threat to the states environment.

title: Former Spitzer Nominee Is Said to Be Investigated
description: ALBANY, Aug. 16  The state inspector general is investigating Gov. Eliot Spitzers recent nominee for chairwoman of the Public Service Commission, according to a former aide to Mr. Spitzer who met with investigators.

title: The Savvy Operator Who Aced That Newfangled Art Form, Opera
description: The 1950 book on Claudio Monteverdi by Leo Schrade, a penetrating study of a pivotal composer, is flawed only by its hyped-up title, Monteverdi: Creator of Modern Music. Monteverdi, the Italian master born in Cremona in 1567, loomed over the uneasy transition from the musical Renaissance to the Baroque. But the creator of modern music?

title: Things That Go Burble in the Night
description: The eerie suggestiveness of the French-Romanian fright flick Them  an almost-real-time thriller, set in and around a besieged house in the woods  seems less old-fashioned than classical. The movie revels in atmosphere, using long unbroken takes and ambient sound (crickets, wind) to lull you into complacency before unleashing nerve-jangling shocks.

title: At Asian Security Meeting, Russian and Iranian Criticize the U.S.
description: BISHKEK, Kyrgyzstan, Aug. 16  Iran used the meeting of a regional security organization here on Thursday to lash out at American plans for a missile defense shield, while President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia took an indirect swipe at what he calls Washingtons unilateral foreign policy.
