description: The State Ethics Commission tightened rules yesterday on the use of state aircraft by public officials, the first concrete change to emerge after a scathing report issued by the attorney generals office last month.

title: Death n Yucks, Hallucinogens n Stiff Upper Lips
description: Theres no dearth of rude humor on screens right now, but Death at a Funeral stands apart because its characters  mostly reserved upper-middle-class British folk who have gathered to bury a patriarch  are determined to keep a stiff upper lip no matter what. Thats no small feat when one of the mourners has ingested a psychedelic drug and another is secretly holding a would-be blackmailer hostage in a room mere meters from where the body lies in state.

title: Now, the Clicking Is to Watch the Ads, Not Skip Them
description: FOR generations, advertising interrupted the entertainment that Americans wanted to read, hear or watch. Now, in a turnabout, advertising is increasingly being presented as entertainment  and surprisingly, the idea of all ads, all the time, is gaining some favor.

title: Send in the Crowd
description: ANYONE should be able to submit questions using online video, and the public could be invited to vote on which questions should be posed to the candidates.

title: The Peoples Court
description: SOME have argued that the community should be choosing which questions to ask the candidates, while others have said that the community should have a chance to weigh in after the debate. Both are novel, but Im interested in how we get the community to participate during the debate.

title: Good News on the Health of the Yankees Top Pick
description: Andrew Brackman is aware of the pedigree of the young pitchers he joined by signing with the Yankees on Wednesday. The Yankees took Ian Kennedy and Joba Chamberlain before the second round in 2006, and both have progressed rapidly through the farm system.

title: The Padilla Conviction
description: It is hard to disagree with the jurys guilty verdict against Jose Padilla, the accused, but never formally charged, dirty bomber. But it would be a mistake to see it as a vindication for the Bush administrations serial abuse of the American legal system in the name of fighting terrorism.

title: In Newark, Proposing a First Step in Regulating Guns
description: NEWARK, Aug. 16  In the latest in a series of law-enforcement steps following the killing of three people here 12 days ago, Mayor Cory A. Booker unveiled what he called a model ordinance on Thursday that would make it easier for the police to track illegal firearms back to the places where they were purchased.

title: Fed Cuts Lending Rate; Dow Closes Up 233 Points
description: Saying it now feels that the recent disorder in financial markets has raised the risk of an economic downturn, the Federal Reserve today approved a half-percentage point cut in its discount rate on loans to banks. The move sent markets surging on Wall Street and in Europe.

title: Sip and Spin
description: IF this is truly the campaign of the new media, candidates should be required to answer questions only on their cellphone, BlackBerry or other personal digital assistant, so we can size up their personal text message codes, ring tones and thumb-typing skills.

title: Life as High School, This Time on Vacation
description: Theres only so much cutesiness a sane adult can stand close-up, even given how bitter that adult inevitably sounds when bashing a successful commercial venture. Hating a phenomenon like High School Musical no longer makes you appear tasteful. It makes you seem stupid, as if you hated all of market capitalism, or all winners.

title: Queens: Girl Is Struck and Killed
description: A truck driven by a man with a suspended license struck and killed a 13-year-old Queens girl riding a bicycle yesterday afternoon, the police said. The man, Carlos Noriega-Olivia, 36, was driving a 2006 Chevy truck on Junction Boulevard in Corona when he turned right onto 57th Avenue and hit the girl, Carolina Hernandez, who was crossing the intersection on her bike around 4:15 p.m., the police said. The girl was taken to Elmhurst Hospital Center, where she was pronounced dead. Mr. Noriega-Olivia was arrested and charged with driving with a suspended license.

title: Lebanese Elections (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Pop and Rock Listings
description: POP

title: With Markets Moving Wildly, Insight Suffers
description: Twenty-first-century financial markets react with lightning speed to events halfway around the world. Investors in China can immediately see what happened in New York and make trades in London based on the news.

title: Keep Em Coming
description: ASK any kid with a cellphone: When the new media are always on and everything is connected, the truth becomes something you assemble with the help of friends. Imagine if presidential debates were not one-night-on-a-stage affairs, but always on.

title: Albany: Doctor Rankings Questioned
description: Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo sent letters yesterday to two insurance companies raising questions about the ranking systems they use for doctors, his office said. In letters to the companies, Aetna and Cigna HealthCare, Mr. Cuomo said the rankings were confusing for consumers, and he asked for information that would justify the ranking systems. Both companies said they would cooperate with the attorney general. Aetna said its system had a process for doctors to raise concerns and to correct errors in rankings. A spokesman for Cigna said it was reviewing the attorney generals letter and could not directly comment on it, other than to say that Cigna would respond to the request for information.

title: To Warren Buffett, Obama and Clinton Are Both Presidential
description: OMAHA  In the Warren Buffett primary, there is nothing but neutrality when it comes to divining who he believes would make the better Democratic presidential nominee: Hillary Rodham Clinton or Barack Obama.

title: Five Years on, a Musical Revolution Marches in a Different Direction
description: WANTAGH, N.Y., Aug. 15  In 2002 the rap-rock juggernaut Linkin Park set out on the first Projekt Revolution tour. The lineup was meant to bridge the rap-rock divide: it included the veteran hip-hop act Cypress Hill, the nu-metal band Adema, and DJ Z-Trip, known for his cross-genre mash-ups.

title: An Ugly Loss the Mets Hope Is Soon Forgotten
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 16  The Mets may go on to win the division, which would reduce Thursday nights 10-7 loss to the Pirates to just Game No. 120 of 162. But if by chance they do not, and they finish in second place by the slightest of margins, they will remember what they saw and how they felt on an unbearably muggy evening in Western Pennsylvania and wish that it would never, ever happen again.

title: Max Roach, Master of Modern Jazz, Dies at 83
description: Max Roach, a founder of modern jazz who rewrote the rules of drumming in the 1940s and spent the rest of his career breaking musical barriers and defying listeners expectations, died early yesterday in Manhattan. He was 83.

title: Kong-Heads for Life
description: You could get calluses just watching The King of Kong: A Fistful of Quarters, Seth Gordons documentary about two men vying for the high score in Donkey Kong. But even if you didnt lose years of your life to that deviously entertaining Reagan-era arcade game, Mr. Gordons movie still succeeds as a portrait of a subculture: Kong-heads who videotape each game to send to Twin Galaxies, a governing body in Hollywood, Fla., empowered to validate high scores.

title: Panel Hints at Russian Involvement in Fallen Missile in Georgia
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 16  A panel of international military experts concluded in a report released Thursday that a missile found in a field in the Republic of Georgia last week fell from an airplane that flew from Russia into Georgia and then returned to Russia.

title: Greece: Premier Seeks Snap Elections
description: Greeces governing conservatives moved to hold parliamentary elections on Sept. 16, six months ahead of schedule, in the hope of winning a new mandate for their economic and social reforms. We have made steady strides in improving our economy, but more needs to be done, a spokesman for Prime Minister Kostas Karamanlis said after a flurry of meetings between Mr. Karamanlis, above, and senior officials of his cabinet. The spokesman said Mr. Karamanlis would meet today with President Karolos Papoulias, before moving to dissolve Parliament. Mr. Karamanliss New Democracy Party swept to power in national elections in 2004, ousting the Socialists, who had held power for a decade. A series of scandals has caused the partys popularity to slip, with recent opinion polls showing it just slightly ahead of the Socialist Party.

title: Areas of Athens Are Engulfed by Growing Fire
description: ATHENS, Aug. 16  Ferocious flames fanned by gales singed the northern outskirts of Athens on Thursday, destroying homes and causing power failures in the worst forest fire to close in on the Greek capital in a month.

title: 2 Bodies Found at Site of Bridge Collapse
description: Two more victims of the highway bridge collapse in Minneapolis on Aug. 1 were identified today by the Hennepin County Medical Examiners office, leaving two more of the missing to be recovered. Those identified today were Vera Peck, 50, whose son died in the bridge collapse as well, and Christine Sacorafas-Mosher, 45.

title: Stevens and Alaska, a Longtime Partnership
description: ANCHORAGE  Senator Ted Stevens, 83 years old, 39 years in office and all but eternal in the minds of many Alaskans, notwithstanding a couple of prickly months in the spotlight, is home again.

title: Workouts, Not Bailouts
description: In April, Henry Paulson, the Treasury secretary, declared that all the signs he saw indicated that the housing market was at or near the bottom. Earlier this month he was still insisting that problems caused by the meltdown in the market for subprime mortgages were largely contained.

title: Notes Detail Pressure on Ashcroft Over Spying
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16  Notes taken by Director Robert S. Mueller III of the F.B.I. say that Attorney General John Ashcroft was barely articulate, feeble and clearly stressed shortly after a hospital-room meeting in March 2004 in which two top White House aides tried to persuade him to sign an extension for eavesdropping on Americans without warrants.

title: Art in Review
description: SUSANNE M. WINTERLING

title: Advocates Hail Lutheran Act on Gay Clergy Members
description: The countrys largest Lutheran denomination officially bars openly gay people from the ministry. But in a move that advocates for gay men and lesbians are hailing as a step toward changing that policy, the denomination is urging its bishops to refrain from disciplining gay members of the clergy who are in committed same-sex relationships.

title:
Where in the World Is That Exotic

Roof Ornament?
description: A new Web game developed by a museum group encourages children to single out an exotic artifact  a stone sculpture of a Chinese sea monster, a decorated shield from the Solomon Islands, an African mask or a Hopi kachina doll  and then search for its geographic origin, gaining information about the object along the way.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings
description: ART

title: Helpful Hints for Saving the Planet
description: Yeah, yeah, yeah, the environment, blah, blah, blah, melting ice caps. To judge from all the gas-guzzlers still fouling the air and the plastic bottles clogging the dumps, it appears that the news that we are killing ourselves and the world with our greed and garbage hasnt sunk in. Thats one reason The 11th Hour, an unnerving, surprisingly affecting documentary about our environmental calamity, is such essential viewing. It may not change your life, but it may inspire you to recycle that old slogan-button your folks pinned on their dashikis back in the day: If youre not part of the solution, youre part of the problem.

title: Bushes Daughter Jenna Engaged
description: CRAWFORD, Tex., Aug. 16  When Jenna Bush started dating Henry Hager, her mother thought it wasnt serious. Laura Bush even said so in a television interview in February 2005, then went on to describe Mr. Hager as a very nice young man.

title: Cutting Off Terrors Money Supply
description: News this week that the Bush administration is on the verge of adding the Revolutionary Guard Corps of Iran to its ever-expanding list of foreign terrorist organizations  the count stands at 42 undesirables, headlined by Al Qaeda, Hezbollah and Hamas  was not exactly music to the ears of Gary M. Osen, a lawyer on a personal and professional campaign to sue banks that he believes bankroll terrorist activities.

title: The Ascent of a Common Man
description: Pocahontas, Iowa

title: Spare Times
description: AROUND TOWN

title: For Giuliani, Ground Zero as Linchpin and Thorn
description: As Rudolph W. Giuliani campaigns around the country highlighting his stewardship of New York City after the Sept. 11 attacks, he is widely hailed for bringing order to a traumatized city. But he has also raised the hackles of rescue and recovery workers by likening his experience to theirs.

title: Judge Sides With Whole Foods on Deal for Wild Oats
description: In the end, the online ramblings of Rahodeb didnt scuttle the plans of Whole Foods Market to buy Wild Oats Markets.

title: Whats on Tonight
description: 8:30 P.M. (Animal Planet) MEERKAT MANOR Flower mounts a rescue mission to retrieve her pups, which she lost in a scuffle with the Zappas, those new neighbors from hell. Meanwhile Mitch tries to reunite the rest of the Whiskers family and along the way runs into Mozart, who has formed a group of her own with her former beau Carlos.

title: A Crier Spreads the Word About Yesterdays Town
description: EAST HAMPTON, N.Y.

title: Missile That Fell in Georgia Was Russian, Panel Says
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 16  A panel of international military experts concluded in a report released today that a missile found unexploded in a field in the Republic of Georgia last week fell from an airplane that flew from Russia into Georgian airspace and then returned to Russia.

title: NASA Rules Out Repair to Gouge in Shuttle
description: Convinced that a small gouge in the belly of the space shuttle Endeavour poses no danger, NASA managers decided last night not to send astronauts on a spacewalk to repair it.

title: Unbuilding a Skyscraper Wounded on Sept. 11
description: It is, Avi Schick said, like watching a video of a building being built, but in reverse.

title: Wakesurfing: Following the Boat Without a Rope
description: THE surf was up on Lake Charlotte, a 255-acre blue gem among the farm fields west of Minneapolis, and Todd Zaugg was yelling at his son to get into the water: All right, seor, youre on!

title: Giants Think Bigger After the Defensive Line Struggles
description: ALBANY, Aug. 16  It is a training camp of Giants, so a couple of big bodies should not cause a stir. But when two new defensive linemen each weighing nearly 350 pounds, and perhaps more,jogged onto the practice field Thursday, more than the ground shook around the rest of the Giants.

title: For Mario Batali, Its Molto Michigan
description: WATCHING Mario Batali shovel a pizza topped with chopped tomatoes, wet chunks of fresh mozzarella and grilled artichokes into his crackling outdoor pizza oven, it is easy to imagine you are in a hill town outside Bologna, perhaps even in Borgo Capanne, where Mr. Batali apprenticed for three years at a trattoria. The surrounding spruce trees and the wind off the lake only add to the air of authenticity, as does the wood smoke that plumes out from the top of the brick oven and the smell of baking bread.

title: Russia: Industrial Output Slows
description: Russian industrial production growth slowed in July after expanding at the fastest annual rate in two and a half years in June, the Federal Statistics Service said. Output grew at an annual rate of 7.8 percent in July, down from 10.9 percent in June, the Statistics Service said. For the month, output fell 2.7 percent after expanding by 4.5 percent in June. Manufacturing output expanded at an annual rate of 12.5 percent in July, compared with 15.6 percent in June, the statistics office said. Electricity, gas and water output expansion accelerated to an annual 3.3 percent from 2.9 percent in June. Mining and quarrying grew 1.2 percent in July, slower than the 2 percent pace of the previous month.

title: Barbecues Main Events
description: SUMMER is winding down, but theres still plenty of sizzle left in the grill. Right up to Labor Day and beyond, crowds will be clustering around monster cooking pits and savoring the smell of sweet, smoldering mesquite at some of the years biggest barbecue festivals.

An article yesterday about Karl Roves criticism of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton misstated when he made remarks to Reuters that were critical of Ms. Clinton. Those comments were on Tuesday, not Wednesday.

title: Venerable Toronto Exchange Faces a Band of Rivals
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 16  Canada does not look like an obvious place to start another stock exchange. Foreign takeovers, like last years acquisition of the giant nickel mining company Inco, and private equity moves on other companies, notably Bell Canada, have stripped the Toronto Stock Exchange of many large listings.

title: 311 Expands With Scouts to Patrol the Streets
description: The citys newest team of inspectors wont write tickets or issue fines. They wont harass landlords over leaky pipes or ensure that builders follow safety codes. The target of this team will be the city itself.

title: Police at the Convention (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: A New Springsteen Album
description: On Oct. 2 Bruce Springsteen will release Magic, an album on which he reunites with the E Street Band for the first time since the 2002 album The Rising, The Associated Press reported yesterday. The album, which is billed as Mr. Springsteens return to rock n roll, was recorded with the producer Brendan OBrien in Atlanta and includes the guitarists Steve Van Zandt and Nils Lofgren, the bassist Garry Tallent, the drummer Max Weinberg, the keyboardists Danny Federici and Roy Bittan, the saxophonist Clarence Clemons, the violinist Soozie Tyrell and the vocalist Patti Scialfa.

title: Boston Scientific Adds 2 Units to Those It Hopes to Sell
description: Boston Scientific said yesterday that it had added its cardiac and vascular surgery units to the list of businesses it wanted to sell to reduce debt and focus on its core businesses.

title: Italian Police Seek to Avert Full Mob War After 6 Killings
description: ROME, Aug. 16  The police moved on Thursday to head off a full-scale mob war as investigators focused on the theory that one of six Italian men killed Wednesday in Germany had been responsible for the killing last Christmas of the wife of a leader in the Ndrangheta crime group.

title: Spare Times: For Children
description: FOR CHILDREN

An article on Tuesday about the governing party of Turkeys presidential nomination of Abdullah Gul, an economist and practicing Muslim, misstated the number of votes he would need to win confirmation in the 500-seat Parliament if he failed in the first two rounds of voting, when a two-thirds majority, or 367 votes, is required. In a third round, he would need 276 votes, not 267.

title: Queens: Woman Accused of Killing Father
description: A 26-year-old Queens woman accused of killing and mutilating her father last month in her Arverne apartment was arrested last night and charged with murder, the Queens district attorneys office said. For the past few weeks, the woman, Brigitte Harris, a security guard at Kennedy International Airport, has been in a Staten Island psychiatric hospital. She admitted herself there after the bound and gagged body of her father, Eric Goodridge, 55, of Staten Island, was discovered in her third-floor apartment on July 28. She was charged with second-degree murder and first-degree manslaughter. If convicted, she faces up to 25 years to life in prison.

title: Case of Spy vs. Vote Monitor in Kazakhstan? Some Clues Surface
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 16  What appear to be internal documents detailing an exchange between Kazakhstans intelligence service and President Nursultan A. Nazarbayev suggest that Kazakhstan conducted intelligence operations against international monitors during the presidential election in 2005, aimed at swaying the conclusions of the monitors reports.

title: Free Elections? (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Spare Times
description: AROUND TOWN

title: Brooklyn: Woman Killed in Hit-and-Run
description: A 54-year-old Brooklyn woman was killed by a hit-and-run driver early yesterday in East New York, the police said. The woman, Eunice Washington of Brownsville, was with her adult son and daughter at Eldert Lane and Linden Boulevard when one of the three hailed a burgundy four-door sedan for a ride. What followed was unclear, but investigators said the family members got into a dispute with the driver. He then reversed over the curb, striking Ms. Washington, and fled, the police said. The police said the man may have been working as a livery car driver. The car also struck the son, who is 28, but he was not seriously injured, the police said.

title: Ripken Brings Whiff of Majors to Youth Game
description: The youth baseball complex in Aberdeen, Md., that bears the Ripken family name is the ultimate playground for young players.

title: Something Is Very Rotten in the City of So Paulo
description: Manda Bala (Send a Bullet), a flashy documentary about corruption, injustice and frog farming in Brazil, is a weird hybrid of political expos and sensationalistic fluff. As it flip-flops between one mode and the other, it suggests a combination of Darwins Nightmare, the recent deadly serious French documentary about the despoiling of Lake Victoria, and Mondo Cane, the sensationalistic 1962 film that inaugurated a genre of globe-trotting documentary voyeurism.

title: Former Yankee Tones Down Comments as Fans Weigh In
description: Gary Sheffield sat in the Detroit Tigers dugout while the Yankees were completing batting practice. Sheffield started to step onto the field but sat down again for an interview. That decision prevented Sheffield from being near several Yankees players and coaches, something that did not matter to him.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,692 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: A Lakeside Refuge Thats a Lot Closer Than It Feels
description: JUST about 65 miles north of New York City, the town of New Fairfield, Conn., attracts weekend residents drawn to the hush of Lake Candlewood, which was created by the Connecticut Light & Power Company in the 1920s. Today, the lake recharges the psychic batteries of the urban professionals who withdraw to the mid-20th-century cottages that sit on its wooded banks.

title: The Flip-Flop Trail
description: WHO Matt Shepard, 50, a real estate agent from Arlington, Va.

title: At Treasury, the Secretary Waits It Out
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16  What happened to the Hammer?

title: People in the News
description: People

title: Atle Selberg, 90, Lauded Mathematician, Dies
description: Atle Selberg, a mathematician whose theoretical work on the properties of numbers was recognized with the Fields Medal and other major prizes, died Aug. 6 at his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 90.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Tuesday about the governing party of Turkeys presidential nomination of Abdullah Gul, an economist and practicing Muslim, misstated the number of votes he would need to win confirmation in the 500-seat Parliament if he failed in the first two rounds of voting, when a two-thirds majority, or 367 votes, is required. In a third round, he would need 276 votes, not 267. (Go to Article)

An article on Monday about Htein Lin, a Burmese artist and former political prisoner whose paintings depicting incarceration in Myanmar, formerly Burma, are on display in London, misidentified Myanmars capital. It is Naypyidaw, not Yangon, formerly Rangoon. (The military government relocated the capital from Yangon to Naypyidaw, a remote jungle city about 200 miles north of Yangon, in 2006.)

title: Ordinary People With Extraordinary Stories
description: Vividly impressionistic and delightfully curious, Primo Levis Journey retraces the writers arduous return from a newly liberated Auschwitz in January 1945 to his home in Italy more than eight months later.

title: More Fears About China
description: Will Beijings leaders never learn? First, Mattel recalled millions of tainted, Chinese-made toys this week  just the latest scare over Chinese goods that is raising doubts worldwide about doing business with China. Now there are reports that the Chinese government is withholding information on a fast-spreading virus decimating its pig population, much as it tried to cover up the SARS epidemic in 2003.

title: College Ratings Race Roars On Despite Concerns
description: Richard J. Cook, the president of Allegheny College in Pennsylvania, will not say precisely how he used to rate his colleges competitors when the annual U.S. News & World Report peer review questionnaire showed up in his mailbox. What he will say is, I filled it out more honestly this year than I did in the past.

title: Russian Used List of Richest Americans to Find Targets for Theft, Officials Say
description: He was a young man with a big plan: taking aim at rich Americans, with the help of the Forbes 400 list, and robbing their financial accounts by trolling the Internet for information all the way from his base in Moscow, prosecutors in Manhattan said yesterday.

title: A Peruvian City Is Left Devastated by Quake
description: PISCO, Peru, Aug. 17  No area along the southern coast of Peru, which was ravaged by an earthquake that killed at least 510 people, was harder hit than this port city.

title: For Better Health Care (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Castillo Pulls for Polanco to Continue His Streak
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 16  Whenever the Tigers visited Minnesota, Luis Castillo would invite his friend Plcido Polanco to his home for lunch. Polanco would reciprocate when the Twins were in Detroit.

title: Lottery Numbers
Error in Skypes Software Shuts Down Phone Service
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 16  The online telephone service Skype was not working for much of the day on Thursday, leaving its 220 million users, some of them small businesses that had given up their landlines, without a way to call colleagues, customers and friends.

title: Yankees Sign Draft Picks, but Not Ambidextrous Pitcher
description: The Yankees managed to sign several of their top draft picks late Wednesday night, a little before the midnight deadline, for close to $7 million in signing bonuses. One pick they did not corral, however, could have been two players in one: Pat Venditte, the most talented ambidextrous pitcher in college baseball history.

title: Destruction and Tsunami After Plates Collide Again
description: The earthquake that struck off Perus southern coast on Wednesday occurred in one of the worlds most active geological areas, where the South America plate collides with the Nazca plate, which underlies part of the Pacific Ocean.

title: F.B.I. Studies Senators Role in Contract
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16  The F.B.I. is investigating whether Senator Ted Stevens of Alaska had a role in arranging a 1999 government contract worth as much as $70 million for a company that oversaw renovations of his house months later, officials said Thursday.

title: Koreas Extraordinary Send-Offs for Ordinary People
description: The volume of art made throughout history to mourn, commemorate and celebrate death trumps just about every other category. Even so, Korean Funerary Figures: Companions for the Journey to the Other World at the Korea Society is unusual because it presents objects created for ordinary people rather than for aristocrats or the wealthy.

title: Tokyo Stocks Plunge as Asian Slump Persists
description: SINGAPORE, Aug. 17  A deep plunge by stocks in Tokyo led a continued slump by Asian markets today, as the recent turmoil brought on by the housing-loan crisis in the United States sparked a rush to cut losses among investor who have been borrowing yen to invest globally.

title: Singapore Airlines to Receive Superjumbo Plane on Oct. 15
description: PARIS, Aug. 16  Singapore Airlines said Thursday that its first Airbus A380 would be delivered Oct. 15, entering service after a costly two-year delay for the plane, the worlds largest passenger jet.

title: The Jets and the Giants Borrow $1.3 Billion for Their New Stadium
description: The Jets and the Giants yesterday completed a $1.3 billion financing agreement to build an 84,000-seat stadium in East Rutherford, N.J.

title: Allies Not Likely to Push Mugabe to Change
description: JOHANNESBURG, Aug. 16  Southern Africas political leaders gathered Thursday in Lusaka, Zambia, to discuss Zimbabwes political and economic collapse, but it appeared unlikely that they would press its president, Robert G. Mugabe, to change any of the policies that critics said had brought his nation to ruin.

title: Blair to Write Book
description: Former Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain, who stepped down in June, plans to write a book, The Associated Press reported yesterday, citing a Blair representative who would not speak on the record because no deal has been made. The representative said that the book, probably a memoir, hasnt been started and is at least a few years from publication. There have been no negotiations with publishers, the representative said, but Mr. Blair has retained Robert Barnett, a Washington lawyer who has acted as book agent for Bill Clinton and Alan Greenspan,. A spokesman for Mr. Blair, Matthew Doyle, declined to comment.

title: For Three Virgins, the Path to Sunrise Is Paved With Excess
description: Horny is as horny does in the sweetly absurd high school comedy Superbad. A tickly, funny tale of three teenage boys revved up by their surging, churning, flooding hormones, the movie joins the tumescent ranks of similarly themed works about male sexual desire  consider Portnoys Complaint, think Porkys  and its somatic epiphanies, treacherous secretions, anguished lessons and apparently limitless storehouse of embarrassments. Behold the man (well, boy): fully sexed and wholly, touchingly virginal.

title: Con Edison Wins Ruling in Pipe Explosion Case
description: Consolidated Edison won its legal fight yesterday to test a piece of equipment that may not have been working properly shortly before last months steam pipe explosion in Midtown Manhattan.

title: Morris Meets Amadeus: Odd, Elective Affinities
description: The most immediately remarkable feature of Mark Morriss triple bill Mozart Dances is that whereas Mozarts piano writing employs flourishes, trills, cascading passagework, Mr. Morris never once has his dancers do anything virtuoso. But this is just the first odd feature of many.

title: Trial Starts for Owners of Nursing Home Hit by Storm
description: ST. FRANCISVILLE, La., Aug. 16  Almost exactly two years after Hurricane Katrina, one of its worst horrors was revisited on Thursday in a courtroom in this sedate antebellum town, far from the coastal nursing home that became a watery tomb for 35 residents.

title: Mortgage Ills Start to Strain Homebuying in Manhattan
description: The turmoil in the international mortgage market is starting to make it harder for New Yorkers to get the large loans that are typical in a city where the average apartment in Manhattan costs $1.3 million. In the past two weeks, banks have been increasing rates on so-called jumbo mortgages, sometimes at the very last minute, according to mortgage brokers and lawyers.

title: Queens: Teenager Stabs Stepfather
description: A teenager fatally stabbed his stepfather, who was assaulting the boys mother, on Wednesday night, the police said yesterday. After consulting with the district attorney, the police said yesterday that no charges had been filed. The police said the stepfather, Arturo Moreno, 33, began arguing with his wife about 9:30 p.m. at their Ozone Park home. The dispute became physical, and the womans 14-year-old son, who was not identified, stepped in. During the altercation, the teenager stabbed Mr. Moreno in the chest, the police said. Mr. Moreno was pronounced dead at Jamaica Hospital Medical Center, they said.

title: Giambis Candor Earns Him a Pass From Selig
description: Jason Giambi will not be disciplined for tacitly admitting earlier this season that he had used steroids. Commissioner Bud Selig announced yesterday that Giambis willingness to cooperate with the investigation being conducted by the former Senator George J. Mitchell into steroid use in baseball swayed his decision.

title: Europeans Plan to Investigate Ratings Agencies and Their Warnings
description: PARIS, Aug. 16  The European Union announced on Thursday that it would investigate whether ratings agencies like Standard & Poors and Moodys were adequately alerting investors to risks like securities backed by subprime mortgages in the United States.

title: Pod People Propagating With a Fierce Indigestion
description: The latest and lamest version of Don Siegels 1956 pulp classic Invasion of the Body Snatchers (from the Jack Finney novel) might have been an accidental camp classic if its politics werent so abhorrent and the movie didnt try to hide its ineptitude behind a veil of pomposity. A miscast Nicole Kidman stars as a Washington-area shrink whos so deep in her own little world she doesnt initially notice that everyone else appears to be mainlining antidepressants. Maybe theyre former patients. Or maybe all those tight skirts she wears have cut off her circulation. That certainly must explain why she barely notices Daniel Craig, wasted here as her best friend.

title: Hits From a Drummer Who Reveled in Change
description: A selected discography of recordings featuring Max Roach, in chronological order:

title: A Bratty American Star in Bollywood
description: In Marigold, a light romantic comedy billed as the first United States-India co-production, India provides one of its biggest stars (the bad boy Salman Khan), gorgeous scenery (Goa, Bombay, Rajasthan), a genre (the Bollywood musical) and even the daughter of a Nobel Prize winner (the actress Nandana Sen, whose father is the economist Amartya Sen).

title: Lutherans Urge Restraint in Disciplining Gay Ministers
description: The countrys largest Lutheran denomination officially bars openly gay people from the ministry. title: Cant Tell a Book (Kapow!) by Its Cover
description: The biggest mystery about two new thrillers, The Intruders and Power Play, is why they look so generic. Their titles suggest nothing but vague, all-purpose peril. The raised letters on their covers scream so loudly that not even a blind person could miss the design style. Stacks and stacks of other books look just like these. Perhaps thats the point. It might be risky in the world of blustery suspense books to indicate that these are anything special. Even though they are.

title: Mr. Bernankes Moment

title: 3 Killed and 6 Injured in Rescue Effort at Mine

title: Britain: Retail Sales Post Gain
description: Retail sales in Britain unexpectedly rose in July by the most in five months as price cuts by stores lured shoppers. Sales climbed 0.7 percent after gaining 0.4 percent in June, which was twice as much as previously reported, the Office for National Statistics said. Tesco, Britains biggest retailer, and Asda, owned by Wal-Mart Stores, cut prices on thousands of products to attract customers during the wettest summer on record. The gain in retail sales was led by electronics and furniture, the statistics office said. Household goods stores reported a 13.4 percent annual increase in sales, the biggest since October 2001. Retail sales rose 4.4 percent from a year earlier. Analysts said the strong figures would encourage the central bank to raise interest rates.

title: Lake Trout: Big, Deep and Seductive
description: LAKE trout have some unflattering nicknames. Mud chickens, theyre sometimes called. Fats. Humpers. Half-breeds. Ken Schultzs Fishing Encyclopedia, a reference book sacred to anglers, while gushing over the brook trout as among the prettiest fish in the world, derides the lake trouts distended belly.

title: Bronx: Police Officer Dragged by Car
description: A police officer was dragged by a car in Williamsbridge early yesterday after he tried to question the driver, whom he suspected of using drugs, the police said. The officer, who was not identified by the police, then shot the driver in the left leg, the police said. The officer had approached the car, at East 228th Street and White Plains Road, on foot about 1 a.m., believing two men in it were smoking marijuana. The car was driven off, and the officer was caught and briefly dragged, the police said. Investigators said the two men were seen throwing marijuana and cocaine from the moving vehicle, which police officers stopped after it had gone about two blocks. The officer was treated for minor injuries at St. Barnabas Hospital, and the driver was in stable condition at Jacobi Medical Center, the police said. Charges against the two men in the car, whose identities were not disclosed, were pending late yesterday, the police said.

title: Queens: Man Charged With Murder
description: A Queens man has been charged with killing one man and wounding another in a shooting last week in Laurelton, prosecutors said yesterday. The man, Rhian Taylor, 21, of 229th Street in Laurelton, was charged with murder and assault, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said Mr. Taylor fired repeatedly into a car after an argument outside a party just before 2 a.m. last Friday. Darion Brown, 22, of 127th Avenue in Laurelton, was hit several times and died, prosecutors said. Another man was shot in the leg, they said.

Its possibly the greatest hair accumulation at an Ivy League college since the hirsute days of the 1960s.

Although the number of pay phones in the city is shrinking  there are now about 22,700  80 percent of the decline has been from phones alongside buildings (where advertising is not permitted) rather than from phones at the curb (the only pay phones where ads are allowed).

title: Revisiting Joe Goulds Secret

For three decades, Gould, a Harvard graduate from a distinguished New England family, had spent his days and nights wandering the bars and taverns of Greenwich Village, staying in flophouses, living off the generosity of friends and strangers. He became unexpectedly famous as the subject of a celebrated profile by the writer by Joseph Mitchell.

title: Social Networking, Here?
description: With all the troubles facing the newspaper business model, Im a big believer that the best hope for reviving the model is to take newspaper websites and turn them into bases for social networks. You look at what happened to newspaper valuations over the last decade, and then what happened to the valuations of social networks like Facebook, Youtube, Myspace and so on, and you wish we could learn some of their techniques for creating communities and monetizing them. The upshot would be more eyeballs, longer time on the site, more free (reader-generated) content, and thus more advertising revenue.

This was classic Chablis at a peak, fresh and nervy and laden with tangy lime and crushed stone flavors. Its texture was captivating, and I thought it would be impossible to inhale these aromas and not love Chablis. I felt both inspired and greatly relieved.

Many beginning musicians give up because that feeling is elusive  few can just pick up a guitar for the first time and play even the simple opening riff to Smoke on the Water. Music is hard work.

She is with the Hamburg Ballet, not the Munich Ballet; there are no Munich Ballet members in Morphoses.

title: China: Cars Banned in Olympics Test
description: More than a million vehicles were ordered off the roads of Beijing as part of a test to gauge the citys preparedness for next summers Olympic Games. With concern mounting that Beijing could be clogged with pollution and traffic during the Olympics, city officials began four days of driving restrictions to determine the impact on air quality and traffic flow. Results will be released later, but traffic was noticeably lighter, reducing some commuting times by half, and air quality seemed better, but a thin gauze of pollution still hung in the air.

title: On the Spot
description: Ive been thinking of a line in A. J. Liebling quoting the man he calls his literary adviser, Whitey Bimstein, who also trained prizefighters. I once asked him how he liked the country, Liebling writes. He said, It is a nice spot.  I love this for the same reason Liebling does  the way it reduces the nonurban land surface of the planet to a single, homogeneous vanishing point. Mr. Bimstein was also perpetuating an ancient poetic habit, singling out an idealized setting from among the chiggers and ticks, the pokeweed and the poison ivy, in the actual countryside. I know some of Mr. Bimsteins rural counterparts. They have lived in the country their whole lives and never once been to the city.

description: There were two perfectly predictable schools of thought being expressed after the conviction of Jose Padilla on Thursday on terrorism-related charges. Supporters of the Bush administration said the conviction justified the more than three years Mr. Padilla spent in military detention before his criminal prosecution, while the administrations opponents said the verdict proved that the criminal justice system should have handled the case in the first place.

description: MOSCOW, Saturday, Aug. 18  President Vladimir V. Putin said Friday that the Russian Air Force would resume regular, long-range patrols by nuclear-capable bombers over the worlds oceans, renewing the practice after a 15-year hiatus in another sign of Russias growing assertiveness.

description: DES MOINES, Aug. 17  Following in the path of Mitt Romney, Rudolph W. Giuliani, Hillary Rodham Clinton and a host of other presidential candidates, Fred D. title: Markets Quake, and a Neutral Strategy Slips
description: We have to atone to our clients, but we have no right to whine for ourselves, said Clifford Asness, the co-founder of AQR Capital Management, a money management firm that has been much in the news recently. When we succeed, we make a boatload of money, we get imitators, and our risk increases. Thats how capitalism works.

title: Baseballs Bad Bet
description: TIM DONAGHY, the National Basketball Association referee who pleaded guilty this week to federal charges stemming from his participation in an illegal gambling scheme, has sent a shudder through professional sports. Those who administer the games rightly fear for the integrity of their livelihoods, and those who watch the games fear for the purity of their pleasure.

title: Journalist Signs to Write a Murdoch Biography
description: Michael Wolff, a columnist for Vanity Fair and the author of Burn Rate, a book about his experiences as an ill-fated dot-com entrepreneur, has signed with Doubleday to write a biography of Rupert Murdoch, whose News Corporation recently bought Dow Jones for $5 billion. The book was sold at auction, for a high six-figure advance, to Bill Thomas, editor in chief of the Doubleday Broadway Publishing Group. The deal was reported yesterday in The New York Post, which is owned by the News Corporation. Mr. Wolff, whose article about Mr. Murdoch appears in the September issue of Vanity Fair, expects to have the cooperation of Mr. Murdoch, members of his family and executives at News Corporation, though a spokesman for the publisher said the book was not an authorized biography. Doubleday expects to publish it in the fall of 2009.

title: Judge Blocks Sentinel Plan to Sell Assets
description: The Sentinel Management Group cannot sell to the Citadel Investment Group assets that belong to two futures brokerage firms, a federal judge ruled yesterday in a $15.2 million lawsuit stemming from credit market volatility.

title: At Camp, Coming Closer to the Earth, and Its Bounty
description: POCANTICO HILLS, N.Y., Aug. 13  Eleven-year-old Cynthia Cabreja, nearly overwhelmed by an enormous red backpack, stared coolly over a mild-shock electric fence at several dozen frolicking baby piglets, many of them suckling furiously at the engorged udders of the three giant sows that had birthed them.

title: A Better Way to Feed the Hungry
description: The traditional method of feeding the worlds hungry with American crops seems to be falling into disfavor. An article in The Times this week by Celia Dugger disclosed that CARE, the big global charity, had decided to stop selling subsidized American farm products in poor African countries because the program was inefficient and undercut local farmers.

title: Germany: Ex-Red Army Member Freed
description: Eva Haule, a former member of the Red Army Faction who was convicted of participating in the murder of an American soldier in 1985 and later in the bombing of the Rhein-Main Air Base in Frankfurt when it was the main base for United States forces in Europe, is being released from prison after 21 years. She is the second former member of the extreme left-wing militant group, which was also known as the Baader-Meinhof gang, to be freed this year.

title: Afghanistan: Official and Family Killed
description: A suicide bomber killed a district chief and three of his children in southern Kandahar Province, officials said. The chief, Khairuddin Kaka, was the top government official in Zhari, a rural district west of Kandahar City that has experienced a string of Taliban attacks. An unidentified man approached Mr. Kaka after he left a house in Kandahar City in the morning with his 2-year-old daughter and 6- and 12-year-old sons, according to a police official. They died when the unidentified man detonated explosives, killing himself as well.

description: Tiger Woods stars in television commercials for the PGA Tours inaugural FedEx Cup playoffs, whistling the theme to Rocky III, and speaking to a portrait of Bobby Jones. But he will not appear in next weeks kickoff tournament at Westchester Country Club.

description: Sitting in a narrow dressing room behind a heavy red curtain at the Birdland jazz club in Midtown, the saxophonist James Moody, 82, rested his head in his hand and remembered gigs with Dizzy Gillespie, Thelonious Monk and someone else: Max Roach, his longtime friend, the legendary jazz drummer who died on Thursday at age 83.

description: SAN ANTONIO, Aug. 17 (AP)  Rescuers searched Friday for people swept away in flash floods caused by the remnants of Tropical Storm Erin, as wary residents across the Gulf Coast watched as Hurricane Dean charged through the Caribbean.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17  The Bush administration is considering designating Eritrea as a state sponsor of terrorism, accusing it of running arms to Islamic insurgents in Somalia, the State Departments top official for Africa said Friday.

title: Happy Birthday, CD
description: The first compact disc ever produced rolled off the assembly line exactly 25 years ago yesterday, according to the BBC. The disc, a recording of The Visitors by Abba, was manufactured at a Philips factory near Hanover, Germany, on Aug. 17, 1982. The first CDs went on sale in November of that year, and since then more than 200 billion are estimated to have been sold worldwide. The creation of the CD, a joint effort of Philips and Sony, marked the beginning of the digital era in sound and image. The CD is still the dominant musical format despite the rapid growth in downloading music, legally or otherwise, from the Internet.

title: Warrant Seeks Saddam Husseins Wife and Daughter
description: BAGHDAD, Aug. 17  An Interpol arrest order for Saddam Husseins eldest daughter and his first wife has been circulated, Iraqi officials said Friday.

title: Edwards Says He Will Drop His Investments in Subprime Lenders
description: DES MOINES, Aug. 17  The John Edwards presidential campaign said on Friday that Mr. Edwards would divest his portfolio at a New York hedge fund of investments in subprime mortgage companies that have foreclosed on victims of Hurricane Katrina. But the campaign said he would keep his $16 million investment in the hedge fund, the Fortress Investment Group.

description: Carolyn Goodman, a Manhattan clinical psychologist who became a nationally prominent civil rights advocate after her son Andrew and two other civil rights workers were murdered by the Ku Klux Klan in Mississippi in 1964, died yesterday at her home on the Upper West Side. She was 91.

title: Theaters Alternative Universe
description: As an experience in scruffy cultural consumption, the New York International Fringe Festival is without parallel in Manhattan, or possibly anywhere else.

title: Ralph Alpher, 86, Expert in Work on the Big Bang, Dies
description: Ralph Alpher, a physicist whose early calculations and theoretical predictions supported the Big Bang concept for the origin of the universe, though his role was largely overlooked as later discoveries proved him right, died last Sunday in Austin, Tex. He was 86.

title: A CBS Reality Show Draws a Claim of Possible Child Abuse
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 17  The ads promoting Kid Nation, a new reality show coming to CBS next month, extol the incredible experience of a group of 40 children, ages 8 to 15, who built a sort of idealistic society in a New Mexico ghost town, free of adults. For 40 days the children cooked their own meals, cleaned their own outhouses, formed a government and ran their own businesses, all without adult intervention or participation.

title: Of Mitt, Monks, and Mowers
description: Mitt Romneys campaign has been trying to position him as the conservative alternative to Rudy Giuliani. They went searching desperately for examples of Rudys closet liberalism that do not involve things Mitt himself was doing until about five minutes ago. (Divorces will only take you so far.) They pounced on immigration, and, suddenly, New Yorkers discovered they are living in a sanctuary city.

title: Latest Genealogy Tools Create a Need to Know
description: Katherine Holdens family had long kept what she called a deep dark secret. When the family discussed its roots, there were hints, but no outright discussion, of a great-grandmother who had lived in South Dakota and was the equivalent of native royalty: the putative daughter of an American Indian chief.

title: Daily Show Goes to War
description: The Daily Show With Jon Stewart often places its mock reporters in mock locations  typically in front of digital backdrops of Congress or the White House. In a break with that tradition, the show announced yesterday that Rob Riggle, right, its senior war correspondent, had actually filed a weeks worth of reports from Iraq. Yes, actual Iraq, not green-screen Iraq, Comedy Central said in a statement. Mr. Riggle, who the channel said is a major in the Marine Corps Reserve and has served in Liberia, Kosovo and Afghanistan, was in Iraq this week as part of a U.S.O. comedy tour. He took along a writer and a producer from The Daily Show and shot segments with the troops whenever the tour schedule allowed. Mr. Riggle is to return from Iraq today, said Renata Luczak, a Comedy Central spokeswoman, who added that what he would bring back with him was a bit of a mystery. Due to intense military security the show had very little contact with them to see what they got, Ms. Luczak said.  The show is getting the footage over the weekend. Mr. Riggles reports, titled Operation Silent Thunder: The Daily Show in Iraq, are to begin on Monday.

title: Dancing Lessons
description: Sabra Johnson, below, a 20-year-old native of Utah, earned the title of Americas Favorite Dancer, along with a grand prize of $250,000, on Thursday night during the two-hour finale of Foxs So You Think You Can Dance. The show powered Fox to its 13th consecutive Thursday-night ratings victory among adults 18 to 49. According to Nielsens estimates, the finale averaged 9.4 million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m., and more than 11 million in its final half-hour. CBS ranked No. 2 over all, as both Big Brother at 8 (7.5 million) and a repeat of CSI at 9 (9.5 million) earned solid second-place finishes in their time slots. CBSs Without a Trace (9 million) dominated the all-rerun 10 oclock hour, ahead of ABCs Men in Trees (3.6 million) and NBCs ER (3.4 million). ABC and NBC finished about even in third for the night, although NBC fared better in the 18-to-49 demographic.

title: The Jets Offense Sputters Without Jones
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Aug. 17  There was a hole in the offensive backfield, a haze obscuring Chad Penningtons vision and an altogether messy look to the Jets offense Friday night.

title: Winehouse Cancels
description: Amy Winehouse, below, has canceled all her August concerts after being hospitalized last week for severe exhaustion, The Associated Press reported. Tracey Miller, a spokeswoman for Ms. Winehouse, the 23-year-old British soul singer, said she was putting her touring commitments aside to address her health issues. Ms. Miller added that her family has requested that the media respect Amys privacy at this time. There will be no further comment. British newspapers reported this week that Ms. Winehouse had checked into  and then out of  a rehab clinic near London. Her husband, Blake Fielder-Civil, said on Thursday that the couple had just gone home to pick up a guitar. Dont worry, he said, shes being looked after. Were going back to this retreat. Shes determined to get well. Ms. Winehouse is scheduled to begin a North American tour next month.

title: Whats on Tonight
description: 10 P.M. (Cinemax) PANS LABYRINTH  (2006) The Mexican-born Guillermo del Toro directed this political fable cum fairy tale, set in a dark forest in 1944 Spain, about a young girl whose fantasies are trampled by her stepfathers fascist politics. The film, in Spanish with English subtitles, received Academy Awards for cinematography, art direction and makeup, but lost the Oscar for best foreign-language film to The Lives of Others, from Germany. Ivana Baquero plays the films heroine, Ofelia, who longs to believe in fairies, princesses and magic lands; Doug Jones, above, plays the woodland creature (a couple of them, actually) who charges her with three tasks. Fairy tales (and scary movies) are designed to console as well as terrify, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. What distinguishes Pans Labyrinth, what makes it art, is that it balances its own magical thinking with the knowledge that not everyone lives happily ever after.

title: Keeping Cool, Clear Tap Water

Unfortunately, that marketing can make tap water seem less clear, less clean and less healthy. When New York City did a survey on tap water recently, one youth was asked whether he drank from the public water fountains. Yes, he said, but Im going to die.

title: Aronian, Bologan Win Chess960 Events in Mainz

The idea is that players cannot use the openings that they have learned for regular chess and must instead rely on their wits from the beginning of the game. A good explanation of the rules and the history of Chess960 can be found here. The home page for the Mainz event, with all the results and some of the games, is here.

title: Designated Villain
description: I come to bury George Steinbrenner, not to praise him. The all-conquering owner of the New York Yankees is not actually dead, of course, though he has withdrawn from public view; in a recent news account, a baseball executive described the Yankee owner as inconsistently lucid. But the era of the man who has in many ways personified baseballto the detriment of a game that many Americans, despite everything, still cherish  has ended. Historians will note that the terminal moment arrived July 31, when the Yankees, though trailing the first-place Boston Red Sox by eight games, allowed the leagues trading deadline to pass without dealing away any of their minor-league prospects in exchange for an established star who might help them win right now.

title: Notes on Prison Camp
description: This short book prints 22 poems by detainees at the military prison at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, that have been cleared for release by the United States military. The poems  some by accomplished writers, others by first-time poets  suffer some flaws, as the books editor, Marc Falkoff, himself a lawyer for 17 detainees, puts it. It is hard to imagine a reader so hardhearted as to bring aesthetic judgment to bear on a book written by men in prison without legal recourse, several of them held in solitary confinement, some of them likely subjected to practices that many disinterested parties have called torture. You dont read this book for pleasure; you read it for evidence. And if you are an American citizen you read it for evidence of the violence your government is doing to total strangers in a distant place, some of whom (perhaps all of whom, since without due process how are we to tell?) are as innocent of crimes against our nation as you are.
