description: I NEVER know whats going to happen in my books, the novelist Hilma Wolitzer was saying on a recent sultry afternoon, in her cool East Hampton living room. I write them as a reader.

title: The War as We Saw It
description: Baghdad

title: MaryBeth Slavin, John Reiss
description: Mary Elizabeth Slavin, the daughter of Brigitte Slavin and Dr. James D. Slavin Jr. of West Hartford, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon to John Donohue Reiss, a son of Rosemary Reiss and Paul J. Reiss of Lake Placid, N.Y. The Rev. Edward Durkin, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Agnes Church in Lake Placid.

title: Next Step for Rerouting Planes May Be in Court
description: AFTER nearly nine years of study and more than a hundred public meetings, Federal Aviation Administration officials say they are weeks away from issuing a final decision on how to reroute airline flights over the region to ease bottlenecks in the sky. Communities that fear a sharp increase in the number of flights rumbling overhead are now turning to what they say is their only chance to stave off noise pollution: the courts.

title: Lights, Camera, Hike!
description: As a guy who spent his teenage years in Texas, who wanted desperately to make the football team, who failed utterly and who as a grown man has followed the dramas of the states schoolboy squads, I can tell you this: High-school football in Texas isnt really about football at all. Coaches will tell you that its a white-hot crucible in which young men, through blood rituals of violence and teamwork, learn painful lessons about who they are and what theyre capable of  that is, if they give 110 percent. It is also, if you believe the parents, a vehicle by which these boys families and community can share in moments of glory before returning to lives of quiet, dusty desperation. The players themselves might disagree, but they just play the game.

title: The Pastime Nacional
description: THE food, by now, has been well chronicled: Vendors lining the edge of Red Hook Park in Brooklyn on summer weekends sling tacos and pupusas on folding tables under tarpaulin roofs. But for many of the people who flock to the park, they are just a warm-up for the main event, the Technicolor baseball games played all day long against a backdrop of post-industrial gray.

title: John Buchanan, Steven Hitt
description: John Scott Buchanan and Steven Randall Hitt were married on Friday. Ann Moore, a civil marriage commissioner for British Columbia, officiated at Queen Elizabeth Park in Vancouver.

title: The Walker and the Walk
description: OCCASIONALLY I think of leaving the city once and for all. Enough of the busyness and ambition, the hothouse summers. But almost as soon as I begin to imagine my pastoral life, I hit a wall. Where would I walk? The woods? Some wind-blasted shore? The sky, the light, yes  but so much of it?

title: Kathleen Roosevelt, Jeffrey Walker
description: Kathleen Ann Roosevelt, a daughter of Ann Roosevelt and James Roosevelt Jr. of Cambridge, Mass., was married yesterday to Jeffrey Thomas Walker, the son of Gail S. Walker and Dr. Richard L. Walker of Somers Point, N.J. The Rev. Kim K. Crawford Harvie, a Unitarian Universalist minister, officiated at the Arlington Street Church in Boston. The Very Rev. Kevin J. OLeary, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: Correction: A Museum to Get Lost In, and How Israel Is Fixing It
description: An article last Sunday about the Israel Museum omitted the name of one designer of the Shrine of the Book. Frederick J. Kiesler designed it with Armand P. Bartos.

title: When Lost Bags Put You on a Carousel
description: FOR a vacation to Italy in June, Dominique Linchet had packed everything she thought her family of four would need when they arrived: toiletries, bathing suits, dental retainers. But when they stepped off their Alitalia flight in Rome, the suitcases they had checked were missing.

title: How to Add Oomph to Organic
description: THE organic industry has gone wild in the last decade, but you wouldnt know it at the Department of Agriculture.

title: Clemens Returns as His Old Self
description: Roger Clemens, who turned 45 this month, must have been conscious of every wrinkle on his face during the top of the fifth inning yesterday at Yankee Stadium. Staring back at him from home plate was Cameron Maybin, the highly acclaimed 20-year-old who made his major league debut Friday for the Detroit Tigers.

title: A Rivers Pulse
description: There isnt room for permanent enemies anymore, said John Cronin, a stalwart of environmental activism in the Hudson Valley and someone you might consider more likely to picket or sue a giant corporation than form a partnership with one. But there was Mr. Cronin on Wednesday, announcing that the Beacon Institute for Rivers and Estuaries, a nonprofit research organization that he runs, was collaborating with I.B.M. to open an ambitious center to study the river as it has never been studied before.

title: Stephanie Shapiro, Jonathan Marden
description: Stephanie Eve Shapiro, a daughter of Bonnie and Michael Shapiro of Hewlett, N.Y., was married last evening to Jonathan Corey Marden, the son of Marsha and Arnold Marden of Yorktown Heights, N.Y. Rabbi Helene Ferris officiated at the Yale Club of New York City.

title: A Chinese Century? Maybe Its the Next One
description: CHINA claims that its economy is growing at 10 to 11 percent a year, and Chinas official analysts say that their nation will catch up with the United States long before the 22nd century arrives. Dont believe it.

title: Musharrafs Plans (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Just Live, Baby!
description: Good Morning, Mr. Davis. Hello. How are you Feeling? Well See!

title: Jazz as It Is and Was, and Flamenco as It Can Be
description: Buika

title: The New 30 Is Now 50
description: THE uncertainties on Wall Street may be sending shivers down the backs of hedge fund titans and their real estate brokers, but so far the upper reaches of the Manhattan property market have been so strong that a report concludes the truly rich now need to think about spending $50 million to acquire a one-of-a-kind property.

title: An Itinerant Refugee in a Hip-Hop World
description: MAYA ARULPRAGASAMS Brooklyn apartment was a neglected mess when she finally returned to it last month after six months abroad. But it took only a day to straighten it up and turn it into her version of a pied--terre, a makeshift multimedia headquarters. An audio mixing board, film canisters and shiny gold and black dancing outfits stood on one side of the apartment, and half of an uneaten papaya waited on a table in the back.

title: Kathryn Swan, Ian Malin
description: Kathryn Foster Swan and Ian Ogden Malin were married yesterday at the First Parish Church, a Unitarian Universalist church in Portland, Me. The Rev. Peter Friedrichs, a Unitarian Universalist minister, performed the ceremony with the Rev. Thomas Shepherd, a retired Episcopal priest, assisting.

title: Americanization 101
description: Washington

title: NASA Moves Up Landing Because of Hurricane
description: With Hurricane Dean headed toward the Gulf of Mexico, the space shuttle Endeavour undocks from the International Space Station today, a day early, and is scheduled to land Tuesday.

title: Corrections
description: Arts & Leisure

title: He Got Out While the Getting Was Good
description: BACK in those heady days of late summer 2002, Andrew Card, then the president's chief of staff, told The New York Times why the much-anticipated push for war in Iraq hadn't yet arrived. "You don't introduce new products in August," he said, sounding like the mouthpiece for the Big Three automakers he once was. Sure enough, with an efficiency Detroit can only envy, the manufactured aluminum tubes and mushroom clouds rolled off the White House assembly line after Labor Day like clockwork.

title: Correction: Appealing to the Senses, and One in Particular
description: A review last Sunday of the restaurant Taste in Garden City misstated its hours. It serves dinner from 5 to 10 p.m. Monday to Thursday and 5 to 11 p.m. Friday and Saturday; it is also open for lunch from 11:30 a.m. to 3 p.m. Monday to Friday.

title: Man, 25, Killed Outside Club in Manhattan
description: A man was stabbed to death on a Manhattan street early yesterday after a dispute in a nightclub in the Flatiron district, the police said.

title: Correction: A Neighborhood in Waiting
description: The Living In article last Sunday, about the Fordham neighborhood in the Bronx, misstated a stop on the No. 4 and D subway lines. It is Kingsbridge Road, not Kingsbridge Avenue.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: SANTA FE FOR KIDS

title: Michael Deaver, 69, Dies; Shaped Reagans Image
description: Michael K. Deaver, who arranged some of Ronald Reagans most memorable photographic backdrops for public consumption and privately gave the president blunt, sometimes contrarian advice, died yesterday at his home in Bethesda, Md. He was 69.

title: AOL Founder Turns to Eco-Resorts
description: Stephen M. Case, who made his fortune in cyberspace as co-founder of AOL, has a new venture firmly rooted in the ground: eco-friendly resorts. Called Revolution Places, his company has set its first project on the northwest coast of Guanacaste, Costa Rica. Planned to open in 2010, the $800 million, 650-acre project, called Cacique, Costa Rica, hit a bump recently when a government agency rejected its environmental impact statement as lacking in specifics. But it is now pushing ahead with a new environmental consultant. The development will combine luxury lodging with sustainable practices like renewable energy. It will provide the community with computer learning centers and give grants of up to $35,000 to local groups to improve the environment. There are to be 120 villas, 330 other residences, a Miraval Spa, an 18-hole golf course and an Agassi/Graf Tennis and Fitness Center (www.revolution.com).

title: Disney Stakes Claim to Ratings Record
description: The Friday night premiere of the Disney Channel movie High School Musical 2 has set ratings records, delivering the largest single audience in basic-cable television history, according to preliminary ratings reports provided by Disney.

title: Jeremiah Milbank Jr., Donor and G.O.P. Official, Dies at 87
description: Jeremiah Milbank Jr., who followed in the footsteps of his father, a leading philanthropist and a close friend of President Herbert Hoover, to become an important Republican fund-raiser and benefactor of people with disabilities, died on Aug. 7 in Charlottesville, Va. He was 87.

title: Watershed
description: There are good reasons to hope  and believe  that the Federal Reserve will ably manage the turmoil in the financial markets. Its surprise lending rate cut on Friday and earlier infusions of cash into the banking system show that it is committed to crisis management.

title: Hue and Cry
description: SOME years ago, a Park Avenue socialite named Mrs. Austin Hancock thought it would be nice to organize a series of boat cruises up the Hudson and transplant to New York the gaiety of the Mississippi River soires of her youth. She arranged this with Daniel McAllister, a local sea captain, who agreed to provide one of his steamboats for the festivities.

title: The Fusion on the Menu Is Art and Food
description: IT was a familiar art-world ritual. Mint BMWs and Audis snaked down a dark alley off the Second Ring Road in Beijing and pulled up to a gray industrial bunker. Samuel Keller, the director of Art Basel Miami Beach, had just jetted in from Switzerland. The local hotshot painters Liu Ding and Liu Wei were huddled with the Svengali-esque curator Pi Li, and in one corner would-be collectors were chatting with one of China's most renowned contemporary artists, Ai Weiwei.

title: Food Aid Program (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: No Shortage of Culprits in Meltdown by the Jets
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Aug. 18  Pete Kendall, whose errant shotgun snap was snapped up by the Minnesota Vikings and returned for a touchdown Friday night, could not have been more accurate after the game. Its back to the drawing board, I suppose, he said.

title: Wi-Fi for L.I.
description: At the rate the world is going, there will someday be at least one Starbucks on every block, and no one will ever be more than 10 steps from a latte and a wireless hot spot. But to tide us over until the day of that grand  or grande  convergence, Long Island is taking a useful step forward in greatly expanding public Wi-Fi access. Nassau and Suffolk Counties announced last week that a vendor had risen to the challenge of extending public wireless coverage across 750 of Long Islands 1,200 square miles, from the Queens border to Montauk.

title: Avoiding the Credit Storm, by Swimming in Midstream
description: WALL STREET remains riveted by the collapse of subprime mortgages and other speculative debt. As the drama unfolds, some of the calmest investors hold mainstream bond portfolios, whose returns have been relatively unaffected.

title: Hostile Takeover
description: Joseph Finder is perhaps the lead player in the corporate thriller genre, a thriving subset of the traditional suspense novel in which executives are both villains and victims. The stakes tend to be smaller here: theres no threat to the free world, no killer virus decimating American cities, no madmen plotting serial mayhem. What there is in Power Play is an off-site business conference gone horribly wrong  and were not talking about a run on bran muffins or a lack of participation in the trust fall exercise.

title: Win Is Tempered by Loss of Easley
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18    The layer of dirt beside second base at R.F.K. Stadium claimed Jose Valentn to a knee injury nearly four months ago. Damion Easley, his replacement, became another victim Saturday night when, on nearly the exact same stretch of infield here, he sustained a Grade 3 sprain of his left ankle during the sixth inning of the Mets 7-4 victory against the Washington Nationals. The injury will probably end Easleys season.

title: In Pursuit of Farm Fresh Flavor
description: MY church is a farm. Give me a few chickens, a long row of carrots and the smell of dirt, and Ill find the open heart and inner peace others might seek from a prayer book or a pew.

title: Shelves That Bear the Weight of Time
description: IF you are tired of your morning commute and long for some middle ground between home and office, you are not alone. Look through the pages of Phaidons mammoth new design survey, Contemporary World Interiors, where you will find hundreds of jaw-dropping, gravity-defying spaces by todays A-list of design  Frank Gehry, John Pawson, Marcel Wanders, OMA, Herzog & de Meuron, to name but a few  and you see that the greatest minds in design share your concerns.

title: Calendar of Events
description: COMEDY

title: When the Issue Is War, Take Nothing for Granted
description: A front-page article 11 days ago prompted a flurry of e-mail accusing The Times of playing into what readers said were Bush administration efforts to gin up hostility toward Iran.

title: Foreigners in Chad (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: More Than Soul
description: West Harlem remains the citys soul food capital, but the neighborhood now offers a variety of other options, like these.

title: Scenic, Yes, but Far From Pristine
description: Eatons Neck

title: Susan Green, Adam Greene
description: Susan Lee Green, a daughter of Barbara B. Green of Nanuet, N.Y., and Dr. John H. Green of Huntington, N.Y., was married on Thursday to Adam Seth Greene, the son of Andrea Greene and Robert M. Greene of Manhattan. Rabbi David E. Greenberg officiated at the Metropolitan Club in Manhattan.

title: Mixed Reviews for Neighbors in Arms
description: New Haven

title: The Week in Westchester
description: Trump Drops North Castle Development

title: In the Land of Nannies and Poodles
description: SHARI SPRINGER BERMAN and Robert Pulcini, the husband-and-wife writing-and-directing team, got their start making documentaries, experience they found essential in taking on The Nanny Diaries. Their film version of the best-selling roman  clef about the distinctly unfamilial lives of Manhattans elite has an anthropological perspective, complete with museum-style dioramas of that strange society known as the Upper East Side. Set to be released on Friday by the Weinstein Company, it stars Scarlett Johansson as the nanny and Laura Linney and Paul Giamatti as the ghastly parents, Mr. and Mrs. X.

title: Correction: Dads in Iraq, and the Familys on Edge
description: A picture caption with the Parenting column last Sunday, about the family of Sgt. Benjamin Phillips, a medic with the New York Army National Guard, referred incorrectly to Sergeant Phillips's military service. He is on his first deployment to Iraq, not his second.

title: Escape From El Salvador
description: I spent the 1980s in the West with job-seeking hobos, in the Deep South with former sharecroppers, in the Steel Belt with downsized workers. If I showed up at your door in those days, your life had been marked by epic tragedy. Its no exaggeration to say that in writing for newspapers and books I closely witnessed 1,000 shattered lives, which is to say I retain 1,000 demons from that decade.

title: Fallujas Calm Is Seen as Fragile if U.S. Leaves
description: FALLUJA, Iraq  Fallujas police chief, Col. Faisal Ismail Hussein, waved aloft a picture of a severed head in a bucket as a reminder of the brutality of the fundamentalist Sunni militias that once controlled this city. But he also described an uncertain future without my only supporters, the United States Marine Corps.

title: Uncle Wiggily in Amherst
description: At a very early age Leslie Garis began to be aware that there were disturbing discrepancies between her real-life family and the idealized ones portrayed in the uplifting juvenile fiction written by her grandparents. The fragile but magnetic father whom Garis adored, and whom she depicts memorably in House of Happy Endings, was at times strangely remote and distracted, even when he managed to speak the right lines. Her pretty young mother, who once wanted to be an opera singer, often locked herself away in her room with migraines, overwhelmed by the difficulties of coping with three children, an emotionally dependent husband and the magnificent turn-of-the-century house they had moved into when they left metropolitan New York in the late 1940s for Amherst, Mass. Even Gariss younger brothers seemed troubled and had difficulties in school. But the Garis children had been brought up to believe that a good person is happy; a happy person is good. For Leslie to admit her family was unhappy would have constituted a flaw in character. Nonetheless, she became a precociously perceptive observer and eavesdropper. Her favorite spy post was an old dumbwaiter; crouched inside it, between floors, she would try to decode the messages carried by the overheard voices of the adults.

title: She Could Have Danced All Night
description: BROOKE ASTOR believed that good music should never go to waste. I remember photographing an awards dinner-dance in 1994 at the Plaza Hotel. After the last speech, most of the guests rushed for the door. Mrs. Astor slipped into a sable jacket.

title: Giraffes, Viziers and Wizards: Variations on the Old Game
description: Five years ago, Bobby Fischer, the former champion, was asked if he still played chess. Referring to a chess variant he introduced in 1996, he replied: Only Fischer Random. I dont play the old chess any more. The old chess is dead; its been played out.

title: Luxury, and How It Became Common
description: WANT to buy luxury products like Louis Vuitton handbags? Gucci shoes? Prada dresses? Theres no need to comb the fashion alleys of New York, Paris or Milan in search of the brands boutique stores. Just zip over to the nearest mall, where high-end department stores hawk luggage, footwear, apparel, jewelry and virtually every other designer-label item that ever appeared under the klieg lights.

title: 2 Firefighters Are Killed in Blaze at Ground Zero
description: Two firefighters were killed yesterday battling a blaze in the Deutsche Bank skyscraper, a vacant relic of the Sept. 11 terrorist attack that was in the process of being dismantled.

title: Ireland Learns to Adapt to a Population Growth Spurt
description: DUBLIN  Inside a north Dublin warehouse, 15,000 cardboard boxes containing the documents of Irelands most recent census rise on new shelving from the concrete floor. The sight is nondescript, but the collated and computer-scanned documents contain evidence that the Republic of Ireland is the fastest repopulating small country in the world.

title: Color Me Bad
description: In his memoir, Jubilee City, the Oklahoma-bred painter Joe Andoe reports that he once got so tanked at a reception in his honor that he forced kisses on married museum curators and had to be dragged from the premises. Twice. Later, his dealer was afraid the spectacle would be taken as a publicity stunt. Some readers may suspect the same about his book, whose subtitle, A Memoir at Full Speed, suggests that Andoe is eager to depict himself as a raw and reckless sort.

title: Karen Borkowsky, Robert Kennedy
description: Karen Ilene Borkowsky and Robert Francis Kennedy were married last evening by Cantor Ronald Broden at the Rainbow Room in New York.

title: Ortizs Grand Slam Helps Schilling Earn Victory for the Red Sox
description: BOSTON, Aug. 18 (AP)  David Ortizs grand slam capped a six-run fifth inning, Curt Schilling earned his first victory since a one-hitter two months ago and the Boston Red Sox defeated the Anaheim Angels, 10-5, on Saturday night in a matchup of the teams with the best records in the majors.

title: How Much String for 500 Rackets?
description: New Haven

title: A Fly-Fishermans Odyssey
description: MY search for trout fishing in Greece began on the slopes of the Taygetus Mountains of southern Greece where Spartan boys once toughened themselves for battle against the Persians at Thermopylae.

title: Keeping That Big Nutcracker Party Coed
description: ON an overcast Saturday outside Public School 199 in Sunnyside, Queens, a long line of parents waited for the doors to open for the School of American Ballets local auditions for beginning students. Up and down the sidewalk two dozen little girls struck poses and spun in circles, unfazed by a light drizzle. Flashes of pink were everywhere: pink sneakers, knapsacks, jackets and leotards, pink ribbons tied around ballet buns.

title: The Watch List
description: Doing his best impersonation of Roy Hobbs in The Natural, RICK ANKIEL, below, has captured the attention of Cardinals fans. The team has been streaking, with Ankiel receiving much of the credit because of his three home runs.

title: A Fearsome Gang and Its Wannabes
description: THE grim execution-style shootings that killed three college students in a Newark schoolyard two weeks ago bore many hallmarks of gangland slayings, and the culprits clearly wanted it that way.

title: Border Patrol Gets an All-Terrain Look
description: SAN DIEGO, Aug. 18 (AP)  Leather belts with brass buckles are out; nylon belts with quick-release plastic buckles are in. Slacks are out; lightweight cargo pants are in. Shiny badges and nameplates are out; cloth patches are in.

title: A Hotelier Is Breaking the Mold Once Again
description: IN the world according to Ian Schrager, the master of the ultrahip hotel, theres no greater currency than a boldface name checking into a stylish guest room or hanging out in the chic bar or restaurant. Mr. Schrager cut his teeth among the in-crowd in the late 1970s and early 80s, as co-founder of the Studio 54 and Palladium nightclubs in New York City, and has since courted the slender, fashionable and martini-prone with such gusto  from the Royalton and Paramount hotels in Manhattan to the Delano in South Beach and the Mondrian in West Hollywood  that he has earned rock-star status of his own.

title: Foul Call
description: At my sons Little League game, a foul ball sailed over the fence and shattered the window of a parked car. Signs at the ball field specify that the league is not responsible. One parent argued that the hitters family should replace the window. Our family thinks the player and his parents have no such obligation: foul balls are part of the game. Who is right?  Steve Fram, Palo Alto, Calif.

title: Lineman, Heal Thyself
description: When his football career ended, John Ed Bradley, a captain and all-conference center at Louisiana State University, developed a walking hangover. It Never Rains in Tiger Stadium (ESPN Books, $24.95) is an unsparing and often beautiful chronicle of his attempt to join polite society.

title: Letters
description: Measuring the Subprime Mess

title: Lottery Numbers
Engineer on Two Wheels
description: LOOKING back, I think even as a small child I was already an environmentalist. It was the way I was brought up.

title: Pass the Popcorn. But Wheres the Movie?
description: AS consumers by the millions install new flat-screen, high-definition TV sets this year, more than half of which will have 50-inch or larger screens, they can proudly say that they are doing their part to modernize the movie-viewing experience at home.

title: Correction: Fears of Interlopers on Wheels Rattle a Tranquil Street
description: An article on July 29 about a plan to install a bicycle path on East 91st Street misstated the circumstances in which East 91st between Second and Third Avenues was closed to traffic. The block was turned into a pedestrian mall during the building of apartment complexes on the site of the former Ruppert Brewery in the early 1970s. As the article reported, the closing remains unofficial, as it is not reflected on Department of Transportation maps; however, the block was not closed as a school's play street. Additionally, because of an editing error, the mistaken statement was erroneously attributed to the Department of Transportation.

title: Leaving Well Enough Alone: The Rise of the Unrestored Classic
description: Pebble Beach, Calif.

title: Where the Salad Travels Less Than You
description: ON a sweltering day in early August, in a community garden near the Home Depot in Brewster, Vicky Zeph is on her knees, rustling among prickly zucchini vines in search of perfect male blossoms.

title: Letters: They Didnt Credit Me
description: To the Editor:

title: The Road to Beijing
description: LOOMING over the Chaoyang district of Beijing, the rising headquarters of China Central Television, or CCTV, will soon angle and cantilever like a colossal Constructivist doughnut, threatening to writhe free of the scaffolding that barely harnesses it. Designed by Rem Koolhaas and Ole Scheeren of the radical Dutch firm OMA, it will be a gravity-defying, 755-foot-tall monument to architectural derring-do  an audacious beacon and backdrop from which the images of a newly ascendant China will be beamed across the globe, one year from now, during the 2008 Summer Olympics.

title: Two More Arrested in Newark Killings
description: NEWARK, Aug. 18  After a frantic manhunt through several states, the authorities arrested two half brothers who are charged in the brutal Aug. 4 murders of three people here.

title: Win. Wipe Out. Repeat.
description: So this was how the day would end for Nicky Hayden, rag-dolling through the rain at 140 miles per hour, his season shattered like his motorcycle, a multimillion-dollar machine depreciating rapidly as it shed chunks of titanium and carbon fiber in the gravel shoulder area where Hayden would eventually skid to a stop. That's a huge crash! the Eurosport TV announcer howled, a fairly obvious observation to anyone who had just watched the white, orange and black Honda dip into a corner of the wet track and chuck Hayden, the reigning Moto Grand Prix road-racing world champion, into the air just two laps from a fourth-place finish that he desperately needed.

title: Grammar Police
description: Dangerous Admissions is Jane OConnors first adult novel, but anyone who is either 4 or lives with a 4-year-old will probably be familiar with her as the author of the best-selling Fancy Nancy books.

title: Spurning Criticism, Rove Blames Democrats
description: WACO, Tex., Aug. 18  During the last eight years, Karl Rove has been lionized and vilified, heralded as making the unlikely election victories of President Bush possible and impugned as reaching too high from an unusually powerful White House perch.

title: Ann Wimpfheimer, Edward Snyder
description: Ann Frieda Wimpfheimer, a psychologist, and Edward Lewis Snyder, a C.P.A., are to be married today by Rabbi Saul Berman at Congregation Ansche Chesed in New York.

title: Passengers Escape as Hijacking in Turkey Goes Awry
description: ISTANBUL, Aug. 18  Two men tried to hijack a Turkish passenger plane with 142 people aboard on Saturday but failed after pilots arranged an emergency landing in the Mediterranean resort of Antalya and the two lost control of the passengers.

title: Detoxing the Big Rigs
description: For anyone concerned about the environment or global warming, few things are more annoying than watching a diesel-powered truck or bus idling for minutes and even hours on end. To their credit, New Jersey officials are finally doing something to stop it.

title: Back From the Future
description: Although youre known as the father of cyberpunk science fiction, your new novel, Spook Country, is set in the post-9/11 present and endows the whole culture with a noirish gloom. At what point did American life become stranger than science fiction? If I had gone into a publisher in New York in 1981 and told them I wanted to write a novel that is set in a world where the climate is out of whack and Mideast terrorists have hijacked airplanes and in response the U.S. has invaded the wrong country  its too much. Contemporary reality is like an overlapping set of dire science-fictional scenarios.

title: Vick Is Trapped in His Circle of Friends
description: The crooked circle Michael Vick drew around himself has tripped and squeezed him.

title: A Hands-On, Intuitive Feel for the City
description: Robert Clark, 46

title: Jamaica Comes Under Assault From Hurricane Dean
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, Aug. 19  Hurricane Dean left a trail of destruction as it surged across the Caribbean today, toppling buildings on islands along its periphery and taking at least eight lives. But it is in the tourist haven of Jamaica where the powerful storm is expected to leave its most destructive mark.

title: Decks: Real Wood or a Look-Alike?
description: NOT long ago, most decks were made of greenish-tinged wood that had been pressure-treated with chromium copper arsenate to make it rot-, mold- and insect-resistant.

title: Kristina Scurry, Evan Baehr
description: Kristina Archena Scurry and Evan John Baehr were married yesterday at the Cornwallville Church in Cooperstown, N.Y. The Rev. Samuel B. Abbott, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

title: Newark Triple Murder Fuels Debate on Treatment of Illegal Immigrants
description: NEWARK, Aug. 17  The radio advertisement, released after the killings of three young people here, starts with a few notes of music and an anonymous voice-over before Rudolph W. Giuliani speaks.

title: Datebook
description: MADRID

title: Another Good Program Gone Sour
description: Too many politicians are busy thumping their chests and furrowing their brows in Albany these days about whether Gov. Eliot Spitzers staff has done anything wrong. It is time to cut the noise, folks; time to get back to work.

title: Reservations for 38, With an Online Travel Planner
description: WHEN Mark Purnell planned a family reunion 10 years ago, he made ample use of the telephone and the United States Post Office. This year, he was on the phone much less and didnt need to buy postage stamps.

title: Is Publishing the Sweetest Revenge?
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Back to You, You Lecherous, Micromanaging Desk Jockeys
description: Football watching has long been a giddy celebration of masculinity. What other conclusion would a visiting anthropologist draw from the repartee of Terry, Howie and Jimmy (or Boomer, Dan and Shannon; or Tom, Mike and Emmitt ... ), the rituals of hearty backslapping and heehaw laughs? So ferociously man-centric is football TV that when a woman tries to infiltrate the proceedings, she is scrutinized with the same incredulity as if she had donned a helmet and walked into a huddle.

title: Seeing Is Believing
description: Is the surge in Iraq working? That is the question that Gen. David Petraeus and U.S. Ambassador Ryan Crocker will answer for us next month. I, alas, am not interested in their opinions.

title: A Soap That Goes to the Mat
description: SEASONAL businesses have devised some creative ways to earn year-round revenue. Several ski resorts, for example, open mountain-biking trails during the summer. Many retailers of patio furniture stock up on pool tables and bar stools when cold weather hits.

title: Venezuelas New Phase (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Fiction Chronicle
description: RAVEL. By Jean Echenoz. (New Press, $19.95.) It cant have been Maurice Ravels thrill-seeking behavior that prompted Echenoz to imagine his way into the head of this musical genius. Indeed, given the delicacy with which Echenoz teases out lifes minutiae, perhaps the attraction was precisely Ravels quietly uneventful existence. Leaving the bathtub is sometimes quite annoying, the opening sentence reads. First of all, its a shame to abandon the soapy lukewarm water, where stray hairs wind around bubbles among the scrubbed-off skin cells, for the chill atmosphere of a poorly heated house. Yes, this is what everyday life is like for Maurice, as it might be for any Jean or Pierre  how to get a good heating system, a good nights sleep or good food while on tour in 1920s America. Ravel was a private man, his life never bared before all, and rather than add gratuitous spice, Echenoz puts his enchanting imagination to work exploring the mundane, the curmudgeonly, the quirky: Ravels refusal to perform unless hes wearing his patent-leather shoes (Street shoes with a conductors tails are out of the question); his exhausting struggles with insomnia (he who invariably chases sleep until dawn only to snag just some mediocre cut-rate, secondhand variety); his fondness for machinery and engines (Bolro is described as an orchestral factory without a purpose, a suicide whose weapon is the simple swelling of sound). This beautifully musical little novel, translated by Linda Coverdale, ends in 1937 at Ravels deathbed, where he leaves no will, no image on film, not a single recording of his voice.

title: On the Road Again
description: In 1951, Jack Kerouac feverishly pounded out the first draft of On the Road in three weeks on a single huge roll of paper. This believe-it-or-not item earns a place on the heroic roster of spontaneous literary combustions  Stendhal writing The Charterhouse of Parma in 52 days, for example. It also stands alongside the image of Jackson Pollock  in the series of photographs taken of him by Hans Namuth just a few months before Kerouacs siege of the typewriter  dripping and flinging and flecking paint on a horizontal canvas, fighting and dancing his work into being. Writing is not usually thought of as excessively physical, which is why some writers feel the need to compensate by racing bulls or whatever, but feeding that 120-foot roll through the typewriter seems like a feat of strength. Most writers merely produce effete works on paper, you might say, but Kerouac went and wrestled with the tree itself.

title: You Dont Know Jack
description: Twenty years ago, like so many slack 17-year-olds before and since, I devoured On the Road and it devoured me. The pages of my copy were dog-eared, -nosed and -throated, and I was beholden to the book in ways I cant quite believe now. Did I really go for midnight drives down by the ruined flour mills with the tape deck blaring Dexter Gordon? Did I really attend a high school costume dance dressed as Jack Kerouac? I know for sure  because proof exists  that the year I graduated I chose this bit of the novels last paragraph as my yearbook entry: And nobody, nobody knows whats going to happen to anybody besides the forlorn rags of growing old. By the time I left for college, the books spell had begun to fade. Late that summer, a dreamy friend asked me to join him in Landmark Forum, the successor to EST, Werner Erhards New Age group seminars. We stood under a streetlight near dawn and argued about it: it had made a real difference to him; to me it seemed a woozy retreat from the world. I had On the Road in my bag, as I always did. When we had run out of things to say I gave it to him. He seemed so much to need it; I thought I no longer did.

title: What Happened in Norfolk?
description: At the Keen Mountain Correctional Center, a gray complex of poured concrete in rural southwest Virginia, Joseph Jesse Dick Jr. sits behind the thick glass pane of a prison interview booth like a specimen in an oversize shadow box. A man of delicate bearing with receding reddish brown hair, a sparse mustache and rectangular prison-issue glasses a bit wide on his long, gaunt face, Dick is here because he pleaded guilty to the 1997 rape and murder of his neighbor Michelle Moore-Bosko  a crime he now says he didnt commit. And maybe he didnt. Such proclamations of innocence are no longer surprising. The imprisoned man exonerated by DNA evidence or a belated confession by the actual killer or the emergence of a credible alibi witness is a narrative of increasing familiarity. But even in the upside-down world of wrongful convictions, the extravagant case of Joseph Dick and his supposed partners in crime is in a class of its own.

title: Feeling Chummy

Early in his career he was known as Nick Foldo because of the way he wilted in the majors. Then in the 1980s he rebuilt his swing under the tutelage of the renowned coach David Leadbetter and became the worlds top player, winning three Masters and three British Opens. He later broke with Leadbetter, as he did with a great many people. But in recent years, a different, easygoing Faldo has been on view in the broadcast booth at CBS and on the Golf Channel. This Nick is funny, insightful and surprisingly comfortable in his new role, though its still not a good idea to get on his bad side.

But shorn of its master-of-the-universe pretensions, the city has rediscovered its essential charm, as a user-friendly Hessian town with big-city accouterments. Its museums are the best in Germany, after Berlin's, and its opera and ballet are top notch. Frankfurt's population is the country's most international  dozens of nationalities, including a large Turkish contingent. title: Thinking Out Loud
description: In Um..., Michael Erard brings together two of humanitys signature traits: using language and messing things up. The way we misspeak is endlessly interesting, but not because it is a sign of bad habits or unconscious feelings. Rather, interruptions and mistakes result from one of the fundamental properties of language, its linearity. Because speech is timebound and words can come only one after the other, the way we stall, stumble and start again provides clues to the way we render thought with sound. Indeed, what is stilted, stuttered and slipped on illuminates how we retrieve words from memory, how we plan ahead of speech, how we unite meaning and intonation in real time, and how we acquire language in the first place.

title: Balance: In Search of the Lost Sense
description: Aristotle was wrong. Often credited as the first to catalog the human body's primary senses, he neglected to mention one of our most important: the sense of balance, that intricate orchestration of nerve impulses that allows us to dance with gravity. His oversight, however, is understandable. While it's easy to detect the role of the eyes, nose, skin, tongue, and ears, the receptors of balance are hidden from view and don't easily give up their secrets. Because the equilibrium sense is mostly autonomic, working below the level of consciousness, like breathing or the beating of a heart, the great philosopher apparently was unable to sense its subtle operation.

title: Um . . . : Slips, Stumbles, and Verbal Blunders, and What They Mean
description: If the world of verbal blunders were the night sky, the Reverend William Archibald Spooner of Oxford University could play the role of the North Star. Spooner, who was born in 1844, was famous for verbal blundering so incorrigible that his exploits have been immortalized in poems and songs and, most enduringly, by lending his name to a type of slip of the tongue he was unusually prone to make. In the spoonerism, sounds from two words are exchanged or reversed, resulting in a phrase that is inappropriate for the setting. For Spooner, these embarrassments ranged from wild to mild. Toasting Queen Victoria at dinner, Spooner said, "Give three cheers for our queer old dean," and he greeted a group of farmers as "noble tons of soil." There was the time he cautioned young missionaries against having "a half-warmed fish in their hearts." He described Cambridge in the winter as "a bloody meek place." Once Spooner berated a student for "fighting a liar in the quadrangle." "You have hissed all my mystery lectures," he reportedly said. "In fact, you have tasted two whole worms and you must leave Oxford this afternoon by the next town drain." A spoonerism can also involve the reversal of two words, as in "Courage to blow the bears of life," or, when saying good-bye to someone, "Must you stay, can't you go?"

So it was that on a December night in 1991 the fifth generation of the Rockefeller family-counting from John D. Rockefeller Sr. and his wife, Laura Celestia ("Cettie") Spelman Rockefeller, for whom the house had been built-gathered in the dining room of Kykuit for a farewell dinner. "It was an extraordinary evening where everyone reminisced about their childhood experiences on the estate," remarked one person afterward. Someone else recalled walking through the house and gardens, "just thinking how sad it was that it was changing. It was the end. It wasn't going to be a family house anymore. It was going to be a public place."

description: ALMATY, Kazakhstan, Aug. 19  President Nursultan Nazarbayev tightened his already considerable grip over the political life of this petroleum-blessed former Soviet republic, after weekend parliamentary elections in which his governing party won every seat being contested.

title: Move Over Mickey: A New Franchise at Disney
description: When High School Musical 2, the sequel to the hit 2006 made-for-television movie, made its debut on the Disney Channel on Friday night, it was a highly anticipated moment for millions of children across the nation.

title: Unchanged (for the Worse) Since 1872
description: The General Mining Law of 1872 is among the last statutory survivors of the boisterous era of westward expansion. Essentially unchanged since Ulysses S. Grant signed it into law, it sets the basic rules for mining hard-rock minerals like gold, copper and uranium on public lands. Useful in its day, it is a disaster now. It requires no royalties from the mining companies and contains no environmental safeguards, allowing mines to wreak havoc on water supplies and landscapes.

title: In Search of Cheneys Virtue
description: Dick Cheney once scoffed that energy conservation can be a personal virtue but is no basis for an energy policy.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,694 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:

title: As PGA Sells Its Playoffs, Some Players Arent Buying
description: In the first year it has been put in practice, the PGA Tours FedEx Cup points race has been embraced and embellished, mocked and misunderstood.

title: Trekking Oer the World, With Her Luck and an Ax
description: Away is a modest name for a book as gloriously transporting as Amy Blooms new novel. Alive with incident and unforgettable characters, it sparkles and illuminates as brilliantly as it entertains. The accomplishment is even more remarkable given the seeming drabness of the story Ms. Bloom tells. She offers a ridiculously beautiful account of a 1926 transcontinental schlep by an immigrant Jewish seamstress from New York toward Siberia in search of her young daughter.

title: Mexico Braces as Hurricane Strengthens
description: FELIPE CARRILLO PUERTO, Mexico, Aug. 20  She has stuffed the familys clothes in plastic bags, put crosses of tape across the windows of her hair salon here and bought canned food for 15 days to feed 10 relatives.

title: Its a Miserable Life
description: Last week the scene at branches of Countrywide Bank, with crowds of agitated depositors trying to withdraw their money, looked a bit like the bank run in the classic holiday movie Its a Wonderful Life.

title: Building a Brand Name, via Business Cards
description: AMONG Internet businesses, perhaps only one has managed to reach a market value of more than $1 billion by getting customers to hand out millions of promotional messages for it.

title: Rash of Injuries Leaves the Giants Hurting in Multiple Places
description: BALTIMORE, Aug. 19  For a short time during a sloppy preseason game against the Baltimore Ravens on Sunday night, the Giants major concerns were on full display all over the field: a questionable rush defense, an unsettling number of penalties, a hit-and-miss offense.

title: Joybubbles, 58, Peter Pan of Phone Hackers, Dies
description: Joybubbles (the legal name of the former Joe Engressia since 1991), a blind genius with perfect pitch who accidentally found he could make free phone calls by whistling tones and went on to play a pivotal role in the 1970s subculture of phone phreaks, died on Aug. 8 in Minneapolis.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Olbermann on NBC

description: To the Editor:

title: Hurricane Pounds Jamaica as It Crosses Caribbean
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, Aug. 19  Hurricane Dean left a trail of destruction as it surged across the Caribbean on Sunday, toppling buildings on islands along its periphery and taking at least eight lives. But it was in the tourist haven of Jamaica where the powerful storm was expected to leave its most destructive mark.

title: The Good War, Still to Be Won
description: We will never know just how much better the fight in Afghanistan might be going if it had been managed more competently over the past six years. But there can be little doubt that American forces  and Afghanistans government  would be in far stronger positions than they are today.

title: British Mosques Teach Civics to Combat Extremism
description: BRADFORD, England  At the Jamia Mosque on Victor Street in this racially and religiously tense town, Idris Watts, a teacher and convert to Islam, tackled a seemingly mundane subject with a dozen teenage boys: Why it is better to have a job than to be unemployed.

title: Standpipe Flaw Examined in Fire at Ground Zero
description: The Fire Department is investigating whether a malfunctioning standpipe sent water cascading into the basement of the flaming Deutsche Bank tower at ground zero on Saturday, denying water to air-starved firefighters battling the seven-alarm blaze above, including the two men who were killed.

title: A Quest to Get More Court Rulings Online, and Free
description: SEBASTOPOL, Calif., Aug. 14  The domination of two legal research services over the publication of federal and state court decisions is being challenged by an Internet gadfly who has embarked on an ambitious project to make more than 10 million pages of case law available free online.

title: Shuttle Scheduled to Land Tomorrow
description: With Hurricane Dean on a path far to the south of Houston and NASAs mission control center at the Johnson Space Center, there is less rush for the space shuttle Endeavour to land tomorrow.

title: An Increase in Diagnoses May Not Mean a Higher Rate of the Disease, a Survey Shows
description: The number of diagnosed cases of diabetes increased by 61 percent from 1991 to 2001, according to the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. That went along with a 74 percent increase in obesity, the agency noted, reflecting the strong correlation between obesity and the development of diabetes.

title: Be Very Afraid
description: Nightmare: Ghost Stories, a haunted house inspired by actual paranormal experiences, will take over the Clemente Soto Vlez Cultural Center on the Lower East Side from Sept. 28 through Nov. 3. The event, presented by the entertainment company Psycho Clan and created and directed by Timothy Haskell, is a follow-up to last years popular Nightmare: Face Your Fear, which was based on the worst fears of New Yorkers who responded to an online poll. This time Mr. Haskell and Chip Meyrelles, the executive director of Psycho Clan, have increased the size of the house to 23 rooms from 13, each featuring a different cause for alarm. New this year will be the Maze  a scary labyrinth designed to freak out even the most intrepid navigator. For tickets and a behind-the-scenes look: hauntedhousenyc.com.

title: Hedge Funds Are Squeezed by Investors and Lenders
description: As summer neared, investors in Sowood Capital Management, a $3 billion hedge fund, had little to complain about.

title: Officials Say 6 Miners May Not Be Recovered
description: HUNTINGTON, Utah, Aug. 19  The six men trapped in a violent collapse deep within a mountain mine nearly two weeks ago may never be found, grim-faced mining officials said Sunday.

title: South Korean Opposition Picks Candidate
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 20  A former mayor of Seoul, Lee Myung-bak, immediately became the front-runner in the South Korean presidential election today by being chosen as the candidate of the main opposition party.

title: Outrageous Farce From R. Kelly: Hes In on the Joke, Right?
description: What is there to say, really, about a multipart R&B soap opera cum sex farce starring an expanding cast of actors and actresses, all lip-syncing to the increasingly kaleidoscopic story-songs of a pop star once known for slow jams and I Believe I Can Fly?

title: Pet Cruelty Accusations Startle Upscale Enclave
description: SADDLE RIVER, N.J., Aug. 17  After spending the better part of two decades knocking on more doors than most people will in a lifetime, Fred Ferguson, a delivery driver with DHL Worldwide Express, has seen his share of sights strange and unpleasant.

title: In Africa, China Is Both Benefactor and Competitor
description: KABWE, Zambia  The courtyard in front of the Zambia China Mulungushi Textiles factory is so quiet, even at midday, that the fluttering of the ragged Chinese and Zambian flags is the only sound hanging in the air.

title: Whats on Tonight
description: 8 P.M. (BBC America) TOP GEAR This popular British automobile series, which uses stunts, time trials and road tests to assess the performance of the most lusted-after cars on the planet, makes its United States debut with back-to-back episodes. First up: Richard Hammond, above, Jeremy Clarkson and James May, the shows hosts, attempt to turn a minivan into a convertible by putting a retractable roof on a Renault Espace. The result? Its a bit like trying to cut your own hair; you could, but you probably shouldnt. Then the men try out new models, during which Mr. Clarkson gets excited by the Koenigsegg CCX, Mr. May finds the Honda Civic newfangled enough to want to drive it again, and Mr. Hammond doesnt like the Micra C+C one little bit. In Episode 2 the team takes a road trip to Iceland and meets up with the chef Gordon Ramsay, who sets a track record for  yep  swearing.

title: Israel Returns Illegal African Migrants to Egypt
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 19  Israel sent approximately 50 African migrants, many reported to be Sudanese refugees from war-torn Darfur, back across the border to Egypt late Saturday night, a move that drew the condemnation of Israeli human rights advocates when it became known on Sunday.

title: U.S. Stocks Flat After Overseas Gains
description: After weeks of volatility, stocks ended the day on Wall Street today pretty much where they started.

title: HSBC in Talks to Buy Stake in Korea Exchange Bank
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 20  HSBC Holdings said Monday that it was in talks with a Texas-based private equity fund, Lone Star, to buy a majority stake in Korea Exchange Bank, which would give HSBC a long-sought retail banking network in one of Asias largest economies.

title: Superbad Aces It
description: The teenage sex comedy Superbad, from Sony Pictures, scored at the box office over the weekend. The film, starring Michael Cera and Jonah Hill (above, left to right) as high school friends trying to buy alcohol for a party, took in an estimated $31.2 million, placing it well ahead of all competitors, according to figures released by Media by Numbers, a box office tracking firm. Last weeks top movie, Rush Hour 3 (New Line), slipped to second place with $21.8 million, bringing its cumulative take to $88.1 million. The Bourne Ultimatum (Universal) came in third with $19 million, bringing its total take up to $163.8 million in three weeks. The Simpsons Movie (Fox) dropped 41 percent and one spot from last week, coming in fourth with $6.7 million, which makes its total $165.1 million after four weeks in theaters. And No. 5 was The Invasion, the sci-fi picture from Warner Brothers starring Nicole Kidman and Daniel Craig; an update of Invasion of the Body Snatchers, it opened with $6 million at the weekend box office.

title: Prime Minister Plays Down Pakistani Rivals Talks
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Aug. 19  Pakistans prime minister played down the discussions between the president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, and the opposition politician Benazir Bhutto in an interview on Sunday. Prime Minister Shaukat Aziz said that any power-sharing deal would depend on the results of general elections later this year rather than on any prior agreement.

title: New CDs
description: RILO KILEY Under the Blacklight  (Warner Brothers)

title: The Inexperienced Liberty Defies Expectations in Making the Postseason
description: Less than an hour before the tip-off yesterday for the game between the Liberty and the Chicago Sky at Madison Square Garden, a 3-pointer in the final second of a game in Uncasville, Conn., left the Liberty with complete control over its future.

title: Defending Wikipedias Impolite Side
description: BEFORE Mike Godwin became general counsel of the Wikimedia Foundation last month, he was the subject of a Wikipedia article. And years before he was the subject of a Wikipedia article, his most famous insight  Godwins Law  had been given the Wikipedia treatment.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Chris Atlas rejoined Cornerstone, New York, as vice president for strategic marketing and brand properties. Before leaving Cornerstone to join Ampd Mobile as senior director for entertainment marketing, he had been director for urban music.

title: On the Road for Reality TV, With a Conniving Briton in America
description: When British freeloaders stride across America as if no one has ever seen it before  Im thinking Louis Theroux, Sacha Baron Cohen  why dont we just call fraud?

title: A Work Unbounded by Musical Categories
description: Lincoln Center seems to be taking a proactive approach to adding new works to the repertory, using Osvaldo Golijovs Pasin Segn San Marcos (2000) as its test case. This polystylistic Passion setting was the centerpiece of a Golijov festival here only last year. Now Mr. Golijov is back as the first (living) composer in residence at the Mostly Mozart Festival, and Pasin was given two more performances, Saturday and yesterday at the Rose Theater. It is clearly a good risk. The capacity audience on Saturday evening loved it enough to give it an extended standing ovation.

title: Ms. Rowling Is Up to Something
description: The Sunday Times of London reported that J. K. Rowling is working on a new book, a detective novel, and has been spotted in action at an Edinburgh cafe. The newspapers source would know a thing or two about sleuthing: It was Ian Rankin, the novelist who created the fictional Scottish police official Detective Inspector John Rebus 20 years ago. (He most recently wrote about Rebus this year in The Naming of the Dead.) Mr. Rankin told a reporter that his wife had spotted her. It is great that she has not abandoned writing or Edinburgh cafes, he said. Ms. Rowling initially worked on her Harry Potter stories in cafes when she was a struggling single mother trying to save on her heating bills.

title: Ad Growth for AOL Called Vital to a Remake
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 17  Just over a year ago, AOL unveiled a radical plan to remake itself into a business built on advertising from one driven by Internet access subscriptions.

title: Atlantic Tells Fans of the Puzzler Not to Fret
description: Ever since The Puzzler, The Atlantic Monthlys difficult but much-loved crossword puzzle, disappeared from the print magazine over a year ago, its fans have been complaining loudly (and sometimes in Latin) about the decision to publish it online only.

title: Iowans Check for Dirt Under Giulianis Nails
description: GREENFIELD, Iowa, Aug. 15  The setting was a small round table in the near-empty Nodaway Diner here in a remote patch of western Iowa. Rudolph W. Giuliani, the former mayor of New York and a candidate for president, had finished his hamburger and was fielding the usual mix of questions. Taxes and terrorism. Iran and Iraq.

title: Editor Acts, and 10 Time Inc. Magazines Revisit Katrina
description: Coincidence or not? This month, 10 of Time Inc.s magazines are running articles about New Orleans.

title: Looking Ahead
description: EYE ON THE ECONOMY Wall Street will be looking for signs of whether the recent volatility in the credit and stock markets could spread to the broader economy. The Conference Board will issue its index of leading economic indicators for July (Monday), and there will be reports on durable goods for July and new home sales for July (Friday).

title: A New Home for DDT
description: Bethesda, Md.

title: Chances for Everybody, in Time, in Latest Debate
description: DES MOINES, Aug. 19  In this presidential election season, there have been debates piled upon debates, a string of opportunities for candidates to be sized up alongside one another. Seldom has an audience been as important, though, as when the Democrats strode onto stage here on Sunday.

title: After Foreclosure, a Big Tax Bill From the I.R.S.
description: Two years ago, William Stout lost his home in Allentown, Pa., to foreclosure when he could no longer make the payments on his $106,000 mortgage. Wells Fargo offered the two-bedroom house for sale on the courthouse steps. No bidders came forward. So Wells Fargo bought it for $1, county records show.

title: European Legal Circles Await Ruling by Top Appeals Court on Microsoft
description: BERLIN  Perhaps the most closely watched figure in European legal circles this summer has been Bo Vesterdorf, the Danish judge who heads Europes top appeals court, with antitrust lawyers hanging on his every public utterance.

title: Downtown, New Worries About Air and Notification
description: Once again yesterday, officials trying to assess the damage walked down the block across from ground zero, past the former Deutsche Bank building, partly dismantled and now charred, but still there. And once again, people who live in the neighborhood were uneasy.

title: He Came, He Saw, He Wimped Out
description: The Last Legion, a sword-and-sandal spectacle from those epic-loving De Laurentiises, invokes a lot of better movies on its circuitous trip from the Roman empire to the Arthurian legend, but it doesnt do the one bit of borrowing that could have made this journey enjoyable.

title: White House Acts to Limit Health Plan for Children
description: The Bush administration, continuing its fight to stop states from expanding the popular Childrens Health Insurance Program, has adopted new standards that would make it much more difficult for New York, California and others to extend coverage to children in middle-income families.

title: Lottery Numbers
Afghan Raid Frees Kidnapped German Aid Worker
description: TIRIN KOT, Afghanistan, Monday, Aug. 20  A German woman who was kidnapped Saturday in Kabul was freed early Monday, German and Afghan officials said. An Afghan television station reported that the woman, an aid worker, was freed in a joint late-night raid by Afghan intelligence services and the police in Kabul.

title: Freedom Bound in Forest Dance
description: Joanna Haigood is obsessed with the notion of memory and place, and being the site artist she is, she digs deeper than most to expose their roots. But none of her works have meant as much to her as Invisible Wings, last performed at Jacobs Pillow in 1998 and being revived this week as part of that dance festivals 75th-anniversary season.

title: In Washington, Mets Finish What They Started
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19  The sky was overcast, not dark, and the backdrop to Sundays game was old and leaky, not new and charming, but take all that away and the Mets were back in an all too familiar place. Eighth inning. Score tied. Against an inferior team that would have liked nothing more than to destroy the Mets plans for a sweep.

title: As Seen on TV! Danny and Sandy 4-Ever and Ever
description: Changing the channel is not an option.

title: Olbermann on NBC
description: Countdown With Keith Olbermann the highly rated cable news program, will be shown on network television on Sunday before a preseason NBC football game between the Philadelphia Eagles and the Pittsburgh Steelers. Since Mr. Olbermann, right, will have a regular role in NBCs football coverage once the season begins  appearing as a co-host on the pregame show Football Night in America on Sundays  this weekends appearance of his cable show will give a wider audience a look at what he has been up for the last four years.  Countdown is rocketing right now over at MSNBC  its ratings are going through the roof, said Phil Griffin, senior vice president of NBC News. (In July Mr. Olbermanns show averaged 721,000 viewers, an increase of 88 percent over last July, according to MSNBC.) Mr. Griffin added, The world has changed, and I think people have come in line with the smart, focused approach he has on the show. No immediate plans for additional network appearances of Countdown have been made, but Mr. Griffen did not rule them out. It may be the first of several times you see Olbermann on the network, he said.

title: In This Campaign, Tequila Meets Java Jive
description: A campaign for a liqueur is treating the product like an energy drink, the better to reach the intended audience of younger consumers who, as the Alicia Bridges song proclaims, love the nightlife.

title: Accounts
Obesity May Be Only One Piece of Diabetes Puzzle
description: The havoc diabetes wreaks is clear. But researchers are puzzled by many aspects of the disease. Why, for example, are most people with Type 2 diabetes overweight or obese, yet most overweight or obese people do not have diabetes?

title: Playing Through Pain, Henin Wins Rogers Cup
description: TORONTO, Aug. 19  Hours before the final of the Rogers Cup on Sunday, the status of the tournaments No. 1 seed remained uncertain.

title: Tips to Help Patients Manage Their Care
description: Dr. John Buse, director of the Diabetes Care Center at the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, is president-elect for science and medicine at the American Diabetes Association and a principal investigator in a federal study asking whether blood sugar control can protect against heart disease in people with Type 2 diabetes.

title: How Solid Is the Deal for Tribune Company?
description: When Tribune Company shareholders gather tomorrow in Chicago to approve an $8.2 billion plan to take the company private, an uncomfortable question is sure to be on many of their minds: Will this deal fall apart?

title: Senator Upset With the Response to Subpoena
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20  The White House did not fully comply today with a subpoena seeking material on the Bush administrations eavesdropping program, and a leading Democratic senator reacted with anger, if not surprise.

title: New Thai Constitution Paves Way for Vote
description: BANGKOK, Monday, Aug. 20  Thai voters endorsed a new constitution on Sunday as the country eases toward the end of nearly a year of military rule and into the messy politics of a democratic election.

title: Make Like an Athlete: Slide, Sway and Crouch
description: Like many other American boys, Nick Seligson-Ross had dreams of becoming a professional baseball player. Instead he grew up to be a modern dancer. Since graduating from Purchase College, State University of New York, in 2000 he has performed with several choreographers, including Peter Pucci (since 2002), Jennifer Muller and H. T. Chen, but the work of Paul Taylor seems to have inspired him the most.

title: A Firehouses Grim Roster Adds Two Names From Blaze
description: The black and purple bunting rose again on the brick firehouse yesterday like a bruise.

title: Hewlett Introduces a Web Feature to Make Document Printing Mobile
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., Aug. 18  Hoping to alleviate a frustration of mobile computing, Hewlett-Packard has quietly introduced a free service designed to make it possible to print documents on any printer almost anywhere in the world. Cloudprint, which was developed over a period of several months by a small group of H.P. Labs researchers, makes it possible to share, store and print documents using a mobile phone.

title: Rising Breed of Migrant: Skilled and Welcome
description: SHARJAH, United Arab Emirates  In this country where foreigners do most of the work, there are migrant maids and migrant masons, migrant tea boys and migrant typists, all doing what most migrant laborers do, menial tasks for meager wages.

title: Footnotes
description: Shawn Klush of Pittston, Pa., was named the ultimate Elvis tribute artist on Friday in the first tournament of Elvis impersonators held by Elvis Presley Enterprises, The Associated Press reported. The contest, in Memphis, was part of Elvis Week 2007 for the 30th anniversary of his death. ... While Sutton Foster (The Drowsy Chaperone) appears in Mel Brookss Young Frankenstein this fall as Inga, the sexy lab assistant, her brother will appear in the new Off Broadway musical Frankenstein. Hunter Foster  has signed on to play the mad scientist in the more serious production, based on the 1818 novel. It begins previews at 37 Arts on Oct. 10.

title: In a Place of Solace, Finding Faith Among the Sorrow
description: PISCO, Peru, Aug. 19  Rita Cabrera stood in front of a statue of a seated Christ and stroked its hands, patted its beard and fought back tears.

title: Yanks Latest Victory Is Another Inside Job
description: The Yankees always study other teams, hunting for players who can help, but their most important scouting last month was within their organization.

title: Consuming Less While Getting More
description: While Americans may feel bombarded by media information, we seem to be consuming less of it, according to the results of a study by Veronis Suhler Stevenson, a private equity firm specializing in the media.

title: Pore Me
description: THE main thing is not to rush. If my pace accelerates past Leisurely Stroll, Im done for. So I give myself time. I allow 30 minutes for a 10-minute walk. I head out at 5 oclock for a 7 oclock meeting 10 blocks away. Men hurry past. Women tut as they shoulder by. Its called a sidewalk, mutters an old lady with a cane.

title: Bon Jovis Openers
description: My Chemical Romance, Big & Rich, Gretchen Wilson, Daughtry and the All-American Rejects will each have two chances to be the opening act for Bon Jovi when these New Jersey rockers perform a 10-concert series to mark the grand opening of the $375 million Prudential Center in Newark. The new arena, which will be home to the New Jersey Devils hockey team as well as Seton Hall Universitys basketball team and a variety of concerts and other events, will officially open on Oct. 25 with the first Bon Jovi concert. My Chemical Romance will open that night and the following. The full schedule is at prucenter.com.

title: Cleveland Diocese Accused of Impropriety as Embezzlement Trial Nears
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 19  A former assistant treasurer of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Cleveland is to go on trial Monday, accused of taking part in widespread financial mismanagement and looting of church funds.

description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing: New York: Bronx: Driver Fatally Shot at Stoplight
description: A gunman fired at least five shots into a car stopped at a traffic light in Mott Haven yesterday, killing its driver and injuring a front-seat passenger, the police said. The shooting happened at 5 a.m. at the corner of East 138th Street and the Grand Concourse, near the access ramp to the Madison Avenue Bridge, the police said. A second passenger, who was seated in the rear and was not injured in the shooting, jumped to the drivers seat and rushed the men to Lincoln Medical and Mental Health Center. The driver, Francisco de la Cruz, 27, was pronounced dead shortly after 7:30 a.m., according to a police spokesman. The injured passenger, also 27, whose name was not released, was listed in critical condition last night. The three men had left a nightclub in the neighborhood and were westbound on East 138th Street when they came under fire, the police said. It was unclear last night what led to the shooting, and there were no arrests.

title: Fox Cancels a Mock News Show, Citing Costs
description: Anyone looking for evidence that liberals are funnier than conservatives might be tempted to point to the demise of Fox News Channels 1/2 Hour News Hour, the networks answer to left-wing news parodies like The Daily Show With Jon Stewart and The Colbert Report on Comedy Central.

title: Dear Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: One Politicians $155 Billion
description: With Wall Street on its latest Tilt-a-Whirl, its troubling to think of a single state official being responsible for investments worth $155 billion. In New York, that financial titan is the comptroller, who is the sole trustee of the state pension fund.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes todays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.

title: Iraqi Governor Is Assassinated
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Aug. 20  The governor of a southern Iraqi province was assassinated today by a roadside bomb, officials said, in the latest attack to open up the prospect of escalating violence among Shiites.

title: Six Killers: About the Series
description: They are the leading causes of illness and death in the United States today: heart disease, cancer, stroke, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, diabetes and Alzheimers disease, in that order. And they have a lot in common.

title: Forget the Calendar: The Beauty Is in 30 Days of Marketing
description: Thirty days hath September, and so, too, will Hearst, which is rewriting the calendar rhyme to celebrate 30-day versions of October and May also.

title: Popular Demand
description: The top 40 people cited in the worlds 56 million blogs, as tracked on BlogPulse.com, tend to be political figures like Rudolph W. Giuliani, above, and celebrities like Britney Spears. Four presidential candidates made the top 10 list on Friday. Hillary Rodham Clinton was No. 11 that day: since July 20, she has otherwise fallen from the top 10 on Aug. 12, the day Merv Griffin died and the day after the Iowa straw poll, and on July 22, when Harry Potter characters took six of the top 10 slots.

title: Officials Say 6 Miners Are Unlikely to Be Found
description: HUNTINGTON, Utah, Aug 19  The six men trapped in a violent collapse deep within a mountain mine nearly two weeks ago may never be found, grim-faced mining officials said today.

title: Coming to City Center
description: The National Theater of Greece will return to City Center in the fall with a six-performance run of Sophocles Electra, directed by the Olivier Award-winning director Peter Stein, who staged last years acclaimed London production of Blackbird, by David Harrower. Electra will be the companys first appearance in the United States under its new artistic director, Yannis Houvardas, who took over the leadership position following the death of Nikos Kourkoulos in January. Performances at City Center (nycitycenter.org) will run Oct. 10 to 14. ... Pennsylvania Ballet (paballet.org) will visit New York this fall for the first time in more than 20 years, appearing at City Center Nov. 14 to 18 with a mixed repertory program comprised of works by George Balanchine, Val Caniparoli and Matthew Neenan.

title: At Virginia Tech, Remembering While Moving On
description: BLACKSBURG, Va., Aug. 19  By move-in day this weekend, the freshman class at Virginia Tech already knew a few of the ropes. Packed into the bleachers of Cassell Coliseum in their orange and maroon T-shirts on Saturday night, they began to jump up and down in unison at the opening chords of Enter Sandman, the Metallica anthem. At the sound of Hokie Hokie Hokie, Hi! they joined in with the 111-year-old nonsense cheer that gave the university mascot its name.

title: Rove Talks: If Mistakes Were Made, They Werent His
description: Karl Rove says he feels like Moby Dick.

title: To Compete With E-Mail Greetings, Funny Cards Try to Be Topical
description: How can a working mom get 8 hours sleep? is the question on the cover of a greeting card newly on the store racks.

title: Leona Helmsley, Hotel Queen, Dies at 87
description: Leona Helmsley, the self-styled hotel queen, whose prison term for income tax evasion and fraud was greeted with uncommon approval by a public who had grown to regard her as a 1980s symbol of arrogance and greed, died today at her summer home in Greenwich, Conn, She was 87.
