title: Queens: Motorcyclist Killed in Crash
description: One motorcyclist was killed and another injured yesterday when they were struck by a car after pulling to the side of the road on the Jackie Robinson Parkway, the police said. The motorcyclists had stopped on the parkways narrow eastbound shoulder, near the Metropolitan Avenue exit in Kew Gardens, to wait for a third rider when they were hit by a black 2001 Acura, whose driver remained at the scene, a police spokesman said. One of the motorcyclists, Leon Vanhatten, 47, was pronounced dead at the scene, while the other, who was not identified, was taken in stable condition to Jamaica Hospital Medical Center, according to the spokesman. As of last night, the authorities had not filed charges against the Acura driver.

title: Debt and Spending May Slow as Housing Falters, Fed Suggests
description: A new research paper co-written by the vice chairman of the Federal Reserve says that consumer debt soared over the last six years mainly because of the rapid increase in housing prices.

title: Caught in a Smoky Maze and Pleading for Help
description: The senior fire official, swearing into his radio, says he could not care less about the fate of the Deutsche Bank building, ablaze late Saturday afternoon.

title: Miners Given Up for Dead in 1968 Say Miracle Is Still Possible in Utah
description: HOMINY FALLS, W.Va., Aug. 16  Since Aug. 6, Jennings Lilly finds himself turning again and again to the television news reports, his thoughts flashing back nearly four decades to a time when he and five fellow miners were trapped for 10 days in a cold, flooded mine only three feet high in these Appalachian hills.

title: Floods Kill 13 in the Midwest
description: Floods soaked much of the midsection of the country from Texas to Minnesota today, causing at least 13 deaths as swirling waters washed out roads, triggered mudslides and forced evacuations of low-lying areas.

title: Social Rift Seen in Thailands Vote on Constitution
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 20  A referendum that approved a new constitution drawn up by the Thailands ruling generals brought a deep social rift into the open, political analysts said Monday, one likely to be a factor in an election later this year and to divide the country for a long time to come.

title: N.F.L.s Vick Accepts Plea Deal in Dog-Fight Case
description: RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 20  Michael Vick, the star quarterback of the Atlanta Falcons, has accepted a plea offer from federal prosecutors in a criminal case stemming from a dog-fighting ring that was run from a property Mr. Vick owned.

title: Greasing the Wheels on the Machinery of Death
description: Death penalty cases can take a long time. Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales wants to move things along.

title: Urban Refugees (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Childs Play
description: The great toy crisis of 2007, the national anxiety outbreak caused by lead paint and dangerous magnets from China, toymaker to the world, leaves millions of parents facing a quandary  What about Christmas?  and a larger question.

title: Anchovy Wars Collateral Damage: Idle Fishermen
description: LA TURBALLE, France, Aug. 16  They call it the anchovy war.

title: Clinton and McCain Address Military Veterans
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo, Aug. 20  In back-to-back speeches before an audience of military veterans here today, Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and John McCain praised the fortitude of American troops fighting in Iraq, but presented starkly different assessments of the war and the strategy going forward.

title: In Moscow, Summer Means a Freeze on Hot Water
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 20  The dour Moscow of cold war film strips is long gone, and this increasingly prosperous city fancies itself striding chest out into the future. But every summer, the people here get a taste of old-style deprivation, as if they were flung back to a time when they had to queue up at dawn to buy a few coils of mealy sausage.

title: For Media Columnist, Everywhere He Turns Its More Murdoch
description: When Michael Wolff, the media columnist for Vanity Fair, decided to pitch a biography of Rupert Murdoch, the chairman of the News Corporation and proud owner-to-be of Dow Jones & Company, he considered HarperCollins Publishers, which put out his last book.

title: News Coverage Shifts to Election From War in Iraq
description: News coverage of the Iraq war fell sharply in the second quarter of the year, as the news media paid increased attention to the presidential campaign and the immigration debate, according to a detailed analysis to be released today.

title: Adviser to Plead Guilty in KPMG Tax Shelter Case
description: The governments tax-shelter case against former KPMG employees and two other executives took a surprise turn yesterday, with one defendant, David Amir Makov, reaching a deal with prosecutors to plead guilty.

title: Caution Over Shuttle Shows Shift at NASA
description: Confronted with the same kind of problem that doomed the space shuttle Columbia, NASA officials, chastened by years of criticism and upheaval in the agency, took a markedly different approach during the current mission of the Endeavour, calling on an array of new tools and procedures to analyze and respond to the problem.

title: French Officials Iraq Visit Offers Lift, U.S. Says
description: BAGHDAD, Aug. 19  Bernard Kouchner, the French foreign minister, arrived in Baghdad on Sunday on the highest-level visit by a French official to Iraq since the 2003 invasion.

title: Brooklyn: Woman Dies in Fire
description: A woman, whom the police identified yesterday as Shirley Kelly, 56, was killed in an apartment fire in Brownsville on Saturday evening. The fire was reported in her apartment on Mother Gaston Boulevard about 7 p.m., the police said. Ms. Kelly was pronounced dead at the scene. The cause of the fire was under investigation, the police said.

title: Global Markets Rally After U.S. Rebound
description: LONDON, August 20  European stocks rose in early trading today following a surge in the Asian stock markets earlier in the day, as investors appetite for equities returned after a move by the U.S. Federal Reserve last week to reduce its discount rate.

title: From an Imposing Bank Tower to a Battered House of Horrors
description: In its death throes, the building shuddered.

title: Police Arrest Sixth Suspect in 3 Killings in Newark
description: NEWARK, Aug. 19  The police here arrested an 18-year-old man early Sunday, calling him the sixth and final suspect in the Aug. 4 playground killings of three young people and the wounding of another.

title: In First Crisis on the Job, Bernankes About-Face Is Weighed
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19  For the last month, the stock market has gyrated as every other day seemed to bring more bad news about the housing and credit markets. Traders awaited a signal from the Federal Reserve and its chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, now in his sophomore year at the helm of the central bank.

title: A Fourth Way to Deliver TV to the Home
description: One of the most covert startups in Silicon Valley, the temporarily named Building B, is lifting its head up today to announce a round of funding. Though executives at the Belmont, Calif., company still arent saying much about their plans, they appear to have sizable ambitions: Building B is aiming to bring both television and other media content, restyled for the Internet age, into your living room in competition with your cable, satellite or telcos IPTV service.

title: Your Comments on Energy Conservation
description: My last column before beginning a book leave is about energy conservation. Dick Cheney once dismissed it as a sign of personal virtue, but no basis for an energy policy  but I argue that in fact conservation is the low-hanging fruit in the effort to address carbon emissions and climate change. There wasnt space in the column to go into this, but theres also a major national security argument for conservation: The more we reduce our oil dependency, the less vulnerable we are to the whims of Iran and Venezuela. Whats more, if we curb demand, that tends to dampen the oil price  which means less revenue for Iran to invest in nuclear weapons.

title: Peer Pressure
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Working Out Your Brain
description: Scientists have suspected for decades that exercise, particularly regular aerobic exercise, can affect the brain. But they could only speculate as to how. Now an expanding body of research shows that exercise can improve the performance of the brain by boosting memory and cognitive processing speed. Exercise can, in fact, create a stronger, faster brain.

title: Understanding F1 press releases
description: Formula Ones annual summer break  I specify summer because this year I seem to recall something like a five week break after the first race and another three week break after the second or third race  is coming to an end. As it winds down and the teams and F1 personnel wind up for the Turkish Grand Prix this coming weekend, the team press releases are beginning to flow into our mailboxes. Beware team press releases.

title: HSBC in Talks to Buy Lone Stars Korean Bank Stake
description: Financial giant HSBC said Monday it is in talks to buy the controlling stake in Korea Exchange Bank currently held by U.S. private equity group Lone Star Funds. The discussions are ongoing, London-based HSBC Holdings said in a statement. If successful, the transaction would depend on obtaining the necessary regulatory approvals in (South) Korea and elsewhere, the bank said.

title: How Solid Is the Deal for Tribune?
description: When Tribune shareholders gather Tuesday in Chicago to approve an $8.2 billion plan to take the company private, an uncomfortable question is sure to be on many of their minds: Will this deal fall apart?

title: The One-Two Liquidity Punch to Hedge Funds
description: As problems that began in subprime mortgage lending have expanded into the broader markets, some hedge funds have come face to face with the ghost of past financial crises: the one-two liquidity punch from banks and investors.

title: Adviser to Plead Guilty in KPMG Tax Shelter Case
description: The governments tax-shelter case against former KPMG employees and two other executives took a surprise turn Sunday, with one defendant, David Amir Makov, reaching a deal with prosecutors to plead guilty.

title: Frances BNP Says Subprime Risk Is Limited
description: The exposure of the French bank BNP Paribas to subprime risk is limited and manageable, while the impact on quarterly earnings from having frozen funds would be zero, its head of asset management said Friday.

title: Sentinel Files for Bankruptcy as Clients Sue
description: Sentinel Management Group filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy Friday, less than a week after the cash-management firm serving the U.S. futures industry halted redemptions from investors because of market volatility.

title: Former Brocade C.F.O. Charged in Options Case
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission filed civil fraud charges against the former chief financial officer of Brocade Communications Systems, saying he turned a blind eye to the high-flying companys stock option backdating scheme.

title: Bubble Wrap Maker May Seal Deal for Alcan Unit
description: Bubble Wrap-maker Sealed Air is close to a deal to buy the packaging arm of Alcan for $4 billion to $5 billion in cash, according to Reuters.

title: El Paso to Buy Peoples Energy for $850 Million
description: Houston pipeline giant El Paso said Friday it will buy Peoples Energy Production for $875 million in cash as part of an effort to upgrade its exploration and production unit.

title: Getting a Few Laughs Out of the Losses
description: As the worlds biggest banks and institutions face the prospect of huge losses amid the current market turbulence, Londons financial employees have apparently been engaging in a little gallows humor to relieve the stress.

title: Note to Aspiring Dealmakers: Beware the Liar
description: In the age of the megadeal, classes in negotiations have become the most popular electives at any business schools across the country. Students aspiring to Americas executive suites are counseled to view every staff meeting, networking cocktail hour, or chance encounter with a senior manager as a negotiating opportunity.

title: F.T.C. Appeals to Block Whole Foods Deal
description: U.S. antitrust authorities asked a federal court for permission to temporarily block organic grocer Whole Foods Markets merger with rival Wild Oats Markets, a spokesman for the Federal Trade Commission said Friday.

title: Macquarie Gets $6.3 Billion for Restructuring
description: Australias Macquarie Bank on Monday said it secured a bank-loan facility of A$8 billion ($6.38 billion) from a syndicate of international and Australian banks, which it plans to use for a restructuring aimed at improving its international presence.

title: Danone Begins Tender Offer for Numico Shares
description: Groupe Danone, the maker of Dannon yogurt and Evian water, said Monday it has set the date for its Royal Numico bid, asking shareholders interested in its cash offer of 55 euros ($74) per share to submit their shares from Aug. 21 to Oct. 31.

title: Related, Vornado Said to Team Up for Virgin Megastores
description: Two of New Yorks biggest real estate developers, the Related Companies and Vornado Realty Trust, have jointly signed a deal to buy Virgin Megastores North America, The New York Post reported.

title: Countrywide Cuts Jobs to Reduce Costs
description: Countrywide Financial, reducing costs as part of its effort to weather a credit crunch, has begun laying off employees involved in originating loans, according to The Wall Street Journal.

title: Nasdaq May Sell L.S.E. Stake
description: Nasdaq Stock Market may sell its 31 percent stake in London Stock Exchange, in what may be an effort to raise cash to sweeten its bid for Swedens OMX.

title: Markets Quake, and Quants Slip
description: Some of the biggest quant funds have gotten clobbered recently.

title: Profit Vs. Indictment: A Traders Curve
description: Like many people, it seems Wall Street traders dont mind committing the crime  as long as they get dont caught.

title: With Debt Dried Up, Apollo Turns to Investing
description: Apollo Management is investing $1 billion of equity in Miami cruise line NCL for a 50 percent stake, in a sign that, with debt financing for large leveraged buyouts all but impossible to find, buyout firms are turning to non-leveraged forms of investment.

title: Will Microsoft Elbow in on XenSource Deal?
description: As the dust settles on an active week in virtualization software, some observers speculated that Microsoft could attempt to top Citrix Systems $500 million bid for virtualization specialist XenSource.

title: NTag Scores $8.3 Million from V.C.s
description: NTag Interactives investors like the companys interactive conference badges so much, they have come back to give the startup a further $8.3 million in growth capital.

title: Orion Energy Plans $100 Million I.P.O.
description: Orion Energy Systems, a maker of lighting systems, filed with U.S. regulators on Monday to raise up to $100 million in an initial public offering of common stock.

title: Missed Signs in a Mortgage Meltdown
description: The devastation of the roiling subprime mortgage market has stunned much of Wall Street, as the shakeup shuttered scores of lenders and rattled some of the worlds biggest investment banks and hedge funds.

title: Virgin Group: Private Equity Firm?
description: Richard Branson and the Virgin Group are having a Blackstone Group moment.

title: KKR Financial to Raise Up to $500 Million
description: KKR Financial, the affiliate of Kohlberg Kravis Roberts that has suffered from the subprime mortgage mess, said on Monday that it plans to raise $500 million from a stake sale to institutional investors and rights to shareholders.

title: Morning Buzz: Many Strands in Investigation of Ground Zero Fire That Killed 2
description: The aftermath of the deadly fire on Saturday that tore through the vacant Deutsche Bank building in Lower Manhattan dominated headlines for a second day today. The Timess package of coverage includes:

title: QuickBits: Calacanis, Moritz and Blodget, Oh My
description: Whats news on blogs and in publications:

title: 2008: Out of Iowa
description: After a week when many of the Democratic candidates lavished their attention on voters in Iowa, some are taking a break from the states coffee shops and corn fields over the next few days.

title: Beijings Weekend Smog Experiment
description: Among the more awe-inspiring things China has pledged to do to prepare for the 2008 Olympic games was to turn the skies over Beijing blue again.

title: A Big-City Mayor in a Small Town
description: Before his trip to the state fair, Rudolph W. Giuliani went off the beaten path to a series of intimate meetings with rural voters in Iowa.

title: Behind the Lens: Vogue Eyewear
description: Shopvogue.tv, a new broadband Internet channel, allows users to watch runway shows and Vogue-created series like "Behind the Lens."

title: Blackstone, Behind the Kitchen Counter?
description: After two of New Yorks most celebrated restaurateurs, Giuseppe and Arrigo Cipriani, pleaded guilty to tax fraud earlier this summer, questions have arisen over the fate of their eponymous restaurant empire.

title: Remembering Leona Helmsley
description: Updated, 4:25 p.m. | Reactions to the death of Leona Helmsley, the hotel operator and real estate developer whose conviction on federal tax evasion charges in 1989 became an emblem of the greedy excesses of the 1980s, have been fairly strong, judging from the dozens of comments that have been posted here since the morning.

title: And One from Column B
description: O.K., lets forget for the moment that Hillary Clinton hasnt won anything yet, and join those like Robert Novak and Stanley Fish, who are already gaming the veep race.

title: The Skim
description: A quick hike through the Sunday (and a few non-Sunday) book review sections.

title: Thornburg Sells $20.5 Billion in Mortgage-Backed Securities
description: Thornburg Mortgage, which forced to stop taking home-loan applications earlier this month because of a cash crunch, said it sold $20.5 billion of mortgage-backed securities as part of a plan to return to business as usual.

title: Lazard Hires 2 for Japanese Unit
description: Lazard said on Monday that it has hired two executives for its Japanese investment banking unit, as it seeks to bulk up that team as part of its global expansion efforts. The boutique investment bank appointed Kazuki Kusaka as a managing director and chief operating officer and Hideo Aono as a director and chief financial officer.

title:
Talk to the Newsroom:
Regional Editor Jodi Rudoren
description: Jodi Rudoren, The Times's deputy metropolitan editor for regional news, answered questions from readers Aug. 20-24, 2007.

title: U-17 World Cup Update
description: The United States U-17 World Cup team was upset Monday by Tajikistan, 4-3, in a wild, back-and-forth game in Changwon, South Korea. This puts the young Americans in a dangerous spot in Group E.

title: Meridian Board Rejects Yamana Golds Bid
description: Meridian Golds board of directors unanimously recommended that shareholders reject a revised bid from Yamana Gold, calling it inadequate in a statement on Monday morning.

title: Some Leading Indicators on Iraq
description: The debate over the success of the Baghdad surge has been thickened by at least two less-than-sunny additions.

title: Bidens Iowa Ads Focus on Iraq Plan
description: Senator Joe Biden went on the air in Iowa yesterday with the first of two television ads meant to highlight his foreign policy experience and his plan for ending the war in Iraq.

title: Corrections
description: The Times welcomes comments and suggestions, or complaints about errors that warrant correction. Messages on news coverage can be e-mailed to nytnews@nytimes.com or left toll-free at 1-888-NYT-NEWS (1-888-698-6397). Comments on editorials may be e-mailed to letters@nytimes.com or faxed to (212) 556-3622.

title: Anand Wins Rapid Championship at Mainz; Navara Wins Open
description: Viswanathan Anand of India atoned for his loss in the Chess960 championship at the Mainz Chess Classic by turning around and winning the traditional rapid championship three days later. Anand beating Levon Aronian of Armenia, his vanguisher in Chess960. The games and results from all of the events at the Mainz Classic can be found at its official Web site.

title: Deutsche Bank Borrows From Fed Discount Window
description: Ever since the Federal Reserve cut its discount lending rate on Friday to help open the markets amid the debt implosion, people have been wondering who would take advantage of the Feds move. Citing unnamed sources, The Financial Times on Monday offered one name: Deutsche Bank.

title:
Animals Were Harmed
During the Writing of This Book
description: In the new issue of The Atlantic Monthly, the critic B. R. Myers dumps  from a great height  on big eaters and non-vegetarians, using as his texts Best American Food Writing 2006 and Michael Pollans The Omnivores Dilemma. His piece is called Hard to Swallow. A better title would have been Against Pigging Out.

title: Clinton at the V.F.W. Convention
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  No, she did not get booed.

title: Cribs: Venture Capital Edition
description: Theres no question that the lifestyles of the private equity crowd have been on display recently. Tales of lavish birthday parties and multimillion-dollar Park Avenue apartments helped drive the current Congressional push to raise the tax rates on buyout firms profits, notably those made from carried interest.

title: Talking Trash: Stricter Penalties for Garbage in Public Bins
description: It is illegal to put household or business trash in a public litter basket, but many people do so.

title: J.P. Morgans Chakrabortti Joins Morgan Stanley
description: J.P. Morgan Chases chief equity strategist has now jumped to a different top perch.

title: Cheap Flights
description: Affordable air service is often a driving force to resort development, allowing buyers quick access to their second homes or vacation retreats. With that in mind, a few noteworthy bulletins on new routes offered by budget airlines:

title: Sounding the Warning Bell
description: Paul Krugman responds to readers comments on his Aug. 17 column, Its a Miserable Life.

title: Solent Closes Battered Fund
description: In the latest instance of the credit crunch claiming a hedge fund victim, Solent Capital of Britain said Monday that it would wind down one of its funds because of the drop in value of its asset-backed securities.

title: Funeral Arrangements for 2 Firefighters
description: This afternoon, the Fire Department announced funeral arrangements for Firefighters Robert Beddia and Joseph Graffagnino, who were killed in the seven-alarm fire that consumed the Deutsche Bank building in Lower Manhattan on Saturday.

title: Odd News Springs From Serbia
description: Everyone loves an underdog, which is why a poor town in the north of Serbia has placed its hopes and dreams in Rocky Balboa. As the story that is proliferating in Google News goes, the village of Zitiste has decided to spark its comeback after years of flooding with the help of a replica of the Rocky statue that stands in Philadelphia.

title: Skype: Microsoft Update Took Us Down
description: This morning Skype released a statement explaining its two-day outage last week  and pinning the root cause on a routine Microsoft update to the Windows operating system that caused masses of users to reboot their PCs at the same time. In an interview last week, Skypes chief security officer said he did not think that Microsoft had anything to do with the services collapse. Skype engineers must have subsequently decided otherwise.

title: No Link Between Yakking and Crashing?
description: When it comes to the relationship between talking on the cell phone and crashing the car, two Berkeley graduate students are rear-ending conventional wisdom.

title: Changing Technology Politics: Cisco-Microsoft
description: In corporate technology circles, people talk of the red team  Microsoft and its allies  and the blue team  led by IBM and Cisco. Today John Chambers, the chief executive of Cisco, and Steven Ballmer, Microsofts chief executive, shared a stage in New York to announce an alliance of necessity.

title: Fear Itself
description: A couple of new polls on terrorism that wont brighten anybodys day: Britons are more suspicious of Muslims than Americans and other Europeans, according to a poll for the Financial Times.

title: Kendall, Out of His Comfort Zone
description: Training camp has been a three-point circus for the Jets offensive lineman Pete Kendall, and there are signs that both Kendall and the team are growing weary of the side-show created by his discontent with his contract. When a media relations assistant approached Kendall during the player availability following Mondays practice, his shoulders drooped visibly. As he walked over to the waiting T.V. cameras, Jets media relations coordinator Bruce Speight barked to his minions, Somebody needs to record Kendall.

title: Thompsons Senate Scorecard
description: With former Tennessee Senator Fred D. Thompson looking more and more like a presidential candidate, his productivity while he was in Congress will likely face scrutiny.

title: In Lower Manhattan, Worries About Emergency Plans
description: Many residents of Lower Manhattan, especially those who lived through 9/11, are not happy with how the city handled the fire that raged through the Deutsche Bank building on Saturday at 130 Liberty Street. As James Barron explains today, residents have expressed alarm that they were not notified in the hours after the fire broke out at 3:30 p.m. Moreover, some residents have argued that the city needs to develop a building-by-building evacuation plan for the area in the event of another calamity.Community Board 1 has scheduled a hearing to demand answers from relevant agencies involved in emergency response. The hearing is set for 6 p.m. on Tuesday in the 19th-floor State Assembly hearing room at 250 Broadway. In a statement, the Community Board said its chairwoman, Julie Menin, and the entire downtown community had many unanswered questions about what went wrong, why things went wrong, and what can/should/must be done to prevent more things from going wrong.

title: Messing With Iowa
description: Heres a bit of news that cannot make Senator Barack Obama happy as he goes about wooing the all-important Iowans: His campaign delayed their states entry into the Union by two years.

title: WCI Strikes Deal with Icahn to End Proxy Fight
description: In what appears to be a humbling development for WCI Communities, the homebuilder said on Monday that it has agreed to let Carl C. Icahn place three directors on its board, ending a long-running proxy fight.

title: Mrs. Helmsleys Conviction: Shock Hits the Hoity-Toity
description: Joseph P. Fried, a reporter for The Times, covered Leona Helmsleys conviction on tax evasion charges on Aug. 30, 1989. He filed an account of his experience with the trial of Mrs. Helmsley, whose death was announced this morning.

title: Help for Businesses Hurt in Steam-Pipe Blast
description: More than a month has passed since a steam pipe exploded in Midtown, but businesses in the vicinity of the blast, near Lexington Avenue and 41st Street, have continued to suffer economic repercussions.

title: Home Health Care Agencies Under Scrutiny
description: Call it the next big thing  well, potentially  in Medicaid fraud. Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo announced today that he had subpoenaed most of the certified home health care agencies operating in the New York City area, the endgame of a two-year investigation into the states home health care industry.

title: Rescue Moments Passed and Present
description: Last Friday, The Lede asked When Should Rescuers Give Up? A few days later, we have a three real-world answers, one hopeful and two that are much less so.

title: MotoGP and the Cult of Valentino Rossi
description: Josh Dean has a very cool article in the current issue of Play magazine about Nicky Hayden, last years champion in the international motorcycle series, MotoGP. Id have to say, it was a pleasant surprise to see the orange and yellow splash of the Repsol Honda RC212V in The Times. Dean does a great job capturing Haydens family life and his struggles coming off his World Championship season.

title: Answers From the Suburbanization of New York Editors
description: Following is the first set of responses from Jerilou Hammett and Kingsley Hammett, the editors of The Suburbanization of New York (Princeton Architectural Press, 2007). The book is a collection of 14 essays about the economic and social changes that have swept the city over the past two decades and the Hammetts, who are husband and wife, run DESIGNER/builder magazine. They are taking questions from City Room readers this week. Readers are invited to submit additional questions here.David: The book and article seem a bit Manhattan obsessed, no? Plenty of immigrants with new ways and flavors in Queens, Brooklyn and the Bronx  and even in Manhattan in Washington Heights and other neighborhoods.

title: Bloggers to the Ramparts! (Stop First at the Registration Booth)
description: They challenged old-world media, railed against corporate journalism, took political candidates to task, aggressively updated the world about their cereal recipes!

title: Ex-White House Spokesman Joins Debate Over Metal Bats
description: The use of aluminum bats in youth baseball and softball games has been hotly debated  perhaps nowhere more so, oddly enough, than in New York City. City Councilman James S. Oddo, a Staten Island Republican, has waged a campaign since 2001 to ban the use of the metal bats in high school games, citing examples of young people who were critically injured or killed by balls hit off such bats.

title: A 1337 Hero Falls
description: He was the original telephone hacker, Joybubbles, and today we belatedly mourn his passing  and remember the heyday of the phone phreaks, not to mention phones themselves  with some exclusive video.

title: Regarding Syria
description: Faiz Shakir at Think Progress tells us that Senator Joe Lieberman wrote in todays Wall Street Journal that the U.S. road to victory in Iraq goes through Damascus. Well, not exactly, but Lieberman did say that the United States must begin focusing on Syria, through which up to 80% of the Iraq-bound extremists transit. Indeed, even terrorists from countries that directly border Iraq travel by land via Syria to Iraq, instead of directly from their home countries, because of the permissive environment for terrorism that the Syrian government has fostered.

title: Blogtalk: Brothels, Rides  and Brrr, Its Going to Be Cold
description: What were reading on the local blogs

title: Obama on Obama Girl
description: The Obama Girl video  that spicy homage to Illinois Senator and presidential candidate Barack Obama  has been steaming up computer screens since its debut in June. The clip has racked up more than 3.1 million views on YouTube.

title: China's Investment in Africa Comes With a Price
description: Textile mills and other factories in Zambia and South Africa have suffered as cheap Chinese goods flood the world market.

title: Heading to Lowes (Part 2)
description: Along with Alisons dad and stepmother, we were heading to Lowes to look at kitchen cabinets (and maybe doors, windows and floors).

title: What I Did on My Summer Vacation
description: Virgil Griffith has been hit with instant celebrity since putting up his WikiScanner Web site last week, which traces the source of millions of changes to Wikipedia.

title: Kerrey Waits for Hagel to Decide
description: Could Bob Kerrey  the former Nebraska senator, governor, one-time presidential candidate, almost New York City mayoral candidate and current president of the New School  be thinking about getting back into politics?

title: Adams Wins Staunton Memorial, Dutch Win the Competition
description: Michael Adams of England won the Fifth Howard Staunton Memorial, held in London at Simpsons-in-the-Strand from Aug. 7-18. Adams, the top seed in the tournament and No. 15 in the world, was the only player to go undefeated. Games from the tournament can be replayed at its official Web site.

title: A Shroud Over Ground Zero
description: The deaths of two firefighters in the remains of the Deutsche Bank building have brought new attention to the languishing demolition project.

title: Is There Anything Good About Men? And Other Tricky Questions
description: What percentage of your ancestors were men?

title: Kazakhstan: Leader Savors Sweep
description: The party of Nursultan A. Nazarbayev, the authoritarian president who has been in power since the Soviet era, trounced all competitors in parliamentary elections over the weekend, taking all 98 contested seats. Leaders of the main opposition group, the All-National Social Democratic Party, said it would contest the results, and election monitors for the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe said they had found flaws in the vote counting in more than 40 percent of the polling places they visited. But the leader of the monitoring team, Consiglio Di Nino, said the elections, nonetheless, offered some progress. In the capital, Astana, Mr. Nazarbayev observed: There are winners and losers at all elections, but in the current situation I believe that all Kazakhstan citizens have won.

title: Criticism of a Gender Theory, and a Scientist Under Siege
description: In academic feuds, as in war, there is no telling how far people will go once the shooting starts.

title: In Unsteady Waters, a Solid Foundation
description: Unlike a gymnast, who launches into a series of flips and twists by pushing against a solid surface, a synchronized swimmer is forbidden to touch the floor, so stability and propulsion for a lift or a throw must come from a teammate who is known as the base. The base is often supported by six other teammates suspended underwater, whipping their legs like egg-beaters and holding their breath, sometimes in the final seconds of an exhausting four-minute routine.

title: Hazards: Smokeless Tobacco on Par With Cigarettes
description: Smokeless tobacco, the kind users put between cheek and gum, is one way to satisfy a craving for nicotine without offensive smoke. But a new study has found that it may be almost as effective as cigarettes in delivering nicotine and carcinogens.

title: Turkey: Gul Falls Short, for Now
description: In a first round of voting, Abdullah Gul, the foreign minister, fell short of the two-thirds majority needed in Parliament to become president. A second round is set for Friday. Mr. Gul, left, an observant Muslim, is opposed by the secular establishment, which includes the army, judiciary and bureaucracy, and which believes that he holds an Islamist agenda. He is widely expected to be elected in the third round, next week, when only a simple parliamentary majority will be needed.
A film review in Weekend on Friday about Marigold referred incorrectly to the rating. It is PG-13; it is not unrated.

title: In Climbing Everest, Survival Rates Favor 40-and-Under Crowd
description: Climbing Mount Everest is hardly a walk in the park, but despite the risks about 1,500 people try to reach the summit each year. This year, more than 600 climbers made it to the top, and 6 people died trying.

title: An Old Record Shop May Fall Victim to Harlems Success
description: Bobby Robinson sat in a lawn chair in the Harlem record store he opened before R & B music got its name, speaking softly about days of old and of an uncertain future, his strong face barely betraying his 90 years of life.

title: China Relaxes a Barrier, Letting Citizens Invest in the Hong Kong Stock Market
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 20  The Chinese government announced today that it would allow mainland Chinese citizens to invest in the Hong Kong stock market, the most significant move to date by Beijing officials to dismantle the barriers that prevent most Chinese from making international investments.

title: Martnez Takes a Step in Front of His Friends
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., Aug. 20  Pedro Martnez clearly took his most decisive step Monday night toward being ready to return to the Mets. Still, he is expected to make at least one more minor league start.

title: A Jets Lineman Learns a Lesson the Hard Way
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Aug. 20  Adrian Jones was complimented on his driving the other day, his aggressiveness during a blocking drill earning praise from the Jets offensive line coach, Tony Wise.

title: Federal Court Delays Wild Oats Acquisition
description: The acquisition of Wild Oats Markets by Whole Foods Market was delayed yesterday by a federal appeals court in Washington.

title: Senator Threatens to Charge White House With Contempt
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20  A leading Democrat threatened on Monday to pursue contempt charges against the White House next month over its response to a subpoena for internal documents on the National Security Agencys domestic surveillance program.

title: Dylan Movie to Open Like a Rolling Premiere
description: Imagine youre a film distributor, handling an experimental movie by one of the countrys most iconoclastic directors. The subject is an enigmatic occasional recluse who is being portrayed by four actors, an actress and a 13-year-old boy. Where do you open that film?

title: The Devil Wears Herms (He Bought It at the Caesars Palace Mall in Las Vegas)
description: Back in the late 1980s, the Prada backpack  made out of black or tobacco-brown parachute fabric trimmed in leather  became the it bag for many would-be fashionistas. It was hip, modern, lightweight and at $450 expensive, but not as expensive as the stratospherically priced bags made by Herms and Chanel. According to the fashion reporter Dana Thomas, that Prada backpack was also the emblem of the radical change that luxury was undergoing at the time: the shift from small family businesses of beautifully handcrafted goods to global corporations selling to the middle market  a shift from exclusivity to accessibility, from an emphasis on tradition and quality to an emphasis on growth and branding and profits.

title: Nascar Postpones Race Again and Considers Backup Plans
description: A few days of rain in Michigan this week could force major changes to Nascars Nextel Cup playoff chase.

title: Vick in a Deal to Plead Guilty to Dogfighting
description: RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 20  Michael Vick, the star quarterback of the Atlanta Falcons, agreed Monday to plead guilty to dogfighting charges in a deal with federal prosecutors that will probably land him in prison while he is in the prime of his N.F.L. career.

title: Mets Acquire Conine for Two Class A Players
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20  Jeff Conine has been traded toward the end of a season three times in the past five years. Conines postseason experience places him in high demand among teams in a pennant race, and the Mets acquired him Monday from the Cincinnati Reds to bolster their bench.

title: Storm Homes In on Mexico After Sweep of the Caribbean
description: FELIPE CARRILLO PUERTO, Mexico, Aug. 20  She had stuffed the familys clothes in plastic bags, put crosses of tape across the windows of her hair salon here and bought canned food for 15 days to feed 10 relatives.

title: Space Shuttle Lands Safely Despite Gouge
description: KENNEDY SPACE CENTER, Aug. 21  The space shuttle Endeavour glided to a safe landing here at 12:32 p.m. Eastern time, apparently not much worse for wear.

title: Firemens Funerals
description: The funerals of two firefighters who died in a blaze on Saturday at the former Deutsche Bank building at ground zero have been scheduled for later this week.

title: Losing Patience
description: Dirk Kempthornes arrival in Washington as secretary of the interior raised hope among conservationists that he would moderate the Bush administrations aggressive search for oil and gas in some of the countrys most environmentally sensitive lands. This has not happened. The Bureau of Land Management, which issues drilling leases and permits, seems to moving as recklessly as it did under Mr. Kempthornes predecessor, Gale Norton, and even the administrations natural allies have finally had enough.

title: Birds Band Together to Raise Offspring in Dire Times
description: In uncertain times, its nice to think that people band together to help one another.

title: Governor of Iraqi Province Assassinated
description: BAGHDAD, Aug. 20  An Iraqi provincial governor was assassinated by a roadside bomb on Monday in an attack that officials said was a result of an internal power struggle with rival Shiite militias, rather than sectarian violence.

title: Bushs Talks With Neighbors Are Overshadowed by Storm
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 20  President Bush met in a wooded resort east of here on Monday with his counterparts to the north and the south  Prime Minister Stephen Harper of Canada and President Felipe Caldern of Mexico  to discuss the drafting of emergency border provisions, the stalled international trade talks, and immigration.

title: New DVDs
description: THREE BY LUIS BUUEL

title: Albany: Spitzer Approves Hydropower Contract
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer approved low-cost hydropower contracts yesterday with western New York municipalities, the Tuscarora Nation and Niagara University. The contracts are part of the agreements to relicense the Niagara Power Project in Niagara Falls, New York States largest power generator. Federal officials approved an application in March to renew the license until September 2057, with low-cost power for local communities part of the agreement that led to the relicensing, state officials said. The project, operated by the New York Power Authority, opened in 1961. Its 13 turbines generate 2,441 megawatts.

title: Feasting on Some Moderns in an Oh-So-Modern Setting
description: Rodins Balzac, a craggy emblem of modernity, kept his head turned away from the musicians sitting to his left on Sunday night. Behind him the windowed wall of the Agnes Gund Garden Lobby at the Museum of Modern Art framed a view of the damp, cold sculpture garden. Auguring autumn, the weather drove the last of the four Juilliard concerts in this years Summergarden series indoors, where the view was just as good and the acoustics were much better: all that interfered was the constant high feedback buzz of a hearing aid (or was it the sound systems speakers?) rather than the sounds of passing traffic.

title: Harvard Endowment Reports 23% Gain for Year
description: The Harvard Management Company, which oversees the universitys endowment, reported today that the endowment had posted a 23 percent gain for the fiscal year ended June 30.

title: Overarchingly Elgar: Victorian, Modern, Worldly and Quite British
description: ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Aug. 19  Few British composers have made as striking an impression on music at an international level as Edward Elgar. Recognizable even now in old photographs for his regal bearing and walrus mustache, in his day Elgar was the highly visible symbol for a glorious resurgence of British music at the dawn of the 20th century. Yet despite the continued popularity of a few pieces, Elgars eminence was in the end surprisingly short-lived.

title: Bush Admits Frustration With Iraqi Leader
description: MONTEBELLO, Canada, Aug. 21  President Bush today acknowledged a certain level of frustration with the leadership in Iraq, and for at least the third time this summer declined to offer an endorsement of Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, the man he once called the right guy for Iraq.

title: Washing After Sex May Raise H.I.V. Risk
description: A study in Uganda has come up with a surprising finding about sex and H.I.V. Washing the penis minutes after sex increased the risk of acquiring H.I.V. in uncircumcised men.

title: Leona Helmsley, Hotel Queen, Is Dead at 87
description: Leona Helmsley, the self-styled hotel queen whose prison term for income tax evasion and fraud was greeted with uncommon approval by a public who regarded her as a 1980s symbol of arrogance and greed, died yesterday at her home in Greenwich, Conn. She was 87.

title: The Future of Textbooks (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Wars Chilling Reality
description: Bryan Anderson, a 25-year-old Army sergeant who was wounded in Iraq, was explaining, on camera  to James Gandolfini, of all people  what happened immediately after a roadside bomb blew up the Humvee that he was driving.

title: To Reap Psychotherapys Benefits, Get a Good Fit
description: Americans seem to like psychotherapy. Whether its for the mundane conflicts of everyday life or life-threatening illnesses like major depression, psychotherapy is widely viewed as a healthy, if not harmless, pursuit.

title: Two Studios to Support HD DVD Over Rival
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 20  Hollywoods squabble over which of two technologies will replace standard DVDs reignited Monday with two studios throwing their weight behind one format and several rivals ramping up support for the other.

title: A Life of Protest and Forgiveness
description: Ben Chaney stood to the side watching mourners fill a grave with the New York soil that gave Carolyn Goodman her eternal blanket.

An article on Saturday about Republican members of the House who have said they will not seek re-election next year misstated the decision of a House Democrat, Luis V. Gutierrez of Illinois. While he announced 18 months ago that he would not seek re-election, he said Thursday that he had changed his mind and would seek a ninth term.

title: Ronald Bracewell, 86, Radio Telescope Pioneer, Dies
description: Ronald N. Bracewell, an astronomer and engineer who used radio telescopes to make early images of the Suns surface, in work that also led to advances in medical imaging, died on Aug. 12 at his home in Stanford, Calif. He was 86.

title: Learning the Simple Life With Stanley of the North
description: Arctic Son, the documentary to be shown tonight on the PBS series P.O.V., follows Stanley Njootli Jr., a 20-something would-be artist, from his aimless existence in Seattle to the Yukon Territory of Canada, a trip taken at his fathers invitation.

title: Swallows Summer Vacation Nears an End
description: A COLONY of purple martin swallows seems to be enjoying the summer on Ocean Driveway at Annadale Beach on Staten Island. The swallows twitter by several openings of the elaborate hexagonal four-story birdhouse set up just for them, white with green trim and 24 openings and terraces.

title: More Students Finish School, Given the Time
description: Faced with 70,000 students or more who are years behind in obtaining the credits needed to graduate from high school, New York City is at the forefront of a movement to recognize that for a significant number, high school might stretch into five, six, even seven years.

title: Plenty of Apples, but Possibly a Shortage of Immigrant Pickers
description: HAMPTONBURGH, N.Y., Aug. 16  With a look of supreme satisfaction, Jeff Crist squinted at the Ginger Golds and Jonamacs ripening under an incandescent sun at his apple orchard here: the trees were so laden that they almost seemed to strain under the effort.

title: Seacrest at the Emmys
description: The busiest man in show business keeps getting busier. Ryan Seacrest, below, the host of American Idol, successor to Casey Kasem on American Top 40, co-host of Dick Clarks New Years Rockin Eve and ubiquitous red-carpet reporter, will be master of ceremonies at the 59th primetime Emmy Awards in Los Angeles on Sept. 16, the Fox network announced yesterday. Mr. Seacrest, 32, will also act as host of the entertainment portion of Foxs Super Bowl broadcast early next year. He was chosen for both roles to attract younger viewers to the tradition-bound broadcasts. Dick Askin, the chairman and chief executive of the Academy of Telvision Arts and Sciences, said Mr. Seacrest should serve as a magnet for viewers, including the highly desirable young-adult demographic.

title: Telltale Isotopes in Marijuana Are Natures Tracking Devices
description: Every so often, a package of marijuana arrives in Jason B. Wests mail at the University of Utah in Salt Lake City. While Dr. West may not be the only one on campus receiving deliveries of illegal drugs, he is probably the only one getting them compliments of the federal government.

title: That Shakespeare Guy Has Them Roaring
description: At one point in Twelfth Night, in her vain pursuit of the in-drag Viola, Olivia exclaims, If one should be a prey, how much the better to fall before the lion than the wolf! Then, at least in the Dog Run Rep version seen Thursday at the Space Gallery, and as played by Margaret Nichols, Olivia gives a come-on of a little roar.

title: Plaintiffs Find Payday Elusive in Vioxx Cases
description: KEENE, Tex.  In Carol Ernsts eyes, two years ago she won a measure of justice.

title: At Risk: Isolating the Factors Involved in Breast Cancer
description: Breast density and high levels of circulating sex hormones are independent risk factors for breast cancer in postmenopausal women, a new study finds.

title: A Fear of Foreign Investments
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20  For years, the Bush administration has shrugged off concerns about the trillions of dollars that the United States owes to China, Japan and oil-producing countries in the Middle East, arguing that these debts give no undue leverage to foreign governments.

title: Brooklyn: Four Men Convicted in Attack
description: Four men were convicted yesterday in State Supreme Court of breaking into a mans home and attacking him last August in an attempt to learn the location of a young Pakistani couple planning to marry against the wishes of the bride-to-bes father, prosecutors said yesterday. The men  Javed Khalid, 53; Azad Malik, 67; Hussain Sada, 29; and Shafiq Mohammed, 41  were convicted of first-degree burglary, said Charles J. Hynes, the Brooklyn district attorney. Mr. Hynes said that the four men forced their way into the West Sixth Street home of Rana Hussain, 48, handcuffed him and punched and kicked him. They demanded the location of Mr. Hussains nephew, then 19, and Mr. Khalids 15-year-old daughter, who had met at James Madison High School and planned to marry, Mr. Hynes said. He said the girl had been promised to a man in Pakistan. Mr. Hynes said they beat Mr. Hussain with a pipe and threatened to shoot him, but he did not say where the couple was. Each of the men faces up to 25 years in prison, prosecutors said.

title: Letters
description: Get Off the Couch

title: Equity Firm to Get Infusion of Cash
description: KKR Financial Holdings, the affiliate of the private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, said yesterday that it would get a $500 million cash infusion after losses from residential mortgages.

title: Russia: BBC Removed From FM Station
description: An FM radio station in Moscow has dropped the BBC Russian Service, the latest in a series of moves that have reduced access in Russia to news produced by Western news organizations. The stations new owners dropped the service on Friday, saying that broadcasting retransmitted content was limited by the terms of the stations license; a similar technicality knocked content from Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty from the air last year at most Russian stations. News on Russian FM radio has lost much of the diversity, as independent and skeptical coverage has been replaced by pro-Kremlin broadcasts and content determined to be positive by station supervisors. The BBC said it planned to appeal the decision to the federal service that administers radio licenses.

title: Can Private Equity Firms Get Out of Buyouts?
description: The whispering persists.

title: The Leona Chronicles
description: The news that Leona Helmsley died yesterday at 87 reminded me of the time I interviewed her husband, Harry, the real-estate magnate who owned a vast empire of Manhattan hotels, office towers and apartment complexes in the 1980s. He was over 70, the first billionaire I had ever met, and I asked him whether he had ever thought about devoting the final segment of his career to good works, like helping the homeless.

title: Ancient Protein Tells a Story of Changing Functions
description: Offering insight into how evolution progresses inside a gene, scientists have pinpointed mutations in an ancient protein that transformed its shape and function more than 400 million years ago.

title: Giving Human Intuition a Place in Airport Security
description: BACK when Times Square was less carefree, a retired New York City police officer I know used to play a private game called Spot the Perp. Walking along Eighth Avenue or on the Deuce, as the then-crime-ridden block of 42nd Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues was known, the former officer would try to pick out from the crowd the person most likely to commit at least a Class B misdemeanor by midnight.

title: Memo Pad
description: FIRST COMMERCIAL A380 FLIGHT Singapore Airlines will begin auctioning seats on eBay next Monday for the first commercial flight of the A380 superjumbo jet, scheduled for Oct. 25 from Singapore to Sydney. Proceeds will go to charity. Singapore will be the first airline to take delivery of the long-delayed Airbus double-decker aircraft, which is certified to hold 853 passengers in a single-class configuration. Singapore said it would configure its A380s with 471 seats in three classes: economy, business and what the airline calls a class beyond first. No United States carriers have ordered the planes, but international airlines that are buying A380s have all said they intend to fly them with no more than about 550 passengers in economy and premium cabins. Singapore, which has ordered 19 A380s, has not yet unveiled its new first-class cabins for the jets, but is expected to do so soon. A380s have previously flown passengers on noncommercial demonstration flights.

title: Jet Li Attacks Censors
description: Jet Li, the martial-arts movie star, has voiced frustration that his Hollywood films do not get shown in his home country, China, The Associated Press reported yesterday. Writing in his blog, alivenotdead.com/26, Mr. Li, above, said his 2000 film Romeo Must Die had been banned by censors for featuring gangsters. In 2001, Kiss of the Dragon was banned because Mr. Lis character, a Chinese policeman, killed people overseas. Mr. Li argued that Chinas film industry was suffering as a result of the restrictions. If gangsters arent appropriate and police officers arent appropriate, then what type of character can there be that wouldnt start an argument? Mr. Li wrote. It leaves only the ancient Chinese stories to be produced." China officially allows only about 20 foreign movies to be shown each year.

title: Solving Murders Is Gory When Youre Clueless
description: Tired of complaining about how much sex there is on television? Watch Murder and complain instead about violence.

title: As Japan and India Forge Economic Ties, a Counterweight to China Is Seen
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 20  When Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan touches down in India this week, it will be the highest-level step yet in what analysts say is a long-term effort to balance, if not contain, Chinas growing economic and political might.

title: Not Paying for Medical Errors
description: Medicare, the government insurance program for older Americans, has announced that it will soon stop paying hospitals for the extra costs of treating certain patients whose illnesses are compounded by preventable errors. The effort wont save much money at first, and it will impose additional testing and documentation burdens on many hospitals, but it should promote better care. If the initial steps are expanded, it could yield greater savings as well.

title: HSBC in Talks to Acquire a Big Stake in Korean Bank
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 20  HSBC Holdings said Monday that it was in talks with a Texas-based private equity fund, Lone Star Funds, to buy a majority stake in Korea Exchange Bank, which would give HSBC a long-sought retail banking network in one of Asias largest economies.

title: Discovering How the Maya Fed the Multitude
description: An enduring question about the Maya civilization in its heyday in the first millennium A.D. has been: How did they feed so many people?

title: Deals for Ford Units Seen Fairly Soon
description: DEARBORN, Mich., Aug. 20  Ford Motor may have chosen the new owner for Jaguar and Land Rover by the time it reports its third-quarter results in October.

title: Regimens: Antioxidants Dont Lessen Strokes for at-Risk Women
description: Supplements of the antioxidants beta carotene, vitamin C and vitamin E may be good for you, but a new study reports that they have no effect, either alone or in combination, in preventing heart attack, stroke or death among women at risk for cardiovascular disease.
A theater review yesterday about the Broadway revival of Grease misspelled the given name of the actress who plays Frenchy. She is Kirsten Wyatt, not Kristen.

title: New Advice by N.F.L. in Handling Concussions
description: Several N.F.L. players in recent years have been knocked unconscious during games and returned to play the same day, a practice that was deemed medically sound by the leagues committee on brain injuries.

title: Injuries in Cruise Film
description: Eleven extras were injured in Berlin on Sunday when they fell out of a truck during the filming of a movie starring Tom Cruise, The Associated Press reported yesterday. The injured were taken to a hospital as filming stopped on the movie, provisionally titled Valkyrie, which stars Mr. Cruise as Germanys most famous anti-Hitler plotter, Col. Claus Graf Schenk von Stauffenberg. All but one of the 11 were released after treatment. The German newspaper Bild reported that Mr. Cruise had not been involved in the weekend filming. The police said that a bolt on a side panel of the truck apparently came loose as the vehicle turned. The accident happened during filming around the Finance Ministry building in Berlin, which was once the Nazis aviation ministry. Mr. Cruises participation in the film has attracted controversy in Germany because he is an adherent of Scientology, which the German government frowns on.

title: Hurricane Loses Strength as It Crosses Mexico
description: CHETUMAL, Mexico, Aug. 21  Hurricane Dean hammered Mexicos Yucatn Peninsula with blistering winds and heavy rain on Tuesday, missing the prime tourist spots of the Mayan Riviera but causing damage in the provincial capital of Chetumal, before being downgraded from Category 5 down to Category 2.

The Talking Business column in Business Day on Saturday, about hedge funds that invest according to computer models, misstated the title of Roger Lowensteins book about the collapse of Long-Term Capital Management, which used that technique. It is When Genius Failed, not When Geniuses Fail.

title: A Resource Center Even a Microsoft Hater Can Love
description: The folks who cant stand Microsoft are legion. If you go to Google and type in I hate Microsoft you will get more than 20 million links. Having a near monopoly in personal computer operating software will engender that kind of response.

title: Trade Panel Supports Request to Put Duties on Chinese Tires
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (Bloomberg News)  Titan International, the biggest American maker of off-road tires, won an initial ruling from the federal government in its bid to have duties imposed on $340 million worth of similar tires from China.

title: Thai Vote Shows Division Among Classes Is Simmering
description: BANGKOK, Aug. 20  A referendum that approved a new Constitution for Thailand brought a deep social rift into the open, one likely to be a factor in an election later this year and to divide the country for a long time to come, analysts said Monday.

title: Risky Loans and a Jittery Economy (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: On TV, Its All Beckham, All the Time
description: David Beckham is a well-distributed superstar, but as the savior of Major League Soccer, its no surprise that he is spread across six TV channels.

title: 2005 Incomes, on Average, Still Below 2000 Peak
description: Americans earned a smaller average income in 2005 than in 2000, the fifth consecutive year that they had to make ends meet with less money than at the peak of the last economic expansion, new government data shows.

title: Cutting Cholesterol, an Uphill Battle
description: Last December, a routine nonfasting blood test revealed that my total cholesterol level, which had long wavered between 190 and 205 milligrams per deciliter of blood serum, was now 222 and flagged as high by the laboratorys computer. A heart-healthy reading should be under 200.

title: Illegal Immigrant Advocate for Families Is Deported
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 20  The federal authorities said Monday that the deporting of a Mexican woman who had sought refuge in churches while being an advocate for illegal immigrant families had not signaled a crackdown on religious groups that provide aid to illegal immigrants.

title: Take Al Qaeda to Court
description: AS the need to close the Guantnamo Bay detention facility becomes more urgent, the question that derails all conversation on the subject is, Yes, but what do we do with the detainees? Some have proposed a new national-security court, a special system to detain and try terrorism suspects, as an answer.

title: Nasdaq to Sell Stake in London Exchange
description: LONDON, Aug. 20  Nasdaq put its stake in the London Stock Exchange up for sale Monday, ending a year-and-a-half-long attempt to buy the rival  one that has included a hostile bid, a dawn raid and a 48-page public defense circular.

title: With Season in Focus, Wrights Vision Is Clear 30/30
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20  David Wrights mind is in overdrive. He is processing the score, the inning, the count and the number of outs. He is studying the pitchers time to home plate, his pickoff move and, if he can sneak a peek, his grip.

title: Seeds Without Bees
description: Q. If North American dandelions have evolved to reproduce asexually, without the need to attract insects for pollination, why do they have those pretty yellow flowers?

title: A Museum in Search of a Home
description: The Dahesh Museum of Art is looking for a new home, it confirmed yesterday, and hopes to find one in Manhattan. The rent is high; its been more difficult than we thought to be in this expensive location, said Pamela M. Dunn, a spokeswoman for the museum, which occupies the first three floors of the IBM Building on Madison Avenue between 56th and 57th Streets. The museums lease runs until 2013, but it is negotiating to sublet its space while simultaneously seeking temporary offices. The Dahesh board, which looked into 2 Columbus Circle before the Museum of Arts and Design bought that building from the city, has also considered sites in upstate New York and in Connecticut, Ms. Dunn said, but would like to stay in Manhattan if possible. A lot of our visitors are tourists, scholars and artists, she said. The museum focuses on European artists of the 19th and early 20th centuries.

title: Investors, on Edge, Grab Up Treasury Bills
description: The stock market was quiet yesterday, but debt markets were anything but.

title: 15 Hussein Aides on Trial in Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD, Aug. 21  The man known as Chemical Ali for his role in gassing villages in northern Iraq stood up and identified himself as the fighter, Ali Hassan al-Majid today, during the first day of the trial for his role in suppressing the 1991 uprising in the south of the country.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,697 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: Clinton and McCain Differ on Iraq at Veterans Meeting
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 20  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton told an audience of war veterans on Monday that some elements of the strategy in Iraq appeared to be achieving success, but said a military solution was unattainable and the best way to honor the service of American troops was to bring them home.

title: Another Deadly Tower Downtown
description: The lessons of the latest disaster at the World Trade Center site are still being pulled from the debris of the fire that killed two New York firefighters in the ghostly remains of the old Deutsche Bank building. But it is clear that this black-shrouded structure should be taken down now with extraordinary concern about protecting the workers and the community around ground zero.

title: Lottery Numbers
Its Lonesome in This Old Town, Until You Go Underground
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 20  Where is everybody?

title: Cuomo, Investigating Medicaid Fraud, Issues Subpoenas to 59 Home Care Agencies
description: ALBANY, Aug. 20  Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo issued subpoenas on Monday to dozens of agencies that provide home health care aides to Medicaid patients in the New York City area, saying preliminary evidence suggested that the home aide industry was rife with fraud.

title: Vick Gambled With Career, and Lost
description: Michael Vick is almost surely going to jail and his football career is probably over. All the years he spent as a pampered celebrity in the general vicinity of education did not provide him with the insight that torturing dogs is not good and, besides that, could get him in trouble.

title: At Least 20 Are Dead in Separate Rainstorms
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 20  Fierce storms that deluged widely separated parts of the country from the upper Mississippi to Texas have caused at least 20 deaths since last week, the authorities said Monday. New rain threatened further flooding in southeastern Minnesota and adjacent Wisconsin.

title: Minnesotans, United (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Golf a Hit on Cruise Ships
description: For years, cruise passengers enjoyed hitting golf balls into the ocean with no pin in sight. The fun ended in 1990 when the International Maritime Organization prohibited the dumping of plastic waste into the sea, which included those little white balls.

title: The Hague: Liberians Trial Off Till 2008
description: For the fourth time this year, judges for the United Nations-backed Special Court for Sierra Leone postponed the start of the war crimes trial of Charles G. Taylor, the former Liberian president. They set the new date for Jan. 7. The trial, dealing with murder, rape and mutilation, charges that stem from Mr. Taylors role in a decade of conflict in Sierra Leone, has been delayed since April as Mr. Taylor requested more time, more staff for his defense team and more legal aid funds. During the hearing yesterday, the judges agreed that the entirely new defense team now in place would be given four months to prepare their case.

title: Cutting Cholesterol, an Uphill Battle
description: Last December, a routine nonfasting blood test revealed that my total cholesterol level, which had long wavered between 190 and 205 milligrams per deciliter of blood serum, was now 222 and flagged as high by the laboratorys computer. A heart-healthy reading should be under 200.

title: U.S. Commander Given Tour by Chinese Military
description: BEIJING, Aug. 21  Amid repeated calls from the Bush administration for China to be more transparent about its military buildup, a visiting senior United States naval commander praised his Chinese counterpart here today for allowing a revealing tour of defense facilities and exercises.

title: Pakistan Releases a Man Accused of Aiding Al Qaeda
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Aug. 21  A Pakistani man accused of aiding Al Qaeda and imprisoned for three years, has been released, according to his lawyer, and American officials made clear their dismay at the news on Monday.

title: Hurricanes Path Reduces Urgency to Land Shuttle Tuesday, NASA Says
description: With Hurricane Dean on a path far to the south of Houston and NASAs mission control center at the Johnson Space Center, there is less rush for the space shuttle Endeavour to land today, mission managers said yesterday.

title: Yes, Deep-Fried Oreos, but Not in Trans Fats
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 17  The deep-fried Combo Plate may be a little more healthful this year at the Great Indiana State Fair. So say the fairs leaders, who, taking a step rarely seen in the realm of corn dogs and fried pickles, have banned oils with trans fats from all the fryers that line the grounds here.

title: Capital One Financial to Quit Residential Mortgage Business
description: In yet another casualty of the fallout in the mortgage industry, the Capital One Financial Corporation said yesterday that it would stop making residential mortgages and close GreenPoint Mortgage, its wholesale mortgage banking unit.

title: Rules May Limit Health Program  Aiding Children
description: The Bush administration, continuing its fight to stop states from expanding the popular Childrens Health Insurance Program, has adopted new standards that would make it much more difficult for New York, California and others to extend coverage to children in middle-income families.

title: Dodd Expresses Confidence in Fed
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21  Senator Christopher J. Dodd, the chairman of the Banking Committee, said today that he had he received assurances that the Federal Reserve was moving to deal with the turmoil spreading from the mortgage market. But he said the response from the Treasury was less encouraging.

title: Chinas Trade in Africa Carries a Price Tag
description: KABWE, Zambia  The courtyard in front of the Zambia China Mulungushi Textiles factory is so quiet, even at midday, that the fluttering of the ragged Chinese and Zambian flags is the only sound hanging in the air.

title: Afghanistan: Kidnap Motive Was Ransom
description: Hours after freeing a kidnapped German aid worker in a raid in Kabul, the Afghan police identified her four kidnappers as local criminals who had demanded a million-dollar ransom, and not Taliban militants. ORA International, the Christian aid group that employed the woman, Christina Meier, 31, said she had been treated well by her captors and allowed to call her husband, who also works for the group. The couple was eating lunch in a Kabul restaurant when she was kidnapped Saturday.

title: The Pernicious Allure of Lead
description: The human body needs a diet enriched with many ingredients from the periodic table that sound less like food than like machine parts or spare change. We must have iron to capture oxygen, copper and chromium to absorb energy, cobalt to sheathe our nerves and zinc to help finger our genes. Other creatures demand the occasional sprinkling of tin, nickel, platinum, tungsten and even strontium.

title: State Inspector General Defends Spitzer Inquiry
description: ALBANY, Aug. 20  The states inspector general, Kristine Hamann, defended her brief but turbulent tenure on Monday in her first detailed interview since her office became embroiled in a controversy over the Spitzer administrations effort to use the state police to tarnish a political rival.

title: Doherty Arrested Again
description: Police arrested Pete Doherty, the lead singer of Babyshambles, on Monday on suspicion of drug possession, The Associated Press reported yesterday. The troubled singer had been performing with his band at the V Festival in Staffordshire, England, on the weekend. He was stopped, along with another man and a woman, in a car in Tower Hamlets in East London. Earlier this month, a judge warned Mr. Doherty that he must prove his desire to quit drugs or face a jail sentence for other drug offenses. He has been undergoing drug treatment under court order because of previous convictions.

title: The Web Way to Magazine Ad Sales
description: THE September issue of Vogue arrives on newsstands today, clocking in at a record 727 advertising pages. That extra-extra large! size, as the cover proudly proclaims, is more than 100 pages fatter than last year and seems to provide evidence of a healthy appetite for print advertising in the fashion industry.

title: Soldiering On, Home to Home, in a Squeezed Health System
description: Annelisa Purdie, a visiting nurse, checks her supplies: stethoscope, blood pressure cuff, alcohol swabs, thermometer. Laptop computer. Air freshener. Good parking karma. Game face.

title: Venezuela: A Decree for the Clocks
description: Moved by claims that it will help the metabolism and productivity of his fellow citizens, President Hugo Chvez said clocks would be moved forward by half an hour at the start of 2008. He announced the change on his Sunday television program, accompanied by his highest-ranking science adviser, Hctor Navarro, the minister of science and technology. This is about the metabolic effect, where the human brain is conditioned by sunlight, Mr. Navarro said in comments reported by Venezuelas official news agency. Mr. Chvez said he was certain that the time change, which would be accompanied by a move to a six-hour workday, would be accepted.

title: Patterns: Weight May Influence School Attendance
description: The more overweight a child, the more likely he or she is to be absent from school, a new report suggests. Researchers studied 1,069 fourth- to sixth-grade students in nine schools in Philadelphia. They recorded height, weight, sex, race and days absent for each. The study appears in the August issue of Obesity.

title: Tenets C.I.A. Unprepared for Qaeda Threat, Report Says
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21  The former head of the Central Intelligence Agency, George J. Tenet, recognized the danger posed by Al Qaeda well before the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, but failed to adequately prepare the C.I.A. to meet the threat, according to an internal agency report that was released in summary form today.

title: Australian Court Rules for Indian

title: Giving Abandoned Bikes New Life So Students Can Ride
description: Emily Allen, 19, a sophomore at New York University, was surveying the rows of bicycle racks in a courtyard behind Tisch Hall over the weekend. Expensive road bikes and mountain bikes were parked there, but Ms. Allen focused on an old gold-colored bicycle with a rusted chain.

title: Utah Search for 6 Miners Is Suspended Indefinitely
description: HUNTINGTON, Utah, Aug. 20  Officials on Monday indefinitely suspended efforts to save six coal miners as a group of mining experts concluded that the area where the men were trapped was structurally unstable and would probably collapse again.

title: Pet Cats Serving as Canaries for a Home Pollutant
description: Hyperthyroidism in cats was virtually unknown three decades ago. But it has become common, particularly in older pets. As in people, cats overactive thyroids can lead to weight loss, rapid heartbeat and other problems.

description: To the Editor:

title: Pakistan Releases a Man Accused of Aiding Al Qaeda
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20  A Pakistani man accused of aiding Al Qaeda and imprisoned in his home country for three years, has been released, according to The Associated Press, and American officials made clear their dismay at the news on Monday.

Because of an editing error, the TV Watch column yesterday about Karl Roves appearances on Sunday-morning talk shows misstated the sponsor of a Washington dinner at which he once performed a rap routine. It was the Radio and Television Correspondents Association, not the White House Correspondents Association.

title: Giants Medical Report Is Delaying Progress
description: The Giants are suddenly confronted with a list of injuries that threatens to undermine their hopes for the looming regular season  concussions, tight hamstrings, a dislocated elbow and a blown Achilles tendon among them. And those were just the ones from the second quarter of Sundays preseason game against the Baltimore Ravens.

title: For Russians, Summer in the City Means a Freeze on Hot Water
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 20  The dour Moscow of cold war film strips is long gone, and this increasingly prosperous city fancies itself striding chest out into the future. But every summer, the people here get a taste of old-style deprivation, as if they were flung back to a time when they had to queue up at dawn to buy a few coils of mealy sausage.

title: A Hospital, Pulse of a Neighborhood, Is Mourned
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 20  It is nearly impossible to walk through Watts and find a person whose life has not intersected with Martin Luther King Jr.-Harbor Hospital.

title: Obama Tells Veterans Iraq Plan Is Failing
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 21  Senator Barack Obama said today that even if the military escalation in Iraq is showing limited signs of progress, diplomatic efforts for stabilizing the country have been a complete failure and American troops should not bear the brunt of prolonged sectarian strife.

title: Whats on Tonight
description: 9:30 P.M. (Sundance) INHERITANCE: A FISHERMANS STORY In this documentary Peter Hegedus shows what can go wrong when mining goes awry, as it did in January 2000 when 120,000 tons of cyanide spilled from a dam near a Romanian gold mine into the Tisza River, killing fish downstream in Hungary and affecting the livelihoods of fisherman who had worked the river for generations. Among them was Balazs Meszaros, above, who has since dedicated himself to rehabilitating his beloved waterway.

title: Democrats, Blaming a Hands-Off Approach, Press for Action to Aid Homeowners
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20  Democrats in Congress and on the presidential campaign trail are seizing on the turmoil in mortgages to criticize the Bush administrations laissez-faire approach to what they believe is a spreading crisis.

title: For a Maestro, Energy Is the Only Limitation
description: LUCERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 20  His baton kept a tight but flowing beat as his left hand, at the end of a thin wrist, went its own way, deftly sculpturing phrases and so often asking for less, less, less.

title: Gaza: Hamas Men Killed in Israeli Airstrike
description: Six Hamas fighters were killed in an Israeli ground-to-ground missile strike on their jeep as they were traveling near the Bureij refugee camp, Palestinian officials said. The Israeli Army said that the men had fired mortars at Israeli targets on Sunday and Monday. A Hamas spokesman, Sami Abu Zuhri, confirmed that the dead men were Hamas fighters and vowed revenge. Separately, the European Union said it would not continue to buy fuel oil for Gaza until it was sure that Hamas would not tax the resulting electricity.

title: Hey, I Wrote That! But the President Said It  Out Loud!
