At least thats what you might conclude from recent books, films and television shows written by a growing number of former White House speechwriters.

title: Inspectors Say Many Flaws Cut Off Water in Fatal Ground Zero Blaze
description: Investigators have found that a standpipe valve between the basement and the first floor of the former Deutsche Bank building was shut, effectively cutting off the only source of water for firefighters battling last Saturdays blaze on the upper floors of the high-rise, according to fire officials.

title: Footnotes

Mr. Pavarotti, 71, was admitted to the hospital on Aug. 8 because of a high fever. ... Peter Gabriel is to be honored as an Icon by Broadcast Music Inc., Bloomberg News reported. Mr. Gabriel, 57, who founded the rock band Genesis in 1967, is to receive the BMI award on Oct. 16 in London. Previous honorees include Ray Davies, Van Morrison, Isaac Hayes, Dolly Parton, Paul Simon, the Bee Gees and James Brown. ... Lincoln Center Theater will present the New York premiere of The Glorious Ones, a new musical, based on a novel by Francine Prose, about a commedia dellarte troupe in Italy during the Renaissance. Book and lyrics are by Lynn Ahrens, music by Stephen Flaherty and choreography and direction by Graciela Daniele. Performances begin on Oct. 11; the opening is Nov. 5 at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater. ... Bob Yesselman, the director of Dance/NYC, is retiring on Sept. 30 from dance administration, after a 36-year career in which he helped manage the American Ballet Theaters Ballet Repertory Company, the Paul Taylor Dance Company, the Joffrey Ballet, the Dallas Theater Center and the Jacobs Pillow Dance Festival.

I believed him when he told me afterward, over dinner at the Venetian, that he hadnt noticed the name tag identifying me as a science writer. But then everyone believes Apollo  as he expertly removes your wallet and car keys and unbuckles your watch.

The 10-week engagement, to be be directed by David Leveaux (the 2004 Fiddler on the Roof), will begin previews on Oct 12 at the Richard Rodgers Theater, with opening night set for Nov. 1. ... Elsewhere on Broadway, since Adam Pascal and Anthony Rapp returned to the cast of Rent in roles they first played in 1996, ticket sales have nearly doubled. So the two have extended their comeback by a month, to Oct 7.

title: Brother vs. Father
description: CBSs Big Brother edged out Foxs reruns of Family Guy on Sunday to draw the nights highest ratings among adults 18 to 49. The CBS reality show garnered 7.6 million viewers to lead the 8 p.m. hour, according to Nielsens estimates, and the two Family Guy episodes, at 9 and 9:30, delivered 5.4 million and 5.8 million viewers respectively. For the night, CBS and Fox shared the lead with the 18-to-49 set, though Fox finished fourth in total viewers. CBS had a sizable advantage in total viewers, thanks in part to 60 Minutes at 7, the most-watched program of the night with 9.6 million viewers. NBC ranked a close second over all among 18- to 49-year-olds, as its preseason football game between the New York Giants and the Baltimore Ravens averaged 6.9 million viewers from 8:30 to 11. ABC finished last among adults 18 to 49 and third in total viewers, ahead of Fox.

title: Death to the SAT
description: The controversial social scholar Charles Murray, writing at The American magazines site, feels its time to abandon the SAT test. His complaints arent totally new: The image of the SAT has done a 180-degree turn. No longer seen as a compensating resource for the unprivileged, it has become a corrosive symbol of privilege. Back when kids just got a good nights sleep and took the SAT, it was a leveler that helped you find the diamond in the rough, Lawrence Universitys dean of admissions told The New York Times recently. Now that most of the great scores are affluent kids with lots of preparation, it just increases the gap between the haves and the have-nots.

About 27 percent of Staten Island adults smoke, compared with about 17.5 percent citywide.The nicotine-replacement items will be handed out to returning commuters at the ferry terminal, from 3 to 6 p.m., Tuesday through Thursday, through Sept. 20.

title: The Classics of Pebble Beach
description: This 1935 Duesenberg SJ Special won Best of Show at the Pebble Beach concours.  More PhotosThousands of spectators turned out for the festivities surrounding the 57th Pebble Beach Concours d'Elegance on the Monterey Peninsula of California, where some of the rarest vehicles in the world were on display and in competition. Judging at the event included 24 classes, from antiques (pre-1916) through post-World War II sports cars, with special categories for Aston Martins and models from the Auburn-Cord-Duesenberg group.   The Best of Show award went to a 1935 Duesenberg SJ Special owned by Harry Yeaggy of Cincinatti. Nicknamed The Mormon Meteor, the car was once raced by Ab Jenkins, who used it to set a 24-hour land speed record in 1935. Readers can see more images of the SJ, as well as some of the other vehicles on display, in this photo gallery. Full judging results can be viewed here.  Classic-car auctions attract much of the attention during Pebble Beach week. A sale run by Gooding & Company featured a set of first-series Rolls-Royce Silver Ghosts as well as a steam-powered vehicle from 1884, known as La Marquise, which is thought to be the world's oldest functioning automobile. La Marquise sold for $3,520,000 including the buyer's premium, well above the pre-auction estimate of just over $1.5 million. Full results from Gooding & Company are available here. La Marquise was featured in an article in Sunday's Times, as were the Rolls-Royces. RM Auctions also held a sale nearby, in Monterey. Results from that auction are available here.    Photos: Highlights From Pebble Beach

Or did we meet one day at a fashion show and just start talking? We quickly discovered that we had a link to the same unpublished Vivienne Westwood profile, for Vanity Fair, in the mid 90s. I had been asked to write a profile of Westwood, which I did, but publication of the piece was delayed and delayed until, eventually, the editorial window closed for her. Michael had photographed herappropriately, under glass. He had found an enormous bell jar and Westwood had gamely consented to be photographed as if her head were a museum specimen. Or an offering at a pagan feast, brightly colored. She is a genius.

But it was a troubling reminder that the aging shuttles have some inherent defects that will always pose a risk as they limp toward retirement in 2010.

title: In One Chains Stores
description: The nations three largest booksellers have made decisions about carrying If I Did It, O. J. Simpsons book about the 1994 murders of Nicole Brown Simpson and Ronald Goldman, Publishers Weekly reported yesterday. Amazon and Barnes & Nobles Web site (barnesandnoble.com) said they would carry the book. But Barnes & Noble stores will not carry it, a spokesman said, because the companys buyers believe there is insufficient customer interest to justify stocking it. Barnes & Noble will special order the book for anyone who requests it, but the decision is a blow to the books publisher, Beaufort Books, which has minimal distribution in independent stores. Borders stores, on the other hand, will carry the title, but will not promote or market the book in any way, a spokeswoman said. If I Did It was to have been published last November by ReganBooks, an imprint of HarperCollins, with an announced printing of 400,000. But it was dropped in response to widespread outrage.

title: Russia: Activist Freed From Psychiatric Clinic
description: A woman held in a psychiatric hospital after publishing an expos in an opposition newspaper detailing the harsh care of patients in the same hospital has been released, her supporters said. The woman, Larisa Arap, had been in custody near Murmansk since July 5. She claimed to have been beaten and drugged. Her case was taken up by rights organizations and advocates for a free press, who said her forced psychiatric treatment was a throwback to Soviet days, when dissidents were labeled as mentally ill and forced to undergo treatment, sometimes including electroshock therapy. Joel Simon, executive director of the New York-based Committee to Protect Journalists, called on the courts to investigate Ms. Araps treatment.

description: The mourners divided themselves into two lines in the huge lobby of the Dyker Heights funeral home yesterday, one wearing black and one wearing blue.

title: Survivor to China
description: A grave digger, a pro wrestler and a chicken farmer are among the 16 people who will compete on Survivor: China, The Associated Press reported yesterday. Other contestants on the show, which is to have its premiere on Sept. 20 on CBS, include a school lunch lady who throws axes and knives and collects Budweiser memorabilia; a Christian radio talk-show host; and a gay Mormon man who thinks the creation of the Spice Girls was the most significant historical event of the past 100 years.

title: Lebanon: Militants Families Can Leave Camp; Truce Reported
description: The army said it had agreed to let the families of Islamic militants holed up in the Palestinian refugee camp Nahr al Bared, north of Tripoli, leave the battered camp. Lebanese and Palestinian officials estimate that up to 100 civilians, mostly the wives and children of the militants, are still inside the camp. Most other residents fled when the fighting started in May. The state-run news agency reported that the Palestinian Clerics Association had mediated the truce between the army and the militant group Fatah al Islam, but it was not clear when it might take place.

title: Vintage Bradbury, Packaged Anew
description: LOS ANGELES  Though slowed by age, Ray Bradbury still speaks with exuberance. Hobbled by a stroke in 1999, he now dictates his work over the phone to his daughter in Arizona, who records and transcribes it before faxing edits back. Mr. Bradbury works in an overstuffed leather chair in a den lined by shelves of VHS tapes of classic movies and history texts. The room is crowded with models of dinosaurs, rocket ships and Jules Vernes Nautilus submarine, his own dusty Emmy, a friends tarnished Oscar and a 52-inch flat-screen television not unlike the ones he presaged in Fahrenheit 451.

title: U.S. Group Accuses Chinese Toy Factories of Labor Abuses
description: SHANGHAI, Aug. 21  A workers rights group in the United States released a report on Tuesday detailing what it called brutal conditions and illegal practices in Chinese toy factories, many of which supply some of the worlds biggest brand-name toy makers, including Walt Disney and Hasbro.

title: Australian Court Rules for Indian
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Aug. 21  A court in Australia ruled Tuesday that the countrys immigration minister had acted improperly when he revoked the visa of an Indian doctor because of his association with two distant cousins suspected of involvement in the botched bombings in London and Glasgow in June.

title: Tribune Shareholders Back Zells Takeover
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 21  The Tribune Company came one step closer to being taken private Tuesday after shareholders overwhelmingly approved an $8.2 billion buyout led by the real estate billionaire Samuel Zell.

title: Critics Say Lessons From 9/11 Were Not Followed in Deutsche Bank Blaze
description: After the Sept. 11 attack at the World Trade Center, an independent consultant studied the Fire Departments performance and identified a number of lapses amid all the undeniable valor of that day. It said that too many men rushed into the buildings before anyone realized the danger they were in, contributing to the staggering death toll.

title: Cowher Relaxes Into Role as Analyst
description: Bill Cowhers summers as an adult have all been in N.F.L. training camps: as a linebacker, an assistant coach or, for the last 15 seasons, as the coach of the Pittsburgh Steelers. He resigned in January, was hired by CBS Sports as a studio analyst for The NFL Today, and in a network conference room yesterday displayed a calmness at odds with his excitable sideline demeanor.

title: Panel on Virginia Tech Shooting Issues Report
description: An internal report by the Virginia Polytechnic Institute about the April massacre on its campus calls for better communication about troubled students, more locks on classroom doors and improved communication to ensure that students are alerted to a campus-wide crisis.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Saturday about Kid Nation and other forthcoming reality television shows facing legal issues misspelled the surname of a chef who stars in one of the shows. He is Gordon Ramsay, not Ramsey. The name was also misspelled in the title of the show, Ramsays Kitchen Nightmares.

title: Chemical Ali and Others Begin Trial for 1991 Attack
description: BAGHDAD, Aug. 21  To a mostly empty gallery, the man known as Chemical Ali for his role in gassing villages in northern Iraq under Saddam Hussein stood up and identified himself as the fighter, Ali Hassan al-Majid on Tuesday, the first day of trial for his role in brutally suppressing the 1991 Shiite uprising in the south of the country.

title: The Warrantless Debate Over Wiretapping
description: CONGRESS just passed, and President Bush hurriedly signed, a law that amends the legal framework for the electronic interception of various kinds of communication with foreign sources. Almost immediately, commentators concluded that the law was unnecessary, that it authorized a lawless and unprecedented expansion of presidential authority, and that Democrats in Congress cravenly accepted this White House initiative only for the basest political reasons. None of these widely broadcast conclusions are likely to be true.

title: State to Fight U.S. Limits on Childrens Health Plan
description: ALBANY, Aug. 21  The Spitzer administration will aggressively lobby against new federal rules that threaten the governors plans to make health care coverage universal for children in New York, state officials said on Tuesday.

title: Misgivings Spoil Plans of Start-Up
description: Three years ago, at a news conference at Tavern on the Green restaurant that featured a free-flowing bar, former President Bill Clinton helped introduce a new Internet search engine, Accoona, which was said to be powered by innovative artificial intelligence technology.

title: Jets Endure the Storm Before the Calm
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Aug. 21  It felt like a damp and drizzly November day at Jets training camp Tuesday, and that was fine for the man in charge. Coach Eric Mangini has not seen everything go his way this preseason, but he could not have asked for better (that is, worse) weather.

title: German Woman Seeks Reunion With North Korean Husband
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 22  Koreans have long looked to Germany for similarities between the nations histories. Both countries have been scarred by war and separation.

title: Harvard Endowment Reports 23% Gain for Fiscal Year
description: The Harvard Management Company, which oversees the endowment of Harvard University, reported yesterday that the endowment had posted a 23 percent gain for the fiscal year ended June 30.

title: College Rankings (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: In Google Earth, a Service for Scanning the Heavens
description: After turning millions of Internet users into virtual explorers of the world with Google Earth, the Internet search giant is now hoping to turn many of them into virtual stargazers.

title: Some Men Rule
description: Fox led the Monday night ratings, rebroadcasting a two-hour special, but CBSs Two and a Half Men rerun earned the nights highest ratings. Nielsen estimated that Two and a Half Men attracted 9.3 million viewers at 9 p.m., while TVs Funniest Moments, on Fox, averaged 7.2 million from 8 to 10. CBS was No. 2 for the night, winning the 10 p.m. hour with a CSI: Miami repeat (7.6 million). ABC trailed close behind, as its Wife Swap rerun led the 8 p.m. hour (7 million), but Fat March, its new series, came in third at 9 (5.6 million). NBC, which broadcast a Heroes repeat at 9 (2.8 million), finished fourth.

title: CBS Was Warned on Kid Nation, Documents Show
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 21  The producers of a CBS reality show featuring 40 children living on their own in the New Mexico desert were warned by the state attorney general's office while the show was being taped last spring that they might be violating the state's child-labor laws, according to interviews with state officials and documents obtained Tuesday under the state's open records act.

title: Bid to Reopen Mine Divides Grieving Utah Town
description: HUNTINGTON, Utah, Aug. 21  As relatives on Tuesday laid to rest one of three men killed here trying to rescue six trapped miners, this grieving mining town was torn over the future of the mine and the prospect of the lost miners being entombed permanently.

title: Brooklyn: Road Closing in Prospect Park
description: Beginning on Monday, East Drive in Prospect Park will no longer be open to motor vehicles on weekday evenings, city officials said yesterday. Currently, drivers can use East Drive on weekdays from 7 to 9 a.m. and from 5 to 7 p.m.. The road is closed on weekends. City officials said the road was being closed as part of an effort to expand recreation in the park. Molly Gordy, a spokeswoman for the Transportation Department, said city traffic studies have indicated that the closing should not unduly affect neighborhoods in the area.

title: California Ends Stalemate With $145 Billion Plan for Budget Deficit
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 21  California lawmakers ended a partisan two-month budget stalemate on Tuesday, signing off on a $145 billion plan to do away with the state deficit through promised line-item vetoes by Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the average income of Americans from 2000 to 2005 misstated, in some copies, the nations total adjusted gross income in 2005. It was $7.43 trillion, not billion.

title: Obama Sees a Complete Failure in Iraq
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 21  Senator Barack Obama said Tuesday that even if the military escalation in Iraq was showing limited signs of progress, efforts to stabilize the country had been a complete failure and American troops should not be entangled in the sectarian strife.

title: Manhattan: Jefferson Market Renovation
description: City Council Speaker Christine C. Quinn announced yesterday $4.9 million in new financing for restoration work of the historic Jefferson Market Library in Greenwich Village. The red-brick building, offset with limestone trim and a distinctive bell and clock tower, is considered the citys premier example of High Victorian Gothic style. A report released this year found deterioration in the buildings facade and rusting of its iron structure, among other problems. The money will be used to renovate its exterior and to shore up its structural integrity.

title: Kazakhstan Threatens to Halt Work on Big Offshore Oil Project
description: The government of Kazakhstan threatened yesterday to suspend work performed by a consortium of foreign oil companies at the Kashagan offshore field, one of the worlds largest oil projects, because of an assertion of environmental damage in the Caspian Sea.

title: For Vacation, Pack a Toque
description: Here are several cooking schools in Paris. All can answer phone requests in English, and all offer classes for children.

title: Broadway Bound, Reluctantly
description: The producers Jeffrey Richards, Jean Doumanian, Steve Traxler and Jerry Frankel wanted to bring August: Osage County, the raved-about play by Tracy Letts, to Broadway from Chicago.

title: Tanja Liedtke, Dancer, 29, Is Killed by Truck in Australia
description: Tanja Liedtke, a dancer and choreographer who was named artistic director of the Sydney Dance Company in early May, died on Friday in Sydney, Australia, after being hit by a truck. She was 29.

title: Despite Mine Law, Tracking Is Years Away
description: PRICE, Utah, Aug. 21  Perhaps the most wrenching aspect of the Crandall Canyon Mine collapse, for rescue workers and families alike, is that no one knows the exact location of the six trapped miners.

title: FedEx Hopes for the Right Bounce From Golf
description: IF you are south of Greenwich Street in Manhattan between noon and 5 p.m. today, look for a weird miniparade: A guy carrying a quiet sign followed by a golfer, his caddy and an entourage of nattily dressed fans.

title: Yes, Tap Water Is Plentiful, but Is It Fit to Drink? (4 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Takes a Step Away From Maliki
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21  When President Bush and Nuri Kamal al-Maliki stood side by side in Jordan last November, the president proclaimed the prime minister the right guy for Iraq.

title: Go Green and Save Money
description: Have your eyes recently popped out of your head when you opened your electric bill? Do you, like me, live in one of those states where electricity has been deregulated and the state no longer oversees the generation price so your utility rates have skyrocketed since 2002?

title: Learning to Cook, With Time Left to See Paris
description: SERIOUS cooks know they can go off to France and take immersion courses, but until recently, I hadnt realized that it is possible to take quickie cooking classes: a few hours, a half day or a day.

title: Fed Seeks Balance as Investors Clamor for Action
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21  Wall Street thinks the Federal Reserve is running short of time.

title: MTV, RealNetworks to Mount Challenge Against iTunes
description: MTV Networks said yesterday that it would fold its floundering digital music service into a venture with RealNetworks, owner of the Rhapsody music subscription service, as part of a renewed challenge to Apples market-leading iTunes store.

title: Many Eligible for Child Health Plan Have No Idea
description: GREENSBORO, N.C.  During the four years that her children were uninsured, Cassie O. Hall used the emergency room as their pediatrician. When Tayana had an asthma attack or Darren developed a stubborn rash, they would head to the hospital and settle in for a long wait.

title: Turkish Palace as Summer Home
description: As Murat and Nina Koprulu were deciding to invest in a summer home away from Manhattan, they figured that it made sense to embrace their family histories: Her mother is an archaeologist working at sites like Petra in Jordan; his ancestors were powerful grand viziers to the Ottoman sultans.

title: Imitation or Flattery in Dueling Shows
description: The endless line of people who have a notion for a new jukebox musical or television talent show is proof of a legal point: nobody owns an idea. But that doesnt mean the battles over exactly who owns what arent some of the hairiest in the theater business.

title: Already, Apple Sells Refurbished iPhones
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 21  Consumers looking for a deal on an iPhone may be able to knock $100 off the price of the smartphone by buying from an unexpected discount source: Apple Inc.

title: Iraq War Brings Drop in Black Enlistees
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21  Joining the Reserve Officer Training Corps was once an attractive choice for people with few options growing up in impoverished, predominantly black East Baltimore. That has all changed, largely because of the war in Iraq.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: The caption for a picture with the On Baseball column on Sunday, showing Phil Rizzuto and Pee Wee Reese together, referred incorrectly to the date the photograph was taken. It was Sept. 29, 1952, not before Game 1 of the World Series, which was played that Oct. 1.

title: Monteverdi, From the Opera to the Church to Lincoln Center
description: A theme of this summers Mostly Mozart Festival is spirituality, explored by way of works from across the expanse of musical history. Having presented the most recent of its examples, Osvaldo Golijovs Pasin Segn San Marcos (2000), over the weekend, the festival offered the earliest, Monteverdis Vespro Della Beata Vergine (1610), at the Rose Theater on Monday evening.

title: Counting on a Hotel to Make a Neighborhood Hot
description: To understand how the meatpacking district in downtown Manhattan was transformed from an obscure collection of a few bistros and boutiques scattered among beef-filled warehouses to a hot residential, commercial and entertainment destination, consider Michael Achenbaums explanation.

title: A Moist Finale to a Summer of Movies in Bryant Park
description: At the drizzling dot of 5 on Monday evening, security guards dropped the barriers to the Bryant Park lawn. Hundreds of people began a slow-motion dash across the lawn for the parks final night of free outdoor movies this summer. By the time Psycho started four hours later, about 2,000 people had grabbed a few square feet of grass and the unlimited romance of a city night outdoors.

title: Virginias Gun Market
description: The Iron Pipeline of Interstate 95 remains alive and deadly, as a new federal study grimly confirms. Saddest of all is the evidence that some of the most far-reaching shady gun marts continue to operate in the state of Virginia, where the suicidal Virginia Tech student shot 32 people to death only four months ago. Virginia dealers have been a standout source for guns used in crimes up and down the seaboard, according to the federal study. They accounted for half of the 10,000 guns tracked by the study in the metropolitan Washington, D.C., area, and one in 11 in New York City.

title: Plummer to Stratford
description: The Stratford Shakespeare Festival in Ontario, Canada, until recently the Stratford Festival, said yesterday that Christopher Plummer would play Julius Caesar next summer in Shaws Caesar and Cleopatra. Mr. Plummer last appeared at the festival in 2002 as King Lear. Anika Noni Rose will play Cleopatra. Des McAnuff, one of Stratfords artistic directors, is to direct. The festivals 2008 summer schedule so far includes Shakespeares Hamlet, Romeo and Juliet, Alls Well That Ends Well, The Taming of the Shrew and Loves Labours Lost. The Trojan Women by Euripides, Fuente Ovejuna by Lope de Vega and Lessings Emilia Galotti will also be performed, along with two musicals, The Music Man and Cabaret. For more information: www.stratford-festival.on.ca.

title: No Breakthroughs at Canada Talks
description: MONTEBELLO, Quebec, Aug. 21  President Bush met with Prime Minster Stephen Harper of Canada and President Felipe Caldern of Mexico here on Tuesday at a gathering that focused primarily on strengthening ties and some thorny trade and border issues, but which produced no breakthroughs.

title: After the Deluge, the Reality of Deprivation
description: MALINAGAR, India  Losing everything he owns has become a routine disaster for Shankar, a landless laborer in the northeastern state of Bihar who saw his home and belongings destroyed in some of the worst floods to hit the north of India in decades.

title: Politics Seen in Nasty Call to Spitzers Father
description: ALBANY, Aug. 21  Lawyers representing Gov. Eliot Spitzers father, Bernard Spitzer, say a prominent political consultant who has been working for State Senate Republicans threatened the elder Mr. Spitzer this month in an anonymous, invective-laced phone message.

title: Atop Delta, a Veteran of Airlines
description: DETROIT, Aug. 21  With Northwest Airlines former chief executive now in charge at Delta Air Lines, could closer ties between the companies be far behind?

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,700 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Monday:

title: China Raises Interest Rates to Cool Its Heated Economy
description: BEIJING, Aug. 21  China announced Tuesday that it would raise interest rates for a fourth time this year in an effort to contain its racing economy and rein in soaring consumer prices.

title: Shuttle Glides Safely Home in Spite of Damage
description: KENNEDY SPACE CENTER, Fla., Aug. 21  The space shuttle Endeavour glided to a safe landing here Tuesday afternoon, apparently not much worse for wear.

title: In Beijing, Orwell Goes to the Olympics
description: Beijing

title: A New World for Sale, Ocean-to-Ocean View
description: When the 13 American colonies won their independence from Britain, they were a thin fringe of settlement clinging to the edge of a vast continent. Within 80 years, by acquisition and conquest, they would fill in what seemed to them millions of square miles of blank space on the map, from the Atlantic to the Pacific. No other sovereign entity ever grew so large so fast to become so rich and so strong, Richard Kluger writes in Seizing Destiny, his detailed history of how the United States put together the pieces of real estate that would eventually make it the wealthiest, most powerful nation on earth.

title: Congestion Pricing (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Rebels of Various Ages, All of Them With a Cause
description: Snapshots, at the Beckett Theater on Theater Row, has a gutsy, self-confident, liberal determination that smacks of bygone idealism. It reminds me of the way my mother, and my friends mothers, campaigned for George McGovern for president in 1972. Those mothers are approaching 70 now, and 70 is the approximate median age of the women in these three short plays, each of which tackles a different important subject: an aging great-grandmother, an unwanted child, a lifelong lesbian love affair.

title: Like Ducks and Penguins, With Nervous Stomachs
description: The smell of Swinburne Island is the smell of the birds: layers of guano, decaying fish, salt water. It is a smell both tangy and rotten, and it intensifies as you fight your way through shoulder-high brush toward the bare branches where cormorants are nesting.

title: Toll in Iraq Bombings Is Raised to More Than 500
description: One week after a series of truck bombs hit two poor villages near the Syrian border, the known casualty toll has soared to more than 500 dead and 1,500 wounded, according to the Iraqi Red Crescent Society, making them by far the worst coordinated attacks since the American-led invasion.

title: Look for More Ways to Treat Diabetes (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: New Accusations Against Priest Convicted of Sexual Abuse
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 21  A Jesuit priest convicted last year of sexually abusing two teenage boys about 40 years ago is facing new accusations of abuse.

title: Pushing Fed to Act Early if Not Often
description: Ben Bernanke got his first chance to use the chairmanship of the Federal Reserve to influence the housing market before he even officially had the job. It came in November 2005, toward the end of his all-day Senate confirmation hearing, when Senator Paul Sarbanes brought up the mortgage business.

title: Mets Have Last Word in Seesaw Game
description: The Mets were bursting with confidence entering last nights game at Shea Stadium, having won six of seven games. But those victories came against the Florida Marlins, the Pittsburgh Pirates and the Washington Nationals, teams that began yesterday in last place.

description: SOME people believe you can improve on a good grilled steak: the Italians use lemon and olive oil, the French compound butter or even barnaise.

description: Howard, S.D.

title: Storm Misses Tourist Spots and Weakens
description: CHETUMAL, Mexico, Aug. 21  Hurricane Dean hammered Mexicos Yucatn Peninsula with blistering winds and heavy rain on Tuesday, missing the prime tourist spots of the Mayan Riviera but causing damage in Chetumal, the state capital, before being downgraded to Category 1 from Category 5.

title: Greenspan and Bernanke: Evolving Views
description: Here are excerpts from some of the comments that Alan Greenspan and Ben S. Bernanke have made about the housing market over the last six years.

title: Michigan Joins the Race for a Me First Primary
description: The primary election calendar is a lot like the weather: Everyone gripes about Iowa and New Hampshire going first, but no one does anything about it.

title: What They Left Undone on Summer Vacation
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Aug. 19  Most of the people in The Autumn Garden, Lillian Hellmans 1951 drama of midlife malaise, have reached the age when, as W. H. Auden wrote, mirrors might be hateful for a while. The joy and pain of the Williamstown Theater Festivals absorbing revival, which runs through Sunday, come from watching a top-drawer cast embody a growing, reluctant awareness of receding hair and chin lines matched by receding hopes.

description: WHITE PLAINS

title: Tiger Woods Takes a Break, but the FedEx Cup Wont
description: HARRISON, N.Y., Aug. 21  The biggest burden the rookie Brandt Snedeker carries is an oversized travel bag for 14 golf clubs.

title: C.I.A. Lays Out Errors It Made Before Sept. 11
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21  A report released Tuesday by the Central Intelligence Agency includes new details of the agencys missteps before the Sept. 11 attacks, outlining what the report says were failures to grasp the role being played by the terror mastermind Khalid Sheikh Mohammed and to assess fully the threats streaming into the C.I.A. in the summer of 2001.

title: Stacking the Electoral Deck
description: The Electoral College should be abolished, but there is a right way to do it and a wrong way. A prominent Republican lawyer in California is doing it the wrong way, promoting a sneaky initiative that, in the name of Electoral College reform, would rig elections in a way that would make it difficult for a Democrat to be elected president, no matter how the popular vote comes out. If the initiative passes, it would do serious damage to American democracy.

title: In Business With Your Children
description: IN THE HUNT

title: Law for Music Acts
description: Music acts that impersonate real performers may be fined $5,000 to $15,000 under a new New York State law, The Associated Press reported yesterday. Called the Truth in Music Advertising Law, it prohibits copycat performances that attempt to cash in through false and misleading representations like names, billings and promotions similar to the original artists. The measure was inspired by recording artists like the Platters, the Coasters and the Drifters, whose acts and routines have been copied without permission. It requires performing groups to have at least one member of the act they are claiming a connection to and a legal right to use that acts name. Otherwise they must label their productions a tribute or salute, own the recording groups service mark or have its authorization. Similar measures have passed or are pending in a dozen states.

title: The Weathers Fine, Hence the Invasion From Arizona
description: SAN DIEGO  Bulletin: Phoenix and Tucson have been evacuated because of summer heat and monsoonal moisture. The emergency shelter is here, or so it seems, for the displaced Arizonans.

title: Group to Urge War Support
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21  A new group of prominent conservatives plans to begin a multimillion-dollar advertising campaign Wednesday to urge members of Congress who may be wavering in their support for the war in Iraq not to "cut and run."

title: An Old Baseball Hand at the Tiller
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 21  The moment called for levity. And John McLaren  baseball lifer, longtime coach under Lou Piniella and, at age 55, a first-time major-league manager with the American League wild-card leading Seattle Mariners  was happy to provide it.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Sunday about the death of two New York City firefighters in a fire at the Deutsche Bank skyscraper at ground zero gave an outdated name in some copies for the hospital where they were taken. It is New York Downtown Hospital, not NYU Downtown Hospital.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A correction in this space on Friday, to an article on Aug. 14 about the number of votes in Parliament the governing party in Turkey would need to win confirmation for its presidential nominee, Abdullah Gul, if he failed in the first two rounds of voting, misstated the total number of seats in the Parliament. If there were a third round, Mr. Gul would indeed need 276 votes, not 267 as originally reported, but the number of seats in Parliament is 550, not 500. (Go to Article)

title: After Prince Charming, a Blonde Tries to Recover
description: It is a relief to open the press kit for Portrait of the Artist as a Dumb Blonde and see pictures of its playwright and star, Sharon Fogarty, with her natural brunet hair. The one-act musical comedy, at Manhattan Theater Source, is a despairing portrait indeed.

title: Lottery Numbers
Gwen Stefani, Covered
description: Gwen Stefani modestly rocked Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, yesterday, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Stefani, 37, performed in costumes that showed almost no skin after Islamic critics claimed that her customary revealing clothes could corrupt the youth of this Muslim-majority nation. I am very inspired tonight, Ms. Stefani told some 7,000 cheering fans at an indoor stadium, wearing a black leotard under a white short-sleeved shirt and black-and-white striped hot-pants suit, with black gloves up to her elbows. She changed costumes for every song, remaining fully covered as she belted out Hollaback Girl and other songs. Under government guidelines, a female artist must be covered from the shoulders to the knees and may not jump, shout, hug, kiss or throw things at the audience.

title: Manhattan: Harlem River Esplanade Expansion
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the city parks commissioner, Adrian Benepe, broke ground yesterday on the second phase of the Harlem River Park Greenway and Esplanade. The $8.7 million project, financed through a combination of city, state and federal funds, will extend the waterfront park and bike path north from 139th Street to 142nd Street. Phase 1, completed in 2003, opened the esplanade from 135th to 139th Street. Phase 2 is expected to be completed by August 2008, the mayor said.

title: So Many Tomatoes to Stuff in a Week
description: OF all the produce that tastes amazingly better in season peaches and apricots, strawberries and peas  none inspires the same cultish devotion as summer tomatoes.

title: New York G.O.P. Severs Ties With Consultant
description: ALBANY, Aug. 22  A prominent political consultant who was accused this week of leaving a threatening, profanity-laced phone message for Gov. Eliot Spitzers 83-year-old father announced today that he would resign from his job and no longer work with State Senate Republicans.

title: Newark: Man Sentenced for Threats to Train
description: A man was sentenced yesterday in Federal District Court to two and a half years in federal prison for making false bomb threats concerning the Hoboken PATH station, prosecutors said. The man, Miguel Reyes, 33, formerly of Newark, pleaded guilty in April to making the false bomb threats, said Christopher J. Christie, the United States attorney for New Jersey. Mr. Reyes admitted that he made three calls to 911 in October and November last year saying there would be an explosion in the station. Compiled by John Sullivan

title: London Calling
description: A look at some of the plays running in London this summer.

title: The Accoona Files 1: A Search Company?
description: A few weeks ago I was happily blogging along, writing the Quick Bits news summary, when I came across coverage of the public offering of Accoona, a New Jersey search company. I was invited to its initial press conference, which was attended by Bill Clinton. I had thought at the time that it was unusual. Ive been to hundreds of tech company events, and none was quite like that. So I spent a little time reading the companys prospectus and reading about its founder (who the company calls Armand Rousso, but who seems to be named Marc Armand Rousso.)

description: Ralph Lauren turned Polo into a $13.5 billion fashion Disney.

description: A look at the auditions for the show "Fuerzabruta," which has cast members perform in a pool.

description: Abbie Cornish, the Aussie Ingnue Of Candy and Elizabeth: The Golden Age, Talks With Lynn Hirschberg about satisfying her wanderlust.

description: The trick to eccentricity: Don't go crazy with it.

title: A Look Back
description: Last summer, The New York Times covered the U.S. Open in a new way. One of the Sports sections first blogs debuted, with The Times senior culture critic Michael Kimmelman leading a team of editors and bloggers who brought you the sites and scenes from Flushing Meadows.

title: With Northwests Ex-C.E.O. Atop Delta, Will a Deal Take Off?
description: With Northwest Airlines former chief executive now in charge at Delta Air Lines, could closer ties between the companies be far behind?

title: Ford Stays the Course, Wherever It May Lead
description: As Ford Motor awaits offers for its Jaguar and Land Rover brands, The New York Times takes a look atwhat has changed in the year since Alan R. Mulally left Boeing to be chief executive at the car maker.

title: Ackmans Win-Win Bet on Target
description: Investors are often counseled, but often forget, that they should protect their downsides as they seek profits. According to Breakingviews, Pershing Square Capitals William Ackman has done just that as he pursues a shakeup of Target, which reported healthy earnings growth for tis second quarter.

title: Upper Deck Drops Bid for Topps
description: A day after an influential proxy adviser threw its weight behind Upper Decks $10.75-per-share bid for Topps, the firm said it had decided to withdraw its offer for the rival maker of trading cards.

title: Trusts Seek $2 Billion From Advisers to Refco
description: Trusts representing creditors of the defunct futures and commodities broker Refco sued its legal, accounting and financial advisers yesterday for more than $2 billion over the companys collapse.

title: Transcontinental Signs Deal for Canadian Printer
description: Canadian media and printing company Transcontinental looks to expand its presence in Ontario after making a $130-million bid to take over PLM Group, Canadas fourth-largest printer.

title: Canadas Biggest Banks Seek to Reassure Investors

Laura Rozen at Mother Joness MoJoBlog brings up the fourth anniversary of something a great proportion of Americans have likely forgotten, or at least tried to erase from their memories: It was only four years ago that Rep. Bob Ney (R-Ohio) and Walter Jones (R-NC) announced the official name change in Congressional cafeterias from French fries and French toast to Freedom Fries and Freedom Toast.

As this blog and an accompanying video reported in June, Parents Against Styrofoam in Schools, a grass-roots group arising out of Public School 154 in Windsor Terrace, Brooklyn, has called for limiting or ceasing the use of polystyrene, a petroleum-based material that can take centuries to decompose.Now, Councilman Bill de Blasio, Democrat of Brooklyn, wants to go even further. He is introducing a bill in the City Council today to would prohibit the use of polystyrene by City agencies and food establishments. Mr. de Blasio, like the Brooklyn parents, want the school system to switch to either reusable plastic trays or trays that are biodegradable.

title: Brooklyn: Good Samaritan Killed
description: A man who stopped to help a driver in a disabled car on the Prospect Expressway early yesterday was killed when a drunken driver in a third car smashed into his car and the broken-down vehicle, the police said. The police said the victim, Rafael Rafailov, 50, stopped to assist a vehicle that was stopped in the middle southbound lane about 1:20 a.m. Mr. Rafailov and the driver of the disabled car were outside their vehicles when a car driven by Alexey Bushuyev, 22, of Brooklyn, struck their cars, the police said. Mr. Bushuyev and the driver of the disabled car, who was not identified, suffered minor injuries. Mr. Rafailov was declared dead at the scene, the police said. Mr. Bushuyev was charged with driving while intoxicated.

title: Out for a Sunday Drive
description: Bill Murray, right, could face a drunken driving charge after cruising through downtown Stockholm in a golf cart and, citing United States law, refusing police requests that he take a breath test, The Associated Press reported yesterday. The police spotted Mr. Murray, 56, early Sunday in the slow-moving vehicle and noticed he smelled of alcohol when they pulled him over. He refused to blow in the instrument, citing American legislation, said Detective Inspector Christer Holmlund of the Stockholm police on Wednesday. So we applied the old method: a blood test. It will take 14 days before the results are in. Mr. Murray, who had been at a golf tournament in Sweden, signed a document admitting that he had been driving under the influence, and agreed to let a police officer plead guilty for him if the case goes to court. Detective Holmlund said it was not clear where Mr. Murray had picked up the vehicle or to whom it belonged. It was a golf cart, the detective said. How it ended up in this predicament I dont know. Mr. Murray is not facing theft charges, he added.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the efforts of a start-up search-engine company, Accoona, to go public misidentified the publication edited by Danny Sullivan, who commented on the performance of the search engine. (Mr. Sullivan founded Search Engine Watch, now owned by Incisive Media, but is no longer its editor.)

title: Keeping Appearances Up, and Costs Down

But the outside, as redesigned by Ms. Luce, is more window than wall. She ordered metal-framed windows from Fleetwood, a California company that she says is very flexible as to size and configuration. A window almost as big as a garage door  7 by 8 feet  costs about $5,000. She added pivot hardware from Rixson, www.rixson.com, to create front and back doors that turn 90 degrees without side hinges.

title: Legal Questions Remain for Freed Scholar in Iran
description: TEHRAN, Aug. 22  Haleh Esfandiari, the Iranian-American scholar freed on bail after three months in prison, is waiting for Iranian judicial officials to inform her whether the travel ban against her will be lifted and a new passport issued to allow her to return to the United States, her husband and her lawyer said Wednesday.

title: The C.I.A. Report
description: The C.I.A. inspector generals report on the agencys failures before Sept. 11 was devastating  but not because it showed that Americas spies missed the rise of Al Qaeda. George Tenet, then the director of central intelligence, rang the Qaeda alarm. He sent a memo to the entire intelligence community saying that he wanted no effort spared in the war with Osama bin Laden. He took on the presidents closest advisers to agitate for a strike on a Qaeda base in Afghanistan.

title: California: Social Security Numbers Printed on Brochures
description: The California Public Employees Retirement System said it accidentally printed the Social Security numbers of almost a half-million retirees on brochures sent out last week. A mail-processing computer inadvertently added the partial or full Social Security number of each retiree on the mailing label attached to a brochure sent to 445,000 people announcing a board election, said a system spokesman, Brad Pacheco. The fund sent letters to its members apologizing and promising new procedures to prevent future mix-ups. The system manages retirement and health care benefits for 1.5 million current and retired public workers and their families.
