description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 22  President Bush delivered a rousing defense of his Iraq policy on Wednesday, telling a group of veterans that a free Iraq is within reach and warning that if Americans succumb to the allure of retreat, they will witness death and suffering of the sort not seen since the Vietnam War.

title: A Childhood Relived, but This Time as a Jet
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Aug. 22  At the autograph session after the Jets practice Wednesday afternoon, one of the last members of the team to relinquish the felt-tip pen was also one of the most anonymous: the backup center Joe Villani.

title: Multiplying the Middle Ground
description: Among other things, the bassist Dave Holland specializes in a sly manipulation of scale. Over the last few years he has led two successful ensembles: a quintet powerful enough to sound much larger, and a big band agile enough to feel much smaller. His new six-piece group appearing at the Blue Note this week occupies a flexible middle ground.

title: At Saratoga, a Jockeys Success Only Grows
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 22  Calvin Borel let an ear-to-ear smile say what a voice silenced by laryngitis would not: He was enjoying his first meet at New Yorks fabled Saratoga Race Course immensely. Borel had just guided Syrianas Song to victory in the second race here Wednesday and was being mobbed by fans as he made his way back to the jockeys room.

title: Black Hawk Fails and Crashes, Killing 14 U.S. Soldiers
description: BAGHDAD, Aug. 22  Fourteen American soldiers died Wednesday when their helicopter crashed in northern Iraq, the military said.

title: Queens: Men Charged in Holdups
description: Four Queens men who prosecutors said were suspected members of the Crips street gang were charged yesterday with robbing at least 16 bodegas in South Queens in the last five months, the authorities said. Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney, said that in one case, the men are charged with robbing one store and walking down the street to rob another just minutes later. The men, Gregory Burrowes, 27, Jeremy Edwards, 20, Keon Gill, 21, and Ryan Carter, 20, are charged with robbery and assault, Mr. Brown said. He said that not all of them participated in every robbery and that some suspects had not yet been arrested. In two of the robberies, he said, shots were fired and a worker was hit in both legs. The police have not yet arrested the suspected gunman, Mr. Brown said.

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: I Lost My Laptop in Outer Space, and Other Tales of Office Theft
description: YEARS ago, back before children and bulk shopping, back when running out of something meant a separate errand, I stole a roll of toilet tissue from the office restroom. It was in the companys interest that I stay longer rather than race out before the shops closed, I reasoned. It wasnt stealing. It was a strategic investment of my time.

title: Opponents Attack Giulianis New York Record
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani has showcased his record running the city of New York as he has campaigned for the presidency. But his performance as mayor is now being turned against him as two of his opponents have begun challenging him on two of the biggest issues in the Republican primary: gun control and immigration.

title: College Board Quits the Loan Business
description: The College Board, the powerful testing organization known for its SAT and Advanced Placement exams, announced yesterday that it was getting out of the student loan business.

title: Home & Garden Calendar
description: Studio Art

title: Foxy Brown Is Jailed for Violating Probation
description: Looking uncharacteristically demure, in a high-collared blue dress with a large silver cross around her neck, the rapper Foxy Brown was jailed yesterday for violating her probation.

title: Large Gardens, Small Lessons
description: RUNNING an organic garden as elaborate as Highgrove is a complex and costly proposition  not a problem, of course, for Prince Charles  but many of the tips that he offers in the new book, The Elements of Organic Gardening, written with Stephanie Donaldson, are surprisingly simple.

title: First on the Clarinet, Later With the Baton
description: The Mostly Mozart Festivals namesake has had competition for the limelight this summer from an impressively eclectic lineup of composers, not least the exuberant Argentine-American Osvaldo Golijov, an enjoyably ubiquitous presence as the festivals first composer in residence. But Mozarts shadow loomed larger over Tuesdays proceedings at Avery Fisher Hall than it has at many other festival events.

title: Deluge Continues in Rain-Soaked Midwest
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 22  Already soaked from days of rain, a broad region from Minnesota to Ohio endured more flooding on Wednesday, as rainfall shattered records and weather forecasts called for more flood watches and additional rain.

title: Being Read to at the Y
description: The 92nd Street Y Unterberg Poetry Center announced its 2007-8 lineup of readings yesterday. Among the writers scheduled to appear are Derek Walcott, the Nobel Prize-winning West Indian poet, on Sept. 17, and the Haitian-American writer Edwidge Danticat and the South African novelist Zakes Mda on Sept. 20. (Ms. Danticat will read from her new memoir, Brother, Im Dying.) Mario Vargas Llosa is to appear on Oct. 15, reading from his new novel, and the Polish poet and essayist Adam Zagajewski on Dec. 6. On Jan. 7 the Nigerian novelist Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie will read, along with Dave Eggers. (After the reading, they will talk with the Sudanese civil war refugee Valentino Achak Deng, on whom Mr. Eggers based his latest fictionalized biography, What Is the What.) Roddy Doyle, from Ireland, and A. L. Kennedy, from Scotland, will read on Jan. 23; the Turkish novelist Elif Shafak reads from her latest novel, The Bastard of Istanbul, on Feb. 11. Andrew Motion, the poet laureate of Britain, will appear on April 7, and the Nobel Prize winner Imre Kertesz, from Hungary, will share the stage with the pianist Andras Schiff on April 17. The full schedule of readings is available at 92y.org.

title: Yonkers: Fire Claims One Victim
description: A 78-year-old woman died after a fire broke out shortly before 6 p.m. yesterday in her apartment complex, the Yonkers police said. The woman, Louise Paciarello, who lived by herself in a first-floor one-bedroom apartment at Kristensen Houses at 45 Seymour Street, was brought out of the burning building to St. Josephs Medical Center, where she was pronounced dead. The fire was under control by 6:15 p.m.; all the other residents of the complex escaped. The cause of the fire is still under investigation.

title: Italys American Baggage
description: Rome

title: Scandal and Suicide in China: A Dark Side of Toys
description: They found the body hanging on the third floor of the Lee Der toy factory.

title: Accident at Deutsche Bank Building Injures 2
description: A piece of construction equipment fell from the 23rd floor of the problem-plagued Deutsche Bank building this afternoon, crashing into a shed and injuring two firefighters, city officials said.

title: Manhattan: Ferry Operation Transfer
description: After 54 years, the replacement of Circle Line as the operator of ferries to the Statue of Liberty is going to take a few months more. The National Park Service said yesterday that Hornblower Yachts, the California company it chose to succeed Circle Line, would begin carrying tourists to the statue and Ellis Island on Jan. 1, instead of Oct. 2. But fares will increase by 50 cents on Oct. 2 to $12 for adults and $5 for children. Hornblower is still negotiating to purchase Circle Lines fleet of seven boats, said Terry MacRae, chief executive of Hornblower. Circle Line, which has operated the service since 1953, has agreed not to contest the park services decision to award the ferry contract to Hornblower.

title: Winning It All
description: A ventriloquist, Terry Fator, took home the million-dollar prize on Tuesday on the finale of NBCs Americas Got Talent. Nielsen estimated that the show attracted the largest audience of this summer on any network, drawing an average of 13.9 million total viewers from 8 to 10 p.m., with a 17 percent increase among those 18 to 49. An hourlong Singing Bee (9.1 million) kept NBC on top during the 10 p.m. hour, ahead of ABCs Primetime: Crime (6.4 million) and CBSs NCIS repeat (6.5 million). CBS and ABC finished roughly tied for second for the night. Big Brother on CBS delivered a solid 7.3 million viewers at 9, while iCaught on ABC trailed with 5 million during that hour. At 8, two episodes of ABCs Just for Laughs, averaging 7.2 million viewers, outdrew CBSs rerun of Power of 10 (6.1 million) and the second part of Foxs On the Lot finale (2.5 million). Fox ranked fourth over all.

title: Appeals Court Grants Bail to Ex-Qwest Chief
description: Joseph P. Nacchio, the former chief executive of Qwest Communications International who was convicted of insider trading, may remain free on $2 million bail while he appeals, a federal court ruled yesterday.

title: Peavy Dominates While Mota Fails Mets Again
description: In a sense, the Mets can cope with last nights 7-5 loss to the Padres because it came against San Diegos ace, Jake Peavy. He is one of the best pitchers in baseball. No one has pitched better on the road than he has. He struck out 11 in six innings. The Mets could not think of enough superlatives afterward to describe him.

title: Worldwide Collaborators, Both Listening and Playing
description: Many people are often uncertain which verb to apply to their experience of attending a concert. I saw a concert, one says, then catches himself: No, I heard it.

title: For 2008 Olympics Campaigns, the Starters Gun Went Off This Month
description: WITH less than a year to go until the 2008 Summer Games, the Olympic rings are everywhere in Beijing. How is an advertiser, even an official sponsor, supposed to stand out?

title: Ticketmaster to End Live Nation Contract
description: Signaling a shake-up in the financial structure of the live entertainment business, Ticketmaster said yesterday that it did not expect to extend its long-term contract with Live Nation, the worlds biggest concert promoter.

title: Scientists Induce Out-of-Body Sensation
description: Using virtual reality goggles, a camera and a stick, scientists have induced out-of-body experiences  the sensation of drifting outside of ones own body  - in healthy people, according to experiments being published in the journal Science.

title: Austrian Interns Run Into U.S. Visa Problems
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 22  An unusual program that allows Austrians to volunteer in Holocaust institutions in the United States in lieu of serving in the Austrian military has been disrupted because of difficulties in obtaining visas from the American government.

title: Asian Stocks Up in Early Trading, Buoyed by Rise on Wall Street
description: SINGAPORE, Thursday, Aug. 23 (Dow Jones)  Asian stocks pushed higher early Thursday, as a strong showing on United States markets inspired investors to unwind some of the recent damage.

title: Does It Feel Like a Playoff?
description: The PGA Tours attempt to heighten interest in the latter part of its season begins today with the start of The Barclays, the first event in a new playoff tournament called the FedEx Cup. But Tiger Woods is absent, raising questions about how much meaning the playoff will have. Can golf, and other sports like Nascar and horse racing, really generate late-season interest with playoff formats, or do they appear more like gimmicks?

title: Your Attention, Please!
description: IN her memoir, DV, Diana Vreeland recalled the time she saw Josephine Baker breeze into the back seat of her Rolls-Royce with Chiquita, her pet cheetah, in tow. According to description, Baker was beautifully dressed in a short black skirt and a barely there Vionnet shirt  no sleeves, no back, no front, just crossed bars on the bias. But the pice de rsistance was her animal accessory. I had never seen anything like it, Vreeland wrote. It was speed at its best, and style.

title: Homemade Shortcuts for the PC
description: Are you ready for a shock? According to a study from the Sloan School of Management at M.I.T., computers actually make you less productive. By the time youve finished stumbling around your software and fiddling with your formatting, youve spent more time than you would have had you just typed the thing on a typewriter.

title: A Memorial Service for Max Roach
description: A memorial service for Max Roach, the bebop pioneer who revolutionized jazz drumming, is scheduled for tomorrow at 11 a.m. at Riverside Church, Riverside Drive at 122nd Street, in Morningside Heights. Friends of Mr. Roach, who died on Aug. 16, are expected to play and speak at the public memorial.

title: Obscure Company Is Behind 9/11 Demolition Work
description: The John Galt Corporation of the Bronx, hired last year for the dangerous and complex job of demolishing the former Deutsche Bank building at 130 Liberty Street, where two firefighters died last Saturday, has apparently never done any work like it. Indeed, Galt does not seem to have done much of anything since it was incorporated in 1983.

title: Deal Restarts Newfoundland Oil Project
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 22  A 15-month standoff between the Canadian province of Newfoundland and Labrador and several major oil companies over an offshore oil project ended Wednesday, putting the $5.6 billion development back in motion.

title: Bronx: Man Stabbed to Death
description: A 20-year-old Bronx man was fatally stabbed in a building in Fordham about 8:15 p.m. yesterday, the police said. The victim, identified as Rafael Perdomo, was taken to St. Barnabas Hospital, where he was pronounced dead. The attacker fled from the scene near the intersection of East 187th Street and Elm Place. There had been no arrests last night, the police said.

title: Against Delusion: Robert Gobers Nuts-and-Bolts Americana
description: BASEL, Switzerland  In this summer of international art exhibitions in Europe, unanimity among viewers and critics has been rare. But the grand retrospective for the American sculptor Robert Gober at the Schaulager museum here is drawing a chorus of superlatives.

title: Despite New Church Rules, Sex Abuse in Catholic School Went Unreported
description: NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Aug. 22  For nearly two years, students at St. Dominic Savio Middle School here  particularly the girls  referred to Christian Butler, a part-time computer teacher, as the Perv.

title: Finding Miners Alive Is Totally Unlikely, Owner Says
description: HUNTINGTON, Utah, Aug. 22  The co-owner of a Utah coal mine where six workers have been buried since an Aug. 6 collapse said on Wednesday that finding life there was virtually, totally unlikely and that he would forever seal the mine and never pull coal from it again.

title: Steep Rise in Fuel Costs Prompts Rare Public Protest in Myanmar
description: SINGAPORE, Aug. 22  In a rare public demonstration in Myanmar, hundreds of people marched Wednesday in the countrys largest city to protest steep increases in fuel costs that have driven up the prices of transportation and commodities, according to witnesses and news reports.

title: Few Initiatives Expected at Summit for Germanys Ruling Coalition
description: BERLIN, Aug. 22  In an end-of-summer rite, Chancellor Angela Merkels coalition government of conservatives and Social Democrats gather Thursday in a Baroque palace outside Berlin to seek unity and direction before the new parliamentary session.

title: Report Raises Strong Doubt About Iraqi Government
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23  A stark assessment released today by the nations intelligence agencies depicts a paralyzed Iraqi government unable to take advantage of the security gains achieved by the thousands of extra American troops dispatched to the country this year.

title: Under the Night Sky, a Vivid History Lesson
description: BECKET, Mass., Aug. 21  It would be nice to feel unmitigatedly positive about Joanna Haigoods Invisible Wings, an ambitious site-specific evocation of slave culture and history, linked to the history of the land that the Jacobs Pillow Dance Festival now inhabits. On Tuesday  a day late, after rain forced the cancellation of the scheduled opening  a new version of this open-air work, first presented at the Pillow in 1998, opened on the festival grounds amid a sense of excitement heightened by the delay.

title: Immigration Checks Ordered in New Jersey
description: TRENTON, Aug. 22  The New Jersey attorney general, Anne Milgram, on Wednesday ordered local law enforcement agencies to inquire about the immigration status of criminal suspects and notify federal authorities whenever they believe someone arrested is in the country illegally.

title: Departed Asset Deployer
description: In his victory lap of self-serving interviews, Karl Rove, the departed White House political guru, waxed humble. Im a myth, he insisted. Wishful thinking.

title: Uncertainty on Vote Dates Intensifies
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22  The uncertainty of the 2008 presidential calendar intensified Wednesday as the Michigan Senate voted to move the states primary to Jan. 15 and leaders of the Florida Democratic Party said they had no intention of delaying their nominating contest.

title: Between Poses, a Barrage of Pickup Lines
description: THE words Do you come here often? are not sweet nothings when you are going into final relaxation during a yoga class. Nor do most yoga practitioners welcome someone who flirts shamelessly as mats are positioned during the lull before the teacher arrives.

title: Fire Dept. Did Not Inspect Pipe in Doomed Building
description: The New York Fire Department failed to visually inspect standpipes in the former Deutsche Bank building every 15 days as required by city rules for buildings being demolished, and had not done any inspections at the building since November 2006, according to records released yesterday by City Hall.

title: New York Athletic Club Picks Jones
description: Cedric Jones, a New England Patriots wide receiver for nine years and an administrator for the N.F.L. for the past 14, yesterday was named the athletic director of the New York Athletic Club. Jones succeeds 84-year-old Ray Lumpp, who is retiring after 47 years. Lumpp began in 1960, the year Jones was born.Jones played for the Patriots from 1982 to 1990. His last position for the N.F.L. was senior director of youth football. Lumpp was an Olympic gold-medal basketball player in 1948 and played five seasons (1948-53) with the Knicks and the Baltimore Bullets.

title: Video Chats Arent Just for Tycoons
description: A few years ago, the phone was the only quick way to get in touch with distant relatives. Their voices were all you got, so it didnt matter if Grandpa was still in his bathrobe and slippers.

title: Political Consultant Resigns After Allegations of Threatening Spitzers Father
description: ALBANY, Aug. 22  The Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, forced one of his top political consultants to resign on Wednesday after allegations that he left a threatening telephone message at the office of Gov. Eliot Spitzers father.

title: Footnotes
description: Bob Dylan and Elvis Costello will tour together this fall, Billboard.com reported. The 13-date tour, on which Amos Lee will also perform, begins on Sept. 22 in Duluth, Ga., and ends on Oct. 9 in Rochester, N.Y. Information and tickets: bobdylan.com/index.html. ... The Metropolitan Opera announced yesterday that Joseph Kaiser will make his Met debut Oct. 3, taking over from the tenor Rolando Villazn opposite Anna Netrebko in Gounods Romo et Juliette. Mr. Kaiser will also sing at the Met on Oct. 6 and Oct. 11. The Met announced last week that Roberto Alagna would sing on Sept. 25 and Sept. 29 in place of Mr. Villazn, who has canceled several months of performances. Mr. Kaiser had been scheduled to sing Steva in Janaceks Jenufa at the Los Angeles Opera from Sept. 27 to Oct. 13; he has been replaced by Jorma Silvasti.

title: Brooke Astors Guardians and Son Battle Over Estate
description: WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 22  Brooke Astors son, Anthony D. Marshall, asked a judge on Wednesday to reject a request by his late mothers court-appointed guardians that they serve as administrators of her estate, saying that they would continue to be hostile and biased against him.

title: City Tightens Rule Barring Private Trash in Public Bins
description: The city will have new powers to crack down on people who put trash in, of all places, public litter baskets, under a bill passed by the City Council yesterday.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Out for a Sunday Drive

title: Along Come Joneses, in Two Takes on Reality
description: Foxs new reality show Anchorwoman posits that even an untutored bikini model can be a newscaster. Court TVs new offering Star Jones suggests that even a veteran television personality cannot handle a live talk show on her own.

title: Brooklyn: Subway Worker Injured
description: A subway track worker was injured yesterday when he fell off a mechanical lift parked beneath the elevated tracks at the Broadway Junction station. A spokesman for Transport Workers Union Local 100 identified the worker as Martin Meyer and said he had worked for New York City Transit for more than 20 years. Mr. Meyer fell from the lift platform about 12:20 p.m. and landed on the cab or hood of the truck on which the lift was mounted, according to the union and the transit agency. The lift was being used to gain access to the underside of the elevated tracks. Mr. Meyer was taken to Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center, where a spokeswoman said he was in stable condition. Paul Fleuranges, a spokesman for the transit agency, said the cause of the accident was unclear. All the safety equipment was in place, he said.

title: With This Software, Digital Home Videos Become Claymation Movies
description: If your home movies are just too dull to be endured, you have a new option: turn your family members into claymation characters.

title: Apply a Mild Shock
description: HAD Dame Edith Sitwell, who chronicled the lives of eccentrics of the 1930s, been confronted with the contemporary spectacles of some of her countrymen, one has to wonder if she would revise her remark that eccentricity is not, as dull people would have us believe, a form of madness. For who, puzzling over how Amy Winehouse, in her state, gets her crazy eyeliner just right, or noting Pete Dohertys newfound propensity for wearing two hats at once, would not consider the possibility that these people are out to lunch?

title: Bidders Wanted. Preservationists Definitely Preferred.
description: FOX ISLAND, N.Y.

title: A Bump in India-U.S. Rapport: Defining Ally
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 22  Affection for things American can be felt regarding many things in this country, from sneakers to accents, to where the elite send their children for university education.

title: How Can We Best Help Afghanistan? (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: JDS Loss Narrows, and Shares Move Higher
description: The JDS Uniphase Corporation, a telecommunications equipment maker, reported a narrower fourth-quarter loss as sales beat analysts estimates.

title: Rose Bampton, Versatile Met Singer, Dies at 99
description: Rose Bampton, an American opera singer who switched from mezzo-soprano to soprano and sang leading roles in both ranges at the Metropolitan Opera, died on Tuesday in Bryn Mawr, Pa. She was 99.

title: Intelligence Chief Reveals Eavesdropping Details
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23  The Bush administration has confirmed for the first time that American telecommunications companies played a key role in the National Security Agencys domestic eavesdropping program after asserting for nearly two years that any role played by the companies was a state secret.

title: Edward Avedisian, Artist Who Painted Bold and Bright, Dies at 71
description: Edward Avedisian, who helped establish the hotly colored but emotionally cool abstract painting that succeeded Abstract Expressionism in the early 1960s, died on Friday in Philmont, N.Y. He was 71 and lived in Hudson, N.Y.

title: A Return to That Drop-Dead Year 1960
description: IM from Bay Ridge. We have manners, Peggy, the pony-tailed secretary, scolds the colleague who has just propositioned her in Mad Men, the new drama on the cable channel AMC. Do Peggys colleagues at Sterling Cooper, the turbo-powered advertising agency where she works, fall a little short in that department?

title: Correction: 	Its Summer: Isnt Anyone at Work?
description: The Lifes Work column on Aug. 9, about low productivity in summer, misstated the name of the research division of Kronos Inc., a productivity management company, which did a survey showing that 39 percent of the 1,077 full-time employees it questioned admitted to calling in sick to enjoy a day off in summer. It is the Workforce Institute, not the Workplace Institute.

title: Kid Nation Parents Gave Show Free Rein
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 22  Children who participated in Kid Nation, a CBS reality show that has come under fire over questions of whether it violated child safety and labor laws, were required to do whatever they were told by the shows producers, 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, or risk expulsion from the show, according to a copy of the contract signed by the children and their parents.

title: New Orleans Flood Plan Upgrade Urged
description: Federal officials outlined plans yesterday for a significant improvement to the New Orleans flood-protection system by 2011, but said the total cost would be more than double the $7.1 billion that Congress has already appropriated for repairs and upgrades.

title: Hikers Guidebook Is Reinvented Online
description: BOSTON, Aug. 22  For people who hike the White Mountains of New Hampshire, the Appalachian Mountain Clubs guidebook for the area has been required reading for 100 years, as essential a part of a hikers gear as a backpack or sturdy boots.

title: Memory Cards for Antiquity
description: Q. How long can I store pictures on a memory card?

title: The Subject Was ... Something Else
description: Trying to talk tennis with Serena Williams, Susan Dominus discovered, is like trying to return one of her 120-m.p.h serves. You just keep swinging and missing. Maybe its because she always gets the same questions about tennis, Dominus says, or maybe its because, for her, its like talking about work.

title: Aprs Rehab: A Lovely Sobriety
description: FASHION designers usually hate things that women can actually wear. Or, at any rate, they hate it when someone calls their clothing wearable. They feel profoundly reduced by the taint of utility. For that reason, a lot of fashion in the last few years has looked not merely extreme but also tangential to womens lives.

title: Pakistan Court Allows Return of Exiled Leader
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Aug. 23  Pakistans Supreme Court ruled today that the former prime minister Nawaz Sharif, who was thrust into exile in 2000 after a military coup, could return to the country, in what could be a direct political challenge to Pakistans president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf.

title: Grace Paley, Writer and Activist, Dies
description: Grace Paley, the celebrated writer and social activist whose short stories explored in precise, pungent and tragicomic style the struggles of ordinary women muddling through everyday lives, died on Wednesday at her home in Thetford Hill, Vt. She was 84 and also had an apartment in Manhattan.

title: Firefighter Killed in Lower Manhattan Is Mourned
description: A fire engine rolled through the streets of Brooklyn this morning, a coffin draped in the red and white flag of the fire department sitting on its back. Bagpipes wailed, a caravan of black cars carrying grieving family members followed, and along the streets, rows and rows of men and women in blue suits stood in silence.

title: Curiouser and Curiouser
description: New York State politics has become an arena best entered through the looking glass. First, Gov. Eliot Spitzers team tried to reveal the bad transportation habits of his chief Republican opponent by pushing state troopers to reveal all. Then came the investigations of his administrations bad habits in using state troopers for political purposes. And now there is The Phone Call.

title: Unsafe Mining
description: The announcement by the operators of the Crandall Canyon Mine that they will keep searching for the six miners trapped below the surface, and close the mine for good if they find no signs of life, is a welcome decision.

title: Tight Leader Board at Met Open
description: Rick Hartmann of Atlantic Golf Club in Bridgehampton, N.Y., shot a four-under-par 67 to hold a one-stroke lead after the first round of the 92nd Met Open Championship at The Meadow Brook Club in Jericho, N.Y. A stroke behind Hartmann were Mark Schaare of Knob Hill (N.J.), Charlie Meola of Fairview Country Club in Greenwich, Conn., and Anthony Casalino of Willow Ridge in Westchester County. Andrew Giuliani of Van Cortlandt, the 2006 M.G.A. Player of the Year, was at par 71.

title: Cue the Film Awards Season and Strike a Somber Note
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 22  Given the signals preceding next months bellwether Toronto International Film Festival, party planners might want pick to up some black crepe to go with those red carpets in the movie awards season to come.

title: 4 Major Banks Tap Fed for Financing
description: The countrys four biggest banks announced yesterday that they had each borrowed $500 million from the Federal Reserve, taking an unusual step to ease the credit squeeze that has been rattling the financial system for weeks.

title: Zimbabwe: Price Crackdown Eased
description: Faced with barren store shelves nationwide, the government has slightly eased its two-month rollback of prices, allowing retailers to mark up the prices of some basic commodities and farm goods by 20 percent. Most commodities vanished from stores when the government ordered all prices cut by at least 50 percent in late June; factories and retailers have been unwilling to restock, because the artificially low prices would have forced them to sell at a loss. The price rollback was an attempt to quell inflation, which was said by the government yesterday to average 7,600 percent a year but is regarded by experts to run at twice that rate. Those experts said the tiny price increases being allowed by the government were unlikely to spur production of new goods. The government has arrested, jailed or fined 12,000 business managers for violating price decrees under the rollback.

title: Passion for Film Spurs New Festivals, but Grueling Work Keeps Them Going
description: Lunch hours were the first casualty of Tom OMalleys ambition. He sacrificed his afternoon breaks sometime last November as he pushed ahead with plans for the inaugural American Cinematic Experience Film Festival. His living room went next, overtaken by piles of paperwork and plastic tubs stuffed with DVD submissions for the event. Then his bank account took a hit.

title: Sarkozys New Order
description: WASHINGTON

title: Showtime in Austin
description: Its not often that a writer turns out an article then finds his topic has become his neighbor. But thats what happened to Michael Hall after he reported a story for the current issue of PLAY on the TV show Friday Night Lights. Hall, a senior editor at Texas Monthly, discovered that Lights, which is filmed in Austin, was making the rounds of the neighborhoods. They shot a bar scene half block from my house last week, Hall says. They park cameras and trucks and catering services a block from our house in a church parking lot. People are used to seeing them. Theyre all over Austin -- bars, record stores, book stores, and generally the hipster places.

title: 2 G.M. Brands, a Similar Car, but Very Different Results
description: DETROIT, Aug. 22  When General Motors first showed off the Pontiac Solstice, the low-slung, head-turning roadster, it seemed the perfect antidote for the brand, whose flagship sedan had become known as the Bland Am.

title: Bangladesh Imposes Curfew to Stifle Protests
description: DHAKA, Bangladesh, Aug. 22  Shattering the calm of seven months of army-backed rule, violent clashes between students and the police led the government to impose an indefinite curfew on Wednesday night in six of the countrys largest cities, in a return of the political instability that prompted a caretaker government to take power in January.

title: Connecticut Court Nominee Withdraws Over Immigrant Remark
description: HARTFORD, Aug. 22 (AP)  Judge John R. Downey of State Superior Court, Gov. M. Jodi Rells nominee for the State Appellate Court, withdrew his name from consideration on Wednesday after court transcripts showed that he had mistakenly claimed that only legal residents could use the court system.

title: Hurricane Dean Fades, Leaving Behind Less Damage Than Expected
description: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 22  Hurricane Dean, with its ferocious winds, monstrous Category 5 status and long trail of death and debris, was certainly no dud. But the weakened storm that swept ashore on Mexicos gulf coast on Wednesday wreaked far less havoc than many anticipated it would.

title: Play iPod D.J., With Those Essential Scratching Sounds and Smooth Transitions From Song to Song
description: As technology marches on, things are left behind. The clock radio supplants the rooster, the horseless carriage overtakes the coach-and-four, and the vinyl record player falls to the Numark iDJ2.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article and headline in Business Day yesterday on the investment returns posted by the endowment of Harvard University misstated the return for fiscal 2007, which ended June 30. The return was 23 percent, not 22.4 percent. (The figure published in The Times did not take into account net distributions to the university.) The article also misstated the value of the University of Virginia endowment. It is $4.3 billion, not $880 million.

title: Manning Makes Strong Defense of Manning
description: Indianapolis Colts quarterback Peyton Manning, whose leadership ability was once questioned by a teammate, joined the fray between his younger brother Eli and the former Giants running back Tiki Barber, now a commentator for NBC. During a television broadcast Sunday night, Barber criticized Elis leadership skills. Eli fired back at Barber on Tuesday, and Peyton took a shot yesterday at former players who join the news media after their playing careers end and then criticize current players.

title: Pettitte Helps Yankees Avoid Sweep in Anaheim
description: ANAHEIM, Aug. 22  The Yankees fled Angel Stadium on Wednesday night, grateful to have won a game, thrilled that they will not have to see this place for another year.

title: Two Monitors, One PC
description: Q. Is there a way to connect two monitors to a Windows XP computer so I can keep my e-mail window up in one and do the rest of my work on the other?

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: Browning of the Clematis

title: Assurances on Buybacks May Cost a Lender
description: Expanding rapidly as the nations largest home mortgage company, Countrywide Home Loans quietly promised investors who bought its loans that it would repurchase some if homeowners got into financial difficulties.

title: Record Profit at Australian Mining Giant
description: BHP Billiton of Australia, the worlds largest mining company, reported an eighth consecutive record profit yesterday and said that weakness in the American housing market showed no sign of reducing demand for commodities in Asia and Europe.

title: Correction
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about the pending deal to take Tribune Company private referred incorrectly to Tribunes retirement benefit plans. The company has not halted contributions to retirement plans, nor would the proposed transaction to take the company private eliminate contributions to a retirement plan in exchange for stock ownership. The article also misstated the decline in Tribunes print and online advertising revenue for the first half of 2007 compared with the same period in 2006. The decline was 8.7 percent, not 11.2 percent. (Go to Article)

title: Older Players Lose the Swagger but Gain the Swag
description: With preteens forming corporate relationships and 20-somethings locked into wildly lucrative deals, tennis marketing often seems dominated entirely by the youth of the sport. But each year, hundreds of seniors across the country take the sports marketing to the opposite end of the age spectrum.

title: Godfather of Soul; Father Many Times Over
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 22  Callers to a certain Houston residence have lately been greeted by a cheerfully assertive message: You have just reached the home of LaRhonda Petitt Brown.

title: Ranch House Made Over: From Modest to Modernist
description: SIX years ago, Greg Lemke, a scientist in La Jolla, Calif., took a close look at his modest 40-year-old house and realized, he said, that the basic structure  plumbing, drains, wiring, roof, furnace  was starting to fall apart. Mr. Lemke, an architecture buff, figured that while fixing all those things, he should try to turn the ordinary ranch house into something more distinguished.

title: Organic Looks Easy, if Youve Got a Royal Staff
description: Tetbury, England

title: Estonia Accuses Ex-Official of Genocide
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 22  The authorities in Estonia on Wednesday said that they had charged a cousin of a former president with genocide in connection with his role as a Communist bureaucrat involved in the deportation of civilians to Siberia in 1949.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on July 31 about efforts to stabilize the shrinking year-round population of Fishers Island, N.Y., an enclave for the wealthy in summer, referred incorrectly to public services on the island. Although most homes have septic tanks, there is in fact a sewer system that serves an estimated two dozen homes, according to an engineer who does inspections on the island.

title: Japanese Trade Surplus Narrowed in July
description: Japans trade surplus narrowed more in July than economists had forecast as automobile exports cooled, heightening concern that growth in Japan, the worlds second-largest economy, might slow.

title: Room to Improve
description: Q. How should I decorate a long, narrow living room?

title: No, I Havent Been Mugged. Why Do You Ask?
description: YOU know fall is upon us when beauty companies start pushing femme fatale makeup.

title: As Industries Wane, Entrepreneurs Reinvent
description: THE Wick family, owners of a century-old company that makes pipe organs, could have easily given up. Demand for the organs has plunged over the last few decades, as churchgoers took a liking to the modern sounds of electronic instruments. Soaring manufacturing costs have made new pipe organs prohibitively expensive, with some organs priced over $1 million.

title: Lehman Closes Subprime Unit and Lays Off 1,200
description: Lehman Brothers, a leader in packaging subprime mortgages into securities, said yesterday that it would shut one of its home lending units and lay off 1,200 employees. The bank said it would take a $52 million charge to third-quarter earnings.

title: South Africa: Study Challenges Garlic Claim
description: In an implicit rebuke to the Health Ministry, the Academy of Sciences of South Africa said its studies had found no scientific basis for the use of nutritional supplements as a first-line defense against H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS. The countrys health minister, Manto Tshabalala-Msimang, has been widely criticized for questioning the safety of anti-H.I.V. drugs and promoting nostrums like garlic, beetroot and lemon as effective agents against the disease. The academys report did not rule out the usefulness of good nutrition in countries like South Africa, where malnutrition is more widespread, and noted that a good diet was important in maintaining the bodys defenses against AIDS. But a healthy diet, it stated, plays a backup role to drugs like antiretrovirals in the bodys fight against AIDS.

title: Tip of the Week: Setting Your Cellphones Alarm-Clock
description: TIP OF THE WEEK: Dont rely on a confusing (or broken) hotel alarm clock when traveling. Most cellphones include an alarm-clock function. Check your phones Tools or Applications menu. And if your phone can receive text messages and you use Googles or Yahoos calendar, you can set the software to send appointment reminders to your phone so you know where you have to be once you get up.

title: Presidential Candidates, Beware Your Children
description: The Bureau for the Monitoring of Theatrical Plot Overuse issued a Level 2 warning this week on story lines featuring a female presidential candidate whose campaign is imperiled by a sex scandal involving her grown son.

title: Council Committee Backs Rezoning Plan to Turn Jamaica Into an Airport Village
description: A plan to transform downtown Jamaica, Queens, into a vibrant airport village while preserving the quiet, low-scale character of neighboring side streets cleared an important City Council committee yesterday, all but ensuring final approval next month for the single largest rezoning of the Bloomberg administration.

title: Mystery and Mirth on the Streets of Laos
description: Laos may seem an unlikely setting for a series of terrifically beguiling detective novels steeped in local color and history. But look at what ingenious use Alexander McCall Smiths No. 1 Ladies Detective Agency books make of the equally exotic culture of Botswana.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An Arts, Briefly report on Aug. 11 about the hiring of Shawn Killinger as a host on the QVC shopping network referred incorrectly to the hours she is scheduled to appear beginning in December. She will be seen overnight, not during the day, and her appearances will last three to four hours, not a guaranteed four hours.

title: HBOs Rivals Say It Has Stumbled, Though Catching Up Is Tough
description: Has HBO, the pay-television channel stocked with so many outstanding shows that it declared itself in a category all its own  as in Its not TV, its HBO  finally tumbled from its pedestal of prestige?

title: Lehman Closes Subprime Unit and Lays Off 1,200
description: Lehman Brothers, a leader in packaging subprime mortgages into securities, is shutting down one of its home lending units and laying off 1,200 employees. The bank said it would take a $52 million hit to third-quarter earnings.

title: Japan Pushes for Stronger Partnership With India
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 22  Japan pushed on Wednesday for stronger economic ties to India with one of the largest business delegations to visit here.

title: Ah, the Tonic of Ginseng! Especially a $65,000 Sprig!
description: JINAN, South Korea  A roadside restaurant here was abuzz one recent morning with talk of a $65,000 ginseng plant.

title: Many Found Sexually Active Into the 70s
description: Most Americans remain sexually active into their 60s, and nearly half continue to have sex regularly into their early 70s, researchers are reporting today as a result of the most comprehensive national survey to date of sexual behavior among older adults.

title: Top Half of Women's Draw Features Drama
description: Maria Sharapova has not won a Grand Slam event since last years United States Open, where she jumped ecstatically on the court in her glamorous black dress, blowing kisses.

title: Sometimes in Life, Threes Not a Crowd
description: OSTERVILLE, Mass.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An art review on Aug. 10 of A Vicious Undertow, a film by Jesper Just at the Perry Rubenstein Gallery, referred incorrectly to another filmmaker whose camera work was similar. He is Max Ophuls, not his son, Marcel Ophuls, a documentary maker.

description: To the Editor:

title: Comeback Chance for Griffin Ends in Fiery Crash
description: The last time Keith Jones saw him, Eddie Griffin was smiling, upbeat and chatty. They met by chance last spring, at a Houston restaurant, and it seemed to Jones, a Rockets vice president, that Griffin  the troubled former Rockets forward  was optimistic.

title: Gambling Dispute With a Tiny Country Puts U.S. in a Bind
description: With long blond hair reaching his shoulders and dozens of cloth bracelets peeking out from under his sleeves, Mark E. Mendel hardly conjures up the image of a typical lawyer.

title: The Liberty Is Hoping Its Big Body Comes Up Big
description: TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 22  When the Liberty opens its W.N.B.A. playoff series Friday night against the Detroit Shock at Madison Square Garden, Janel McCarville will play power forward or center. For a while, it did not seem she would be playing meaningful time anywhere, let alone become one of the most promising young players in womens basketball.

title: Reed Finds a Familiar Face in Comeback Try as a Giant
description: ALBANY, Aug. 22  J. R. Reed trotted onto the practice field on his first day as a Giant about as anonymously as possible. His name had not yet been added to his No. 30 jersey Wednesday morning. In fact, he did not even have the number to himself. Another No. 30, DeCori Birmingham, worked out across the field at running back.

title: Strike a Pose (Theres Nothing to It), and Dance, Priestesses, Dance
description: Like very high priestesses of separate and ancient religious cults, the dance soloists Pilar Rioja and Roxane DOrlans Juste have come together to share a program, 2 Styles, 1 Passion, at Repertorio Espaol. You could say that each in her own way is a dancer of the old school, at least in the sense that Randall Jarrell applies to a character in his novel Pictures From an Institution when he says, And if her school had been any older it would have been dead. It has been years since I have witnessed performances so wholly devoid of spontaneity and yet so anxious to indicate great artistry.

title: Manhattan: Hotel Evacuated in Fire
description: A small fire in a restaurant at 511 Lexington Avenue yesterday afternoon led to an evacuation of the Radisson Lexington Hotel, fire and hotel officials said. The Fire Department said a fire was reported on the first floor of the building about 3:30 p.m. Fire officials said 78 firefighters responded, and the fire was contained in the ductwork. The fire was under control about 4:30 p.m., fire officials said. Two civilians and one firefighter were treated for minor injuries, the department said. Brian Dunne, a spokesman for the hotel, said the restaurant, Raffles Cafe, was a separate business from the hotel, which was not damaged.

title: Drugstore Clinics Spread, and Scrutiny Grows
description: The concept has been called urgent care lite: Patients who are tired of waiting days to see a doctor for bronchitis, pinkeye or a sprained ankle can instead walk into a nearby drugstore and, at lower cost, with brief waits, see a doctor or a nurse and then fill a prescription on the spot.

description: To the Editor:

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday, about the discovery of remains of a field of manioc grown by the Maya in Central America in the first millennium A.D., referred incorrectly to the nature of the discovery. The researchers said it was the earliest evidence for cultivation, not domestication, of the tuber in the Americas. Manioc was domesticated  that is, modified to become a more usable food resource  a few thousand years earlier, probably in Brazil.

title: Like Mice on a Treadmill
description: If youve dusted off a pair of old running shoes since reading Gretchen Reynoldss compelling article on the effect of exercise on the brain, youre not alone. Most of the experts I interviewed said theyve started exercising more, Reynolds says. Ive run every day since I wrote the story.

title: Lottery Numbers
Two Weeks Later, Evidence and Memories of the Tornado Remain Vivid
description: For many New Yorkers, the tornado that struck southwestern Brooklyn two weeks ago may be little more than a memory of a novel visit by a typically Midwestern weather phenomenon. But on the blocks where the Category 2 tornado touched down, evidence of the destruction is still fresh.

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: Just Looking Could Be Costly Under Proposed Voyeurism Law
description: When women in his Queens district started complaining of a strange man standing under the steps of the elevated subway at Ditmars Boulevard, looking up their skirts, City Councilman Peter F. Vallone Jr. said he was as surprised as anyone to learn there was no law against it.

title: Whats on Tonight
description: 9 P.M. (CNN) GODS CHRISTIAN WARRIORS In the late 1970s conservative Christians began to play a larger role in American politics, a response in part to Roe v. Wade, the United States Supreme Court decision that legalized abortion. By the 1980 national election the Moral Majority, founded by the Rev. Jerry Falwell, helped defeat 12 incumbent senators. Whoever speaks up most gets to shape the culture, Ron Luce, the evangelical activist, said more recently to a crowd of thousands in San Francisco at this years BattleCry rally, above, whose mission is to train young Christians to battle secular virtue terrorists. In this special, the final installment in a three-part series about religious fervor, Christiane Amanpour looks at the ways evangelicals influence American politics, and speaks with Mr. Falwell in what was to be his last interview, just one week before his death in May, about his battle against abortion and his thoughts on the 2008 presidential campaign.

title: Head Turners
description: Make them stop and stare (for the right reasons).

title: BofA Buys $2 Billion Stake in Countrywide
description: Bank of America said Wednesday that it has agreed to invest $2 billion in troubled lender Countrywide Financial, buying preferred shares that carry an interest rate of 7.25 percent and can be converted into common stock at $18 each.

title: Top Banks Tap Federal Reserve for Financing
description: The countrys four biggest banks announced Wednesday that they had each borrowed $500 million from the Federal Reserve, taking an unusual step to ease the credit squeeze that has been rattling the financial system for weeks.

title: Takeover Talks Buoy Nymex Stock
description: Wall Street registered its approval Wednesday of a potential takeover of the commodities exchange operator Nymex, sending the parent companys stock higher. The share price jumped after the chairman of Nymex Holdings, Richard Schaeffer, said late Tuesday that the company had had preliminary discussions with a possible buyer. He said any deal must offer a meaningful premium to the current stock price.

title: Appeals Court Grants Bail to Ex-Qwest Chief
description: Joseph P. Nacchio, the former chief executive of Qwest Communications International who was convicted of insider trading, may remain free on $2 million bail while he appeals, a federal court ruled Wednesday.

title: Is the Bonus Bonanza Over?
description: Wall Street bonuses may be cut for the first time in five years as a result of the credit market freeze that is paralyzing leveraged buyouts, mergers and myriad computer-driven trading strategies, according to specialists.

title: RCM Takes Computer Task Bid Public
description: RCM Technologies, which provides specialty professional staffing, made public Wednesday its $105 million offer for Computer Task Group after it was rebuffed twice by the board.

title: Looking to Dump the Deal, MGIC Sues Radian for More Info
description: MGIC Investment, which agreed in February to buy rival mortgage insurer Radian Group but has since had second thoughts, has filed a federal lawsuit in Milwaukee to force the Philadelphia company to give it more information.

title: PayPal Founder Sees Gold in Sparkly Slides
description: PayPal founder Max Levchins latest start-up Slide, which makes helps MySpace and Facebook users make sparkly slide shows, may seem frivolous. But Mr. Levchin expects the lighter side of the Web to generate serious money, even more than PayPal did, which he sold to eBay for $1.5 billion in 2002.

title: Neuromed Swallows $53.3 from Investors
description: Neuromed Pharmaceuticals, a developer of pain medicines, announced Wednesday that it had raised $53.3 million in private financing to develop an opioid painkiller.

title: TXU and Its Bidders Spent $17 Million on Lone Star Lobbying
description: TXU and the private equity firms trying to buy the company spent about $17 million on lobbyists and advertising during the most recent session of the Texas state Legislature, according to a report by a group that tracks political spending.

title: 3i Plans to Build $1 Billion India Fund
description: Publicly listed British private equity house 3i Group plans to build on its already strong relationships in India with the establishment of its first dedicated India infrastructure fund, which has an initial target of $1 billion.

title: Deal Chatter Lifts Stocks
description: Stocks rallied Wednesday, building on the recent recovery, as takeover talk and bets that the Federal Reserve will cut interest rates next month cooled worries about the impact of the tightening credit market on equities and the economy.

title: HSBC to Shut Mortgage Office and Lay Off 600
description: The U.S. mortgage unit of HSBC said Wednesday it will close an office in Indiana, a move that will affect about 600 workers, amid a severe downturn in U.S. credit and housing markets.

title: Hedge Funds Seek to Block Arcelor Takeover
description: Three hedge fund investors in steel giant Arcelor asked a Dutch court Wednesday to block the companys 30 billion euro ($40 billion) takeover by Mittal Steel, saying that a revised share swap deal has cost them 152 million euros ($205 million).

title: Another Mortgage Lender Shuts Its Doors
description: Amstar Financial became the latest subprime casualty, announcing Wednesday that it is closing its mortgage banking subsidiary and transferring the operations to The Money Store.

title: Paris Hedge Fund Hit By Sentinel Collapse
description: Further indications of the financial damage done by the collapse of Sentinel Management Group started to emerge on Wednesday when Capital Fund Management, a Paris hedge fund, said it stood to lose 27 percent of its assets as a result of the cash management firms troubles.

title: Is VMwares Stock Too Hot?
description: The initial public offering VMware, the years best so far, was a bright spot amid gloomy market conditions. But MarketWatch notes that some analysts think that the virtualization software makers stock, which has already soared more than 150 percent, may be burning too hot, too fast.

title: Welcome, YouTube. Seriously.
description: When YouTube pitched its new ad format, it described to me the semi-transparent overlay ads as something that has not been available before. It probably should have added: on YouTube.

title: Regulators Cry Foul on Dubais OMX Stake
description: Borse Dubais planned $4 billion cash bid for OMX seemed in jeopardy on Thursday after Swedens Financial Supervisory Authority ruled it broke the law when it bought a large stake in the Nordic market operator on August 9. But the regulator will allow the sale to continue.

title: Blow to HSBC Bid for Korea Exchange
description: HSBC has suffered an early setback in its attempt to secure a 2.5 billion pound ($5 billion) takeover of Koreas sixth-largest banking group, Korea Exchange Bank.

title: Britains Law Firms See $24 Billion Bonanza
description: The top 100 legal firms in Britain collected more than 12 billion pounds ($24 billion) in fees over the last year and the best-paid partners netted more than 2 million pounds each from their share of profits, according to a report in Legal Business magazine.

title: Goldman Fund Is Said to Rebound
description: Goldman Sachss Global Equity Opportunities hedge fund rose 12 percent last week after the securities firm shored up the money-losing pool with $3 billion of cash, investors told Bloomberg News.

title: Banks Balk at Funding Home Depot Deal, Report Says
description: Home Depots plans to sell its wholesale supply division to a group of private equity buyers is in doubt because the investment banks involved are reluctant to fund the deal, even at a lower price, The Financial Times reported.

title: Perimeter Pulls In 2nd Round of Investments
description: Perimeter eSecurity, a provider of network security services, said on Thursday that it will have boosted its fundraising to more than $100 million this year after a second round of investments, this time from Goldman Sachs, Bessemer Venture Partners and the Stripes Group.

title: Ex-Wal-Mart Executives Suit Dismissed from Michigan Court
description: The scandal-filled legal battle between Wal-Mart Stores and its former senior marketing executive, Julie Ann Roehm, has been tossed from a Michigan state court, Portfolio.com reported.

title: Calculating a Private Equity Tax Hike
description: Efforts in Congress to more than double taxes on managers of private equity firms would generate little or no extra revenue to help pay for middle-class tax cuts that many lawmakers are seeking, a study finds. Buyout and venture capital firms would restructure their affairs to sidestep new tax laws, according to the study, by Michael Knoll, a law professor at the University of Pennsylvania.

title: K.K.R. Denies Delaying I.P.O.
description: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts on Wednesday denied a report by the Times of London saying that the private equity firm has put its $1.25 billion initial public offering on hold.

title: Flight for Safety
description:
The number of Iraqis fleeing their homes has soared since the American troop buildup began in
February, according to data from humanitarian groups.

title: Ford C.E.O. Warns of Credit Impact on Jaguar Sale
description: Ford Motor Chief Executive Alan Mulally said on Wednesday that volatility in global credit markets was a concern in its disposal of British luxury brands Jaguar and Land Rover, but the conditions were not slowing down the sale.

title: Morning Buzz: Behind Ground Zero Demolition Work, a Little-Known Company With Problems
description: In a front-page article, Charles V. Bagli, David W. Dunlap and William K. Rashbaum reveal that the John Galt Corporation, the subcontractor hired last year to demolish the former Deutsche Bank building at 130 Liberty Street, is not much more than a corporate entity meant to accommodate the people and companies actually doing the demolition job.In fact, the real companies behind Galt are the Regional Scaffolding and Hoisting Company, which is not in business to demolish skyscrapers, and former executives from Safeway Environmental Corporation, a company that had already been removed from one contract at 130 Liberty because of concerns about its integrity.

title: 2008: Who Owns Change?
description: Its a classic campaign theme thats bound to come up in presidential races. And, during the 2008 election cycle in particular, when it comes to the idea of change, each of the leading Democratic presidential contenders is trying it on for size.

title: Another in a series of F1 press conference reports
description: Felipe Massa was in quite a good mood at the beginning of the press conference, it seemed, as this race in Turkey is the place where he scored his first Formula One victory, last year.

title: In Pakistan, a Court Opens Doors for Musharrafs Foes
description: When Iftikhar Mohammad Chaudhry was reinstated as the chief justice of Pakistans Supreme Court in early July, the question immediately arose of how intensely he would challenge Gen. Pervez Musharraf, the man who tried to remove him.

title: Waiting for Products to Arrive
description: The other day, I was looking at some absolutely amazing pictures of my kids, on a beach, at sunset, that my wife took with our trusty Canon SD800 digital camera. It was just amazing to see the quality that could come from a little tiny shirt-pocket cam like that. I smiled. Yep, I thought, the pocket digital camera has finally arrived.

title: The Psychology of Numeracy
description: In this months Wired magazine, columnist Clive Thompson makes an outrageous and thought-provoking claim: that geeks like Bill Gates are better suited to comprehending the worlds problems than non-geeks.

title: Goldman to Take Stake in Chinese Cement Maker, Report Says
description: Goldman Sachs is in advanced talks to take a quarter of a privately owned cement maker in east China for nearly $80 million, marking the latest foreign foray into the countrys fragmented cement sector, Reuters reported Thursday citing an unnamed source.

title: Sporting Steroids: Ban the Ban?
MySpace, MTV Plan Candidate Chats
description: The popular social networking site MySpace is teaming up with MTV to hold a series of candid, unfiltered discussions this fall between young voters and the major Republican and Democratic presidential candidates.

description: An Associated Press-Ipsos poll released this week indicated that liberals read more than conservatives, and Pat Schroeder  the president of the American Association of Publishers, and the former Democratic House member from Colorado  made headlines when she tried to interpret the results.

title: Glowing Tents to Light Up Roosevelt Islands Southern Tip
description: Roosevelt Island has had many names: Mannings Island, Blackwells Island, Welfare Island. It has also been the home of institutionalized populations: orphans, smallpox victims, patients with mental illness.

title: Does It Feel Like  a Playoff?
description: The PGA Tours attempt to heighten interest in the latter part of its season begins today with the start of The Barclays, the first event in a new playoff tournament called the Fed Ex Cup. But Tiger Woods is absent, raising questions about how much meaning the playoff will have. Can golf, and other sports like Nascar and horse racing, really generate late-season interest with playoff formats, or do they appear more like gimmicks?

title: A Pair of Crushing Defeats in Baseball
description: The only thing worse than losing is losing really, really badly. And the only thing worse than that is losing so badly that history is made. And thats what happened last night in Baltimore, where the Rangers routed the Orioles 30-3, an offensive outburst unseen in 110 years.

title: Remaining On the Ground
description: Ill be on book leave for the next few months, slaving away on a book with my wife and so writing neither my column nor contributing to this blog. In my absence, Ive recruited a first-rate team of diverse commentators to blog in this space  and hence make this space far more interesting than it ever was when it was just my sandbox.

title: U-17 Update: Bad News
description: [UPDATED] The young Americans are out. Or, at least close to it. They could be playing for pride only in the final game of the first round of the U-17 World Cup in South Korea. They lost to Tunisia, 3-1, Thursday. The United States is bottom of the group with 0 points. Only a game on Aug. 26 against Belgium is keeping the Yanks around. Belgium beat Tajikistan 1-0.

title: CMon, Tim!

description: We New Yorkers like to think were on the front edge of things, but there are trends  or at least curiosities  that pass us by. That happen elsewhere but not here, allowing others to enjoy what we are so cruelly denied. That force us to accept that we may not really be at the center of the universe. That leave us bereft.

title: Firefighter Is Mourned in Brooklyn
description: Updated, 12:32 p.m. | Firefighters in their dress uniforms lined Fort Hamilton Avenue in Dyker Heights, Brooklyn, this morning at the funeral for Firefighter Joseph Graffagnino, 33, who died in the fire that consumed the former Deutsche Bank building in Lower Manhattan on Saturday.The funeral Mass at Saint Ephrems Church, at 929 Bay Ridge Parkway at Fort Hamilton Parkway, began shortly after 10 a.m. Gov. Eliot Spitzer and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg were both scheduled to speak. The other firefighter who was killed on Saturday, Robert Beddia, 53, is to be buried on Friday after a funeral Mass at St. Patricks Cathedral.

title: Raising the Roof
description: My head today is full of stray and no-account thoughts, replies to Big Mama and other points of interest. title: New Construction Accident at the Deutsche Bank Building
description: Updated, 3:20 p.m. | A piece of construction equipment fell from the scaffolding surrounding the troubled, partly demolished Deutsche Bank building in Lower Manhattan at 1:54 p.m. today, injuring two firefighters, according to city officials.The officials said that the injuries to the two firefighters were not life-threatening, but that one firefighter suffered a head contusion. The injured firefighters were taken to St. Vincents Hospital in Greenwich Village. It was not clear if anyone else was injured. Maria Newman of The Times has prepared a news article on the accident.

title: A Rare Four-Letter Day in The Times
description: Some readers have noticed that The Times, in reporting about Roger J. Stone Jr. and accusations that he made a threatening phone call to Gov. Eliot Spitzers father, included an unexpurgated transcript of the call in print, as well as audio.

description: Brazil will bring a potent, star-studded lineup that includes Ronaldinho and Kak to the United States in September for its games against the United States in Chicago on Sunday, Sept. 9, and against Mexico in Foxborough, Mass., on Wednesday, Sept. 12. Both games fall on FIFA international fixture days.

title: Quick Bits: The Late Edition
description: Jonathan Schwartz, chief executive of Sun Microsystems, says on his blog that he is changing the companys ticker symbol from SUNW to JAVA, because, well, Java is everywhere. (By the way, he explains that SUNW stood for Stanford University Network Workstation.) The funny part is the reaction down in the comments section. For instance: Jonathan, this is one more indication the board needs to look for someone with REAL ideas to lead a once great company. Youre all driving wonderful technology innovative and real engineers designed in the ground. Youre just a marketing weenie. Laugh, but name another chief executive who would let that go up. (Jonathan Schwartzs Weblog)

description: Even for Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, who has experienced more than one last stand during his time atop Iraqs shaky coalition government, the past few days must have been grueling. Several prominent senators and presidential candidates are calling for his ouster, President Bush and his lieutenants are voicing frustrations and a National Intelligence Estimate on Iraqs progress, released today, expressed deep doubts that he can overcome sectarian differences.

title: Learning to Stop Worrying and Love Surveillance
description: On Sept. 18, the United States will be waking up to life without the Pentagons Talon program, a database set up to track terrorism threats but later expanded to include nonviolent protests.

title: Sacco and Vanzetti, 80 Years Later
description: Throughout the 1920s, huge workers rallies were held in Union Square to demand the release of Nicola Sacco and Bartolomeo Vanzetti, the two Italian-American anarchists who had been arrested for murder in 1920. As night fell on Aug. 23, 1927  80 years ago today  a rally gathered in the square. Around midnight, a sign went up: Sacco Murdered. A short while later, another sign: Vanzetti Murdered.

title: Looking at the Extraordinary Steam-Blast Pipe
description: Con Edison officials said that they still cannot tell what caused a steam pipe to explode under Lexington Avenue last month, leaving one person dead and two seriously injured. But they showed pieces of the ruptured pipe to reporters at the companys sprawling plant in Astoria, Queens, this afternoon.Sections of the pipe, including one peeled open like a tin can, were laid out in an aluminum shed. Outside, rust-colored pieces of various other pipes and valves found in the crater were arrayed on the ground.

description: The efforts by ad agencies to whip up online-video trends are almost heartbreakingly dumb. But its wrong to weep for all of them.

description: The Food and Drug Administration today addressed a concern long thought to be on its agenda: sunscreen labeling.

title: Los Angeless Other Soccer Team
description: Not everyone in Los Angeles is embracing David Beckham. The L.A. Galaxy midfielder has catapulted the Major League Soccer team to the top of the soccer worlds consciousness. But the team, which has two M.L.S. titles in 11 years, is not the only team in the city. Chivas USA, founded in 2004, attempts to draw on a much deeper history and, the team hoped, a more loyal and far-reaching fan base.

title: Sony Defeats Truman
description: This just in from video-game reporting headquarters: Sony may be a consumer electronics giant, but its public relations folks arent so powerful when it comes to prognostication.

description: Senator John Warner, veteran of wars past and longtime Republican of Virginia, today called on President Bush to issue a strong signal to the Iraqi government by withdrawing a small contingent of American troops home around Christmastime.

description: Being around William Lanzana's love for food and family helped to soften Melanie Miller's idea that marriage is an antiquated institution.

title: Changes to Yahoo Video on the Way
description: Yahoos new chief executive, Jerry Yang, is hunkered down in the midst of a 100-day strategic review of the company (Kara Swisher of All Things Digital tells us were on Day 37) and isnt talking to the press. In fact, most of Yahoos top brass isnt talking either.

description: JAZZ
