description: Madeleine B. Stern, a prominent rare-book dealer, biographer and literary sleuth who helped bring to print Louisa May Alcotts long-lost Gothic tales of murder, sexual subjugation, opium dens and other things simply too dreadful to mention, died on Saturday at her home in Manhattan. She was 95.

title: Job Security Isnt Concern to the Yankees Mussina
description: DETROIT, Aug. 24  Mike Mussina flew home to Pennsylvania on Thursdays day off, and he took his son fishing. He was as successful with a rod as he was with a ball on Tuesday, when he started the Yankees 18-9 loss to the Angels.

title: The C.I.A. Report: Is Anyone Accountable? (4 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Never Mind the Details: The Mayor Is Rich
description: If you want a taste of how large Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is living, consider this: Last year, he bought a new property, his ninth, in Florida where his younger daughter, Georgina, can ride her horses; he paid his household help at least $500,000; and he still owns a prestigious Park Avenue condominium where a former companion, Mary Jane Salk, lives.

title: A Star on the Court Who Mingles Off It
description: Roger Federer is not lonely at No. 1. He has plenty of company off the court.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: The End

title: Ex-University Head in Texas on Trial for Money Misuse
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 24  With Texas Southern University struggling to survive as one of the nations largest historically black colleges, the former president once hailed as its savior faced a state jury here Friday, charged with misspending hundreds of thousands of dollars on personal luxuries.

title: Protest Broken Up by Armed Hamas Force
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 24  Members of the Hamas Executive Force broke up a demonstration by Fatah, Hamass rival, in Gaza City on Friday, firing into the air and briefly detaining journalists who were trying to document the events, according to news media reports.

title: When Seemingly Unimportant Cards Can Send a Vital Signal
description: At the first European Universities Bridge Cup, held in Bruges, Belgium, Aug. 4 to 9, the award for the best-played deal went to Jrmie Tignel, who was on the Paris Polytechnic team.

title: With Software and Soldering, a Non-AT&T iPhone
description: AT&T is paying millions to be the exclusive United States provider of Apples much-hyped and glowingly reviewed gadget, the iPhone.

title: Using All of Her Body to Cook, Latin Style
description: Ingrid Hoffmann, the latest arrival on the Food Network  her show Simply Delicioso is shown on Saturday mornings  seems to be quickly staking her claim as the countrys pre-eminent cleavage cook.

title: American Instincts in a French Executive
description: Denis Hennequin is a rock n roll chief executive.

title: A Dream Restored
description: SOWETO, South Africa  Unnoticed by the outside world, part of Arthur Ashes legacy  a tennis center for black South Africans  descended into decay and ruin long before his death in 1993.

title: Companies Agree to Pay to Settle SAT Error Suit
description: Two big testing organizations, the College Board and NCS Pearson Inc., said yesterday that they had agreed to pay $2.85 million to settle a class-action lawsuit involving more than 4,000 students whose SAT exams were incorrectly scored in 2005.

title: In Air Attack, U.S. Soldiers Kill 18 Gunmen
description: BAGHDAD, Aug. 24  American soldiers battled Shiite militiamen in a poor neighborhood in northern Baghdad early on Friday, firing from helicopters and killing 18 gunmen, the American military said.

title: Dispensing Friendship With Clients Stationery
description: A flier taped outside the Yorkville Copy Service on the Upper East Side boldly asks passers-by, in thick block lettering, if they happen to be F.O.B.

title: Squelching the Citizenrys Back Talk
description: The White House certainly has been guilty of mismanagement and lack of preparation on the big things, like the Iraq war and Hurricane Katrina. But it turns out that President Bushs encounters with ordinary Americans have been micromanaged and laboriously controlled for the past five years to weed out the merest whiff of protest. Citizen volunteers are enlisted to vet cranky-looking sorts outside the event, and rally squads of zealots are prompted to pounce on anyone who manages to slip through with an outspoken thought or an unscripted word.

title: After Plea, Vick Is Given Suspension by the N.F.L.
description: The National Football League suspended Michael Vick indefinitely without pay yesterday after he admitted in court papers that he paid for dogfighting bets and helped kill underperforming dogs.

title: Getting Their Groove Back, With Help From the Magic of Dance
description: David Leventhal, a member of the Mark Morris Dance Group, is teaching a combination from Mr. Morriss Three Russian Preludes to a crammed class of dance students. Mark made this for Baryshnikov, he tells them. Then I danced it. Now youre the third people to learn it.

title: Lebanon: Militants Families Leave Camp
description: Families of Fatah al Islam militants holed up in the battered Palestinian refugee camp Nahr al Bared, north of Tripoli, were permitted to leave under a temporary truce with the army. Their evacuation clears the way for a possible final military assault to end more than three months of fighting between the militant group and the Lebanese Army. A spokesman for the Palestinian Clerics Association, which mediated the operation, said 22 women and 41 children left the camp in buses accompanied by army vehicles, bound for interrogation. Two children were taken to a hospital. The battle days were not easy, and exhaustion features were apparent, said Sheik Mohammad al-Hajj, the associations spokesman. But the army has promised to release them very quickly. A senior military official said the army, which had been calling on the remaining civilians to leave the camp for weeks, might now open a final assault. The army does not have to worry about injuring children or women anymore, he said. Most of the camps 30,000 residents fled in May, early in the fighting. The army estimates that 70 militants remain inside. They have rejected calls to surrender.

title: When It Comes to Foreign Policy, What Counts as Experience?
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24  During Sundays Democratic debate, the candidates spent an awful lot of time discussing whether Senator Barack Obama has enough foreign policy experience to be president  so much so, in fact, that Mr. Obama quipped that to prepare for this debate I rode the bumper cars at the state fair.

title: Crucial Relief for Diabetics (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: To Woo Europeans, McDonalds Goes Upscale
description: LONDON  Taking a respite from an afternoon of shopping, Ita Clift sips a cappuccino at a McDonalds. Though she rarely sets foot in the fast-food restaurant, Ms. Clift says she dropped in to this one in the Edgware Road section of Northwest London for a quick boost of energy and because the restaurant looked so nice and sophisticated.

title: Wachovia Sues Mortgage Specialist Firm in Dispute Over Collateral
description: The Wachovia Corporation, the bank based in Charlotte, N.C., has sued the jumbo-mortgage specialist Thornburg Mortgage for failing to return collateral used in a derivatives transaction.

title: Pakistan Prepares for Former Prime Ministers Return
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Aug. 24  Officials from the party of former Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif announced Friday that he would be returning to Pakistan within weeks, but the government sent mixed signals on how it would respond to a Supreme Court ruling that threw open the coming parliamentary campaign to all political players.

title: Fighting Al Qaeda (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Window Gazing (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Luxury Miami Condo Conversion Is Facing Financial Trouble
description: In a sign that the real estate slowdown has hit even the most desirable locations, the developer converting the Savoy Hotel in the South Beach section of Miami into multimillion dollar Fendi-designed condominiums and condo hotels may be facing foreclosure.

title: Chvez Is Ready to Return to Mets After Long Layoff
description: More than 11 weeks since going on the disabled list with a strained left hamstring, Endy Chvez returned to Shea Stadium and pronounced himself fit to rejoin the Mets. General Manager Omar Minaya said Chvez, who was awaiting clearance from the teams training staff and doctors, should be added to the roster by the end of this weekend.

title: After Two Years, a Tangled Mix of Good and Bad
description: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 24  It is hurricane anniversary season in New Orleans, and the beleaguered city is threatened with a new inundation: a tidal wave of reports, assessments, stock-takings, prognostications and tongue-lashings.

title: A Treaty Whose Time Has Come
description: A solemn international treaty known as the Law of the Sea Convention will celebrate its 25th anniversary this December, and for 25 years the mere mention of its name has been enough to induce deep slumber. Yet for all kinds of reasons  not least growing fears about the availability of energy resources  people are finally paying attention. That includes the Senate, where right-wing scare tactics and official inertia have long blocked the treatys ratification, leaving America as the only major power standing on the sidelines.

title: Spirited Reminders of a Time Long Gone
description: The Lincoln Center Out of Doors festival has always had a populist tinge, particularly under the directorship of Jenneth Webster. With free admission and a wide range of dance and music events, the festival sprawls into just about every nook and cranny of Lincoln Center Plaza every summer, encouraging ambling passers-by to stop, look and perhaps even stay a while to watch the goings-on.

title: Yankee Caps Pulled After Protesters See Gang Links in Symbols and Colors
description: Major League Baseballs official cap manufacturer said yesterday that it would remove headwear bearing the colors and symbols of three gangs  the Bloods, the Crips and the Latin Kings  one day after activists protested the sale of the caps at retail stores in East Harlem.

title: Running an Empire? No Sweat
description: Richard D. Parsons sat down at a quiet table by a window at Porter House New York, the fine year-old steakhouse on the fourth floor of the Time Warner Building, and looked at his watch. It was 7 p.m. Im going to have to leave at 8:30, he said. Ive got another meeting. He shot me a small, pained shrug. Its the middle of August, and Im still busting my chops.

title: Leslie Lukash, Medical Examiner, 86, Dies
description: Dr. Leslie Lukash, who, as a self-described diagnostician of death helped identify the corpse of Josef Mengele, the Nazi doctor, and who oversaw the autopsies of as many as 50,000 bodies in more than four decades as the medical examiner of Nassau County, died on Aug. 16 in Manhasset, N.Y. He was 86.

title: One Part Cement, Two Parts Whimsy, One Odd Park
description: ST. LOUIS  In an industrial area here known for truckyards, not art, a sculptor and entrepreneur named Bob Cassilly stands on a 100-foot-tall hill, created from some of the 182,000 truckloads of dirt that have been unloaded and applied to the skeleton of a former cement factory.

title: Access to the Courts (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Minister Guilty in Gay Marriage Case
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 24 (AP)  A Presbyterian minister was found guilty of violating church law for officiating the weddings of two lesbian couples, the ministers defense team said Friday.

title: Chinese Seek to Buy a U.S. Maker of Disk Drives
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 24  A Chinese technology company has expressed interest in buying a maker of computer disk drives in the United States, raising concerns among American government officials about the risks to national security in transferring high technology to China.

title: New-Home Sales Climb, Giving Markets a Break
description: A rise in sales of new homes last month provided an unexpected respite from the steady stream of dismal housing market statistics lately, but economists cautioned that it was unlikely to last.

title: Giuliani Boasts of Surplus; Reality Is More Complex
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani has been broadcasting radio advertisements in Iowa and other states far from the city he once led stating that as mayor of New York, he turned a $2.3 billion deficit into a multibillion dollar surplus.

title: Who Will Pay for the Next Hurricane?
description: Philadelphia

title: Jammin With Gabriel
description: They were rambunctious geniuses  Charlie Parker, Dizzy Gillespie, Bud Powell and Max Roach  the nucleus of a group of immensely talented musicians who engineered a revolution in jazz as wondrous and profound as the birth of Cubism in painting.

title: A Second Day, a Second Massing of Grief for a Lost Firefighter
description: Amid the somber majesty of St. Patricks Cathedral, thousands of firefighters, friends and relatives paid tribute yesterday to Robert Beddia, a 23-year veteran of the New York Fire Department, evoking his professionalism and the simple pleasures in his life, from poker and paddle ball to the many nieces and nephews he doted on.

title: To Pick a Kicker, Giants First Need to See Them Kick
description: ALBANY, Aug. 23  As much as the Giants would like to see their offense move the ball crisply against the Jets in Saturdays preseason game, they really could use a few stalled drives. Field goals may be more important than touchdowns.

title: 2 Palestinians Killed After Attacking Israeli Army Post
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 25  Two Palestinian gunmen entered Israel from the Gaza Strip early today, attacking an Israeli Army post near the Erez crossing and moving nearly half a mile into Israel before soldiers killed them, Israeli and Palestinian officials said.

title: Head-On Collision in Connecticut Kills 4 Teenagers and Injures 3 Adults
description: BRISTOL, Conn., Aug. 24  Four teenagers from nearby towns who had met on MySpace never made it home from an evening swim at another friends pool on Thursday night. They were killed when the driver of their speeding Subaru sports car lost control and veered into an oncoming car in the opposite lane, according to the police and interviews with young people who knew them.

title: A Consumption Tax (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Guilty Plea Is Arranged in Tax Plot
description: The owner of the nations largest maker of machine tools agreed yesterday to plead guilty to conspiracy in cheating the government out of $34.3 million in taxes through what the I.R.S. called deceptive and elaborate tax evasion schemes.

title: Russia: Swiss Reject Request for Yukos Records
description: A high court in Switzerland has sharply criticized Russias case against Yukos, the former Russian oil giant that was essentially put out of business by Russian prosecutors after its founder, Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, clashed with President Vladimir V. Putin. In a decision released this week, the Swiss court denied the prosecutors efforts to obtain documents about Swiss operations of Yukos and suggested that the prosecutors had repeatedly abused their power. Mr. Khodorkovsky is serving an eight-year prison sentence in Siberia for tax evasion and fraud, charges that his supporters call trumped up.

title: An Economists Task: Building a Model for His People
description: Ramallah, West Bank

title: Difficult Cleanup Lies Ahead for Soaked Midwest
description: OTTAWA, Ohio, Aug. 24  Hundreds of families were kept out of their homes here on Friday as Main Street remained at the bottom of a milelong lake created by flooding from the Blanchard River.

title: Max Roach Is Remembered for Music and More
description: Max Roach was remembered at his funeral not just as a brilliant drummer who helped bring about radical changes in American music, but also as a committed activist who worked hard to bring about radical changes in American society.

title: Southeast Queens Is Split Over Makeover Proposal
description: When Gloria Black looks into Jamaicas future, she sees a grand restoration: Department stores will move into spaces where discount jewelers sell removable gold teeth; vacant storefronts, their windows taped up with yellowing newspaper, will fill one by one. The prosperous downtown of the 1960s  the one that drew families from Harlem and Brooklyn and South Carolina  will return to southeast Queens.

title: Wall Street, Still a Little Wobbly, Steadies Itself
description: THE stock market steadied this week after more than a month of volatility, partly in reaction to the Federal Reserves decision on Aug. 17 to encourage banks to borrow directly from the Fed at a lower rate and help ease the credit squeeze that has been rattling the financial system.

title: As Woes Grow, Mortgage Ads Keep Up Pitch
description: Wall Street may have soured on the mortgage business. But on television, radio and the Internet, the industry is as ebullient as ever.

title: Military Says It Can Repair Guantnamo Trial Defects
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24  In an effort to revive the war crimes trials at Guantnamo, military prosecutors argued on Friday in a special appeals court that defects in their cases identified by two military judges in June could be repaired and that the prosecutions could proceed.

title: New Laws for Housing Tax Break
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer signed into law yesterday three bills to revamp a popular tax break for developers and encourage the construction of thousands of apartments for low-income New York City residents.

title: A Detective Is Suspended Over Station House Escape
description: A police detective in Queens was suspended yesterday, a day after he let a nimble murder suspect escape from a third-floor window of a precinct station house during questioning, the police said.

title: A Trainer Takes It Slow and Saddles Fast Horses
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 24  Shug McGaughey is a patient man, and a prudent horse trainer. He does not feel compelled to enter horses in every big race; he shows up in them only when he believes he can win. He is here with Sightseeing for the Grade I, $1 million Travers Stakes on Saturday.

title: Bank of China Shares Plunge
description: BEIJING, Aug. 24  After appearing immune to the turmoil engulfing the mortgage market in the United States, China suffered its first serious setback Friday from exposure to subprime loans.

title: Ex-Klansman Is Sentenced to Life for Killings in 1964
description: JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 24  Calling the crime unspeakable because only monsters could inflict this, a federal judge on Friday sentenced a former member of the Ku Klux Klan to three life terms in prison for his role in the 1964 kidnapping and murder of two black teenagers in Mississippi.

title: The Ones to Watch in Osaka
description: With an Olympics looming in Beijing next year, the world track and field championships that begin today in Osaka, Japan, are a nine-day prologue to the main event, complete with the requisite heat and humidity.

title: Dollars for Sale
description: During the worst of the markets recent volatility, many investors moved their money into supersafe Treasury securities, temporarily boosting the dollar against the euro and the British pound. But of late, the dollar has resumed its downward trend of the past several years. And policy makers and currency traders are once again hypervigilant for signs that Asian central banks might redeploy part of their dollar-based debt holdings into non-American investments.

title: Whats on Tonight
description: 10 P.M. (Cinemax) THE DEPARTED (2006) Matt Damon plays Colin Sullivan, the boyish but sinister protge of an Irish- American mobster (Jack Nicholson, far left with Mr. Damon) who goes undercover as a state police officer; Leonard DiCaprio is Billy Costigan, a state cop who infiltrates the underworld and slowly loses his grip. Now each organization has discovered that it has a mole in its midst. Martin Scorsese won his long-awaited Academy Award for best director with this crime thriller, based on the Hong Kong film Infernal Affairs, which also snared Oscars for best picture, best editing (the wondrous Thelma Schoonmaker) and best adapted screenplay (William Monahan). Writing in The New York Times, Manohla Dargis gave a nod to Alec Baldwin and Mark Wahlberg in their roles as detectives: As do the rest of the actors, they prove that what really counts here, in the end, isnt the film, but all its swaggering men.

title: Choi Has Firm Grip on Greens and the Leader Board
description: HARRISON, N.Y., Aug. 24  In the midst of a wicked putting slump two years ago, K. J. Choi resorted to the well-worn path of the 30-handicapper: He watched an infomercial that all but promised to change his life.

title: Women in NASA Triangle Face Each Other in Court
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Aug. 24  The first time Capt. Lisa M. Nowak met Capt. Colleen Shipman was seven months ago in a parking lot at Orlando International Airport. They were together again on Friday, in a tense courtroom.

title: A Vietnam Quagmire of Ones Own (7 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: With Troop Rise, Iraqi Detainees Soar in Number
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24  The number of detainees held by the American-led military forces in Iraq has swelled by 50 percent under the troop increase ordered by President Bush, with the inmate population growing to 24,500 today from 16,000 in February, according to American military officers in Iraq.

title: Its Still Fat (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Generals Differ on the Timing of Troop Cuts
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24  As the Bush administration mulls options for withdrawing forces in Iraq, fault lines are beginning to emerge in a debate between commanders in the field who favor slow reductions and senior generals at the Pentagon who favor cutting the number of combat troops more deeply.

title: After Warning, Contractor Got Bank Tower Job
description: The City Department of Investigation strongly cautioned Lower Manhattan development officials against using contractors with ties to a troubled demolition company to tear down the contaminated Deutsche Bank building, a person with knowledge of the events said yesterday. But development officials went ahead and approved such a company anyway.

title: NASA Believes It Has Found Reason Foam Fell on Shuttle
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24  NASA engineers think they have found the cause of and a remedy for foam falling from brackets on the space shuttle fuel tank like that which recently damaged the Endeavour heat shield tiles, agency officials said Friday.

title: If Theres a High-Definition TV in Your Future, Wait Till After the Holidays
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 24  Consumers walking into an electronics store looking for a big-screen high-definition TV may find that the place looks and feels different from how it was last Christmas.

title: New Yorks Toxic Tower
description: With each days news about the dismantling of the old Deutsche Bank building at the World Trade Center site, blame for the deaths and injuries of New York firefighters spreads. Contractors, workers, inspectors, city and state officials  the list of the accused is growing extremely long. Enough. It is a time to find out what went wrong, fix it and devise a workable way to deconstruct this dangerous structure safely and soon.

title: A Gift Offer for Artists in China: Museums
description: SHANGHAI, Aug. 24  For years their work could not be exhibited in China, but now the countrys leading contemporary artists are being courted by major art collectors abroad and their paintings set records at international auction sales. A local government in Sichuan Province  the area in western China known for its natural beauty, spicy food and talented painters  is taking notice.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,716 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Thursday:

title: Stopping Penny, Mets Help Prez Win
description: The first seven innings went down like iced tea on an August afternoon. But no game, at least none that the Mets play, can end without the requisite nail-biting, Pepto-Bismol-swilling and head-shaking that have come to define the first three games of their homestand. So it was that last night, in the ninth inning, with the Mets clinging to a four-run lead, the Los Angeles Dodgers loaded the bases against Billy Wagner with one out to recall all those not-so-fond recent memories.

title: Georgia Says It Fired on a Military Craft Violating Airspace
description: MOSCOW, Saturday, Aug. 25  Georgian police forces fired machine guns at an unidentified military aircraft that violated a remote area of Georgian airspace on Wednesday, a senior Georgian official said early on Saturday.

title: A Summer Island Rallies Around Its Aging Chapel
description: COUSINS ISLAND, Me.  Gray-shingled with an inviting porch, this little islands tiny chapel looks like a summer home, its stained-glass windows the only sign that it is something more.

title: Jet That Helped Defeat an Alaska Governor Is Sold
description: It grounded one governor and did not exactly fly off the shelf on eBay, but the jet that came to symbolize the troubles of the former Alaska governor Frank H. Murkowski has landed with a new owner.

title: Iraqi Factions Self-Interest Blocks Political Progress
description: BAGHDAD, Aug. 24  The National Intelligence Estimate released Thursday illustrated convincingly that, despite the troop buildup, Iraq has failed to forge the political reconciliation that could lead to long-term security and economic growth.

title: U.S. Bomb Dropped; 3 British Soldiers Die
description: LASHKAR GAH, Afghanistan, Aug. 24  Three British soldiers died in southern Afghanistan on Thursday in an apparent friendly-fire episode involving a bomb dropped by an American plane, British officials said Friday.

title: Greece: Fires Claim 15 Lives
description: At least 15 people died as at least 140 forest fires raged out of control in the southern Peloponnesian peninsula. Fueled by winds and a three-day heat wave with temperatures up to 104 degrees that left forests and scrubland parched, the blazes, some of the worst in a decade, destroyed scores of homes and thousands of acres. The high winds prevented firefighting planes from taking off, news accounts said, leaving just ground forces to fight the fires. The emergency brought an appeal by the government for urgent help from other European Union countries. News reports said some of the victims had been trapped by flames near their homes and in their cars as they tried to flee. Tourists were also reported to be among the dead. With national elections in less than a month and public outrage already high over the governments handling of a rash of earlier fires, the governing conservatives called for a 24-hour suspension of campaigning as act of mourning for those killed in yesterdays infernos.

title: In Court Ruling, Noriega Is Cleared for Extradition to France
description: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 24  A federal judge in Miami paved the way Friday for Manuel Noriega, the former Panamanian general ousted by the American military in 1989, to face money laundering charges in France once his prison term in the United States ends next month.

title: At 70, McCain Takes On Talk of His Age
description: Senator John McCain was fielding questions at a town-hall-style meeting earlier this month in Ankeny, Iowa, when a woman raised her hand and asked him, from one white head to another white head, why he wanted to be president in such troubled times.

title: Quake Orphan Reflects Perus Loss, and Anger
description: PISCO, Peru, Aug. 23  Through the choking smoke and with little light to guide him, Luis Palomino dug furiously through the rubble of the San Clemente church here two hours after last weeks earthquake buried parishioners under a pile of adobe stones.

title: Germany to Ease Limits on Some Foreign Workers
description: BERLIN, Aug. 24  In a major shift in policy, the German government announced Friday that it would ease labor restrictions for skilled workers from East European members of the European Union in an effort to overcome serious shortages in key economic sectors.

title: Suspect Is Charged in Sexual Attacks in Miami and New York
description: A man the authorities said sexually assaulted three women in Miami and a homeless woman in Manhattan was tracked down after a two-year manhunt and arrested this week in Queens, the New York police said last night.

title: Two Big Law Firms in Merger Talks
description: Two major American law firms are in advanced talks about a merger that would create one of the nations biggest legal advisers, a person briefed on the matter said yesterday.

title: Praising Private Equity
description: THE conventional wisdom is that private equity firms are focused strictly on the short term.

title: Experts May Have Found Remains of Czars Children
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 24  Scientists in a Russian provincial capital say they may have unearthed the remains of two of Czar Nicholas IIs children, and are hoping to solve one of the enduring mysteries surrounding the start of the Bolshevik revolution.

title: A Top Sprinter Learns to Push Himself
description: OSAKA, Japan, Aug. 24  Tyson Gays secret to becoming the fastest man in the world this year is tucked away in a tattered three-ring binder.

title: A Guiding Hand on Icy Terrain
description: TUCSON, Aug. 21  The sun was a blistering spotlight on the desert landscape. Inside a resort hotel, John W. Schutt, mountaineer and guide to uninhabitable terrain, spoke of crevasses and ice fields, snowmobile convoys and the frozen, wind-swept places where he has spent most of his life.

title: Altria Board to Consider a Spinoff Overseas
description: The maker of the worlds most popular cigarette, Marlboro, may decide next week that American consumers are too much trouble.

title: Turkey: Presidency Remains Deadlocked
description: Abdullah Gul, the foreign minister and candidate of the governing party, again failed to win a two-thirds majority of votes in Parliament to become president. He is widely expected to cinch the post in a third round of voting next week, when only a simple majority will be needed.

title: Subway Supervisor Is Demoted for His Role in Fatal Acccident
description: The superintendent who investigators said was partly responsible for the death of a subway track worker has been demoted and will be assigned to a job as a cleaner, a person with knowledge of the disciplinary action said yesterday.

title: Little Room for Shorter Players on the Beach
description: Finding attractive players has never been a problem in professional beach volleyball, as is evident at the A.V.P. Brooklyn Open tournament on Coney Island, where world and Olympic champions will compete through Sunday. But it takes more than ripped abs and skimpy swimsuits to help fans appreciate the game.

title: In the Corner With the Gladiators: Trying Out the Life of the Cut Man
description: I GRABBED the mixed martial arts fighter Delson Heleno by the back of the neck and stared into his fiery brown eyes. Delson is a Brazilian-born welterweight, 29 years old, 5 foot 11 and 170 pounds, with a coffee-colored complexion and cauliflower ears. His shaved head was glistening with sweat and his chest heaved in anticipation of his bout in the International Fight League World Championship Semifinal.

title: Soggy, Endless Night in Motown
description: After a four-hour rain delay, it might be past Joba Chamberlains bed time.

title: A Threatened Future for Solidaritys Birthplace
description: The Gdansk shipyard in Poland may be forced in to bankruptcy as it faces European regulators and a modernizing economy that has left it behind.

title: F1 travel advice diary
description: Yesterday I put up no blog post, due to reasons of F1 logistical difficulties. I want to share those difficulties with you in order to A) Help readers with their own F1 travel plans, B) Give another angle to behind the scenes information, and C) Complain.

title: Its China vs. Russia, and China Leads
description: Halfway through a team match between China and Russia in the Russian city of Nizhniy Novgorod, China leads 27.5-22.5. The match started Aug. 20 and ends Aug. 30. Today is a rest day for the team match, which resumes tomorrow. The Russian Chess Federations Web site is covering the match, but it is all in Cyrillic. Chessbase.com and The Week in Chess are also following the match and they have the virtue for English speakers of not being in Cyrillic.

title: Poli-Book Best Sellers for August
description: With this month coming to a close, a few new titles have quickly moved onto the political best seller list of The Caucus, including books by two senators in the 2008 presidential race.

title: 2008: Judgment Day for Florida Democrats
description: Florida Democrats are once again crying disenfranchisement  this time pointing the finger at the Democratic National Committee. Party officials are set to vote today on whether to punish the Sunshine State for moving its primary up too far, to Jan. 29. The D.N.C. could eliminate all of the state partys delegates to the national nominating convention in 2008 and bar candidates from campaigning there before the primary.

title: Going Down to Yasgurs Farm
description: Yasgurs farm in upstate New York

A news analysis article on Thursday about President Bush's speech comparing the mission in Iraq to other wars described imprecisely the timing of the American withdrawal from Vietnam. While President Johnson in 1968 refused requests from commanders to increase the military commitment in Vietnam by hundreds of thousands of troops, the reduction in forces began in 1969, not 1968.

A listing of American military deaths on Monday included erroneous information provided by the Department of Defense on the surname of a soldier killed in Iraq. His legal name was Willard M. Powell, not Willard M. Kerchief III.

A front-page article on Wednesday about a report by the Central Intelligence Agency's inspector general twice misspelled the name of one of the Sept. 11 hijackers. The correct spelling is Nawaf al-Hazmi, not Nawaf al-Hamzi.

title: The Wonder Room
description: Selfridges in London has gone from high street to high end with the Wonder Room (right), its new luxury jewelry and gift emporium set to open Sept. 1. Shoppers who enter the 19,000-square-foot space from bustling Oxford Street will be able to stroll through an arcade of miniboutiques hawking such big-ticket items as Tiffany diamonds and Chanel fine jewelry, pause for a glass of wine in the Wonder Bar, then duck into a Dover Street Market-like concept store featuring an ever-changing bazaar of obscure perfumes, first-edition books, rare teas and other curiosities. "We didn't want the space to have a precious, museumlike quality," explains Anne Pitcher, the buying and merchandising director for Selfridges. "It's entirely accessible. It's Herms to Chrome Hearts, with a wall of sunglasses in between, and that's the fun of it."

They were the final strains of a riveting football season that was packed with epic games, high drama and a surprise ending.

Some of the statistics are bound to shock: Of Chinas 560 million urban dwellers only 1 per cent breathe air that meets European Union air quality safety standards.

title: Jets and Giants: Can You Feel the Excitement?
description: People are elbowing their way into Giants Stadium, getting ready to watch the annual preseason game between the Jets and Giants. A half-hour from game time, there must be, oh, 1,247 people in the stands. If they would quit going to the beer line, we could get an accurate count.

title: Torre Puts His Trust in Tampa. No, Really, He Does.
description: In past years, Joe Torre might have gotten a suggestion on pitching coming from Tampa, Fla., and ignored it. Billy Connors, a confidant of George Steinbrenners and a nemesis of the former pitching coach Mel Stottlemyre, was the organizations pitching guru.

title: Like the Virgins
description: Your window to brag that you knew the Virgins when is about to close. Until last year, they had no label, no shows and no record, so knowledge about this cool New York band was strictly by hipster word of mouth. Donald Cumming and Wade Oates met while modeling on a Ryan McGinley shoot in Mexico and decided to start a band to play the songs that Cumming had been recording in his East Village bedroom. They had barely recruited Nick Zarin-Ackerman and Erik Ratensperger and sent out demos before they were opening for Patti Smith and Sonic Youth and touring with Jet. It didnt hurt that the model Jessica Stam was seen wearing their T-shirt backstage at the Lanvin show. As for the actual music (expect a major-label album in the new year), think the Strokes you can dance to.

title: Drop Foreseen in Median Price of U.S. Homes
description: The median price of American homes is expected to fall this year for the first time since federal housing agencies began keeping statistics in 1950.

title: Christine Green, Paul Jarrett
description: Christine Lorraine Green, the daughter of Kathleen B. Green and David R. Green of East Greenwich, R.I., was married yesterday to Paul McGarty Jarrett, a son of Maureen O. McGarty and Dr. David B. Jarrett, both of Athens, Ga. The Rev. Charles F. Flagg, a Unitarian Universalist minister, officiated at the Governor Henry Lippitt House Museum in Providence.

title: Diet by the Sword
description: I am trying not to think what Freud would say about this roomful of mostly women brandishing big sticks. At Equinox on Broadway and 19th Street, we stand in rows facing a mirror, eyes trained on our wooden swords as well as on our leader, Ilaria Montagnani. Moving to the beat of music that sounds like rhythmic jackhammering, we squat, lunge, slice and slash. The class is called Forza. The footwork is simple, and there are only 13 sword moves. The difficulty comes in making each cut precise, putting the whole body behind the swing and controlling the stick.

description: Maria Ostrovsky, the daughter of Olga Ostrovsky and Zinovy Ostrovsky of Brooklyn, was married last evening to Andrew David Fagenholz, a son of Dr. Linda S. Fagenholz and Dr. S. Allen Fagenholz of Erie, Pa. Rabbi Stephen A. Klein officiated at Tarrytown House, a hotel in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Spirits in the Material World
description: If recent history has revealed an appalling tolerance for prognosticators who are invariably, fatally wrong, it has also been unjust to the farsighted augurs who somehow always manage to get it right. When an author has correctly anticipated the extent to which peoples identities would someday be defined by their presence on the Internet, foreseen how the medium would generate its own pantheon of heroes and villains with nicknames like Essjay and lonelygirl15, and even name-checked the Japanese Harajuku scene before it could be hijacked by Gwen Stefani, he tends to have certain labels attached to him, like an old beater priced to sell at a used car lot: prophet, visionary, futurist. But what if he just wants to be a writer?

title: Correction: The Road to Clarity
description: An article on Aug. 12 about typographical changes in American road signs refers erroneously to one adaptation of the Clearview typeface for standard design applications. A Greek version is planned; it does not yet exist.

title: Editorial Notebook: A Big Thinker From a Small Town Exits Politics
description: Keith Robbins, a 38-year-old Republican, has been the first selectman in the small town of Bozrah for eight years. But there is nothing small about the way he thinks. He is president of the Connecticut Conference of Municipalities and has, for two years in a row, led the Southeastern Connecticut Council of Governments.

title: In Natures Casino
description: It was Aug. 24, 2005, and New Orleans was still charming. Tropical Depression 12 was spinning from the Bahamas toward Florida, but the chances of an American citys being destroyed by nature were remote, even for one below sea level. An entire industry of weather bookies  scientists who calculate the likelihood of various natural disasters  had in effect set the odds: a storm that destroys $70 billion of insured property should strike the United States only once every 100 years. New Orleanians had made an art form of ignoring threats far more likely than this; indeed, their carelessness was a big reason they were supposedly more charming than other Americans. And it was true: New Orleanians found pleasure even in oblivion. But in their blindness to certain threats, they could not have been more typically American. From Miami to San Francisco, the nations priciest real estate now faced beaches and straddled fault lines; its most vibrant cities occupied its most hazardous land. If, after World War II, you had set out to redistribute wealth to maximize the sums that might be lost to nature, you couldnt have done much better than Americans had done. And virtually no one  not even the weather bookies  fully understood the true odds.

title: Capturing Bob: A Family Affair
description: The only person in fashion more wonderfully deranged than the outlaw photographer Terry Richardson was, not surprisingly, his father. Throughout the 1960s and 70s, Bob Richardsons highly charged blackand-white images brought somber emotion to the glossy but sometimes sterile world of fashion. Much of Richardsons oeuvre was destroyed during his erratic career, which was marked by mental illness and homelessness. The first comprehensive overview of his work is being published this fall, including his unfinished autobiography. Edited by his son, Bob Richardson (Grafiche Damiani) features a wide range of his best work, like his daring assignments for Harpers Bazaar  one infamous piece featured the model Donna Mitchel in tears  and early portraits of Anjelica Huston, then his girlfriend. I am not ashamed of anything, he said in 2002, three years before his death at the age of 77. I have no secrets. I am free.

title: At a Home Office, Lifes Little Interruptions
description: MORNINGS my wife drives off to work, while I go down to my office in the back of the house and start reporting and writing.

description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 25  There are no naming rights on the table and there will not be any logo-bearing neon signs, tower-to-tower banners or screaming billboards put up, either. That might ruin the view.

title: Have Clipboard, Will Canvass
description: KATIE GOLIEB assumed her ready position in the middle of a Park Slope sidewalk: wide stance, hips swaying, clipboard cradled in her right arm. An approaching woman in heels and a skirt, seeing that she had been marked, quickened her step, but not before Ms. Golieb called out to her.

title: Court Wont Hear Battle Over Embryos
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Aug. 25 (AP)  The Texas Supreme Court has refused to consider the case of a woman who wanted custody of three frozen embryos after her divorce.

title: Family Blessings
description: Not long ago while leaving a restaurant in Brooklyn, I walked into a strange and holy ritual. A red-haired priest in black suit and white clerical collar was out on the sidewalk blessing an iguana. Scales iridescent in the sun, the reptile looked like a small dragon. People gathered around and the sacrament had the undeniable air of divinity. After the priest made the sign of the cross over the lizard, he moved into the restaurant surrounded by true believers urging him to bless their son, their baby, their little yappy dog.

title: Revved-Up Reflections
description: IM a firm believer that loud tailpipes save lives, said Justin Theroux, as he pointed his matte black Ducati motorcycle down West Fourth Street on a recent Sunday and jerked the throttle, sending out a jet-level whine that ripped a gash in the evening calm surrounding Washington Square Park.

title: The New Halston?
description: When Harvey Weinstein announced this spring that he was going into the dress business, a couple of magazines made a fuss, but for the most part the fashion people treated him exactly as they would any newcomer. They regarded him with surprise and suspicion. It makes no difference that Weinstein is a successful producer of movies (he and his brother, Bob, started Miramax Films) and that those movies defied all kinds of conventions to win a total of 45 Oscars. Nor is there anything about his person that would send a fashion editor up the wall. He is polite, gregarious, at times charming. None of the bad faults for which he is legendary in Hollywood  the screaming, the harassing  are on display in fashion circles. And maybe it is for that reason that something about the sight of this bearish hetero sitting among the thin, knowing fashionistas compels sympathy as much as bemusement. Instead of getting in someones face, Weinstein, in this environment, has the companionable air of a man holding out his mitts so his wife can unwind her knitting yarn.

title: Driver Charged After One Is Killed and Three Are Hurt in Crash in the Village
description: A delivery worker was killed and three others were injured early yesterday when a drunken driver crashed a sport utility vehicle into their parked van at an intersection in Greenwich Village, the police said.

title: Spains Quiet Corner
description: FOR over 50 years all this was in ruins, said Jos Luis Cuerda, hands spread, nodding toward a mountainside covered with terraced rows of young winding vines and the massive stone home behind us, his adopted Galician sliver of Spain. Stretched out before him now, spilling from lush terraces, were fledgling plants: albario, treixadura, godello, torronts, loureira. These are grape varietals native to the Ribeiro, a region of broad valleys near Ourense, the capital of the province of the same name.

title: The Art of Collaboration: One Vision, Many Hands
description: FOR most of her career, Marcy B. Freedman, a video and performance artist in Peekskill, worked alone. Then she met Gene Panczenko, another video artist there, and things changed. The two joined forces, marrying his technical expertise and her ideas. Gene was my first collaborator, Ms. Freedman, 57, said. Our first project went so well that I was inspired to do more.

title: Sexual Preference
description: I swooned at the sight of Ccilia Sarkozy at her husbands inauguration in May. In her champagne silk Prada dress, the bodice stroking her torso, tiny pleats opening up at her waist and the skirt falling gracefully over the knees, she looked fresh, modern and sensual. And I wasnt the only fashion editor to salute this injection of glamour into a world usually dominated by pantsuits and momsy coat-and-dress combos. The French fashion press was even comparing her to Jacqueline Kennedy during the White House years.

title: Wassup? Docs
description: At the fall shows, the catwalks reverberatedwith the sound of stomping boots as Dr. Martens  those Humvees of footwear and artifacts of a million misspent youths  enjoyed a fashion moment. Yohji Yamamoto spearheaded the return, collaborating with the brand to create a limited-edition line; chunky lace-up boots also lent a subversive edge to feminine frocks at Chlo.

title: Eye Spy
description: Perched on the edge of her seat in a passenger lounge at La Guardia Airport, Clarissa Dalrymple rears back from her carry-on, aghast. Damn it! she says in a booming stage whisper. I forgot my pearls.

title: Never Mind the Monologue: Audition by Endurance
description: SIX feet off the ground, on a treadmill in a darkened theater, J. D. Smith was running, really pounding it, his forehead blistered with sweat, his white shirt billowing. Suddenly he stumbled, his legs moving but not connecting, like a colts. He doubled over. But just as quickly he righted himself, and the pounding began again. Then he heaved forward, falling face first toward the ground.

title: Getting Honest About Gambling
description: This year, after 10 years of avoiding the issue, the Connecticut General Assembly authorized a study to examine the effect of gambling on the state as a whole. This is a good step forward. After all, Connecticut is home to two casinos, Mohegan Sun and Foxwoods, that are among the worlds largest. The states lottery offers numerous games of chance, sold by about 3,000 vendors. And while gambling is harmless fun for many adults, it is a serious problem for some. It is therefore important for the state to get a balanced picture.

title: History Boy
description: Chris Benz may be originally from Seattle, but dont expect his customers to rock out in lumberjack flannels or defaced denim. I like the ease and recklessness of grunge, but Im not into holes, says the 24-year-old Parsons graduate (top), who was awarded a Council of Fashion Designers of America scholarship before interning for Marc Jacobs and working for J. Crew. His debut collection (go to www.chris-benz.com) was inspired by old-school glamour: the jazz-era shirtdresses, mohair jackets, mink jockey caps and twill jodhpurs had a flapper-meets-slacker vibe that never seemed stagey. Ill do slouchy pants with low belt loops and a wallet chain for a tomboy look, he says. But Im just as likely to put a chiffon flower on a blouse that Jordan Baker might have worn in The Great Gatsby.  He says his historical eclectism comes from a childhood spent rummaging through his grandmothers attic. Cedar chips and old clothes? Just dont call it grunge.

Brozonowicz, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Mary Mother of the Redeemer Church in Groton, Conn.

title: Kelli OHara and Greg Naughton
description: AS performers, Kelli OHara and Greg Naughton know that show business relationships are more notable for their drama than for their longevity. Yet, this couple is betting that theirs will be a long run.

description: ON its way to becoming the nations largest mortgage lender, the Countrywide Financial Corporation encouraged its sales force to court customers over the telephone with a seductive pitch that seldom varied. I want to be sure you are getting the best loan possible, the sales representatives would say.

title: Tales From Tehran
description: Your first novel, The Septembers of Shiraz, has become a surprise hit, in part because it so vividly captures the veiled world of post-revolutionary Iran and the unjust fate of one Isaac Amin, a Jewish rare-gem dealer who winds up in jail. Is the novel at all autobiographical? Its loosely based on my familys experiences. When I was 8, my father was arrested for being a Zionist spy. We didnt know where he was. My mom would go out looking for him. And then he just reappeared one day, about a month later.

title: Universal Faith
description: Another school year, another round of controversy about religion in public education. This fall, two new yet already divisive publicly financed schools are set to open: the Khalil Gibran International Academy in Brooklyn and the Ben Gamla Charter School in Hollywood, Fla. Both describe themselves as nonsectarian institutions that emphasize a particular language  Arabic and Hebrew, respectively  and both have been criticized on the assumption that they will be organized around the distinctive cultures (and thus religions) associated with those languages. Meanwhile, at the University of Michigan at Dearborn, a small firestorm has erupted over plans to install foot baths in school washrooms to help Muslim students perform the ablutions required for daily prayer.

title: Yonkers Keeps Going for the Green
description: YONKERS, the jewel of the Hudson? Thats the plan. Adding more green space to balance new high-density housing, Mayor Philip A. Amicone last week announced the dedication of seven acres of parkland downtown, most of it on the riverfront.

title: John W. Gofman, 88, Scientist and Advocate for Nuclear Safety, Dies
description: Dr. John W. Gofman, a nuclear chemist and doctor who in the 1960s heightened public concerns about exposure to low-level radiation and became a leading voice against commercial nuclear power, died on Aug. 15 at his home in San Francisco. He was 88.

title: The Politics of Appearance
description: So shoot me: at the end of the day (and the beginning, if it comes to that), in the high-definition show business of politics  as in everything else  looks matter. Appearance, whether we like it or not, has become the coin of the realm, the locus of our conversation: in our image-saturated, relentlessly scrutinizing Visual Age, we trade in it, subliminally or overtly, whether we are talking of Victoria Beckham or Hillary Clinton. All meaningful discourse seeks to end appearances, the sociologist Jean Baudrillard observes in his landmark 1979 book, Seduction, but then goes on to note that it is also an impossible undertaking.

title: Op-Chart: A New, Improved Congress?
description: JUST before Congress adjourned for its August recess, Democrats engaged in a flurry of legislative activity, while Republicans complained about a do-nothing Congresss meager policy accomplishments. Deep partisan differences, narrow majorities and a Republican in the White House have frustrated Democratic ambitions and fueled a toxic atmosphere in both chambers of Congress. The publics low approval ratings reflect broad discontent with the direction of the country but also displeasure with Congress for failing to reverse course on Iraq and for continuing the bitter partisan warfare.

title: Manhattan House Fight Escalates
description: THE huge $1.1 billion redevelopment of the Manhattan House on East 66th Street was to be the biggest condo conversion deal ever for Prudential Douglas Elliman and its best-selling broker, Dolly Lenz.

title: Endless Summer Job
description: In 1982, after my sophomore year of college, an agency arranged a summer job for me: a couple needed someone to assist the cook at their estate in the Hamptons. My friends couldnt believe I would sink so low  why not stay in the city, they asked, and attend rallies protesting apartheid? But the truth was that I was poor and really needed money for the school year.

title: Politicizing a Triple Murder
description: Common sense tells us that the one thing Newark does not need after its triple murder this month is a bunch of presidential hopefuls trying to exploit the situation. Unfortunately, that is exactly what the city is getting  first from Rudolph Giuliani, then from a much longer shot for the Republican presidential nomination, Tom Tancredo. Both have been trying to make political hay out of an unfortunate police error instead of addressing larger problems.

title: Sequels: Stay Fresh or Die Hard
description: I BLAME Aliens. Even though, 12 years earlier, in 1974, The Godfather: Part II had proven that a sequel could be both financially and critically successful, it was James Camerons exhilarating monsters-meet-the-military take on Ridley Scotts elegant space nightmare Alien that really stirred things up. Changing directors and adding writers, Aliens showed that you could significantly alter the mood, visual grammar and overall sensibility of the original, please critics and still recoup almost five times your production costs. More than any sequel before it, Aliens demonstrated that a good idea  and a female action hero in minimal underwear  had legs.

title: Sexual Politics
description: I am a lawyer. During a first date with another lawyer, we had sex, and I wore a condom. Days later, when I came down with a bad fever and couldnt determine the cause, she revealed that she had genital herpes. A judgeship will soon open up in her county, and shes a near lock for it. But if I report her lapse of sexual ethics, I doubt that the selection committee will pick her. Should I?  NAME WITHHELD

description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 25  A pair of synchronized explosions tore through two popular spots in the southern Indian city of Hyderabad on Saturday evening, killing at least 30 people and wounding 60 others in what state officials called a terrorist attack.

description: Pacific breezes cool the vines and keep grapes fresh in the Casablanca Valley, a young wine region west of Santiago, Chile, that is best known for whites.

description: MALIBU, Calif.

title: 36 Hours in Ottawa
description: OTTAWA has always had image problems. Back in 1857, when it beat out its rivals Toronto and Montreal in a bid to become Canada's national capital, the Governor General bemoaned Parliament's move to what seemed a frontier outpost on the Ottawa River as an exile to wilderness. Since then, this city of 1.2 million has been written off as a staid hub of government. But beneath Ottawa's buttoned-up, civil-servant demeanor lies a surprisingly vibrant community, with enough green space, trails and water within city limits to satisfy the most hyperactive of travelers. (Go ahead, call it the San Francisco of eastern Canada  it's worthy.) This summer, as the unlikely capital celebrates its 150th anniversary, Ottawa is embracing its wilder side.

title: Let the Dames Begin
description: Hugh Johnson, a serious if eccentric wine writer, did a delightful pop-up book years ago about hosting a fantasy dinner. Since it was his fantasy, he had dibs on the guests and the wines, and so entertained Napoleon, Sir Winston Churchill and other high-ranking poobahs. The Samurai Sipper has often fantasized similarly, only Id pass on Thomas Jefferson an d have Edie Falco over for a post-Carmela henfest instead. Id toy with serving a pinot grigio from Lorraine Braccos vineyards in Italy, but would decide thats overkill. A 2003 Rosso del Soprano from Astor Wines and Spirits, 399 Lafayette Street, is hardly subtle. Still, Edie might be struck by the wines wild grapes, grown since antiquity in Messina, and by my $150,000 Steinway & Sons Model D music system, which didnt fall off a truck.

title: Minding the Meeting, or Your Computer?
description: BACK in 1994, when portable PCs started their descent from 15-pound luggables to todays 5-pound laptops, I started taking mine to meetings at Microsoft, and so did my colleagues. So novel. So useful.

title: Wang Gives Weary Yankees Exactly What They Need
description: DETROIT, Aug. 25  Before he shut off his cellphone on Saturday morning, Joe Torre took one last call as he wearily returned to the Yankees suburban hotel around 4:30 a.m. It was Brian Cashman, the general manager, asking Torre if he needed a fresh pitcher for Saturday.

title: The Sound and the Fury, and Possibly the Danger
description: BRISTOL, Tenn., Aug. 25  The roar of nearly 50 revving engines reverberated through the mostly empty stands Friday at Bristol Motor Speedway as Nascars elite Nextel Cup teams took to the half-mile oval racetrack for practice.

Lasser, both of Brookline, Mass. Rabbi Chester Diamond officiated at the historic Henry Clay building in Louisville.

title: We Who Are on Vacation in Rome Salute You
description: I will endure to be burned, to be bound, to be beaten and to be killed by the sword is not the typical oath uttered by tourists visiting Rome these days. But the Rome Cavalieri Hilton (www.cavalieri-hilton.it) aims to change all that with its gladiator training program.

title: Blog Is the New Black
description: Are designers the new journalists? God help us, but it may be true, judging from the number of young talents who have taken to the keyboard. Sue Stemp, known for her thigh-baring cocktail frocks, has a Web site to chronicle the adventures of herself and her daughter, Kitty Babe. Hanuk Kim keeps a visual diary, which he e-mails to a select group; Chris Benz regularly reports on the goings-on in his West Village brownstone; and Hollywoulds Holly Dunlap says her site attracts an average of 80,000 hits a day. Hedi Slimane posts his austere photography on MySpace (above), which is also where the London avant-garde darling Gareth Pugh announces casting calls and requests for assistants. Even Donna Karan has given blogging a try, as a guest on HuffingtonPost.com. Her reason for doing so is clearly resonating with her colleagues: Ive simply gotten to a point in my life, she wrote, where I want to address people, not simply dress them.

title: A Field Trip for the Congestion Panel

Given that it includes both outspoken proponents and opponents of Mayor Michael Bloombergs proposal for congestion pricing, its meetings should be lively. They should also be open to the public, which will have to feel invested in any plan that has a hope of working. In addition, its vital that commission members be well-informed on the massive problem before them.

title: Top Shelf
description: Dont be surprised if the saleswoman at Saks asks for ID before she hands over Diors new LOr de Vie La Crme. Laced with Chateau dYquem, its the latest in cosmetic hooch, at an intoxicating $320 a jar. Capitalizing on the fact that grape seeds are packed with antioxidants (the scourge of free radicals, those molecular demons behind wrinkles), the cosmetics industry has been hitting the bottle since 1995, when the French company Caudalie introduced a skin cream spiked with Bordeaux. Now even a scion of vintners is getting into the act. Davi, the new skin-care line by Carlo Mondavi, is a blend of grape leaf, fermented grape extract, green tea and other vitamin-loaded ingredients. But wine isnt the only booze young Hollywood is packing for rehab these days. Thierry Muglers upcoming Angel La Part des Anges is a Cognac-inspired scent that is aged in cherry wood to produce a richer, plummier nose. Japans SK-II contains a byproduct of sake, and Jo Malones Blue Agava & Cacao has enough tequila notes that all you need is salt and a squeeze of lime. You can also fade your freckles with Caudalies latest: Vinoperfect Day Perfecting Cream SPF 15, a pigment-lightening compound that, sadly, does nothing for a hangover.

description: WOULD that thinking made it so, people sometimes wistfully say. But Christopher deCharms, the chief executive of Omneuron, a start-up in Menlo Park, Calif., believes the adage.

description: Are you ready, boys and girls? Lets play Why Is It Fashionable? All you have to do is pick an object. Not just any object, of course, but one thats hot, something like a coat or a chair that, when you pick it apart, tells you everything you need to know about the zeitgeist.

description: A dentist accused of exposing himself to a patient and then refusing to let her leave his Brooklyn office was arraigned in Brooklyn Criminal Court yesterday.

title: Louder Than Words
description: In July 1944, a member of the German resistance slipped a briefcase of explosives under Hitlers table as part of a conspiracy to take down the Third Reich. The bomb went off, but someone had unwittingly edged the briefcase aside and Hitler of course survived. The conspirators were arrested, their failure confirming Hitlers belief that he had been chosen to make history. Among those rounded up was the German lawyer and aristocrat Adam von Trott, who as a Rhodes Scholar in prewar Oxford had been a friend of the British philosopher Isaiah Berlin.

title: No Ordinary Joe
description: Flick through any fashion publication from the mid-1990s, and its likely to feel about as relevant as an episode of Sex and the City. But anyone lucky enough to get their hands on an issue of Joes magazine will have a hard time figuring out when it was published. At first glance, its oversize pages look undoubtedly contemporary  there is a long interview with Miuccia Prada, and photo shoots by David Sims, Mario Sorrenti, Craig McDean and Steven Klein. Only after careful inspection is it apparent that the Bruce Weber images of a nude, nubile Kate Moss are pre-rehab; on another page, Naomi Campbell is gently holding a baby rather than clutching a Swarovski-encrusted BlackBerry.

title: Nonfiction Chronicle
description: THE HALF-LIFE OF AN AMERICAN ESSAYIST. By Arthur Krystal. (David R. Godine, $24.95.) Arthur Krystal is not really a go-getter. A self-described aimless, melancholic, bumptious freelance writer, he shirks fashionable topics, even if they might bring in a buck. In the engaging title piece of this slim, occasionally stuffy volume, Krystal makes a vigorous case for the virtues of old-fashioned literary criticism, twitting the navel gazers of creative nonfiction, which he dismisses as just a fancy word for memoir: Writing interestingly about Jane Austen requires more imagination than confessing to having slept with someone named Jane Austen from Beaumont, Texas. Krystal ranges widely, taking on subjects ranging from the typewriter to boxing, and hes not afraid of weighty topics: he slogs through the notebooks of Paul Valry, ponders different theories of beauty and offers a defense of the seven deadly sins. (On the whole, he writes, it helps to have sin around; its like having a set of instructions for building a life that God approves of.) In My Holocaust Problem, Krystal (whose grandparents died in the camps) complains that the profusion of Holocaust books, films and memorials  the pomp and circumstance of remembrance  has trivialized the event. If the argument isnt terribly original, he subtly ponders the obligations of remembrance. In his charming concluding essay, Who Speaks for the Lazy?, Krystal returns to justifying his underachieving ways: Lets face it, some boys and girls become writers because the only workplace theyre willing to visit is the one inside their heads.

They observed that their policies were better for the middle classes. And yet the middle classes did not support Democrats. They tended to vote, in large numbers, for the morally and intellectually inferior party, the one, moreover, that catered to the interests of the rich.

title: Challenging the Generals
description: On Aug. 1, Gen. Richard Cody, the United States Armys vice chief of staff, flew to the sprawling base at Fort Knox, Ky., to talk with the officers enrolled in the Captains Career Course. These are the Armys elite junior officers. Of the 127 captains taking the five-week course, 119 had served one or two tours of duty in Iraq or Afghanistan, mainly as lieutenants. Nearly all would soon be going back as company commanders. A captain named Matt Wignall, who recently spent 16 months in Iraq with a Stryker brigade combat team, asked Cody, the Armys second-highest-ranking general, what he thought of a recent article by Lt. Col. Paul Yingling titled A Failure in Generalship. The article, a scathing indictment that circulated far and wide, including in Iraq, accused the Armys generals of lacking professional character, creative intelligence and moral courage.

title: Wild Calabria
description: Donna Leon has staked out Venice, Magdalen Nabb knows every narrow street in Florence, and Andrea Camilleri holds Sicily in the palm of his hand. But only Michael Dibdin, in the clever and exuberantly witty police procedurals he created for a dyspeptic cop named Aurelio Zen, tried to wrap his arms around the whole of Italy. Braving his way province by province  from the mountains of Alto Adige (in Medusa) to the caves of Sardinia (in Vendetta)  the British-born author produced crime stories that capture the idiosyncratic essence of each region while contributing to a dynamic study of the Italian national character in all its unruly glory.

title: Brooke Grossman, Andrew Russakoff

Many of the comments, which were posted at nytimes.com/travel, made general recommendations for strategies like renting villas or apartments rather than staying in hotels; others were based on specific experiences. Here are 10 new suggestions, gleaned from the reader responses, to add to the 10 in the original column.

title: The Devil Sells Prada
description: Luxury, Socrates once declared, is artificial poverty. Im not poor, but theres nothing like an afternoon spent shopping for luxury goods to make me feel that way. On a recent jaunt through some of Midtown Manhattans snazzier stores, I began to wonder why this should be the case. When, I asked myself, did it become commonplace to charge several thousand dollars for a mass-produced handbag? How could the flimsy designer sundress I bought on sale  a steal, the saleswoman assured me  still wind up costing a whole months salary? Why is my favorite brand of lipstick more expensive than a nice bottle of Italian wine? When did these products values grow so distorted, and what is the would-be customer to make of it all?

As an unsmiling teacher paced back and forth, we grudgingly revealed details about our inner selves in the questionnaires little spaces.
