title: Luxe Populi
description: Luxury for the masses  the crusade that got under way in the late 80s  implied that schoolteachers and cab drivers, having been denied Birkin bags and 911 Turbo convertibles for all of recorded history, were finally coming into their natural birthright. Affordable luxury would bring lifes finer things within reach and spread them around. Luxury brands began a precarious balancing act, continuing to bask in their exclusivity while opening the gates to a whole new breed of customer by introducing entry-level products at accessible prices. Poor Holly Golightly, stuck in the 60s, munching her breakfast in front of Tiffanys windows, hankering after the diamonds on display. If she were around today, she could go in and buy herself a piece of the brand: say, a $125 sterling-silver key ring.

title: The Larder System
description: All right  Ive had it up to here with getting older. And so I have decided Im going to put an end to it. I have tried this before. In fact, if I had a minute less for every self-help book Ive bought, fish-oil capsule Ive swallowed and lotion Ive slathered on my face in the hopes of looking younger, Id be back playing with blocks. But this time its going to be different. This time I have the guarantee of Dr. Jeannette Graf, a dermatologist and the author (with Alisa Bowman) of Stop Aging, Start Living. Dr. Jeannette writes, Not only does this program help you look more youthful on the outside, it also slows the aging of every cell in your body on the inside. And lets face it, nobody wants to have 17-year-old skin and a 51-year-old spleen.

title: Hot Ticket
description: The New York Racing Association offers video replays of individual races at Saratoga, Belmont and Aqueduct through RaceReplays.com after a 5- to 10-minute delay. They remain available for the length of each race meeting.

title: Countering Bridges Dark Allure
description: TARRYTOWN

title: New Direction for a Folk Festival With an Eye on Conservation
description: IF Judy Collins isnt enough to bring out the crowds for this years Connecticut Folk Festival, maybe a more diverse group of performers and an expanded Green Expo, with representatives from up to 70 organizations, businesses and state agencies, will do the trick.

title: Melanie Miller, William Lanzana
description: The Rev. Melanie Dawn Miller and William Michael Lanzana were married yesterday at the historic James House in Sleepy Hollow, N.Y. The Rev. Michael W. Caine, a United Church of Christ minister, officiated.

title: Yes, Were in Newark
description: ON a sultry August afternoon in the Forest Hill district of Newark, Julie Hodge trimmed the lower branches of a pine tree growing across the property line of her brick colonial house, hoping to convince her neighbors that the whole tree didnt need to come down. Nearby, there were residents painting shutters, replacing porch floor boards and planning for an evening at the open-air jazz concert in Branch Brook Park, just down the hill.

title: Why the Roller Coaster Seems Wilder
description: STOCKS regained some composure last week, and not a moment too soon for investors worn out by the markets turbulence. Credit markets remain easily spooked, however, and justifiably so. There is still so much that investors do not know about what lurks in portfolios around the world and exactly when it might jump out and say boo!

title: Lousy Is the Best They Can Ever Be
description: LONDON

title: West 142nd Street: Almost $2.9 Million
description: SOME people buy town houses in Harlem for their rich historical detail, the intricately carved moldings, the oak paneling, the Victorian grace. Others look for buildings that can be reshaped into starkly modern spaces.

title: Jilian Gersten, Brian Shuman
description: Jilian Cahan Gersten, a daughter of Cora Cahan and Bernard Gersten of Katonah, N.Y., is to be married this afternoon to Brian Scott Shuman, a son of Joyce Shuman and Robert Shuman of Greensboro, N.C. Rabbi Andy Bachman is to officiate at the home of the brides parents.

title: Out of Alaska: Zoo Seeks a Move South for Elephant
description: ANCHORAGE, Aug. 25 (AP)  A proposal is on the table to move Alaskas only elephant out of the state, a plan that has found favor with both the Alaska Zoo and animal rights groups.

title: What? And Leave Show Business?
description: I consider myself a worker, said David Greenspan, who has been an actor, writer and director in New York for nearly 30 years. Im facing the same things that workers are facing throughout the country.

title: Its Bird Eat Bird in a Cluttered Sky
description: THE summer travel season is building toward its Labor Day peak, and fliers are growing ever angrier about delays. Now, the beleaguered airline industry is trying to shift the blame onto an unlikely villain: corporate jets, which the airlines claim are literally crowding passenger planes out of the sky.

title: Will the Credit Crisis End the Activists Run?
description: RATTLING the saber wont be good enough, Carl C. Icahn, the colorful investor who has made billions of dollars aiming at corporate America with vitriolic shake-up and breakup campaigns, lamented to me last week. Its going to be somewhat more difficult.

title: Katherine Wallach, Jason Ginsburg
description: Katherine Jean Wallach and Jason Andrew Ginsburg are to be married today at the Four Seasons Hotel in Hampshire, England. Laura Redwood, superintendent registrar for North East Hampshire, is to officiate.

title: Heilman (Not Wagner) Keeps Mets on Track
description: There are still 34 games remaining in the Mets season, which, for the most pessimistic of fans, means there are 34 excruciating ways to lose, 34 different things that can go awry.

title: How Congestion Pricing Could Play Out
description: COMMUTING to Manhattan by car has long meant enduring mind-numbing traffic and paying more and more for tolls, parking and gas. So in April, when Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg proposed charging cars $8 to enter Manhattan below 86th Street on weekdays, suburban drivers had reason to groan yet again.

title: Final Score
description: Several times while reading Bearing the Body, I found myself recalling Virginia Woolfs remark that Middlemarch was one of the few English novels written for grown-ups. Id always assumed I knew what Woolf meant, but Bearing the Body, Ehud Havazelets extraordinary first novel, made me consider what might be involved in writing for adults at our own cultural moment  adults who may have noticed that life in general, and people in particular, can be difficult, complicated and strange.

title: No Free Lunch
description: In the 1930s, the Schechter brothers ran a chicken business in Brooklyn. The name Schechter is derived from the Yiddish word for butcher, and this is what the brothers did: they slaughtered chickens and sold them to shops. The brothers seemed to be typical immigrants, at once struggling and succeeding.

title: Classics Elevate Londons Summer
description: LONDON

title: 180 Degrees
description: To the Editor:

title: Edwards Wins a Race Devoid of Bristol Drama
description: BRISTOL, Tenn., Aug 25  The other 41 drivers served as little more than a colorful backdrop to a two-car race Saturday night between Carl Edwards and Kasey Kahne at Bristol Motor Speedway.

title: Correction: Workers Paradise, and With a Nice View
description: A column last Sunday on the leftist summer colonies of northern Westchester misstated the title of Dan Thaler. He is one of two vice presidents of the Shrub Oak homeowners association, not its president.

title: Grounding Air Albany
description: The abuse of New York States taxpayer-financed official aircraft has been one of many problems obscured by all the fuss over Gov. Eliot Spitzer administrations trooper blooper, as one of his friends calls it. There are more than enough investigations now into whether Mr. Spitzers administration overreached by persuading state troopers to release politically damaging information about his Republican foe, State Senator Joseph Bruno. Now it is time for the Legislature to protect taxpayers from paying for trips to political fund-raisers like the ones that Mr. Bruno was enjoying before all this mess become topic No. 1 in Albany.

title: Unshelved
description: Masha Hamilton has good story sense. She started out as a journalist for The Los Angeles Times, The Associated Press and other news organizations, reporting from Russia, Africa and the Middle East. Its not surprising, then, that when she began a new career as a novelist she demonstrated a knack for setting her fiction in volatile, real-life situations. Her first novel, Staircase of a Thousand Steps, was a coming-of-age story set in a Middle Eastern village in 1966. Her second, The Distance Between Us, followed a war correspondent who found herself in the midst of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

title: Mailer Gets Hammered
description: In this era of instant cultural gratification, it is rare to have to wait 36 years to watch a film. But thats how long it took for me to see Maidstone, Norman Mailers legendary exercise in improvisatory semifictional cinma vrit. It finally arrived at the Walter Reade Theater at Lincoln Center this past July like a video transmission from the faraway Planet 60s  a civilization in the throes of a crackup. I had been itching to see it ever since reading Mailers extraordinary essay on its creation, A Course in Film-Making, in New American Review in 1971, by which point the film had come and gone. For reasons its creator could hardly have anticipated, this lurid, ludicrous, lunatic spectacle was worth the wait.

title: Beijing Air Raises Questions for Olympics
description: OSAKA, Japan, Aug. 25  With temperatures rising into the low 90s and with the humidity closing in on 90 percent Saturday, some marathoners could not bear it at the track and field world championships.

title: Washington to Pittsburgh, by Bike
description: Heres a way to kiss summer goodbye or take in the fall foliage without having to deal with traffic: bicycle from Washington to Pittsburgh using more than 300 miles of off-road trails through retired railway corridors.

title: Teach the Toddlers
description: IN 1997, Albany passed legislation that was supposed to make publicly financed prekindergarten classes available to every 4-year-old in the state. A decade later, New York City has fallen far short of that goal. This school year, at least 17,000 city children will not get slots in the high-demand program.

title: Love Us or Hate Us, Ya Cant Ignore Us
description: DO Europeans hate America or love it? Lately the answer might seem a no-brainer. But The Anti-Americans, a one-hour documentary that has its premiere on PBS on Monday night, suggests that the correct response is: Both. We have, the show declares, a hate-love relationship.

title: A Drugstore-Clinic Caveat (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Afiya McLaughlin-White and Devin Johnson
description: Afiya McLaughlin-White and Devin Antoine Johnson are to be married this evening at Glen Island Harbour Club in New Rochelle, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. Calvin O. Butts III, the pastor of the Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem, will perform the ceremony.

title: Love as an Illusion: Beautiful to See, Impossible to Hold
description: IN Brokeback Mountain, the 2005 critical hit and cultural flashpoint that won Ang Lee an Academy Award for best director, love is a haunting, elusive ideal briefly attained but forever out of reach. Mr. Lees new movie, Lust, Caution, which will have its premiere at the Venice International Film Festival this week, is also a tragic melodrama, one in which the lovers are up against forces beyond their control, but it takes a harsher view of romance. This time love is a performance, a trap or, cruelest of all, an illusion.

title: The Heist, the Getaway and the Sawed-Off Leg
description: BERNARD McMAHON, a k a Bennie the Bum, a former bootlegger and onetime crony of the dapper gangster Legs Diamond, bent down to untangle a rope from a sawed-off shotgun. His speedboat, laden with stolen loot, was racing across Gravesend Bay. Suddenly, a blast punctuated the motors hum. The shotgun had accidentally gone off, leaving McMahons left knee a bloody mess.

title: Erin Dittus, Russell Lang
description: Erin Leigh Dittus, a daughter of Rebecca L. Dittus and Dr. Robert S. Dittus of Brentwood, Tenn., was married yesterday to Russell William Lang, a son of Karen K. Lang and Roger P. Lang of Pompton Plains, N.J. The Rev. J. Mark Forrester, a United Methodist minister, performed the ceremony at the Wightman Chapel in Nashville.

title: 400 Candles, and a Yearlong Blowout
description: WHEN the makers of the 2002 movie Catch Me If You Can were looking for a stand-in for France for a pivotal scene, they looked to Quebec City. With its fortified stone walls, narrow streets, venerable churches, beckoning cafes, and French-speaking populace, Quebec oozes Old World Gallic charm.

title: Christina Krettecos, Kevin White
description: Christina Dora Krettecos, a daughter of Elizabeth and Theodore Krettecos of Fort Lee, N.J., was married yesterday to Kevin Andrew White, a son of Lene White of Maple Glen, Pa., and the late Leland White. The Rev. Dr. Robert G. Stephanopoulos, the dean of the Greek Orthodox Archdiocesan Cathedral of the Holy Trinity in New York, performed the ceremony there.

title: Mothers Day
description: When Sean Wilseys memoir, Oh the Glory of It All, was published in 2005, I went through it in great mouthfuls, laughing so hard I choked on my own spit, gasping with such noisy abruptness on the subway that I was forced to explain to my fellow passengers the contents of the passage I had just read, and why they had to immediately run out and buy this book. When I got to the end, rather than face the searing disappointment that there was no more book left to be read, I immediately turned back to Page 1 and started all over again.

title: Pawleys Island, S.C.: The Original Hammock Shop
description: At the Original Hammock Shop on Pawleys Island, a historic seaside resort in South Carolina, you can see rope hammocks made the same way they've been made for more than 100 years, and then take one home.

title: Creatures of Habit
description: Whether on the local news or the latest episode of CSI, meth is the drug of the moment. Last summers big-budget Miami Vice visited a meth-addled trailer park as well as the high seas of the sexier cocaine trade, and November brought the countrys first National Methamphetamine Awareness Day.

title: Beyond the Selectric
description: GROWING up, I was surrounded by family members who were entrepreneurs. My father had his own public relations firm and did very well. But he fell ill when I was in high school, and my family suffered a reversal. It was a formative experience.

title: Make Wine, Not War
description: Bergerac, France

title: The Rubble of My Marriage, Hidden by Katrinas
description: HURRICANE KATRINA came along at a strangely appropriate time for me. Its shattered lives and lost homes fell right in line with how my life was going at the moment.

title: Louisa Livingston Kennedy, Voice of Iran Hostages Families, Dies at 73
description: Louisa Livingston Kennedy, the wife of a senior American official held captive during the Iranian hostage crisis who became a highly visible spokeswoman for the hostages families, died on Aug. 19 on Mount Desert Island, Maine. She was 73 and made her home on the island.

title: Jack Kirby, a Comic Book Genius, Is Finally Remembered
description: The fear of being forgotten after death is endemic in the creative arts. In the case of the iconic comic book artist Jack Kirby, it happened while he was still alive. By the 1960s, Mr. Kirby had already revolutionized the comic book business more than once. Working as principal artist and in-house genius for Marvel, he created a voice and an aesthetic unmatched by any other company.

title: Charmaine Smith, Sean Wright
description: Dr. Charmaine Angelina Smith and Dr. Sean Anthony Wright were married last evening in Philadelphia. The Rev. Charles Zlock, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Agatha-St. James Church.

title: A Meteor Returns for a Victory Lap
description: IN much the way George Steinbrenner opens his wallet wide each year trying to field a winning Yankees team, similarly competitive collectors search for significant vintage cars and dig deep, hoping to bring home a Best of Show award, or at least a class win, from the Pebble Beach Concours dlgance.

title: Chill Seekers
description: On a cool day in July, Kaz Adachi, a sculptor wearing a long, stiff apron and Wellington boots, was bent over two large blocks of ice fused end to end as he created a sushi bar for a wedding at the Manhattan restaurant Country. A Chopin mazurka was occasionally muffled by the roar of the chain saw Adachi used to gouge and groove the blocks.

title: The Artwork Runs Hot, With Infusions of Cool
Captain America
description: If Bush America appears to be tanking  as the Iraqi war grinds into its fifth year and the universal sympathy vote that was ours after 9/11 has soured into a sort of universal distaste  Polo America is having a banner year. This began to become clear to me not long ago, as I walked across Red Square in Moscow. Spotting a young student wearing board shorts emblazoned with the Stars and Stripes, I stopped him to inquire what this sanctified emblem of Jeffersonian democracy signified in his mind. Ralph Lauren brand, he said flatly and moved on.

title: Dead of Night: Yankees Lose at 3:30 A.M.
description: DETROIT, Saturday, Aug. 25  By the third inning, the out-of-town scoreboard at Comerica Park was scrolling through Saturdays games. That made sense, in a way, because it already was Saturday.

title: Tales of Spotting Snarls From Above
description: CONSIDER the morning I coined the phrase Tour de Merritt.

Shell instant-message her friends about that ridiculous question on the trig test, and shell drive to the mall for a burger with her boyfriend.

William Holland, was married yesterday to David Leigh Franklin, a son of Barbara and Herbert M. Franklin of Washington. Stephen F. Williams, a senior judge of the Federal Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, officiated at the Lake Shore Country Club in Glencoe, Ill.

title: Traditional Japanese With a Pan-Asian Bent
description: NOT too many years ago, some people we know would not eat raw fish. We suspect that maki sushi (rolled sushi) and all its fancy spinoffs with whimsical names are responsible for their change of heart. Like many converts, they have gone on to enjoy the delicate nuances of sashimi, what good Japanese sushi restaurants are all about.

description: When the citys Health Department warned last month of a surge in cases of Legionnaires disease in Parkchester, a complex of 171 apartment buildings southeast of Bronx Park, one possible culprit was thought to be Parkchesters central fountain.

Kellner of New York. The Rev. Frank C. Strasburger, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the Tehma Golf Club in Carmel, Calif.

description: DAVID LETTERMAN

title: Back in Print
description: In 1964, a 3-year-old girl named Laudomia was unhappily confined to her sickbed. It was, as these things go, not a bad place to be confined; her bedroom was on the third floor of the Palazzo Pucci, a massive 14th-century villa in Florence, just behind the Duomos pearl-gray immensity. But she was bored and restless, and so, to cheer her up, her father, an Italian aristocrat, brought her some perfume.

title: Entry-Level
description: Just as BMW offers its more accessible 3 Series to younger buyers, many perfume houses offer beginning fragrances for their younger consumers. Each house follows its own logic.

title: When Bad News Follows You
description: A BUSINESS strategy of The New York Times to get its articles to pop up first in Internet searches is creating a perplexing problem: long-buried information about people that is wrong, outdated or incomplete is getting unwelcome new life.

description: RUED LANGGAARD: SYMPHONIES 2 AND 3; SYMPHONIES 12 TO 14

description: THE land around Unison, Va.  a clutch of homes 50 miles west of Washington, with no stoplight or commercial enterprise looks much as it did around 145 years ago when Union and Confederate soldiers clashed in the fields.

title: For Skate Parks, Its a Material World
description: IT was the kind of day that cried out for heel flips off the halfpipe, but you would not have guessed it by the looks of the Sydney E. Frank skate park in New Rochelle, N.Y. Sun rolled off the year-old ramps on a warm Wednesday afternoon, but the park sat empty.

title: The Nureyev Nobody Knows, Young and Wild
description: A POINT comes in the afterlife of an artist when, for the time being, biography has pretty much done its work. The essential history is known; the ambience is broadly understood; the relationship between the life and the work has yielded its chief mysteries. Barring bombshells any future surprises are apt to be minor: not revelations, just minutiae.

title: A Turnaround: Stocks Up, Volatility Down
description: The stock market bounced back last week, with the three major indexes all posting weekly gains of more than 2 percent.

title: The Market Is Bumpy, but Liquor Is Quicker
description: Just as a storm of change has been rattling the New York Stock Exchange of late, so has there been a change in the weather at the New York Wine Exchange, a well-stocked shop on Broadway near Battery Place, just a few blocks from its namesake. On a chilly evening last week, a marketing analyst named Effie Philippakos seemed to embody these fluctuations after she hurried into the store and headed straight for the spirits.

title: Ins de la Fressange | Style Emissary
description: Even muses have trouble getting dressed. Im the type of person who wakes up and has nothing to wear, says Ins de la Fressange, a roving ambassador for Roger Vivier accessories. Though she was once a model, a muse to Karl Lagerfeld at Chanel, the official face of the Marianne (Its like the French version of Uncle Sam except with big breasts) and the designer of her own clothing line, she refuses to take fashion too seriously. Her style is a simple mix of T-shirts, tailored trousers and cropped jackets, worn with piles of accessories and a sense of humor. Ive always been the bouffon du roi, or court jester, she says. One time, before I walked onto a runway, I burned the top of a cork from a wine bottle and smeared a moustache above my lip.

title: Lily Mayer, Robert Roscoe
description: Laura Elizabeth Mayer, the daughter of Margery and Theodore V. H. Mayer of Larchmont, N.Y., was married yesterday to Robert Russell Fawcus Roscoe, a son of Jennifer Kenny of Hartfield, England, and the late John Roscoe, who lived in Clifton-upon-Dunsmore, England. The Rev. Thomas E. Nicoll performed the Episcopal ceremony at St. Johns Church in Larchmont.

description: Michelle Lyn Volpe and Christopher John Solgan were married yesterday. The Rev. Richard D. Baker officiated at St. Malachys Roman Catholic Church in Manhattan.

description: Andy Roddick, who says his kitchen skills are lackluster, cooked with celebrity chefs as the guests at the Dacor Taste of Tennis charity event Thursday in Manhattan.

title: Jae Gruenke, Eric Barnhill
description: Jae Gruenke and Eric Charles Barnhill were married yesterday in New York. Tony Hileman, the senior leader of the New York Society for Ethical Culture, officiated.

title: Street Sense Wins Travers, but Works Harder Than Expected
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 25  Calvin Borel knew the horseplayers were wrong. The colt he was riding, the Kentucky Derby winner Street Sense, was not a lock to capture the 138th Travers Stakes, and the six other horses in the Midsummer Derby were better than they looked.

description: MONTICELLO, N.Y., Aug. 25  Who is the most formidable Jewish ballplayer who ever lived?

description: Caroline Nancy Pelham and Eric Michael Burton were married yesterday in Manchester-by-the-Sea, Mass. The Rev. Aaron Fulp-Eickstaedt, a Presbyterian minister and a cousin of the bridegroom, officiated at the couples home there.

title: Arsenal and Chelsea Win
description: Arsenal handed Manchester City its first loss of the season yesterday in the English Premier League, 1-0, and Chelsea beat Portsmouth, 1-0, to move into first place.Cesc Fabregas scored in the 80th minute to give Arsenal the victory and Frank Lampard scored in the first half for Chelsea, which has 10 points from four games. Manchester City is second with 9 points, 2 more than Wigan, Liverpool and Arsenal.In other matches, Liverpool beat Sunderland, 2-0; Birminghan won at Derby County, 2-1; Aston Villa defeated Fulham, 2-1; Bolton beat Reading, 3-0; and Wigan drew, 1-1, at West Ham.

title: With Market Plans Afoot, Resistance Rises to More Fancy Foods
description: WHEN Fiorello La Guardia opened the Essex Street Market on the Lower East Side in 1940, his goal was to clear the neighborhoods streets of the shoddy pushcarts that he found so unsightly.

title: Correction: Where Sheep Once Grazed, Now Poems Take Root
description: A caption in the Workspace photo essay last Sunday misidentified the actor depicted in a portrait in the home of the poet Donald Hall. It is Charles Laughton, not Charles Lawson.

title: Dead Co-op Issue Gets a Second Life
description: A RECENT Manhattan court decision added a twist to a question that co-op lawyers thought had been answered by the states highest court in a 2005 ruling on designating a holder of unsold shares in a co-op.

title: What Genius Cast This Play?
description: Gertrude Garnet: the very name suggests a woman of mystery and allure. With her flaming red hair in a seductive upsweep, gams encased in seamed stockings, and ensembles trimmed extravagantly in fur and leather, Gertrude is an out-and-out stunner. Add a come-hither manner and a sexy, gravelly voice, and youll understand why men find her totally irresistible.

title: Maria Shim and Nicholas Fox
description: Maria So-Hee Shim and Nicholas Charles Fox were married yesterday afternoon at Beltane Ranch, an inn in Glen Ellen, Calif. The Rev. Timothy Boeve, a minister of the Reformed Church in America, officiated.

title: Go Suck on a Topaz
description: Indian women have always gone the distance for beauty. Theyve had to. Even now, when globalization has plunked down card shops and appliance outlets in every town with more than five sacred cows, makeup-buying options are limited outside the big cities. In most places, youre talking waxy lipstick in three cadaverous shades, sold at the general store. But theres a reason, beyond a fortunate gene pool, that India regularly cleans up at the international Miss Strut pageants. Women there have a history of being resourceful, as Sharada Dwivedi and Shalini Devi Holkar explain in Almond Eyes, Lotus Feet (Collins), a fascinating compendium of traditional beauty and healing remedies spun as the fictional memoir of a princess.

title: EASTERN LEAGUES
description: Colonial (F.C.S.)

title: The Eye of the Beheld
description: ASK the federal agency charged with policing products that can be labeled organic: it is one of todays most abused terms, right up there with guaranteed electronics and luxury apartments.

description: To the Editor:

title: Jos Saramago, the Unexpected Fantasist
description: One evening in June, the Portuguese novelist Jos Saramago was addressing a small gathering at a book party in Lisbon. The occasion was the reissue of a volume of his poems originally published in 1975. Saramago, who is 84, is an austere man, extremely tall and so lean that he is practically concave. The night was hot, but he was wearing, as usual, a dark suit and tie. An outspoken atheist, Saramago maintains that religion is to blame for most of the worlds violence. Yet in his old age he resembles nothing so much as a steely churchman from a Renaissance altarpiece, a St. Jerome in the desert.

title: After Brush With Law, Hawaiis Brennan Seeks Redemption
description: HONOLULU  After every home game, Colt Brennan waves to his probation officer as he leaves Aloha Stadium.

title: Drafted and Thrown Into Duty
description: Andrew Miller made his 12th start of the season for Detroit on Friday in the opener of the Tigers four-game series with the Yankees. Joba Chamberlain, the biggest thing to hit New York since the Beatles, pitched his ninth scoreless inning in relief and was certain to relieve for the Yankees in another of the games, which are critical to the playoff races.

title: Liberian Ex-Leaders War Crimes Trial Is Stalled
description: PARIS, Aug. 25  When Charles Taylor, the former president of Liberia, was arrested 17 months ago on war crimes charges and ordered to face international judges, it was heralded as a milestone for justice in Africa.

title: Lara Ballard and Gigi Sohn
description: Lara Ann Ballard and Gigi Beth Sohn were joined in a civil union ceremony yesterday. Greg Trulson, a justice of the peace, officiated at the Moose Meadow Lodge in Waterbury, Vt.

title: Letters
description: How Long Will It Take for China to Catch Up?

description: Beacon

title: Dropping the Chicken
description: Everything from the television-immortalized kitchen in Julia Childs Cambridge house has been disassembled and reverently reinstalled at the Smithsonian Institution. Everything, that is, except the original iconic pegboard wall Paul Child designed to hang her prized copper pots, with hand-drawn outlines showing where each one goes. That wall and those pots are now enshrined 3,000 miles away in the Napa Valley, at Copia, the American Center for Wine, Food and the Arts. All Julia Childs papers  manuscripts, lectures, fan mail  are back East, in the Schlesinger Library at Radcliffe. Except, of course, for those memories lodged in the minds and files of still very living Julia-ists, like her legendary editor, Judith Jones.

title: Quake Victims Included in Aid Drive for Peru
description: HARRISON

title: The Odd Woman Out, but Still Very Much at Home
description: I AM a person who likes a certain amount of peace and quiet. My three sons, on the other hand (now 12, 10 and 6), can induce chaos just by their presence. They bang and throw themselves about. They careen into table corners and door jambs. They howl in pain.

title: Trump on the Beach
description: Say what you will about Robert Moses, master builder, despoiler of neighborhoods, symbol of all that is great and terrible in urban planning. At least he kept his name off things. And most of what he built, including his greatest achievement, Jones Beach State Park, was for the enjoyment and enrichment of the middle class. As high and mighty as Moses became, he never completely jettisoned the public from public servant.

title: Tyson Gay Wins 100-Meter Title
description: OSAKA, Japan, Aug. 26  Tyson Gay already had been part of a victory celebration at a world championships. He already had done a lap around the track with an American flag wrapped around his shoulders and his compatriots in a festive mood.

title: The Letter That Changed the Future
description: ON July 12, someone slipped a letter under Ann Shannons front door and under the front door of every other apartment in Knickerbocker Plaza, a hulking government-subsidized complex on Second Avenue at East 91st Street.

title: In 2008 Race, Little Ones Go on the Trail With Daddy

Some products offer vague instructions on how to use them; others are shrouded in self-serving dermababble thats best deconstructed by molecular biologists and chemists. Some products are self-explanatory, but provide no clues as to where they fit into your daily routine. When exactly do you use a primer? title: Inside the List
description: WHY IS EVERYONE NAKED, MOTHER? Pat Montandons new memoir, Oh the Hell of It All, is a response of sorts to her son Sean Wilseys memoir, Oh the Glory of It All, which made the hardcover list for three weeks in 2005. Montandons book definitely isnt her first. In 1968 she published a chic and sunny primer called How to Be a Party Girl. Poking around in that earlier book does give you a sense of what it must have been like to be Sean Wilsey. Chapter Five is titled Why Is Everyone Naked, Mother? The answer: Shh, darling, this is a Garden of Eden Party. Youll understand when youre a little older. Run along, now. Montandons book also includes this helpful advice: Suppose you read in the newspaper one morning that a rarely seen comet is approaching Earth, and will be visible on a certain evening a few weeks off. Do you yawn and go on to the stock market reports and the obituaries? Not if youre a Party Girl. You telephone the City Fathers ... and you ask them if they would like to lend you the Planetarium, for a Comet-Viewing Party. When Playboy asked Montandon to pose for a centerfold, she declined: Experts in the entertainment field tell me theres such a thing as overexposure, and I certainly wouldnt want to be a bore. Alex Kuczynski reviews the new book this week.

title: Dress Mode
description: I dont like pants. Or I should say, I dont like wearing pants. The entire jeans revolution of the past decade  the special rinses; the cuts that amplify the derrire or lengthen the leg; the low rise and the boot cut  does not intrigue me. The only time I wear pants is to walk my dog, and I wear them then only when the weather is freezing. Mostly, I use pants as a kind of fatness monitor: a particular pair of very narrow A.P.C. jeans functions like a scale. Twice a week, every week, I try them on. If theyre tight, I cut out chocolate; if theyre loose, I rejoice. Either way, the jeans stay on my body for about 15 minutes, long enough to truly gauge the fit, and then I change into a dress or a skirt. Like I said, I dont like pants.

I used to hang around the New York Dolls, and they were definitely into those jackets. I remember having one that was black on the outside with red pleats in the back. Eventually, I started noticing lots of women in the music scene doing a West Side Story kind of tough-girl look with motorcycle jackets in different colors. Its cool that these jackets keep coming back  biker style is an American classic.

title: Up Front
description: The novelist Darcey Steinke has two central themes. Ive always liked to write about sex and violence, she said by phone the other day. And shes always been drawn to religion and divinity, and how a physical life would fit into that. Both strands appear in Steinkes novels  which include Suicide Blonde, Jesus Saves and Milk  and are the heart of her most recent book, Easter Everywhere, a memoir about growing up as the daughter of a Lutheran minister, which appeared this spring. Why a memoir? I had a lot of theological ideas about myself and about religion and God, and I felt they were getting in the way of my fiction writing, Steinke said. Everybody was in the pulpit. Fiction is so much about paradox and ambiguity  so is religion  but I had all these new exciting ideas getting in the way. A devotee of Augustines Confessions, she thinks memoirs should transcend the pulp-paperback form  I was a sinner and now Ive been saved  yet still engage with ideas of spiritual transformation. Im all for 12-step, but I want there to be some sense of people wrestling with God, she said.

title: The Forgotten Man: A New History of the Great Depression
description: Floods change the course of history, and the Flood of 1927 was no exception. When the waters of the Mississippi broke through banks and levees that spring, the disaster was enormous. A wall of water pushed down the river, covering the area where nearly a million lived. Commerce Secretary Herbert Hoover raced to Memphis and took command. Hoover talked railroads into transporting the displaced for free and carrying freight at a discount. He commandeered private outboard motors and built motorboats of plywood. He urged the people who were not yet flooded out, such as the population around the Bayou des Glaises levee, to evacuate early, then rescued with the trains those tens of thousands who had ignored his warning. He helped the Red Cross launch a fund drive; within a month the charity had already collected promises of more than $8 million, an enormous figure for the time.

title: Bearing the Body

The light over the houses was a charged blue, not as in winter when it drained abruptly into night, but softer, a presence, almost liquid, an invitation, a tease. In the street, a car circled a second time, its radio up, and he leaned in to hear but caught only the thin edge of a melody before it turned the corner and faded.

But Fi registered this one, maybe because she knew she wouldn't be hearing sirens for a while.

title: India After Gandhi
description: Freedom came to India on 15 August 1947, but patriotic Indians had celebrated their first "Independence Day" seventeen years before. In the first week of January 1930, the Indian National Congress passed a resolution fixing the last Sunday of the month for countrywide demonstrations in support of purna swaraj, or complete independence. This, it was felt, would both stoke nationalist aspirations and force the British to seriously consider giving up power. In an essay in his journal Young India, Mahatma Gandhi set out how the day should be observed: "It would be good if the declaration [of independence] is made by whole villages, whole cities even.... It would be well if all the meetings were held at the identical minute in all the places."

title: Circling My Mother: A Memoir
description: In the year 1908, Pierre Bonnard painted The Bathroom and my mother was born. The posture of the young woman in the painting is that of someone enraptured by the miracle of light. The light is filtered through the lace curtains, and its patterning is reflected in the water that fills the tub into which she is about to step. Even the floral spread on the divan from which she has just risen is an emblem of prosperity and joy. Bonnard is famous for painting bathing women; in all her life my mother has never taken a bath. At three, she was stricken with polio, and she never had the agility to get in or out of a bathtub. She told me that once, after I was born, my father tried to lift her into a bath, but it made them both too nervous.

title: Superbad Scores Again
description: The raunchy teenage sex romp Superbad, starring Michael Cera, Jonah Hill (far right) and Christopher Mintz-Plasse (near right) as high school friends on a quest for alcohol and girls, held the top spot at the box office for the second consecutive weekend, grossing $18 million and upping the films cumulative gross to $68.6 million in 10 days, according to estimates released yesterday by the box office tracking company Media by Numbers. The summer has been superhot for Hollywood, as the overall box office reached a record $4 billion, beating the 2004 record of $3.95 billion with one more weekend to go before summer is over. This weekend alone the top 12 movies took in $90.2 million, an increase of 7 percent over the same weekend in 2006. The thriller The Bourne Ultimatum (Universal) moved up from last weekend, rising to second place from third with an estimated haul of $12.4 million in its fourth week of release, and a cumulative take of $185 million in four weeks. Swapping places with Bourne, the comedy Rush Hour 3 (New Line), starring Jackie Chan and Chris Tucker, dropped to third place with $12.3 million for the weekend and $109 million overall in three weeks. Rounding out the top five were two new releases, Mr. Beans Holiday (Universal), the Rowan Atkinson comedy, which made $10.1 million, and the action film War (Lionsgate), with Jet Li and Jason Statham, which took in $10 million.

title: The Tame, the Trashy and the Rocker Quality
description: VH1s Rock of Love With Bret Michaels is carnival sludge: a nauseating paste of fried dough, cigarette ash, salt and grain alcohol. The rococo pageantry and high spirits of Flavor of Love, the channels seminal reality dating competition, starring the hype man Flavor Flav, have gone missing from this, the rock version.

title: Djokovic Looking for a Piece of the Pie
description: In a way, Novak Djokovics tennis career began at the Red Bull, the pizza-and-pancakes place his parents opened about 15 years ago in the Serbian ski resort town of Kopaonik.

title: Taste of Victory: Online Outcry Revives a Chocolate Bar
description: LONDON, Aug. 26  Two weeks ago, a Facebook member in Manchester, England, added her name to an online campaign to bring back a chocolate bar called Wispa, discontinued by its maker, Cadbury, four years ago.

title: Whats on Tonight
description: 7 P.M. (USA) UNITED STATES OPEN  Venus and Serena Williams will play back-to-back matches following the opening-night festivities, which will celebrate the 50th anniversary of Althea Gibsons historic victory at what was then called the National Championships. During the ceremony, titled Breaking Barriers, African-American female pioneers in the fields of sports, entertainment, politics and the arts will converge on the court to celebrate Gibsons life and career. Serena Williams, above, was the first black woman since Gibson to win the United States Open; Venus Williams was the first black woman since Gibson to win Wimbledon. Tonight Serena is scheduled to play Angelique Kerber of Germany and Venus will play a qualifier. For Venus this years tournament is about more than tennis; this budding designer will be decked out in an outfit and shoes from her new EleVen label, which is produced in partnership with the retailer Steve & Barrys. The morning rounds begin at 11.

title: Orchestra Exchange Program
description: The Osnabrck Symphony Orchestra of Germany, led by the conductor Hermann Baeumer, will perform a program of Beethoven and Brahms in Tehran on Wednesday and Thursday, the Associated Press reported. The visit is part of an exchange program between the two nations, and follows a concert by the Tehran Symphony Orchestra last year in Osnabrck. Its a very small step in improving relations between the people in the two countries, said Michael Dreyer, the head of Osnabrcks Morgenland Festival, which played host to last years visitors from Iran. The female German musicians will observe Iranian law and wear headscarves.

title: More Primary Care Doctors (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Testing a Format, in a Test of Firsts
description: When YouTube pitched its new advertising format to me, it described the semitransparent ads it is overlaying on videos as something that has not been available before. It probably should have added: on YouTube.

title: Unauthorized Enjoyment of Song Irks Law Firm
description: It sounds like the setup for a joke: a law firm picks a fight with a legal blogger over the leak of an internal song celebrating  well, itself.

title: Raymond Barre, 83, Former French Premier, Dies
description: PARIS, Aug. 26  Raymond Barre, a prominent economist who was prime minister of France from 1976 to 1981, died in Paris on Saturday. He was 83.

title: An 80-Year-Old Poet for the MTV Generation
description: MtvU, the subsidiary of MTV Networks that is broadcast only on college campuses, will announce today that it has selected its first poet laureate. No, he doesnt rap. And its not Bob Dylan, or even Justin Timberlake.

title: Forty Years of Growth, Except Where It Was Expected
description: Sometime in the 1950s, Amelia Delgado planted a sapling outside her Lower East Side tenement at 145 Clinton Street, where she and her husband, Ramon, were raising five children. The children are grown, have done well and now have children of their own. Her husband died 14 years ago.

title: Popular Demand
description: Companies advertising on the cable and network television broadcasts of last years United States Open Tennis spent a total of $91.3 million. Roger Federer, above, and Maria Sharapova will defend their singles championships in the 14-day tournament, which starts today.

title: After the Big 2
description: The Next Big One?

title: In Full Summer, Pattern Emerges for Venus Williams
description: Venus Ebony Starr Williams stepped into her design company offices dressed in a tropical peasant skirt that flowed like a waterfall to her sandals. Winston, her 3-year-old springer spaniel, trailed with happy indifference.

title: Bostons Other Japanese Pitcher
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 26  He came to the Red Sox as the other Japanese pitcher, a 31-year-old rookie reliever still mistaken for his more celebrated teammate by autograph seekers and in the occasional newspaper photo caption. Earlier this season, a Boston cabbie kept raving about this new guy, Hideki Okajima, unaware that his favorite left-hander was riding in the back seat.

title: Bank Profits May Well Suffer, but Credit Crisis Hardly Leaves Them Defenseless
description: Banks these days are like football players running the gantlet drill: the turmoil in the credit markets is bound to hit them on one side or the other, even if they make it through.

title: A Solution Seen to Brain Drain
description: A new academic study details the benefits and the threat of a reverse brain drain  skilled foreign workers going back to their home countries because they cannot get visas in the United States. One of the studys authors has a solution that is not in step with the high-tech lobby. He advocates getting rid of the H-1B visa, the temporary work permit for skilled workers.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes todays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.

title: Pie Show
description: Joe Carlucci, the owner of Famous Joes, a Danbury, Conn., pizzeria, is also a pizza acrobat and will demonstrate his singular way with a hunk of dough on Saturday on the corner of Mulberry and Broome Streets in Little Italy. In a 40-minute performance set to Italian folk music, Mr. Carlucci, who won a gold medal at the Squadra Acrobatica Pizza Olympics in Salsomaggiore, Italy, in both 2006 and 2007, will perform gymnastics while balancing and tossing several pies.

title: The Kibbutz Sheds Socialism and Gains Popularity
description: KIBBUTZ YASUR, Israel  For much of Israels existence, the kibbutz embodied its highest ideals: collective labor, love of the land and a no-frills egalitarianism.

title: W.H.O. Urges Effort to Fight Fast-Spreading New Diseases
description: ROME, Aug. 25  New infectious diseases are emerging at an unprecedented rate, and far greater human mobility  by planes, trains and ships  means that diseases have the potential to spread rapidly across the globe, a World Health Organization report warned this week.

title: Twin Cities Editor Planning Online Daily
description: Joel Kramer, the former editor and publisher of The Star Tribune of Minneapolis, is expected today to announce plans for an online, nonprofit daily newspaper for the Minneapolis-St. Paul area, the countrys 14th largest media market.

title: His Next Line to Cross
description: RAFAEL NADAL could continue banging from behind the baseline, flexing his muscular left arm and sending weary opponents flailing across courts of clay.

title: A Political Crisis Brews in Greece as Fires Rage
description: MAKISTOS, Greece, Aug. 27  When the water ran out, with pinecones popping and the flames still high around his house, George Dimopoulos switched to wine. He made it himself two years ago, and, nearly alone in his village as it all but burnt down on Friday night, he poured liter after liter, 200 in all, into his little copper hand-pumped crop sprayer  and sprayed and sprayed.

title: So Bad Theyre Good
description: Tom OHorgan, who directed the original production of Hair, almost 40 years ago, will be honored at the opening night of the second annual Bad Plays Festival, which runs Sept. 10 to 30 at the Players Theater on Macdougal Street in Greenwich Village. The three-week festival, presented by NY Artists Unlimited (nyartists.org), comprises plays intended to be so bad  meaning irreverent, satirical and bawdy  that they are, its hoped, quite good.

title: The Muse Who Made the Guitars Gently Weep
description: Pattie Boyd calls herself a muse, and she has the ravishing love songs (George Harrisons Something, Eric Claptons Layla and Bell Bottom Blues) to prove it. But in Ms. Boyds case, being a muse also means never having paid a light bill until she was 45, jobless and suddenly unplugged from the world of rock n roll royalty.

title: A Socialist Plot
description: Suppose, for a moment, that the Heritage Foundation were to put out a press release attacking the liberal view that even children whose parents could afford to send them to private school should be entitled to free government-run education.

title: BET Says Cartoon Was Just a Satire
description: Black Entertainment Televisions new animation division seems to have stepped right into a pitfall of self-parody: a short cartoon video it introduced on July 20, Read a Book, seems to flaunt every negative stereotype in the African-American community.

title: Using Muscle to Improve Health Care for Prisoners
description: SAN JOSE, Calif.  Last year, shortly after receiving extraordinary powers to overhaul the medical system in Californias prisons, Robert Sillen, armed with a stack of court papers, issued a blunt warning to cabinet officials at the governors office in Sacramento.

title: Tourist in Russia Stumbles Into a Legal Predicament
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 25  Two months ago, Roxana Contreras was exploring a provincial Russian town when a street vendor persuaded her to buy some Red Army medals and old ruble notes the day before she was to return to her home in St. Louis, she said.

title: A Director Sounds Off, but Is Soon Reassured
description: It used to be much easier for Hollywood to keep its employees under lockdown, so to speak. Faced with a volatile director who has trouble staying away from a microphone? Attach an attack-dog publicist to his hip and  presto!  problem solved.

title: Vick Pleads Guilty in Dog-Fighting Case
description: RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 27  Michael Vick formally accepted a plea agreement from the federal government today at the United States District Court here, pleading guilty to a felony charge stemming from a dog fighting ring run from a property he owned.

title: Sarajevo Film Festival Awards
description: A Turkish film about the fear of God overwhelming a true believer caught up in a powerful religious group was chosen as the best movie at the 13th Sarajevo Film Festival, Reuters reported. Takva: A Mans Fear of God, directed by Ozer Kiziltan, won the Heart of Sarajevo award, which comes with a prize of 25,000 euros ($34,100). A jury led by the British actor Jeremy Irons made the decision, and the award was presented at the festivals closing night ceremony Saturday. In the film a pious Istanbul man leads a solitary life until a religious group recruits him to work as a rent collector. His new job, which thrusts him into the modern world, tests his religious devotion. The seven-day festival included screenings of more than 170 feature films, shorts and documentaries.

title: Pavarotti Goes Home
description: Luciano Pavarotti, below, was released from a hospital in his hometown, Modena, Italy, on Saturday after more than two weeks of treatment and testing since he was admitted with a high fever on Aug. 8, the BBC reported. Mr. Pavarotti, 71, underwent surgery for pancreatic cancer last July, and has not been seen in public since. At the time, he was in the midst of a farewell tour and had hoped to continue the tour this year, but so far his health has not allowed him back onstage.

title: The MacArthur Lunch
description: United Nations

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A map of Greece with an article yesterday about fires there included an erroneous mileage scale, showing a span that should have been labeled 100 miles instead of 10. (Go to Article)

title: No Votes, Just Hugs, Smiles and Pop
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y., Aug. 24  If youre starting to feel that this summer has been one long, hot slog, just be glad youre not Jordin Sparks. Or Sanjaya Malakar. Or Melinda Doolittle. Or whats-his-name, the bald one.

title: New York City Fire Dept. Disciplines 3 Officers After Blaze
description: The New York City Fire Department relieved three officers of their commands today as it continued its investigation into the fire at the former Deutsche Bank building that killed two firefighters earlier this month.

title: Mexicos Plutocracy Thrives on Robber-Baron Concessions
description: Growing up in Mexico City, I always knew Mexico was an unjust country  a place where small coteries of the privileged control all power and wealth while half the population lives in poverty. But it never occurred to me that Mexico would have billionaires.

title: For Stricker and Caddie, Overdue Tears of Joy
description: HARRISON, N.Y., Aug. 26  In the half-light of a hazy summer evening, when all of his work was done, Steve Stricker closed his eyes and let the tears fall.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption with a Page One article on Thursday about the electricity shortages in Baghdad and elsewhere caused by armed groups seizing control of switching stations in the power grid misstated in some copies the reason numerous electrical wires span the streets of the city. The wires are fed by private generators that are used as backups for districts without power from the central grid. The owners of the generators are not the ones withholding power from the grid.

title: Way Before Lindsay and Britney, Chaos Swirled Around Iphigenia
description: If you think Lindsay Lohan has family problems, meet the new party girl on the scene, a blond ditz who should make the editors of Us Weekly drool.

title: Remember Squirtle and Jigglypuff? Theyre Back
description: Playground fads come and go, as those who have found themselves with neglected collections of Beanie Babies can attest.

title: Jets Young Linemen Have Lessons to Learn
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Aug. 26  The Jets inexperienced left guards were not the only linemen exposed Saturday night.

title: For the Road
description: Cormac McCarthy has been awarded the James Tait Black Memorial Prize for fiction for his novel The Road, the BBC reported. The prize was announced at the Edinburgh International Book Festival on Saturday, and Mr. McCarthy was not in attendance. Mr. McCarthys 10th novel, the story of a father and son in a postapocalyptic world, also won the Pulitzer Prize for fiction. In Edinburgh, Byron Rogers won in the biography category for his book The Man Who Went Into the West: The Life of R. S. Thomas, about the Welsh poet. In announcing the awards Judge Professor Colin Nicholson of the University of Edinburgh said both books were destined to become classics in their respective genres. The University of Edinburgh began awarding the two prizes in 1919, and past winners include D. H. Lawrence and E. M. Forster.

description: To the Editor:

title: With Turnover High, Schools Fight for Teachers
description: GREENSBORO, N.C.  The retirement of thousands of baby boomer teachers coupled with the departure of younger teachers frustrated by the stress of working in low-performing schools is fueling a crisis in teacher turnover that is costing school districts substantial amounts of money as they scramble to fill their ranks for the fall term.

title: Turkish Delight F1 style
description: It was not a great weekend for my photo harvest  too hot and too many other problems. Just imagine what its like for the men and women whose job it is only to take photos all day at every race  36 degree Celsius temperatures, and elsewhere, rain, snow.

title: Mortgage Crisis Forces Sale of German Bank
description: The eastern German state of Saxony was forced to sell a troubled state-run bank Sunday as the global liquidity crisis set off by the United States subprime mortgage problems claimed its first major European victim.

title: Boston Hedge Fund Star Loses $400 Million
description: James Pallotta, Bostons highest-paid hedge fund manager and a part owner of the Boston Celtics, told investors in his $8.5 billion Raptor fund Friday that some of the investments in the fund were simply crushed by the market turmoil of the past month, losing $400 million in a matter of weeks and leaving his investors with an 8 percent loss so far this year.

title: Red Sox Owner Henry Scores Mansion
description: Call it inside baseball. John W. Henry, commodity trader and principal owner of the Boston Red Sox, has ponied up $16 million for the 18,000-square-foot Brookline, Mass., home of Los Angeles Dodgers owner Frank H. McCourt Jr.

title: Price for Home Depot Unit Plunges in a Tight Market
description: To save its struggling deal, Home Depot was forced to drop the sale price of its commercial supply business by nearly $2 billion yesterday, according to The New York Times, becoming one of the first big buyouts to be renegotiated as a result of the recent tightening of credit and problems in the housing market.

title: Tata Confirms Interest in Ford Brands
description: Ratan Tata, the chairman of Tata Group, has confirmed that the Indian conglomerate is interested in acquiring Ford Motors Land Rover and Jaguar luxury brands.

title: Arrow Shareholder Reverses Position on Teleflex Deal
description: In an about-face, a major shareholder in Arrow International said Friday that it would support the proposed $2 billion acquisition by Teleflex, according to a regulatory filing.

title: Tishman Closes $1.7 Billion Chicago Deal
description: The Chicago real estate community heaved a sigh of relief Friday as Tishman Speyer closed on one of the citys all-time largest property sales.

title: Rio Tinto Extends Alcan Bid
description: Rio Tinto plans to extend its $38.1 billion takeover offer for Canadian aluminum giant Alcan, giving it more time to obtain regulatory approvals.

title: Unauthorized Enjoyment of Song Irks Law Firm
description: It sounds like the setup for a joke: a law firm picks a fight with a legal blogger over the leak of an internal song celebrating  well, itself.

title: Nasdaq May Sell L.S.E. Stake to Deutsche Borse, Report Says
description: The Nasdaq Stock Market is seeking to sell up to half of its 31 percent stake in the London Stock Exchange to Deutsche Borse for more than 400 millon pounds ($806 million), according to The Guardian.

title: Hearst Launches Offer for TV Business
description: The Hearst Corporation announced late Friday that it plans a $23.50 per share tender offer for the 27 percent of Hearst-Argyle Television that it does not already own.

title: Banks Can Weather Credit Crisis, but At a Cost
description: Banks these days are like football players running the gantlet drill: the turmoil in the credit markets is bound to hit them on one side or the other, even if they make it through.

title: Inotek Pharmaceuticals Swallows $19.3 Million
description: Inotek Pharmaceuticals, a drug developer, said it secured a $19.3 million funding round to support preclinical and clinical studies.

title: What Happened to Rooting for the Underdog?
description: Tennis is one of the toughest sports for non-elite professional athletes. Not only do you have to play qualifying tournaments just to get into major events like the U.S. Open (unless your country is hosting the Grand Slam, in which case you may get a wild-card entry), but once there, you often face a seeded opponent in the first round and with that the prospect of an early exit. And few fans know your name. They might cheer you on from time to time to extend the match, but when push comes to shove, most fans cheer for players they know  their favorite top seeds.

title: Hard Times for Buyout-Backed I.P.O.s
description: Private equity firms, until recently the high flyers of finance, have had a tough summer.

title: Rivals Try to Pick Off Bears Hedge Fund Clients, Report Says
description: Bear Stearns rivals are reportedly trying to poach the investment banks prime brokerage customers, telling them its too risky to stay while the firm deals with fallout from the subprime mortgage crisis.

title: Backers of BCE Buyout Insist Deal Is on Track
description: Its the biggest question in Canadian finance right now: Will BCE close the countrys largest buyout ever?

title: Pluggd Taps V.C.s for $6 Million
description: The lure of inside-the-video search was enough to hook Intel Capital, Draper Fischer Jurvetson Frontier, and Labrador Ventures into offering $6 million in a first round of funding to  Pluggd of Seattle.

title: Despite Market Woes, Sellers Target Real-Estate Record
description: It may seem like a long-shot given the recent news from Wall Street, but a group of homeowners is holding firm on an ambitious goal  to break the record for the most expensive home sale in American history.

title: In Defense of Private Equity
description: The conventional wisdom is that private equity firms are focused strictly on the short term.

title: Inside the Countrywide Lending Spree
description: On its way to becoming the nations largest mortgage lender, Countrywide Financial often led potential borrowers to high-cost and sometimes unfavorable loans that resulted in richer commissions for Countrywides smooth-talking sales force, outsize fees to company affiliates providing services on the loans, and a roaring stock price that made Countrywide executives among the highest paid in America, according to The New York Times.

title: Guilty Plea Is Arranged in Tax Plot
description: The owner of the nations largest maker of machine tools agreed Friday to plead guilty to conspiracy in cheating the government out of $34.3 million in taxes through what the I.R.S. called deceptive and elaborate tax evasion schemes.

title: Wachovia Sues Specialist Firm Over Collateral
description: Wachovia has sued the jumbo-mortgage specialist Thornburg Mortgage for failing to return collateral used in a derivatives transaction.

title: Altria Board to Consider a Spinoff Overseas
description: The maker of the worlds most popular cigarette, Marlboro, may decide this week that American consumers are too much trouble.

title: Dewey, LeBoeuf Agree to Merger
description: Two major American law firms agreed on Monday to a merger that, if approved by their partners, will create one of the nations biggest legal advisers.

title: Embattled Attorney General Resigns
description: WACO, Tex., Aug. 27  Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales, whose tenure has been marred by controversy and accusations of perjury before Congress, announced his resignation in Washington today, declaring that he had lived the American dream by being able to lead the Justice Department.

title: Just How Contagious Is That Hedge Fund?
description: Hedge funds may well stay vulnerable to the kind of rapidly spreading losses that have been precipitated this summer by problems in the subprime mortgage market, Mark Hulbert argues in The New York Times.

title: Will Credit Crisis End the Activists Run?
description: The recent credit crunch may strip activist shareholders like Carl C. Icahn of an important tool of their trade. The reason: Their strategies often depend on access to cheap capital.

title: U.S. Steel Buys Canadas Stelco
description: United States Steel has reached a deal to take over Stelco, making the company the final domino to fall in the Canadian steel industry.

title: Morning Kickoff
description: Who doesnt like to begin the day reading about football? We certainly do. And when we read something that interests us, we like to pass it on. So heres our first installment of the daily morning kickoff, a collection of newsworthy and/or eyebrow-raising stories and links from around the country. Enjoy.

title: Hotel Check-in Kiosks: Long Overdue
description: Each year, my wife and I each take each of our two older kids on individual special weekends awaythat is, four trips total (the babys not old enough to appreciate it). Its a treat for both participants; one-parent/one-child has a very different dynamic, and more bonding moments, than the constant uproar of whole-family trips.

title: Acer Strikes $710 Million Deal for Gateway
description: Acer agreed to acquire Gateway for $710 million to overtake Lenovo Group as the worlds third-biggest maker of personal computers.

title: Gonzales Resigns as Attorney General
description: A senior administration official said that Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales, whose tenure has been marred by controversy and accusations of perjury before Congress, will announce his resignation this morning in Washington.

title: Topps Postpones Shareholder Vote
description: Topps said on Monday that it would postpone a shareholder vote on a proposed $385 million takeover by two private equity companies, less than a week after rival Upper Deck withdrew its higher bid for the baseball card maker.

title: Morning Buzz: Older Firefighters, and More Fallout from the Deutsche Bank Blaze
description: Robert Beddia, the 53-year-old firefighter who was killed on Aug. 18 in the fire at the former Deutsche Bank building, was among the 502 firefighters, out of a department of 9,090 uniformed firefighters, who are 50 or older. Michael Wilson, after interviewing many older firefighters, reports that they spoke of new challenges since they were probies, or first-year firefighters, from generation gaps around the kitchen table to sore knees and weary backs.

title: 2008: Candidates on Katrina
description: This week marks the second anniversary of Hurricane Katrina, and several of the presidential candidates are traveling to New Orleans and the Gulf Coast, the site of the hurricanes devastation, to focus on the unfinished business of recovery and restoration.

title: Gonzales, a Surprisingly Unanticipated Resignation
description: The resignation of Attorney General Alberto Gonzales, first reported this morning by The New York Times, appears to have achieved the distinction of being both highly expected and, somehow, not expected all. Following are updates from the best sources around the Web.

title: Gonzales Is Resigning
description: Attorney General Alberto Gonzales is resigning today, the Timess Steven Lee Myers reports, with a 10:30 a.m. announcement planned. The nations chief prosecutor has been under fire throughout much of this year, with calls for his resignation emanating from Democrats and some leading Republicans.

description: Shares in Home Depot rose 1.9 percent to $35.33 in afternoon trading Monday on news that the sale of the companys wholesale supply unit, HD Supply, is still on track. The retailing giant agreed to trim the price to $8.5 billion as it prepares to sell the unit to Bain Capital, the Carlyle Group and Clayton Dubilier & Rice.

description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

description: Every major has at least one player who comes out of nowhere to inexplicably make the later rounds. Marion Bartoli did it at Wimbledon. Inspired by Pierce Brosnan, she made the finals.

description: Amid the recent market turmoil, securities firms and hedge funds have been scrambling to escape from money-losing trades. But could another kind of Wall Street transaction  the one between husbands and wives  start unwinding as well?

description: Arthur Weinstein, a Manhattan lawyer and vice president of the Council of New York Cooperatives, took questions from City Room readers this week. He is no longer taking questions. Read his answers here: Part 1, Part 2, Part 3, Part 4, and the final set, Part 5.)

description: UpdatedIn an extremely brief statement, Attorney General Alberto Gonzales announced his resignation, saying that he would complete his work by Sept. 17.

title: We Decided Not to Cover Bob Saget
description: The news cant be predicted, but traditionally the week before Labor Day has been a slow period in the news. Many politicians and government officials are on vacation. Parents, teachers and students are savoring a final respite before the start of the school year. Office workers are distracted by thoughts of the holiday weekend ahead.

Even Latecomers to Web Retailing Are Turning Profits
description: During the tech bust, GSI Commerce increased its business by buying distressed online retailers like Fogdog.com and Ashford.com, and running the entire operations more efficiently than the retailers could themselves.

title: Study Finds Elevated Asthma Rates Among 9/11 Workers
description: A study published today by the citys Health Department shows that 3.6 percent of the 25,000 rescue and recovery workers enrolled in the World Trade Center Health Registry reported developing asthma after working at ground zero, a rate 12 times what would be normally expected for the adult population over the time period covered in the survey.

title: Joke of the Day
description: The Defense Secretary briefed the President this morning. He told Bush that three Brazilian soliders were killed in Iraq. To everyones amazement, the color ran from Bushs face, then he collapsed onto his desk, head in hands, visibly shaken, almost whimpering. Finally, he composed himself and asked the Defense Secretary, Just exactly how many is a brazillion?  www.office-humour.co.uk

title: Is an M.T.A. Fare Increase Justified?
description: A new report by the state comptroller, Thomas P. DiNapoli, urges the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to hold off on raising fares and tolls. The authoritys board is scheduled to vote in December on a fare and toll proposal increase that would increase revenue from riders and motorists by 6.5 percent and raise about $300 million a year; it is not clear whether the $2 base fare for a subway or bus ride would increase as well.The new report [pdf] suggests that the authoritys fiscal outlook is unclear. The authority has recorded record surpluses in the last few years, largely driven by the real estate and mortgage taxes generated by the hot property market. However, the authority is projecting steep deficits starting next year and anticipates that the shortfall could be as high as $2.1 billion by 2011.

title: Fire Department Disciplines 3 Officers; Smoking Is Cited as Fires Cause
description: Updated, 3:27 p.m. | Three Fire Department officers were relieved of their commands this morning as the investigation continued into the fatal Aug. 18 fire in the former Deutsche Bank building. At an afternoon news conference, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced that smoking was the probable the cause of the fire and acknowledged that failures in oversight, judgment and responsibility had occurred.

description: George Hotz, a New Jersey teenager, got most of the attention last week for hacking the iPhone, but at least one other group claims to have come up with a way of liberating Apples popular gadget from AT&Ts wireless network. A group calling itself iPhoneSimFree, which first demonstrated its technique to Engadgets editor, Ryan Block, said it could unlock the iPhone without any changes to the iPhone hardware itself. If it works, the solution could potentially be more broadly accessible to people who want to use their iPhones on GSM networks other than AT&Ts.

The bonds are taxable mortgage revenue bonds, not taxable municipal bonds. Also, the article misstated the amount of bonds to be issued. The Ohio Housing Finance Agency says the sale will be based on market demand; the program has not been reduced to $25 million from $100 million.

title: The House Lawyer Departs
description: Attorney General Alberto Gonzales has finally done something important to advance the cause of justice. He has resigned. But his departure alone cannot remove the dark cloud that hangs over the Justice Department. President Bush needs to choose a new attorney general of unquestioned integrity who would work to make the department worthy of its name again  and provide the mandate to do it. Congress needs to continue to investigate the many scandals Mr. Gonzales leaves behind.

title: Democrats Face Online Diagnoses, but No Cure Yet
description: Although last years midterm elections ended in a historic Democratic take-back of Congress, party leaders and grass-roots supporters alike have acknowledged that the gains owed more to public unhappiness with the Iraq war and the presidency of George W. Bush than with any bold new policies advanced by the Democrats. In fact, the current race for the White House finds the Democratic Party facing both a deep-seated identity crisis and a Republican Party that, while weakened, still boasts a redoubtable infrastructure buttressed by a daunting message machine.

title: A Veteran of Comedy Rediscovers His Dark Side
description: In the second episode of FXs legal thriller Damages, a billionaire C.E.O. named Arthur Frobisher, who is being sued by his former employees for bilking them of their life savings, reinforces his Enron-era scoundrel credentials by cheating on his wife, snorting cocaine and putting out a contract on the life of a young woman whose only crime was having accidentally glimpsed him getting into a car with his broker.

description: Airbus won a contract from EgyptAir for five 330-200s, a deal valued at $881 million at list prices. The order from the expanding Egyptian carrier includes options for an additional three planes, Airbus said. EgyptAir, the state-owned airline based in Cairo, said in a preliminary announcement Aug. 15 that two A330-200F planes to be used for training were part of the order, which will bring to 12 the number of A330-200s in EgyptAirs fleet. Airbus is based in Toulouse, France.

description: A federal investigation of Senator Robert Menendez over potential conflicts of interests with recipients of government financing has shifted focus to the lobbying work of his former chief of staff and confidante, according to lawyers and others familiar with the case.

title: Ancient Diamonds Add Layer to Debate About Ancient Earth
description: It sounds like something you might see for sale on a home shopping channel: diamonds encased in zircon. But these crystals are much more valuable to scientists who study the early history of the Earth.

title: How Do You Move a Career Into High Gear? By Breaking the Rules
description: If you want to be a concert pianist when you grow up, there are certain rules. You do start playing as a young child. You dont drop out of Juilliard. You do win competitions and get the attention of managers at a young age. You dont end up at 30 with no management and no bookings, raising the money yourself for your first recording. And you definitely dont make your New York recital debut with Bachs demanding Goldberg Variations, which are supposed to reflect the wisdom of long experience, and Baroque style.

title: Facing Trial, Government Agrees to Improve Conditions at Immigrant Center
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 27  The federal government and lawyers for immigrant children have announced an agreement to improve living conditions at the nations main family detention center for illegal immigrant suspects.

title: A Connecticut Town Debates the Need for a Kind of Belt-Tightening
description: STRATFORD, Conn., Aug. 27  The elderly residents of Stratford were calling Alvin ONeal, a town councilman, with a persistent complaint. When they went to the supermarket, the library or anywhere else about town, all they saw were teenagers with saggy pants, their underwear more than peeking out.

title: For Dance Troupe, Travel Is a Test of Poise
description: For dancers in the Mark Morris Dance Group, air travel is a bitter enemy. Moving dynamically through space is our job and our passion. On a long flight, we feel like caged tigers. We are used to moving, but instead were angry, sad, bored and hungry.

title: 3 Disciplined Over Fatal Fire at Bank Tower
description: More than a week after two New York City firefighters died in a smoky fire at the former Deutsche Bank building, city officials relieved three senior fire officers of their posts yesterday, asserting they had failed to inspect the building or to draw up a specific plan on how to fight a fire inside the contaminated tower.

title: Peace Dam Still Waits for the Flood That Never Came
description: HWACHEON, South Korea  In 1986, as South Korea was busy preparing for its largest ever international event, the 1988 Summer Olympics in Seoul, North Korean soldiers broke ground on a gigantic dam just above the Demilitarized Zone.

title: Hughes Is Back; Velocity Is Lacking
description: DETROIT, Aug. 27  As he watched Phil Hughes pitch Sunday from his home in Connecticut, Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman noticed that Hughes was not throwing as hard as usual. His fastballs were averaging 88 to 91 miles an hour, Cashman said, when they should have been 91 to 93.

title: Unstable Crane Causes Evacuation in Stamford
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Aug, 28  An unstable 180-foot crane hung precariously over downtown Stamford today as police kept drivers, office workers and residents away and engineers worked on plans to shore the crane up, repair it and then remove it from a construction site on Richmond Hill Avenue.

description: When the wife and younger daughter of Rear Adm. Kenneth P. Moritsugu of the Navy were fatally injured in separate automobile accidents, he authorized the donation of organs and tissues from both of them.

title: Second Record Level for Afghan Opium Crop
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Aug. 27  Opium cultivation in Afghanistan grew by 17 percent in 2007, reaching record levels for the second straight year, according to a United Nations report released Monday.

title: After Trailblazer Is Honored, Williamses Carry On Her Legacy
description: On her way to the court on opening night at the United States Open, Venus Williams seemed momentarily flummoxed. In the hallway from the locker room at Arthur Ashe Stadium, she was greeted yesterday by an array of stars, an eye-popping lineup of African-American women who came to honor the tennis icon Althea Gibson. Williams paused to kiss Jackie Joyner-Kersee, to say hello to Roberta Flack, seeming as if she wanted to hug each of them.

title: Utley Rejoins Phillies and Shows Them What They Were Missing
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 27  When Chase Utley entered the lineup Monday night for the first time in a month, Phillies fans stood and cheered in hopes that this fractured season, like Utleys once broken hand, would finally heal itself.

title: Survey Shows a High Rate of Asthma at Ground Zero
description: Rescue and recovery workers at ground zero have developed asthma at a rate that is 12 times what would be expected for adults, according to findings released yesterday by the New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene.
