description: The nations poverty rate fell in 2006 for the first time this decade, the Census Bureau reported today, even as the percentage of Americans without health insurance coverage hit a record high.

title: Dow Falls 280 Points on Economic Concerns
description: As Wall Street tried to sort through some problematic readings on the economy and new concerns surfaced about the safety of owning financial stocks, investors pushed the market down sharply today.

title: Buddha Gets a Biopic
description: Born into a princely family in the sixth century B.C. in Kapilavastu on the border between present-day India and Nepal, Gautama Buddha abandoned luxury for spiritual enlightenment. Now the life of this man, who founded Buddhism, will be the subject of a film, Agence France-Press reported. Based on research by the Sri Lankan scholar Nimal DSilva and others, the film will be shot in India and Sri Lanka by Shyam Benegal, an Indian director, for release in 2009. It is a venture of the Light of Asia Foundation, based in Colombo, Sri Lanka, and Beyond Dream Entertainment, based in India. The message of the movie gives answers to global crises of conflict and environmental problems, said Navin Gooneratne, chairman of the foundation.

title: Poland and Germany Argue Over Art
description: Poland and Germany were embroiled yesterday in a dispute about art removed from each country during World War II, Agence France-Presse reported. Polands foreign minister, Anna Fotyga, said she had asked the culture ministry to compile a list of Polish works in German museums. Germany, meanwhile, was seeking the return of artifacts transported to Poland to avoid destruction during the war. Tono Eitel, the German negotiator, expressed frustration over Polands refusal to return pieces  including original scores by Mozart, texts by Goethe and a manuscript of the German national anthem  transported from Berlin to Krakow to protect them from Allied bombing. Poland considers everything found in its territory at the end of World War II to be its property.

description: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 28  The Taliban agreed today to release 19 South Korean church volunteers held captive in Afghanistan since mid-July, the South Korean government announced, signaling an end to a wrenching hostage crisis that has gripped the country for 41 days.

title: Asbestos, Hidden in Plain Sight
description: Libby, Montana sets a high bar for itself. An opening voice-over, covering idyllic home-movie scenes of life in the West, proclaims: Either this is the most horrific story Ive ever heard in my life, or those people are completely crazy. It couldnt have happened.

title: After Photo Finish, Campbell Emerges With Gold
description: OSAKA, Japan, Aug. 27  A race that lasted barely more than 11 seconds required quite a bit longer to unravel on Monday night.

title: Venturing Into the Mines of Uganda, in Search of the Marburg Virus
description: Researchers reported for the first time last week that they have found the Marburg virus in a nonprimate species  bats.

title: Math and Reading SAT Scores Drop
description: Average scores on the reading and math sections of the SAT test declined slightly this year, as the number of high school students taking the standardized exam grew larger and more diverse than ever before, according to a report released this morning by the College Board on the performance of the high school class of 2007.

title: Insights: Racial Disparity Affirmed in Tobacco Advertising
description: The density of billboards advertising tobacco products is more than twice as high in black neighborhoods as in white, researchers have found in a review of studies.

title: Core Issues Raised in Mideast Talks
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 28  Prime Minister Ehud Olmert of Israel and the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, discussed the core issues of contention between their peoples at a meeting here today, but it was unclear how detailed their talks had been.

title: Grandeur of the North, Yours by the Bushel, From Sibelius
description: In 1997 Colin Davis conducted an unforgettable Sibelius program with the London Symphony Orchestra at Avery Fisher Hall. I could not have been the only person in the audience that night hearing one engrossing work  Lemminkainens Return, a short and craggy tone poem  for the first time.

title: Digital South Park
description: Never underestimate the explanatory power of South Park, the animated Comedy Central show created by Matt Stone and Trey Parker. Again and again over the past 11 seasons, South Park has offered a satiric primer on adult behavior, including notably trenchant, compact analyses of the Mormon faith and whatever you choose to call Scientology. It would be interesting, now, to see a South Park episode devoted entirely to the groundbreaking new contract Mr. Stone and Mr. Parker have just signed with Viacom, the parent company of Comedy Central. The contract creates a new digital hub for all things South Park and also brings Mr. Stone and Mr. Parker half of the ad revenue their show generates. Historically, that kind of revenue sharing goes entirely against the principles of Hollywood.

title: Teenager Takes Turn on Scout Team
description: Jesse Levine keeps his short brown hair hidden under a cap and his arms covered by sleeves. His shorts are a conventional length.

title: Famous Friends on Tour for a Halberstam Book
description: The command post is a set of Manhattan publishing offices, and the foot soldiers include Joan Didion, Seymour Hersh, Bob Woodward, Anna Quindlen, Alex Kotlowitz, Paul Hendrickson, Samantha Power and Bill Walton. They are going on David Halberstams book tour for him.

title: The Wise Men, Redux
description: In 1948, a Republican lawyer named Herb Brownell managed Thomas Deweys presidential campaign. When Dwight Eisenhower was beginning his run in 1952, Brownell flew to Paris to tell Ike how to campaign  how to do scheduling, how to organize a campaign team, which positions to take on Social Security and the budget.

title: Prosecutors Seek Reporters Testimony in Murder Case Against Couple
description: After a year and a half of legal maneuvers and pretrial motions, murder charges against the parents of 7-year-old Nixzmary Brown now hang on their own words, a judge said yesterday.

title: Gonzales, Loyal to Bush, Was Firm on War Policies
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27  Days after President Bushs secret eavesdropping program was publicly revealed in December 2005, a battle-weary Alberto R. Gonzales stood before a room of reporters at the White House and asserted that the president has the inherent authority under the Constitution, as commander in chief, to engage in this kind of activity.

title: Nonprofit Payday Loans? Yes, to Mixed Reviews
description: APPLETON, Wis.  This city of 70,000 has five McDonalds franchises, three Pizza Huts, four Starbucks shops  and 19 payday loan stores, brightly lighted storefronts with names like EZ Money and Check Into Cash that offer two-week loans without credit checks.

title: For the Pilgrim on a Budget, the Vatican Has Air Charters
description: PARIS, Aug. 27  It already has its own postal service, its own bank and even its own Internet domain. On Monday, the Vatican inaugurated its latest venture: a low-cost charter airline to ferry thousands of Catholic pilgrims from Italy to popular religious sites around the world.

title: The Life of a Scullery Maid or Factory Slave? No Thanks
description: STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 24  Anyone game for a venture into the mountain air will find great pleasure in the Berkshire Theater Festivals production of Mrs. Warrens Profession, Shaws lively indictment of prudishness and patriarchal prejudice, in a two-week run here.

title: Israeli Says Hamas Is Training Hundreds Abroad
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 27  Hamas has sent hundreds of its fighters abroad for military training, most of them to Iran, the Israeli Armys deputy chief of staff says, and Israel has the names of more than 100 of them.

title: Two Years Later, a Street Still Waits for Its Promised Gentrification
description: Two years ago Freddy Saint-Aignan and his wife, Angelika, found the perfect location for their fledgling bar/restaurant, the Sugar Lounge: Columbia Street in Brooklyn.

title: Two Infusions of Vision to Bolster New Orleans
description: In the two years since Hurricane Katrina, what has the rebuilding effort produced? No grand designs. No inspired vision for the future of New Orleans. There have been only a handful of earnest, grass-roots proposals to preserve whats left of the historic fabric.

title: Hazard: High-Fat Diet Raises Risk of Colon Cancer Return
description: Colon cancer survivors with diets high in meat and refined grains triple their risk of recurrence or death compared with those who eat fruits, vegetables and fish, a new study reports.

title: Assigning Blame for the Mess in Iraq (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Taste of Victory for Isner and Young, 2 Promising Americans
description: When John Isner stepped to the United States Open baseline for the first time in his career, casting a slim 6-foot-9 shadow on the Armstrong Stadium court, the fans fell silent in anticipation of a serve that was an event unto itself.

title: A World of Eloquence in an Upturned Palm
description: ATLANTA  The chimpanzees, after spotting the humans at the corner of their compound, came over to us with their arms outstretched and their palms turned upward. This was the chimps way of asking for a banana  and a lot more, as researchers here at the Yerkes National Primate Research Center have discovered.

title: Martnez Is Pleased With Test
description: JUPITER, Fla., Aug. 27  Pedro Martnezs normally pinpoint control was not present Monday night. He threw far more balls against the Class A Palm Beach Cardinals than he had in any of his other rehabilitation efforts. Yet Martnez said that was a good thing.

title: Holding Kids Hostage
description: The governors of New York and New Jersey were upset and not trying to hide it.

title: What Looks and Sounds Like a Bailout?
description: A recurring question in the recent turmoil in the financial markets has been whether the Federal Reserve would bail out the banks, nonbank lenders and investors who are complicit in the excesses that sparked the credit crisis. Events have overtaken the debate. The bailout is well under way.

title: Did Chernobyl Leave an Eden for Wildlife?
description: In recent years, there have been reports that the area around the Chernobyl nuclear plant had become something of a wildlife playground. The reports suggested that animals like wild boar, wolves and moose had flourished in the 40-mile-diameter exclusion zone, which was contaminated by low-level radiation from the disaster in Ukraine 21 years ago.

title: Headliner Cant Make It? Heres a First-Class Fill-In
description: Abbey Lincoln, singing at two free outdoor concerts in New York in two consecutive days, on the same weekend as the memorial service for her ex-husband, Max Roach, and not too long after open-heart surgery: all this seemed a bit much to hope for. And it didnt happen. Ms. Lincoln was scheduled to play both days of the 15th annual Charlie Parker Jazz Festival over the weekend  in Marcus Garvey Park in Harlem on Saturday and in Tompkins Square Park in the East Village on Sunday  but had canceled by Saturday afternoon.

title: Bigger Than Las Vegas? Thats Macaos Bet
description: MACAO, Aug. 22  Las Vegass days as the capital of excess may be numbered.

title: New Shop Promises Results Clients Can Gauge
description: STAN RAPP, a longtime direct marketer, is embarking on his third (at least) career, joining forces with a private equity fund to start an agency that intends to use the new media to help forge closer, and more measurable, connections with consumers.

title: Deterrent to School Safety (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Gatlins Drug Case Puts Concerns on the (Massage) Table
description: OSAKA, Japan, Tuesday, Aug. 28  At the hotel for the United States track and field team, inside a room usually used for late-night karaoke, a team of massage therapists awaited its next clients Monday, with creams, sprays and lotions at the ready.

title: Letters
description: Debating a Hypothesis

title: Best Choices to Be Stranded: Syracuse, Albany, Pepperoni
description: ITS been an awful year for air travel, with delays and cancellations at record levels, with passengers stuck for hours on packed planes waiting to take off.

title: Suspect Seaweed
description: Q. I have seen some warnings about hijiki seaweed as a possible source of high levels of arsenic. How alarmed should I be?

title: 3 Colleges in Accord on College Board Inquiry
description: Fairfield University, Trinity College and Sacred Heart University, all in Connecticut, will pay tens of thousands of dollars each to various scholarship funds under agreements reached with the states attorney general, Richard Blumenthal. The accords end an investigation into relationships the institutions had with the College Board, the owner of the SAT and Advanced Placement examinations and a provider of student loans. The inquiry found that the College Board gave discounts on financial aid software to the colleges in return for being listed on their preferred lender lists given to students. The College Board announced last week that it was leaving the loan business.

title: Spitzer Talks of Suing to Expand Health Plan
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer said Monday that New York would consider suing federal health officials if the state was not granted a waiver to expand its federally subsidized health insurance program for children.

title: As Brazil Defends Its Bounty, Rules Ensnare Scientists
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Marc van Roosmalen is a world-renowned primatologist whose research in the Amazon has led to the discovery of five species of monkeys and a new primate genus. But precisely because of that work, Dr. van Roosmalen was recently sentenced to nearly 16 years in prison and jailed in Manaus, Brazil.

title: Kazakhs Suspend Permits for Oil Field
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 27  The government of Kazakhstan suspended environmental permits on Monday for a consortium of foreign energy companies developing a potentially huge oil field in the Caspian Sea, threatening to slow development of the largest oil find in the world since the discovery of Prudhoe Bay off Alaska three decades ago.

title: Prosecutor Asks to Drop Hazing Charge Against 2 Rider Officials
description: TRENTON, Aug. 27, (AP)  The Mercer County prosecutor has asked a judge to drop charges of aggravated hazing against two Rider University officials in a case involving the drinking death of a fraternity pledge.

title: Phillies Give Mets a Reminder the Race Is Only Beginning
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 27  The push toward the playoffs, it is said, does not traditionally begin until the calendar page flips to September. But tell that to Phillies Manager Charlie Manuel, who, fighting for every last edge, was ejected for arguing a close play at first base in the bottom of the first inning.

title: Homeless Man Held in Burglary of Dodds Office
description: HARTFORD, Aug. 27 (AP)  Police officers arrested a suspect on Monday in connection with a weekend burglary at the downtown office of Senator Christopher J. Dodd, a Democratic presidential candidate.

title: Collaborators in a Quest for Human Perfection
description: Within a building secluded behind iron gates, in a laboratory painted black, two men in black masks and long hooded black robes stand over an operating table. One is tall and one is short, and of course they are trying to create life  any fan of horror movies knows that. But this is no movie: it is quite true, a little-known piece of early-20th-century medical history that segues seamlessly into the living horror of World War II.

title: Sudan: Aid Agency Chief Expelled
description: Paul Barker, CAREs country director for Sudan, said the government had abruptly expelled him from the country. Mr. Barker, who said he had been told Saturday that he had 72 hours to leave Sudan, said the government did not provide a specific reason but said it had something to do with security. Sudanese government officials could not be reached for comment. Last week, the European Commissions envoy and a Canadian diplomat were expelled. Jan Pronk, the chief United Nations envoy, was expelled last October. CARE is one of the largest aid agencies in Sudan, spending around $20 million there each year on health, education and economic development projects. More than half of that money goes to the western war-torn region of Darfur.

title: Candidates Call Anew for Rebuilding of New Orleans
description: The presidential candidates returned to New Orleans yesterday to press for the rebuilding of the city, using the coming second anniversary of Hurricane Katrina to attack the Bush administration while highlighting their own initiatives to aid the people there.

title: The C.I.A.s Problem (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A review yesterday about the chorus Schola Cantorum de Venezuela referred incorrectly to a performance in which it participated last year, the Pasin Segn San Marcos. The work was performed at Lincoln Center as part of the Great Performers series, not as part of the Lincoln Center Festival.

title: Justice Served?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: The Claim: Swallowed Gum Takes a Long Time to Digest
description: THE FACTS

title: Departures Offer Chance for a Fresh Start as Term Ebbs
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27  The back-to-back resignations of Karl Rove and Alberto R. Gonzales, two longtime aides to President Bush who have become lightning rods on Capitol Hill, amount to a political housecleaning for the White House, providing Mr. Bush a fresh chance to make what he can of his remaining months in office.

title: Bush Warns U.S. Withdrawal From Iraq Would Destabilize Mideast
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28  A hasty American withdrawal from Iraq would leave the Middle East disastrously exposed to further violence and instability, President  Bush warned today, as he sought to set the terms for a major debate in Washington next month over the future American presence in Iraq.

title: 2 Big Law Firms Announce Merger
description: Two major New York law firms announced yesterday that they had agreed to merge, creating what will be one of the nations largest law firms, with broad international reach.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The Talking Business column in Business Day on Saturday about Richard D. Parsons, chief executive of Time Warner, misspelled the name of the employer of Richard Greenfield, a media analyst who commented on Time Warners stock price. It is Pali Research, a division of Pali Capital  not Peri Research.

title: Noriega Can Be Extradited to France
description: MIAMI, Aug. 28  A federal judge in Miami ruled today that Manuel Antonio Noriega, the former Panamanian general ousted by the American military in 1989, can be extradited to France, where he faces charges of money laundering and up to a decade in prison.

title: Tyrees Broken Wrist Adds to Giants Injury Troubles
description: The Giants cannot stem the onslaught of injuries. David Tyree, a receiver and special-teams star, broke his left wrist in Saturdays preseason game against the Jets, Coach Tom Coughlin said. He is expected to be out for up to six weeks.

title: For Davydenko, a New Kind of Grind
description: The last thing Nikolay Davydenko appears to be is the kind of tennis player likely to do something splashy, much less crazy. He is fair-haired but prematurely balding, athletic but unimposing, efficient but unspectacular.

title: In a Rare View, Rings on Uranus Show Their Changes
description: Its that time of year on Uranus  time for the semiannual ring-plane crossing, when the planets ring system appears edge-on to observers on Earth. (Unlike the other planets, Uranus spins on its side, making for extreme changes in viewing angles.) The crossing allows telescopes to take pictures of the rings from the unlighted side, free from the glare that can obscure faint parts of them.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An art review on Thursday about Robert Gober: Work 1976-2007 in Basel, Switzerland, misstated the name of the Los Angeles museum where a Madonna by the artist was first shown. It was the Museum of Contemporary Art, not the Los Angeles County Museum of Contemporary Art.

title: China in Africa (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Magdalen Nabb, Mystery Writer in Italy, Dies at 60
description: Magdalen Nabb, an expatriate English author whose sensitively wrought crime novels, set in her adopted city, Florence, won her the admiration and friendship of Georges Simenon, the writer whose sensibility most matched her own, died in Florence on Aug. 18. She was 60 and had lived and worked there since 1975.

title: Perking Up Convention Halls
description: For years, industry slang for a convention center was a box with docks. It was blunt but apt shorthand. In recent years, though, convention center managers have been learning the lesson that hotel companies have already discovered: it is not enough to offer just a place to stay or meet.

title: Awaiting Sentence, Vick Speaks of Mistakes
description: RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 27  Standing before microphones, reporters and cameras is nothing new for quarterback Michael Vick. But at a news conference Monday morning, the subject matter had nothing to do with touchdown passes or long, improvised runs downfield.

title: Greek Leaders Criticized Over Fires
description: ATHENS, Greece, Aug. 28  The fires that tore omnivorously through scores of villages and olive groves here may now also be changing Greeces political landscape. The government of Prime Minister Kostas Karamanlis, facing national elections next month, came under increasing criticism today, not only over its handling of the fires but also over whether it stoked Greeks fears about who might be to blame.

title: Peggy Samuels, Biographer and Art Historian, Dies at 84
description: Peggy Samuels, an amateur art historian who with her husband, Howard, wrote or edited 10 books on art and United States history, including a revealing biography of Frederic Remington, the renowned painter of the American West, died Thursday at her home in East Falmouth, Mass. She was 84.

title: At Risk: Gestational Diabetes May Be Tied to Type of Cancer
description: Gestational diabetes may be associated with a substantially increased risk for pancreatic cancer, a new study has found.

title: Beijing Seeks New Scrutiny of Investments by Outsiders
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 27  After a quarter-century of welcoming and even courting foreign investors, Beijing officials are starting to show considerably more caution. Chinese lawmakers are set to pass legislation this week that would limit foreign acquisitions in China on national security grounds.

title: Memo Pad
description: CANCELLATIONS SOAR The number of domestic flights that were canceled by airlines nearly doubled from June 1 through Aug. 15 of this year, to 30,471, from 16,049 in that period in 2006, according to FlightStats.com. There were more total flights in that period  1,437,600 flights compared with 1,406,780 flights last year.

title: Sarkozy Lists Foreign Priorities, With Iran First
description: PARIS, Aug. 27  In his first major foreign policy speech as president of France, Nicolas Sarkozy called the Iranian nuclear crisis the most serious weighing on the international order today and said that Iran could be attacked militarily if it did not live up to its international obligations to curb its nuclear program.

title: Topps Delays Vote on Buyout Offer
description: The Topps Company has postponed a shareholder vote on a proposed $384.5 million buyout from a group led by Michael D. Eisner, the former Walt Disney Company chief executive, giving investors more time to consider the offer.

title: Redone Home Depot Deal Not Thought Contagious
description: As the deal for Home Depots wholesale supply unit was renegotiated over the weekend, a question lingered about whether the push to lower the price was a harbinger for other buyouts.

title: Former Islamist Is Voted in as President of Turkey
description: A former Islamist was elected president of Turkey today, breaking an 84-year grip on the office by the countrys secular establishment and ushering a new Islamic middle class from Turkeys heartland into the center of political life in the staunchly secular state.

title: In Greece, Wine Saves Life; a Mothers Arms Do Not
description: MAKISTOS, Greece, Aug. 27  When the water ran out, with pine cones popping and the flames still high around his house, George Dimopoulos switched to wine. He made it himself two years ago, and, nearly alone in his village as it all but burned down on Friday night, he poured liter after liter, 200 in all, into his little copper hand-pumped crop sprayer, and sprayed and sprayed.

title: Race Takes 11.01 Seconds. Results Take 5 Minutes.
description: OSAKA, Japan, Aug. 27  A race that lasted barely more than 11 seconds required quite a bit longer to unravel Monday night.

title: Hes in Iraq. U.S. Reward: Deport Wife?
description: While Alexander Gomez was in Iraq at the United States governments bidding, that same government was trying to kick his wife out of this country. For the Colombian-born Mr. Gomez, more accurately Specialist Gomez of the New York Army National Guard, something was definitely out of kilter.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an editorial on Sunday misstated a new rule governing the expansion of the State Childrens Health Insurance Program. States must show that they have enrolled 95 percent of the children in families with incomes below 200 percent of the poverty level before they can extend the limit above 250 percent, not to 250 percent.

title: Fatal Fires in Greece
description: The government of Greece is facing a crisis over whether it was up to the task of handling the country's worst fires in more than a century.

title: Mondays Wild-Card Update
description: Wow. Three of the four wild cards I mentioned this morning won their first-round matches on Monday.

title: Game Over for Vick?
description: Michael Vick formally pleaded guilty to a felony charge of conspiracy stemming from a dogfighting kennel being run from a property he owned in Surry, Va. A plea agreement with the government was filed Friday at the courthouse.

title: Architects Add Zip on the North Folk
description: Images of the work of Long Island architects.

title: $400,000 Homes
description: Homes on the market in California, Florida and New Mexico.

title: Day 2 at the Open
description: It was a day without surprises as Maria Sharapova, Andy Roddick, Martina Hingis and Lleyton Hewitt all advanced easily to the next round.

title: Courts Rule Against Hedge Funds in Mittal-Arcelor Deal
description: Courts in the Netherlands and France refused to grant injunctions seeking to block Mittal Steels proposed $41 billion acquisition of a rival steel maker, Arcelor.

title: Switzerlands ABB to Sell Plant
description: ABB, the Swiss engineering company, will sell an oil and gas production plant, Lummus Global, to the Chicago Bridge and Iron Company for $950 million, ABB said.

title: Thornburg Pays Collateral Owed to Wachovia
description: Thornburg Mortgage, the jumbo mortgage specialist sued by Wachovia last week, said Monday that it had repaid the $5.1 million in collateral that was the basis of the banks litigation.

title: Refco Trusts Sue on Behalf of Currency Clients
description: Trusts representing creditors of the defunct commodities broker Refco said Monday that they had sued its legal and accounting advisers for more than $500 million on behalf of 75 foreign exchange customers.

title: French Firm Snaps Up Fotolog
description: Fotolog, a photo-sharing social network founded by Meetups co-founder and chief executive. Scott Heiferman, has been acquired. After several days of rumors that the company was up for sale, the French company Hi-Media Group announced on Monday that it had acquired Fotolog for $90 million in cash and stock.

title: Former XenSource Chief Now Heads Rival Start-Up
description: As virtualization software continues to garner attention following VMwares successful $1.1 billion initial public offering and Citrixs rich $500 million purchase of XenSource, a co-founder of XenSource resurfaced Monday as the head of a rival start-up.

title: Canadas Regulators Scrutinize Radio Deal
description: Astral Media faced tough questions Monday from Canadian broadcast regulators who suggested the broadcaster is low-balling the C$1.08 billion ($1.02 billion) purchase price of Standard Broadcasting, a deal that will create the largest commercial radio company Canada has ever seen.

title: Buffetts Berkshire Raises Railroad Stake
description: Warren E. Buffetts Berkshire Hathaway bought more than 10 million shares of the railroad company Burlington Northern Santa Fe since Thursday, increasing its stake to 14.8 percent, according to regulatory filings.

title: Are Associate Lawyers in the Firing Line?
description: The current turmoil in the credit market has some law firm leaders predicting future layoffs of associates, according to The Legal Intelligencer.

title: Bank of Americas Lewis: a Modern-Day Morgan?
description: Sentiment is growing that Bank of Americas Kenneth Lewis may have won a place in the pantheon of great Wall Street titans by using his financial clout to help the country avoid economic ruin, writes MarketWatchs David Weidner.

title: Ohio Files Antitrust Suit Against Insurers
description: The state of Ohio has filed an antitrust lawsuit accusing Marsh & McLennan, the American International Group and three other insurers and their subsidiaries of price fixing and other anti-competitive behavior, the attorney general, Marc Dann, said Monday.

title: After Gateway Deal, Eyes Turn to Lenovo
description: As executives at Gateway and Acer carried on about the many benefits of their $710 million merger announced Monday, TheStreet.com speculated that Acers nemesis, Lenovo, might make a counteroffer for Gateway.

title: Whole Foods Closes Wild Oats Deal
description: Whole Foods Market said on Monday it had bought smaller rival Wild Oats Markets, following months of delays as U.S. antitrust authorities sought to block the $565 million deal. The acquisition extends Whole Foods dominance in the expanding natural and organic grocery market and eliminates one of the chains chief retailing rivals.

title: Doubles, Anyone? Anyone?
description: When was the last time you heard someone say his or her favorite tennis players were the Bryan brothers or the Martin Damm/Leander Paes team?

title: Deutsche Bank Loses Hedge Fund Executive
description: Hedge fund rainmaker John Dyment has left Deutsche Bank in New York to join Shumway Capital Partners, a hedge fund based in Greenwich, Conn. Mr. Dyment was global head of the German banks hedge fund capital group.

title: China Eastern Airlines Close to Stake Sale, Report Says
description: China Eastern Airlines will sign an agreement Sunday to sell a stake of itself to Singapore Airlines and Singapores state-owned investment company, Temasek Holdings, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing undisclosed sources.

title: Waiting for the Social Networking I.P.O.s
description: Social networking Web sites have fired up the media industrys deal headlines the past couple of years, and now it looks as if social networking could heat up the market for initial public offerings, according to The Hollywood Reporter.

title: Investors Tell Tales of V.C. Hardball
description: Some top venture-capital firms eager to expand into new markets are twisting their investors arms to get them to go along, according to The Wall Street Journal.

title: Medco Health Coughs Up $1.5 Billion for PolyMedica
description: The pharmacy benefits management company Medco Health Solutions said Tuesday it would pay $1.5 billion in cash for a diabetes treatment supplier, PolyMedica.

title: Merrill Analyst Downgrades Three Rivals
description: Merrill Lynch is apparently not so hot on some of its rivals prospects right now.

title: Judge Delays Ruling on Bear Funds Offshore Liquidation
description: Two bankrupt Bear Stearns hedge funds will have to wait another week or so before finding out if a New York judge will allow the bulk of their reorganization to take place in the Caribbean.

title: NBC Universal Eyes Sparrowhawk Media, Report Says
description: NBC Universal is holding discussions to buy Sparrowhawk Media, which owns the international operations of the Hallmark Channel, for about $350 million, according to Reuters. Sparrowhawk, a private equity group backed by Providence Equity Partners and 3i purchased the international arm of the Hallmark Channel in 2005 for about $242 million.

title: L.S.E. Rises on Renewed Takeover Buzz
description: Shares of the London Stock Exchange rose by as much as 5 percent Tuesday morning, on speculation that a new takeover bid could be triggered if the Nasdaq Stock Market sells its entire stake to another exchange.

title: American Water Works Plans $1.5 Billion I.P.O.
description: American Water Works, a subsidiary of the European utility RWE, filed with United States regulators to sell as much as $1.5 billion in stock in an initial public offering. All the shares to be sold are held by a unit of RWE, which bought American Water Works in 2003 for $4.6 billion.

title: Conrad Black Asks Judge to Overturn Guilty Verdict
description: Conrad Black, the former chairman of Hollinger International, who was convicted of fraud and obstruction of justice for stealing millions from the company, asked a federal judge to order his acquittal or give him a new trial. In papers filed today with Judge Amy St. Eve of United States District Court in Chicago, Mr. Blacks attorneys argued that evidence prosecutors presented to the jury during his 15-week trial doesnt support last months guilty verdict.

title: Carlyle Affiliates 2nd Bailout Pummels Shares
description: Shares of an $18 billion Dutch investment fund affiliated with the Carlyle Group dropped Tuesday, retreating after it received its second bailout from its private equity parent in a week, MarketWatch reported.

title: Simons Renaissance Said to Pursue Private Offering
description: Renaissance Technologies, the $30 billion hedge fund run by James H. Simons, is said to be considering a share sale, apparently shrugging off concerns about volatile global markets.

title: Buyout Chiefs See Lower Returns Ahead
description: Private equity funds are likely to book significantly lower returns in the next few years, as tighter credit markets limit the resale value of their portfolio companies, buyout professionals and analysts told Bloomberg News.

title: Morning Buzz: Fallout From Fire, Man Suspected in Multiple Killings, Ground Zero Asthma and More
description: The citys decision yesterday to discipline three Fire Department officers in the wake of the Deutsche Bank fire dominates local news coverage today. With the continuing revelations about malfunctioning equipment, inadequate fire plans and careless actions by contractors, the public pressure for answers continues to mount.In an overview, Al Baker notes that fire union officials criticized the decision to remove the officers from their command; some critics have started to call for the resignation of the fire commissioner, Nicholas Scoppetta. Meanwhile, the district attorneys investigation into the case continues. An accompanying article by John Sullivan notes that the inspection system was revamped after seven people died in a Harlem apartment fire in 1987. But the scale of the work involved, with New Yorks dense network of buildings, is daunting. Firefighters conduct general inspections while civilians perform reviews of critical systems like sprinklers. The number of inspections by fire companies fell sharply between the 2005 and 2006 fiscal years, for reasons that are not clear.

title: Home Depot Confirms New Price for Supply Unit
description: Home Depot said on Tuesday that it was lowering the price of its wholesale supply unit business by nearly $2 billion, confirming media reports. As previously reported, the retailer will sell HD Supply to a consortium of private equity firms for $8.5 billion, while holding onto a 12.5 percent stake in the unit and backing $1 billion in financing.

title: 2008: Thompson Talk
description: Could the announcement be just a week away? Former Senator Fred D. Thompson has been hedging all summer on officially joining the Republican presidential field, but if the latest chatter in political circles is right, he may jump in as early as next Tuesday.

title: More on Gonzaless Resignation
description: Following are some interesting nuggets within todays eruption of news articles on Attorney General Alberto Gonzaless resignation.

title: Tuesday Morning Kickoff
description: For your reading pleasure:

title: Wheels: Inside a Citron Museum of Sorts
description: The Citron Conservatoire includes an example of nearly every car ever produced by the automaker. More Photos  Tucked to one side of Citrons sprawling auto factory in Aulnay-sous-Bois, about 20 minutes outside of Paris, is a gray and mirrored-glass building surrounded by a fringe of green grass. One double-chevron logo adorns the awning of the entrance, but otherwise the structure is nondescript and incredibly reserved, like a warehouse from the future.   This is the Citron Conservatoire, the company's private museum, which houses an extraordinary collection of cars and an example of nearly every car the company has ever produced.  Stepping inside its immediately clear that this is no parts depot. Rally cars, dune buggies, show concepts and elegant DS sedans from the 1950s all sit in orderly rows under high ceilings. A two-passenger helicopter powered by a Wankel rotary engine  developed by Citron and the defunct German manufacturer, NSU  guards the end of a long line of former show cars dating back to the 1970s.   Photos: Inside the Citron Conservatoire  Also included among the hundreds of classic cars are incredibly detailed and carefully organized archives: hand-written sales logs from the 1920s, original design sketches and even blueprints for the first Citron dealerships.  The Conservatoire isn't usually open to the public, though this doesnt mean that the cars in the collection are camera shy. Nearly all of the vehicles are kept in excellent running condition. Many are used on a regular basis, for a wide range of classic car events and publicity campaigns. On rare occasions, the Conservatoire is open to groups, including journalists and Citron clubs from around the world.  I walked down row after row and found a gold-colored mystery machine hidden among the rest of the cars. Built sometime around 2000 -- Citron isnt clear about the exact date -- it was only a foam mock-up, and lacked an engine and interior. Based on the humdrum Citron Xantia sedan, its mini pickup lines were awkward. To be honest, its unremarkable in every way except one: it was a little-known styling exercise for a proposed return to the United States market.   Denis Huile, director of the Conservatoire, pointed out one small clue to the concepts American aspirations. Rather than sitting on Citrons standard Michelin tires, this car wore chunky all-terrain Goodyears. Yet the car never appeared at an auto show and, to the best of Mr. Huiles ample knowledge, was never given an official name. In the end, nothing came of the proposed return to the United States, and the idea faded into obscurity.   But in an automobile museum that really isnt a museum, is it any wonder that the most intriguing car is the one that doesnt even have a name?   Photos: Inside the Citron Conservatoire

title: Orders for Simpson Book Soar
description: Beaufort Books, the publisher of If I Did It, the recently revived book in which O. J. Simpson hypothesizes about how he might have murdered Nicole Brown Simpson and Ronald Goldman in 1994, announced yesterday that it would print 125,000 copies and would likely go back to press before the book is released around Sept 13. Eric Kampmann, owner and president of Beaufort, said the company already had orders for 116,000 copies from chain bookstores, independents and online retailers. Although Barnes & Noble announced that it would not sell the book in its stores, advance orders online at bn.com propelled it to No. 1 on its best-seller list on Monday, and it hovered between No. 2 and 5 yesterday. Last fall, after a public outcry, HarperCollins scuttled plans for a 400,000-copy print run by its Regan Books imprint. Since then, the Goldman family won the rights in bankruptcy court to publish the book. Separately, Denise Brown, sister of Ms. Brown Simpson, said yesterday in a statement that she was withdrawing from a planned Sept. 13 appearance on The Oprah Winfrey Show alongside members of the Goldman family. At the time of accepting this proposition from Oprah, a publisher was not yet established, and publication was still pending, Ms. Brown said, adding: Since then, the Goldmans have retained a publisher who is rushing the book to market as we speak. And thus, has made the show a moot point for me.

title: Shorter Waits for Botox Than Examinations of Moles
description: Patients seeking an appointment with a dermatologist to ask about a potentially cancerous mole have to wait substantially longer than those seeking Botox for wrinkles, says a study published online today by The Journal of the American Academy of Dermatology.

title: Strahan Has Decided When Hell Decide
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Aug. 28  Michael Strahan told the Giants he would announce his retire-or-return decision on Wednesday or Thursday, the team said.

title: Selected Studies: Stroke
description: Government agencies, universities and corporations frequently enroll patients in studies designed to test the effectiveness of new drugs, procedures and medical devices. Participants may benefit by gaining access to experimental therapies, and they make an important contribution to scientific research. For more information, please visit ClinicalTrials.gov, a service of the National Institutes of Health.

title: John Gardner, Who Continued the James Bond Series, Dies at 80
description: John Gardner, a prolific British thriller writer who wrote more novels about Bond  James Bond  than Ian Fleming did, died on Aug. 3 after collapsing near his home in Basingstoke, England. He was 80.

title: Questions on Citys Role in Demolition Near 9/11 Site
description: The former headquarters of Deutsche Bank, at the edge of ground zero, has been in state hands for more than three years, ever since the Pataki administration fashioned a deal to buy and demolish it. The wounded tower had stood as both an ugly reminder of Sept. 11 and the slow progress in rebuilding downtown Manhattan.

title: Ex-Astronaut to Enter a Plea of Insanity on Assault Charges
description: Capt. Lisa M. Nowak, the Navy officer and former astronaut who confronted a romantic rival at the Orlando, Fla., airport in February, will plead insanity at her trial on assault and kidnapping charges, according to a notice filed yesterday in State Circuit Court in Orlando.

title: What to Ask About Alzheimer's Disease
description: Confronting a new diagnosis can be frightening  and because research changes so often, confusing. Here are some questions you may not think to ask your doctor, along with notes on why theyre important.

title: Stocks Fall Across Asia After U.S. Losses
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Aug. 29  The volatility triggered by the mortgage meltdown in the United States further plagued stock markets today, prompting a drop of all major indices in Asia a day after a battering on Wall Street.

title: Selected Studies: Headaches
description: Government agencies, universities, and corporations frequently enroll patients in studies designed to test the effectiveness of new drugs, procedures and medical devices. Participants may benefit by gaining access to experimental therapies, and they make an important contribution to scientific research. For more information, please visit ClinicalTrials.gov, a service of the National Institutes of Health.

title: Lucerne to Getan Opera House
description: The Lucerne Festival in Switzerland said yesterday it planned to build a 1,000-seat opera house, adding an important element to its classical music offerings. The festival put construction costs at $85 million, though it must still find a site and hold a competition for an architect. The hall will be flexible enough to present chamber music, music theater and experimental works, said Michael Haefliger, the events executive and artistic director. Taking place in summer and at Easter time, the festival operates in the Culture and Convention Center on Lake Lucerne, a much-praised modern building designed by Jean Nouvel. It has been trying to compete with its better-known rivals in Salzburg, Austria and Bayreuth, Germany, both opera destinations. This project represents a quantum leap for the Lucerne Festival, said Jrg Reinshagen, the festivals board president, and will position Lucerne even more prominently at the forefront of the international music scene.

title: U.S. Releases Group of Iranians Held in Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD, Wednesday Aug. 29  Members of an Iranian Energy Ministry delegation visiting Baghdad at the invitation of the Iraqi government were released Wednesday, a day after being arrested at their hotel by American troops and led away in handcuffs and blindfolds.

title: Dress Like Your Child, and the Terrorists Win
description: Fathers in America used to have sons. Now they have mini-mes. Pop and his offspring head out to the mall dressed in the same outfits: baggy shorts, sneakers, athletic socks and T-shirt, topped by a baseball cap. At home they watch Cartoon Network, play video games and eat lots of breakfast cereal. One is older and bigger, the other smaller and younger, but their tastes overlap to a remarkable degree. Todays child truly is father to the man.

title: Tracing the Path from DNA to Dementia
description: Dr. Marcelle Morrison-Bogorad is director of the neuroscience and neuropsychology of aging program at the National Institute on Aging. In collaboration with the Alzheimer's Association, the institute runs the Alzheimer's Disease Genetics Initiative, which is collecting and banking genetic and cellular material from families in which multiple relatives have late-onset Alzheimer's, the most common form of the disease.

title: Cautious Optimism for Sufferers of Joint Pain
description: For decades patients with osteoarthritis resigned themselves to what seemed to be the bodys inevitable breakdown. People grow old, doctors told them. Hips and knees wear out. What can you do?

title: The Attorney General We Need (6 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Spring Awakening Perks Up
description: For a while there the musical Spring Awakening was barely making enough in a good week to meet its running costs. But after winning a raft of Tony Awards, unveiling a new advertising campaign and posting strong summer grosses, the show has recouped its original $4.2 million investment, said Ira Pittleman, one of its lead producers.

title: Close Political Ally of Brazilian President to Face Corruption Trial
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 28  A corruption scandal that has hovered like a black cloud over President Luiz Incio Lula da Silva for two years intensified this week after Brazils Supreme Court voted to put his former chief of staff on trial on corruption charges.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Monday about a program in South Texas that helps families gradually rebuild shacks into homes misstated the surname of the Starr County ombudswoman who oversees the states Colonia Initiatives Program. She is Blanca Juarez, not Suarez. Also, the article carried an incorrect dateline, and a picture caption repeated the error. The article and photograph were from Rio Grande City; there is no town named Rio Grande.

title: Idaho Senator Says He Regrets Guilty Plea in Restroom Incident
description: BOISE, Idaho, Aug. 28  Senator Larry E. Craig said Tuesday that he regretted his guilty plea in connection with an airport restroom incident, and he accused an Idaho newspaper of hounding him in recent months.

title: Horticulturalists Seek to Go Native on Interstates
description: NEWARK, Del.  For Americans on the move, a rest stop on the East Coasts main drag, Interstate 95, seems an unlikely setting for a revolution. But to a growing number of horticulturalists the vegetation stretching beyond the gas pumps toward the highway median might as well be marching behind a fife and drum.

title: A Surgeon's Own Back Story
description: Dr. James N. Weinstein is editor of the medical journal Spine and chairman of the department of orthopedic surgery at Dartmouth-Hitchcock Medical Center in Lebanon, N.H.

title: What to Ask About Back Pain
description: Confronting a new diagnosis can be frightening  and because research changes so often, confusing. Here are some questions you may not think to ask your doctor, along with notes on why theyre important.

title: The Necessity, and Elusiveness, of Sleep
description: Why do we sleep?

title: Isinbayevas Boasting Exceeds Her Heights
description: OSAKA, Japan, Wednesday, Aug. 29  While her competitors struggled, one dropping out with a leg injury, another puffy-eyed and crying after a dispute with the judges, Yelena Isinbayeva remained in her bubble.

title: A Sobering Census Report: Americans Meager Income Gains
description: The economic party is winding down and most working Americans never even got near the punch bowl.

title: Beyond the Fringe
description: Record sales of 1.7 million tickets were announced yesterday, a day after the end of the 60th Edinburgh Festival Fringe, by organizers, the BBC reported. Sales increased 10 percent from last years total at the arts festival, which began on Aug. 5. ... The 75th Venice Film Festival opens today, with all 22 films in competition for the Golden Lion to be seen in their world premieres, Agence France-Presse reported. That has occurred only once before, last year.

title: SAT Scores Dip Slightly in a More Diverse Field
description: Average reading and math scores on the SAT test declined slightly this year, as the number of high school students taking the standardized exam grew larger and more diverse than ever, according to a report released yesterday by the College Board on the high school class of 2007.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A report in the Arts, Briefly column on Monday about Have You Seen Steve Steven?, a forthcoming production at the East 14th Street Theater, misstated the name of the presenter. It is the collective 13 Playwrights Inc., not 12 Playwrights Inc.

title: Keep the Electoral College (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: One Mortgage Lender, at Least, Is Hiring
description: One mortgage lender announced that it was hiring yesterday as it tried to take advantage of the turmoil in the market, while another said it was cutting jobs.

title: Report Cites Other Arrests at Airport
description: The arrest report accusing Senator Larry E. Craig of disorderly conduct in a bathroom stall at Minneapolis-St. Paul International Airport said Mr. Craigs actions followed numerous arrests regarding sexual activity in the public restroom.

title: Selected Studies: Childhood Asthma
description: Government agencies, universities and corporations frequently enroll patients in studies designed to test the effectiveness of new drugs, procedures and medical devices. Participants may benefit by gaining access to experimental therapies, and they make an important contribution to scientific research. For more information, visit ClinicalTrials.gov, a service of the National Institutes of Health.

title: Amid All the Cheers, a Few Signs of Change
description: Take a 19-year-old Disney-groomed actress, beloved by tweens and former tweens. Put her onstage at Radio City Music Hall. Give her a microphone. No, a working microphone. Sounds like a recipe for disaster, right?

title: After Blaze, New Focus on Smoking at Work Sites
description: Alan Theibotot was doing what a smoker does yesterday. He was smoking. More precisely, he was smoking during lunch.

title: U.N. Secretary General to Meet Sudanese Leader
description: UNITED NATIONS, Aug. 28  Secretary General Ban Ki-moon announced Tuesday that he would travel to Sudan, Chad and Libya next week to press for an end to fresh violence in Darfur and for speedy deployment there of a joint African Union-United Nations peacekeeping force.

title: S.& P. Cuts British Firms Debt Rating
description: A London money management firm, Cheyne Capital Management, may be forced to liquidate the assets backing its $10 billion commercial paper program in the latest casualty of the jittery credit market.

title: What to Ask About Prostate Cancer
description: Confronting a new diagnosis can be frightening  and because research changes so often, confusing. Here are some questions you may not think to ask your doctor, along with notes on why theyre important.

title: Tracking an Urban Plague
description: Dr. David L. Rosenstreich is director of the division of allergy and immunology at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine in New York. He is a former senior investigator with the Inner City Asthma Study, which identifies factors related to the development of asthma in children.

title: A Breakthrough in Joint Pain
description: Revolutions are rare in the management of chronic disease, which tends to be a matter of incremental progress. But over the past decade, patients with rheumatoid arthritis have seen advances in treatment that most could barely have imagined. A new class of drugs called biologic response modifiers has transformed the lives of countless R.A. sufferers, so much so that many have been able to return to active, rich lives.

title: Bush Cites Nuclear Risk of Leaving Iraq
description: RENO, Nev., Aug. 28  President Bush told a receptive audience of veterans on Tuesday that an American withdrawal from Iraq would unsettle the entire Middle East, create a haven for Al Qaeda and embolden a belligerent Iran. He said Tehrans nuclear programs threatened to put a region already known for instability and violence under the shadow of a nuclear holocaust.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A picture on Friday with an article about the impending release from prison of Arthur Bremer, who shot Gov. George C. Wallace, appeared in mirror image. The photograph, taken by The Associated Press in 1972, showed Mr. Bremer facing left, surrounded by police officers and security agents. The A.P. incorrectly re-released the picture last week with him looking right.

title: What You Get for... $400,000
description: Sarasota, Fla.

title: Judge Upholds Right to Ban Metal Bats
description: In a case closely watched by baseball organizations and bat manufacturers across the country, a federal judge yesterday upheld a New York City law banning the use of metal bats in high school baseball games.

title: Medco to Acquire Diabetes Supplier
description: Medco Health Solutions, the biggest American manager of drug benefits, has agreed to buy PolyMedica, the largest supplier of glucose-testing supplies for patients with diabetes, for $1.3 billion, the companies announced yesterday.

title: The Shock Comes Back and Ousts the Liberty
description: AUBURN HILLS, Mich., Aug. 28  It has been a week of big comebacks in the W.N.B.A. playoffs, but the Liberty found itself on the wrong side of one Tuesday night, and it ended its season.

title: China: Communist Party to Meet Oct. 15
description: A major congress expected to produce a new Communist Party leadership team will open on Oct. 15, the state news media reported. The dates of the gathering, held just twice a decade, had been kept secret for months by President Hu Jintao and other top leaders. Mr. Hu, who is also chief of the party, is expected to use the congress to place allies in major leadership positions to solidify his grip on power.

title: Jersey City Landlords Prosper in New Yorks Shadow
description: Although a few companies in other industries have begun moving in, office real estate in Jersey City is still very much an annex of Wall Street. Since modern towers started springing up along its waterfront in the 1990s, its fortunes have usually risen and fallen with the ebbs and flows in the financial markets.

description: Government agencies, universities, and corporations frequently enroll patients in studies designed to test the effectiveness of new drugs, procedures and medical devices. Participants may benefit by gaining access to experimental therapies, and they make an important contribution to scientific research. description: Confronting a new diagnosis can be frightening  and because research changes so often, confusing. Here are some questions you may not think to ask your doctor, along with notes on why theyre important.

title: Astronauts Were Not Impaired for Missions, NASA Says
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29  A NASA investigation into astronauts use of alcohol before space missions has found no evidence of heavy drinking or drunkenness prior to launches, according to an agency report released today.

title: Ocean Grove: Clash Over Civil Unions
description: New Jersey is seeking to dismiss a lawsuit claiming that it is pressuring the Ocean Grove Camp Meeting Association into allowing civil unions at its boardwalk pavilion. The state argues in its motion, filed on Monday in Federal District Court in Trenton, that the federal courts are not the proper jurisdiction for the lawsuit. The association, a Methodist group, said in its lawsuit that the state was violating its First Amendment rights by pressuring it to allow the ceremonies. The New Jersey Division on Civil Rights is investigating two discrimination complaints from gay couples whose requests to use the pavilion, which the association owns, for civil union ceremonies were denied. The association filed a separate request with the court asking that the discrimination investigation be stopped. Compiled by John Sullivan

title: Selected Studies: Weight Loss and Obesity
description: Government agencies, universities, and corporations frequently enroll patients in studies designed to test the effectiveness of new drugs, procedures and medical devices. Participants may benefit by gaining access to experimental therapies, and they make an important contribution to scientific research. For more information, visit ClinicalTrials.gov, a service of the National Institutes of Health.

title: Doctor Accused of Sex Abuse May Face Additional Charges
description: BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Aug. 28  A New Jersey doctor facing charges that he sexually abused 10 women in his care may have abused more patients, an official who had been briefed on the case said on Tuesday.

title: Bush Sees Hope in New Orleans 2 Years After Storm
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29  President Bush toured New Orleans today, delivering a message of hope to a city devastated by wind and flood two years ago and still divided over the speed and effectiveness of federal help.

title: Queens: Boy on Bicycle Killed in Crash
description: A 12-year-old boy was killed yesterday afternoon in Springfield Gardens when he was hit by a box truck while riding his bicycle, the police said. The boy, who was not named yesterday pending family notification, was riding alongside the truck just before 1 p.m. near 130th Avenue and Springfield Boulevard when he was hit by the vehicle, the police said. He was pronounced dead at the scene. No charges were issued against the driver yesterday, the police said.

title: In Troubled District, School Starts With Enough Books but Not Enough Money
description: ROOSEVELT, N.Y., Aug. 22  Students returning to school here can expect to find some things they have learned to do without in the five years their district has been under state control: enough textbooks for everyone, correct class assignments, even toilet paper in the bathrooms.

title: Few Iraqis Reach Safe U.S. Havens Despite Program
description: BAGHDAD, Aug. 28  Despite a stepped-up commitment from the United States to take in Iraqis who are in danger because they worked for the American government and military, very few are signing up to go, resettlement officials say.

title: How to Eat (and Read) Close to Home
description: NO one would ever mistake Edible Brooklyn for Edible Atlanta, though both are quarterly food magazines that share a corporate parent and a typeface. But the story titles in the latest issue of the Brooklyn version might flummox Atlantans. There is, for example, Fresh Kills, about a live poultry market in Williamsburg, and Late Night Nosh, which is self-explanatory, at least in New York City.

title: Army Colonel Is Acquitted in Abu Ghraib Case
description: A military jury announced that an Army officer who was convicted of a lesser charge and acquitted of all others Tuesday in the Abu Ghraib prison scandal would receive a formal reprimand as his sentence.

title: A New Role, but for Her, Familiar Turf
description: Marcia V. Lyles, New York Citys new deputy chancellor for teaching and learning, knows intimately just how students can get lost in the shuffle. In her sophomore year in high school in Harlem, Ms. Lyles was caught skipping class almost daily.

title: Lawyer Quits Firm to Focus on Inquiry
description: William S. Lerach, a leading securities class-action lawyer who has been embroiled in a seven-year federal investigation into possible kickbacks to plaintiffs for their testimony, is retiring from his firm.

title: New Orleans Pauses to Remember Victims of Katrina
description: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 29  A day of mourning and remembrance for the victims of Hurricane Katrina began today with a solemn bell ringing at a cemetery at precisely 9:38 a.m., the moment when a key levee breached two years ago and devastated this Gulf Coast town.

title: Census Shows a Modest Rise in U.S. Income
description: The nations median household income grew modestly in 2006, the Census Bureau reported yesterday, even as the percentage of people without health insurance hit a high.

title: Taliban Will Release Hostages, South Korea Says
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 28  The Taliban agreed Tuesday to release 19 South Korean church volunteers held captive in Afghanistan since mid-July, the South Korean government announced, signaling an end to a wrenching hostage crisis that had gripped the country for almost six weeks.

title: The Limits of Willpower
description: Dr. Barry E. Levin, a neurologist at New Jersey Medical School, has been investigating the brain's role in obesity for more than 20 years. His recent findings suggest that exercise early in life may prevent obesity, even in people who have a genetic propensity to gain weight.

title: Three Former Champions Advance at Open
description: Svetlana Kuznetsova, Martina Hingis and Lleyton Hewitt  three former United States Open champions  easily advanced to the second round of the Open today.

title: Some Balk at Giuliani Role in 9/11 Ceremony
description: Each year since Sept. 11, 2001, Rudolph W. Giuliani has spoken at New York Citys commemorations of the attacks. At past ceremonies he has read off the names of some of the dead, given readings by Lincoln and Churchill, and recited poetry.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A picture on Friday with an article about an accident at the Deutsche Bank building in Lower Manhattan in which two firefighters were injured by a falling forklift carried an erroneous credit. The photograph, showing the demolition scene, was by Suzanne DeChillo of The New York Times, not by Cary Conover for The New York Times.

title: June Bingham Birge, Who Wrote Books and Plays, Dies at 88
description: June Bingham Birge, the author of books and plays, died on Aug. 21 at her home in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. She was 88.

title: Footnotes
description: A police log in Santa Monica, Calif., listed attempt suicide as the reason for officers response to a call from the home of the actor Owen Wilson, below, on Sunday, The Associated Press reported. The log did not indicate who made the call. Mr. Wilsons press representative, Ina Treciokas, declined yesterday to answer questions seeking to determine if Mr. Wilson, who was hospitalized, tried to kill himself. ... Bruce Springsteen and the E Street Band announced yesterday their first full-scale international tour since 2002-3. The 13-country journey begins in Hartford on Oct. 2, the release date for Mr. Springsteens album Magic, and ends in London on Dec. 19. Mr. Springsteen and the band are to perform at the Continental Airlines Arena in East Rutherford, N.J., on Oct. 9 and 10 and at Madison Square Garden on Oct. 17 and 18.

title: Panama: U.S. Backs Noriega Extradition
description: Manuel Antonio Noriega, the deposed Panamanian strongman who is ending a 15-year prison sentence in Miami, can be extradited to France, where he faces charges of money laundering and up to a decade in prison, a federal judge in Miami ruled. The decision by Magistrate Judge William C. Turnoff followed a decision last week by another federal judge that rejected an argument that Mr. Noriega, above, should be returned to Panama when his current term for drug trafficking and racketeering ends on Sept. 9. A lawyer for Mr. Noriega vowed to appeal. The final decision on whether Mr. Noriega, 73, can be extradited to France lies with Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice.

title: Governor Refuses Blame in 35 Hurricane Deaths
description: ST. FRANCISVILLE, La., Aug. 28  Gov. Kathleen Babineaux Blanco was summoned to a courtroom on Tuesday to testify in a homicide case over Hurricane Katrinas single biggest loss of life, and she refused to take blame for the deaths of 35 patients who drowned at a nursing home.

title: A Hidden Cause of Headache Pain
description: Four percent of Americans suffer headaches daily, and scientists have suspected culprits as diverse as undiagnosed jaw disorders, genetic susceptibility and stress. But according to recent research, a sizeable and growing number of headaches are being caused by the very medications taken to alleviate them  and the problem is far more common than scientists had realized. Half of chronic migraines, and as many as 25 percent of all headaches, are actually rebound episodes triggered by the overuse of common pain medications. Both prescription and over-the-counter drugs may be to blame.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day on Aug. 20 about the greeting card market referred imprecisely to the number of paper cards sold relative to online cards, and misattributed the statistic. The statement that the paper card market is five times as large as the e-card market applied to cards sold by one company, American Greetings, not the industry at large, and it should have been attributed to American Greetings  not the Greeting Card Association, a trade group.

title: Arrest Ordered for Russian Oil Entrepreneur, a Critic of the Kremlin
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 28  A Russian court issued an arrest warrant Tuesday for Mikhail S. Gutseriev, a former owner of Russneft, a large young oil company, on charges of tax evasion and fraud, a month after he published a letter critical of the government on a company Web site and in a Russian business newspaper.

title: A Saints Dark Night
description: THE stunning revelations contained in a new book, which show that Mother Teresa doubted Gods existence, will delight her detractors and confuse her admirers. Or is it the other way around?

title: Burning Man Is Torched
description: Flames early yesterday singed but did not consume the figure of the Burning Man looming atop a pavilion at the Burning Man counterculture arts festival in the Black Rock Desert of Nevada, The Reno Gazette-Journal reported. The fire, reported at 2:58 a.m., was extinguished in 23 minutes. Onlookers shouted save the man and cheered the firefighters. Paul Addis, 35, of San Francisco, was arrested on suspicion of arson and illegal possession of fireworks, according to the sheriffs department, The Associated Press reported. The official man-burning ceremony is scheduled for late Saturday.

title: G.O.P. Plans Early-Primary Penalties
description: The Republican National Committee plans to penalize at least five states holding early primaries, including New Hampshire and Florida, by refusing to seat at least half of their delegates at the national convention in 2008, a party official said yesterday.

title: Bloomberg Proposes Expanding Tax Credit to Fight Poverty
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28  Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg took his antipoverty message to a national stage on Tuesday, proposing an $8.5 billion expansion of the federal earned income tax credit to bring more poor people, especially men, into the work force.

title: New Remedies for an Everyday Complaint
description: Dr. Robert Kunkel has been a headache specialist at the Cleveland Clinic for more than 35 years. He is past president of the American Headache Society and the National Headache Foundation.

title: A Surplus of Treatment Options, Few of Them Good
description: Back pain is one of the most common medical complaints, so its no surprise that treatments for it have multiplied over the years. That ought to be good news; instead, many patients find that sudden back pain opens the door to a world of medical controversy. Virtually every pharmaceutical or surgical remedy has been challenged in recent years, and for all the money sufferers spend on doctor visits, hospital stays, procedures and drugs, studies clearly show that most people with back pain heal the old-fashioned way: on their own, slowly, without significant intervention.

title: Iraqi Cleric Halts Militia Activities for 6 Months
description: BAGHDAD, Aug. 29  The radical Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr on Wednesday said that he was suspending for six months his Mahdi Army militias operations, including attacks on American troops, only hours after his fighters waged running street battles with Iraqi government forces for control of Karbala, one of Iraqs holiest cities.

title: Two Hits, One Short and One Far, Beat the Mets
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 28  The momentum in this series smacked in front of the plate, kicked off a chunk of dirt and hugged the third-base foul line before coming to a halt beside the chalk. The Phillies, fooled by Tom Glavine through seven innings, tied the score in the eighth on Aaron Rowands swinging bunt that traveled about 30 feet.

title: Republicans Plan to Penalize States on Primaries
description: The Republican National Committee plans to penalize at least four states holding early primaries, including New Hampshire and Florida, by refusing to seat at least half their delegates at the partys national convention in 2008, a party official said Tuesday.

title: Pension Inquiry Scrutinizes Fees to a Hevesi Consultant
description: ALBANY, Aug. 28  State investigators have been scrutinizing fees paid to the political consultant Hank Morris by investment firms seeking business with the New York State pension fund, including $12.3 million the Carlyle Group paid to a firm that employed Mr. Morris, according to companies that have been contacted as part of the inquiry.

title: Damon Gets a Chance to Carry the Yankees
description: Johnny Damon tilted his head to the left as he trotted toward first base, a subtle gesture to try and help keep his fly ball down the right-field line in fair territory. It was not like Carlton Fisk waving his arms wildly to try and keep to keep his ball fair in the 1975 World Series. It was simply a head tilt.

title: Greek Government Faces Political Fallout From Fires
description: ATHENS, Aug. 28  The fires that tore omnivorously through scores of villages and olive groves here may now also be changing Greeces political landscape: the government of Prime Minister Kostas Karamanlis, facing national elections next month, came under increasing criticism Tuesday, not only over its handling of the fires but also over whether it intensified Greeks fears about who might be to blame.

title: Mussina to Lose His Spot in the Rotation, for Now
description: There are no games to waste in a race to the postseason, no time to let a proud veteran work through his problems with a playoff spot at stake. The Yankees delivered that point after last nights game, announcing that the rookie Ian Kennedy would replace Mike Mussina in the rotation, at least for now.

title: NBC Buys TV Group Overseas
description: NBC Universal announced yesterday the acquisition of a group of international cable television channels owned by Sparrowhawk Holdings of London, a deal that Jeff Zucker, the president and chief executive of NBC, said was the first sign of a strategic shift at the company.

title: Newark: Shooting Suspect Extradited
description: One of the six suspects accused of killing three people and wounding a fourth in a schoolyard shooting in Newark on Aug. 4 was extradited from Virginia to New Jersey yesterday, the authorities said. The suspect, a 16-year-old, will be held at a juvenile detention center and will likely appear for a hearing in family court next week, according to Paul M. Loriquet, a spokesman for the Essex County prosecutor. He was captured in Woodbridge, Va., on Aug. 18, barely an hour after the authorities arrested his half brother, Rodolfo Godinez, 24, in Maryland. Mr. Godinez is fighting his extradition to New Jersey. Investigators said the two half brothers are part of a group of six men and teenagers charged with murder, robbery, and other crimes in the attack of four youths who were at the playground that night.

title: Flood-Soaked Queens Blames Development, Lagging Sewers and Climate Change
description: For most of New York City, the flash flooding on the morning of Aug. 8 was brief, if breathtaking. But try telling that to Kathleen Conway of Woodside, Queens, whose son-in-law is busy ripping out the mold-grimed walls of her live-in basement before they crumble.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A report in the Metro Briefing column in some copies on Thursday, about the death of a 78-year-old Yonkers woman whose apartment was set on fire, included an erroneous given name from the police for the victim. She was Louise Paciarello, not Madeline.

title: Fears for Amy Winehouse
description: The father-in-law of the British singer Amy Winehouse urged her fans yesterday to boycott her music and said she should be ineligible for awards until she seeks treatment for drug addiction, the BBC reported. In an interview with BBC Radio 5 Live, Giles Fielder-Civil said that Ms. Winehouse, left, and her husband, Blake, Mr. Fielder-Civils son, would die without medical help. Perhaps it is time to stop buying records, he said. Its a possibility, to send that message. But Ms. Winehouses father, Mitch, said, It wont send any message to Amy at all, unfortunately, adding, If I thought it would, it would be a great idea. Mr. Fielder-Civil said he believed that Ms. Winehouse, a nominee for a Mercury Music Prize, an MTV Video Music Award and four Music of Black Origin (MOBO) Awards for her 2006 album Back to Black, had been using cocaine, crack cocaine and possibly heroin. His wife, Georgette, said she feared that her son and Ms. Winehouse would eventually die unless they received medical help. In a statement, officials of Island Records, Ms. Winehouses label, said, We have been doing everything we can to help with Amys personal problems over the past few weeks. Ms. Winehouse, who is to turn 24 on Sept. 14, was hospitalized this month for severe exhaustion and withdrew from concerts in the United States and Canada to address her health.

The driver of the third car, Alexey Bushuyev, 22, crashed to a halt nearby. His blood alcohol level tested at .11 percent, above the legal driving limit of .08 percent, prosecutors said. The manslaughter charges in the indictment carry a maximum penalty of 15 years in prison, prosecutors said. A lawyer for Mr. Bushuyev, Susan Kellman, said the charges were excessive. title: Hot Pants
description: A proposal before the Atlanta city council to criminalize the public wearing of low-riding, underwear-exposing pants is intriguing. (See tomorrows Thursday Styles section.) Lets turn back the hands of time. Lets construe a disorderly fashion with disorderly conduct. This has been done many times in history, and for a reminder, I turn to one of my favorite studies, Aileen Ribeiros Dress and Morality (Holmes & Meier Publishers: 1986). She cites Richard Steele, in The Spectator, from 1711: The most improper things we commit in the conduct of our lives, we are led into by the force of fashion. People who complain that there is nothing new in fashion are quite correct. Fashion has always offended someone. But I wonder whether the Atlanta council members who support the ban are appalled at the indecency of baggy pants or the fact that the look has been so lasting and pervasive in our culture.

title: Canada: Bombardier Posts Loss on Write-Off
description: Bombardier, the commercial aircraft maker, posted a quarterly loss after writing off its investment in the Metronet Rail subway unit in Britain. The results, however, topped analysts estimates. The net loss was $71 million, or 5 cents a share, in contrast to net income of $58 million, or 3 cents, a year earlier, Bombardier said. Sales in the second quarter, which ended July 31, rose 15 percent, to $4.04 billion. Metronet, the London Underground contractor in which Bombardier and four European companies were joint-venture partners, collapsed last month at a cost to Bombardier of $162 million in write-offs. Excluding the Metronet charge, profit at Bombardier, which is based in Montreal, rose 60 percent, to $91 million.

title: China: Earnings Decline 11% at Oil Producer
description: Cnooc, a Chinese offshore oil producer, said first-half profit declined 11 percent, less than analysts had expected, as the company reined in operating costs. Net income slid to 14.6 billion yuan ($1.9 billion) from 16.3 billion yuan a year earlier, the Beijing-based company said, reflecting lower average oil prices. Oil and gas production rose to the equivalent of about 467,000 barrels of oil a day, Cnooc said. Oil and gas sales fell 6.4 percent, to 33.2 billion yuan. The average price Cnooc received for its oil fell 5.8 percent, to $58.80 a barrel. Gas prices gained 1.3 percent.
