title: Keith Richards Replies to Swedish Critics
description: The Rolling Stones guitarist Keith Richards, right, demanded an apology from Swedish newspapers for their disparaging reviews of the bands performance in their country this month, The Associated Press reported. This is a first!, Mr. Richards wrote in a letter published by the newspaper Dagens Nyheter. Never before have I risen to the bait of a bad review. But, he said, he was standing up for our fans all over Sweden and wanted to say that you owe them, and us, an apology. He said: Write the truth. It was a good show. The newspapers Expressen and Aftonbladet gave negative assessments of the show on Aug. 3 at Ullevi Stadium in Goteborg. Expressen suggested that Mr. Richards, 63, was superdrunk onstage, and Markus Larsson, Aftonbladets music writer, gave the concert a score of two on a five-point scale and said Mr. Richards appeared a bit confused. Mr. Larsson, writing yesterday in the newspapers online edition, said: It is Keith who should apologize. After all, it costs around $145, he pointed out, to see a rock star who can hardly handle the riff to Brown Sugar anymore.

title: Queens: Dogs Sniff Out DVDs

Brown, the Queens district attorney, said yesterday. Mr. Brown said the dogs were trained to smell chemicals used in making the discs.

title: All the Right Moves

Despite its perpetual need for money, it always seemed to be one of the many struggling arts organizations that somehow manage to survive.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29  The Federal Bureau of Investigation is looking into a spate of bomb threats phoned in to businesses in a dozen states that resulted in employees wiring thousands of dollars overseas.

title: Continuing Myanmar Protests Defy Junta
description: BANGKOK, Aug. 30  Linking arms for mutual support, grim in the face of plainclothes paramilitary gangs, small groups of protesters in Myanmar have staged street demonstrations for nearly two weeks in the most sustained defiance of the countrys ruling junta in a decade.

title: Muscle Strain Keeps Ramrez Out
description: Manny Ramrez had a strained left oblique muscle, so he did not play for the Boston Red Sox last night, and he will probably miss several games. Ramrez was not even available to pinch-hit as Mariano Rivera rumbled through the likes of Eric Hinske in the ninth inning and the Yankees won, 4-3.

title: Not All HDTVs Can Keep Up With the Action
description: Sit for the first time in front of a high-definition TV tuned to a nature program broadcast in HD, and the reaction is almost always the same: a dropping of the jaw. But if youre a sports fan or serious video gamer, the same set showing the Super Bowl or a car-racing game might elicit a different response: the screen cannot keep up with the action.

title: Commemorations for a City 2 Years After Storm
description: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 29  This city remembered Hurricane Katrinas second anniversary Wednesday with sadness, hurt and flashes of anger over a recovery that has returned it to only a portion of its former self.

title: Idaho Senators Colleagues Say He Should Resign
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29  The political career of Senator Larry E. Craig of Idaho appeared to be collapsing Wednesday as fellow Republicans called for his resignation and party leaders ousted him from his committee leadership posts amid the fallout over his arrest in a mens room and his guilty plea in the case.

title: Hurricanes and Profits (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: In Kennedy, Yankees See Familiar Approach
description: Mike Mussina was the 20th overall pick in the 1990 draft. He was a polished pitcher from the Pacific-10 Conference, and he was in the major leagues for the Baltimore Orioles by the end of the following season.

title: Arthur Jones, 80, Exercise Machine Inventor, Dies
description: Arthur Jones, a wild-animal enthusiast, filmmaker and entrepreneur whose Nautilus fitness machines helped to transform the fitness industry and the way ordinary people exercise, died on Tuesday at his home in Ocala, Fla. He was 80.

title: Boy, 9, Is Held in Death of Toddler at Day Care Center
description: A 9-year-old boy was accused yesterday of repeatedly beating a toddler in the head at a day care center being run in a private home in Woodbridge, N.J., eventually causing his death, the authorities said.

title: Trotting on Their Own Four Hooves
description: RALPH LAUREN was lying on the grass in the late afternoon sun, eyeing the willowy teenage girls, flushed from humidity, cantering their steeds. Clad in an orange Polo shirt, Ralph  the Yorkie, not the noted designer  was but one of many preppy attendees of the Hampton Classic horse show, where it actually feels appropriate for a dog to wear a collared shirt rather than a collar.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A picture caption in some copies yesterday with a sports article about the Yankees 5-3 victory over the Red Sox referred incorrectly to Derek Jeters fifth-inning home run. It was a solo home run, not a two-run homer.

title: See Jane Run. See Her Run Faster and Faster.
description: ONE day, about two years ago, my son asked me a probing question. Are you running just to run, he asked, or do you have some purpose in mind? Id been running for years but never thought to ask myself why. His question made me realize I wanted a goal. And it led me to pick one that now sounds kind of ludicrous, a five-kilometer race that was to be run in two weeks.

title: Investors Buy Stake in Global Hyatt
description: The Global Hyatt Corporation, the hotel company controlled by the Pritzker family of Chicago, said yesterday that it would sell a minority stake to a group of investors, including Goldman Sachs Capital Partners, for $1 billion.

title: Nokia to Introduce Digital Music Service
description: LONDON, Aug. 29  In the same converted 19th-century fish market where Apple announced the European introduction of its iTunes music store three years ago, Nokia said on Wednesday that it would soon introduce its own digital music service, along with an easier-to-use Apple-style mobile interface and an Apple-style touchscreen handset.

title: Iran Expanding Its Nuclear Program, Agency Reports
description: VIENNA, Aug. 30  Iran is expanding its nuclear program in defiance of United Nations resolutions, even as it has promised to answer questions about an array of suspicious nuclear activities in the past, the International Atomic Energy Agency said Thursday.

title: Marquee Opener Is Not a Sign of Things to Come
description: After California traveled to Knoxville to kick off last season and fell behind Tennessee, 35-0, in the third quarter of a humiliating loss, the Bears and the Pacific-10 Conference spent the rest of the season dealing with the repercussions.

title: Eagles to Use Backups as McNabb Gets Night Off
description: With Donovan McNabb ready for the regular season, the Philadelphia Eagles will play their backup quarterbacks tonight against the Jets.

title: It Wouldnt Be Opera Without an Outrage
description: BAYREUTH, Germany, Aug. 29   Every opera season demands a scene-chewing scandal to feed fans appetites for outsize drama, and this summer that niche has been filled in Europe by the new production here of Wagners Meistersinger. Tuesday was its final performance, and it was a mess, as advertised, but at least it was a diverting mess.

title: Synching Pearl to PC
description: Q. I bought a BlackBerry Pearl phone because I was told I could have an organizer and a cellphone in one device. Is there a way to synchronize it with my computer so that I can enter the information onto the computer instead of typing it in on the BlackBerry?

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Friday about political contributions by Silicon Valley executives omitted the name of one presidential candidate who recently visited Googles headquarters in Mountain View, Calif., and erroneously included another candidate. John Edwards spoke there; Barack Obama did not. The article also referred imprecisely to contributions from Google employees to Ron Paul, another candidate. Mr. Paul received $3,550 in employee contributions before he visited on July 13, not after.

title: Ramrez Out With a Muscle Strain
description: Manny Ramrez was not in the starting lineup for the Boston Red Sox last night because of a strained left oblique muscle, and it is possible that he will miss several days with the injury.

title: White House Is Gaining Confidence It Can Win Fight in Congress Over Iraq Policy
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29  The White House is growing more confident that it can beat back efforts by Congressional Democrats to shift course in Iraq, a significant turnabout from two months ago, when a string of Republican defections had administration officials worried that President Bushs troop buildup was in serious danger on Capitol Hill.

title: From an 1890s Renovation to an 1860s One
description: DARROLD ENDRES and his wife, Janet Fritz, pitied Litchfield House long before the state let them take it over. In the early 1990s, they would take breaks from restoring their 1890s farmhouse in the Boston suburb of Billerica by hiking in the forest at Great Brook Farm State Park in nearby Carlisle, Mass. Whenever they walked past an empty 1860s farmstead on the grounds, they peered in.

title: Between the Lines, Its Still a Game
description: This Saturday, the slap-happy band of analysts for ESPNs College GameDay will take their traveling road show to Blacksburg, Va. Ordinarily, the quartet of Desmond Howard, Kirk Herbstreit, Chris Fowler and Lee Corso mug for the gathered crowd of college students, make outlandish statements meant to provoke debate and throw it to a commercial. This time, however, theyll have their solemn television faces on.

title: Va. Tech President Defends Reaction to Shootings
description: RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 30  A day after a scathing state report criticized Virginia Techs actions before and after the shooting massacre in April, Charles W. Steger, the university president, defended his administrations actions today and said he had no plans to resign.

title: Lottery Numbers
Correction
description: A recent Op-Ed article about the execution of Nicola Sacco and Bartolomeo Vanzetti described the original charges against the two men incorrectly. The charges did not include possession of subversive pamphlets. And Sacco and Vanzetti faced only one trial together, not three.

title: Correction
description: An earlier version of this article paraphrased incorrectly from a comment Senator Obama made to the convention about protests at military funerals. He said: When men and women who died in service to this country are laid to rest, there must be no protests near the funerals. Its wrong and it needs to stop. He did not say that it was wrong for anti-war activists to protest at military funerals.

title: When Man in Black Was Just Johnny
description: Of all the music-related memoirs due this fall, Vivian Cashs is liable to be the most surprising. With abundant evidence to make her case, Ms. Cash, the first wife of Johnny Cash, explains how her role in his life was expunged by the mythology that sprung up around him. Her book, put together with the help of Ann Sharpsteen, vehemently corrects the impression created by people of the Nashville mind-set, who prefer that I be written out of Johnnys history altogether.

title: Older Doughnut Lovers Revolt in Putnam County
description: MAHOPAC, N.Y., Aug. 28  Joe Hajkowski, a 75-year-old retired sprinkler fitter who lives in nearby Putnam Valley, is a man on a mission: to reinstate the free doughnuts at the day center for older people here that he visits regularly.

title: Paternal Penguins Pique Parents
description: An award-winning childrens book based on the true story of two male penguins who reared a baby penguin stands atop the American Library Associations annual list of works that drew the most complaints from parents, library patrons and others, The Associated Press reported. Published in 2005, the book, And Tango Makes Three, by Justin Richardson and Peter Parnell, with illustrations by Henry Cole (Simon & Schuster), was named one of that years best by the association. But some parents and educators complained that it advocated homosexuality. In all, the number of books challenged last year was 546, compared with 406 in 2005, but low in contrast to the figures recorded in the mid-1990s, when challenges exceeded 750 a year. The American Library Association defines a challenge as a formal, written complaint filed with a library or school requesting that materials be removed because of content or appropriateness. Other books on the 2006 list included the Nobel Laureate Toni Morrisons Bluest Eye and her Pulitzer Prize-winning Beloved, both challenged for language and sexual content. Judith Krug, director of the associations Office for Intellectual Freedom, said 30 books were banned last year.

title: Gonzales Faces Inquiry Into Veracity of His Testimony
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30  The Justice Departments internal watchdog disclosed today that he was investigating whether sworn statements to Congress by Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales were intentionally false, misleading or inappropriate.

title: Changelings Passing Like Blips in the Night
description: How to describe States & Resemblance? Two men dressed only in dance belts began the half-hour piece on Tuesday night by darting amid an audience reclining on a patch of grass, waiting for a screening of The Apartment to begin. The action then moved a little south to another part of Elevated Acre, a rooftop park overlooking the East River in Lower Manhattan. A woman in plain Korean shaman dress gently swayed beside the path and then disappeared into a stand of tall reeds.

title: A Polarizing Bush Despite a New Cast
description: Alberto R. Gonzales, the polarizing attorney general, is going, and Karl Rove, the polarizing political adviser, is on the way out.

title: Circuits: Make Your Mark in Photography With an Assist From a Printer
description: Forward-thinking graffiti artists may wish to try their designs on Hewlett-Packards $249 A826 Home Photo Center, which will reach store shelves in the first weeks of September.

title: Iranians Seized in Baghdad Freed by U.S. After a Day
description: BAGHDAD, Aug. 29  Members of an Iranian Energy Ministry delegation visiting Baghdad at the invitation of the Iraqi government were released Wednesday, a day after being arrested at their hotel by American troops and led away in handcuffs and blindfolds.

title: Brooklyn: Man Accused in Shooting
description: A Brooklyn man was charged yesterday with fatally shooting another man near Prospect Park last week, the police said. The police said that the suspect, Tony Canales, 26, shot Antonio Bruce, 25, of Stanley Avenue about 11:20 p.m. on Aug. 22. Mr. Bruce was shot once in the abdomen on Parkside Avenue, the police said. Mr. Canales was charged with murder.

title: Botero Gives Abu Ghraib Art to Berkeley
description: The Colombian artist Fernando Botero, right, has donated 25 paintings and 22 drawings inspired by the abuse of Iraqis imprisoned at Abu Ghraib to the University of California, Berkeley, Agence France-Presse reported. The gift, valued at $10 million to $15 million, will be housed at the universitys art museum, said Kathleen Maclay, a Berkeley spokeswoman. She said final details of the gift were being worked out. The art, a sharp departure from Mr. Boteros familiar images of corpulent figures, was based on photographs and testimony of the detainees. One painting depicts a prisoner face to face with a snarling dog; others show naked and beaten Iraqis in heaps on cell floors. The art toured Europe in 2005, was displayed at Berkeley this year and is now on view in Milan in a Botero retrospective. Although his works regularly sell at auction for $1 million or $2 million, he has said that this series is not for sale and should have a home in the United States or Baghdad. ... Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore has acquired nearly 6,000 books, photographs and letters by and about the curmudgeonly journalist H. L. Mencken from the estate of George H. Thompson, an accountant who collected the material from 1962 until his death last year, The Associated Press reported.

title: Guidelines Are Issued on Asthma and Youths
description: Children ages 5 to 11 with asthma require different treatment than do adults, guidelines issued yesterday by the National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute say.

title: Not the Killer, but Still Facing a Date With the Executioner
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 29  Kenneth Foster has a date on Thursday with the executioners needle. Not for killing anyone himself, but for what he was doing  and might have been thinking  the night in 1996 when he was 19 and a sidekick gunned down a San Antonio law student.

title: Hilly Kristal, 75, Catalyst for Punk at CBGB, Dies
description: Hilly Kristal, who founded CBGB, the Bowery bar that became the cradle of New York punk and art-rock in the 1970s and was the inspiration for musician-friendly rock dives around the world, died in Manhattan on Tuesday. He was 75.

title: Mens Room Chronicles
description: It is time for Republicans to start asking themselves whether theres something about ceremonial leadership positions that causes their colleagues to collapse under stress.

title: Traveling With a Birds-Eye View
description: To see nature with a dose of adrenaline, consider a zip-line canopy tour, an increasingly popular adventure activity held at tree-top heights. From Africa to Alaska, thrill-seekers harness themselves to cables and slide from one tree stand to another, often for less than 20 seconds between stops, braking with a gloved hand. An entire canopy tour, sometimes coupled with hiking or other activities, can last up to four hours. Now with global appeal, canopy tours got their commercial foothold in Costa Rica, where its estimated that 25 percent of visitors see the rainforest hanging from zip lines. More than 1 million people have participated in the Original Canopy Tour, a Costa Rica-based outfitter that also has operations in Belize, Nicaragua, and Mexico, among other places. Injuries are rare, and prices are usually less than $100 even in the most exotic locales, so set aside your fear of heights and view forests in a whole new way.

title: Yahoos New President Oversees a Shake-Up
description: Susan L. Decker, Yahoos new president, is putting her stamp on the company in a reorganization of its management ranks that creates a new division responsible for generating the bulk of the companys revenue.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Tuesday about the toll taken on Greece by the recent fires gave an incorrect location for the town of Zaharo. As the accompanying map showed, it is on the Ionian Sea, not the Aegean.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: The Saturday Interview column in Business Day last week, about the market for green fashions, carried incorrect information in a quotation from George Feldenkreis, chairman of Perry Ellis International, about the amount of pesticide required to produce one T-shirt. About 0.038 ounces of pesticide are required, not three pounds.

title: Room to Improve
description: Q. Can I decorate walls with texture instead of color?

title: Houses Still Looking for Resident Curators
description: FOR those who think they might have what it takes to be resident curators, at least 26 houses are available in Delaware, Maryland and Massachusetts.

title: Coming Attractions From P.S. 122
description: Performance Space 122 announced its fall season, and as is often the case with its shows, which combine theater, music, dance, art and multimedia, many works are hard to explain. The season includes medEia, a modern version of Medea by the Dutch theater company Dood Paard, and The International Show, a theater-and-video piece inspired by the work of a German Beat poet that is a collaboration between Iver Findlay, a founder of the Collapsable Giraffe theater company; the playwright and director Young Jean Lee; and others. The lineup culminates with the American premiere of Cest Duckie!, the Olivier Award-winning hit in London, a nightclubcabaret-vaudeville-balloon-art burlesque show in which audience members, who are requested to honor a dress code of swanky evening, order their own tabletop performances.

title: At the Open, Night Sessions Can Be Electric
description: Almost every night of the United States Open, under the bright lights of Arthur Ashe Stadium, a few seemingly lucky professional tennis players showcase their talent in the most hyped events of the day. But behind the scenes of the glitz and glamour, as with any New York production, there is more work to be done than most fans could imagine.

title: Judge Orders a Web Site Selling Tax-Evasion Advice to Close
description: A Web site that sells materials stating that individuals can legally stop paying taxes has been shut on the order of a federal judge.

title: Stress Rates High for 9/11 Workers
description: One of every eight rescue and recovery workers from the World Trade Center site showed signs of post-traumatic stress disorder when they were interviewed in 2003 and 2004, the citys Department of Health and Mental Hygiene reported yesterday.

title: U.S. Weapons, Given to Iraqis, Move to Turkey
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29  Weapons that were originally given to Iraqi security forces by the American military have been recovered over the past year by the authorities in Turkey after being used in violent crimes in that country, Pentagon officials said Wednesday.

title: Jeepers! Peepers in New York
description: In the list of wrongs that needed righting, the subway peeper is probably not too high on the average New Yorkers anxiety list. Still, City Councilman Peter Vallone Jr. of Queens thinks it is time to make something he calls nonconsensual voyeurism illegal.

title: Have Dog Will Travel at the Open
description: The chic tan carryall that Venus Williams slung over her left shoulder as she left the interview room at the United States Open yesterday carried something more precious to her than cash, Cartier baubles or rackets.

title: Later Sex and Health Risks (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Whats on Tonight
description: 10 P.M. (MTV) CELEBRITY RAP SUPERSTAR Eight celebrities go mouth to mouth under the tutelage of some of the hip-hop worlds best-known rappers. Big Boi, DMC and Da Brat will judge the contestants each week, after which viewers will provide feedback; both count toward the overall score. The aspiring rappers are the blogger Perez Hilton; the aging rocker Sebastian Bach; Hugh Hefners playmate Kendra Wilkinson; the actors Shar Jackson, Efren Ramirez, Countess Vaughn and Jason Wahler; and the former National Football League player Jamal Anderson. Their tutors include Redman, Warren G, Too Short, Bubba Sparxxx, Bizarre, MC Lyte and Tone Loc, above left, with Mr. Hilton. Kevin Hart is host.

title: Brother Defends Fire Captain Disciplined After Blaze
description: A fire captain who was reassigned for having failed to inspect the former Deutsche Bank building before this months fatal fire was following a department policy that recognized the risk of sending firefighters into the contaminated building, the captains brother said yesterday.

title: Martnez to Audition for Mets Brain Trust
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 29  Get your T-shirts now: The Pedro Martnez Reunion Tour will make a one-time stop in Atlanta on Friday so that he can throw his between-starts bullpen session in front of some very interested Mets coaches and officials.

title: Taliban Release 12 of 19 Hostages From South Korea
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Aug. 29  Bringing a six-week hostage ordeal closer to an end, the Taliban released 12 of 19 remaining Korean hostages on Wednesday. The seven still in Taliban custody were widely expected to be released Thursday.

title: Threat Seen in History of Demolition
description: In the fall of 2005, the planned demolition of the former Deutsche Bank headquarters finally seemed to have gotten back on track.

title: For a Talented Red Sox Rookie, Its a Walk to the Park
description: Dustin Pedroia lives about 20 yards from Fenway Park, so he may have the easiest commute in Boston, a city of more than half a million people. Pedroias walk from the Red Sox clubhouse to his position at second base is actually longer than his one-minute commute.

title: Wariness Urged in Using Credit Cards for Medical Bills
description: Although special financing plans for health care carry risks, using regular credit cards to pay medical bills may be even more dangerous to household finances.

title: No Evidence of Drunken Astronauts, NASA Says
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29  An internal investigation has found no evidence of heavy drinking or drunkenness among astronauts before space missions, NASA officials said Wednesday.

title: Pakistan Leader Says Deal Not Set
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Aug. 30  The exiled former prime minister Benazir Bhutto said Wednesday that Pakistans president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, had agreed to resign as army chief as part of a nearly completed deal that would allow him to serve another term as president if he is re-elected and allow her to return to Pakistan to run for prime minister.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An obituary on Aug. 12 about Moe Fishman, a veteran of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade, Americans who fought in the Spanish Civil War, referred incorrectly to his high school education. He was a graduate of Stuyvesant High School in Manhattan; he did not drop out. (He later dropped out of City College, primarily for financial reasons.)

title: Abu Ghraib Swept Under the Carpet
description: We would have been hard pressed to think of a more sadly suitable coda to the Bush administrations mishandling of the Abu Ghraib nightmare than Tuesdays verdict in the court-martial of the only officer to be tried for the abuse, sexual assault and torture of prisoners that occurred there in 2003.

title: The Independent Woman Who Became a Victim at the End of a Rural Road
description: Until last year, Betty Jane Dehart, 81, a retired seamstress in Greencastle, Pa., drove a 23-year-old Mercury of questionable reliability. Then her daughter and her son-in-law bought her a new Hyundai.

title: Bottled Blondes, You Too Can Break Free
description: IN an image-obsessed culture predominated by bottled blondes and man-made brunettes, a naturally gray-haired woman can be made to feel that she stands out like dandruff on a dark sweater.

title: A Popular Womens Champion, and a Player Trying to Get There
description: Their matches were separated by a few hundred yards last night, but the gap between Serena Williams and Ahsha Rolle might as well be measured in light-years.

title: Early 1800s Farm Life in Maryland, but Grander
description: GALE JOHNSON is a bridal shop owner turned interior decorator and self-described perfectionist, and her husband, T. J., is a retired Air Force flight engineer turned historic preservation projects manager specializing in federal buildings. Theyre both highly focused on keeping chaos at bay, or trying to.

title: Mending a Bruised Image
description: In one spot, a father sits on the sofa with his young children, reading to them from a large book while a daughter nestles her head on his neck.

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column in Business Day yesterday, about animal rights groups promoting vegetarianism as a way to curb greenhouse gases, misstated the annual budget of Vegan Outreach, a nonprofit group that has campaigned on the issue. It is $500,000, not $5 million. (Go to Article)

title: A Top Executive Resigns at Delta
description: The chief operating officer at Delta Air Lines, James M. Whitehurst, resigned yesterday, a week after being passed over for promotion to the top post.

title: Baseballs Stretch Run
description: This years chase for the eight playoff spots in baseball is the tightest in recent memory. The wild-card system, first used in 1995, has made September baseball exciting for more cities, but does the current system provide adequate compensation for the team that finishes with the best record in each league?

title: Chrysler Operated at a Loss in Its Final Quarter as a Part of Daimler
description: AUBURN HILLS, Mich., Aug. 29  Chrysler lost money in the second quarter, its last under the wing of the German automaker DaimlerChrysler, its former parent said Wednesday.

title: The Mayor Wants Tourists to Be Welcomed. Hospitably.
description: New Yorkers no longer pride themselves on being masters of the brusque brushoff, or so Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg would have visitors believe.

title: How to Increase Savings (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Group Fined by F.E.C. for Campaign Violations
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29  A Democratic-leaning voter turnout group agreed to pay a $775,000 penalty for violating federal rules during the 2004 election, the Federal Election Commission announced Wednesday.

title: River Watchers, Tackling Speeders and Thin Budgets
description: OLD SAYBROOK, Conn., Aug. 25  Barreling down the river in his Sea Ray yacht, a dozen sailboats bobbing and writhing violently in its wake, an out-of-state boater chose the wrong day to speed by Saybrook Point.

title: Organic Dairy Agrees to Alter Some Practices
description: A huge Colorado organic dairy agreed yesterday to stop applying the organic label to some of its milk and make major changes in its operation after the Department of Agriculture threatened to revoke its organic certification for, among other problems, failing to provide enough pasture to its cows.

title: Doctors Offering No-Interest Loans to Patients
Sadr Suspends His Militias Military Operations
description: BAGHDAD, Aug. 29  The radical Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr said Wednesday that he was suspending for six months his Mahdi Army militias operations, including attacks on American troops, only hours after his fighters waged running street battles with Iraqi government forces for control of Karbala, one of Iraqs holiest cities.

title: Man Sentenced to Death Wins a Reprieve
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 30  Hours before his scheduled execution as a disputed accomplice in a 1996 murder, Kenneth Foster won a rare commutation to life in prison today after Gov. Rick Perry followed the recommendation of his Board of Pardons and Paroles and granted a death row reprieve.

title: The Care of Diabetics (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: After Clashes, Curfew Is Set in Taj Mahal Area
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 29  The police imposed a curfew in the northern Indian city of Agra, home to the countrys most popular tourist attraction, the Taj Mahal, after a fatal road accident early Wednesday morning fueled violent clashes on the streets.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Keith Richards Replies to Swedish Critics

title: Fate of the Cosmos (and of a Studio) Hangs in the Balance
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 29  Not since Dorothy landed on the witch has a young girl shouldered quite so many worries as 12-year-old Lyra Belacqua.

title: First Job? Share the Bounty
description: NORTH HAVEN, N.Y.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An obituary on Aug. 16 about the composer and cabaret entertainer John Wallowitch misidentified the label on which one of his albums, Wallowitch and Ross, appeared. It was Miranda Music  not Original Cast Records, which was one of the distributors.

title: Brooklyn: Prisoner Escapes, Briefly
description: A prisoner who was being treated at a hospital escaped by crashing through a plate-glass window early yesterday morning, the police said. The suspect, Gregory Pollock, 46, was arrested for possession of a controlled substance and resisting arrest. The police said that Mr. Pollock was being treated at Long Island College Hospital in Cobble Hill at 1:40 a.m. for reasons the police did not specify when he assaulted an officer and ran off, crashing through the window. He was captured about two hours later, five miles away, in Brownsville. The officer guarding Mr. Pollock will not face any disciplinary action, said Officer Martin Speechley, a Police Department spokesman. He was the third prisoner to escape in the last week. Maxie Dacosta Jr., 27, a murder suspect, leaped from a third-floor window of the 103rd Precinct station house in Jamaica, Queens, last Thursday. Ezekiel Edwards, 17, facing attempted robbery charges, escaped early on Friday after he slipped out of his handcuffs and squeezed through a window at the 77th Precinct station house in Crown Heights. Both are still at large. Mr. Pollock faces two new charges: assault and escape.

title: Locked, Loaded and Looney
description: As the Armys suicide rate hits record levels in the Iraq war, theres small wonder practically everyone in Congress wants to deal with the parallel emerging crisis of depressed veterans tempted to take their own lives. Everyone, that is, except Senator Tom Coburn, Republican of Oklahoma. He stands alone in blocking final passage of a suicide prevention bill in fear that the governments record-keeping on troubled vets might somehow crimp their ability to purchase handguns.

title: Gaza: Israeli Gunfire Kills 3 Children
description: A 10-year-old Palestinian girl and two boys, 10 and 12, were killed by Israeli fire in northern Gaza. In a statement, the Israeli Army said that it had fired at rocket launchers in the area. Separately, the Israeli deputy prime minister, Haim Ramon, said that Israel had offered several months ago to release 450 Palestinian prisoners in exchange for Cpl. Gilad Shalit, the Israeli soldier seized in June 2006 during a Hamas-led raid inside Israel but that the Egyptian-brokered talks broke down because of disagreement over which prisoners would be released. At an event for Corporal Shalits 21st birthday on Monday, his father, Noam, accused Israeli leaders of a clear and utter failure of the system in his sons case.

title: Circuits: Keeping Pocket-Size Data Under Lock and Key
description: Most U.S.B. drives are tiny enough for toting data anywhere  but are also small enough to lose easily. Armed with a set of buttons on its case, the Flash Padlock U.S.B. drive from Corsair puts a hardware lock on the pocket data vault by requiring the user to punch in a code to see the stored files when the drive is connected to a computer.

title: An Investor Activism Uncommon in Japan
description: TOKYO, Aug. 29  Tomomi Yano was an unlikely maverick. When the unassuming Mr. Yano became head of investment at one of Japans biggest pension funds in 2001, corporate executives here assumed that he was simply another former bureaucrat parachuting into semiretirement. Japans vast government-run pension system, the reasoning went, would provide a comfortable nest after his 31 years at the labor ministry.

title: After 10 Years, Fascination With Diana Hardly Fades
description: LONDON, Aug. 29  Ten years have passed since Diana, Princess of Wales, died and Britain erupted in a febrile convulsion of grief and anger, but in some ways you would hardly know it.

title: Disneys Musical No. 1
description: Despite a decline of 40 percent in sales, the soundtrack for Disneys High School Musical 2 remained at the head of the Billboard class for a second week last week, chalking up sales of 367,000 copies in the United States, Nielsen SoundScan reported. Second place went to the rapper Talib Kweli on sales of 60,000 copies of his album Ear Drum (Blacksmith Music/Warner Brothers). The two-disc Miley Cyrus set Hannah Montana 2: Meet Miley Cyrus, another Disney release, fell to third place from second, with 58,000 copies sold. Yet another soundtrack, Hairspray (New Line), climbed to fourth from fifth on 53,000 sales, changing places with Vol. 25 in the Now Thats What I Call Music! series, with sales of 52,000 copies.

title: Clinton Donor Under a Cloud in Fraud Case
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons campaign said yesterday that it would give to charity $23,000 it had received from a prominent Democratic donor, and review thousands of dollars more that he had raised, after learning that the authorities in California had a warrant for his arrest stemming from a 1991 fraud case.

title: Marines Trials in Iraq Killings Are Withering
description: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., Aug. 29  Last December, when the Marine Corps charged four infantrymen with killing Iraqi civilians in Haditha, Iraq, in 2005, the allegation was as dark as it was devastating: after a roadside bomb had killed their buddy, a group of marines rampaged through nearby homes, massacring 24 innocent people.

title: A Hobbled Nadal Struggles Through Round 1
description: Second-seeded Rafael Nadal struggled with knee trouble and an unheralded first-round opponent before defeating 123rd-ranked Alun Jones, 7-5, 3-6, 6-4, 6-1, Tuesday afternoon at the United States Open. After the match at Ashe Stadium, Nadal told the crowd that he hoped to be 100 percent for his second-round match on Friday. He was anything but against Jones, who had 4-1 leads in each of the first two sets.

title: For Rutgers and Schiano, the Future Is Now
description: What was once unimaginable will be a reality tonight when Rutgers kicks off its season at home against Buffalo. The Scarlet Knights are a ranked team (No. 16) and a double-digit favorite, they have a Heisman Trophy contender and will be playing before a packed stadium that will be sold out for every game this season.

title: No Time for Threats
description: French President Nicolas Sarkozy made the wrong gesture at the wrong time by brandishing the possible use of force against Irans nuclear weapons program in his first major foreign policy address. The United States and its allies need to be stepping up their efforts to resolve the serious dangers posed by Iran through comprehensive negotiations and increased international economic pressure, not by talking about military action.

title: Vistas and Close-Ups, Staged by a Filmmaker
description: PAWLING, N.Y.

title: A Camera for Generation Z
description: For the first decade of the digital camera revolution, most manufacturers dangled only one carrot in front of prospective buyers: more megapixels. You felt inferior if your camera took 3-megapixel photos when the latest models had 5.

title: Airport Scrutiny of Headgear Raises Bias Claims From Sikhs
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29  A new federal policy that subjects travelers who wear any type of head covering to possible additional screening at airport checkpoints has prompted vociferous protests from Sikh organizations, who say they are being singled out for ethnic profiling.

title: Neither Arenas Nor Dives, New Clubs Hope to Succeed With More Style
description: Its the kind of thing you might expect to see in a multimillion-dollar concert hall in Berlin or Los Angeles, not in a rock club in a former mayonnaise plant in Brooklyn: a sloped ceiling incorporating sophisticated acoustical design, made up of eight curved segments that are suspended from the roof on rubber mounts.

title: Knowledge Is Priceless but Textbooks Are Not
description: MY 18-year-old daughter recently perfected a new technique to avoid the stress of packing for college.

title: A New Stage for Arthur Millers Most Private Drama of Fathers and Sons
description: It had been something of an open secret for years, but most people did not learn the story of Daniel Miller until last week, when Vanity Fair published an article called Arthur Millers Missing Act.

title: Taliban Free Remaining Koreans
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Aug. 30 The Taliban freed the seven remaining South Korean missionaries it was holding hostage in Central Afghanistan this evening, Afghan officials announced. All of the hostages appeared to be in good condition.

title: From Video Highlight to Bench Jockey
description: Every college athlete needs to make adjustments after arriving from high school. At least West Virginias Noel Devine gets to learn from one of the best. Devine, the small running back known for his spectacular plays that became must-view fare online, starts his college football career on Saturday playing behind Steve Slaton, who, after rushing for more than 1,700 yards last year is considered a top contender for the Heisman Trophy. Hes like a big brother to me, Devine says of Slaton, who the coaches asked to mentor Devine on and off of the field. Devine is also competing for the slot of second-string running back with Jock Sanders, another true freshman. Its a challenge, he says, that makes you know that you cant slack on the job.

title: School Syllabus, Independent Style
description: WHEN I was a kid, back-to-school shopping meant my mother would take me to a department store wherever we were living during my peripatetic childhood and some man would put a measuring tape in places I felt were inappropriate. But, they explained, we needed an inseam measurement. Plus, I was a chubby kid, so the whole thing was embarrassing, with Mom and Mr. Inseam poking their heads into the dressing room at the crucial moment of sweaty tugging and twisting before the garment was actually affixed onto my body in the proper position.

title: Cigars Go Hundreds of Miles While Store Moves Hundreds of Feet
description: Fewer than 140 paces separate the former Nat Sherman cigar store, in a Fifth Avenue skyscraper, from what will be its new location on East 42nd Street.

title: Richard Jewell, 44, Hero of Atlanta Attack, Dies
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 29  Richard A. Jewell, whose transformation from heroic security guard to Olympic bombing suspect and back again came to symbolize the excesses of law enforcement and the news media, died Wednesday at his home in Woodbury, Ga. He was 44.

title: 2 Sides Push Smooth Process on Naming Attorney General
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29  White House officials said Wednesday that the search for a successor to Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales would probably last at least several days. The officials said they were trying to strike a conciliatory tone with Senate Democratic leaders who will control the confirmation.

title: Rescuers Pull Man From Hole at Work Site in New Jersey
description: WOODBRIDGE TOWNSHIP, N.J., Aug. 29  A worker connecting a home to the townships sewer main was critically injured on Wednesday after being buried up to his neck in dirt for almost four hours when the walls of the hole he was working in collapsed, the authorities said.

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: Faith and Civic Pride Clash Over Parade on Yom Kippur
description: HERKIMER, N.Y.

title: Suit Takes Aim at Rules on Immigrant Workers
description: The A.F.L.-C.I.O., the Central Labor Council of Alameda County in California, the American Civil Liberties Union and other legal groups filed a lawsuit challenging new rules from the Department of Homeland Security that would force employers to fire illegal immigrant workers. The rules, announced Aug. 10, give employers 90 days to dismiss workers whose Social Security numbers do not match the records of the Social Security Administration. The suit charges that because there are inaccuracies in the agencys records, the rules would threaten jobs of American citizens and legal immigrants. It seeks to stop the agency from sending out a round of letters to employers starting next Tuesday that would include a notice about the new rules.

title: Circuits: A Musical Smartphone, Aiming to Increase the Cool Quotient
description: A funny thing happened when Motorola first introduced its Q smartphone. It found that many buyers were casual users, not BlackBerry converts itching for an e-mail fix. The company decided to make the Q look a little cooler and added music and easy-to-use messaging features  thus the new Q Music 9M.

title: One Dead and Two Wounded in Bronx Shooting
description: A man who was fired from his job as a janitor in Co-op City in the Bronx and lost a lawsuit to get his job back returned to the housing complex this morning with a .38-caliber revolver and shot three former colleagues, one of them fatally, according to the police.

title: Angry Crowd Questions Contractor
description: Frustrated Lower Manhattan residents and city officials confronted executives of the construction company overseeing the demolition of the Deutsche Bank building at a packed two-hour meeting last night.

title: A Wave of Players From Serbia Sweeps Into the Open
description: The venerable CBS commentator Andy Rooney said the other day that he could not keep track of Hispanic baseball players. He apparently cannot distinguish the fierce El Duque from the effervescent Reyes from the low-key Beltrn, and thats too bad.

title: Changes Proposed for Education Law
description: President Bushs signature education law, No Child Left Behind, which ties school aid to standardized-test scores, may be changed to elevate other criteria and exclude results for some non-native speakers of English, legislators said. States would be able to develop assessments of progress, and tests would go beyond English and math to include history and science, according to a proposal on the House education committees Web site. Schools would be judged partly on graduation rates and college enrollment. This draft is a work in progress, subject to change over the coming weeks, said Representatives George Miller, Democrat of California and chairman of the committee, and Howard P. McKeon of California, the panels ranking Republican. The draft has not been endorsed by the full committee.

title: A Quiet Cultural Force Leaves New York Richer as He Returns to Austria
description: Christoph Thun-Hohenstein, the director of the Austrian Cultural Forum, might have been chosen to match his building. Both are striking presences on the New York cultural scene: tall and thin and often cited. Both wrap their strengths in a diffident but notable charm.

title: Helmsley, Through Will, Is Still Calling the Shots
description: Leona Helmsley, the hotelier with the bossy streak, was famed in life for riding roughshod over everyone, from her offspring to her maid. Her demise last week at age 87, it seems, did nothing to alter her autocratic manner. Mrs. Helmsley, it appears, is a posthumous control freak.

title: EMI Chief Leaves After Private Equity Takeover
description: Eric Nicoli stepped down as chief executive of the EMI Group yesterday ahead of private investors purchase of the music corporation, which had tried unsuccessfully throughout his eight-year tenure to merge with rivals.

title: Home & Garden Calendar
description: Art of a Dynasty

title: Nothing Down, $0 a Month, Hammer Required
description: WHY would some people willingly spend decades  and hundreds of thousands of dollars  renovating houses they will never own? For a small but growing number of so-called resident curators living in old and cherished state-owned houses up and down the East Coast, the answers include the pleasure of bringing an abandoned landmark back to life, freedom from mortgage payments and the chance to live in the kind of home that would otherwise be out of reach.

title: Streaming Radio to the Stereo
description: Q. My wife and I are music aficionados and would like to hear streaming classical stations on our home stereo system. How do we plug our receiver into the PC so we can listen to these Internet stations on good speakers?

title: A Brilliant Shooter, Slowed by a Lackluster Narrative
description: AN eight-foot-tall metal creature that looks like a human tank wearing a diving helmet stands next to a little girl as she drains blood from a corpse. I lob several proximity mines onto the ground between us. There is a huge explosion as the creature steps on a mine; then its glowing yellow faceplate turns red.

title: For Irans Shiites, a Celebration of Faith and Waiting
description: QUM, Iran, Aug. 28  Qum is not usually thought of as a fun place. It is a gray, sun-baked city that serves as the center of learning for Shiite Islam. Its personality is solemn, its shops tend to be old, low-rise and rundown, and it is full of clergy members and police officers.

title: For Yankees, Squirrels Visit May Be Omen (a Bad One)
description: If a scholar of Norse mythology had been in the stands of Yankee Stadium on Tuesday night, he or she probably would have advised Yankees fans to not make too much out of the 5-3 victory against the Red Sox.

title: Fighting Through Knee Pain, Nadal Grinds Out a First-Round Victory
description: On the eve of the United States Open, Rafael Nadal was preparing to take the next flight home to Spain. His left knee was so painful after practicing Sunday, it was impossible, according to his uncle and coach, Toni Nadal, for him to play.

title: Brotherly Love for CBS
description: On a night in which two of CBSs Big Brother contestants also competed on CBSs Power of 10, that network easily led Tuesdays ratings over all. Both series also earned their largest audiences of the summer, according to Nielsens estimates, as Power of 10 delivered 9.7 million viewers at 8, and Big Brother drew 8.2 million at 9, as well as the nights best ratings among adults 18 to 49. CBS remained on top at 10, as its repeat of NCIS (7.7 million) outpaced ABCs Primetime: Crime (5.1 million) and a rerun of NBCs Law & Order: Special Victims Unit (5.4 million). Fox ranked No. 2 over all in total viewers, largely thanks to a repeat of House at 9 (7.9 million). In the 18-to-49 set, NBC tied Fox for second place, while ABC finished last. NBCs special Live From New York: The First Five Years of Saturday Night Live  attracted six million viewers from 8 to 10.

title: Hedge Fund Seeks Bankruptcy Abroad
description: Basis Capital Fund Management, an Australian firm that has said losses in its Basis Yield Alpha hedge fund could exceed 80 percent, filed for bankruptcy protection yesterday for the fund, citing defaults in subprime mortgages in the United States.

title: Footnotes
description: With five nominations, the tropical singer-songwriter Juan Luis Guerra led the way when the eighth annual Latin Grammy nominations were announced yesterday. Ricky Martin and Calle 13 received four nominations each, and Beyonc and Shakira were nominated for their duet Beautiful Liar, The Associated Press reported. The awards are to be presented in Las Vegas on Nov. 8. ... Owen Wilson, hospitalized amid reports of a suicide attempt, has dropped out of the DreamWorks comedy Tropic Thunder, The Associated Press reported. Citing reports in Daily Variety and The Hollywood Reporter, the news agency said the decision was characterized as a mutual agreement between the actor and Ben Stiller, the director.

title: Man Accused in Robberies of Six Banks Changes Plea
description: NEWARK, Aug. 29  After jailhouse interviews in which he appeared to confess his crimes, and after signing a plea agreement regarding six bank robberies in the Mad Hatter case, James G. Madison abruptly changed his mind on Wednesday afternoon.

title: No Shortage of Fairy-Tale Finishes at Worlds
description: OSAKA, Japan, Aug. 29  Finding a good story line on Wednesday night at the track and field world championships required considerably less effort than the athletes were expending as they chased gold, silver and bronze.

title: Tip of the Week: Reassigning Key Functions
description: TIP OF THE WEEK: If you keep hitting Caps Lock by accident and want to make it go away  or really wish some keys were in different places  a key remapping program can make life easier by letting you reassign certain key functions. Free keyboard mapping programs include Map Keyboard for Windows (www.inchwest.com) and DoubleCommand for the Mac (doublecommand.sourceforge.net).

title: Giulianis Budget Record: Disciplined Management (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day on Aug. 10 about international fallout from troubles in the United States subprime mortgage market misidentified the bank that bailed out IKB Deutsche Industriebank, which held subprime investments. It was the government-owned KfW development bank, which is IKBs largest shareholder  not the Bundesbank, which is the central German bank.

title: After Fourth Defeat in a Row, the Mets Send a Distress Signal
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 29  The first loss here this week did not disturb the Mets too much because their healthy lead remained intact. The second one stung a little bit more, but they figured there were still two games left to salvage a split and leave in good shape. But the third one, a controversial 3-2 defeat to the Philadelphia Phillies on Wednesday night, left them outraged, confused and one game away from being swept.

title: Manhattan: Police Affidavit Is Rebuffed
description: A Federal District Court judge refused, for procedural reasons, to consider an affidavit from a deputy police commissioner about the release of intelligence files related to the arrest of demonstrators at the 2004 Republican National Convention. In the affidavit, the deputy commissioner, David Cohen, objected to limits on information that could be blacked out from the files approved earlier by Magistrate Judge James C. Francis IV. The judge, Kenneth M. Karas, said yesterday that he would not consider the affidavit under court rules. He said it could be submitted to Judge Francis, but added that the city may have to explain why it did not offer such a declaration before appealing Judge Franciss order.

title: Profit Falls at DaimlerChrysler
description: AUBURN HILLS, Mich., Aug. 29  DaimlerChrysler said today that its net income fell during the second quarter and that it would take a charge of nearly $3.4 billion for the sale of the Chrysler Group to Cerberus Capital Management.

title: Save the Astronauts First (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Circuits: More Brains, Brawn and Charm for Robotic Broom
description: The fifth generation of the Roomba robotic broom still doesnt have the personality of Rosie, the Jetsons mechanical maid, but its getting closer. Press a button and a pleasant womans voice explains the Roombas features as it scuttles about demonstrating.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Friday about the escape of a homicide suspect from a police station in Queens misstated the date that the police say the slaying occurred. It was July 28, not last Thursday.

title: Kraft Appoints Finance Chief
description: Kraft Foods said yesterday that it had hired Timothy R. McLevish, chief financial officer of the Ingersoll-Rand Company, to become its finance chief in October.

title: A Digital Camera That Adds Sound and Travel Tips
description: Digital cameras are starting to compete with cellphones as the most versatile gadget. Samsungs new i85 model packs an 8-megapixel camera inside its brushed aluminum body, as well as a personal media player for enjoying digital music and video between shots.

title: Stocks Rally as Investors Chase Deals
description: The stock market recovered almost all of its losses from Tuesdays sharp sell-off as investors went bargain-hunting yesterday at Wall Streets equivalent of a late summer sale.

title: Injuries and Time Take Their Toll on Giants
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Aug. 28  The Giants will face two opponents Thursday night, and neither comes dressed in a New England Patriots uniform. The Giants, more than anything, are facing injuries and time.

title: Bragging Time: Show Me the Cards in the Show-Me State
description: Local rivalries add a certain zest to sporting events. For example, when the Mets play the Yankees, there is always a little extra electricity in the New York City air.

title: Long Wait for 1,500 Title Ends for Lagat and U.S.
description: OSAKA, Japan, Aug. 29  Racing around the final bend of the 1,500 meters, a blur of multicolored jerseys heading toward the finish line, both Americans in the field, Bernard Lagat and Alan Webb, were in position to win. But only one of their bodies did what its brain had begged.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: The Executive Pursuits column in Business Day on Saturday, about the life of a cut man, who attends to fighters injuries, misstated the name of a mixed martial arts team that recently participated in the semifinals of the International Fight League championship. The team is the Tokyo Sabres, not the Tokyo Sharks.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,724 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:

title: Welcome, Students. Now Watch It.
description: Its the time of year when the streets of Morningside Heights, Greenwich Village and a few other neighborhoods are filled with new, unfamiliar faces: college freshmen. Various guides on paper and on the Internet tell these students what they should see and do in their new hometown. Here, then, is the opposite, from the staff writers of The New York Times: a list of things they should not do.

title: After 4 Years, Last Charges Dropped in Quattrone Case
description: A federal judge formally approved a request by prosecutors to dismiss all remaining charges against Frank P. Quattrone, the former Credit Suisse banker.

title: Clemens Relies on Guile to Outduel Beckett
description: When Josh Beckett broke off a curveball to end the first inning last night, he looked so dominant that it could have been the 2003 World Series all over again. Alex Rodriguez took it for strike three, immediately flipping his bat toward the Yankees dugout in a sign of surrender.

title: Yankees Win, Lose All Sense of Reason
description: The Yankees were so giddy after smacking around Josh Beckett for 13 hits in their 4-3 win on Wednesday, they didnt make much sense in their clubhouse interviews. Or, to put it more accurately, they exaggerated a lot in praising each other.

title: Older and Better
description: In todays style section Gina Kolata writes about how some older women runners are faster than younger runners in road races.

title: The Hottest Topic
description: Lets take a little break from the Strahan watch to return to that other player who has been a topic of conversation. Its been awhile since weve given you a space here to talk about Michael Vick. And, well, a lot has happened since then.

title: Making it Hard to Throw Away
description: My column today is about pay-as-you-throw trash collection, to me a brilliant and underutilized idea. The basic concept is that we should pay for trash removal the way we pay for electricity use: the more you use, the more you pay. Communities use various measures to determine how much your household is throwing away, then charge you accordingly.

title: Day 4 at the Open
description: Martina Hingis, Andy Roddick, Tommy Haas and Maria Sharapova advanced on the fourth day of play at Flushing Meadows.

title: Contemporary Caribbean
description: Images from "Infinite Island" at the Brooklyn Museum.

title: Abstraction's Myriad Themes
description: Images from "The Abstract Impulse: Fifty Years of Abstraction at the National Academy."

title: Schemes in Spanish
description: Like Oceans Eleven, if directed by Robin Hood and financed by Telemundo, Ladrn Que Roba a Ladrn is an effervescent comedy coasting on the charisma of its stars.

title: Violence in the Name of Justice
description: In the latest flashy, pretentious exploitation movie from James Wan (Saw and Dead Silence), Kevin Bacon plays Nick Hume, an insurance adjuster who sees his oldest son die at the hands of a machete-wielding young punk during a street gangs robbery of a gas station.

title: Spiritual Q & A
description: When the filmmaker Rick Ray arrived in India to direct a travel video, an interview with the Dalai Lama was supposed to be part of his compensation. When he discovered that he would have to arrange it himself, he did, by e-mail.

title: A Teenager in Search of a Soul
description: Self-Medicated opens with a very clever fake-out, as innocent pedestrians on the Las Vegas Strip are randomly fired at in what appears to be a drive-by shooting. The scene is energetic and ominously gripping: qualities that the movie unfortunately fails to sustain.

title: A Fairy Tale From India
description: Once upon a time in southern India there lived a feisty lower-caste girl named Vanaja, whose hard-drinking father couldnt properly care for her. She found employment with her villages wealthy landlady, Rama Devi, who took her under her wing and taught her Kuchipudi dance.

title: Police Interview With Sen. Larry Craig
description: Transcript of June 11 police interview with Sen. Larry Craig:

title: Migrating for Work
description: The Indian state of Kerala, celebrated for its alternative model of development, is dependent on remittances.

title: BNP Reopens Funds Affected by Subprime Loans
description: BNP Paribas, the French bank, said it reopened two investment funds it had frozen amid problems in the subprime mortgage sector in the United States.

title: German Bank Inquiry Reaches Executives
description: Prosecutors in Dsseldorf are investigating seven current and former executives of WestLB, a bank owned by the German government, a spokesman told The Associated Press. The executives, six of them not identified, are suspected of violating a German law in connection with large losses in speculative transactions this year, a spokesman for the prosecutors office, Arno Neukirchen, told the news service.

title: Romney Shows a Little Leg in New Ad
description: The creative team for Mitt Romney is adding to the picture they are assembling for Iowa and New Hampshire voters with a new ad that features him quite literally running hard as a narrator declares at every step, hes met extraordinary challenges.

title: Deltas C.O.O. Resigns
description: The chief operating officer at Delta Air Lines, James M. Whitehurst, resigned Wednesday, a week after being passed over for promotion to the top post. Delta, which chose Richard Anderson, the former chief executive of Northwest Airlines as its chief on Aug. 21, said Mr. Whitehursts departure was effective immediately.

title: EMI Chief Leaves After Private Equity Takeover
description: Eric Nicoli stepped down as chief executive of the EMI Group Wednesdayahead of private investors purchase of the music corporation, which had tried unsuccessfully throughout his eight-year tenure to merge with rivals.

title: Sarkozy to Decide on Suez Merger in September
description: President Nicolas Sarkozy will decide by the end of September whether to back the merger of the utility Suez with the state-run Gaz de France, a Cabinet spokesman said Wednesday.

title: Alltel Investors Approve $24 Billion Buyout
description: Alltel shareholders overwhelmingly approved a $24.7 billion buyout Wednesday that put the wireless company in the hands of two private equity firms.

title: Former C.B.O.T. Executive to Serve as Sentinel Trustee
description: Fred Grede, a former Chicago Board of Trade executive, was appointed trustee in the Sentinel Management Group bankruptcy Wednesday.

title: The Man Behind the Muscles
description: Was it just sore knees and the unforgiving hard court surface that caused Rafael Nadal to struggle in his four-set victory over Alun Jones? Or could he have been brooding about something inside the tender recesses of his mind, buried deep within his muscular armor?

title: Microsoft Buys Parlano
description: Microsoft announced on Wednesday plans to acquire Parlano, a developer of group chat applications for large corporate customers. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.

title: Chinas ICBC Buys Macau Lender
description: Industrial and Commercial Bank of China said on Wednesday it would acquire Macaus third largest lender, Seng Heng Bank. ICBC, Chinas largest bank, will pay 4.55 billion Hong Kong dollars ($590 million) for a 79.93 percent stake in the Macau bank, which is majority-owned by Stanley Ho.

title: Citigroup Leads $400 Million Deal for Cupmaker
description: Citigroups venture capital arm led a $400 million deal for a controlling stake in Waddington North America, a maker of disposable cups, dinnerware and cutlery, according to Reuters.

title: New Electric Car Start-Up Revs Its Engine
description: Another day, another electric car company.

title: Carlyle Capital Sees Smoother Sailing Ahead
description: Carlyle Capital, a unit of the private equity firm the Carlyle Group, said on Wednesday it hopes the worst of the credit crunch has passed, allowing it to resume paying a dividend.

title: Tenet Denies Possibility of Bankruptcy
description: Tenet Healthcare said Wednesday it has sufficient financial resources to stage a turnaround, rebutting an analysts report that sent its shares to a record low on Tuesday.

title: New Study Criticizes Hedge Fund Salaries
description: After a month of disappointing returns and the high-profile collapse of several hedge funds, a new report has come out just in time to further raise the ire of those who feel that the rich fees collected by fund managers are undeserved.

title: EndoGastric Solutions Takes $30 Million
description: A medical device maker, EndoGastric Solutions, has raised $30 million in venture capital, money that the company plans to use for sales and for marketing its StomaphyX device. The product was approved for sale in the United States in March.

title: RBS Bankers Out Amid Debt Market Turmoil
description: The collapse of the subprime mortgage market has claimed the scalp of a senior Royal Bank of Scotland executive in the United States and six of his colleagues.

title: Carrefour to Spin Off European Real Estate Arm
description: French supermarket giant Carrefour on Thursday responded to its fiercest critics  including some of its own shareholders  by announcing a plan to spin off its European real estate into a separately listed company.

title: Rivals May Try Burberry On for Size, Analyst Says
description: Is the Burberry Group an acquisition target? A Merill Lynch analyst thinks so and has identified luxury goods makers PPR and Coach as possible buyers.

title: Yahoos New President Oversees a Shake-Up
description: Susan L. Decker, Yahoos new president, is putting her stamp on the company in a reorganization of its management ranks that creates a new division responsible for generating the bulk of the companys revenue.

title: Lehman Cuts Estimates on Rivals
description: Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley, Merrill Lynch and Bear Stearns, four of the five largest securities firms, will earn less than expected through next year after a rout in subprime mortgages, according to a Lehman Brothers analyst.

title: Goldman Said to Lose London Dealmaker
description: A top Goldman Sachs dealmaker in London who has worked on some of the investment banks most high-profile telecoms and media deals is leaving the the firm, The Telegraph reported. Alain Carrier, a Canadian, is leaving for a job in the Canadian government, according to the newspaper.

title: Investors Buy $1 Billion Stake in Global Hyatt
description: Global Hyatt, the hotel company controlled by the Pritzker family of Chicago, said Wednesday that it would sell a minority stake to a group of investors, including Goldman Sachs Capital Partners, for $1 billion.

title: Lehman, Goldman Are Said to Raise Funds for L.B.O. Debt
description: In an attempt to capitalize on a credit crunch that has depressed prices for leveraged loans in the secondary markets, Goldman Sachs and Lehman Brothers are actively raising funds to buy leveraged loans that trade at discounts in the secondary market, The Deal.com reports.

title: American Home Mortgage to Auction Loans
description: The bankrupt home loan provider American Home Mortgage Investment, said on Wednesday a federal bankruptcy judge has authorized the auction by two affiliates of 5,700 mortgage loans with an unpaid principal balance of about $1.62 billion.

title: Buyout Tax Debate Hits the Hamptons
description: It may be the late-summer doldrums, but the debate over taxes and private equity is hardly on vacation. It has just gone to the Hamptons  like much of the rest of Wall Street.

title: H&R Block to Renegotiate Unit Sale to Cerberus
description: H&R Block, the tax preparation company, said on Thursday it is renegotiating the sale of its money-losing Option One Mortgage subprime lending unit to Cerberus Capital Management, casting doubt on it ability to complete the transaction.

title: MovieBeam: An Encore Presentation
description: David Pogue reviews the MovieBeam, a box that connects directly to your TV set and holds 100 movies on its hard drive.

title: Morning Buzz: More Deutsche Bank Questions, Leona Helmsleys Dog, Moving 800,000 Cigars and More
description: In late 2005, the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation had approved a tentative arrangement with three large contractors to do the complex work of dismantling the former Deutsche Bank building in Lower Manhattan. But just as a draft contract was being completed, the deal fell apart  days after the president of one of the companies, North American Site Developers Inc. of Waltham, Mass., received an anonymous telephone call telling him to stay out of New York.William K. Rashbaum and Charles V. Bagli report that the F.B.I. investigated the threat, sending two agents to interview the companys president, Chris Berardi. The collapse of the deal cleared the way for the hiring of the John Galt Corporation, the troubled subcontractor that is a focus of the criminal inquiry into the Aug. 18 fire at the building that left two firefighters dead.

title: A More Pessimistic Report on Iraq
description: Add another assessment of the Iraq surge to the pile. A draft of a progress report requested by Congress from the Government Accountability Office is strikingly negative and questions a more optimistic report by the administration in July, according to The Washington Post, which obtained a copy.

title: 2008: Return to Sender
description: After new details emerged about the criminal record of one of Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons top donors  who has also given generously to many other Democrats over the years  her campaign announced that it would give the $23,000 contribution from New York businessman Norman Hsu to charity. The question remains whether other donations that he bundled will be returned.

title: Thursday Morning Kickoff
description: Its game day! Warning: watching this video from our friends over at Sunday Morning Quarterback may make you want to get up and tackle the person in the cubicle next to you. We dont condone that, no matter how satisfying it might be.

title: Craigs Next Move
description: In its third consecutive daily editorial about Senator Larry Craig, the Idaho Statesman editorial page asks Craig to resign.

title: Man Shoots Three Former Co-Workers in the Bronx; 1 Is Killed

title: Iraqi Chemical Agent Is Found at U.N.; No Public Danger, Authorities Say

title: An East Harlem Funeral Is Held on the Sidewalk to Protest a Church Closing

When the church closed in February as part of a round of parish closings ordered by the Archdiocese of New York, Mrs. Gonzalez was devastated. She joined a small but fervent group of protesters who have urged the archdiocese to reconsider.So Mrs. Gonzalezs family decided that the most fitting way to honor her memory was to hold a funeral ceremony outside the church, in lieu of the funeral Mass that would have been observed inside the parish had it stayed open. The ceremony was held outside the church at 9:30 a.m. today.

title: Scissors Author Settles Suit
description: A $2 million lawsuit against the author Augusten Burroughs, by the family that sued him for defamation for his best-selling book Running With Scissors, has been settled, The Associated Press reported yesterday. Financial terms were not disclosed, but Mr. Burroughs and the publisher, St. Martins Press, agreed to call the volume a book instead of memoirs in the authors note, although the word memoir will still appear on the cover and elsewhere, and to change the acknowledgments in future editions to say that the Turcotte familys memories of events he describes are different from my own. In addition future editions will express regret for any unintentional harm to them. But in a statement released yesterday by St. Martins, Mr. Burroughs declared his work an entirely accurate memoir. Howard Cooper, a lawyer for the family, said financial terms of the settlement were confidential. Mr. Burroughs lived with the Turcottes as a teenager, and though the book calls them the Finches, the lawsuit maintains that they are easily identified.

title: China: Antimonopoly Law Approved
description: After 13 years of reviewing drafts, the National Peoples Congress approved a law that bans price-fixing, collusion, excessive market concentration and other monopolistic practices by private and state-owned businesses alike. The law marks another step toward a market economy and away from a centrally planned economy in which a series of giant state-owned enterprises held vast and unchallenged monopolies. The laws most controversial provision, added this summer, calls for the government to conduct more formal reviews of foreign purchases of Chinese companies based on their potential to harm national security, including economic security. The law will take effect on Aug. 1, 2008.

Waxman, Democrat of California, has renewed his demand that the Bush administration explain how millions of White House e-mail messages may have been lost, disclosing for the first time that there was a daily audit of the message system. title: France: Sarkozy Favors a Utility Merger
description: President Nicolas Sarkozy said he favored a merger of Gaz de France and the energy operations of Suez, implying Suez would have to shed its waste and water units to complete the long-pending deal. Ive proposed that Suez merge its energy business with Gaz de France to create a large gas and electricity group, Mr. Sarkozy, left, said in a speech to a Paris business group. This requires that Suez make a strategic choice to specialize in energy. Suezs chief executive, Gerard Mestrallet, has resisted considering a sale of the waste and water units, which account for about a third of operations. He declined to say whether he would be willing to hive them off for the deal to go through. The original plan to combine Suez and Gaz de France is now valued at about 56 billion euros ($76 billion). It has been mired in political and valuation concerns since it was first put forward in February 2006 to ward off a possible bid for Suez from Enel of Italy and to create Europes second-biggest utility.
