title: Bronx: Man Kills Companion and Himself
description: A 32-year-old Bronx man fatally shot his 27-year-old longtime companion and then killed himself yesterday as the couples 9-month-old baby was nearby, the police said. The bodies of the couple, Arlington Marshall and Tricia Spooner, both shot in the head in what investigators called a murder-suicide, were discovered around 8:30 p.m. in Mr. Marshalls basement apartment at 730 East 227th Street in Williamsbridge. A .38-caliber gun was recovered at the scene.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The byline for a front-page article yesterday about the legal troubles of a prominent Democratic fund-raiser and contributor to Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons campaign misidentified one of the writers. The article was by Mike McIntire and Leslie Wayne  not by Leslie Eaton, another Times reporter.

title: Spare Times
description: ON THE STREET

title: Brooklyn: Sentence Imposed for Norman
description: Former State Assemblyman Clarence Norman Jr., left, was returned to State Supreme Court in Brooklyn yesterday from the Oneida Correctional Facility in Rome, N.Y., for imposition of another sentence of one to three years in prison, prosecutors said. That sentence had been stayed while Mr. Norman appealed a lower court decision, but was imposed after the appeal was denied, prosecutors said. Mr. Norman, who is now sentenced to serve three to nine years, has been imprisoned on two other charges since June. He was convicted in February of extorting money from judicial candidates.

title: Got Arachnophobia? Heres Your Worst Nightmare
description: WILLS POINT, Tex., Aug. 29  Most spiders are solitary creatures. So the discovery of a vast web crawling with millions of spiders that is spreading across several acres of a North Texas park is causing a stir among scientists, and park visitors.

title: One Dead and Two Wounded in Bronx Shooting
description: A former janitor enraged at losing his job opened fire with a pistol early yesterday at the Bronx housing complex where he lived and had once worked, killing his former supervisor and injuring two others, one critically, the police said.

title: Trouble in Paradise? Call a Shaman, Hold the PlayStation
description: It would be nice to say that characters in kids animated television shows have only recently become pitchmen, but its a long tradition. Back in the mid-60s you had Linus the Lionhearted, a mascot for the breakfast cereal Crispy Critters, with his own show on CBS (later on ABC), which also featured Sugar Bear, star of Sugar Crisp cereal. (Both characters were created by the Ed Graham ad agency.) In 1969 the Federal Trade Commission banned TV shows based on selling a sponsors product, and that was that.

title: Portable Theater (Just Go With the Flow)
description: UNDER a full moon on Tuesday night, in a little-known corner of Staten Island, the Mabou Mines theater company was afloat, rehearsing its latest work. Jutting from Pier 7 1/2, a 90-foot barge, built up with several stories of scaffolding and filled with actors, musicians, costumes and props, bobbed gently in New York Harbor.

title: Shiites Tale: How Gulf With Sunnis Widened
description: BAGHDAD, Aug. 30  Shatha al-Musawi, a Shiite member of Parliament, first encountered the Sunni-Shiite divide on the day the Americans captured Saddam Hussein. Hearing the news with a close Sunni friend named Sahira, Ms. Musawi erupted like a child.

title: Yankees Sweep Red Sox Behind Wang
description: The sweep last August was more emphatic. The Yankees won five games, not three, and they did it in Fenway Park, rampaging past a Boston Red Sox team that would not qualify for the postseason.

title: Mortgage Firm Sells $500 Million in Stock
description: Thornburg Mortgage, a jumbo-mortgage specialist that was forced to stop making new loans, has sold $500 million of convertible preferred stock to raise cash.

title: Yankees Pitches Get Red Sox Attention
description: Kevin Youkilis thought Joba Chamberlains first 98 mile-an-hour fastball over his head might have been accidental. But when Chamberlain followed that with an identical fastball again near his skull, it took Youkilis only a few tenths of a second to decide that Chamberlain was trying to drill him.

title: Lessons in Apologies (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Mussina Is Finally Dealing With Being Removed From the Rotation
description: Mike Mussina met with reporters yesterday and apologized for taking three days to discuss his removal from the Yankees rotation. In a way, though, his silence said enough.

title: Protests Persist in Myanmar, Despite Arrests by Junta
description: BANGKOK, Aug. 30  Linking arms for mutual support, grim in the face of plainclothes paramilitary gangs, small groups of protesters in Myanmar have staged street demonstrations for nearly two weeks in the most sustained defiance of the countrys ruling junta in a decade.

title: Drug for Growth Disorder Approved
description: The Food and Drug Administration gave approval to a drug used to treat a rare condition that causes the body to produce too much growth hormone. The treatment, Somatuline Depot, will offer a new option for patients with acromegaly, which causes excess growth of the hands, feet and head. Ipsen SA, the Paris-based company that owns the drug in Europe, licensed American rights to the company Tercica, which is based in Brisbane, Calif., in November.

title: In the Decade Since
description: Has it been 10 years already since Diana died? So it seems, and the best evidence isnt the calendar. Its the photographs of Diana, Princess of Wales, staring out at us from the newsstands and the Web and the television. They remind us how distant the near-past can seem, how sensitive we are to the nuances of the present.

title: More Realism, Less Spin
description: A new report from Congresss investigative arm provides a powerful fresh dose of nonpartisan realism about Iraq as President Bush tries to spin people into thinking that significant  or at least sufficient  progress is being made. With a crucial debate on Iraq set for next month, the report should be read by members of Congress who may be wavering in the fight with the White House over withdrawing American troops.

title: Movies
description: MOVIES

title: Musharrafs Aides Deny a Deal With Bhutto
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Aug. 30  Pakistani government officials denied Thursday that the countrys president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, had agreed to resign as army chief before presidential elections, contradicting statements a day earlier by Benazir Bhutto, an exiled former prime minister.

title: 2 More U.S. Priests Align With African Anglicans
description: Deepening the disarray in the Anglican Communion over homosexuality, the archbishop of Kenya, Benjamin Nzimbi, consecrated two American priests as bishops of the Anglican Church of Kenya to serve disaffected Episcopalians in the United States. The new bishops, William Murdoch of Massachusetts, at right in photo, and Bill Atwood of Texas, left, will minister to Americans who have grown alienated from the Episcopal Church, the American branch of Anglicanism, which takes a liberal stance on homosexuality. The consecration at All Saints Cathedral in Nairobi followed similar consecrations of Americans by the archbishops of Nigeria and Rwanda. But those consecrations across regional boundaries have not been officially recognized by the archbishop of Canterbury, the Most Rev. Rowan Williams, spiritual leader of the worldwide communion of 77 million members.

title: Marketing Sprint Begins When the Race for the Gold Ends
description: OSAKA, Japan, Friday, Aug. 31  When Tyson Gay hits full speed on the track, his face tells the story.

title: A Festival Rooted in Female Ingenuity
description: STOCKBRIDGE, Mass.  In 1927 a wealthy New Englander who went by the sturdy name of Mabel Choate set out to preserve a building that housed a neglected 39-year-old social club in the central Berkshires, the Stockbridge Casino. Designed by Stanford White, the building had been described by The Pittsfield Sun in 1888 as the areas first symptom of dissipation and gaiety.

title: So Far, Few Surprises at the Open
description: Andy Roddick, a former United States Open champion, and Donald Young, an 18-year-old junior whose game is catching up to the hype that has surrounded him, each caught a break Thursday at the United States Open when their opponents could not finish their second-round matches.

title: For McEnroe, Mellowing From Superbratty to Cuddly
description: John McEnroe will always be trailed by his youthful image as the spoiled superbrat in need of long-term therapy. But thats O.K., it really is, he said, because he is capitalizing on tantrums of yore in films (Mr. Deeds and Anger Management), on TV (CSI: NY and 30 Rock) and in a new American Express commercial in which he apologizes to a fictional chair umpire, hugs him and says, Youre not evil!

title: John Who? Isner Stands Out in a Crowd in More Ways Than One
description: Dan Magills telephone rang Wednesday morning. When he answered it the voice on the other end of the line said, Hey, Coach, its John.

title: Virginia Tech President Stands by Actions
description: RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 30  A day after a scathing state report criticized Virginia Techs handling of the shooting massacre in April, Charles W. Steger, the university president, defended his administrations actions Thursday and said he had no plans to resign.

title: Governor Commutes Sentence in Texas
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 30  Hours before his scheduled execution as a disputed accomplice in a 1996 murder, Kenneth Foster won a rare commutation to life in prison on Thursday after Gov. Rick Perry followed the recommendation of the Texas Board of Pardons and Paroles and granted a death row reprieve.

title: Taliban Free Remaining 7 Koreans Held Captive
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Aug. 30  The Taliban freed the seven remaining South Korean hostages in central Afghanistan on Thursday, Afghan officials announced, ending a six-week hostage crisis that had placed enormous political pressure on the South Korean government.

title: Whats on Tonight
description: 10 P.M. (CMT) CROSS COUNTRY His first gigs were in the hardscrabble honky-tonks and dance halls of Texas. But these days his singles consistently reach the Top 10 of the country-music charts, including last summers No. 1 hit Wherever You Are. She arrived on the scene as a finalist in the 2003 edition of Nashville Star. Now shes a two-time Country Music Association Horizon Award nominee. In this special those two, Jack Ingram and Miranda Lambert, above, share songs, stories and their love for all things country. They also pay tribute to their Texas roots with a cover of Waylon Jenningss Are You Sure Hank Done It This Way.

title: Environmental Agency Calls for Sealing of Damaged Tower
description: The federal Environmental Protection Agency has told the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation that it wants the fire-damaged former Deutsche Bank building at 130 Liberty Street to be sealed up soon to protect public health and the environment.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings
description: CLASSICAL

title: Letter to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I know this is vacation season, and I hate to be a killjoy, but I feel compelled to respond to your article Wakesurfing: Following the Boat Without a Rope (Aug. 17).

title: Go West, Old Man
description: Every year we go to the beach, and every year it becomes more obvious that beach vacations are a metaphor for the human predicament. For while in his soul the contemporary man seeks to realize the loftiness of his essential nature, in actual life he finds himself whacking a ball against the windmill arm in an eternal game of mini-golf.

title: From the Netherlands, With Attitude
description: NORTH ADAMS., Mass.  The Dutch painter and video artist Erik van Lieshout may not be the worlds biggest kvetch, but he could be a runner-up. In three up-close-and-personal videos at the Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art, Part 1, Part 2 and Up! (as well as a short fourth, Lariam, that is much more focused), Mr. van Lieshout whines, cries and wallows in hypochondria, parading his boorish self-obsession before his mother, his shrink and his editor friend Core, whom he taunts and bullies.

title: Abandoned at the Border
description: FOR more than a year, men and women in our armed forces have been urging the United States to bring to safety the Iraqi translators and others who have worked beside them and are now the victims of retaliation. A Marine captain, Zachary Iscol, said he owed his life and the lives of his men to his Iraqi translator. Just coming to work was an act of heroism and courage on his part, Captain Iscol said.

title: Barclays Helps Rescue Debt Fund
description: LONDON, Aug. 31  Barclays, the British bank forced earlier this week to deny reports of exposure to troubled debt products, said on Friday that it helped rescue a $1.6 billion debt fund at a London-based asset management firm.

title: History Repeats as Yankees Sweep Red Sox
description: The sweep was more emphatic last August, when the Yankees rampaged into Fenway Park and won five games to bury the Boston Red Sox. The best the Yankees could do this time was to win three at Yankee Stadium and chisel a chunk from Bostons sizable lead in the American League East.

title: I.B.M. Researchers Advancing Computer Processing Ability
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 30  Researchers at I.B.M. laboratories say they have made progress toward storing information and computing at the level of individual atoms.

title: The Face That Greeted Residents as They Greeted Their Day
description: At Co-op City, the massive apartment complex in the Bronx, Audley Bent was the smiling face that greeted people every morning as they left their homes for work. As a supervising porter, he was the dapper man who knew their grandsons names, the guy in the tie who complimented them on their lipstick or their shirts.

title: Mexico: Police Find Small Bomb at Skyscraper
description: About 10,800 people were evacuated from the 55-story Torre Mayor in Mexico City, after an anonymous caller warned the skyscrapers management of a bomb. The police said they had found a small explosive device in a car on one of the parking levels of the office tower. They said the device was too small to have caused significant damage. The citys public security secretary, Joel Ortega, said it was not known who had planted the device.

title: Use of Bundlers Raises New Risks for Campaigns
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30  In amassing $52 million in campaign contributions in the first half of this year, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton relied on a platinum pyramid of 233 Hillraisers, including the movie director Steven Spielberg, the party powerbroker Vernon E. Jordan Jr., and the real estate mogul William C. Rudin.

title: Manhattan: Body Found in Times Square Hotel
description: The body of a woman was found under a bed in the Carter Hotel in Times Square yesterday, with her head and legs covered in plastic, the police said. The victim, who was described by the police as in her 20s but whose name was not released pending family notification, was discovered shortly before 2:30 p.m. in a sixth-floor room of the hotel on West 43rd Street. The medical examiner will determine the exact cause of death, the police said.

title: A Designer Handbag Amid the Briefcases on the Tax Beat
description: Lee Sheppard, who was wearing her standard black and sporting punky streaked blonde hair, strolled into a recent tax conference at Columbia University in Manhattan and waded through a sea of tailored suits.

title: Burning Questions After a Blaze
description: THE tragedy of the fire at the Deutsche Bank building in lower Manhattan will not be alleviated by an arbitrary transfer and public humiliation of three good fire officers who were not even at the scene. If Deputy Chief Richard Fuerch, Battalion Chief John McDonald and Capt. Peter Bosco did something wrong, they should be tried in a court of law and given the same rights as all other people in our country. A sudden and unexpected transfer is a burdensome and embarrassing upheaval for a family. It is a department discipline tool that has no recourse and no court of appeals.

title: From a Single Plant, a World-Class Garden Grows
description: BARBARA PACKER is no dabbler. Exhibit A: The Climbery, her seven-acre clematis garden at the weekend retreat she shares with her husband, Ira Weinstein, near Livingston, N.Y., in Columbia County. With 600 varieties and 6,000 vines, its the largest private clematis collection in the world, according to the International Clematis Society. Ms. Packer takes her gardens ranking in stride. Formerly a lawyer specializing in cases involving exposure to toxic substances, she is used to focusing her considerable energies and achieving results.

title: Theater Listings
description: THEATER

title: Tennis Fans Find Excuses to Flee the Office for Flushing Meadows
description: It takes a special kind of tennis fan to appreciate Fabrice Santoro, and a more special fan still to play hooky from work in order to see him play. Mr. Santoro, a 34-year-old journeyman on the pro tour, is currently the 44th-best player in the world, according to the Association of Tennis Professionals computer ranking. He has an inelegant, open-toed style of play, with two-handed slicing ground strokes off both sides.

title: Syria Says It Will Require Visas for Some Iraqi Refugees
description: BAGHDAD, Friday, Aug. 31  Syria informed the Iraqi government on Thursday that it would start requiring visas for some Iraqis next month, Iraqs Foreign Ministry said, a step that would reduce access to the last remaining haven for fleeing Iraqis.

title: Gross-Out Fanfares for the Common Man
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Its a crystal clear afternoon here, and for once  just once  Mike Rowe is clean.

title: Bank in Germany Posts Loss Because of Bad Stock Trades
description: PARIS, Aug. 30  WestLB, the troubled German state-run bank, said Thursday that it had lost more than $820 million on speculative trades in global stock markets in the first half of 2007  pushing it into a net loss for the period and renewing pressure for it to find a merger partner.

title: Confronting Syphilis, Quite Candidly
description: ITS like this.

title: President of Standard & Poors Steps Down
description: Kathleen Corbet, president of the credit rating company Standard & Poors, resigned after lawmakers and investors criticized the company for failing to judge the risks of securities backed by subprime mortgages.

title: Benjamin Aaron, an Expert in Labor Law, Dies at 91
description: Benjamin Aaron, a scholar of labor law and a member of presidential commissions who throughout his career promoted increased democracy in the workplace and protection for workers not represented by unions, died Saturday in Los Angeles. He was 91 and lived in Santa Monica, Calif.

title: Marthas Vineyard B&B&D (Dinner)
description: MARTHA'S VINEYARD is one of the few American destinations without a regional bed-and-breakfast inn association, which tells you something right off: This is an island of independent-minded New Englanders.

title: Roddick Receives a Gift on His 25th Birthday
description: Andy Roddicks racket flashed three times in the sun as he lunged for each volley Jos Acasuso drilled at him with increasing ferocity until Acasuso could only capitulate.

title: Judge Wont Order Tightening of Limits on Campaign Donors
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP)  The Federal Election Commission can continue to regulate independent political groups case by case and does not need to adopt new rules to govern them, a federal judge said Thursday.

title: Dance Listings
description: DANCE

title: Inquiry Into Police Opens Old Wounds in Yonkers
description: YONKERS, N.Y., Aug. 30  When Mayor Philip A. Amicone joined community leaders here in April to announce a settlement to decades-long litigation over housing segregation, it seemed as if this city might finally begin to shed the reputation for racial discord that had helped define it for generations.

title: 2 Boston Firefighters Die in Restaurant Blaze
description: BOSTON, Aug. 30  Two Boston firefighters were killed and 11 others were injured battling a blaze that appeared to start in a grease-caked ventilation shaft at a Chinese restaurant on Wednesday night, officials said Thursday. They were the first Boston firefighters to die in the line of duty since 1994.

title: The Jets Win in a Rough Final Audition
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 30  Those who like offensive football had to wait until the fourth quarter to enjoy the Jets 13-11 preseason victory over the Philadelphia Eagles on Thursday night.

title: New Worries for Small Banks
description: For Americas small banks, the changing financial landscape of the last decade meant that many opportunities were no longer available. The big national banks went after consumer lending and came to dominate the market for credit cards. Lending to big companies had long since migrated away from local banks.

title: Tony Snow to Step Down in September
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31  Tony Snow, whose face became familiar to millions of television viewers as well as the Washington press corps in his two years as chief White House spokesman, plans to leave his post on Sept. 14.

title: Sarkozy Urges French to Play the Game of Globalization
description: PARIS, Aug. 30  In a country that has long resisted globalization, President Nicolas Sarkozy bluntly told France on Thursday to stop kidding itself and face up to it  but in a French way.

title: Suit Filed Over Security Steps at NASA Facility
description: Twenty-eight scientists, engineers and other workers at one of NASAs top research centers filed suit in federal court yesterday challenging new security measures, including questions about loyalty and sexual orientation, that they say violate their constitutional rights.

title: N.Y.U. Plans a Branch in Abu Dhabi, Officials Say
description: New York University is planning to announce next month that it will open a full-fledged branch campus in Abu Dhabi, to be paid for by the Abu Dhabi government, according to officials close to negotiations that have stretched over more than a year.

title: Shape of Pivotal Senate Race Hinges on Warner Decision
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30  Senator John W. Warner of Virginia, one of the Republican Partys most influential figures on military issues and an increasingly critical voice on the course of the war in Iraq, will announce Friday whether he will run for re-election next year or, as many expect, retire.

title: Carrefour, French Retail Giant, to Sell 20% of Its Property Unit
description: LONDON, Aug. 30  Carrefour, the French supermarket chain and the worlds second-biggest retailer, said Thursday that it planned to sell part of its real estate portfolio in an initial public offering, bowing to pressure from investors including the French billionaire Bernard Arnault.

title: In Need of Relief, the Mets Find None
description: Philadelphia

title: A Museum Shows How It Played Catch-Up
description: The fabled conservatism of the National Academy, longtime home of the retrograde and anachronistic in art, has faded over the years as this venerable institution has increasingly sought to attract new, younger members and audiences.

description: ART

title: Microsoft Settles a Dispute Over a Feature in Its Browser
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (Bloomberg News)  Microsoft said Thursday that it had settled an eight-year patent dispute that resulted in a $521 million jury verdict against it. Terms of the accord were not disclosed.

title: Building a Modern Arsenal in India
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 30  India is developing a military appetite to match its growing economic power.

title: Gay Secures Sprint Double With a Record Run
description: OSAKA, Japan, Aug. 30  For anyone who watched Tyson Gay win the 100 meters in spectacular fashion at these track and field world championships, it seemed quite clear by the end of the curve what was going to happen in the 200.

title: In Response to a Rider Survey, More Trains on the 7 Line
description: Is it worth getting up 20 minutes earlier if it means your train to work will be less crowded?

description: WHO Rita Bass, 57, a former state employee, and her husband, Ray, 70, a retired assistant school superintendent, from Clarkesville, Ga. WHAT 1-bedroom condominium WHERE Athens, Ga.

title: Aura of the Big Time and the Result to Go Along With It
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Aug. 30  The black strips under Tiquan Underwoods eyes said in neat silver writing exactly what he was feeling after Thursday nights game: Im Back.

title: Democratic Donor Turns Himself In
description: After defying an arrest warrant since 1992, a valued and reliable rainmaker for the Democratic Party surrendered today at a California court to face a grand theft charge, according to wire reports.

title: Luring, and Keeping, Good Teachers (6 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Mirza Focusing on Success, Not Appearance
description: When Sania Mirza became the first woman from India to advance as far as the fourth round of a Grand Slam tournament  at the 2005 United States Open  she felt the glory and the sting of her instant success.

title: Republicans Say Senator Will Resign Over Sex Sting
description: Senator Larry E. Craig, Republican of Idaho, plans to resign his seat on Saturday after Republican leaders put intense pressure on him to leave in the aftermath of an undercover sex sting, Republican Party officials said Friday.

title: 20/20 Hindsight Through What Were Once Rose-Colored Glasses
description: GOLDMAN SACHS has an exercise that it periodically does with its employees. It asks them what the bank, and the industry, is doing that, in hindsight, will look stupid (they probably dont phrase it as such, but that is what they mean).

title: Cancer Society Focuses Its Ads on the Uninsured
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 30  In a stark departure from past practice, the American Cancer Society plans to devote its entire $15 million advertising budget this year not to smoking cessation or colorectal screening but to the consequences of inadequate health coverage.

title: Thompson to Announce Bid for G.O.P. Nomination
description: Fred D. Thompson will formally announce his bid for the Republican nomination for president next Thursday, starting with a Webcast and followed by a five-day swing through the early voting states, his campaign said today.

title: Bernanke Says Fed Is Prepared to Act
description: JACKSON HOLE, Wyo., Aug. 31  Ben S. Bernanke, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, declared on Friday that the central bank stands ready to take additional actions as needed to prevent the chaos in mortgage markets from derailing the broader economy.

title: In Vietnam: Stars and Stripes, and Innocence Undone
description: Denis Johnsons wildly ambitious new novel, Tree of Smoke, reads like a whacked-out, hallucinogenic variation on such whacked-out, hallucinogenic Vietnam classics as Francis Ford Coppolas Apocalypse Now, Michael Herrs Dispatches, Robert Stones Dog Soldiers and Stephen Wrights Meditations in Green. It features a central character who comes to see himself as a combination of the Quiet American and the Ugly American, and another who comes across as a latter-day version of Kurtz in Conrads Heart of Darkness.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption on Wednesday about a wildfire near Ketchum, Idaho, misstated the date the fire started. It was set by a lightning strike on Aug. 16, not last Friday.

title: Thai Censors Lift YouTube Ban
description: BANGKOK, Aug. 31  Thai censors lifted their ban of YouTube today after five months of blocking the online video site because it had carried material seen as insulting to the countrys highly venerated king.

title: Katrina All the Time
description: Two years ago today, Americans watched in horror as a great city drowned, and wondered what had happened to their country. Where was FEMA? Where was the National Guard? Why wasnt the government of the worlds richest, most powerful nation coming to the aid of its own citizens?

title: Fears of Mob Feud Lead to Arrest of 32 in Italy
description: ROME, Aug. 30  The Italian police carried out a major raid on Thursday, arresting 32 people, in part to stop a deadly feud between warring crime families. The arrests were linked to the fatal shooting of six men outside a pizzeria in Germany this month.

title: U.S. Says Company Bribed Officers for Work in Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30  An American-owned company operating from Kuwait paid hundreds of thousands of dollars in bribes to American contracting officers in efforts to win more than $11 million in contracts, the government says in court documents.

title: Jazz Listings
description: JAZZ

title: A Latino Biennial That Bucks a Global Trend
description: This age of international art biennials has produced a class of continent-hopping artists identified less by nationality and ethnicity than by an allegiance to issues raised by globalization  or, as the art world likes to call it, globalism. (An exception is the Venice Biennale, founded about the same time as the modern Olympics and following a similar protocol, with nations selecting those they consider their strongest artists to represent them.)

title: Chemical From Iraq Discovered at U.N.
description: No unconventional weapons were found in Iraq after the United States-led invasion in 2003. But a potentially deadly chemical agent produced by Saddam Husseins regime has turned up, improbably, in an office at the United Nations in New York, and it had the F.B.I. and the city police scrambling yesterday.

title: Chamberlain Draws Bostons Attention
description: Kevin Youkilis thought Joba Chamberlains first 98 mile-an-hour fastball over his head might have been accidental. But when Chamberlain followed that with an identical fastball again near his skull, it took Youkilis only a few tenths of a second to decide that Chamberlain was trying to drill him.

title: For the Record
description: Tuesdays editorial about South Park should have said the television show is in its 11th season, not its 12th.

title: Outdoor Funeral for a Protester of a Church Closing
description: Carmen Gonzalez, of East Harlem, died at 72 on Monday. She had regularly attended Mass at Our Lady Queen of Angels, a Roman Catholic parish on 113th Street in East Harlem, for years. When the church closed in February as part of a round of parish closings ordered by the Archdiocese of New York, Mrs. Gonzalez was devastated. She joined a small but fervent group of protesters who urged the archdiocese to reconsider.

title: Mets Ask Wagner to Get Six Outs, but He Records Only Four
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 30  Billy Wagner was sitting on a beige couch with an ice pack resting on his left shoulder and a towel on his right. His eyes blinked every few seconds but his head, propped up by a hand, did not move. In the stunned silence produced by a bad inning, a tough game and a forgettable series, Wagner just stared directly ahead, alone with his thoughts after experiencing all three.

title: Assessing the Wounds of an Ancient Assyrian Ruler
description: Archaeologists are all abuzz about some enormous, newly reinstalled ninth-century B.C. Assyrian sculptures at the Bowdoin College Museum of Art in Brunswick, Me. They say they cant wait until it reopens on Oct. 14, after a two-year, $20 million renovation and expansion, to see what curators discovered when they remounted five ancient bas reliefs from a royal compound at Nimrud in northern Iraq.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a subheading yesterday with a report by The Associated Press in some copies of the baseball roundup reversed the score of the game between Detroit and Kansas City. The Royals  not the Tigers  won 5-0.

title: Senator Warner Will Not Seek Re-election
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31  Senator John W. Warner of Virginia, one of the Republican Partys most influential figures on military issues and an increasingly critical voice on the course of the war in Iraq, announced today that he will not run for re-election next year.

title: Before the Summer Buzz Fades Away
description: Film: Humor for the Culture Wars

title: Panel Will Urge Broad Overhaul of Iraqi Police
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30  An independent commission established by Congress to assess Iraqs security forces will recommend remaking the 26,000-member national police force to purge it of corrupt officers and Shiite militants suspected of complicity in sectarian killings, administration and military officials said Thursday.

title: Malta: Another Tragedy at Sea
description: Twenty-five migrants were feared dead in the waters south of Malta after their boat capsized as a Greek tug neared to rescue them. Maltese officials said just three people were plucked from the water after the migrants all moved to one side of their boat waiting for the tug. There was no word on where they had come from. While the number of often-deadly crossings from Africa to Europe is down this summer, the pace of boats arriving in Malta and Italy has picked up in recent weeks.

title: Somber and Soulful World Fusion Meets Dance Club
description: Smoke machine, strobe lights and ... sitar? That was the combination at the Highline Ballroom on Wednesday night. Anoushka Shankar, Ravi Shankars daughter and musical disciple, and Karsh Kale, a tabla drummer who is also an electronica producer and programmer, have collaborated on an album, Breathing Underwater (Manhattan), and their band headlined a triple bill of world-music fusions to commemorate the 15th anniversary of Global Rhythm magazine. The transcontinental bill also included the South African trumpeter Hugh Masekela and the Guadeloupean New York saxophonist Jacques Schwarz-Bart.

title: Only the Prices of Tickets Are in Regular-Season Form
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass., Aug. 30  The empty seats at Gillette Stadium nearly outnumbered the occupied ones for the preseason game between the New England Patriots and the Giants on Thursday night. The $5 game program featured Patriots quarterback Tom Brady on the cover, yet he and every other first-string teammate did not play for fear that they could get hurt. The Giants trotted out their usual starters, then reeled most to the sideline before the end of the first quarter.

title: Tape Shows a Senator Protesting After Arrest
description: BOISE, Idaho, Aug. 30  In the moments after Senator Larry E. Craig was arrested in an airport mens room, he accused an undercover police sergeant of entrapping him, emphasized that he did not want to go to court or to jail and frequently said, I dont recall, when asked about his reported sexual advances to the officer.

description: To the Editor:

title: China Replaces Key Ministers
description: BEIJING, Aug. 30  The Chinese government replaced its finance minister on Thursday and appointed four other ministers in a reshuffling that foreshadows bigger personnel changes on the horizon as the Communist Party prepares for a pivotal political gathering in October.

title: Bush Plans Steps to Help Troubled Borrowers
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30  President Bush, in his first response to low-income families hit by the subprime mortgage crisis, plans to announce several steps Friday aimed at helping Americans with credit difficulties to meet the rising cost of their housing loans, administration officials said Thursday.

title: Justice Dept. Inquiry Focuses on Gonzaless Claims
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30  The Justice Departments internal watchdog disclosed Thursday that he was investigating whether sworn statements to Congress by Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales were intentionally false, misleading or inappropriate.

title: The Tide Is Still Going Out
description: A chestnut from the investor Warren Buffett  you only find out who is swimming naked when the tide goes out  has been quoted a lot lately as investors learn more about excessive risk-taking by lenders, bankers, hedge funds and other investors.

title: Iraq's Search for Reconciliation
description: Shatha al-Musawi, a Shiite lawmaker, is struggling to move past her difficult history in order to help Iraq move forward.

title: Vacation Time
description: An article in todays New York Times says that I.B.M. has stopped keeping track of its employees vacation time. Instead, for the past few years, employees at all levels have made informal arrangements with their direct supervisors, guided mainly by their ability to get their work done on time.

title: Blake Finally Wins in Five
description: The business trip you still need to expense. The online profile you regret having written. Untreated acne on your back. Your somewhat scattered beauty-pageant explanation for American deficiencies in geography. We all wish we could sweep certain issues behind us and move on. For James Blake, its five-set matches.

title: Hong Kong Art, Part 2: The Mall
description: There was a showdown in 2004, when both the Paris-based Centre Pompidou and the U.S.-based Guggenheim were vying for favor here and brought out top works for exhibition  their eyes firmly on a bid to open a branch in Hong Kongs planned West Kowloon cultural district. (Neither succeeded, but thats for another blog.)

title: Sarkozy Favors a Utility Merger
description: President Nicolas Sarkozy said he favored a merger of Gaz de France and the energy operations of Suez, implying Suez would have to shed its waste and water units to complete the long-pending deal.

title: Chinese Antimonopoly Law Approved
description: After 13 years of reviewing drafts, the National Peoples Congress approved a law that bans price-fixing, collusion, excessive market concentration and other monopolistic practices by private and state-owned businesses alike.

title: Judge Rejects Bankruptcy for 2 Bear Stearns Hedge Funds
description: Bear Stearns hit a wall in its efforts to shield two hedge funds seeking bankruptcy protection from investor claims by arguing that they are based in the Cayman Islands.

title: As Losses Mount, WestLB Under Pressure to Merge
description: WestLB, the troubled German state-run bank, said Thursday that it had lost more than $820 million on speculative trades in global stock markets in the first half of 2007  pushing it into a net loss for the period and renewing pressure for it to find a merger partner.

title: Thornburg Mortgage Sells $500 Million in Stock
description: Thornburg Mortgage, a jumbo-mortgage specialist that was forced to stop making new loans, has sold $500 million of convertible preferred stock to raise cash.

title: President of S&P Steps Down Amid Criticism
description: Kathleen Corbet, president of the credit rating company Standard & Poors, resigned after lawmakers and investors criticized the company for failing to judge the risks of securities backed by subprime mortgages.

title: Sentinel Gets Courts Okay to Pay Some Bills
description: Sentinel Management Group, a cash-management firm that recently filed for bankruptcy protection, won court permission to pay payroll, rent, utilities and insurance expenses in an amount up to $97,500.

title: Another chess vs. F1 analogy, this time for Ferrari vs. McLaren
description: Regular readers of this blog will know that I like chess as well as F1, and often like to make comparisons between the two. (Im a garbage chess player, with little knowledge of any openings  but these days computer software allows uneducated players to find a game at any time, and to watch as spectators as the worlds best players confront one another, and software estimates for the viewer who is leading.)

title: Reassessing Banks Hedge-Fund Love Affair
description: For The New York Times Jenny Anderson, the most boneheaded thinking to come out of the hedge fund and private equity mania was the one by a handful of investment banks to pay astronomical sums for stakes in hedge funds, volatile businesses that banks should understand quite well (its the same as their own, she notes).

title: Reklaim Drives Off With $7 Million from Goldman Sachs
description: Reklaim Technologies, which hopes to create a profitable business around selling the byproducts of recycled tires, has secured $7 million in venture financing from Goldman Sachs.

title: Franklin Reverses Position on TXU Buyout
description: Franklin Resources, the large TXU, the electric utility, shareholder that had opposed selling the power company, said Thursday it has changed its mind.

title: They Know Her Name Now: Ahsha Rolle
description: If Ahsha Rolle wants to continue competing at this years Open, shell have to keep winning in singles. Rolle and her doubles partner, Angela Haynes, were crushed on Thursday by Vania King (an 18-year-old Californian who lost in the first round of singles but is still alive in doubles and mixed doubles) and Emilie Loit, 4-6, 1-6.

title: Investors Said to Push Canadian Exchange Merger
description: Major shareholders in the TSX Group, the parent of the Toronto Stock Exchange, and its rival, the Montreal Exchange have mobilized to push for a merger between the companies, a deal the two exchanges have discussed but so far failed to reach.

title: WCI Shareholders Elect Icahn to Board
description: Shareholders of WCI Communities, a struggling homebuilder, elected the billionaire Carl C. Icahn to the board on Thursday, more than four months after management rejected his $22-per-share takeover bid.

title: Court Deals Blow to J&J Suit Over Guidant Sale
description: A federal court judge dealt a blow to Johnson & Johnson in its $5.5 billion lawsuit over the sale of Guidant to Boston Scientific, dismissing some claims and only allowing part of the case to proceed. The ruling, which was made public on Thursday, throws out the case against Abbott Laboratories but allows J&J to go ahead with its claim against Guidant for breach of contract.

title: Deutsche Banks Closes London Trading Desk
description: Deutsche Bank has shut down its proprietary credit trading desk in London and up to seven employees have left the bank  including department head Gerry Jackson  as the credit crunch claimed yet more scalps Thursday. The remaining members of the team, believed to be about 15 strong, have been given other jobs in the bank, according to The Telegraph.

title: A History of Dance
description: Images from the Joyce Theater.

title: Russian Steel Magnate Buys Arsenal Stake
description: A Russian mining magnate, Alisher Usmanov, has acquired a stake in Arsenal, the British soccer club, from David Dein, the clubs former vice-chairman and a close ally of manager Arsene Wenger.

title: Where Will Business Objects Strike Next?
description: Business Objects has long been bandied about as a potential takeover target. But the reality is that the company, which makes business-intelligence software, has been the one doing the buying in recent years.

title: Convio Files for I.P.O.
description: Convio, which provides fundraising and advocacy software and services for nonprofit organizations, plans an initial public offering, according to a regulatory filing Thursday with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Lone Star Halves Offer for Accredited
description: Lone Star Funds cut its takeover bid for Accredited Home Lenders, the subprime mortgage company, by 44 percent, to $214 million, after the company laid off 60 percent of its workers and stopped making new loans.

title: WPP Invests in Backer of MySpace China
description: WPP has invested in a Chinese venture capital firm that is leading the introduction of MySpace in China, according to The Telegraph. The advertising giant has ploughed an undisclosed sum into China Broadband Capital Partners, a Beijing-based investor in the technology and media sectors.

title: Barclays Borrows from Bank of England Again
description: Barclays, blaming a technical breakdown in Britains bank-clearing system, borrowed heavily from the Bank of Englands lending facility for the second time in two weeks. Separately, Barclays also said it would take part in a rescue of a $1.6 billion debt fund it helped create.

title: Private Equity Cites Progress in Tax Fight
description: The head of the Private Equity Council, a private-equity lobbying group whose founding members include the Blackstone Group and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, says the industry has made progress in its battle against proposed tax increases being considered in Congress.

title: K.K.R. Battles Banks Over First Data Terms
description: As Labor Day looms, one of the biggest tests of whether anxious debt investors will get back into the market is hitting some road blocks. Kohlberg Kravis Roberts is in talks with major Wall Street banks over the $24 billion in debt it needs to complete a deal for First Data, according to media reports.

title: Morning Buzz: Bronx Shootings, Iraqi Chemical Agent, Scoppettas Defense and More
description: A workplace shooting in the Bronx is the talk of the New York newspapers this morning. Paulino Valenzuela, 44, a janitor who had been fired from his job at Co-op City and then lost a lawsuit to get his job back, returned to the building where he had worked, killing a former supervisor, Audley Bent, 59, and shooting and injuring a supervisor, Phillip Zudrima, and a janitor, Sander Palaj. Mr. Palaj was in critical condition. The Timess coverage includes an overview by Cara Buckley and a profile of Mr. Bent, the slain victim, by Alan Feuer and Trymaine Lee.The New York Post calls the shooting a Bronx rampage, while The Daily News notes that Mr. Valenzuela seemed calm when he turned himself in at a Bronx criminal courthouse, saying, I just killed somebody.

title: YouTube and the Censors: An Update
description: Its hard to think of a good analogy for exactly what YouTube is becoming in modern society. It has attracted a critical mass of public attention in a way that predigital analogues like public-access cable television or the sign-encrusted kiosks of Paris or the proverbial Hyde Park Corner soap box never could  to the point that it now matters pretty strongly to people and businesses and governments what is said and shown there, and they are doing things about it.

title: Financial Stocks Surge Ahead of Bush Speech
description: Goldman Sachs, Blackstone Group and Countrywide Financial were among the financial firms whose shares moved sharply higher Friday before the opening bell as investors eagerly awaited an announcement from President Bush about what steps the government would take to help Americans with their mortgages.

title: Thrift Shops Join a New Social Movement
description: Liberty House, a boutique on the Upper West Side that sells crafts and imported clothing and jewelry, began its existence in the late 1960s as a chain of stores with locations around the city based on a simple concept: Volunteers would sell merchandise, like quilts produced by craft cooperatives in the South, and all the profits from those sales would be returned to the producers, benefiting causes like the civil rights movement.Most of the stores branches closed in the 1970s, and those that remained converted to for-profit businesses  though they retained the social consciousness of the West Side home neighborhood where they put down roots.

title: Closing the Book (by Opening Books) on Summer Rituals
description: When I see people immersed in a book in public, I always wonder what theyre reading. Sometimes, on the subway, I even move closer to sneak a peek at the title. Since I grew up reading in New York, I know, too, that the city itself can infuse the experience of a book. So when my editors asked for volunteers with ideas for our Summer Rituals series, I leaped at the chance to roam the city with my curiosity unleashed, hunting for readers to interview. My article, which ends the series, was put up on the Web today and will appear in Saturdays paper.Jury duty did crimp my plans a bit. I had hoped to return to a garden at the Cloisters in Fort Tryon Park, where I used to go sometimes as a teenager to find just the right reading atmosphere. (Mainly what I recall reading there is The Ladys Not for Burning, a delightful play in verse by Christopher Fry that is set in 1400; it was a gloomy autumn day, though, and Gregorian chant was playing in the background.)

title: Looking the Baiji Sighting News in the Mouth
description: After spending years on nearly everyones list of noteworthy critically endangered species, the baiji, or Yangtze river dolphin, seemed finally to have slipped away last year when a thorough six-week search of the Yangtze river basin in China, the creatures sole habitat, failed to turn up a single one in the wild. (Andy Revkin wrote about the development in The New York Times  TimesSelect subscription required.)

title: Fantasy Football Intervention
description: Im hooked on the A&E show Intervention. If you havent seen it (and if not, you should start TiVOing it post haste) this is the premise: they follow an addict  usually coke/crack, heroin, crustal meth or alcohol  and chronicle the typical day-to-day life of addiction. The lying, the stealing, the manipulating of friends and loved ones. It can be depressing at times, but its as riveting as HBOs Flight of the Conchords is hysterical (unlike The Two Coreys, which I had high hopes for, but is clearly scripted, totally unfunny, and Haim looks like hes been riding lifes Tilt-a-Whirl for wayyyy too long.)
